COPYRIGHT

为了我的父母

For my parents

软件很难。

Software is hard.

——Donald Knuth，

《计算机编程的艺术》一书的作者

—Donald Knuth, author of

The Art of Computer Programming

作者注

AUTHOR’S NOTE

世界上的书架上摆满了软件开发人员的指导书籍。这不是其中的一个。我自己也只是一个初级程序员。我不会尝试去教专家。如果我的研究发现了一些以前未知的创新或构建更好软件的防故障见解，那么我会更明智地寻求投资者，而不是读者。

The shelves of the world are full of how-to books for software developers. This is not one of them. I’m barely an elementary programmer myself. I wouldn’t presume to try to teach the experts. And if my research had uncovered some previously unknown innovation or fail-safe insight into building better software, I’d be smarter to seek investors, not readers.

因此，虽然我希望程序员会喜欢这项工作，但它对我们其他人来说也同样重要，甚至更多。它提出了一个问题并讲述了一个故事。为什么好的软件这么难制作？由于即使是现在，在二十一世纪之初，计算机时代已深入五十年之际，似乎仍然没有人有一个明确的答案，因此我通过探索的方式提供了一个软件的制作故事——一个软件这是关于一群人再次将肩膀扛在代码巨石上并将其推上山的故事，他们受到新旧障碍的阻碍，努力创造出有用、丰富和持久的东西。

So while I hope that programmers will enjoy this work, it is meant equally or more for the rest of us. It poses a question and tells a tale. Why is good software so hard to make? Since no one seems to have a definitive answer even now, at the start of the twenty-first century, fifty years deep into the computer era, I offer, by way of exploration, the tale of the making of one piece of software—a story about a group of people setting their shoulders once more to the boulder of code and heaving it up the hill, stymied by obstacles old and new, struggling to make something useful and rich and lasting.

第0章                           

CHAPTER 0                           

软件时间

SOFTWARE TIME

[1975–2000]

[1975–2000]

那是 1975 年的冬天。我在终端室的电传打字机前弯下腰，这是一台笨重的控制台，每次打字机头向左猛击以开始新的一行时，它都会摇晃。我盯着那些脏兮兮的黑色代码。几个小时前我就忘记了时间；必须是在午夜之后。看门人已经关掉了大厅的灯。我没有得到任何人的许可，可以使用该大学免费向高中生提供的计算机帐户在纽约大学物理大楼闲逛。但后来也没有人说不。

It was winter 1975. I hunched over the teletype in the terminal room, a hulking console that shook each time its typewriter head whammed leftward to begin a new line. I stared at smudgy lines of black code. I’d lost track of the time several hours before; it had to be after midnight. The janitors had switched off the hall lights. I didn’t have anyone’s permission to hang out there in the NYU physics building, using the computer account that the university was giving away, for free, to high school students. But then nobody was saying no, either.

当时我十五岁，爱上了一款名为“苏美尔”的游戏，这款游戏让我负责新月沃地的一个古老城邦。今天的电脑游戏玩家可能会嘲笑它的粗鲁：它的进程是在纸卷轴上逐行敲出全大写字母。你需要做出决定，分配几蒲式耳的谷物用于饲养和种植，然后程序会告诉你你的城市每年的表现如何。“汉谟拉比，”它会像一位害怕被斩首的谄媚首相那样宣布，“我请求报告……。。。”

I was fifteen years old and in love with a game called Sumer, which put me in charge of an ancient city-state in the Fertile Crescent. Today’s computer gamers might snicker at its crudity: Its progress consisted of all-capital type pecked out line by line on a paper scroll. You’d make decisions, allocating bushels of grain for feeding and planting, and then the program would tell you how your city was doing year by year. “Hammurabi,” it would announce, like an obsequious prime minister who feared beheading, “I beg to report . . . ”

在玩了几天后，我就用尽了游戏的所有可能性。但与当今大多数吸引青少年的游戏不同，Sumer 邀请了修补。任何人都可以检查它的内部：游戏是一组简单的计算机指令，存储在纸带上，纸带上有小排的八个孔。（电传打字机一侧的塑料托盘中堆积的五彩纸屑几乎与游戏一样有趣。）它不知何故像一种轻浮的地下出版物一样落在了我的一群朋友中，我们不假思索地分享了它。如果您花几个小时学习简单的基础知识，修改它几乎和播放它一样容易：您只需将磁带的指令加载到计算机中并开始向程序添加行即可。

Within a couple of days of play I’d exhausted the game’s possibilities. But unlike most of the games that captivate teenagers today, Sumer invited tinkering. Anyone could inspect its insides: The game was a set of simple instructions to the computer, stored on a paper tape coded with little rows of eight holes. (The confetti that accumulated in a plastic tray on the teletype’s side provided nearly as much fun as the game.) It had somehow landed among my group of friends like a kind of frivolous samizdat, and we shared it without a second thought. Modifying it was almost as easy as playing it if you took the couple of hours required to learn simple Basic: You just loaded the tape’s instructions into the computer and started adding lines to the program.

苏美尔是一块空白的画布——原始的历史，随时可以被青少年的想象力塑造。我和我的朋友们采用了它简单的结构并开始进行添加。让玩家选择不同的宗教！如果我们偶尔爆发黑死病怎么办？野蛮人入侵者会很酷。嘿，弹射器呢？

Sumer was a blank canvas—history in the raw, ready to be molded by teenage imaginations. My friends and I took its simple structure and began building additions. Let’s have players choose different religions! What if we throw in an occasional bubonic plague? Barbarian invaders would be cool. Hey, what about catapults?

那天晚上，我沉迷于叛逆。苏美尔对于民众起义一向有粗暴的规定。如果你的管理工作搞砸了，人民就会起来推翻你的权力。（苏美尔的原作者是一位乐观主义者。）我认为游戏中的叛乱需要更加多样化，因此我开始发明附加内容——新的子程序，这些子程序将使苏美尔陷入内战或引入竞争对手政府争夺合法性。

That night I was obsessed with rebellion. Sumer had always had a rough provision for popular uprising; if you botched your stewardship badly enough, the people would rise up and remove you from power. (Sumer’s original author was an optimist.) I thought there needed to be more variety in the game’s insurrections, so I started inventing additions—new subroutines that would plunge Sumer into civil war or introduce rival governments competing for legitimacy.

我不在乎已经有多晚了。F 火车通宵运行，带我回到皇后区。革命必须定制！

I didn’t care how late it was. The F train ran all night to take me home to Queens. The revolution had to be customized!





四分之一个世纪后，2000 年 5 月，我坐在旧金山的一间办公室里，盯着现代电脑屏幕（高分辨率，数百万种颜色）。我的键盘两侧摆着一排排喝得半醉的咖啡纸杯。当时是上午5:00 。米。

A quarter century later, in May 2000, I sat in an office in San Francisco and stared at a modern computer screen (high resolution, millions of colors). Wan ranks of half-guzzled paper coffee cups flanked my keyboard. It was 5:00 A.M.

我当时四十岁，是在线杂志《沙龙》的创始人和现任总编辑，负责一个软件开发项目。我们花了几个月的时间精心策划。它承诺通过动态功能彻底改变我们的网站。它在我面前崩溃了。

I was forty years old, a founder and now managing editor of the online magazine Salon, and in charge of a software development project. It had taken us months of meticulous planning. It promised to revolutionize our Web site with dynamic features. And it was disintegrating in front of me.

首席程序员在昼夜不停地工作了数周之后，终于宣布他的工作已经完成，并启程前往夏威夷进行一个计划已久的家庭度假。这让他的老板、我们公司的技术副总裁查德·迪克森（Chad Dickerson）想弄清楚为什么存储我们网站所有文章的数据库不会与应该将这些数据组装到发布页面中的程序进行对话。查德已经连续两个晚上没睡，试图解决这个问题。否则，周一早上，我们的 200 万读者将在我们的网站上找到除了旧新闻之外的任何内容。

The lead programmer, after working around the clock for weeks and finally announcing that his work was done, had taken off for Hawaii on a long-planned family vacation. That left his boss, Chad Dickerson, our company’s technology VP, to figure out why the database that stored all our Web site’s articles would not talk to the programs that were supposed to assemble that data into published pages. Chad had been up for two nights straight trying to fix the problem. Otherwise, our two million readers would find nothing but old news on our site come Monday morning.

我们以前不是开发过软件吗？（是。） 我们不是测试了一切吗？（显然，还不够好。）我们怎么会搞砸得这么严重？（没有好的答案。）

Hadn’t we built software before? (Yes.) Didn’t we test everything? (Not well enough, apparently.) How could we have screwed up so badly? (No good answer.)

我吃了自动售货机里的最后一袋椒盐卷饼，踱着步，等待着。没有任何帮助。时间太多了。是时候阅读一位不幸的同事发来的电子邮件了，他计划举办一场香槟和蛋糕庆祝活动来庆祝新项目，并回复道：“也许我们应该推迟。” 是时候感到疏远和陷入困境，并想知道将我们系统的中央服务器命名为 Kafka 是否是一个明智的想法。

I ate the last bag of pretzels from our vending machine, paced, and waited. Nothing helped. There was too much time. Time to read the email from a hapless colleague who’d planned a champagne-and-cake celebration in honor of the new project, and to respond: “Maybe we should hold off.” Time to feel alienated and trapped and wonder whether it had been a smart idea to give our system’s central server the name Kafka.

我们终于在上午9:00 左右发布了新的“改进”网站的第一版。米。当我的同事们按照周一早上的惯例出现在办公桌前时，他们花了一段时间才意识到我们中有六个人前一天晚上从未回家过。

We finally published the first edition of our new, “improved” site at around 9:00 A.M. As my coworkers showed up at their desks in their usual Monday morning routines, it took them a while to realize that a half dozen of us had never gone home the night before.

几周之内，随着我们的开发人员解决了最紧迫的问题，软件就平静下来了。但每当我听说一家公司准备通过推出大型新软件方案来“升级其平台”时，我都会感到畏缩。

Within a few weeks the software calmed down as our developers fixed the most pressing problems. But every time I hear about a company preparing to “upgrade its platform” by introducing a big new software scheme, I cringe.





20 世纪 90 年代科技产业的繁荣给我们带来了“互联网时代”的概念。这个短语对不同的人来说有不同的含义，但大多数情况下它的意思是“快”。在数字时代的新时间分配下，一切都会以令人惊叹的速度发生——技术会出现，公司会崛起，财富会创造。这意味着你没有时间去完善任何东西——但不必担心，因为其他人也没有能力。

The 1990s technology-industry boom introduced us to the concept of “Internet time.” The phrase meant different things to different people, but mostly it meant fast. Under the digital age’s new temporal dispensation, everything would happen—technologies would emerge, companies would rise, fortunes would be made—at gasp-inducing speed. That meant you couldn’t afford the time to perfect anything—but no need to worry, because nobody else could, either.

事实证明，互联网时间转瞬即逝，很快就被新的货币所取代，而这些新货币并未受到十年投资热潮的影响。但流行语贩子却说对了。时间在软件制作过程中的表现确实有所不同。当一切顺利时，你可能会忘记时间的流逝，处于心理学家称之为“心流”的状态。当事情变得糟糕时，你就会陷入困境，被冻结在维度之间，无法移动或看清前进的道路。不管怎样，你已经把时钟远远抛在了后面。您正处于软件时间。

Internet time proved fleeting and was quickly displaced by newer coinages untainted by association with a closed-out decade’s investment fads. But the buzzword-mongers were on to something. Time really does seem to behave differently around the act of making software. When things go well, you can lose track of passing hours in the state psychologists call “flow.” When things go badly, you get stuck, frozen between dimensions, unable to move or see a way forward. Either way, you’ve left the clock far behind. You’re on software time.





新手程序员在新语言中的第一个任务通常是编写一个名为“Hello World”的例程——一段代码，可以成功地召唤出计算机的声音，并命令它通过输入这些单词来向主人打招呼。在我的 Sumer 游戏的简单语言 Basic 中，它看起来像这样：

A novice programmer’s first assignment in a new language, typically, is to write a routine known as “Hello World”—a bit of code that successfully conjures the computer’s voice and orders it to greet its master by typing those words. In Basic, the simple language of my Sumer game, it looks like this:



10 印刷“你好，世界！”

10 PRINT "HELLO WORLD!"

20 停止

20 STOP



“Hello World”程序是无用但令人愉快的口技练习；他们鼓励初学者，并与每个程序员的乐观主义者交谈。如果我能让它跟我说话，我就能让它做任何事！计算机协会（即计算机行业的 ABA 或 AMA）维护着一个网页，其中列出了近 200 种不同语言的“Hello World”版本。它是程序代码的罗塞塔石碑。

“Hello World” programs are useless but cheerful exercises in ventriloquism; they encourage beginners and speak to the optimist in every programmer. If I can get it to talk to me, I can get it to do anything! The Association for Computing Machinery, which is the ABA or AMA of the computer profession, maintains a Web page that lists versions of “Hello World” in nearly two hundred different languages. It’s a Rosetta stone for program code.

“Hello World”在 Java 中看起来更加令人生畏，Java 是当今商业世界的主力编程语言之一：

“Hello World” looks more forbidding in Java, one of the workhorse programming languages in today’s business world:



类 HelloWorld {

class HelloWorld {

                                    公共静态无效主（字符串参数[]）{

                                    public static void main (String args[]) {

                                                                        System.out.println("你好世界！");

                                                                        System.out.println ("Hello World!");

                                    }

                                    }

}

}



Public static void：用 Java 编写的无数程序代码块都包含这个神秘的序列。这些词具有特定的技术含义。但我总是将它们视为一首机器诗，唤起人们对荒凉的边缘的渴望，在这种状态下，兴高采烈地开始的软件项目往往会以失败告终。

Public static void: gazillions of chunks of program code written in Java include that cryptic sequence. The words carry specific technical meaning. But I’ve always heard them as a bit of machine poetry, evoking the desolate limbo where software projects that begin with high spirits too often end up.





如果您与计算机编程有任何关系，那么很难不对它产生爱/恨的关系。作为一名青少年游戏玩家，我尝到了编码带来的巨大乐趣。作为一名记者，我见证了软件世界无穷无尽的灾难故事——跨国公司、政府机构和军工巨头，全都在代码的冰山上沉没。作为一名经理，我必须乘坐我自己的桌面泰坦尼克号。

It’s difficult not to have a love/hate relationship with computer programming if you have any relationship with it at all. As a teenage gamer, I had tasted the consuming pleasure of coding. As a journalist, I would witness my share of the software world’s inexhaustible disaster stories—multinational corporations and government agencies and military-industrial behemoths, all foundering on the iceberg of code. And as a manager, I got to ride my very own desktop Titanic.

二十五年的软件历史中这段令人沮丧的轨迹可能不是代表性的经历，但它是我的经历。根据硅谷的数字乌托邦主义，事情应该朝相反的方向发展。在沙龙网站发布失败后的几个月里，这种差异开始困扰着我。

This discouraging trajectory of twenty-five years of software history may not be a representative experience, but it was mine. Things were supposed to be headed in the opposite direction, according to Silicon Valley’s digital utopianism. In the months following our train wreck of a site launch at Salon, that discrepancy began to eat at me.

编程不再处于起步阶段。我们现在依赖极其复杂的软件来运行我们的世界。为什么经过半个世纪的研究和实践，在预算内按时生产计算机软件仍然如此困难？为了使其可靠和安全？塑造它以便人们可以轻松学习它，并使其灵活以便人们可以根据自己的需要进行调整？这只是时间和经验的问题吗？一些根本性的突破即将到来吗？或者，软件的本质是否有某种东西，即它的抽象性、复杂性和可塑性，注定了它的制造者会陷入一个充满棘手的延迟和无法根除的错误的世界——一些不稳定或善变的东西总是会让我们失望？

Programming is no longer in its infancy. We now depend on unfathomably complex software to run our world. Why, after a half century of study and practice, is it still so difficult to produce computer software on time and under budget? To make it reliable and secure? To shape it so that people can learn it easily, and to render it flexible so people can bend it to their needs? Is it just a matter of time and experience? Could some radical breakthrough be right around the corner? Or is there something at the root of what software is, its abstractness and intricateness and malleability, that dooms its makers to a world of intractable delays and ineradicable bugs—some instability or fickleness that will always let us down?

“软件很难，”编程领域最受尊敬的教科书的作者 Donald Knuth 写道。但为什么？

“Software is hard,” wrote Donald Knuth, author of the programming field’s most respected textbooks. But why?





也许你注意到我把这章称为第 0 章。我并不是想开一个古怪的玩笑，而是想向计算机程序员和我们其他人之间的一个小差异致敬：程序员从零开始计数，而不是从一开始计数。这种习惯的完整解释在于计算机中央处理单元内的寄存器设计和数据数组结构的深奥领域。但我发现的最直白的解释来自一个网页，它试图向我们其他人解释黑客的方式——黑客这个词的原始含义是“痴迷的编程修补匠”，而不是后来的小报含义“数字闯入艺术家。”

Maybe you noticed that I’ve called this Chapter 0. I did not mean to make an eccentric joke but, rather, to tip my hat to one small difference between computer programmers and the rest of us: Programmers count from zero, not from one. The full explanation for this habit lies in the esoteric realm of the design of the registers inside a computer’s central processing unit and the structure of data arrays. But the most forthright explanation I’ve found comes from a Web page that attempts to explain for the rest of us the ways of the hacker—hacker in the word’s original sense of “obsessive programming tinkerer” rather than the later, tabloid sense of “digital break-in artist.”

为什么程序员要从零开始数？因为计算机是从零开始计数的！因此，程序员也训练自己以这种方式计数，以避免他们和他们必须指导的机器之间产生误解。这一切都很好，除了一个令人痛苦的事实，即大多数使用这些机器的人习惯性地从一数起。因此，在系统的内部，数据被存储和操纵——我们的金钱、我们的工作生活和我们富有想象力的创作的代表，全部转化为机器可读的符号——计算机程序和编程语言通常包括很少的偏移、翻译“+1”或“-1”，以确保计算机从零开始计数的内容列表与人类用户从一开始计数的内容列表保持同步。

Why do programmers count from zero? Because computers count from zero! And so programmers train themselves to count that way, too, to avoid a misunderstanding between them and the machines they must instruct. Which is all fine, except for the distressing fact that most of the human beings who use those machines habitually count from one. And so, down in the guts of the system, where data is stored and manipulated—representations of our money and our work lives and our imaginative creations all translated into machine-readable symbols—computer programs and programming languages often include little offsets, translations of “+1” or “-1,” to make sure that the list of stuff the computer is counting from zero stays in sync with the list of stuff a human user is counting from one.

在计算机的二进制数字世界中，所有信息都被简化为零和一的序列。但在机器计数和思考的方式与我们计算和思考的方式之间，零和一之间存在着差距。当您寻找软件错误、延迟以及对人类欲望的顽固抵抗的解释时，您就会在这个空间找到它们。

In the binary digital world of computers, all information is reduced to sequences of zeros and ones. But there’s a space between zero and one, between the way the machine counts and thinks and the way we count and think. When you search for explanations for software’s bugs and delays and stubborn resistance to human desires, that space is where you’ll find them.





当这本书开始在我的脑海中成形时，我每天都会开车经过旧金山湾大桥去上班。一天早上，当我的车艰难地爬上连接奥克兰海岸和大桥东跨高架中心的长斜坡时，我注意到右侧有一个新物体挡住了蓝色海湾海水和绿色马林山的全景：一座高高的红色起重机的尖端就在桥的甲板上露出来。第二天、第三天，它都在那里，很快，十几台起重机就加入了行列，沿着桥的北侧排列，就像一排机械野兽在低谷，准备以倒霉的通勤者为食。

As this book began taking shape in my thoughts, I would drive to work every day over the San Francisco Bay Bridge. One morning, as my car labored up the lengthy incline that connects the Oakland shore to the elevated center of the bridge’s eastern span, I noticed, off to the right, a new object blocking the panorama of blue bay water and green Marin hill: The tip of a high red crane peeked just over the bridge’s deck level. It was there the next day and the next, and soon it was joined by a line of a dozen cranes, arrayed along the bridge’s north side like a rank of mechanical beasts at the trough, ready to feed on hapless commuters.

双层桥这半部分的更换工作已经开始。在 1989 年洛马普列塔地震期间，其上层的一块 50 英尺厚的建筑倒塌到了下层道路上。现在，一座更安全、更现代化的建筑将会取代旧建筑而拔地而起。

Work was beginning on a replacement for this half of the double-decker bridge. A fifty-foot chunk of its upper level had collapsed onto the lower roadway during the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake. Now a safer, more modern structure would rise next to the old.

在接下来的几周和几个月里，每台 240 英尺高的起重机开始将直径 8 英尺、长 300 英尺的生锈钢管敲入海湾地板。清晨，我们有时能听到我位于伯克利山的家中的轰鸣声。一百六十个巨大的桩将填充混凝土以支撑新桥的高架桥。整个过程精心设计，执行顺利；它感觉是不可避免的，它的展开充满了我们对工程这个词的所有信心。

In the weeks and months that followed, each of the 240-foot-tall cranes began pounding rust-caked steel tubes, 8 feet in diameter and 300 feet long, into the bay floor. In the early morning hours we could sometimes hear the thuds in my home in the Berkeley hills. One hundred sixty of these enormous piles would be filled with concrete to support the new bridge’s viaduct. The whole process was choreographed with precision and executed without a hitch; it felt inevitable, its unfolding infused with all the confidence we place in the word engineering.

如果一次讨论软件缺陷的话题超过几分钟，那么肯定有人最终会用拳头敲击桌子说：“为什么我们不能像建造桥梁一样构建软件呢？”

If the subject of software’s flaws is discussed for more than a few minutes at a time, it is a certainty that someone will eventually pound a fist on the table and say, “Why can’t we build software the way we build bridges?”





桥梁与摩天大楼、水坝和类似的纪念性建筑一样，是我们对物理宇宙的技术掌握的明显体现。在过去的半个世纪中，软件已经成为这种塑造世界的人类制品的无形而又普遍的对应物。“我们的文明依靠软件运行，”Bjarne Stroustrup 说道，他发明了一种广泛使用的计算机语言 C++。

Bridges are, with skyscrapers and dams and similar monumental structures, the visible representation of our technical mastery over the physical universe. In the past half century, software has emerged as an invisible yet pervasive counterpart to such world-shaping human artifacts. “Our civilization runs on software,” says Bjarne Stroustrup, who invented a widely used computer language called C++.

乍一听，这似乎是一种古怪且自私的主张。我们的文明在没有 Microsoft Windows 的情况下也能过得很好，对吗？但软件不仅仅是您用来发送电子邮件或撰写报告的程序；它还包括您使用的程序。它已经渗透到我们生活的每一个角落，而我们很多人都没有注意到。它存在于我们的厨房用具、汽车、玩具和建筑物中。我们的企业和银行、我们的选举和新闻媒体、我们的电影和交通网络、我们的医疗保健和国防、我们的科学研究和基本公用事业服务——我们日常生活的一切都依赖于脆弱的计算机代码线程。

At first this sounds like an outlandish and self-serving claim. Our civilization got along just fine without Microsoft Windows, right? But software is more than the program you use to send email or compose a report; it has seeped into every cranny of our lives, without many of us noticing. It is in our kitchen gadgets and cars, toys and buildings. Our businesses and banks, our elections and our news media, our movies and our transportation networks, our health care and national defense, our scientific research and basic utility services—the stuff of our daily existence hangs from fragile threads of computer code.

我们为它们的脆弱付出了代价。根据美国国家标准与技术研究所 2002 年的一项研究，软件错误每年给美国经济造成约 595 亿美元的损失，因为三分之二的项目严重延迟或超出预算，或者不得不彻底取消。

And we pay for their fragility. Software errors cost the U.S. economy about $59.5 billion annually, according to a 2002 study by the National Institute of Standards and Technology, as two out of three projects came in significantly late or over budget or had to be canceled outright.

我们的文明依赖于软件。然而，即使对于专家来说，创建软件的艺术仍然是一个黑暗的谜团。历史上我们从来没有如此完全地依赖过一种产品，而很少有人知道如何做好它。我们对软件系统的日益依赖与我们在如何健全软件系统方面的知识的稳步但缓慢的进步之间存在着巨大的、有时令人恐惧的差距。依赖性呈指数级增长，而技能以及应用技能的意愿却只能沿着缓慢的路线前进。

Our civilization runs on software. Yet the art of creating software continues to be a dark mystery, even to the experts. Never in history have we depended so completely on a product that so few know how to make well. There is a big and sometimes frightening gap between our accelerating dependence on software systems and the steady but slow progress in our knowledge of how to make them soundly. The dependence has increased exponentially, while the skill—and the will to apply it—advances only along a plodding line.

如果你与程序员讨论这个问题，请做好遭受鞭打的准备。一方面，您可能听说事情从未如此光明：我们拥有比以往更好的工具、更好的测试、更好的语言和更好的方法！另一方面，您还会听说，自计算机时代到来以来，我们并没有真正取得多大进展。计算机先驱莫里斯·威尔克斯 (Maurice Wilkes) 在他的回忆录中描述了 1949 年的那一刻，当时，他拖着打孔卡走上楼梯，到达英国剑桥一台名为 EDSAC 的原始计算机，他看到了未来：我余生的一部分时间将花在寻找自己程序中的错误上。” 从威尔克斯的顿悟到现在，尽管有大量的创新，程序员却一直在艰难的调试中挣扎。他们的工作百分之一是灵感，剩下的就是汗流浃背的侦探工作；他们的产品从来都不是成品或完美的，只是不同程度的“破损较少”。

If you talk with programmers about this, prepare for whiplash. On the one hand, you may hear that things have never looked brighter: We have better tools, better testing, better languages, and better methods than ever before! On the other hand, you will also hear that we haven’t really made much headway since the dawn of the computer era. In his memoirs, computing pioneer Maurice Wilkes wrote of the moment in 1949 when, hauling punch cards up the stairs to a primitive computer called EDSAC in Cambridge, England, he saw the future: “The realization came over me with full force that a good part of the remainder of my life was going to be spent in finding errors in my own programs.” From Wilkes’s epiphany to the present, despite a host of innovations, programmers have been stuck with the hard slog of debugging. Their work is one percent inspiration, the rest sweat-drenched detective work; their products are never finished or perfect, just varying degrees of “less broken.”





软件是一大堆麻烦。然而我们不能也不会简单地关闭计算机并走开。这些让我们感到沮丧和困扰的软件也以新的功能吸引着我们，并以更快、更好的工作和生活方式的承诺让我们着迷。回不去了。我们对这些东西的需要多于我们讨厌的东西。

Software is a heap of trouble. And yet we can’t, and won’t, simply power down our computers and walk away. The software that frustrates and hog-ties us also captivates us with new capabilities and enthralls us with promises of faster, better ways to work and live. There’s no going back. We need the stuff more than we hate it.

所以我们梦想新的、更好的事物。在许多方面开创了现代软件研究领域的专家 Frederick P. Brooks, Jr. 在 1987 年写了一篇颇具影响力的文章，题为“没有灵丹妙药”，他宣称，无论我们对计算机程序的编写感到多么沮丧，我们永远不会找到神奇的、变革性的突破——我们只能期待适度的、渐进的进步。布鲁克斯的观点很难反驳，但却很难接受，今天你在参加计算机行业会议或浏览程序员网站时，不可能不碰到那些决心证明他错误的人。

So we dream of new and better things. The expert who in many ways founded the modern field of software studies, Frederick P. Brooks, Jr., wrote an influential essay in 1987 titled “No Silver Bullet,” declaring that, however frustrated we may be with the writing of computer programs, we will never find a magic, transformational breakthrough—we should expect only modest, incremental advances. Brooks’s message is hard to argue with but painful to accept, and you can’t attend a computer industry conference or browse a programmers’ Web site today without bumping into someone who is determined to prove him wrong.

有些人梦想拆除当今软件的整个大厦，并用新的、完全不同的东西取而代之。其他人只是渴望能够不那么严格地响应人类愿望和行动的程序，渴望能够做我们想做的事情然后不妨碍我们的软件，渴望我们可以信赖的代码。

Some dream of ripping down the entire edifice of today’s software and replacing it with something new and entirely different. Others simply yearn for programs that will respond less rigidly to the flow of human wishes and actions, for software that does what we want and then gets out of our way, for code that we can count on.

我们梦想着它，然后我们尝试把它写下来——然后一切都崩溃了。

We dream of it, then we try to write it—and all hell breaks loose.

第1章                           

CHAPTER 1                           

注定

DOOMED

[2003 年 7 月]

[JULY 2003]

迈克尔·托伊将手掌放在脸颊上，将下巴抵在手腕上，眯着眼睛看着他的 PowerBook，开始了冗长的叙述。

Michael Toy places his palms on his cheeks, digs his chin into his wrists, squints into his PowerBook, and begins the litany.

“约翰注定要失败。从现在到下一个版本，他计划工作 500 个小时。。。。凯蒂注定要失败。她的时间比宇宙中的时间还要多。布莱恩基本上是注定失败的。而且他只上半场。安迪——安迪是唯一一个看起来没有注定失败的人。他的名单上没有数百人。”

“John is doomed. He has five hundred hours of work scheduled between now and the next release . . . . Katie’s doomed. She has way more hours than there are in the universe. Brian is majorly doomed. Plus he’s only half time. Andy—Andy is the only one who doesn’t look doomed. There are no hundreds on his list.”

夏日里，这些程序员坐在加利福尼亚州贝尔蒙特一张不起眼的会议室桌子旁，他们看起来并没有注定要失败。他们静静地听经理讲话。玩具是个高个子男人，有着令人印象深刻的直觉和马尾辫，但当他详细描述程序员们落后进度的程度时，他似乎陷入了沮丧的空间。现在是 2003 年 7 月 17 日，他开始感到自己注定要在不到两个月的时间内完成所有工作，然后他们应该完成项目的另一个工作版本。

They don’t look doomed, these programmers sitting around a nondescript conference room table in Belmont, California, on a summer day. They listen quietly to their manager. Toy is a tall man with an impressive gut and a ponytail, but he seems to shrink into a space of dejection as he details how far behind schedule the programmers have fallen. It’s July 17, 2003, and he’s beginning to feel doomed himself about getting everything done in the less than two months before they are supposed to finish another working version of their project.

“每个拥有比宇宙中的时间还要多的清单的人都需要和我坐下来仔细研究一下。”

“Everybody who has a list with more time than there is in the universe needs to sit down with me and go over it.”

这些列表是错误列表，即未解决或“开放”问题或缺陷的名册。它们共同提供了这些软件开发人员所知道的必须在其产品中修复的所有内容的完整说明。该错误列表存在于一个名为 Bugzilla 的程序中。Toy 的程序员还使用 Bugzilla 来跟踪为了完成项目发布而必须完成的所有编程任务；每个人负责将他或她的列表输入 Bugzilla 以及每项任务完成所需时间的估计。

These lists are the bug lists—rosters of unsolved or “open” problems or flaws. Together they provide a full accounting of everything these software developers know must be fixed in their product. The bug lists live inside a program called Bugzilla. Toy’s programmers are also using Bugzilla to track all the programming tasks that must be finished in order to complete a release of the project; each one is responsible for entering his or her list into Bugzilla along with an estimate of how long each task will take to complete.

“现在我们来谈谈为什么我们落后了。有人有故事要讲吗？”

“Now let’s talk about why we’re behind. Does anyone have a story to tell?”

沉默了一分钟。约翰·安德森 (John Anderson) 是一位身材瘦长的编程老手，他的头衔是系统架构师，事实上，他也是该项目的首席编码员，他终于用柔和的声音开口说道。“有很多原因。为了建造一些东西，你必须有一个蓝图。我们并不总是有这样的人。然后你遇到了意想不到的问题。在您确定可以构建某件事之前，很难知道需要多长时间。”

There’s silence for a minute. John Anderson, a lanky programming veteran whose title is systems architect and who is, in a de facto sort of way, the project’s lead coder, finally speaks up, in a soft voice. “There’s a bunch of reasons. In order to build something, you have to have a blueprint. And we don’t always have one. Then you hit unexpected problems. It’s hard to know how long something’s going to take until you know for sure you can build it.”

“但你不能只是举手说，我辞职了。” Toy 通常更喜欢快速取消议程上的事情，以一种在程序员中很流行的“让我们尽快离开这里”的轻快态度来召开开发人员会议。但今天他很坚持。他不会让日程安排问题消失。“我们需要做出猜测，然后找出我们的猜测出了什么问题。”

“But you can’t just throw up your hands and say, I quit.” Toy usually prefers to check things off his agenda fast, running his developers’ meetings with a brisk attitude of “let’s get out of here as fast as we can” that’s popular among programmers. But today he’s persistent. He won’t let the scheduling problems drop. “We need to make guesses and then figure out what went wrong with our guesses.”

该项目的年轻程序员之一杰德·伯吉斯 (Jed Burgess) 发言。“不确定性更加复杂：你的估计是基于别人的估计。”

Jed Burgess, one of the project’s younger programmers, speaks up. “There’s a compounding of uncertainty: Your estimates are based on someone else’s estimates.”

玩具开始检查安德森的错误。“著名的无闪烁窗口调整大小问题。那是怎么回事？”

Toy begins reviewing Anderson’s bugs. “The famous flicker-free window resizing problem. What’s up with that?”

正式地，这是 Bugzilla 中的第 44 号错误，最初于 2003 年 1 月 19 日输入，并标记为“调整窗口大小时窗口显示不闪烁”。我第一次听说无闪烁窗口大小调整问题是在 2003 年 2 月的一次会议上，当时由 Toy 管理的程序员开源应用基金会 (OSAF) 完成了其项目的最早版本 Chandler，这是一个内部版本，不是甚至在 0.1 版本之前就已公开发布。最终，钱德勒应该成长为一名强大的“个人信息管理员”（PIM），负责组织和共享日历、电子邮件、待办事项列表以及我们生活中的所有其他杂散信息。目前，该计划还处于萌芽阶段。

Officially, this was bug number 44 in Bugzilla, originally entered on January 19, 2003, and labeled “Flicker Free window display when resizing windows.” I had first heard of the flicker-free window resizing problem at a meeting in February 2003 when the Open Source Applications Foundation (OSAF), whose programmers Toy was managing, had completed the very earliest version of its project, Chandler—an internal release not for public unveiling that came even before the 0.1 edition. Ultimately, Chandler was supposed to grow up into a powerful “personal information manager” (PIM) for organizing and sharing calendars, email, to-do lists, and all the other stray information in our lives. Right now, the program remained barely embryonic.

在那次二月份的会议上，安德森曾短暂提到闪烁错误——当你改变钱德勒屏幕上的窗口大小时，一切都会闪烁一秒钟——作为一个小问题，他想调查和解决这个问题，因为，尽管它没有阻止程序运行，这冒犯了他的审美。现在，近六个月过去了，他仍然没有解决这个问题。

At that February meeting, Anderson had briefly mentioned the flicker bug—when you changed the size of a window on the Chandler screen, everything flashed for a second—as a minor matter, something he wanted to investigate and resolve because, though it did not stop the program from working, it offended him aesthetically. Now, nearly six months later, he still hasn’t fixed it.

今天，安德森解释说，这个问题比他想象的更棘手。这不仅仅是修复他或他的同事编写的代码的问题；而是修复他或他的同事编写的代码的问题。它的根源在于名为 wxWidgets 的软件主体，Chandler 团队已采用该软件作为其项目的构建块之一。安德森必须要么等待运行 wxWidgets 的程序员修复他们自己的代码，要么找到一种方法来解决他们的缺陷。

Today Anderson explains that the problem is thornier than he had realized. It isn’t simply a matter of fixing code that he or his colleagues have written; its roots lie in a body of software called wxWidgets that the Chandler team has adopted as one of the building blocks of their project. Anderson must either wait for the programmers who run wxWidgets to fix their own code or find a way to work around their flaw.

“所以你最初估计这需要四个小时的工作，”托伊说。“这似乎已经偏离了一个数量级。”

“So you originally estimated that this would take four hours of work,” Toy says. “That seems to have been off by an order of magnitude.”

“这就像寻宝，”安德森镇定自若地回答道。“你必须找到第一件事。你必须在上路之前得到第一个线索，而且你不知道需要多长时间。”

“It’s like a treasure hunt,” Anderson, unflappable, responds. “You have to find the first thing. You have to get the first clue before you’re on your way, and you don’t know how long it will take.”

“所以你最初估计这个错误需要四个小时。现在你有八个小时。”

“So you originally estimated four hours on this bug. You now have eight hours.”

“有时候，”安德森富有哲理地说，“你早上醒来，一个想法就会突然出现在你的脑海里，然后就完成了——就像这样。”

“Sometimes,” Anderson offers philosophically, “you just wake up in the morning, an idea pops into your head, and it’s done—like that.”

米切尔·卡普尔（Mitchell Kapor）在交流过程中一直安静地坐着。卡普尔是开源应用基金会的创始人和资助者，而钱德勒是他的宝贝。现在他从黑色的 Thinkpad 上抬起头来。“识别具有寻宝方面的问题有用吗？是否有一类任务具有这种不确定性？”

Mitchell Kapor has been sitting quietly during the exchange. Kapor is the founder and funder of the Open Source Applications Foundation, and Chandler is his baby. Now he looks up from his black Thinkpad. “Would it be useful to identify issues that have this treasure-hunt aspect? Is there a certain class of task that has this uncertainty?”

“在研究这个 bug 的第一个小时内，”伯吉斯志愿者说道，“你就知道它会是什么。”

“Within the first hour of working on the bug,” Burgess volunteers, “you know which it’s going to be.”

因此，大家一致认为：具有黑洞般质量的错误（您甚至无法确定需要多长时间才能修复的错误）将在 Bugzilla 中贴上特殊警告标签。

So it is agreed: Bugs that have a black hole–like quality—bugs that you couldn’t even begin to say for sure how long they would take to fix—would be tagged in Bugzilla with a special warning label.

会议结束后不久，Toy 坐在办公桌前，调出 Bugzilla 屏幕，并输入错误编号 44“调整窗口大小时不闪烁窗口显示”的新关键字：可怕。

Shortly after the meeting, Toy sits down at his desk, calls up the Bugzilla screen, and enters a new keyword for bug number 44, “Flicker Free window display when resizing windows”: scary.





Toy 的宿命论语言不仅仅是个性的怪癖：Gallows 幽默是编程文化的一部分，他在 Netscape 期间学到了自己独特的词汇。尽管如今网景作为一家网络浏览器公司而被人们所铭记，其软件和股票引发了互联网的繁荣，但它的开发人员一直认为自己是一群注定要失败的人，被不可能的最后期限所诅咒，注定会失败。

Toy’s fatalistic language wasn’t just a quirk of personality: Gallows humor is a part of programming culture, and he picked up his particular vocabulary during his time at Netscape. Though today Netscape is remembered as the Web browser company whose software and stock touched off the Internet boom, its developers had always viewed themselves as a legion of the doomed, cursed with impossible deadlines and destined to fail.

事实上，OSAF 的程序员并没有什么特别注定的命运：他们中的几个人刚刚从一次会议回来，他们向一群热情的同行展示了他们的工作，他们告诉他们，他们的愿景可以“更清晰”，但大多数人看起来看着钱德勒的蓝图，说道：“我现在就想要它！” 尽管软件行业已连续三年不景气，但他们却为一家由 Kapor 资助的 500 万美元的非营利组织工作。他们的项目雄心勃勃，但他们的队伍中包括取得了可观成就的资深程序员。安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 编写了原始 Macintosh 操作系统的核心部分。约翰·安德森 (John Anderson) 为 Macintosh 编写了最早的文字处理器之一，后来在史蒂夫·乔布斯 (Steve Jobs) 的 Next 管理软件团队。Lou Montulli，另一位没有参加会议的 Chandler 程序员，编写了 Netscape 浏览器的关键部分。之前他们的眼神都充满了厄运。

There was, in truth, nothing especially doomed about OSAF’s programmers: Several of them had just returned from a conference where they presented their work to an enthusiastic crowd of their peers—who told them that their vision could be “crisper” but who mostly looked at the blueprint for Chandler and said, “I want it now!” Though the software industry had been slumping for three straight years, they were working for a nonprofit organization funded by $5 million from Kapor. Their project was ambitious, but their ranks included veteran programmers with estimable achievements under their belts. Andy Hertzfeld had written central chunks of the original Macintosh operating system. John Anderson had written one of the first word processors for the Macintosh and later managed the software team at Steve Jobs’s Next. Lou Montulli, another Chandler programmer who was not at the meeting, had written key parts of the Netscape browser. They’d all looked doom in the eye before.

同样，第 44 号错误也没有什么特别可怕的。自从计算机软件从纯文本、一次一行的宇宙迁移到今天的图形世界以来，这是程序员们承担责任的常规问题。窗口和鼠标景观。让 Toy 害怕的并不是 Bug 44 的本质，而是无法知道修复需要多长时间。拿一个这样的未知数，将其与钱德勒所有其他类似的未知数放在一起，将它们相互乘以，你就会遇到开发经理的噩梦：进度表中的一个“黑洞”，一个不确定且可能不可知的时间鸿沟。

Similarly, there was nothing especially scary about bug number 44. It was a routine sort of problem that programmers had accepted responsibility for ever since computer software had migrated from a text-only, one-line-at-a-time universe to today’s graphic windows–and-mouse landscape. What scared Toy was not so much the nature of Bug 44 but the impossibility of knowing how long it would take to fix. Take one such unknown, place it next to all the other similar unknowns in Chandler, multiply them by one another, and you have the development manager’s nightmare: a “black hole” in the schedule, a time chasm of indeterminate and perhaps unknowable dimensions.

两个月前，整个钱德勒团队由十几名程序员组成，连续召开了一周的会议，试图解决一系列他们称之为“蛇”的问题——这是托伊从网景废墟中抢救出来的一个词。蛇不仅是一个难题，而且是一个难题。这是一个“我们对如何解决尚未达成共识的重要问题”。在 OSAF 中， “蛇”取代了“龙”一词的更宽松用法来描述相同的现象。

Two months before, the entire Chandler team of a dozen programmers had met for a week of back-to-back meetings to try to solve a set of problems that they had dubbed “snakes”—another word Toy had salvaged from Netscape’s ruins. A snake wasn’t simply a difficult problem; it was an “important problem that we don’t have consensus on how to attack.” Snake superseded a looser usage at OSAF of the word dragon to describe the same phenomenon.

黑洞、蛇、龙——这些隐喻都在最平凡的问题上涂抹了一层神话般的英雄主义：如何安排多个程序员以便真正完成工作。您可以整天将数字输入 Bugzilla；您可以召开一次又一次的会议来讨论改进流程。软件时间仍然是一条蛇，而且似乎所向无敌。

Black holes, snakes, dragons—the metaphors all daubed a layer of mythopoetic heroism over the most mundane of issues: how to schedule multiple programmers so that work actually got done. You could plug numbers into Bugzilla all day long; you could hold one meeting after another about improving the process. Software time remained a snake, and it seemed invincible.

对于 OSAF 房间里的任何人来说，这都不是什么新闻。软件项目对日常调度的独特抵制是臭名昭著的，但也被广泛接受。在软件开发领域，迟到是如此普遍，以至于必须为其发明一个新的委婉说法：延误。

This was hardly news to anyone in the room at OSAF. The peculiar resistance of software projects to routine scheduling is both notorious and widely accepted. In the software development world, lateness was so common that a new euphemism had to be invented for it: slippage.

当然，每个领域都有其延迟的传奇故事。诉讼的蜗牛速度是众所周知的，任何真正按时完成工作的建筑承包商都会遭到难以置信的目光。但软件时间像莫比乌斯带一样弯曲和扭转的方式有一些奇怪和更令人困惑的地方。进展似乎在剧烈的痉挛中前进，然后无缘无故地停止了。你认为你快完成了，然后你一转身，六个月过去了，没有任何可衡量的进展。

Certainly, every field has its sagas of delay; the snail’s pace of lawsuits is legendary, and any building contractor who actually finishes a job on time is met with stares of disbelief. But there’s something stranger and more baffling about the way software time bends and twists back on itself like a Möbius strip. Progress seems to move in great spasms and then halt for no reason. You think you’re almost done, and then you turn around and six months have passed with no measurable progress.

感觉就是这样：工作区深处的某处有一根电线松动了。当它连接起来时，工作就会快速进行。如果不是，工作就会停止。内部的每个人都煞费苦心地试图找出哪根电线松了，哪里停电了，而外部的观察者则试图提供有用的建议，然后失去耐心，猛烈地踢了整个事情。

This is what it feels like: A wire is loose somewhere deep inside the workings. When it’s connected, work moves quickly. When it’s not, work halts. Everyone on the inside tries painstakingly to figure out which wire is loose, where the outage is, while observers on the outside try to offer helpful suggestions and then, losing their patience, give the whole thing a sharp kick.

历史上的每个软件项目都曾有过松动的情况。每一次改进软件制作的努力都是为了保持软件的紧密性。

Every software project in history has had its loose wires. Every effort to improve the making of software is an effort to keep them tight.





对软件时间问题最早、最好的诊断可以在 Frederick Brooks 1975 年出版的《人月神话》一书中找到。Brooks 是一位经验丰富的 IBM 编程经理，他亲眼目睹了当时最大的软件项目（即 IBM System/360 操作系统的创建）的愚蠢之处。那台巨大而昂贵的大型计算机将成为未来二十年大企业的支柱，但它的酝酿和诞生却受到了延误和成本超支的困扰。正如布鲁克斯所说，它已经成为一个“焦油坑”，一个对企业野兽来说的粘性陷阱，甚至是像 IBM 这样“伟大而强大”的企业。布鲁克斯在 IBM 的团队对自己的落后程度感到困惑，于是派出了一波又一波的新程序员来从事这项工作，就像李将军命令一个又一个旅向公墓岭发起冲锋一样，结果却发现增援部队远未完成该项目越过驼峰，实际上让事情变得更糟。

The earliest and best diagnosis of the problem of software time can be found in a 1975 book by Frederick Brooks, The Mythical Man-Month. Brooks was a veteran IBM programming manager who had seen firsthand the follies of the largest software project of its day, the creation of the operating system for the IBM System/360. That huge, expensive mainframe computer would become the mainstay of big business for the next two decades, but its gestation and birth were plagued with delays and cost overruns. It had become, as Brooks put it, a “tar pit,” a sticky trap for corporate beasts, even ones as “great and powerful” as IBM. Brooks’s group at IBM, confounded by how far behind they’d fallen, flung waves of new programmers at the job, like General Lee’s ordering one brigade after another to charge up Cemetery Ridge—only to find that the reinforcements, far from getting the project over its hump, actually made things worse.

于是他提出了布鲁克斯定律，这既是一个原则，也是一个悖论：“为一个晚期的软件项目增加人力，会让它变得更晚。”

And so he formulated Brooks’s Law, which is both a principle and a paradox: “Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later.”

布鲁克斯定律自提出以来的三十年里，其合理性已被一再证明。但它是如此违反直觉，以至于它仍然经常让程序员和经理感到困惑，他们常常宁愿假装它不适用于他们，也不愿处理其令人不安的影响。

The soundness of Brooks’s Law has been borne out over and over in the three decades since its formulation. But it is so deeply counterintuitive that it still regularly flummoxes programmers and managers, who often would rather pretend that it does not apply to them than deal with its disturbing implications.

布鲁克斯指出，软件开发人员通常是乐观主义者，他们认为每个错误都可以快速修复，并且新错误的数量将会减少，直到最后一个错误被解决。这种乐观情绪，加上程序员希望取悦那些委托他们创造新东西的不耐烦的顾客，从一开始就扭曲了时间表。布鲁克斯发现，在实践中，几乎所有软件项目只需要六分之一的时间来编写代码，以及一半的时间来测试和修复错误。但真正计划按照这样的细目来分配开发人员时间的项目经理却很少见。

Brooks noted that software developers are typically optimists who assume that each bug can be fixed quickly and that the number of new bugs will diminish until the last one has been licked. This optimism, along with the programmers’ desire to please the impatient patrons who have commissioned them to create something new, skews the schedule from the start. In practice, Brooks found, nearly all software projects require only one-sixth of their time for the writing of code and fully half their schedule for testing and fixing bugs. But it was a rare project manager who actually planned to allocate developers’ time according to such a breakdown.

接下来，布鲁克斯认为，“用于估计和调度的工作量单位”是“一个危险且具有欺骗性的神话”。“人月”是一个科学管理的概念，它假设生产力可以分解为离散的、相同的、可互换的单位。因此，如果一百个人（当时的性别假设只是随地域而定）可以在一个月内生产五十个小部件，那么一个小部件需要两个人月——而且你应该能够更快地生产出相同数量的小部件通过向该项目投入更多的工人。想要在三天内获得五十个小部件而不是三十个吗？只需派遣一千名工人而不是一百名工人来完成这项工作。

Next, Brooks argued, the “very unit of effort used in estimating and scheduling” was “a dangerous and deceptive myth.” The “man-month” was a concept of scientific management that assumed productivity could be broken down into discrete, identical, fungible units. So if one hundred men (in those days the gender assumption simply came with the territory) could produce fifty widgets in one month, then a single widget required two man-months—and you ought to be able to produce the same number of widgets sooner by throwing more workers at the project. Want your fifty widgets in three days instead of thirty? Just throw one thousand workers at the job instead of one hundred.

布鲁克斯观察到，“只有当一项任务可以分配给许多工人而他们之间没有沟通时，人和月才是可以互换的商品。“对于软件来说，每个项目都是不同的，工具也在不断变化，每次向团队添加新成员时，老手都必须放弃他们正在做的事情来让后来者跟上进度，每个人都需要停下来重新分配他们的任务，让新人有事可做。在你意识到之前，你已经比计划更加落后了。布鲁克斯认为，在最糟糕的情况下，这会造成灾难性的延迟循环，这是一场“再生调度灾难”，每次重置时间表都会触发雇用更多人员，迫使另一个新的时间表到位。布鲁克斯对这种前景感到畏惧：“这就是疯狂。”

Brooks observed that “men and months are interchangeable commodities only when a task can be partitioned among many workers with no communication among them.” With software, where every project is different and the tools are in constant flux, each time you add a new member to a team, the veterans must drop what they are doing to bring the latecomer up to speed, and everyone needs to pause to reapportion their tasks to give the newcomer something to do. Before you know it, you’re even further behind schedule. In the worst cases, Brooks saw, this set up a disastrous loop of delay, a “regenerative scheduling disaster” in which each resetting of the schedule triggers the hiring of more bodies, forcing yet another new schedule into place. Brooks quailed at that prospect: “Therein lies madness.”

无论如何，布鲁克斯发现，创建软件的大部分工作也受到“顺序约束”的影响，这些约束限制了任务分解的程度：无论有多少人参与，都必须先完成一项任务，然后才能处理下一项任务在...上下功夫。“无论分配多少女性，生孩子都需要九个月的时间，”他写道。

In any case, Brooks found that much of the work in creating software also suffers from “sequential constraints” that limit how far you can go in splitting up tasks: One task must be completed before the next can be tackled, regardless of how many hands work on it. “The bearing of a child takes nine months,” he wrote, “no matter how many women are assigned.”

最后，程序员之间的生产力存在巨大差异——优秀的程序员在给定时间内完成的工作量通常是平庸程序员的十倍，而工作质量通常是普通程序员的五倍（以速度和效率）——使布鲁克斯的案件与人月结案。如果一个人的工作与另一个人的工作有如此大的不同，那么这个标准就毫无用处。

Finally, the extreme variations in productivity from programmer to programmer—a great programmer was typically able to produce ten times as much work in a given amount of time as a mediocre one, and the work was typically five times as good (measured in terms of speed and efficiency)—sealed Brooks’s case against the man-month. If one man’s work was so drastically different from another’s, that yardstick was useless.





布鲁克斯定律表明，编程团队的理想规模是一个永远不需要停下来与同事沟通的单个开发人员。这种方法简化了一切，并且还保证了该项目将保留布鲁克斯所说的“概念完整性”：所有部分都朝着同一目标并根据和谐的计划进行调整。确实，软件的历史充满了独狼所取得的突破。但是，太多的软件已经变得过于庞大，一个人无法生产——从使程序更易于使用的复杂图形界面，到可靠、有用地存储我们信任计算机的大量信息所需的数据结构的复杂性和。从布鲁克斯时代开始，操作系统是管理计算机系统资源并使其电路响应用户及其程序的基本代码，但最近扩展到软件的各个领域，编程已成为一项集体努力、一项团队运动。

Brooks’s Law implies that the ideal size for a programming team is one—a single developer who never has to stop to communicate with a colleague. This approach streamlines everything, and it also provides insurance that the project will retain what Brooks calls “conceptual integrity”: the alignment of all its parts toward the same purpose and according to a harmonious plan. Indeed, the history of software is full of breakthroughs made by lone wolves. But too much software has simply grown too huge for one person to produce—from the elaborateness of the graphic interface that makes programs easier to use to the complexity of the data structures required to reliably and usefully store the huge volumes of information we trust our computers with. Beginning in Brooks’s day with operating systems—the basic code that manages a computer system’s resources and makes its circuitry responsive to users and their programs—but more recently spreading to every arena of software, programming has become a group effort, a team sport.

按照行业标准，OSAF 的十几名程序员代表了一个相对较小的团队，但自 2002 年 10 月钱德勒正式宣布这一消息以来，他们在九个月的工作中已经遇到了布鲁克斯几十年前概述的大部分问题。尽管他们可以使用所有基于计算机的工具，从邮件列表和博客到错误跟踪器和源代码版本控制系统，但保持彼此同步是极其困难的。制定日程几乎和满足日程一样困难。每一次新的延误都会带来雇用更多人员的诱惑，但新雇用的人似乎从未加快进度。

The dozen or so programmers at OSAF represented a relatively small team by industry standards, but in their nine months of work since Chandler’s official announcement in October 2002, they had already encountered most of the problems that Brooks had outlined decades before. Despite all the computer-based tools at their disposal, from mailing lists and blogs to bug-trackers and source-code version-control systems, staying in sync with one another was fiendishly difficult. Making a schedule was nearly as hard as meeting one. And each new delay introduced the temptation to hire more bodies, yet the new hires never seemed to speed the schedule along.

然而，在一个重要的方面，OSAF 的工作给布鲁克斯带来了全新的困扰。卡普尔基金会得名的开源软件开发方法在“人月神话”时代根本不存在。与此后的任何其他发展相比，开源以废除布鲁克斯定律的前景对编程世界产生了更大的吸引力。

In one vital respect, however, the work at OSAF represented an entirely new wrinkle on Brooks. The open source software development methodology from which Kapor’s foundation took its name simply did not exist in the days of The Mythical Man-Month. And more than any other development since then, open source has tantalized the programming world with the prospect of repealing Brooks’s Law.





当您购买典型的商业程序（或“收缩包装软件”）时，您会收到一个可以在您需要时随时在计算机上运行的文件。该文件是“二进制”或“机器可执行”文件：它包含机器级代码、难以理解的密集的 0 和 1 序列，大多数人甚至大多数程序员都无法读取。这个二进制文件不是人类劳动的直接产物，而是编译器的输出——一种计算机程序，它采用人类程序员用 Java、C 或 C++ 等语言编写的代码行，并将它们翻译成机器语言。

When you buy a typical commercial program—or “shrink-wrapped software”—you receive a file that runs on your computer anytime you need it. This file is a “binary” or “machine-executable” file: It contains machine-level code, impenetrably dense sequences of zeros and ones that is unreadable by most human beings and even most programmers. This binary file is not the direct product of human labor but, rather, the output of a compiler—a computer program that takes lines of code that human programmers wrote in a language like Java or C or C++ and translates them into the machine’s language.

软件公司出售二进制文件，因为这是您使用他们的产品所需要的；但他们也喜欢它，因为它可以保护他们的秘密。比如说，如果你想了解 Microsoft Word 是如何编写的，你无法通过查看其二进制文件来找到答案。你需要查看源代码——数千行人工编写的程序代码，这些代码是编译器的基础。但微软和大多数商业软件企业一样，不会让你这样做。其程序的源代码是其最令人垂涎​​的资产，知识产权法的柏林墙保护着这些宝藏。

Software companies sell a binary file because that’s what you need in order to use their product; but they also like it because it protects their secrets. If you want to understand, say, how Microsoft Word was written, you can’t find out by peering into its binary file; you would need to see the source code—the thousands of lines of human-written program code that was grist for the compiler. But Microsoft, like most commercial software enterprises, won’t let you. The source code to its programs is its most coveted asset, and a Berlin wall of intellectual property law protects the treasure.

这使得比尔·盖茨的公司能够创造出历史上最赚钱的软件特许经营权。这也意味着，当微软软件出现问题时，即使您是一名熟练的程序员，您也无法自行修复。你必须等待微软修复它，因为只有它的程序员才能访问代码。

That has enabled Bill Gates’s company to create the most profitable software franchise in history. It also means that when something goes wrong with Microsoft software, you can’t fix it yourself, even if you are an adept programmer. You have to wait for Microsoft to fix it, because only its programmers have access to the code.

学术计算领域一直具有更加开放的精神：免费共享源代码遵循免费共享所有科学研究的传统。虽然微软在 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代逐渐主宰个人计算软件行业，但这个领域离开了聚光灯，但它从未消失。20 世纪 90 年代中期，当互联网在数百万台个人电脑桌面上全面开花时，正是大学界在政府资助的帮助下播下了种子并成长起来。特别是，它开发了允许不同公司制造、使用不同硬件构建、运行不同操作系统软件的计算机之间轻松互连的协议。将孤立的计算群岛联合成一个全球网络的软件概念并不是在追求利润的企业家的办公室中产生的，而是来自在大学和公共资助的研究中心工作的理想主义研究人员的发布和共享心态。

The realm of academic computing has always had a more open ethos: Free sharing of source code followed the tradition of free sharing of all scientific research. While Microsoft was coming to dominate the personal-computing software industry through the 1980s and 1990s, this realm left the spotlight, but it never disappeared. When the Internet burst into full bloom on millions of personal-computer desktops in the mid-1990s, it was the university world, with an assist from government funding, that had planted and grown its seeds. In particular, it had developed the protocols that allow easy interconnection between computers made by different companies, built with different hardware, running different operating system software. The software concepts that united computing’s isolated archipelagoes into one global network arose not in the offices of profit-seeking entrepreneurs but from the publish-and-share mind-set of idealistic researchers working in universities and publicly sponsored research centers.

那个世界——一个充满极客热情和合作理想的环境——在 20 世纪 90 年代经历了某种自我意识的觉醒。程序员们在他们所构建的网络上互相看着对方，眨了眨眼，意识到他们共享一套与微软主导的个人计算主流不同的实践和理念。他们的灵感和工具来自两位核心人物：理查德·斯托曼和莱纳斯·托瓦兹。

That world—an environment of geekish enthusiasms and cooperative ideals—experienced a sort of waking to self-consciousness in the 1990s. Programmers looked at one another across the network they had built, blinked, and realized that they shared a set of practices and philosophies different from those of the Microsoft-dominated personal-computing mainstream. They took their inspiration and tools from two central figures: Richard Stallman and Linus Torvalds.

1985 年，古怪的 MIT 天才 Stallman 对商业软件行业锁定代码的习惯感到愤怒，成立了自由软件基金会。它开发了一种特殊的软件许可证，表示您可以拥有您想要的所有代码，并重用它，并将其合并到新产品中，但您使用该代码创建的任何内容都必须受到相同的许可条款的保护。这个许可证被称为 GPL（GNU 公共许可证），明确旨在限制自由程序的私有化，它的批评者开始将其视为一种令人讨厌的传染性病毒；比尔·盖茨嘲笑它是反资本主义的，并将其与吃豆人——一种胃口极大的电子游戏小动物进行了比较。但对于斯托曼和加入他的乐队的程序员来说，这是抵御商业侵犯的有效屏障。

In 1985, Stallman, an eccentric MIT genius who was irate about the commercial software industry’s habit of locking up code, established the Free Software Foundation. It developed a special kind of software license that said you could have all the code you wanted, and reuse it, and incorporate it into new products—but anything you created with that code had to be covered, in turn, by the same licensing terms. This license, called the GPL (for GNU Public License), was explicitly designed to limit the privatization of free programs, and its critics came to view it as a sort of nasty infectious virus; Bill Gates derided it as anticapitalist and compared it to Pac-Man, the video game critter with the vast appetite. But for Stallman and the programmers who joined his band, it was an effective barricade against the encroachments of commerce.

斯托曼和他的团队在相对默默无闻的情况下工作了数年，试图构建 GNU 的各个部分——该项目旨在创建在大学计算中心占主导地位的 Unix 操作系统的免费版本。与此同时，一位名叫 Linus Torvalds 的年轻芬兰程序员开始在互联网新闻组上发布有关他自己的一个小型操作系统项目的文章——“只是一个爱好，不会像 gnu 那样庞大和专业，”他在 1991 年的一条消息中宣称。随着该项目吸引了志愿者贡献者，Torvalds 对他们表示欢迎，并逐渐将他们塑造成现在的 Linux 社区。Linux 为 GNU 提供了它所缺少的核心组件，即操作系统的“内核”，即数字大脑的焦点核心。

Stallman and his cohorts labored for years in relative obscurity trying to build the pieces of GNU—a project to create a free version of the Unix operating system that predominated in university computing centers. Meanwhile, a young Finnish programmer named Linus Torvalds began posting to Internet newsgroups about a little operating-system project of his own—“just a hobby, won’t be big and professional like gnu,” he declared in a 1991 message. As the project attracted volunteer contributors, Torvalds welcomed them and gradually shaped them into what is now known as the Linux community. Linux provided GNU with the central component it was missing, the operating system’s “kernel,” the focal core of the digital brain.

20 世纪 90 年代，纯粹主义者称之为“GNU-Linux”的操作系统逐渐成熟，成为稳定、免费的 Unix 版本，其内部结构也被暴露出来。随着商业世界开始接受它，构建它的程序员开始检查自己的方法，将他们的实践形式化，并给它们命名：开源软件开发。

In the 1990s, the operating system that purists call “GNU-Linux” steadily matured into a stable, free version of Unix, with its innards laid bare. And as the business world began to embrace it, the programmers who built it started examining their own methods, formalizing their practices and giving them a name: open source software development.

开源的支持者喜欢区分“免费啤酒中的免费”和“免费言论中的自由”：并非所有开源软件产品都不需要成本，但所有开源软件都可以免费检查、改编和重用。开源世界充满了有争议的阵营：例如，斯托曼的追随者认为“开源”一词是一种出卖，更喜欢“自由软件”标签；关于不同许可条款的争论充满了宗教热情。但各个领域的拥护者都有一个共同的信念：任何人都可以修改的软件一定会随着时间的推移以“封闭”软件无法比拟的方式得到改进。

Proponents of open source like to draw the distinction between “free as in free beer” and “free as in free speech”: Not all open source software products cost nothing, but all open source software is free to be examined, adapted, and reused. The open source world is full of contentious camps: Stallman’s followers, for instance, view the phrase “open source” as a sellout and prefer the “free software” label; and debates over differing licensing terms are pursued with religious fervor. But advocates of every stripe share one article of faith: that software anyone can tinker with is bound to improve over time in ways that “closed” software can’t match.





媒体广泛将开源描述为对微软的挑战，事实也确实如此。但挑战是间接的。商业软件是一种旨在盈利的软件，很难想象还有谁能比微软更好地做到这一点。挑战微软的唯一方法就是改变游戏的目标。如果软件的目的不是盈利怎么办？如果你只是给程序员一个享受乐趣并展示他们才能的机会呢？当然，这听起来有些荒谬的乌托邦。但如果自我激励的程序员实际上写出了更好的代码呢？如果他们做得更有效呢？

Open source is widely portrayed in the media as a challenge to Microsoft, and it is. But the challenge is indirect. Commercial software is software that is designed to turn a profit, and it is hard to imagine anyone figuring out how to do that better than Microsoft. The only way to take Microsoft on is to change the game’s objective. What if the point of software wasn’t profit; what if you just gave programmers a chance to have fun and show their chops? Of course this sounds absurdly utopian. But what if self-motivated programmers actually produced better code? And what if they did so more efficiently?

开源不仅为生产和分发软件提供了替代的经济基础；它可以从根本上改变软件开发的具体流程——将软件从与世隔绝的少数人转移到分散的人群。程序员埃里克·S·雷蒙德 (Eric S. Raymond) 1997 年发表的一篇文章《大教堂和集市》仍然是对这一变化最有说服力的解释。雷蒙德是一位老派的长期黑客，他描述了当他第一次意识到托瓦兹技术的含义时所感受到的顿悟：

Open source doesn’t just offer an alternative economic basis for producing and distributing software; it can radically change the nuts-and-bolts process of developing software—moving it from the cloistered few to a distributed crowd. “The Cathedral and the Bazaar,” a 1997 essay by programmer Eric S. Raymond, remains the most cogent explanation of that change. Raymond, a longtime hacker of the old school, described the epiphany he felt when he first realized the implications of Torvalds’s techniques:



多年来我一直在宣扬小型工具、快速原型设计和进化编程的 Unix 福音。但我也相信存在一定的关键复杂性，在此之上需要一种更集中的、先验的方法。我认为最重要的是软件。。。需要像大教堂一样建造，由个别巫师或一小群法师精心打造，在出色的隔离中工作，在它到来之前不会发布任何测试版。Linus Torvalds 的开发风格——尽早发布、频繁发布、委派一切能委派的人、对混杂持开放态度——令人惊讶。这里没有安静、虔诚的大教堂建筑，相反，Linux 社区似乎就像一个充满不同议程和方法的热闹集市。。。一个连贯而稳定的系统似乎只有通过一系列奇迹才能出现。事实上，这种集市风格似乎很有效，而且效果很好，这一事实令人震惊。

I had been preaching the Unix gospel of small tools, rapid prototyping and evolutionary programming for years. But I also believed there was a certain critical complexity above which a more centralized, a priori approach was required. I believed that the most important software . . . needed to be built like cathedrals, carefully crafted by individual wizards or small bands of mages working in splendid isolation, with no beta to be released before its time. Linus Torvalds’s style of development—release early and often, delegate everything you can, be open to the point of promiscuity—came as a surprise. No quiet, reverent cathedral-building here—rather, the Linux community seemed to resemble a great babbling bazaar of differing agendas and approaches . . . out of which a coherent and stable system could seemingly emerge only by a succession of miracles. The fact that this bazaar style seemed to work, and work well, came as a distinct shock.



《大教堂与集市》剖析了 Torvalds 管理 Linux 项目的风格（当时）五年来从个人爱好到全球现象的发展，并从中得出了一套原则。“软件的每一个优秀作品都是从满足开发人员的个人需求开始的。” 程序员被激励并被引导去完成他们最好的工作，因为他们渴望完成一些让他们高兴或满足个人需求的事情。“优秀的程序员知道该写什么。伟大的人知道要重写（和重用）什么。” 如果程序员能够抓住已经编写的东西并将其适应新的目的，那么没有程序员会愿意从头开始构建东西。

“The Cathedral and the Bazaar” dissected Torvalds’s style of managing the Linux project over (then) half a decade’s development from personal hobby to global phenomenon and derived a set of principles from it. “Every good work of software starts by scratching a developer’s personal itch.” Programmers are motivated and led toward their best work by a desire to accomplish something that pleases them or fulfills a personal need. “Good programmers know what to write. Great ones know what to rewrite (and reuse).” No programmer will want to build something from scratch if he can grab something that is already written and adapt it to new ends.

在Unix世界中，程序员早已习惯于自由地共享他们的源代码。但对于重要的工作，大教堂模式长期以来一直是免费软件和商业软件的默认模式。Linux 最重要的前身 BSD Unix 很大程度上是比尔·乔伊 (Bill Joy) 的作品，他后来与他人共同创立了 Sun Microsystems。Stallman 的自由软件基金会也以大教堂的方式生产了其流行的 GNU 软件工具，就像迄今为止许多程序员桌面上的 emacs 编辑器一样。Torvalds 和 Linux 改变了这一点，证明“混杂的”、集市式的方法可以生产出不断变得更好的大型、有用的软件。当 Raymond 撰写《大教堂与集市》时，Linux 和其他开源软件项目（例如 Apache Web 服务器）取得了成功（在我撰写本文时，其市场份额大约为三分之二，而 25微软竞争产品的百分比）——已经开始引起人们的注意。

In the Unix world, programmers had long been accustomed to freely sharing their source code. But for important work, cathedral mode had long remained the default, for both free and commercial software. The most important predecessor to Linux, BSD Unix, was largely the work of one man, Bill Joy, who went on to cofound Sun Microsystems. And Stallman’s Free Software Foundation produced its popular GNU software tools—like the emacs editor found on so many programmers’ desktops to this day—under a cathedral approach, too. Torvalds and Linux changed that, demonstrating that a “promiscuous,” bazaar-style approach could produce big, useful software that kept getting better. By the time Raymond wrote “The Cathedral and the Bazaar,” the successes of Linux and other open source software projects—such as the Apache Web server (with, at the time I write this, a roughly two-thirds market share compared to 25 percent for Microsoft’s competing product)—were already beginning to make heads turn.

但雷蒙德是第一个在托瓦兹的作品中看到对布鲁克斯定律的明显超越的观察者——一种新的软件工作模式，允许你利用大量程序员的技能，而不会将你的项目拖入泥潭。雷蒙德确定了实现这一目标的两个关键先决条件：廉价且广泛的网络访问，例如互联网，可以实现开发人员之间快速、可靠的通信，以及存储公共的、可公开访问的共享知识和代码池；围绕托瓦尔兹这样的领导风格建立的合作团体精神的兴起，鼓励新人，欢迎贡献，并努力最大限度地增加合格参与者的数量。

But Raymond was the first observer to see, in Torvalds’s work, an explicit transcendence of Brooks’s Law—a new mode of working on software that allowed you to harness the skills of a large number of programmers without dragging your project into the mire. Raymond identified two key prerequisites for this: cheap, widespread access to a network, like the Internet, that enabled fast, reliable communication among developers and storage of common, openly accessible pools of shared knowledge and code; and the rise of a cooperative group ethos built around a leadership style, like Torvalds’s, that encouraged newcomers, welcomed contributions, and strove to maximize the number of qualified participants.

雷蒙德写道，一旦建立了这些条件，您就可以极大地改进在任何程序中查找和修复错误的过程。您不必因为害怕竞争性偷猎而嫉妒地囤积您的代码，而是可以将其向全世界展示并邀请您的同事加入，如果您有一些引人注目的东西并且知道如何与开发人员合作，那么您可以建立一个自我强化的反馈循环集体的专业知识将会发挥作用。

Once you have established these conditions, Raymond wrote, you could drastically improve the process of finding and fixing bugs in any program. Instead of jealously hoarding your code out of fear of competitive poaching, you could hang it out for the whole world and invite your colleagues in—and if you had something compelling and knew how to work the developer crowd, a self-reinforcing feedback loop of collective expertise would kick in.

“如果有足够大的 Beta 测试人员和联合开发人员基础，几乎每个问题都会被快速表征，并且修复对某人来说是显而易见的。或者，不那么正式地说，“只要有足够多的眼球，所有的虫子都是浅薄的。” 我将此称为：“莱纳斯定律”。”雷蒙德认为，这种新型的网络驱动的公开同行评审打破了弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯的残酷悖论。“针对布鲁克斯定律，我提出以下反建议：只要发展协调员拥有至少与互联网一样好的通信媒介，并且知道如何在没有强制的情况下进行领导，那么多个头脑必然比一个头脑更好。”

“Given a large enough beta-tester and codeveloper base, almost every problem will be characterized quickly and the fix obvious to someone. Or, less formally, ‘Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow.’ I dub this: ‘Linus’s Law.’” Raymond argued that this new style of network-powered open peer review had broken the back of Frederick Brooks’s cruel paradox. “To Brooks’s Law I counterpropose the following: Provided the development coordinator has a communications medium at least as good as the Internet, and knows how to lead without coercion, many heads are inevitably better than one.”

雷蒙德的文章引起了编程界的轰动，并引发了一股兴奋的浪潮。布鲁克斯咬牙切齿的 IBM 大型机项目完全符合雷蒙德对“大教堂风格”编程的描述。20 世纪 90 年代末，微软的神职人员仍在建造大教堂，特别是在华盛顿州雷德蒙德。但门外帐篷城市的喧闹声却越来越难以忽视。

Raymond’s essay caught and then fueled a wave of excitement in the programming world. The IBM mainframe projects that Brooks cut—or broke—his teeth on precisely fit Raymond’s description of a “cathedral style” of programming. In the late 1990s, cathedrals were still being built, especially in Redmond, Washington, by Microsoft’s priesthood. But the hubbub from the tent cities beyond their gates was getting hard to ignore.

尽管如此，从大教堂式的僵局到开源集市的效率的过渡并不像最狂热的开源倡导者所想象的那么简单或轻松。一方面，正如雷蒙德承认的那样，布鲁克斯本人至少预示了推动新运动的一些原则：在《人月神话》中，他写道：“维护一个广泛使用的程序的总成本通常是 40% 或 40%。”更多的开发成本。令人惊讶的是，这一成本很大程度上受到用户数量的影响。更多用户发现更多错误。” 事实上，在布鲁克斯年轻时的编程世界中，免费提供程序源代码是常态：当时软件还不是价值数十亿美元的产业的基础；软件只是一个价值数十亿美元的产业的基础。它只是您从计算机制造商那里获得的东西，以便计算机可用并且有用，并且它是免费共享的。布鲁克斯在其 1975 年出版的书中，在个人计算机软件行业诞生和微软成立之前完成，他将一种成熟的“编程产品”定义为一种有充分记录的“任何人都可以使用它、修复它并扩展它”。它”——这听起来更像是莱纳斯·托瓦兹的作品，而不是比尔·盖茨的作品。布鲁克斯还抱怨“交付不完整（没有源代码或测试用例）”的程序。对他来说，一个完整的程序可以提供其源代码作为进一步工作的基础。

Still, the passage from cathedral-style logjam to the efficiency of open source bazaars was not quite as simple or as painless as open source’s most fervid advocates would have it. For one thing, as Raymond acknowledged, Brooks himself had foreshadowed at least some of the principles that drove the new movement: In The Mythical Man-Month, he had written, “The total cost of maintaining a widely used program is typically 40 percent or more of the cost of developing it. Surprisingly this cost is strongly affected by the number of users. More users find more bugs.” In fact, in the programming world of Brooks’s youth, free availability of a program’s source code was the norm: Software was not then the basis of a multibillion-dollar industry; it was simply something you obtained from a computer’s manufacturer so that the computer would be usable and useful, and it was freely shared. In his 1975 book, completed right before the birth of the personal-computer software industry and the founding of Microsoft, Brooks defined a full-fledged “programming product” as one well enough documented that “anyone may use it, fix it, and extend it”—which sounds more like the work of Linus Torvalds than of Bill Gates. Brooks also complained about programs that are “incompletely delivered (no source code or test cases).” A complete program, to him, was one that provided its source as a basis for further work.

因此，开源本身，即可供程序员研究和扩展的源代码的可用性，已经成为布鲁克斯记录的世界的一部分。但开源方法论和基于互联网的协作集市仍然是未来的事情。雷蒙德的主要见解不是解释为什么程序员访问源代码是有用的，而是认识到互联网和托瓦尔兹式领导力的重要性，使访问代码变得有价值。

So open source itself, the availability of source code for programmers to study and extend, was already a part of the world Brooks chronicled. But the open source methodology and the Internet-based collaborative bazaar still lay in the future. Raymond’s key insight was less a matter of explaining why it was useful for programmers to have access to source code than of identifying the importance of the Internet, and of Torvalds-style leadership, in making that access to code valuable.

《大教堂与集市》为 Torvalds 的开源品牌的飞跃提供了令人信服的案例，但它并没有完全解决 Brooks 在从头开始构建新软件的过程中发现的困难。雷蒙德展示了开放集市如何在不激活布鲁克斯定律的严酷逻辑的情况下利用更多程序员的才能，但他无法证明开放源代码可以更容易地预测编写新程序需要多长时间。计划或加快向等待的公众交付的速度。《大教堂与集市》实际上并没有废除布鲁克斯定律并解决软件开发中的时间问题；它描绘了一个编程的替代宇宙，其中时间根本不那么重要，因为工作是合作性的而不是公司性的，工作人员都是志愿者，动机是乐趣和自我，而不是经济奖励。

“The Cathedral and the Bazaar” made a persuasive case for Torvalds’s brand of open source as a leap forward, but it didn’t fully come to grips with the difficulties Brooks had identified in the process of building new software from scratch. Raymond showed how the open bazaar could harness the talents of a larger number of programmers without activating the harsh logic of Brooks’s Law, but he couldn’t show that open source made it any easier to predict how much time it would take to write a new program or to speed its delivery to a waiting public. “The Cathedral and the Bazaar” doesn’t actually repeal Brooks’s Law and solve the problem of time in software development; it maps an alternate universe for programming in which time is simply less important because the work is cooperative rather than corporate, the workers are all volunteers, and the motivation is fun and ego, not financial reward.

“享受预示着效率，”雷蒙德写道。“快乐是一种资产。” 这些理想主义的格言很鼓舞人心，但它们尚未在该领域得到最终的证明。开源似乎也遭受了其自身令人沮丧的延迟。自雷蒙德的文章发表以来，最引人注目的新开源项目是 Mozilla——一个在 Netscape 公司残骸上构建的网络浏览器。在与微软的最后阵痛中，网景拥抱了开源并发布了其浏览器的源代码。今天的结果是一个仍在不断发展的免费程序，已有数百万人使用。它的最新版本 Firefox 实际上已经开始蚕食微软 Internet Explorer 的市场份额。但 Mozilla 经过了令人痛苦的漫长时间才变得如此有价值，同时微软的竞争巩固了它的主导地位。开源运动的新集市在很多方面改变了计算，但它们并没有比旧的大教堂建造者更快地为用户带来新产品。

“Enjoyment predicts efficiency,” Raymond wrote. “Joy is an asset.” The idealistic maxims are inspiring, but they have yet to be conclusively proven in the field. Open source seems to suffer from its own species of frustrating delays. The highest profile new open source project in the years since the publication of Raymond’s essay was Mozilla—a Web browser built out of Netscape’s corporate wreckage. In the last throes of its battle with Microsoft, Netscape had embraced open source and published its browser’s source code. The result today is a still-evolving free program used by millions. Its most recent incarnation, Firefox, has actually begun eating into the market share of Microsoft’s Internet Explorer. But Mozilla took an agonizingly long time to become that valuable, and meanwhile the competition at Microsoft cemented its dominance. The new bazaars of the open source movement have changed computing in many ways, but they are not notable for bringing new products to users any faster than the old cathedral builders did.

为用户带来新产品是 Kapor 和他的 Chandler 开发人员在 2003 年夏天渴望做的事情。他们是一个奇怪的混合体：他们的功能就像一个开源项目，因为他们在互联网上发布源代码并试图围绕它建立一个志愿者开发者社区；但他们的感觉和行为也像一家典型的软件初创公司，核心程序员团队试图推出新产品，并担心需要多长时间。对于卡普尔来说，他白手起家创建了莲花开发公司，后来又当了几年风险投资家，创业模式就是他所熟悉的世界，而开源则是他正在摸索的世界。

And bringing a new product to users was what Kapor and his Chandler developers ached to do in the summer of 2003. They were an odd hybrid: They functioned like an open source project in that they were posting their source code on the Internet and trying to build a community of volunteer developers around it; but they also felt and acted like a classic software start-up company, with a core group of programmers trying to get a new product off the ground and worrying about how long it was taking. For Kapor, who had built Lotus Development Corporation from the ground up and later spent a couple of years as a venture capitalist, the start-up model was the world he knew, and open source was the world he was groping toward.

他创建 Chandler 的动机无疑是借用 Raymond 的话来说，“抓个人之痒”，这是对 PIM 软件的雄心勃勃的重新思考，以实现轻松的数据共享并在三种最流行的个人计算机上运行。他想要打造 Chandler，因为他渴望类似的东西，而现有的类似产品根本不符合他脑海中的形象。但他并没有像一个孤独的开源黑客那样，通过发布第一块代码开始；他像企业家一样，首先转租了一些办公空间。

His motivation to create Chandler—an ambitious rethinking of PIM software to enable easy sharing of data and to run on the three most popular kinds of personal computers—was, undoubtedly, to use Raymond’s phrase, “scratching a personal itch.” He wanted to build Chandler because he craved something like it, and similar existing products simply didn’t match the picture in his head. But he didn’t begin, as a lone open source hacker might have, by posting a first chunk of code; he began, as an entrepreneur would, by subleasing some office space.

与许多软件初创公司一样，OSAF 的最初挖掘是时髦的、非正式的、即兴的。卡普尔在硅谷半岛边缘的贝尔蒙特找到了办公地点，那里是一个不起眼的低矮办公园区，就在企业数据库巨头甲骨文的玻璃塔园区附近。该建筑还设有“甲骨文大学”。隔壁有一家美国长住汽车旅馆，供在甲骨文停留的移民商人使用。但 2002 年春天，当卡普尔第一次将他刚刚起步的公司搬到四楼的一个角落时，办公大楼里有大量空置，使用了一家名为 Reactivity 的软件公司不再需要的空间。这就是硅谷自我补充的方式，就像森林一样：科技行业在增长和分解的常年循环中运行，新公司总是在上一波增长浪潮中其他公司倒塌所产生的空白空间中萌芽。

As with so many software start-ups, OSAF’s first digs were funky, informal, improvised. Kapor had found space in Belmont on the Peninsula fringe of Silicon Valley, in a nondescript low-slung office park just down the road from the glass-towered campus of Oracle, the giant producer of corporate databases. The building also housed “Oracle University.” An Extended Stay America motel was going up next door for migrant businesspeople stopping off at Oracle. But the office complex had plenty of vacancies in the spring of 2002 when Kapor first moved his fledgling company into a corner of the fourth floor, using space no longer needed by a software firm called Reactivity. That’s the way Silicon Valley replenishes itself, forest-like: The technology industry moves in a perennial cycle of growth and decomposition, and new companies have always germinated in the empty space created by the toppling of other companies from a previous wave of growth.

OSAF 的开发人员分散在公司的空地上，在整个房间的白板上写满了潦草的文字。当空间不足时，他们将干记号笔涂在有色窗户上。2003 年 1 月，当我第一次拜访他们时，他们就像办公室草原上的自耕农一样，挤在显示器凉爽的篝火周围，试图引发一场革命。

OSAF’s developers spread out in the corporate void, filling room-length whiteboards with their scrawls. When they ran out of space, they applied their dry markers to the tinted windows. At the time I first visited them in January 2003, they had the appearance of homesteaders on an office prairie, huddled around the cool campfires of their monitors, trying to spark a revolution.

2003 年 7 月，OSAF 从其贝尔蒙特办公空间迁至旧金山市中心的办公室，位于一栋旧阁楼建筑的顶层，该建筑已根据环保原则进行了彻底改造：回收木制品和太阳能供暖。屋顶上还设有狗跑道，以实现卡普尔所追求的“狗友好环境”。许多开发商都养狗，去年他和妻子养了一对活泼的拉布拉多犬，名叫科斯莫和钱德勒。（猎犬从程序中取了他的名字，反之亦然。）

In July 2003, OSAF moved out of its Belmont space into offices in downtown San Francisco, on the top floor of an old loft building that had been completely remodeled according to eco-friendly principles: recycled wood products and solar heating. It also had a dog run on the roof for the “dog-friendly environment” that Kapor sought. Many of the developers owned dogs, and the previous year he and his wife had acquired a pair of frisky labradoodles named Cosmo and Chandler. (The hound took his name from the program, not vice versa.)

新的空间很漂亮，天花板上有裸露的大横梁，但也像新的、无人居住的办公室一样，有点荒凉。有人在白板上写下了大字：“欢迎来到霍华德街。” 后来，有人擦掉了一堆字母，又加上了一个，所以黑板上现在写着：“我们来到三号病房。” 这对另一名工作人员来说太惨淡了，他擦掉了一个r，留下了一个更积极的圣经预言：“我们走向你。”

The new space was beautiful, with big exposed beams in the ceilings, but also—as new, unlived-in offices often are—a bit forlorn. Someone had written in huge letters across a whiteboard: “Welcome to Howard Street.” Later, someone else erased a bunch of letters and added one so that the board now read: “We come to ward three.” That was too bleak for another staffer, who erased an r, leaving a more positive biblical prophecy: “We come toward thee.”





卡普尔反复告诉他的程序员，非营利组织 OSAF 将按照与风险投资资助的初创企业不同的规则运作，在互联网繁荣后的日子里，这些初创企业的残骸散落在旧金山湾区——留下了 OSAF 以南的新社区。市场街感觉就像一个城市死区。在 5 月份的一次会议上，他向一些担心自己的团队增长太大、太快的人保证：“我们不会按照硅谷死亡行军的神话来运作，没有交付产品和获得收入的最后期限，产品质量失控。每个经历过那件事的人——几乎包括这个房间里的每个人——都知道那是什么感觉。如果我们沿着这条路走下去，我们就会惨败。”

Kapor repeatedly told his programmers that the nonprofit OSAF was going to operate under different rules from the venture-capital-funded start-ups whose wreckage, in those post–Internet boom days, littered the San Francisco Bay area—leaving OSAF’s new neighborhood south of Market Street feeling like an urban dead zone. At a May meeting he reassured some of them who feared that their team was growing too big, too fast: “We’re not operating with the mythology of the Silicon Valley death march, with the deadline to ship a product and get revenue, where the product quality goes out the window. Everybody who’s been through that—and that pretty much includes everyone in this room—knows what that’s like. If we go down that route, we will have failed miserably.”

Kapor 兑现了这一承诺：OSAF 的增长稳定但谨慎，事实上，到夏末，许多程序员担心招聘速度太慢。从理论上讲，开源模式意味着志愿者会蜂拥而至，推动 Chandler 的工作向前发展，少数程序员定期出现在 OSAF 的开放互联网中继聊天频道上，并关注其临时代码发布。但这些外部贡献者能做的事情还很少。“我们只是在玩开源游戏”，在 2003 年经济低迷的几个月里，我听到不止一位 Chandler 团队的人这样说，当时项目有时似乎陷入了停滞。钱德勒既不受投资者规定的最后期限的驱动，也不受大量开源代码的推动，陷入了令人沮丧的困境。

Kapor kept this promise: OSAF’s growth was steady but careful, and indeed by summer’s end many programmers worried that hiring was too slow. In theory, the open source model meant that volunteers would throng to push work on Chandler forward, and a handful of programmers showed up regularly on OSAF’s open Internet Relay Chat channel and paid attention to its interim code releases. But there wasn’t much that such outside contributors could do yet. “We’re just playing at open source,” I’d hear from more than one of the Chandler crew during the slow months of 2003, when it sometimes seemed as though the project was becalmed. Chandler—neither driven by investor-dictated deadlines nor fueled by a critical mass of open source code—was caught in a dispiriting limbo.

六月，Michael Toy 开设了一个博客，思考他作为 Chandler 的开发经理的工作。在他的第一篇文章中，他思考了为什么钱德勒的进展似乎如此缓慢。将 OSAF 与他在 Netscape 的经历进行对比，他将部分责任归咎于 OSAF 更加民主、层级较少的结构——正是《大教堂与集市》所倡导的组织顽固程序员的有效技术的结构：“在 OSAF，我们统治达成普遍共识，决策进展缓慢。最重要的是我们做出正确的决定。在 Netscape，最重要的事情是我们需要编写代码，因此几乎任何为人们解除障碍并让代码得以编写的决定都是正确的。OSAF 的问题是，似乎很难清理出一条可以编写代码的道路。”

In June, Michael Toy started a blog musing on his work as Chandler’s development manager. In his first posting, he pondered why progress on Chandler seemed so agonizingly slow. Contrasting OSAF with his experience at Netscape, he laid part of the blame on OSAF’s more democratic, less hierarchical structure—the very structure that “The Cathedral and the Bazaar” had championed as an efficient technique for marshaling stubborn programmers: “At OSAF we rule by general consensus, and decisions happen slowly. The most important thing is that we make good decisions. At Netscape the most important thing was that we needed to write code, and so almost any decision which unblocked people and let code get written was the right one. The problem at OSAF is that it seems really hard to clear a path so that code can be written.”

托伊认为，部分差异在于钱德勒的新奇感。它不像许多开源项目那样进行重写；它有宏伟的抱负。“在 Netscape，浏览器是一个已知的数量，它只需要重新编写。在 OSAF，钱德勒之所以与众不同，很大程度上是因为它采用了新颖独特的数据处理方法。对于这究竟意味着什么的不确定性似乎会在每一个决定中出现，我们试图立足的基础仍然在冷却。”

Part of the difference, Toy felt, lay in Chandler’s novelty. It was not a rewrite like so many open source projects; it had grand ambitions. “At Netscape the browser was a known quantity, it just needed to be re-written. At OSAF, much of what will make Chandler special is a new and unique approach to data. The uncertainty about exactly what this means seems to pop up as part of every decision, the ground on which we are trying to stand is still cooling.”

三十年前，弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯 (Frederick Brooks) 观察到，“构建软件的难点在于决定说什么，而不是说出来。” OSAF 正在证明这句格言的持续真理。

Thirty years before, Frederick Brooks had observed, “The hard thing about building software is deciding what to say, not saying it.” OSAF was proving the maxim’s continued truth.

托伊在博客上发泄不满六周后，我与安迪·赫茨菲尔德进行了交谈。在 OSAF 会议上，赫茨菲尔德的声音最一致地敦促开发人员停止设计并开始编码，或者至少在不等待地面冷却的情况下开始编码。“我的风格，”赫茨菲尔德告诉我，“就是让事情进展得非常快，然后把它变成伟大的事情，这就是你做这件事的原因。你并不是为了让它成为普通的东西而努力的。你正在努力做一些伟大的事情。但你需要开始它！关键是让令人兴奋的工作继续下去；其余的事情会自行解决。一旦你们做了自己该做的事情，你们就会互相激发——一个良性循环。”

I sat down with Andy Hertzfeld six weeks after Toy had vented his frustrations in his blog. At OSAF meetings Hertzfeld’s voice was the most consistent in pushing the developers to stop designing and start coding—or at least to start coding without waiting for the ground to cool. “My style,” Hertzfeld told me, “is to get something going really quick and then turn it into the great thing that is the reason you’re doing it. You’re not working on it to have it be run-of-the-mill. You’re working on it to do something great. But you need to get it started! The key is getting exciting work going; the rest of it will take care of itself. You’re sparking off each other—a virtuous cycle—once you’re doing the thing you’re there to do.”

托伊提出了这样的问题：“是否有可能在没有巨大压力的情况下完成伟大的工作，或者压力是天才不可或缺的一部分？”

Toy had framed the question: “Is it possible to do great work without great pressure, or is pressure an indispensable part of genius?”





在思考钱德勒的间隙，托伊有时会利用他的博客来表达他对棒球的热情，甚至贴出他在八月的一个星期四下午偷偷溜到的一场巨人队比赛的照片。如果他有时间带着一本《人月神话》去帕克贝尔公园（当时称为帕克贝尔公园），并在局之间翻阅它，他会发现以下段落：“一位棒球经理认识到非身体天赋、拼搏精神，是伟大球员和伟大球队的必备天赋。它的特点是跑得比必要的快，行动的比必要的早，比必要的努力更努力。这对于优秀的编程团队也至关重要。”

In between his musings about Chandler, Toy sometimes used his blog as an outlet for his enthusiasm for baseball, even posting photos from a Giants game that he had slipped off to one Thursday afternoon in August. If he’d had time to take a copy of The Mythical Man-Month with him to Pac Bell Park (as it was then known) and flipped through it between innings, he would have found the following passage: “A baseball manager recognizes a nonphysical talent, hustle, as an essential gift of great players and great teams. It is the characteristic of running faster than necessary, moving sooner than necessary, trying harder than necessary. It is essential for great programming teams, too.”

钱德勒的程序员们经过九个月的努力，产品仍然是愿景而不是代码，但他们仍然没有找到他们的热情。

With nine months of work under their belt and a product that remained more vision than code, the Chandler programmers still hadn’t found their hustle.

“快乐是一种财富，”埃里克·雷蒙德宣称。“开源的成功最重要的影响之一很可能是告诉我们，游戏是最具经济效率的创造性工作模式。”

“Joy is an asset,” Eric Raymond had declared. “It may well turn out that one of the most important effects of open source’s success will be to teach us that play is the most economically efficient mode of creative work.”

激动人心的话语。但随着夏天接近尾声，钱德勒维尔仍然没有欢乐。

Stirring words. But as summer drew to a close, there was, as yet, no joy in Chandlerville.

第2章                           

CHAPTER 2                           

议程的灵魂

THE SOUL OF AGENDA

[1968—2001]

[1968—2001]

周四早上，钱德勒开发团队的十几名成员聚集在旧金山霍华德街 543 号五楼的大会议室里参加每周一次的员工会议。笔记本电脑打开并锁定 WiFi 信号，咖啡杯冒着热气，狗在漫游，人们在聊天。然后，米奇·卡普尔从双扇门里探出头来，没有大张旗鼓地说：“这是你认识的人。” 他领着一个穿着蓝色西装、看上去有些眼熟的高个子男人，在闲聊声平息下来时，他僵硬地站了一会儿。

One Thursday morning, a dozen or so members of the Chandler development team gathered for the weekly staff meeting in the big conference room on the fifth floor of 543 Howard Street in San Francisco. Laptops opened up and locked on to WiFi signals, coffee cups steamed, dogs roamed, and people chatted. Then, with no fanfare, Mitch Kapor poked his head through the double doors and said, “Here’s someone you know.” He led in an oddly familiar-looking tall man in a blue suit who stood stiffly for a moment while the chatter subsided.

然后来访者说话了。“我是阿尔·戈尔。我曾经是美国下一任总统。” 唯一没有掉下巴的就是狗。

Then the visitor spoke. “I’m Al Gore. I used to be the next president of the United States.” The only jaws that didn’t drop were the dogs’.

这位前副总统出席了卡普尔为一家社会责任投资基金主办的会议。他似乎有点不确定自己为什么站在一群程序员面前，除了“继续努力！继续努力！”之外，他没有太多可说的。你们正在改变世界！” 然后他又走了出去。

The former vice president had shown up to attend a meeting Kapor was hosting for a socially responsible investment fund. He seemed a little unsure why he was now standing in front of a bunch of programmers, and he didn’t have a lot to say other than “Keep up the great work! You guys are changing the world!” Then he stepped out again.

目前尚不清楚戈尔对钱德勒和 OSAF 有多少了解，但猜测他们的目标是“改变世界”是一个不错的选择。在硅谷，这句话至少自二十年前史蒂夫·乔布斯向百事可乐首席执行官约翰·斯卡利进行传奇式的推销以来，这句话就一直是一个战斗口号，当时他询问这位高管，他是否愿意余生“卖糖水”，或者来制造计算机并改变世界。世界。

It wasn’t clear how much Gore actually knew about Chandler and OSAF, but guessing that their goal was “changing the world” was a pretty good bet. In Silicon Valley that phrase had been a rallying cry at least since Steve Jobs’s legendary pitch to Pepsi CEO John Sculley twenty years before, asking the exec whether he preferred to “sell sugar water” the rest of his life or come build computers and change the world.

对于一个疲惫的耳朵来说，这可能听起来难以置信的天真，但在钱德勒工作的人们——就像，根据我的经验，世界各地的软件开发人员——都是希望他们的工作能够改变人们的生活。也许大多数程序员所共有的理想主义是编程的辛苦和挫折的直接结果。如果您必须与令人畏惧的抽象概念作斗争或消灭成群结队的错误，那么远大的抱负可以帮助您渡过难关。
