To a jaded ear it might sound impossibly naive, but the people working on Chandler—like, in my experience, software developers everywhere—were motivated by the hope that their work might make a difference in people’s lives. Perhaps the idealism most programmers share is a direct consequence of the toil and frustration of programming. If you’re going to have to wrestle with daunting abstractions or squash armies of bugs, big ambitions can help pull you through the slog.

尽管戈尔可能弄错了时态——钱德勒实际上并没有改变世界（至少还没有）——但他的愿望是正确的。钱德勒确实被改变世界的梦想所激励。但它开始得比较温和，有一点点刺激，一种日常的烦恼——一种痒。

Although Gore might have gotten the tense wrong—Chandler wasn’t actually changing the world (not yet, anyway)—he got the aspiration right. Chandler was indeed fueled by world-changing dreams. But it began more modestly, with a small irritation, an everyday annoyance—an itch.





早在 2001 年，一台 Microsoft Exchange 服务器就放在旧金山市中心米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 办公室外的壁橱里。卡普尔几乎不想把时间花在壁橱里，但作为 Exchange 出现问题时的第一响应者，他在新千年之初经常发现自己在那里，而且经常是在奇怪的时间。卡普尔的妻子弗雷达·卡普尔·克莱因 (Freada Kapor Klein) 在同一办公套件中经营着一家小型非营利组织，员工使用微软的软件共享日历以及管理电子邮件。

Back in 2001, a Microsoft Exchange server sat in a closet just outside Mitch Kapor’s office in downtown San Francisco. The closet was hardly where Kapor wanted to spend his time, but as the first responder when there were problems with Exchange, that was where he frequently found himself at the start of the new millennium, often at odd hours. Kapor’s wife, Freada Kapor Klein, ran a small nonprofit organization from the same office suite, and staff members used Microsoft’s software to share calendars as well as to manage email.

Exchange 是一个大型程序，能够为公司处理数百倍于此规模的数据流；它是大多数“微软商店”（围绕比尔·盖茨的产品构建软件世界的公司）的核心。卡普尔对盖茨以及这位微软创始人在软件领域所代表的一切的反感是有记录的。他对使用 Exchange 并不满意，但在当时（2000 年和 2001 年，硅谷科技繁荣达到顶峰然后急转直下），这是小组调度中最难以忍受的选项。尽管如此，它看起来还是很疯狂，远远超出了办公室所需的力量。成本也更高：您必须专门使用一台计算机作为服务器，您必须为该服务器支付 Windows 许可证费用，您必须为 Exchange 软件本身授予许可，并且如果您没有全职技术人员，你必须聘请顾问每月花几个小时来调整设备。在您意识到之前，您花费了数千美元只是为了保持少数日历同步。

Exchange is a big program capable of handling the flow of data for companies hundreds of times this size; it is the beating heart of most “Microsoft shops”—firms that have built their software universes around Bill Gates’s products. Kapor’s antipathy to Gates and everything the Microsoft founder stood for in the software field was a matter of record. He was not happy about using Exchange, but at the time—in 2000 and 2001, as the Silicon Valley tech boom peaked and then nosedived—it was the least unbearable of available options for small-group scheduling. Still, it seemed crazy, far more powerful than the office needed. Costlier, too: You had to dedicate a computer as the server, you had to pay for a Windows license for that server, you had to license the Exchange software itself, and if you didn’t have a full-time technician on staff, you had to pay a consultant to come in for a few hours every month and give the thing a tune-up. Before you knew it, you were spending thousands of dollars just to keep a handful of calendars in sync.

必须有更好的方法。为什么一定要邀请微软参加聚会？为什么您计算机上的日历无法直接与同事计算机上的日历对话？在这种“点对点”方法中，各个计算机通过直接相互连接形成一个网络。服务器只是一个中间人；可以省去中间商。

There had to be a better way. Why did you have to invite Microsoft to the party? Why couldn’t the calendar on your computer talk directly to the one on your coworker’s machine? In that sort of “peer-to-peer” approach, individual computers form a network by connecting directly to one another. The server was just a middleman; middlemen could be cut out.

由于 Napster 的一夜成功，点对点最近成为网络世界的热门概念，Napster 向数百万人展示了该概念的有限版本，向他们展示了如何轻松地交换音乐文件。音乐行业和法院介入并关闭了 Napster，但那时点对点的愿景已经占据了主导地位。一方面，它起作用了。另一方面，它具有可扩展性：您可以将该原理应用于更多数量的计算机和用户，并且它仍然有效，而无需任何人在某些中央设施上花费大量资金。最后，它还具有推动个人计算机革命早期的反独裁诉求：承诺推翻计算界的大祭司，这些大师几十年前运行着大型计算机，现在守卫着服务器机房的大门。 ，并让每个人都能用办公桌上的盒子做出惊人的事情。

Peer-to-peer had recently become a hot notion in the online world thanks to the overnight success of Napster, which introduced a limited version of the concept to millions of people by showing them how easily they could trade music files. The music industry and the courts stepped in and shut Napster down, but by then the peer-to-peer vision had taken hold. For one thing, it worked. For another, it scaled: You could apply the principle to ever higher numbers of computers and users, and it still worked, without anyone’s having to spend a fortune on some central facility. Finally, it held the same antiauthoritarian appeal that had fueled the early days of the personal computer revolution: a promise to dethrone the high priests of computing, the gurus who had run the big mainframe computers decades before and now guarded the door of the server room, and empower Everyman to do amazing things with the box on his desk.

毕竟，卡普尔作为个人计算先驱的轨迹就是在二十年前开始的。现在他知道自己想再次制作软件，并且他一直在想要解决什么问题。也许就是这样。

That, after all, was where Kapor’s own trajectory as a personal-computing pioneer had started two decades before. Now he knew he wanted to make software again, and he’d been wondering what to tackle. Maybe this was it.





对于任何关注 20 世纪 80 年代初期个人计算爆炸性崛起的人来说，当时《时代》杂志让 PC 击败人类竞争对手，成为 1982 年的“年度机器”，卡普尔的名字将永远与一个名为“计算机”的程序联系在一起。莲花1-2-3。这不是第一个电子表格；它是第一个电子表格。这个里程碑属于丹·布里克林 (Dan Bricklin) 的 VisiCalc，它向商业世界展示了微型计算机（内存和功率比上一代冰箱大小的小型计算机更少的小型台式机）可以做有用的工作。Lotus 1-2-3 为世界提供了不同寻常的灵活性和传奇般的出色设计。VisiCalc 主要在流行的 Apple II 计算机上运行，​​但 1-2-3 是专门为新型 IBM PC 构建的。IBM 第一个进入台式计算机市场的产品在大多数办公室中仍然很少见，但 Kapor 将自己的业务押在了它身上，并构建了 1-2-3 来展示其功能和速度。事实证明，该程序非常受欢迎，以至于人们开始购买新的 IBM PC，以便能够运行 Lotus 的软件。它是计算机行业“杀手级应用”这一陈词滥调的体现。

To anyone who followed the explosive rise of personal computing in the early 1980s, when Time magazine let the PC elbow human competitors off its year-end cover to become 1982’s “Machine of the Year,” Kapor’s name will be forever associated with a program called Lotus 1-2-3. It wasn’t the first spreadsheet; that milestone belonged to Dan Bricklin’s VisiCalc, which showed the world of business that microcomputers, small desktop machines with less memory and power than the previous generation of refrigerator-sized minicomputers, could do useful work. What Lotus 1-2-3 offered the world was unusual flexibility and legendarily good design. VisiCalc ran mostly on the popular Apple II computer, but 1-2-3 was built specifically for the new IBM PC. IBM’s first entrant in the desktop computer market was still a rarity in most offices, but Kapor bet his business on it and built 1-2-3 to show off its power and speed. The program proved so popular that people began to buy new IBM PCs just so they could run Lotus’s software. It was the embodiment of the computer industry cliché of the “killer app.”

然而，“杀手”并不是该公司创始人在选择其受佛教启发的名称时想到的那种术语。Lotus 1-2-3 让公司一夜成名——在 80 年代一度比微软还要大——并且让卡普尔变得富有（据《商业周刊》报道，当时价值 1 亿美元左右）。但这并没有让他高兴。正如他在 1990 年向采访者大卫·甘斯 (David Gans) 解释的那样，当时 Lotus 传奇还让人记忆犹新：“重要的是要明白，在我成为数字资本家之前，我曾经教授冥想，然后我是一个心理部门的顾问。当地社区医院，这是一次成长的经历。我拥有咨询心理学硕士学位。所以我几乎走遍了整个地图。我只是有点迷上了电脑；我并没有想成为比尔·盖茨——比尔·盖茨想成为比尔·盖茨。我的观点实际上从来没有完全由需要成功建立一家大公司并赚很多钱来决定。简而言之，我创办了一家名为 Lotus 的小公司，并制作了数百万人最终购买的软件产品，然后这家小公司变成了拥有数千名员工的庞大公司，每年赚取数亿美元。这太糟糕了。我个人感觉很糟糕。所以我离开了。有一天我就离开了。”

“Killer,” however, was not the kind of term the company’s founder had in mind when he chose its Buddhist-inspired name. Lotus 1-2-3 transformed the company into an overnight success—for a time in the eighties it was bigger than Microsoft—and made Kapor rich ($100 million or so at the time, according to Business Week). But it didn’t make him happy. As he explained to interviewer David Gans in 1990, when the Lotus saga was still a fresh memory: “It’s important to understand that before I was a digital capitalist I used to teach meditation, and then I was a counselor in the psych unit of a local community hospital, which was a formative experience. I have a master’s degree in counseling psychology. So I’ve been pretty much all over the map. I just kind of fell into computers; I didn’t set out to be Bill Gates—Bill Gates set out to be Bill Gates. My perspective was really never totally shaped by needing to succeed in building a big company and making a lot of money. In a nutshell, I started this little company called Lotus and made this software product that several million people wound up buying, and this little company turned into this enormous thing with thousands of employees making hundreds of millions of dollars a year. And it was awful. It felt awful to me personally. So I left. I just walked away one day.”

卡普尔于 1986 年 7 月从莲花公司辞职——正如他向Inc描述的那样，“让自己从自己的成功中解脱出来” 。当时的杂志。但在他离开之前，他仍然关心一个项目，并且他在 Lotus 呆了足够长的时间来完成它。这个想法就像基于计算机的人工智能一样雄心勃勃，也像每天堆积在卡普尔夏威夷衬衫胸前口袋里的一堆小纸一样平凡——名片、便利贴、笔记本页。并非所有人都被埋在纸片中，但生活向每个人抛出了大量的细节。计算机比人类更擅长记住小细节。电脑不能帮助我们保持井井有条吗？您可以购买日历程序和地址簿等，但是每天流入忙碌的人生活中的所有随机的、难以分类的信息又如何呢？

Kapor resigned from Lotus in July 1986—“extricating myself from my own success,” as he described it to Inc. magazine at the time. But before he walked away, there was a project he still cared about, and he stuck around Lotus just long enough to finish it. The idea was as ambitious as computer-based artificial intelligence and as mundane as the pile of small papers—business cards, Post-its, notebook pages—that accumulated every day in the breast pocket of Kapor’s Hawaiian shirts. Not all of us are buried in scraps of paper, but life throws a barrage of details at everyone. Computers are better at remembering small details than human beings. Couldn’t PCs help us stay organized? You could buy calendar programs and address books and the like, but what about all the random, hard-to-categorize information that flows into a busy person’s life each day?

Lotus 项目称为 Agenda，旨在解决 Kapor 的小纸片问题。计算机倾向于严格地按设定的、预定义的类别存储信息，该系统对于企业库存、财务账户和电话簿来说相当有效。卡普尔口袋里的文件——提醒、要做的事情、想法、建议等等——并不那么容易分类。他希望能够将它们即时转储到计算机中，并担心稍后组织它们。他需要指望能够轻松快速地找到它们。

The Lotus project, called Agenda, aimed to solve Kapor’s little-pieces-of-paper problem. Computers tend to store information rigidly, in set, predefined categories, a system that works reasonably well for business inventories, financial accounts, and phone directories. The papers in Kapor’s pocket—reminders, things to do, ideas, recommendations, and so on—weren’t so easy to categorize. He wanted to be able to dump them into the computer on the fly and worry about organizing them later. And he needed to count on being able to find them easily and quickly.

Lotus Agenda 程序于 1988 年正式推出，是一个优雅简单的列表生成器，具有一些不寻常的功能，使其成为软件传奇。你可以用它来管理你的日常生活，但你也可以用它来组织学术研究、音乐收藏、工作项目，以及任何涉及许多小信息的东西。它的“自动分配”功能——给定一个模糊的短语，比如“下周五与约翰共进午餐”，它可以计算出“下周五”的日期——感觉就像魔法一样；目前还很难找到与之匹配的软件。它还引入了一种独特的新方法来组织数据——介于传统计算机数据库的严格结构和文字处理的自由格式之间。

Lotus Agenda, the program that was officially unveiled in 1988, was an elegantly simple list maker with a few unusual features that elevated it into a software legend. You could use it to manage your daily life, but you could also use it to organize academic research, a music collection, a work project, anything that involved many small bits of information. Its “automatic assignment” feature—given a vague phrase like “lunch with John next Friday,” it could figure out the date of “next Friday”—felt like magic; it’s still hard to find software that matches it. And it introduced a unique new approach to organizing data—halfway between the rigid structures of traditional computer databases and the free format of word processing.

Agenda 在无人区开辟了新天地，将计算机逻辑的严格领域与人类现实的模糊性分开。推动其创建者（Kapor 与 Jerry Kaplan 合作，后者后来创立了笔式计算初创公司 Go，以及 Edward J. Belove）的原则是雄心勃勃的：用户应该能够输入数据，而不必担心数据的结构。存储它的软件；用户应该能够轻松扩展和修改数据结构，添加新类别而不会丢失任何信息；用户应该能够建立新的方式来查看数据，并通过他们自己创建的视图来操作和更改数据。

Agenda broke new ground in the no-man’s-land that separated the strict realm of computer logic and the fuzzy ambiguities of human reality. The principles that drove its creators (Kapor worked with Jerry Kaplan, who went on to found the pen-computing start-up Go, and Edward J. Belove) were ambitious: Users should be able to input their data without worrying about the structure of the software that will store it; users should be able to extend and modify the structure of the data easily, adding new categories without losing any information; users should be able to build new ways of viewing their data and to manipulate and change the data through those views that they created themselves.

你可以通过看看二十年后我们现在使用的软件有多么少来实现这些目标来衡量这些目标有多么大胆。每当某个程序或网站要求您按照它的方式而不是您的方式填写空白字段时，不要在社会安全号码中添加连字符！不要在信用卡号码中包含空格！——您遇到了 Agenda 以其独特的方式解决的问题。

You can gauge just how bold these goals were by seeing how little of the software that we now employ, two decades later, meets them. Every time a program or a Web site demands that you fill in a blank field its way rather than your way—don’t put a hyphen in that Social Security number! don’t include the spaces in that credit card number!—you are encountering a problem that Agenda, in its own idiosyncratic way, had solved.

Agenda 赢得了好评并培养了一批狂热的追随者。对它的赞美之词仍然遍布网络，其中包括James Fallows 1992 年在《大西洋月刊》上发表的一篇文章，其中写道：“在我尝试过的所有计算机程序中，Agenda 无疑是最有趣的，并且是其中的两三个程序之一。最有价值。” 尽管 Agenda 激发了人们的热情，但它从未达到“杀手级”的地位。这在一定程度上是因为，路特斯已经成为在商业市场寻求“大胜利”的企业巨头，它不太知道如何利用它，而且也许并不热衷于出售一位放弃了创始人的创意。公司。此外，Agenda 在 DOS 下运行，这是微软最初为 PC 设计的操作系统，未来显然属于 Macintosh 和 Windows 风格系统的图形世界。（卡普尔说 Lotus 开发了 Agenda 的 Windows 版本，但从未发布。）Lotus 的营销部门发明了“个人信息管理器”一词来描述 Agenda 开辟的新软件类别，该术语今天以缩写形式出现在我们面前： Microsoft Outlook 仍被视为 PIM。但随着 20 世纪 90 年代的过去，Lotus 成为了 Agenda 的“孤儿”，正如软件行业所说的，不再由其制造商改进或支持的程序。

Agenda won rave reviews and developed a cult following. Paeans to it still dot the Web, including one from a 1992 article in The Atlantic by James Fallows that reads: “Of all the computer programs I have tried, Agenda is far and away the most interesting, and is one of the two or three most valuable.” For all the devotion it inspired, though, Agenda never achieved “killer” status. This was in part because Lotus, which had become a corporate behemoth looking for “big wins” in the business market, didn’t quite know what to do with it and was perhaps not enthusiastic about selling the brainchild of a founder who had forsaken the company. Also, Agenda ran under DOS, Microsoft’s crude original operating system for the PC, and the future plainly belonged to the graphical world of Macintosh- and Windows-style systems. (Kapor says Lotus developed a Windows version of Agenda but never released it.) Lotus’s marketing department invented the term “Personal Information Manager” to describe the new software category Agenda had opened up, and the term is with us today, in acronym form: Microsoft Outlook is still considered a PIM. But as the 1990s wore on, Lotus “orphaned” Agenda, as the software industry says of programs that are no longer being improved or supported by their makers.

也许这个计划是超前于时代的。也许它是公司优先事项错位的不必要的受害者。或者，尽管它具有创新性和灵活性，但对于大多数用户来说，它的功能有点过于通用——正如法洛斯所说，“对于凡人来说，功能太强大了”。

Maybe the program was ahead of its time. Maybe it was an unnecessary victim of misplaced corporate priorities. Or perhaps, for all its innovation and flexibility, it was a little too versatile for most users—as Fallows put it, “too powerful for mortal men.”





卡普尔离开了莲花。他在麻省理工学院短暂教授软件设计。他创立了一家名为 On Technology 的新公司，开发软件供人们通过计算机网络进行协作。他是在线公民自由游说团体电子前沿基金会的主要创始人（和资助者）。他在互联网时代早期对那些将乘上九十年代繁荣浪潮的公司进行了一些明智、有远见的投资，并且在大多数专家仍然拥抱封闭网络的“围墙花园”方法时，他倡导开放网络美国在线、CompuServe 和 Prodigy 等运营商。后来，他从波士顿搬到硅谷，成为 Accel Partners 的风险投资家，但他很快发现自己不适合这个职位。（“我的心与企业家同在，”他后来向我解释道，“当你是风险投资家时，很多时候你必须采取相反的方式行事。你是在为有限合伙人的利益服务” [主要投资者]，有时利益是一致的，但有时却不一致。”）

Kapor moved on from Lotus. He taught software design briefly at MIT. He founded a new venture called On Technology that developed software for people to collaborate across a computer network. He was a key founder (and funder) of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the online civil liberties lobby. He made some smart, farsighted investments in the early Internet era in companies that would ride the wave of the nineties boom, and he campaigned for an open network at a time when most experts were still embracing the “walled garden” approach of closed-network operations like America Online, CompuServe, and Prodigy. Later, he moved from Boston to Silicon Valley and became a venture capitalist at Accel Partners, a role he quickly found himself unsuited for. (“My heart is with the entrepreneur,” he explained to me later, “and when you’re a VC, there are too many times that you have to act in a contrary way. You’re serving the interests of the limited partners [chief investors], and sometimes the interests are aligned, but sometimes they’re not.”)

但他从未真正离开议程。他说，“他对这个产品如此依恋，就像我的孩子一样。” 当他开始结束自己作为风险投资家的职业生涯时，他与一些程序员签订了合同，使用 Java 构建最新版本的 Agenda。但结果并不令人满意。“这感觉很狭窄，很老式，”卡普尔说。“这有点像建造一辆福特 T 型车。我们现在对汽车了解得更多了！” 事实证明，他珍视的并不是 Agenda 的“功能集”（它可以做的具体事情的列表），而是该程序的动态灵活性精神，即“先放入，后做决定”的精神。当卡普尔思考 Microsoft Exchange 的不足并开始梦想发明一些东西来取代它时，卡普尔决定，无论他的新软件采取什么形式，它都必须体现 Agenda 的灵魂。

But he never really moved on from Agenda. He remained, he’d say, “so emotionally attached to this product, it’s like my child.” As he began winding down his career as a venture capitalist, he contracted with some programmers to build an up-to-date version of Agenda using Java. But the result was unsatisfying. “It felt narrow, old-fashioned,” Kapor says. “It was kind of like building a model-T Ford. We know a lot more about cars now!” It turned out that what he cherished was not the “feature set” of Agenda—the list of specific things it could do—but the program’s spirit of dynamic flexibility, of “put it in first, make decisions later.” Whatever shape his new software would take, Kapor decided, as he pondered the inadequacies of Microsoft Exchange and began to dream of inventing something to put in its place, it would have to conjure the soul of Agenda.

随着后来成为 Chandler 的项目的种子开始发芽，他当时唯一确定的另一件事是，他希望新产品开源。2001年春天，互联网新经济一片废墟，老式的、以营利为目的的初创软件公司失去了市场青睐。当时没有人认为挑战 Microsoft Exchange 和 Outlook 程序在电子邮件和个人信息管理领域的主导地位有前途。但卡普尔对开源的吸引力并不是简单的机会主义。他关注了九十年代末开源运动的兴起。他发现其中的想法很投机，更重要的是，他发现其中的论点很有说服力。

The only other thing he was sure of at that point, as the seeds of the project that would become Chandler began to sprout, was that he wanted the new product to be open source. In the spring of 2001, the Internet’s new economy lay in ruins, and old-fashioned, for-profit start-up software companies were out of market favor. No one at the time thought there was a future in challenging the dominance of Microsoft’s Exchange and Outlook programs in the world of email and personal information management. But Kapor’s attraction to open source wasn’t simple opportunism. He had followed the rise of the open source movement in the late nineties; he found its ideas congenial, and even more important, he found its arguments persuasive.

对于一个职业生涯体现了创业软件资本家胜利、其财富源自销售收缩包装程序的人来说，这并不是一个明显或不可避免的选择。早在 20 世纪 80 年代，在 Lotus 时代，卡普尔就痛苦地坐在自己的办公室里，而自由软件运动的蓬头垢面、脾气暴躁的火炬手理查德·斯托曼 (Richard Stallman) 则带领一群来自编程自由联盟的纠察队在外面的街道上高呼口号。他们抗议 Lotus 的软件版权政策和“外观诉讼”，这些政策试图阻止其他程序员模仿 Lotus 程序的用户界面功能。卡普尔说，他实际上对抗议活动表示同情。但即使他不再担任首席执行官，他仍然觉得有义务支持他创立的公司；正是这种“难以忍受的个人冲突”导致他永远离开了公司。

This was not an obvious or inevitable choice for someone whose career epitomized the triumph of the entrepreneurial software capitalist and whose fortune originated in the sale of shrink-wrapped programs. Back in the 1980s, in his Lotus days, Kapor had sat miserably in his office while Richard Stallman, the disheveled and cantankerous torchbearer of the free software movement, led a crowd of chanting picketers from the League for Programming Freedom in the street outside. They were protesting Lotus’s policies on software copyrights and “look-and-feel lawsuits” that tried to block other programmers from mimicking user interface features from Lotus programs. Kapor says he actually sympathized with the protest. But even though he was no longer the CEO, he felt obligated to support the company he had founded; it was just this sort of “intolerable personal conflict” that led him to leave the company for good.

现在不再有这样的冲突了。卡普尔已经成为一名细心的慈善家，开源方法让他有机会感受到自己在做他喜欢的软件设计的同时也在做出公共贡献。“我与莱纳斯·托瓦兹和其他人共进午餐，”卡普尔回忆道，“我说服自己这并不疯狂。” 开源运动的可能性非常小——你的意思是没有人拥有代码？而你就放弃了？——诉诸他特立独行的理想主义。Torvalds 以结果为导向的开源案例吸引了他商人的实用主义。

Now there were no such conflicts. Kapor had become a careful philanthropist, and the open source approach gave him the chance to feel he was making a public contribution while doing the kind of software design that he loved. “I had lunch with Linus Torvalds and other people,” Kapor recalls, “and I convinced myself that it wasn’t crazy.” The very improbability of the open source movement—you mean nobody owns the code? and you just give it away?—appealed to his maverick idealism. And Torvalds’s results-oriented case for open source appealed to his businessman’s pragmatism.

开源运动已经与商业世界经历了几轮复杂的共舞。2000年春天，互联网股市热潮达到顶峰时，Linux经历了自己的小泡沫，包括Red Hat和VA Linux在内的一批开源公司纷纷上市。在随后的互联网泡沫破灭期间，开源股票的表现并不比任何其他技术投资好。但世界各地的公司仍然需要运行计算机系统，在从 2000 年市场崩盘开始并在 9/11 后的日子里加深的勒紧裤腰带的时代，基于开源的系统的价格标签看起来非常有吸引力。

The open source movement had already been through several rounds of a complicated dance with the business world. At the height of the Internet stock market craze in the spring of 2000, Linux had experienced its own mini-bubble, and a number of open source companies, including Red Hat and VA Linux, had gone public. Open source stocks fared no better than any other technology investments during the dot-com wipeout that followed. But the corporations of the world still needed to run computer systems, and in the era of belt tightening that started with the market crash of 2000 and deepened in the days after 9/11, the price tag of open source-based systems looked very attractive.

在开始采用 Linux 及其同类产品时，企业不得不应对一些反对开源的争论。批评者说，要小心：如果没有公司支持代码，你将永远无法在需要时获得帮助。事实上，越来越多的公司在开源系统上提供服务合同，越来越多的程序员和系统管理员对它们了如指掌。批评者还谴责开源项目的“分叉”倾向，即通过分裂成敌对阵营来应对技术分歧。由于没有人拥有该代码，因此任何人都可以将其带向新的方向。这有时会导致类似听起来令人困惑的产品激增；但只要有一个核心项目得到了持续改进代码的熟练开发人员的忠诚，为什么有人会担心呢？最后，批评者认为，开源方法仍然没有证明它们在开发可供那些不依赖计算机技术的人们使用的产品方面的价值。

In beginning to embrace Linux and its ilk, businesses had to contend with several arguments against open source. Beware, said critics: Without a company behind the code, you’ll never get help when you need it. In fact, there were more and more companies offering service contracts on open source systems, and more and more programmers and system administrators who knew them inside and out. The critics also decried the tendency of open source projects to “fork”—to respond to technical disagreements by splitting into rival camps. Since no one owned the code, anyone could take it in a new direction. This sometimes led to confusing proliferations of similar sounding products; but as long as there was a core project that held the allegiance of skilled developers who continued to improve the code, why should that worry anyone? Finally, critics argued, open source methods still hadn’t proved their value in developing products that were usable for people who didn’t live and breathe computer technology.

这种抱怨，因为它基本上是真实的，所以最刺痛。卡普尔希望他的新项目能够回答这个问题。

That complaint, because it was largely true, stung the most. And Kapor hoped his new project would answer it.

Torvalds 被称为 Linux 操作系统终身的仁慈独裁者，他对他所象征的运动的长期前景始终表现出冷静的乐观态度。“在科学领域，”正如他在 2004 年接受《商业周刊》采访时所解释的那样，“整个系统建立在人们查看其他人的结果并在此基础上构建的基础上。在巫术中，有人有一个小秘密并守护着它，但从未允许其他人真正理解它并在此基础上继续发展。传统软件就像巫术。在历史上，巫术刚刚消亡。软件领域也会发生同样的情况。当问题变得足够严重时，你不能让一个人或一家公司保守他们的秘密。你必须让每个人分享知识。”

Torvalds, who is known as Benevolent Dictator for Life of the Linux operating system, consistently exudes a calm optimism about the long-term prospects for the movement he symbolizes. “In science,” as he explained in a 2004 interview in Business Week, “the whole system builds on people looking at other people’s results and building on top of them. In witchcraft, somebody had a small secret and guarded it—but never allowed others to really understand it and build on it. Traditional software is like witchcraft. In history, witchcraft just died out. The same will happen in software. When problems get serious enough, you can’t have one person or one company guarding their secrets. You have to have everybody share in knowledge.”





2001 年春天，Mitch Kapor 建立了开源应用基金会作为一个非营利组织，并雇用了第一批员工。正如他后来所说，他需要一些“双手合十的人”来开始探索想法。他聘请了两名年轻的程序员 Morgen Sagen 和 Al Cho，他们曾在互联网泡沫破灭的 Excite@Home 中一起工作过。

In the spring of 2001, Mitch Kapor established the Open Source Applications Foundation as a nonprofit organization and hired its first employees. He needed, as he later put it, some “people with good pairs of hands” to begin exploring ideas. He hired two young programmers, Morgen Sagen and Al Cho, who had worked together at the dot-com flameout Excite@Home.

此时卡普尔只知道他想要构建的三件事：它将是开源的。它会解决交易所的问题。它将把议程的灵魂带向未来。除此之外，一切都是白纸。

At this point Kapor knew only three things about what he wanted to build: It would be open source. It would scratch the Exchange itch. And it would carry the soul of Agenda into the future. Beyond that, it was a blank slate.





使用计算机作为掌握信息浪潮的工具的梦想与计算本身一样古老。负责监督美国政府二战研究计划的万尼瓦尔·布什 (Vannevar Bush) 在 1945 年发表的一篇题​​为“正如我们所想”的文章中，公布了他的 Memex 蓝图，这是一款内部装有录音机的桌面控制台，可以让研究人员随时访问个人知识宝库。布什的 Memex 为新兴的计算领域提供了自己的圣杯。几十年来，它一直激励着有远见的发明家们设计出顽固的新技术，以期对人类大脑进行升级。

The dream of using the computer as a tool to master tides of information is as old as computing itself. In a 1945 essay titled “As We May Think,” Vannevar Bush, who oversaw the U.S. government’s World War II research program, unveiled his blueprint for the Memex, a desk console with tape recorders in its guts that would give a researcher ready access to a personal trove of knowledge. Bush’s Memex provided the nascent field of computing with its very own grail. For decades it would inspire visionary inventors to devise balky new technologies in an effort to deliver an upgrade to the human brain.

迄今为止，Memex 梦想中最雄心勃勃、最具影响力的追随者是道格拉斯·恩格尔巴特 (Douglas Engelbart)，他如今被誉为电脑鼠标之父。恩格尔巴特是一名前雷达技术员，也是诺伯特·维纳控制论的学生，1950 年的一天醒来时顿悟：世界上有如此多的问题，而且日益复杂化，人类解决这些问题的唯一希望就是找到更快变得更聪明的方法。 。他发誓将毕生致力于开发“增强人类智力的框架”。从 20 世纪 60 年代初开始，在斯坦福研究所的支持下，他聚集了一批研究人员，开始突破概念和技术基础。这项工作最终于 1968 年在旧金山会议中心举行的传奇性公开示威中达到顶峰。该事件的视频仍然可以在网上观看，这意味着今天任何人都可以通过关注一些网络链接并单击鼠标来观看恩格尔巴特向世界介绍链接、鼠标以及许多其他个人元素的概念。我们现在认为计算是理所当然的。

By far the most ambitious and influential acolyte of the Memex dream was Douglas Engelbart, best known today as the father of the computer mouse. Engelbart, a former radar technician and student of Norbert Wiener’s cybernetics, woke up one day in 1950 with an epiphany: The world had so many problems, of such accelerating complexity, that humankind’s only hope of mastering them was to find ways to get smarter faster. He vowed to devote his life to developing a “Framework for the Augmentation of Human Intellect.” Beginning in the early 1960s under the aegis of the Stanford Research Institute, he gathered a band of researchers and began breaking conceptual and technical ground. The work culminated in a legendary public demonstration in 1968 at the San Francisco Convention Center. A video of that event is still available online, which means that today anyone can, by following some Web links and clicking a mouse, watch Engelbart introduce the world to the very idea of a link, and the mouse, and many other elements of personal computing we now take for granted.

如果您观看这些视频，您就会了解到 Engelbart 的“oNLine System”（NLS）是 PIM 等。它的目标是让用户“存储想法、研究它们、在结构上关联它们并交叉引用它们”。它提供了今天计算机用户所说的大纲程序——一种具有可扩展和可折叠节点的分层结构信息线的程序。但这个大纲可以通过网络共享——不仅在单个办公室内，而且可以在旧金山市中心的礼堂和三十英里外的门洛帕克的 SRI 办公室之间远程共享，正如恩格尔巴特向 1968 年的观众展示的那样。如今，NLS 闪烁的单色屏幕和模糊的排版看起来很过时，但其功能和设计仍然是现代系统难以匹敌的协作基准。

If you watch those videos, you’ll learn that Engelbart’s “oNLine System,” or NLS, was, among other things, a PIM. Its goal was to allow users to “store ideas, study them, relate them structurally, and cross-reference them.” It provided what a computer user today would call an outliner—a program with expandable and collapsible nodes of hierarchically structured lines of information. But this outliner could be shared across a network—not only within a single office but remotely, between the downtown San Francisco auditorium and the SRI office in Menlo Park, thirty miles away, as Engelbart showed his suitably impressed 1968 crowd. Today the NLS’s flickery monochrome screens and blurry typography look antediluvian, but its capabilities and design remain a benchmark for collaboration that modern systems have a tough time matching.

Engelbart 向 1968 年的观众展示了使用 NLS 制作、存储和共享购物清单是多么容易。但 NLS 的真正目的是帮助恩格尔巴特的程序员更好地编程。在 1962 年发表的论文中，恩格尔巴特阐述了他对增强人类智能的研究计划，他解释了为什么计算机程序员是最有前途的初始目标群体。他列出了九个不同的原因，包括程序员对计算机的熟悉程度以及他们所面临的问题的智力挑战。但他也指出，“成功的成果可以在增强研究计划本身中利用，以提高研究和开发增强系统所涉及的计算机编程活动的有效性。设计、实施和修改计算机程序的能力对于研究进展速度非常重要。” 换句话说，如果 NLS 可以帮助程序员更好地编程，他们就能够更快地改进 NLS。你会有一个积极的反馈循环。用恩格尔巴特喜欢的术语来说，你就是自力更生。

Engelbart showed the 1968 audience how easy it was to use NLS to make and store and share a grocery list. But the real purpose of NLS was to help Engelbart’s programmers program better. In the 1962 essay that laid out his plan of research into the augmentation of human intelligence, Engelbart explained why computer programmers were the most promising initial target group. He listed nine different reasons, including the programmers’ familiarity with computers and the intellectual challenge of the problems they confronted. But he also noted that “successful achievements can be utilized within the augmentation-research program itself, to improve the effectiveness of the computer programming activity involved in studying and developing augmentation systems. The capability of designing, implementing, and modifying computer programs will be very important to the rate of research progress.” In other words, if NLS could help his programmers program better, they’d be able to improve NLS faster. You’d have a positive feedback loop. You’d be, in the term Engelbart favored, bootstrapping.

对于恩格尔巴特来说，引导意味着“改进过程的改进”。今天，这个术语可能隐约提醒我们，每次打开计算机时，我们都在“启动”。早期计算机系统的构建者借用了“自力更生”概念中的术语来描述计算机启动和运行的悖论。当您第一次打开计算机时，其内存是空白的。这就形成了一种先有鸡还是先有蛋的悖论：计算机的硬件需要某种操作系统软件才能加载任何程序——包括操作系统本身。计算机系统发明者通过使用一种名为“引导加载程序”的小程序摆脱了这一困境，该程序为机器提供了足够的能力将大型操作系统加载到内存中并开始正常运行。在早期的计算中，人类操作员会通过控制台开关或打孔卡手动进入引导加载程序。现代计算机将其存储在固定存储芯片上。

To Engelbart, bootstrapping meant “an improving of the improvement process.” Today the term may dimly remind us that each time we turn on our computers we’re “booting up.” The builders of early computer systems had borrowed the term from the concept of pulling one’s self up by the bootstraps to describe the paradox of getting a computer up and running. When you first turn a computer on, its memory is blank. That sets up a sort of chicken-and-egg paradox: The computer’s hardware needs operating system software of some kind in order to load any program—including the operating system itself. Computer system inventors escaped this dilemma by using a small program called a “bootstrap loader” that gave the machine just enough capabilities to load the big operating system into memory and begin normal functioning. In early generations of computing, human operators would enter the bootstrap loader manually via console switches or from punch cards; modern computers store it on fixed memory chips.

对于恩格尔巴特来说，引导与其说是一个工程问题，不如说是一种抽象的、有时甚至是深奥的方式来谈论他的“增强”计划的目标。推动涉及“反馈积极的研究结果，以改善研究人员本身开展工作的方式”。这是一种“三阶现象”，它与改进流程无关，比如让人们更快地解决问题。这是关于提高改进流程的速度，比如弄清楚如何加快教人们更快地解决问题的方法。

For Engelbart, bootstrapping was less an engineering problem than an abstract and sometimes abstruse way of talking about the goals of his “augmentation” program. Boostrapping involved “the feeding back of positive research results to improve the means by which the researchers themselves can pursue their work.” A “third-order phenomenon,” it wasn’t about improving a process—like, say, getting people to solve problems faster. It was about improving the rate of improving a process—like figuring out how you could speed up ways of teaching people to solve problems faster.

这不是一个简单的区别，这可能是恩格尔巴特的项目与他的鼠标不同，从未引起轰动的原因之一。也许另一个原因是他决心坚持他的“增强”计划的纯粹版本。与后来将“可用性”一词提升为口头禅的计算机创新者不同，恩格尔巴特并没有对让工具变得简单易学抱有很大的信心。计算机是人类理性的一种假肢，恩格尔巴特希望它功能强大且用途广泛。他不想仅仅为了让使用者在使用安全带的头几天或几周感到轻松而削弱它。典型的办公室工作人员可能会习惯熟悉的打字机键盘，但恩格尔巴特认为，他构建的“和弦键组”看起来像五个钢琴键，允许熟练的用户用一只手输入文本，为用户提供了更多的权力适应它所需要的努力是值得的。他的愿景是人与机器之间的“共同进化”：机器将改变人类用户，提高他的工作能力，即使人类用户不断改进机器。事实上，当聚集在他的斯坦福实验室周围的研究人员将 NLS 融入他们的生活时，可以观察到类似的情况。据恩格尔巴特传记作者蒂埃里·巴迪尼 (Thierry Bardini) 介绍，“一些惊讶的访客报告说，[恩格尔巴特的团队已经形成了]奇怪的规则或习惯，例如能够用‘奇怪’的手语进行交流。一些工作人员偶尔会通过在琴键上显示特定和弦条目的手指位置来跨越房间的距离进行交流。”

This is not a simple distinction to fathom, and that may be one reason Engelbart’s project, unlike his mouse, never caught fire. Another reason, perhaps, was his determination to stick to a pure version of his “augmentation” plan. Unlike later computer innovators who elevated the term “usability” to a mantra, Engelbart didn’t place a lot of faith in making tools simple to learn. The computer was to be a sort of prosthesis for human reason, and Engelbart wanted it to be powerful and versatile; he didn’t want to cripple it just to ease the user’s first few days or weeks in the harness. The typical office worker might be comfortable with the familiar typewriter keyboard, but Engelbart believed that the “chord keyset” he had built, which looked like five piano keys and allowed a skilled user to input text with one hand, gave users so much more power that it was worth the effort required to adapt to it. His vision was of “coevolution” between man and machine: The machine would change its human user, improving his ability to work, even as the human user was constantly improving the machine. And, indeed, as the band of researchers clustered around his Stanford lab wove the NLS into their lives, something like that could be observed. According to Engelbart biographer Thierry Bardini, “Some astonished visitors reported that [Engelbart’s team had developed] strange codes or habits, such as being able to communicate in a ‘weird’ sign language. Some staff members occasionally communicated across the distance of the room by showing the fingers position of a specific chord entry on the keyset.”

今天，你可以从我们在 1968 年的视频中看到的恩格尔巴特的照片中感受到一点这种怪异的感觉：他耳朵上戴着耳机，一只手移动鼠标，另一只手按着和弦键，他看起来就像一个地球——即将出发的宇航员带领着一次内太空之旅，相信他正在向我们展示一个更美好的未来。然而，从 1968 年演示的顶峰开始，他的项目就陷入了混乱。他希望不断改进现有的 NLS，而他的许多年轻工程师则希望扔掉它，并使用每年提供的更新、更强大的硬件重新开始。随着时间的推移，他的组织失去了使命感，并在七十年代中期在人类潜能运动和沃纳·艾哈德的领导下沉没。

You can glean a little of that sense of weirdness today in the picture of Engelbart we encounter in the 1968 video: With a headset over his ear, one hand moving the mouse, and the other tickling the chord keyset, he looks like an earth-bound astronaut leading a tour of inner space, confident that he is showing us a better future. From the apogee of the 1968 demo, though, his project fell into disarray. He wanted to keep improving the existing NLS, whereas many of his young engineers wanted to throw it away and start afresh with the newer, more powerful hardware that each new year offered. Over time, his organization lost its sense of mission and, in the mid-seventies, foundered on the shoals of the human potential movement and Werner Erhard’s est.

恩格尔巴特要求用户适应机器的要求在随后的几十年里几乎没有得到追随者。正如计算先驱艾伦·凯后来所说，“恩格尔巴特，无论好坏，都在尝试制造一把小提琴”，但“大多数人不想学小提琴。” 这种简单与强大、方便与微妙之间的张力，标志着随后软件历史的每个阶段。我们大多数人可能一开始就对可用性原则抱有一种可以理解的偏见：计算机应该让我们更轻松地完成某些类型的工作；为什么他们不应该承担繁重的工作呢？但是，当恩格尔巴特的项目的全部目的是弄清楚技术如何帮助人们的思维方式呈指数级改善时，将恩格尔巴特的项目斥为“对用户怀有敌意”是不公平的。

Engelbart’s demand that users adapt to the machine found few followers in subsequent decades. As computing pioneer Alan Kay later put it, “Engelbart, for better or worse, was trying to make a violin”—but “most people don’t want to learn the violin.” This tension between ease and power, convenience and subtlety, marks every stage of the subsequent history of software. Most of us are likely to start with an understandable bias toward the principle of usability: Computers are supposed to make certain kinds of work easier for us; why shouldn’t they do the heavy lifting? But it would be unfair to dismiss Engelbart’s program as “user-hostile” when its whole purpose was to figure out how technology could help make exponential improvements in how people think.

计算机科学家杰伦·拉尼尔讲述了年轻的恩格尔巴特和人工智能领域的创始人、麻省理工学院的马文·明斯基之间的相遇故事。在明斯基预言他的研究项目将赋予计算机惊人的推理能力后，恩格尔巴特回答说：“你将为计算机做这一切。你要为人民做什么？”

Computer scientist Jaron Lanier tells a story about an encounter between the young Engelbart and MIT’s Marvin Minsky, a founding father of the field of artificial intelligence. After Minsky waxed prophetic about the prodigious powers of reason that his research project would endow computers with, Engelbart responded, “You’re gonna do all that for the computers. What are you going to do for the people?”





米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 总是将恩格尔巴特视为他的灵感来源之一，而 Agenda 在某种意义上是 NLS 的后代。尽管它的野心比较温和，并且由于对 DOS 的依赖而部分受到削弱，但它向愿意努力获得一些不熟悉技能的人类用户发出了类似的动态新能力的承诺。当卡普尔和他的第一批员工开始尝试勾勒新项目的轮廓时，这份遗产成为了他们穿越面前可能性海洋的指南。

Mitch Kapor always cited Engelbart as one of his inspirations, and Agenda was in a sense a descendant of NLS. Although more modest in its ambitions and partially crippled by its dependence on DOS, it dangled a similar promise of dynamic new power to the human user who was willing to make the effort to acquire some unfamiliar skills. As Kapor and his first employees began trying to sketch the outlines of their new project, that inheritance served as one guide through the sea of possibilities that lay before them.

恩格尔巴特研究之后的几十年里，计算领域发生了持续的革命。机器从后台办公室移到每张桌子上，进入每个家庭。图形用户界面 (GUI) 是由恩格尔巴特的一些前同事等人在施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心开发的，然后由苹果公司的麦金塔电脑普及。互联网连接了世界各地的计算机，形成了一个巨大的、难以驾驭的全球公共空间。

The decades following Engelbart’s research saw a continuous revolution in computing. Machines moved out of the back office onto every desk and into every home. The graphical user interface (GUI) was developed at Xerox’s Palo Alto Research Center by, among others, some of Engelbart’s former colleagues and then popularized by Apple’s Macintosh. The Internet connected the world’s computers to form a vast, unruly global commons.

没有人可以否认这些新奇事物改变了世界。另一方面，很难说他们已经成功地提供了恩格尔巴特所设想的那种对人类能力进行喷气式推进的东西。每一次基于计算机的人类生产力、便利性或创造力方面的进步似乎都会带来阴影。我们的进步梦想受到崩溃、病毒和垃圾邮件的困扰。许多热情的支持者所描绘的数字化进步的图景忽略了实际程序员将脆弱的代码转变为功能形状的史诗般的努力的痛苦记录。这一记录是一场又一场灾难，就像陨石坑一样在该领域的历史时间线上留下了痕迹。

No one can deny that these novelties have changed the world. On the other hand, it’s hard to argue that they have yet succeeded in providing anything like the sort of jet-boost to human capacity that Engelbart envisioned. Each computer-based advance in human productivity or convenience or creativity seems to call forth a shadow; our dreams of progress are troubled by crashes and viruses and spam. The picture of digital progress that so many ardent boosters paint ignores the painful record of actual programmers’ epic struggles to bend brittle code into functional shape. That record is of one disaster after another, marking the field’s historical time line like craters.

如今，任何考虑开始大型软件开发项目的人都必须应对这种令人难以置信的令人沮丧的经验负担。它嘲笑任何有着雄心勃勃计划的新人，仿佛在说，是什么让你认为自己与众不同？

Anyone contemplating the start of a big software development project today has to contend with this unfathomably discouraging burden of experience. It mocks any newcomer with ambitious plans, as if to say, What makes you think you’re any different?





《纽约时报》 2005 年 1 月 14 日的头条新闻报道了来自华盛顿特区的一些麻烦：“联邦调查局即将取消一项耗资 1.7 亿美元的计算机检修计划，这项计划被认为对反恐行动至关重要，但充满了技术和规划问题。” 该局花费了十年时间和 4 亿美元实施了一项名为 Trilogy 的雄心勃勃的计划，以实现其计算机系统的现代化，更换三万台台式计算机并建立一个安全的现代化数字通信网络。但是，当谈到 Trilogy 耗资 1.7 亿美元的第三部分时，即名为 Virtual Case File 的软件，该软件可以将新系统连接在一起，使全国各地的特工能够随时访问最新数据，并使 J. Edgar Hoover 的继承人摆脱纸质时代。联邦调查局撞上了冰山。最初的一项适度计划是向该局古老的基于大型机的文档存储系统添加一些简单的类似 Web 的访问，逐渐发展成为“用于收集、共享和分析证据和情报数据的新的协作环境”的总体规划（因为它贸易杂志Infoworld中对此进行了描述）。9/11 之前雇用的承包商发现，危机过后，其客户大幅扩大了其愿望清单。FBI 预计在 2003 年 12 月之前完成产品，但得到的是一个漏洞百出的原型机。承包商抱怨道：联邦调查局难道不明白，当它通过扩大项目来“改变要求”时，原定的交货日期就变得不可能满足了吗？也许联邦调查局很难跟上时间表的变化，因为它的首席信息官不断更换。

The lead story in the New York Times on January 14, 2005, reported some trouble from Washington, D.C.: “The Federal Bureau of Investigation is on the verge of scrapping a $170 million computer overhaul that is considered critical to the campaign against terrorism but has been riddled with technical and planning problems.” The bureau had spent a decade—and $400 million—on an ambitious program named Trilogy to modernize its computer system, replacing thirty thousand desktop computers and building a secure, modern digital communications network. But when it came to Trilogy’s $170 million third part—software called Virtual Case File that would tie the new systems together, giving agents across the country ready access to the most current data and moving J. Edgar Hoover’s heirs out of the paper era—the FBI hit an iceberg. An original modest plan to add some simple Web-like access to the bureau’s ancient mainframe-based document storage system steadily ballooned into a master plan for a “new, collaborative environment for gathering, sharing, and analyzing evidence and intelligence data” (as it was described in the trade journal Infoworld). The contractor hired before 9/11 found that its client had radically expanded its wish list in the wake of that crisis. The FBI expected a finished product by December 2003, but what it got was a bug-ridden prototype. The contractor complained: Hadn’t the FBI understood that when it “changed the requirements” by expanding the project, the original delivery date became impossible to meet? Maybe the FBI was having a hard time keeping up with the schedule changes because it was cycling through one chief information officer after another.

当碎片散布在国会委员会房间的地板上时，参议员帕特里克·莱希（Patrick Leahy）将虚拟案件档案项目称为“慢动作的火车失事”。Trilogy 的困境导致机构内部人士将其称为“悲剧”。但这个情节对于任何相关方来说都不应该太令人惊讶。联邦调查局的麻烦与一千零一个公共部门软件灾难故事相呼应。美国国税局可以与联邦调查局相媲美，并提高赌注：在过去四十年中，它已三次尝试对其计算机系统进行现代化改造；迄今为止，它尚未取得成功，并且仍然很大程度上依赖于 20 世纪 60 年代摇摇欲坠的主机系统，该系统由相当于口香糖和打包线的数字设备连接在一起。20 世纪 70 年代，吉米·卡特 (Jimmy Carter) 总统放弃了首次升级 IRS 系统的尝试；第二次计划于 1995 年被国会取消，经过 10 年的努力和 20 亿美元的投入未能实现有效的升级。最近的努力遭受了严重的延误和成本超支。手指指向了常见的问题：需求列表不断变化和添加；美国国税局 (IRS) 的监督有限或被动；旋转门首席信息官；不切实际的预算和时间表。

“A train wreck in slow motion,” Senator Patrick Leahy called the Virtual Case File project when its debris lay spread out on a congressional committee room floor. Trilogy’s woes led agency insiders to dub it “Tragedy” instead. But the plot shouldn’t have been too surprising to any of the parties involved. The FBI’s troubles carry echoes of a thousand and one public-sector software disaster stories. The Internal Revenue Service can match the FBI’s bruises and raise the ante: It has tried three times in the last four decades to modernize its computer systems; it has had no success to date and still relies largely on a rickety mainframe system dating back to the 1960s that is held together by the digital equivalent of chewing gum and baling wire. The first attempt to upgrade IRS systems was abandoned by President Jimmy Carter in the 1970s; the second was canceled by Congress in 1995, after ten years’ labor and $2 billion failed to produce a working upgrade. The most recent effort has suffered massive delays and cost overruns. Fingers point to the usual problems: constant changes and additions to the list of requirements; limited or passive oversight by the IRS; revolving-door CIOs; unrealistic budgets and schedules.

政府软件项目的编年史中有无数类似的故事，从导弹防御系统的三个十年的传奇故事到当今五角大楼的“未来作战系统”计划，该系统将在“信息中心”模型上重建美国陆军- 一项依赖于仍处于蓝图阶段的复杂新硬件和软件系统的计划（“vaporware”）。在美国以外的地区，情况也好不到哪儿去。例如，2004 年 11 月，英国的整个养老金系统在《卫报》所称的“政府历史上最大的计算机崩溃”中陷入瘫痪：显然，这是一次将七台计算机从 Windows 2000 升级到 Windows XP 的简单尝试相反，它被广播到数万台毫无准备的工作机器上。

There are countless similar stories in the annals of government software projects, from the three-decade saga of the missile defense system to the present-day Pentagon plan for a “Future Combat System” that will rebuild the U.S. Army on an “infocentric” model—a plan dependent on complex new hardware and software systems that remain in the blueprint stage (“vaporware”). Outside the United States, the picture does not look much better. In November 2004, for instance, the entire pension system for the United Kingdom was brought to its knees in what the Guardian called “the biggest computer crash in government history”: Apparently, a simple attempt to upgrade seven computers from Windows 2000 to Windows XP was instead broadcast to tens of thousands of unprepared working machines.

但不要仓促下结论说政府是问题所在；这才是问题所在。私营企业的记录并不能提供多少安慰。企业界也充斥着灾难故事。麦当劳的“创新”计划——该公司投入了 1.7 亿美元，试图将整个快餐连锁店转变为一个“实时网络”，让管理人员能够即时报告每批炸薯条的精确状态，但失败了。还有福特的“珠穆朗玛峰”采购系统，这是一个为期五年、耗资数亿美元的黑洞。人们很容易将大量失败的巨型项目视为反常现象、企业和政府官僚机构的猖獗行为。但你会发现大大小小的、公共的和私人的、新旧的软件项目中都出现了类似的悲惨故事。尽管细节有所不同，但模式重复得令人沮丧：移动目标。目标波动。不切实际的时间表。错过了最后期限。成本膨胀。绝望。混乱。

But don’t jump to the conclusion that government is the problem here; the record in private industry offers little solace. The corporate landscape is littered with disaster stories, too. There’s McDonald’s “Innovate”—$170 million down the drain in a failed effort to turn the entire fast-food chain into a “real-time network” that would give execs instantaneous reporting on the precise status of each individual batch of French fries. And there’s Ford’s “Everest” procurement system, a five-year, several-hundred-million-dollar black hole. It’s tempting to view the multitude of monster projects gone bad as anomalies, excrescences of corporate and government bureaucracies run amok. But you will find similar tales of woe emerging from software projects big and small, public and private, old and new. Though details differ, the pattern is depressingly repetitive: Moving targets. Fluctuating goals. Unrealistic schedules. Missed deadlines. Ballooning costs. Despair. Chaos.





1995 年，一家位于马萨诸塞州的咨询公司 Standish Group 发布了一份关于软件项目失败的研究报告，称为“CHAOS Report”。该公司一直将这个名字大写，就好像它是一个缩写词一样，但它似乎除了这个词的原始含义之外并不代表任何其他东西。Standish 对大、中、小型公司的 365 名信息技术经理进行了调查，发现他们的项目中只有 16% 是成功的（“按时、按预算完成，所有特性和功能均符合最初指定的要求”）。在其余的项目中，31% 的项目“受损”或被取消——彻底失败。其余的（53%）被认为是“项目受到挑战”，这是一种委婉的说法，即他们超出了预算、延迟了和/或未能交付所有承诺的特性和功能。

In 1995, a Massachusetts-based consulting firm called the Standish Group released a study of software project failures that it called the CHAOS Report. The firm has always capitalized the name as if it were an acronym, but it doesn’t seem to stand for anything other than the word’s original meaning. Standish surveyed 365 information technology managers at large, medium, and small companies and found that only 16 percent of their projects were successful (“completed on time and on budget, with all features and functions as initially specified”). Of the remainder, 31 percent were “impaired” or canceled—total failures. The rest, 53 percent, were considered “project challenged,” a euphemistic way of saying that they were over budget, late, and/or failed to deliver all the promised features and functions.

你可以对这项研究的设计和定义提出质疑，但除了对软件行业来说是个坏消息之外，没有办法将其描述为任何其他东西。Standish 对 1995 年的报告进行了定期更新，结果表明该领域的成功率稳步但缓慢地提高——2004 年的最新公开数据显示，成功 (29%) 和失败 (18%) 的数字大致翻转自 1995 年以来，“有挑战”的人数（53%）保持稳定。无论该行业取得了怎样的进步，超过三分之二的时间仍然未能实现。

You could quibble with the study’s design and definitions, but there is no way to portray it as anything but bad news for the software industry. Standish followed up the 1995 report with regular updates, and they have shown a steady but slow improvement in the field’s success rate—the most recent public number, from 2004, shows the success (29 percent) and failure (18 percent) numbers roughly flipped from 1995, but the “challenged” number (53 percent) holding steady. Whatever progress the industry has made, more than two-thirds of the time it is still failing to deliver.

回到该领域最喜欢的类比，即软件制作和桥梁建设之间的类比，1995 年的报告认为，软件的问题不仅仅是太多的中游修正和后期设计变更的问题，而这些是建造者永远不会容忍的。桥梁；这也是一个未能从错误中吸取教训的问题：“当桥梁倒塌时，我们会进行调查，并就失败的原因撰写报告。但在计算机行业中情况并非如此，故障被掩盖、忽视和/或合理化。结果，我们不断地犯同样的错误。”

Returning to the field’s favorite analogy, the one between software making and bridge building, the 1995 report argued that the problem with software wasn’t just a matter of too many midstream course corrections and late design changes that would never be tolerated by the builders of bridges; it was also a problem of failing to learn from mistakes: “When a bridge falls down, it is investigated and a report is written on the cause of the failure. This is not so in the computer industry where failures are covered up, ignored, and/or rationalized. As a result, we keep making the same mistakes over and over again.”

但事实上，存在一种完整的软件灾难类型；书架上摆满了诸如《软件失控》和《死亡行军》之类的书籍，记录了一个又一个不幸项目的失败。这些技术雄心勃勃的故事冲进了人类愚蠢的浅滩，形成了一种文学，其最终的趣味性不如事实，而是神话叙事。这个故事一遍又一遍地重复着：一群热心、雄心勃勃的技术专家出发去解决一些新奇、棘手的问题。他们被糟糕的管理者、不断变化的需求和弄巧成拙的行为所背叛。他们把这个领域交给了不可避免的会计师和律师清理小组。

In fact, though, there is an entire software disaster genre; there are shelves of books with titles like Software Runaways and Death March that chronicle the failures of one star-crossed project after another. These stories of technical ambition dashed on the shoals of human folly form a literature that is ultimately less interesting as fact than as mythic narrative. Over and over the saga is the same: Crowds of ardent, ambitious technologists march off to tackle some novel, thorny problem. They are betrayed by bad managers, ever-changing demands, and self-defeating behavior. They abandon the field to the inevitable clean-up squad of accountants and lawyers.

迄今为止，这一流派的权威著作是《软件的极限》，这是一本杂乱但充满激情的书，作者是一位名叫罗伯特·布里彻的工程师。布里彻是大型软件灾难的老手，这场灾难是所有其他灾难都可以衡量的火车失事：联邦航空管理局的高级自动化系统（AAS）。AAS 是一项空中交通管制系统现代化计划；它始于 1981 年，并于 1994 年“终止”，花费了数十亿美元，几乎没有任何成果。

The genre’s definitive work to date is The Limits of Software, a disjointed but impassioned book by an engineer named Robert Britcher. Britcher is a veteran of big software’s ur-disaster, the train wreck against which all other crack-ups can be measured: the Federal Aviation Administration’s Advanced Automation System (AAS). AAS was a plan to modernize the air traffic control system; it began in 1981 and “terminated” in 1994 after billions of dollars had been spent, with virtually nothing to show.

Britcher 曾参与 IBM 在 20 世纪 60 年代构建的原始空中交通管制系统，然后在战壕中为计划中的替代系统工作，他写道，AAS“可能是有组织工作历史上最大的失败”。美国联邦航空局为其新系统制定了一套规则：为其创建的每个软件都必须可重复使用。整个系统必须是“分布式的”，这意味着每个空中交通管制员的工作站都将其信息与所有其他工作站实时同步。到新系统的切换必须是无缝的，并且所有更改都必须在现有系统运行时进行。（这“就像在汽车沿着收费公路行驶时更换发动机一样。”）纸质打印输出可能有助于这一过程——当旧计算机系统变得不稳定时，空中交通管制员依赖它们——但联邦航空局禁止打印机：它们是太老派了。不断地。

Britcher, who had worked on the original air traffic control system built by IBM in the 1960s and then labored in the trenches on its planned replacement, writes that AAS “may have been the greatest debacle in the history of organized work.” The FAA laid down a set of rules for its new system: Every bit of software created for it must be reusable. The entire system had to be “distributed,” meaning that each air traffic controller’s workstation would synchronize its information in real time with all the others. The cut-over to the new system had to be seamless, and all changes had to be made while the existing system was running. (This was “like replacing the engine on a car while it is cruising down the turnpike.”) Paper printouts might help that process—air traffic controllers relied on them when the old computer system got flaky—but the FAA forbade printers: They were too old-school. And on and on.

在鼎盛时期，AAS 计划每天花费政府 100 万美元；两千名 IBM 员工参与了该项目，为每行程序代码生成了一百页的文档。但最终，布里彻得出结论：“该软件无法编写。” 美国联邦航空局的要求根本超出了人和机器的能力。“如果你想了解一下情况，”他写道，“你可以阅读《伊利亚特》。 ” 凭借其悲剧性的必然性，强大的人被更强大的力量所困，《软件的极限》本身就是一种数字《伊利亚特》 ，里面充满了注定要失败的桌面战士。在布里彻记录的编程活动中，参与者——与其说是过度劳累，不如说是因挫败感而过度劳累——砸坏了他们的汽车，发疯了，自杀了。一名项目经理开始沉迷于吃纸，随着延误的增加，他在会议上吃得越来越多。没有人——显然包括作者在内——能够毫发无伤地逃脱。

At its peak, the AAS program was costing the government $1 million a day; two thousand IBM employees labored on the project, producing one hundred pages of documentation for each line of program code. But in the end, Britcher concludes, “The software could not be written.” The FAA’s demands were simply beyond the capacity of human and machine. “If you want to get a feel for how it was,” he writes, “you can read the Iliad.” With its sense of tragic inevitability, of powerful men trapped by even more powerful forces, The Limits of Software is itself a kind of digital Iliad populated by doomed desktop warriors. In the programming campaigns Britcher chronicles, the participants—not so much overworked as overtaxed by frustration—smash their cars, go mad, kill themselves. A project manager becomes addicted to eating paper, stuffing his maw with bigger and bigger portions at meetings as the delays mount. No one—including, plainly, the author—escapes scar free.



我认识的一位工程师这样描述 AAS。你住在一所简陋的房子里，你看到冰箱在运转。有时冰会融化，门又不平，修理工似乎每个月都会出来一次。现在您注意到它体积庞大且不节省能源，并且您已经在西尔斯看到了这些新产品。所以是时候了。你要做的第一件事就是考察几个州的一些土地并考虑建造新房子。然后你会见到贝聿铭和一些伟大的建筑师并举行设计决选。这需要一段时间，所以你必须忍受冰箱，它现在发出的嗡嗡声让你彻夜难眠。您查看了几个计划，甚至构建了一两个原型。时间流逝，你最终选择了一种设计。建筑开始前会有一场盛大的庆祝活动。然后你建造。并构建。庆祝活动仍在继续；每一块砖都令人兴奋。然后你改变主意。您真的想要一座有红木地板和正式花园的日式房子。所以你开始重新设计你拥有的东西。移动几块砖和一些草皮。最后，你得到了一些看起来不错的东西。然后，有一天晚上，你上床睡觉时发现冰箱里的嗡嗡声消失了。出了点问题。沉默让你保持清醒。你花了太多钱了！你根本就不想动啊！现在你发现孩子们不喜欢新房子。事实上，你女儿说“我讨厌它”。这样你就减少了损失。十五年后，花费了几十亿美元，旧冰箱仍在运行。不知何故。

One engineer I know described the AAS this way. You’re living in a modest house and you see the refrigerator going. The ice sometimes melts, and the door isn’t flush, and the repairman comes out, it seems, once a month. And now you notice it’s bulky and doesn’t save energy, and you’ve seen those new ones at Sears. So it’s time. The first thing you do is look into some land a couple of states over and think about a new house. Then you get I. M. Pei and some of the great architects and hold a design run-off. This takes a while, so you have to put up with the fridge, which is now making a buzzing noise that keeps you awake at night. You look at several plans and even build a prototype or two. Time goes on and you finally choose a design. There is a big bash before building starts. Then you build. And build. The celebrating continues; each brick thrills. Then you change your mind. You really wanted a Japanese house with redwood floors and a formal garden. So you start to re-engineer what you have. Move a few bricks and some sod. Finally, you have something that looks pretty good. Then, one night, you go to bed and notice the buzzing in the refrigerator is gone. Something’s wrong. The silence keeps you awake. You’ve spent too much money! You don’t really want to move! And now you find out the kids don’t like the new house. In fact, your daughter says “I hate it.” So you cut your losses. Fifteen years and a few billion dollars later, the old refrigerator is still running. Somehow.





如果程序员过于关注过去软件灾难的遗留问题，那么就永远不会编写出任何东西。失败的可能性太令人畏惧了。我们只能祈祷我们的旧冰箱不会坏掉。但除了像布里彻纪念的联邦航空局退伍军人那样的困扰的倦怠之外，大多数新软件创建的参与者要么对过去一无所知，要么对未来鲁莽地充满信心——愉快地确信这一次事情会有所不同。

If programmers paid too close attention to the legacy of software disasters past, nothing would ever get coded. The likelihood of failure would be too daunting. We would just have to cross our fingers and pray that our old refrigerators wouldn’t conk out. But except for haunted burnouts like those FAA veterans that Britcher memorializes, most participants in the creation of new software are either blissfully ignorant of the past or recklessly confident of the future—blithely certain that this time things will be different.

“所有程序员都是乐观主义者，”弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯 (Frederick Brooks) 在 1975 年写道。也许只是因为计算机年轻了，程序员年轻了，而且年轻人总是乐观主义者。” 但程序员与生俱来的乐观主义常常被他们对困难和问题的直率所掩盖。记者知道，当你无法从销售人员或营销人员那里得到有关产品的直接答案时，工程师（在没有被锁起来或被命令保持沉默的情况下）会说出残酷的事实。在我与钱德勒最初的软件架构师约翰·安德森（John Anderson）的第一次交谈中，当我了解到该项目还处于起步阶段时，他在我对面坐下，在我提出问题之前，他宣布：“这就是我们的三个最大的失败是。” 因此，如果程序员本质上是乐观主义者，那么他们也会对不利因素有敏锐的洞察力。对灾难场景的超活跃想象力是一项专业资产；为了练习他们的手艺，他们必须考虑所有可能出错的事情。

“All programmers are optimists,” Frederick Brooks wrote in 1975. “Perhaps the hundreds of nitty frustrations drive away all but those who habitually focus on the end goal. Perhaps it is merely that computers are young, programmers are younger, and the young are always optimists.” But programmers’ innate optimism is often obscured by their forthrightness about difficulties and problems. Reporters know that when you can’t get a straight answer from a salesperson or a marketer about a product, an engineer will (when not locked away or ordered to be silent) speak the hard truth. In my very first conversation with Chandler’s original software architect, John Anderson, at a time when I understood the project to be in its infancy, he sat down across from me and, before I could ask a question, declared, “Here’s what our three biggest failures are.” So if programmers are optimists by nature, they also have a keen eye for the downside. A hyper-active imagination for disaster scenarios is a professional asset; they have to think through everything that can go wrong in order to practice their craft.

意大利激进分子安东尼奥·葛兰西曾说过，如果你想改变世界，你需要“理智上的悲观主义，意志上的乐观主义”。今天的软件创建者不太可能继承这种二元思维模式。

If you want to change the world, the Italian radical Antonio Gramsci famously declared, you need “pessimism of the intellect, optimism of the will.” Today’s software creators are improbable heirs to that binary mind-set.

当米奇·卡普尔开始想象将成为钱德勒的项目时，他无疑是一个乐观主义者。对于软件行业来说，这是一个黑暗的冬天，处于下行周期的底部。但他有足够的财力来追求自己的幸福，有成功企业家卷起袖子的渴望，当然还有他和世界需要什么的想法。

As he started imagining the project that would become Chandler, Mitch Kapor was certainly an optimist. It was a dark winter for the software industry, the bottom of a down cycle. But he had the financial wherewithal to follow his bliss, the eagerness of the successful entrepreneur to roll up his sleeves, and, of course, an idea of what he and the world needed.

当我第一次联系卡普尔讨论撰写他的作品时，他告诉我钱德勒会做出一个糟糕的案例研究。“我们是非典型的，”他说。“我们是开源的，我们是非营利组织，我们采用‘软件设计宣言’（Kapor 在 1990 年写的一篇文章）中设计优先的方法。我们正在努力实践我们所宣讲的内容。”

When I first approached Kapor to discuss writing about his work, he told me that Chandler would make a bad case study. “We’re atypical,” he said. “We’re open source, we’re nonprofit, and we’re taking the design-first approach of the ‘Software Design Manifesto’ [an essay Kapor had written in 1990]. We’re trying to practice what we preach.”

从某种意义上说，他是对的。钱德勒缺乏软件项目的许多常见限制。在截止日期后面没有任何公司等级制度；没有不耐烦的投资者坐在台下，准备在代码无法交付时终止。但这也让这个案子在我看来更有价值。在观察钱德勒的进步时，我们可以排除大部分金钱方面的因素；该项目的命运不会受到财务压力的影响，而财务压力常常被认为是软件灾难的罪魁祸首。钱德勒从技术、文化和心理层面探讨了软件开发的技术、文化和心理维度，将其从商业世界的紧迫性中解放出来。如果编程本质上存在固有的障碍，阻止我们从软件中获得我们想要的东西，也许我们会在这里看到它们。如果卡普尔和他的团队对如何克服这些障碍提出了新的见解，那就更好了。

He was, in a sense, right. Chandler lacked many of the usual constraints of software projects. There was no corporate hierarchy standing behind its deadlines; there were no impatient investors sitting offstage, ready to pull the plug if the code didn’t ship. But that also made the case look, to me, more valuable. In observing Chandler’s progress, we could factor out most of the money side of things; the project’s fate would not be shaped by the financial pressures that so often take the blame for software disasters. Chandler offered a look at the technical, cultural, and psychological dimension of making software, liberated from the exigencies of the business world. If there are barriers inherent in the very nature of programming that prevent us from getting what we want out of software, perhaps we would glimpse them here. And if Kapor and his team emerged with new insights into how to overcome those barriers, even better.

但在说钱德勒非典型的同时，卡普尔也援引了各地项目负责人为试图消除瘫痪记忆而提出的口头禅：这一次将会有所不同。面对历史，他表现出了乐观的态度——不仅是行业的历史，还有他自己的历史。在技​​术方面，他离开 Lotus 并完成 Agenda 后创办的公司，事实证明，并没有那么不同。Kapor 于 1987 年开始怀揣着让 PC 软件变得更加智能的雄心——将 Agenda 识别日期和某些名称的能力打造成一个更广泛、开放的产品，该产品可以在所有不同类型的计算机上运行，​​使办公室工作人员能够进行协作。尽管似乎没有人完全确定 On 正在构建什么，但显然它会令人印象深刻。但一年半之后，几乎没有什么可展示的，“我们拿出了计划并拍摄了它，”卡普尔告诉《华尔街日报》。

But in saying Chandler was atypical, Kapor was also invoking the mantra that project leaders everywhere offer to try to clear the air of paralyzing memories: This time will be different. He was flinging his optimism in the face of history—not just the industry’s, but his own. On Technology, the company he had started after leaving Lotus and finishing Agenda, had turned out, well, not so different. Kapor had started in 1987 with high ambitions to make PC software smarter—building Agenda’s ability to recognize dates and some names into a broader, open product, one that would work on all different kinds of computers, enabling groups of office workers to collaborate. Though no one ever seemed quite certain exactly what On was building, clearly it would be impressive. But after a year and a half with virtually nothing to show, “We took the plan out and we shot it,” Kapor told the Wall Street Journal.

他将公司规模削减了一半，缩小了安的目标，并将新计划交给了一个小团队。两年后，On 推出了第一个产品：Macintosh 操作系统的附加组件，使用户可以更轻松地组织和查找文件。该公司随后又发布了两款软件产品：一个用于通过计算机网络召开会议的工具，以及一个用于协作编辑共享备忘录的程序。这些产品大受欢迎，但未能引起轰动，而且仅限于麦金塔电脑，麦金塔电脑已成为一个狭窄、孤立的市场。与此同时，《论技术》又成为软件灾难巨著的又一章。

Cutting the size of the company in half, he slimmed down On’s goals and handed the new plan to a small team. Two years later, On shipped its first product: an add-on to the Macintosh operating system that made it easier for users to organize and find files. The company went on to release two more software products: a tool for setting up meetings over computer networks, and a program for collaboratively editing a shared memo. The products were critical hits but failed to catch fire, and they were limited to the Macintosh, which had become a narrow, isolated market. Meanwhile, On Technology had become one more chapter for the software disaster tomes.

卡普尔是对的：钱德勒是非典型的。但哪个项目不是呢？

Kapor was right: Chandler was atypical. But what project wasn’t?

“不存在所谓的典型软件项目，”安迪·赫茨菲尔德喜欢说。“每个项目都是不同的。”

“There’s no such thing as a typical software project,” Andy Hertzfeld liked to say. “Every project is different.”

第3章                           

CHAPTER 3                           

原型和 Python

PROTOTYPES AND PYTHON

[2001年—2002年11月]

[2001—NOVEMBER 2002]

您如何组织音乐收藏？如果您有堆积如山的 CD，除非您愿意让它们处于完全混乱的状态，否则您必须首先选择一种方法：也许按艺术家的字母顺序排列。或者，您将开始按流派进行组织 - 摇滚乐在一堆，爵士乐在另一堆，古典音乐在另一堆 - 然后按艺术家的字母顺序在这些堆中排序。如果您比较非正统，也许您会按标题、标签或发行年份的字母顺序对它们进行排序。或者，您可能只是让它们根据您购买的时间进行积累，就像按时间顺序分层的地质地层一样。

How do you organize a music collection? If you have a mountain of CDs, unless you’re content to leave them in a state of total disorder, you have to pick one approach to begin with: alphabetical by artist, maybe. Or you’ll start organizing by genre—rock in one pile, jazz in another, classical in another—and then sort alphabetically by artist within those piles. If you’re more unorthodox, maybe you’ll order them alphabetically by title or by label or by year of release. Or maybe you just let them accumulate according to when you bought them, like geological strata layered in chronological sequence.

不过，一旦您选择了一种归档专辑的方法，您就已经做出了承诺；切换到不同的方案需要付出比我们​​大多数人愿意投入的更多的工作。（2004 年，旧金山的一位概念艺术家决定根据装订的颜色对旧书店中的所有书籍进行重新分类。他写道，这项工作需要“二十个人在咖啡因和酒精的推动下通宵达旦地工作”。披萨。”）这是物理对象世界的限制。但也有优点。一旦你习惯了你的安排一段时间，你就会发现你可以根据感觉记忆来定位东西：你的手指只是记得埃尔维斯·科斯特洛的部分就在最上面架子的右侧，因为他们以前已经多次到达那里了。

Once you pick an approach to filing your albums, though, you’re committed; switching to a different scheme requires more work than most of us are willing to invest. (In 2004, a San Francisco conceptual artist decided to re-sort all the books in a used bookstore according to the color of their bindings. He wrote that the effort required “a crew of twenty people pulling an all-nighter fueled by caffeine and pizza.”) That’s a limitation of the world of physical objects. But there are advantages, too. Once you’ve lived with your arrangement a while, you discover you can locate things based on sense memory: Your fingers simply recall that the Elvis Costello section is over at the right of the top shelf because they’ve reached there so many times before.

随着音乐收藏开始迁移到我们的计算机上，我们发现我们获得了一系列全新的可能性：我们可以立即突发奇想地重新排序数千首歌曲，应用任意数量的标准进行任意组合。我们的音乐软件甚至可以让我们通过以前无法使用的镜头来查看我们的收藏，例如“我以前听过多少遍这个？” 我们从大量的录音中获得了与从物理世界中获取某些东西并将其建模为数据时所获得的同样的力量。但我们也失去了一些在现实世界中视为理所当然的简单提示——CD盒书脊的颜色会下意识地引导我们的手指，或者只是将一个盒子扔到CD播放器顶部来提醒自己这就是你接下来想听到的。

As music collections have begun to migrate onto our computers, we find that we’ve gained a whole new set of possibilities: We can instantly reorder thousands of songs at a momentary whim, applying any number of criteria in any combination. Our music software even lets us view our collections through previously unavailable lenses, like “How many times have I listened to this before?” We’ve gained the same power over our troves of recordings that we get any time we take something from the physical world and model it as data. But we’ve also lost some of the simple cues we take for granted in the physical world—the color of the CD box’s spine that subliminally guides our fingers, or the option to just toss a box on top of the CD player to remind yourself that that’s what you want to hear next.

当我们将生活的某些方面转移到软件代码中时，我们很容易被新奇的可能性所诱惑，而忽略了我们可能会放弃多少。一个精心设计的程序将充分利用这些新功能，而不试图违背进化留给我们的物理世界方向。（我记得昨天这个按钮的位置，因为我的大脑能够记住太空中的位置，所以明天它最好在同一个地方！）

When we move some aspect of our lives into software code, it’s easy to be seduced by novel possibilities while we overlook how much we may be giving up. A well-designed program will make the most of those new capabilities without attempting to go against the grain of the physical world orientation that evolution has bequeathed us. (I remember the location of this button from yesterday because my brain is wired to remember locations in space, so it had better be in the same place tomorrow!)

然而，很多时候，我们最终得到的软件不仅令人困惑地脱离了我们可以触摸和感受的世界，而且无法兑现灵活性和多功能性的承诺，而这正是“走向数字化”的初衷。您想按流派组织您的音乐吗？继续，但请不要期望添加到我们预先加载到程序中的流派列表中。您是一位歌剧迷，需要一种与老鹰乐队和阿姆 (Eminem) 不同的文件排序方案吗？抱歉，我们将艺术家和歌曲标题类别深深地融入到软件的结构中，如果您希望跟踪作曲家、歌手和咏叹调，您将需要一个全新的程序。

Too often, though, we end up with software that’s not only confusingly detached from the world we can touch and feel but also unable to deliver on the promise of flexibility and versatility that was the whole point of “going digital” in the first place. You want to organize your music by genre? Go ahead, but please don’t expect to add to the list of genres we’ve pre-loaded into the program. You’re an opera fan and need a different scheme for sorting files than the one that works for the Eagles and Eminem? Sorry, we baked the Artist and Song Title categories so deeply into the software’s structure that you’ll need a whole new program if you expect to track composers and singers and arias.

发生这种情况并不是因为程序员想把你围起来，而是因为他们自己经常被他们使用的工具和材料围住。软件是抽象的，因此看起来它应该具有无限的可塑性。然而，尽管它具有空灵的灵活性，但它也可能顽固地、令人发狂地难以驾驭，而且它的僵化不断地让我们感到惊讶。

This happens not because programmers want to fence you in, but because they are so often themselves fenced in by the tools and materials they work with. Software is abstract and therefore seems as if it should be infinitely malleable. And yet, for all its ethereal flexibility, it can be stubbornly, maddeningly intractable, and it is constantly surprising us with its rigidity.

这种悖论在编程项目的最初阶段就出现了，当时团队正在选择攻击角度并选择要使用的语言和技术。这些关于软件基础的决定，乍一看可能看起来是轻量级和可逆的，但事实证明具有浇筑混凝土的所有重力和后果。

That paradox kicks in at the earliest stages of a programming project, when a team is picking the angle of attack and choosing what languages and technologies to use. These decisions about the foundations of a piece of software, which might appear at first to be lightweight and reversible, turn out to have all the gravity and consequence of poured concrete.





2001 年春天，Mitch Kapor、Morgen Sagen 和 Al Cho 开始定期会面，讨论他们将要构建的软件。在他在 Excite@Home 的最后一年，随着公司开始分崩离析，萨根根据自己的需要和娱乐构建了一个基于网络的小程序，使书签和其他随机个人信息易于查找和分类。他借鉴了这一经验，就像卡普尔借鉴议程一样，当他们开始提出看似简单的问题时：我们如何组织信息？我们将如何为该组织建模？我们需要构建什么结构才能与计算机共享该问题的答案？

In the spring of 2001, Mitch Kapor, Morgen Sagen, and Al Cho began meeting regularly to talk about the software they were going to build. During his last year at Excite@Home, as the company began to come apart at the seams, Sagen had built for his own needs and amusement a little Web-based program to make bookmarks and other random personal information easy to find and sort. He drew on that experience, just as Kapor was drawing on Agenda, as they began asking deceptively simple questions: How do we organize information? How would we model that organization? What structure would we need to build to share the answer to that question with a computer?

会议持续不断。白板已满。

The meetings stretched on; the whiteboards filled up.

由于新软件通常需要很长时间才能可供任何人使用，因此程序员经常根据“用例”（关于想象中的人们如何需要或想要使用程序的假设场景）来测试他们的假设。OSAF 项目的一个早期出现并将不断重复出现的用例是组织大型个人音乐收藏。这个例子是自然而然的。在他年轻的《Wanderjahre》中，Kapor 曾做过一段时间的 DJ。2001 年的那个时候，苹果公司现在流行的 iTunes 程序才刚刚诞生，并且仅限于 Mac 电脑；其配套设备 iPod 当时还不存在。

Because it so often takes ages before a new piece of software is ready for anyone to use, programmers often test their assumptions against “use cases”—hypothetical scenarios about how imaginary people might need or want to use a program. One use case for the OSAF project that emerged early on, and would keep reappearing, was organizing a big personal music collection. The example came naturally; in his youthful Wanderjahre, Kapor had done time as a DJ. And at that time in 2001, Apple’s now-popular iTunes program had only just been born and was limited to Macs; the iPod, its companion device, did not yet exist.

Sagen 和 Cho 开始勾勒出程序需要什么样的数据结构才能满足该用例和其他用例。您需要什么类型的类别和标签？这些类别之间如何相互关联？基本数据（例如，包含音乐的实际文件）如何与描述音乐的所有元数据、艺术家姓名、专辑标题和歌曲编号相关？您将如何有效地存储所有东西？有没有一种方法可以完成这一切，而不会将您锁定，让您在进行过程中不断添加新类型的元数据？

Sagen and Cho began to sketch out what kind of data structures a program would require in order to meet that and other use cases. What kinds of categories and labels would you need? How would those categories relate to one another? How would the basic data (say, the actual files containing music) relate to all the metadata, the artists’ names and album titles and song numbers that describe the music? How would you efficiently store everything? And was there a way of doing it all that didn’t lock you in, that let you keep adding new kinds of metadata as you went along?

经过几周的时间和完整的白板后，他们得出了一个广泛的答案。您可以用简单的三部分格式对任何内容进行建模，该格式看起来类似于简单英语句子的主谓宾排列：

After a certain number of weeks and full whiteboards, they came up with a broad answer. You could model just about anything in a simple three-part format that looked something like the subject-verb-object arrangement of a simple English sentence:



<这个> <有关系> <那个>

<this> <has-relationship-with> <that>



然后他们发现，他们提出的答案已经被概述，并且至少部分由蒂姆·伯纳斯·李（Tim Berners-Lee）领导的研究人员实施，这位科学家是十几年前发明了万维网的。伯纳斯·李有一个梦想，他称之为语义网，这是现有网络的升级版本，依赖于更智能、更复杂的数据表示。语义网将建立在称为 RDF（资源描述框架）的技术基础之上。RDF 将所有信息存储在“三元组”中，即声明事物之间关系的三个部分的语句。这与萨根独立勾画的结构非常接近，优点是多年来已经投入了大量工作来整理细节。

Then they discovered that the answer they’d come up with had already been outlined and at least partially implemented by researchers led by Tim Berners-Lee, the scientist who had invented the World Wide Web a dozen years before. Berners-Lee had a dream he called the Semantic Web, an upgraded version of the existing Web that relied on smarter and more complex representations of data. The Semantic Web would be built on a technical foundation called RDF, for Resource Description Framework. RDF stores all information in “triples”—statements in three parts that declare relationships between things. This was very close to the structure Sagen had independently sketched out, with the advantage that a considerable amount of work over several years had already been put into codifying the details.

“优秀的程序员知道该写什么，”埃里克·雷蒙德在《大教堂与集市》中写道。“伟大的人知道重写（和重用）什么。” 没有必要重新发明 RDF 轮子；也许 OSAF 可以搭便车。

“Good programmers know what to write,” Eric Raymond had written in “The Cathedral and the Bazaar.” “Great ones know what to rewrite (and reuse).” There was no need to reinvent the RDF wheel; maybe OSAF could just hitch a ride on it.





音乐库的用例并没有停留很长时间；下一位加入 OSAF 的程序员就体现了这一点。安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 因其对 1984 年苹果 Macintosh 原始操作系统的核心贡献而声名鹊起，该操作系统奠定了未来二十年个人计算的发展方向，并为硅中的每个新项目设定了创新和优雅的标准。谷仍向往。在他离开苹果公司的几年里，麦金塔电脑推出后不久，赫茨菲尔德把他的技术技能、孩子气的热情和想象力贡献给了几次雄心勃勃的失败——首先是 General Magic，一家旨在彻底改变市场的初创公司。手持“数字助理”，然后是 Eazel，一家开源公司，在完成为 Linux 用户设计的程序之前，在互联网泡沫破裂中就耗尽了资金。

The music library use case didn’t stay hypothetical for very long; the next programmer to join OSAF embodied it. Andy Hertzfeld had made a name for himself thanks to his central contributions to the original operating system for Apple’s Macintosh in 1984, which established the course of personal computing for the next two decades and set a standard for innovation and elegance that every new project in Silicon Valley still aspires to. In the years since he had left Apple, soon after the Macintosh’s introduction, Hertzfeld contributed his technical skill, boyish enthusiasm, and imagination to a couple of ambitious failures—first, General Magic, a start-up company that aimed to revolutionize the market for handheld “digital assistants,” and then Eazel, an open source company that ran out of money in the dot-com collapse before it could complete the programs it had designed for Linux users.

赫茨菲尔德已经成为开源福音的狂热信徒和直言不讳的皈依者。在 Eazel 关闭的同一天，正在考虑是否将他的新项目开源的 Kapor 来拜访他，并向他讲述了他对 OSAF 的计划。几个月后，赫茨菲尔德决定作为全职志愿者加入卡普尔的项目。除了是软件界的传奇人物之外，他还是一位严肃的音乐收藏家，拥有数千张数字化唱片的库存，并且特别热衷于鲍勃·迪伦 (Bob Dylan) 的变质目录。换句话说，他是一个行走的用例。

Hertzfeld had become a fervent and vocal convert to the open source gospel; on the same day that Eazel shut down, Kapor, who was trying to decide whether to go open source with his new project, came to visit him and told him about his plans for OSAF. A few months later Hertzfeld decided to join Kapor’s project as a full-time volunteer. In addition to being a software legend, he was also a serious music collector with a stockpile of several thousand digitized recordings and a particularly avid dedication to the metamorphic catalog of Bob Dylan. In other words, he was a walking use case.

赫茨菲尔德开始参加 OSAF 的每周粉笔演讲，并很快开始构建 Vista，这是 Kapor 所设想的那种灵活程序的工作原型。赫茨菲尔德会离开，编写一些代码，然后返回卡普尔的办公室，展示 Vista 可以实现的新技巧。

Hertzfeld began joining OSAF’s weekly chalk talks and soon began to build Vista, a working prototype of the kind of flexible program Kapor had in mind. Hertzfeld would go off, write some code, and then return to Kapor’s office to show off the new tricks Vista could do.

Vista 是一个“面向用户”的程序：它负责向用户显示数据并确定输入、组织和更改该数据的方式。它将所有信息存储在 Shimmer 中，这是 Morgen Sagen 在 RDF 基础上构建的一个数据库，或者在 OSAF 世界中被称为存储库。Vista 和 Shimmer 一起让我们看到了 Kapor 梦想的突破：一种工具，让您可以根据您而不是计算机设定的规则，在一个程序中管理您的生活细节。但它的作用有限，而且崩溃了很多。这是一个真正的原型，旨在汲取它可以教授的任何教训，然后丢弃。

Vista was a “user-facing” program: It took care of displaying data to a user and shaping how you could input, organize, and change that data. It stored all its information in Shimmer—a database, or, as it came to be called in the OSAF world, repository, that Morgen Sagen had built on an RDF foundation. Together, Vista and Shimmer offered a glimpse of the kind of breakthrough Kapor dreamed of: a tool that let you manage your life’s details from within one program according to rules set by you rather than the computer. But it was limited, and it crashed a lot. It was a true prototype, designed to be milked for whatever lessons it could teach and then discarded.

在任何引入新技术或设计的项目中，弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯（Frederick Brooks）建议，“计划扔掉一个”，因为你几乎肯定不会第一次就把它做好。你所能控制的只是你是否真的计划出错，或者轻率地“承诺向顾客提供一次性产品”。

In any project that is introducing a new technology or design, Frederick Brooks had advised, “plan to throw one away,” because you almost certainly won’t get it right the first time. All you can control is whether you actually plan to get it wrong, or rashly “promise to deliver a throwaway to customers.”





到 2002 年春天，卡普尔对他想要构建的项目有了更清晰的了解。与 Agenda 一样，它将是一个 PIM（个人信息管理器），一个用于管理电子邮件、约会、地址、任务和笔记的工具。但它将是“跨平台”的：无论您使用 Windows、Mac 或 Linux 这三种当今最流行的个人计算机操作系统，您都可以运行它。它将被明确设计，以便任何开发人员都可以为其添加新功能。开源程序员可以编写新的模块或“包”来管理数码照片或音乐收藏。非技术用户将能够即时向程序添加新的类别和标签。

By the spring of 2002, Kapor had a clearer picture of the program he wanted to build. Like Agenda, it would be a PIM, or personal information manager, a tool for managing email, appointments, addresses, tasks, and notes. But it would be “cross-platform”: You could run it whether you were using Windows, Mac, or Linux, the three most popular personal computer operating systems of the day. And it would be explicitly designed so that any developer could add new capabilities to it. Open source programmers could code new modules or “parcels” for, say, managing digital photos or music collections. And nontechnical users would be able to add new categories and labels to the program on the fly.

这些都是雄心勃勃的目标。卡普尔开始招聘开发人员。凯蒂·帕兰特 (Katie Parlante) 是第一个加入的人，她是一位在斯坦福大学接受过培训的勤奋好学的软件开发人员，她在互联网泡沫时期曾在两家繁荣与萧条的初创公司工作过。帕兰特善于深思熟虑，镇定自若，有时她似乎对 OSAF 的争论犹豫不决，但她拥有敏锐的技术头脑，当她发言时，人们都会倾听。安静的背后，是她的坚持，这些年她将稳步走向OSAF管理层的中心。但目前她很高兴研究用户行为模式，探索 PIM 可以帮助人们避免繁琐的电话标签游戏的方法，并收集用户对其日历软件最常见的抱怨。

These were ambitious goals. Kapor began hiring developers. Katie Parlante, a studious Stanford-trained software developer who had spent the dot-com years at two boom-and-bust start-ups, was the first addition. Parlante had a reflective presence and an even keel, and she sometimes seemed to hang back from the fray of OSAF’s disputes, but she had a sharp technical mind, and when she did speak up, people listened. Behind her quietness, she was persevering, and over the years she would steadily move toward the center of OSAF’s management. But for now she was happily researching user behavior patterns, exploring ways a PIM could help people avoid the tedious game of telephone tag, and compiling the most common complaints users have about their calendar software.

Parlante 加入 OSAF 后不久，Kapor 聘请了一位名叫 John Anderson 的资深程序员作为 OSAF 的系统架构师。定义这个标题并不简单。有一次，我坐在军事软件承包商会议的宴会厅里，看到雷神公司的工程副总裁询问人群中有多少人认为自己是“系统架构师”。一半观众举起了手。另外三分之一的人认为自己是“系统工程师”。雷神公司高管随后要求他们定义“系统架构师”并将其与“系统工程师”区分开来。接下来是长时间的沉默，然后是一连串结结巴巴、不满意的回答。人群中有些人似乎受到了冒犯，仿佛这个问题本身就是无礼的。最后，一位与会者站起来，开始背诵 IEEE（电气和电子工程师协会）标准文件中的措辞，该文件的样板官僚语言仅强调了演讲者的观点：满屋子的专业人士的工作依赖于精确的规范，但他们无法组成一个完整的会议。也没有就自己的职称达成简单、明确的定义。

Shortly after Parlante joined OSAF, Kapor hired a veteran programmer named John Anderson as OSAF’s systems architect. Defining that title is not simple. I once sat in a banquet room at a conference for military software contractors and watched as Raytheon’s vice president of engineering asked the crowd how many considered themselves “systems architects.” Half the audience raised their hands. Another third identified themselves as “systems engineers.” The Raytheon exec then asked them to define “systems architect” and distinguish it from “systems engineer.” A long silence followed and then a series of faltering, unsatisfying stabs at an answer. Some in the crowd seemed affronted, as if the very question were impertinent. Finally, one attendee stood up and started reciting the verbiage from an IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) standards document, whose boilerplate bureaucratic language only underscored the speaker’s point: that a room filled with professionals whose work depended on precise specification could neither compose nor agree upon a simple, unambiguous definition of their own job titles.

在 OSAF，约翰·安德森 (John Anderson) 的系统架构师头衔意味着他主要负责选择程序员用来创建软件的构建块：他们应该使用哪种编程语言进行编码？他们应该使用什么工具来创建程序的图形界面——用户实际看到的窗口、菜单和对话框？他们应该使用什么样的软件技术来存储程序的数据？他们应该采用什么数据交换标准？有一千个选择要做，每个选择都有一系列令人眼花缭乱的选择。

At OSAF, John Anderson’s systems architect title meant that he held chief responsibility for choosing the building blocks that the programmers would use to create their software: Which programming language should they code in? What tools should they use to create the program’s graphical interface—the windows and menus and dialogue boxes that users would actually see? What kinds of software technologies should they use to store the program’s data? What standards for data exchange should they adopt? There were a thousand choices to make, and a bewildering array of options for each choice.

安德森拥有博士学位。拥有动物学博士学位和一生构建软件的经验，特别是针对 Macintosh 和 Next 平台的软件。他在 Next 的管理生涯给他留下了一些伤痕。“坦率地说，作为一名经理，我可能做得很糟糕。我真的不知道自己在做什么，”他现在说道。“但我学到了很多东西。过去，我总是认为最好的想法获胜，因为它是最好的想法。我意识到，实际上存在政治。不管你信不信，这都是一种全新的体验。” 最近，他成为了一位备受推崇的独立顾问，空降到有特别棘手技术问题的公司。“作为一名承包商有点像作为一个功能失调的家庭中的客人。结束后你就有机会离开，”他说。“当你真正成为组织的一部分时，你永远不会感受到所有的情感纠葛和拉锯战。我必须自己探索很多有趣的问题。”

Anderson has a Ph.D. in zoology and a lifetime’s experience building software, especially for the Macintosh and Next platforms. His management stint at Next had left him with some bruises. “Frankly, I probably did kind of a bad job as a manager. I didn’t really know what I was doing,” he now says. “But I learned a lot. In the past, I always thought the best idea won because it was the best idea. And what I realized was, there’s actually politics. Believe it or not, that was a new experience.” Most recently he had become a highly regarded independent consultant, parachuting into companies with particularly thorny technical problems. “Being a contractor is kind of like being a houseguest in a dysfunctional family. You get a chance to leave when it’s over,” he says. “And you never build up all those emotional tangles and tugs-of-war you feel when you’re really part of an organization. I got to explore a lot of interesting problems on my own.”

安德森习惯了稳定的合同工作流，但他在 2002 年初遇到了困难，当时互联网经济低迷席卷了科技行业的经济。他开始打电话给朋友，寻找线索。安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 向他介绍了 OSAF，他回忆道，“这是第一个项目，看起来和我自己做的项目一样有趣。那是在最有趣的阶段——一切都那么早，没有什么事情搞砸了。”
