Anderson was used to having a steady flow of contract work, but he hit a dry patch at the start of 2002, when the dot-com downturn cascaded through the tech-industry economy. He started calling friends, looking for leads. Andy Hertzfeld told him about OSAF, and, he recalls, “It was the first project that came along that seemed as fun as the project I was working on on my own. And it was at the funnest stage—everything was so early that nothing was screwed up.”





对于程序员来说，就像作家、艺术家以及所有从白纸开始工作的人一样，项目“最有趣”的时刻往往发生在最开始的时候，此时，令人眼花缭乱的可能性世界敞开着，在痛苦的妥协关闭任何可能性之前。门。

For programmers, just as for writers and artists and everyone whose work involves starting with a blank slate, the “funnest” time of a project often falls at the very beginning, when worlds of giddy possibility lie open, and before painful compromises have shut any doors.

弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯写道：“程序员就像诗人一样，他们的工作只是稍微脱离了纯粹的思想。” “他在空中建造他的城堡，从空中，通过发挥想象力进行创造。很少有创作媒介能如此灵活、如此容易打磨和返工、如此容易实现宏大的概念结构。”

“The programmer, like the poet, works only slightly removed from pure thought-stuff,” Frederick Brooks wrote. “He builds his castles in the air, from air, creating by exertion of the imagination. Few media of creation are so flexible, so easy to polish and rework, so readily capable of realizing grand conceptual structures.”

布鲁克斯的这段话与莎士比亚《仲夏夜之梦》中一些最著名的台词相呼应：

Brooks’s passage carries echoes of some of Shakespeare’s best-known lines from A Midsummer Night’s Dream:



疯子、情人和诗人

The lunatic, the lover, and the poet

都是想象中的紧凑。。。

Are of imagination all compact . . .

诗人的眼睛，在疯狂地滚动，

The poet’s eye, in a fine frenzy rolling,

从天上看向地上，从地上看向天堂；

Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven;

随着想象力的涌现

And as imagination bodies forth

未知事物的形式，诗人的笔

The forms of things unknown, the poet’s pen

将它们变成形状，并赋予空虚的虚无

Turns them to shapes, and gives to airy nothing

当地的居住地和名字。

A local habitation and a name.



这句话出自雅典公爵忒修斯之口，他将“疯子、情人和诗人”归为自己想象力飞翔的受害者。作为“冷静理性”的信徒，他鄙视他所描述的劳动——“沸腾的大脑”的“技巧”。

The words belong to Theseus, the Duke of Athens, who lumps together “the lunatic, the lover, and the poet” as victims of their own imagination’s flights. A devotee of “cool reason,” he’s contemptuous of the labor he describes—the “tricks” of “seething brains.”

但我们可能会以不同的方式听到他的话：它们提供了任何创造性工作在使想象成为现实的过程中需要什么的精确轮廓。程序确实“只是稍微脱离了纯粹的思想事物”，但它们不能保持思想事物，否则它们不会做任何事情。程序员必须从思想领域中获取一个想法，并将其体现在功能性的代码行中——为其分配计算机世界中的“本地栖息地和名称”。

But we may hear his words differently: They offer a precise outline of what any creative work requires in the process of making the imagined real. Programs are indeed “only slightly removed from pure thought-stuff,” but they cannot remain thought-stuff or they will not do anything. Programmers must take an idea from the realm of thought and embody it in functional lines of code—assigning it “local habitations and names” in the world of the computer.





20 世纪 50 年代和 60 年代最早的商用计算机的存储体是由称为铁氧体磁芯的绕线线圈构建的。从那时起，即使业界放弃了半导体芯片的电磁体，程序员仍将计算机的主动存储器称为“核心”。在许多系统中，当出现问题时，当机器由于不可调和的冲突或意外错误而死机时，就会出现“核心转储”——计算机会丢弃所有内容，停止运行，并吐出一个报告确切内容的文件它在失败时的记忆，为bug猎人提供了一堆可以挖掘的线索。

The memory banks of the earliest commercial computers, in the 1950s and ’60s, were built out of wound wire coils known as ferrite cores. Ever since, even as the industry abandoned electromagnets for semiconductor chips, programmers have referred to the computer’s active memory as “core.” In many systems, when something goes wrong, when the machine freezes up because of an irreconcilable conflict or unexpected error, there is a “core dump”—the computer drops everything, grinds to a halt, and spits out a file reporting the exact contents of its memory at the moment of failure, offering bug hunters a heap of clues to dig through.

核心是一个物理实体，而不仅仅是一个隐喻。它有当地的居住地和名称。您计算机的内存是大量实际位置（无论它们在当今的先进芯片中多么微观），并且这些位置都有名称和地址。在任何给定时刻，该存储器中的每个地址、每个位都将包含一个“1”或一个“0”；这是一个简单的开关，可以打开或关闭。计算机中发生的所有其他事情，无论是保存公司账簿还是运行《毁灭战士》死亡竞赛，都是建立在二进制基础上的——因为中央处理器芯片或 CPU 遵循程序员的指令，从内存中获取这些位，操纵它们，然后将它们放回去。

The core is a physical entity, not just a metaphor. It has local habitations and names. Your computer’s memory is a vast array of actual locations—however microscopic they may be in today’s advanced chips—and those locations have names and addresses. At any given instant each address in that memory, each bit, will contain a one or a zero; it is a simple switch, and it will be on or off. Everything else that happens in a computer, whether it is keeping a corporation’s books or running a Doom death-match, is built on that binary foundation—as the central processor chip, or CPU, following a programmer’s instructions, takes those bits from memory, manipulates them, and then puts them back.

软件不同；它没有核心。它就像洋葱一样，是一层层的东西，每一层都精心而不稳定地建立在前一层之上，每一层都指望下面的一层不会移动或改变太多。软件开发者喜欢谈论砌砖；怀疑论者看到的是纸牌屋。无论哪种方式，都会有稳定的积累。新的层堆积在旧的层上。

Software is different; it has no core. It is onionlike, a thing of layers, each built painstakingly and precariously on the previous one, each counting on the one below not to move or change too much. Software builders like to talk about laying bricks; skeptics see a house of cards. Either way, there’s a steady accumulation going on. New layers pile on old.

程序员将这些增加称为“抽象层”，因为每次添加新的层时，复杂和具体的东西就会被转化为更简单和更通用的东西。抽象一词源自拉丁语，意为抽离；这是该术语的计算机科学定义：“将多个较小的操作组合成一个可以通过名称引用的单元的过程。” 抽象从托儿所开始。当孩子们意识到如果他们想要一个苹果时，他们不必找到一个苹果来指着它，而只需说出所指的那个词，他们就会学到这一点。他们还了解到，抽象依赖于一种共同语言，依赖于对“苹果”这个词所指的对象类别的共同假设。

Programmers call these accretions “layers of abstraction,” because each time a new one is added, something complex and specific is being translated into something simpler and more general. The word abstraction comes from the Latin for draw away; here’s one computer science definition of the term: “The process of combining multiple smaller operations into a single unit that can be referred to by name.” Abstraction begins in the nursery. It is what children learn when they realize that if they want an apple, they don’t have to find one to point to but can simply say the word that refers to it. They also learn that abstraction depends on a common language, on shared assumptions of what class of objects the word apple refers to.

“这就是程序员所做的”，埃里克·辛克 (Eric Sink) 写道，他是一位程序员，他领导了 Web 浏览器的创建，该浏览器后来成为微软的 Internet Explorer。“我们构建了一堆抽象概念。我们设计自己的抽象，然后将它们堆放在我们从其他人那里获得的层之上。” 而且每年这些堆都越来越高。

“This is what programmers do,” wrote Eric Sink, a programmer who led the creation of the Web browser that became Microsoft’s Internet Explorer. “We build piles of abstractions. We design our own abstractions and then pile them up on top of layers we got from somebody else.” And every year the piles grow higher.





汇编语言位于堆的最底部，位于核心内存的顶部，它是半个世纪前发明的，旨在使程序员更容易手动操作核心的零和一。他们可以编写等效的汇编语言指令，而不是简单地编写大量二进制代码（例如 10110000 01100001），该指令使用名称如“mov”的命令，并为变量提供更容易记住的标签。您仍然用手推动钻头，但您有一些更容易抓住的手柄。

At the very bottom of the pile, sitting right on top of the core memory, is assembly language, invented half a century ago to make it easier for programmers to manipulate the core’s zeros and ones by hand. Instead of simply writing lots of binary code, like 10110000 01100001, they could write the equivalent assembly language instruction, which uses commands with names like “mov” and gives variables easier-to-remember labels. You’re still pushing bits around by hand, but you have some easier handles to grab.

对于大多数人来说，汇编语言很难学习，也很难编写。用程序员兼散文家 Ellen Ullman 的一句令人难忘的话说，它“接近机器”；如果它不在机器的头部内，它就会在机器的耳边低语。它的适应性也不是很强；每种类型的 CPU 都有不同的汇编语言，每次想要在不同品牌的计算机上运行代码时都需要重写代码。因此，过去的程序员开始添加更多的抽象层，每一层都离机器更远，更接近人类。

For most human beings assembly language is difficult to learn and arduous to write. In the memorable phrase of programmer-essayist Ellen Ullman, it’s “close to the machine”; if it’s not right inside the machine’s head, it’s whispering in its ear. It’s also not very adaptable; there’s a different assembly language for each type of CPU, requiring you to rewrite your code each time you want to run it on a different make of computer. So the programmers of yore started adding more layers of abstraction, with each layer moving a little further away from the machine and closer to the human being.

从 20 世纪 50 年代中期到 1960 年代中期的十年间，新编程语言出现了寒武纪大爆发，其中包括许多仍在使用或成为当今主力的祖先的语言：Lisp、Cobol、Algol、Basic。（从技术上讲，这些语言名称都是首字母缩略词，您经常会发现它们都是大写的，但我不会打扰您的眼睛。）第一个获得广泛使用的是 Fortran——“FORmula TRANslated system”的缩写。在 Fortran 中，繁琐的汇编语言过程序列被总结为简短的命令。人类程序员会编写一系列这些命令——源代码；然后，一种在计算机上运行的称为编译器的超级程序会将这些命令翻译成机器自己的语言的目标代码。

The decade from the mid-1950s to the mid-1960s saw a sort of Cambrian explosion of new programming languages, including many that are still in use or that became the ancestors of today’s workhorses: Lisp, Cobol, Algol, Basic. (These language names are technically all acronyms, and you’ll often find them in all upper case, but I’ll spare your eyes.) The very first to achieve wide use was Fortran—short for “FORmula TRANslating system.” In Fortran, laborious sequences of assembly language procedures were summarized in brief commands. The human programmer would write a sequence of these commands—source code; then a kind of uberprogram running on the computer called a compiler would translate those commands into object code in the machine’s own language.

就好像人们通过逐个字母地拼写每个单词来进行交流一样，突然间学会了如何用音节交谈。

It was as if people who had communicated by spelling out every word to one another, letter by letter, suddenly figured out how to talk in syllables.

这一飞跃是巨大的——如此之大以至于 Fortran 的推广者一开始认为他们并没有掌握多少先进的计算机编程技术，而是完全超越了它。他们写道，他们的发明将“几乎消除编码和调试”。他们将 Fortran 称为“自动编码系统”，因为它用相对更易读的命令序列（如 READ、ASSIGN、GOTO 和 STOP）取代了机器语言的不透明二进制代码或唯一更易于访问的汇编语言。Fortran 语言最初似乎提供了一幅乐土图景，在那里，让计算机屈服于人类愿望的艰苦斗争——正如 Fortran 发明者约翰·巴科斯 (John Backus) 描述的原始编码工作那样，“与机器肉搏战”——消失了，取而代之的是这是一个神奇的系统，它可以让人们用自己的语言直接向机器传达他们的需求。

The leap was vast—so vast that at first Fortran’s promoters believed they had not so much advanced computer programming as entirely transcended it. Their invention, they wrote, would “virtually eliminate coding and debugging.” They touted Fortran as an “automatic coding system,” since it replaced the opaque binary code of machine language or the only slightly more accessible assembly language with a relatively more readable sequence of commands like READ, ASSIGN, GOTO, and STOP. Fortran seemed at first to offer a view of a promised land where the hard struggle to bend computers to human wishes—“hand to hand combat with the machine,” as Fortran inventor John Backus described the work of primitive coding—vanished, replaced by the magic of a system that let people communicate their wants and needs directly to the machine, in their own language.

但就像接下来几十年的许多编程创新一样，它无法实现自己的梦想。最终，尽管 Fortran 具有独创性和实用性，但它解决了一组问题，却又引入了其他问题。在它推出后的十年内，整个编程领域都成为其自身成功的受害者，专家们聚集在国际秘密会议上，思考摆脱“软件危机”的出路。

But like so many innovations in programming over the following decades, it could not deliver on its dream. Ultimately, Fortran, for all its originality and utility, solved one set of problems only to introduce others. Within a decade of its introduction, the entire field of programming was the victim of its own success, and experts gathered in international conclaves to ponder a way out of “the Software Crisis.”





Fortran 繁荣的一个原因是它违背了专家的预测，即这种高级语言的代码将不可避免地比人类手工编写的机器代码运行得更慢。当你向上移动一层，离机器更远时，你要求计算机做更多的工作；使用 Fortran，您必须先通过编译器运行源代码，然后计算机才能运行您的程序。但一旦你这样做了，结果代码就会变得非常高效：事实证明，Fortran 编译器“自动”生成的程序与人们直接用机器或汇编语言编写的程序一样好。对于计算机科学家来说，这表明 Fortran 编译器具有惊人的效率，近乎美丽。事实证明，运行 Fortran 程序只需要花费一点额外的计算机时间，并且节省了更多的程序员时间。

One reason Fortran prospered was that it defied the experts’ prediction that the code of such a higher-level language would inevitably run more slowly than the handcrafted machine code composed by human beings. As you moved up the pile of layers, further from the machine, you asked the computer to do more work; with Fortran you had to run your source code through the compiler before the computer could run your program. But once you did, the resulting code turned out to be remarkably efficient: The programs that the Fortran compiler produced “automatically” proved just as good as the programs people coded directly in machine or assembly language. For computer scientists, that revealed the Fortran compiler to be a thing of marvelous efficiency, verging on beauty. It turned out to cost only a little extra computer time to run Fortran programs, and it saved a lot more programmer time.

在 Fortran 发明的时代，计算机时间是昂贵的。这些机器数量少，体积大，而且价格昂贵。但这种情况已经开始改变。大约在 Fortran 兴起的同时，1965 年，英特尔公司创始人戈登·摩尔 (Gordon Moore) 提出了他著名的定律，描绘了计算机硬件功能的快速增长：摩尔注意到，计算机芯片上可以安装的晶体管数量会增加呈指数增长，每一两年翻一番。尽管摩尔对确切的数字进行了几次调整，但要点从未改变。任何随着时间的推移定期翻倍的数字很快就会变得非常大。将每个芯片的晶体管数量加倍意味着您可以以两倍的速度或一半的成本处理计算机指令。由于这种现象，在摩尔观察之后的四十年里，你可以指望计算机硬件每年变得更快、更便宜。

In the era of Fortran’s invention, computer time was costly; the machines were few and big and fantastically expensive. But that was already beginning to change. At about the same time that Fortran was taking off, in 1965, Intel Corporation founder Gordon Moore propounded his celebrated law plotting the rapid growth in the power of computer hardware: The number of transistors you could pack on a computer chip, Moore noticed, increased exponentially, doubling every year or two. Although Moore tweaked the exact figure a couple of times, the essential point never varied. Any number that doubles regularly over time gets really big surprisingly soon. Doubling the number of transistors per chip meant you could process computer instructions twice as fast or at half the cost. Thanks to this phenomenon, throughout the four decades following Moore’s observation, you could count on computer hardware to get faster and cheaper every year.

对于程序员来说，这意味着年轻的计算习惯（当您必须微调或“优化”代码以使用尽可能少的内存和尽可能少的“周期”（处理器时间单位）时）不一定是最好的本能带到未来。多年来，当 Kapor 和 OSAF 开始他们的工作时，很明显处理器时间比程序员时间更便宜。许多严肃的软件开发人员——比如每一个字都很重要的作家，或者想尽一切办法利用尸体的厨师——仍然保持着节俭和纪律的美德。但当要在让计算机更努力地工作和让程序员更努力地工作之间进行权衡时（就像经常发生的那样），做出选择再容易不过了。

For programmers this meant that the habits of computing’s youth—when you had to fine-tune or “optimize” your code to use as little memory and as few “cycles” (units of processor time) as possible—were not necessarily the best instincts to carry into the future. Over the years, certainly by the time Kapor and OSAF began their work, it became clear that processor time was cheaper than programmer time. Many serious software developers—like writers who make every word count or cooks who find ways to use every last scrap of a carcass—still maintain the virtue of frugality and discipline. But when it comes down to a trade-off between making the computer work harder or making the programmer work harder, as it so often does, the choice couldn’t be easier to make.

那是因为软件不存在摩尔定律。芯片的容量每隔一两年就会增加一倍；我们的大脑没有。

That’s because there is no Moore’s Law for software. Chips may double in capacity every year or two; our brains don’t.





当 John Anderson、Andy Hertzfeld 和 Mitch Kapor 在 2002 年夏天坐下来选择 OSAF 将使用的编程语言时，他们不需要互相提醒这段历史。这是他们过去三十年在个人电脑行业经历的一部分。自 Fortran 发明以来的这些年里，出现了名副其实的编程语言 Babel，每种语言都有优点和缺点。有些更适合商业应用，有些更适合科学；有些适合快速而肮脏的工作，有些则适合实现宏伟的抱负。每种成功的语言都有其传播者骨干。他们之间的争论常常类似于宗教派别之间的裂痕，甚至利害攸关的问题也带有教义之争的味道。编程语言设计的中心冲突一直是弥尔顿困境，即自由意志和宿命之间的选择。例如：该语言是否应该赋予程序员直接进入计算机内存的能力，以及犯机器崩溃错误的自由？或者语言是否应该创建安全区域来限制出错的可能性——但代价是束缚程序员的双手？

When John Anderson, Andy Hertzfeld, and Mitch Kapor sat down in the summer of 2002 to select the programming language OSAF would use, they did not need to remind one another of this history. It was part of what they had experienced over the previous three decades in the personal computer industry. In the years since Fortran’s invention, a veritable Babel of programming languages had emerged, each with strengths and weaknesses. Some were better suited for business applications, others for science; some were good for quick and dirty jobs, others for fulfilling grand ambitions. Each successful language had its cadre of evangelists. The arguments between them often resembled rifts between religious sects, and even the issues at stake had the flavor of doctrinal disputes. The central conflicts in programming language design have always been Miltonic dilemmas, choices between free will and predestination. For instance: Should the language give programmers the power to poke directly into the computer’s memory—along with the freedom to make machine-crashing mistakes? Or should the language create zones of safety that limit the possibility of error—at the cost of tying the programmer’s hands?

对于 Vista 原型，赫茨菲尔德使用了一种名为 Python 的语言，该语言是由一位名叫 Guido van Rossum 的荷兰程序员于 20 世纪 80 年代末发明的，他以英国喜剧团 Monty Python 的飞行马戏团的名字命名了该语言。（Monty Python 打破形式的荒诞主义总是在计算机实验室中找到了一些最忠实的粉丝；我们将大量未经请求和不需要的电子邮件称为“垃圾邮件”，这要感谢互联网先驱者，他们试图为这种现象命名，他们回忆起一个 Python 例程，其中包含午餐菜单只提供各种“鸡蛋、香肠、垃圾邮件、垃圾邮件、垃圾邮件和垃圾邮件。”）

For the Vista prototype, Hertzfeld had used a language called Python, invented in the late 1980s by a Dutch programmer named Guido van Rossum who named it in honor of Monty Python’s Flying Circus, the British comedy troupe. (Monty Python’s form-smashing absurdism has always found some of its truest fans in computer labs; we call the flood of unsolicited and unwanted email “spam” thanks to the Internet pioneers who, looking to name the phenomenon, recalled a Python routine featuring a luncheonette menu offering nothing but variations on “eggs, sausage, spam, spam, spam, and spam.”)

Python 是一种解释型语言。编译语言提前通过编译器运行程序员的源代码，将其翻译成机器可读的二进制代码，而解释语言则在运行程序时执行该翻译。源代码由解释器逐行翻译并馈送到处理器执行。这使得解释型语言的效率降低，因为您总是同时运行两个程序，即您要使用的程序和解释器。但这也让他们变得更加灵活。程序员不必等待每个代码更改都通过编译器运行来查看其是否有效，并且程序可以灵活地动态响应更改。这就像在前往斯洛博维亚旅行时携带预翻译的旅游指南或携带人工翻译之间的区别。口译员会增加您的开销，但如果发生地震或叛乱，有斯洛博维亚专家在您身边会方便得多。

Python is an interpreted language. Where compiled languages run programmers’ source code through a compiler ahead of time to translate it into machine-readable binary code, interpreted languages perform that translation when you run the program. The source code gets translated line by line by the interpreter and fed to the processor for execution. This makes interpreted languages less efficient, since you’re always running two programs at once, the program you want to use and the interpreter. But it also makes them nimbler. The programmer doesn’t have to wait for each code change to be run through the compiler to see whether it worked, and the program has the flexibility to respond to changes on the fly. It’s like the difference between carrying a pretranslated guidebook on your trip to Slobovia or bringing along a human interpreter. Interpreters add a lot more to your overhead, but if there’s an earthquake or an insurrection, having that Slobovian expert at your elbow is going to be a lot handier.

像 Python 这样的解释性语言是许多软件开发人员所鄙视的对象，他们将它们视为“脚本语言”——用于编写短程序脚本的工具，对于快速编写一些实用代码很有用，但不足以完成严肃的工作。但到了 2002 年，Python 的拥护者开始挑战这个假设。

Interpreted languages like Python were the object of a certain disdain from many software developers, who viewed them as “scripting languages”—tools for cranking out short program scripts, useful for whipping up some quick utility code, inadequate for serious work. But by 2002, Python advocates were beginning to challenge that assumption.

安东尼·巴克斯特 (Anthony Baxter) 是一位尖刻的澳大利亚程序员，曾担任 Python 新版本的经理，他介绍了一个基于 Python 的互联网电话项目，并用一张幻灯片说道：“‘脚本语言’我闪亮的金属屁股！” （他是在向马特·格罗宁 (Matt Groening) 的《飞出个未来》系列中脾气暴躁的机器人本德 (Bender) 最喜欢的一句台词致敬。) 安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 也对 Python 赞不绝口。他喜欢说，使用 Python 的效率是使用 Java 的三倍，这反过来又使他的效率比使用 C 时高出三倍，C 是个人计算机行业或大学界大多数程序员使用的语言。已经咬牙切齿了。Python解释器本身是用C编写的；这使它成为另一层，一种更高级的语言，在阶梯上又迈了一步，离机器更远，更接近人类。

Anthony Baxter, an acerbic Australian programmer who served as a manager for new releases of Python, introduced talks about a Python-based Internet telephony project with a slide that read: “‘Scripting Language’ my shiny metal arse!” (He was paying homage to a favorite line of Bender, the grumpy robot in Matt Groening’s Futurama series.) Andy Hertzfeld, too, was singing Python’s praises. He liked to say that he was three times more productive using Python than using Java, which in turn had made him three times more productive than he’d been when he used C, the language most programmers in the personal computing industry or the university world had cut their teeth on. The Python interpreter itself is written in C; that makes it another layer, a higher-level language, one more step up the ladder, further from the machine and closer to the human being.

通常，使用 Python 等高级语言或其长期竞争对手 Perl 编写的代码可能比使用较低级别编写的代码更紧凑、更简洁；更多的东西被抽象了。Van Rossum 表示，Python 程序通常可以使用比 C 或 C++ 程序少三倍、五倍甚至十倍的代码来完成相同的任务。这不仅意味着程序员需要编写和输入的内容更少；而且 这意味着当程序员需要返回并添加新功能或修复错误时，他们可以更轻松地弄清楚代码的作用。“我确信单个程序员拥有一定数量的代码，他们可以在头脑中处理，或者在文件中轻松管理，”van Rossum 说。“代码量大致以代码行数表示，而不是代码实际执行的复杂性。因此，如果代码数量是原来的五倍，那么维护起来确实需要花费五倍的精力。”

Typically, code in higher-level languages like Python—or its longtime rival, Perl—can be tighter and less verbose than code written at a lower level; more stuff has been abstracted. Van Rossum says that a Python program can usually accomplish the same task as a C or C++ program using three, five, or even ten times less code. That doesn’t only mean that there’s less for a programmer to write and type; it means that when programmers need to go back and add a new feature or fix a bug, it’s easier for them to figure out what the code does. “I’m convinced that a single programmer has a certain amount of code that they can handle in their heads, or in a file, that they can comfortably manage,” van Rossum says. “And the amount of code is expressed roughly in lines of code, not in the complexity of what the code actually does. So if there’s five times as much code, then it really takes five times as much effort to maintain.”

尽管范罗苏姆为自己的语言选择了异想天开的名字，但他基本上是一个严肃的实用主义者。Monty Python 粉丝的精神很少渗透到他的谈话中，比如当他用一张传记幻灯片向程序员观众介绍自己时，上面写着：

Despite his whimsical choice of a name for his language, van Rossum is mostly a no-nonsense pragmatist. The spirit of the Monty Python fan slips into his conversation only rarely, as when he introduces himself to an audience of programmers with a biographical slide that reads:



4 岁：第一套乐高套件

Age 4: First Lego kit

10 岁：第一套电子设备

Age 10: first electronics kit

18 岁：第一个计算机程序（在打孔卡上）

Age 18: first computer program (on punched cards)

21 岁：第一个女朋友:-)

Age 21: First girlfriend:-)



正如狗常常与它们的主人相似一样，编程语言似乎最终以某种微妙的方式反映了它们的创造者的气质和个性。例如，语言学家拉里·沃尔（Larry Wall）是 Perl 之父，他是一个滑稽的人，热衷于语言和视觉双关语。在 2004 年的一次开源程序员秘密会议上，他对 Perl 新开发进行了年度回顾，他找到了一种方法，将对屏幕保护程序不断变化的视觉几何形状的思考与他最近与胃肿瘤的斗争联系起来，然后将这一切联系起来以及 Perl 程序员社区“为彼此表演随机的美丽行为”的愿景。

Just as dogs often come to resemble their owners, it seems that programming languages end up reflecting the temperaments and personalities of their creators in some subtle ways. For instance, Larry Wall, the linguist who is the father of Perl, is a droll spirit enamored of verbal and visual puns. At a conclave for open source programmers in 2004, delivering an annual review of new Perl developments, he found a way to connect a meditation on the mutating visual geometries of screensavers with an account of his recent battle with a stomach tumor, then tied it all together with a vision of the community of Perl programmers “performing random acts of beauty for each other.”

因此，得知 Perl 本身是一种最重视表达灵活性的语言就不足为奇了。它的口号之一是“有不止一种方法可以做到这一点。” （喜欢缩写的程序员，又添加了一层抽象，将其归结为 TMTOWTDI。）那些不太喜欢 Perl 的人认为，Perl 提供的以多种方式实现相同结果的自由也使程序员更难阅读 Perl 的内容。另一个人的代码。van Rossum 说，对于 Python，它就是 TOOWTDI：只有一种方法可以做到这一点。在一位观察者对这两种语言的支持者的描述中，珍珠岩是“混乱/好骗子的原型”，而“Python支持者是和平的，戴着小绳子的眼镜类型，就像霍比特人或荷兰人一样。”

So it’s no surprise to learn that Perl itself is a language that prizes flexibility of expression above all; one of its slogans is “There’s more than one way to do it.” (Acronym-happy programmers, adding one more layer of abstraction, boil this down to TMTOWTDI.) Those less in love with Perl argue that the freedom it offers to achieve the same result any number of ways also makes it harder for programmers to read one another’s code. With Python, van Rossum says, it’s TOOWTDI: There’s only one way to do it. In one observer’s characterization of the two languages’ partisans, Perlites are “chaotic/good trickster archetypes” where “Pythonistas are peaceful, have-their-glasses-on-a-little-string types, like hobbits or the Dutch.”

Perl 和 Python 群体多年来一直保持着激烈的竞争，但他们对相对性能和偶尔爆发的扔馅饼的赌注更多的是有趣而不是痛苦。范罗森和沃尔在 20 世纪 90 年代中期第一次见面。“Perl 和 Python 社区已经发生了冲突，但 Larry 和我相处得很好，”van Rossum 说。“我们都没有特别关心或担心如果另一种语言‘获胜’会发生什么。我们俩都没有为胜利投入太多的自我。我们没有进行那种比赛。”

The Perl and Python crowds have kept up a heated rivalry for years, but their bets about relative performance and occasional outbreaks of pie-throwing are more playful than bitter. Van Rossum and Wall met for the first time in the mid-1990s. “The Perl and Python communities were already head-butting, but Larry and I got along just fine,” van Rossum says. “Neither of us was particularly concerned or worried about what would happen if the other language would ‘win.’ Neither of us had much ego invested in winning. We didn’t do that kind of competition.”

Perl 和 Python 之类的语言在 20 世纪 90 年代后期的互联网繁荣时期崭露头角，当时面临紧迫期限的公司转向这些“脚本语言”作为“粘合代码”或“胶带”，将 Web 服务器和数据库捆绑在一起正常运作的网站。但他们仍然被认为是轻量级的。例如，一些程序员对 Python 对空格的使用嗤之以鼻：许多语言使用括号或其他符号来标记离散的代码块，而 Python 只是使用缩进。这使得 Python 代码对程序员来说很容易理解，但它也可能很脆弱，因为当您将代码从一个操作系统移动到另一个操作系统时，缩进往往会在电子邮件中消失或发生变化。

Languages like Perl and Python came into their own during the Internet boom of the later 1990s, when companies faced with tight deadlines turned to these “scripting languages” as the “glue code” or “duct tape” to strap Web servers and databases together into functioning Web sites. But they were still considered lightweights. Some programmers, for instance, turn up their noses at Python’s use of white space: Where many languages use brackets or other symbols to mark off discrete blocks of code, Python simply uses indents. That makes Python code easy on a programmer’s eyes, but it can also be fragile, since indents tend to vanish in email or change when you move code from one operating system to another.

Python 引起批评者嗤之以鼻的另一个方面是其“输入”变量的方法的相对深奥的问题。编程变量与我们代数教室黑板上的那些 x 和 y 类似，但不完全相同：它们是数据的占位符，是计算机内存中插槽的名称，这些插槽将填充用户输入的信息（或者程序本身的另一部分将输出）。例如，当您在银行程序中输入起始余额时，程序会将其分配给名称为“余额”的变量。开始. 程序会在某个时刻为该变量分配一个值，也许是通过询问您。然后，它将该值存储在计算机的内存中，并在下次程序代码引用余额时。开始，计算机将检索该值。

Another aspect of Python that caused critics to sniff was the relatively esoteric question of its approach to “typing” variables. Programming variables are similar to, but not exactly the same as, those x’s and y’s that filled the blackboards of our algebra classrooms: They are placeholders for data, names for slots in the computer’s memory that will be filled with information a user will input (or another part of the program itself will output). When you type in your starting balance in a banking program, for instance, the program assigns it to a variable with a name like balance. starting. The program assigns that variable a value at some point, maybe by asking you. It then stores the value in the computer’s memory, and the next time the program code refers to balance. starting, the computer will retrieve that value.

有些编程语言的设计相对严格，要求程序员在创建新变量时提前声明它是什么类型：简单整数？浮点数十进制数？包含任何类型字符的字母数字字符串？其他语言则更为宽松。当源代码通过编译器运行时，某些语言会在编译时强制执行这些规则；其他人直到运行时（程序执行时）才会强制执行它们。术语“静态类型”和“动态类型”以及“强类型”和“弱类型”描述了这些方法，但它们的使用含糊不清并且被广泛误解。可以说，它们本身就是弱类型的。一位名叫本杰明·皮尔斯 (Benjamin Pierce) 的计算机科学家是有关该主题的整本书的作者，他曾经写道：“我花了几周的时间试图整理强类型、静态类型、安全类型等术语，结果令人惊讶地发现难的。这些术语的用法多种多样，以至于几乎毫无用处。”

Some programming languages are designed to be relatively strict about requiring programmers, when they create a new variable, to declare in advance what type it is: A simple integer? A floating point decimal number? An alphanumeric string containing any kind of character? Other languages are more permissive. Some languages enforce these rules at compile time, when the source code is run through the compiler; others don’t enforce them until run time, when the program is executed. The terms static and dynamic typing, and strong typing and weak typing, describe these approaches, but they are ambiguously used and widely misunderstood; they are themselves, as it were, weakly typed. A computer scientist named Benjamin Pierce, who is the author of whole books on the subject, once wrote, “I spent a few weeks trying to sort out the terminology of strongly typed, statically typed, safe typed, etc., and found it amazingly difficult. The usage of these terms is so various as to render them almost useless.”

尽管或可能由于这种混乱，程序员的邮件列表和论坛上充斥着关于该主题的激烈争论。这些区别看似小事，但在代码领域，它们是准宗教战争的内容。Python 的批评者对 Python 相对宽松的打字方式嗤之以鼻。该语言的支持者认为，与竞争对手相比，它在这一领域的权衡更加明智。不管怎样，它的解释性质确保了它会被许多人认为是一种不太严肃的语言。但在其他几个主要方面，Python 更类似于工业级语言，而不是与之混在一起的脚本语言。首先，它提供了“垃圾收集”：当为每个变量声明内存空间的程序不再需要该空间时，Python 就像 Java 和其他近代语言一样，负责释放它。（许多较旧的语言要求您手动管理内存，从而将程序员变成了为内存提供临时信息的房客的酒店服务员。）此外，Python 与 Java 和 C++ 一样，是“面向对象的”。

Despite or perhaps because of this confusion, programmers’ mailing lists and forums are overloaded with heated arguments on the subject. These distinctions may seem a small matter, but in the land of code they are the stuff of quasi-religious war. Python’s detractors looked down their noses at what they view as its relative laxity on typing; the language’s partisans argued that it makes the trade-offs in this area more intelligently than its competitors. Either way, its interpreted nature ensured that it would be considered a less serious language by many. But in a couple of other major respects, Python more closely resembles industrial-strength languages than the scripting languages with which it got lumped. First, it provided “garbage collection”: When the program, which claims a space in memory for each variable, no longer needs the space, Python, like Java and other languages of recent vintage, takes care of freeing it up. (Many older languages required you to manage memory by hand, turning the programmer into a sort of hotel clerk for the memory’s temporary informational lodgers.) Also, Python, like Java and C++, was “object oriented.”

面向对象编程：与任何其他超出程序员封闭世界的神秘术语相比，这个术语更难以清晰明了并引发误解。即使在阅读了有关该主题的数百页、与专家讨论并参加了有关该主题的许多冗长讲座之后，我也不能百分百自信地说我自己对这个短语的解释会让每个读者满意。尽管如此，这里还是要说一下：面向对象的技术不是围绕连续的命令行来组织程序，而是围绕称为对象的代码块来组织程序，当其他对象调用它们时，这些代码块就会启动并执行操作。对象通过严格定义的输入和输出与其他对象相关，因此编写必须与它们交互的代码的程序员不需要关心它们内部发生的事情。面向对象编程为该领域引入了全新的词汇。软件对象通过发送“消息”和触发“事件”来相互交互。通常，对象可以被组织成共享特征的“类”，并且它们可以从其“父母”继承特征。（这个术语有时会给面向对象编程的讨论带来马克思主义理论与遗传科学的奇怪联系。）

Object-oriented programming: More than any other of the arcane terms that have migrated beyond the closed world of the programmer, this one has resisted clarity and invited misunderstanding. Even after reading hundreds of pages on the subject, discussing it with experts, and attending a number of lengthy lectures on the topic, I cannot say with 100 percent confidence that my own explanation of the phrase will satisfy every reader. Still, here goes: Object-oriented techniques organize programs not around sequential lines of commands but instead around chunks of code called objects that spring to life and action when other objects call on them. Objects relate to other objects via strictly defined inputs and outputs, so that programmers writing code that must interact with them need not concern themselves with what’s happening inside them. Object-oriented programming introduced a whole new vocabulary to the field. Software objects interact with one another by sending “messages” and triggering “events.” Typically, objects can be organized into “classes” that share traits, and they can inherit characteristics from their “parents.” (This terminology sometimes gives discussions of object-oriented programming the strange ring of Marxist theory cut with genetic science.)

面向对象编程的历史可以追溯到 20 世纪 60 年代，但直到 20 世纪 80 年代末，这种方法才席卷市场，当时程序员开始从命令行界面的顺序世界（一种真正的线性环境）中转移出来。用户与计算机的交互逐行进行——导致图形界面的无政府状态，用户可以随时单击任何地方（“启动一个事件”），而程序就像一个细心的守门员，最好是准备好。面向对象编程的原理看起来像是管理这个混乱世界的理想工具。

The history of object-oriented programming stretches back to the 1960s, but the approach didn’t sweep the market until the late 1980s, when programmers began to move from the sequential world of the command-line interface—a literally linear environment, in which the user’s interaction with the computer happened line by typed line—to the anarchy of the graphical interface, in which the user might click anywhere (“initiate an event”) at any moment, and the program, like an attentive goalie, had better be ready. The principles of object-oriented programming looked like an ideal tool for managing this chaotic world.

在这股热潮达到顶峰之前，技术媒体已经抓住了对象的概念，并将其过度简化为简单地表示“可重用的代码片段”。软件对象（如 Fortran 和许多其他先前的创新）将改变一切，将编程本身从一项艰巨的任务简化为从库​​中借用组件的简单苦差事。但在实践中，尽管面向对象的方法在程序员构建更加复杂的代码大厦时为他们提供了帮助，但它并没有为营销人员的乌托邦开辟道路，让程序​​员可以编写一次组件并在任何地方重用它们。周围有越来越多的代码：对象、函数和模块的库，越来越多地在开源许可下可用，这意味着您可以免费修改它们并合并它们。着手大型新项目的程序员可以站在更高的巨人的肩膀上。但他们仍然必须决定要去哪里。

Before the fad peaked, the technology press had latched onto the notion of objects and oversimplified it to mean, simply, “bits of reusable code.” Software objects—like Fortran and so many other previous innovations—would change everything, reducing programming itself from a monumental undertaking to a simple chore of borrowing components from libraries. But in practice, though the object-oriented approach gave programmers a leg up as they constructed ever more complex edifices of code, it did not open a road to the marketers’ utopia where programmers could write components once and reuse them anywhere. There was more and more code around: libraries of objects and functions and modules, increasingly available under open source licenses that meant you could tinker with them and incorporate them for free. Programmers setting out on big new projects could stand on the shoulders of ever taller giants. But they still had to decide where they wanted to go.

正如弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯 (Frederick Brooks) 在他的《没有灵丹妙药》一文中所说：“构建软件系统最困难的部分是准确地决定构建什么。”

As Frederick Brooks put it in his “No Silver Bullet” essay: “The hardest single part of building a software system is deciding precisely what to build.”





Python 对 Kapor 和公司的吸引力有很多原因。就像他们想要构建的程序一样，它是开源和跨平台的（相同的 Python 程序可以在 Windows、Macintosh 和 Linux 计算机上运行）。Python 的一些较新的替代品有其吸引力——由日本程序员发明的 Ruby 赢得了很多关注——但 Python 拥有成熟的优势。这不仅意味着它很久以前就消除了许多错误并简化了性能，而且还意味着程序员已经为其构建了大量工具 - 新层和帮助程序，以便 OSAF 编码人员不必从头开始。正如 Python 爱好者喜欢说的那样，该语言“自带电池”。Python 在开发人员时间和机器时间之间进行权衡，这意味着它肯定不如其他一些语言那么快，但它允许您找到代码中的瓶颈并对其进行优化。您可以下拉“更接近机器”，用 C 语言重写那些限制性能的部分，并获得两全其美的效果。Python 爱好者们对“Guido 的时间机器”充满敬畏：似乎常常，当程序员抱怨 Python 中的某个特定缺点时，van Rossum 指出该语言的最新更新已经解决了该问题，从而引发了开玩笑说他能够回到过去修复他的创作。

Python appealed to Kapor and company for many reasons. Like the program they aimed to build, it was open source and cross-platform (the same Python program could run on Windows, Macintosh, and Linux computers). Some newer alternatives to Python had their allure—one called Ruby, invented by a Japanese programmer, was winning a lot of attention—but Python had the advantage of maturity. This meant not only that it had long ago ironed out many bugs and streamlined its performance, but also that programmers had built piles of tools for it—new layers and helper programs so that the OSAF coders wouldn’t have to start from scratch. As Python devotees liked to put it, the language came with “batteries included.” Python’s trade-offs between developer time and machine time meant that it was certainly not as fast as some other languages, but it allowed you to find bottlenecks in the code and optimize them. You could drop down “closer to the machine,” rewrite those performance-limiting sections in the C language, and get the best of both worlds. And Python enthusiasts talked with awe of “Guido’s time machine”: It seems that often, when programmers complain of a particular shortcoming in Python, van Rossum points out that the most recent update of the language has already solved the problem—giving rise to the joke that he’s able to travel backward in time to fix his creation.

技术行业的每一个决定都有一个安全的选择——这就是一句老话的体现：“没有人会因为购买 IBM 而被解雇”。OSAF “没有人被解雇”的编程语言选择是 Java。它满足了 Kapor 团队已经确定的许多需求：它是跨平台的、面向对象的；商务人士对此感到满意；程序员很清楚这一点。但它并不是真正的开源软件（Sun Microsystems 拥有它），Kapor 在 Java 中构建现代版本的 Agenda 的经验让他怀疑它能否构建他梦想的那种漂亮、直观的图形用户界面。

For every decision in the technology industry there is a safe choice—an embodiment of the old saying, “Nobody ever got fired for buying IBM.” The “no one ever got fired” choice of programming language for OSAF would have been Java. It satisfied many of the needs that Kapor’s team had identified: It was cross-platform and object-oriented; business people were comfortable with it; and programmers knew it well. But it was not truly open source (Sun Microsystems owned it), and Kapor’s experience building a modern version of Agenda in Java left him doubtful that it could build the sort of beautiful, intuitive graphical user interface he dreamed of.

Python 在这方面也并不完美。John Anderson 和 Katie Parlante 回顾了许多被称为 GUI 构建器的 Python 跨平台工具包——用于构建窗口、菜单、按钮和所有其他屏幕“小部件”的组件集，使 Python 程序在 Windows 屏幕上栩栩如生， Macintosh 和 Linux 用户。其中之一，wxWidgets/wxPython，脱颖而出（最初名为wxWindows，该项目放弃了Windows标签，以避免与微软发生法律纠纷）。Wx 还没有完全实现——Macintosh 工具尤其不发达——但是只要多一点努力和时间，Anderson 相信它会为 OSAF 工作。

Python wasn’t perfect in this regard, either. John Anderson and Katie Parlante reviewed a number of cross-platform toolkits for Python known as GUI builders—sets of components for building windows, menus, buttons, and all the other onscreen “widgets” to bring a Python program to life onscreen for Windows, Macintosh, and Linux users. One of them, wxWidgets/wxPython, stood out (originally named wxWindows, the project dropped the Windows label to avoid a legal dispute with Microsoft). Wx wasn’t quite there yet—the Macintosh tools were especially underdeveloped—but with a little more effort and time, Anderson believed it would work for OSAF.

作为替代方案，开发人员简要考虑了使用 Mozilla 项目构建的工具，该项目是在 Netscape 的基础上构建的开源 Web 浏览器。Mozilla 拥有适用于所有三个操作系统平台的 GUI 构建技术，并且经过了几年的开发。但它并没有像 wxWidgets 那样走得那么远，Kapor 的程序员试图展望一两年的前景并猜测在哪里下注，担心它可能不会像他们需要的那样发展得那么快。他们还担心使用 Mozilla 工具构建的程序对于他们计划支持的不同操作系统平台的用户来说不会感觉“原生”；菜单、对话框和窗口可能看起来很奇怪并且行为异常。

As as alternative, the developers briefly considered using tools built by the Mozilla project, the open source Web browser built on Netscape’s remains. Mozilla had GUI-building technology that worked well across all three operating system platforms and had a few years of development under its belt. But it wasn’t as far along as wxWidgets, and Kapor’s programmers, trying to peer one or two years out on the horizon and guess where to place their bets, worried that it might not develop as quickly as they needed. They also worried that programs built using Mozilla’s tools wouldn’t feel “native” to users of the different operating system platforms they planned to support; the menus and dialog boxes and windows might look odd and behave unexpectedly.

卡普尔、安德森和他们的同事还简要考虑了一种更激进的替代方案来解决他们的跨平台问题。是否可以选择将他们的程序完全构建为基于 Web 的服务，这种服务不需要单独的客户端程序，而只需搭载在 Web 浏览器上？长期以来，此类程序一直被认为是琐事或玩具，但到 2002 年，软件行业的领导者开始认识到它们的优势。他们意味着用户可以将数据保存在某个地方的服务器上，并根据需要将其调用到他们在家中、办公室或路上使用的任何计算机上。

Kapor, Anderson, and their colleagues also briefly considered a more radical alternative to solving their cross-platform problem. What about the option of building their program entirely as a Web-based service, one that didn’t need a separate client program but simply piggy-backed on the Web browser? Such programs had long been considered trifles or toys, but by 2002, software industry leaders were beginning to warm to their advantages. They meant that users could keep their data up on a server somewhere and call it down as needed to any computer they might be working on at home, at the office, or on the road.

Kapor 了解所有这些论点并仔细考虑了它们，但最终他觉得你无法提供他的程序将提供的那种丰富的交互，即从 Web 浏览器内的“议程的灵魂”继承的灵活性。无论如何，还没有。你能做的事情有太多限制——你在屏幕上操纵和拖动东西的容易程度以及数据在窗口中更新的速度有多快。

Kapor knew all those arguments and considered them carefully, but in the end he felt that you just couldn’t provide the kind of rich interaction his program would offer, the flexibility inherited from the “soul of Agenda,” inside a Web browser. Not yet, anyway. There were too many limits on what you could do—on how easily you could manipulate and drag stuff on screen and how quickly data would update in a window.

基于网络的程序感觉很笨重，而笨重是卡普尔最不希望任何人与他的作品联系在一起的词。

Web-based programs just felt clunky, and clunky was the last word Kapor would ever want anyone to associate with his work.





由于有如此多的可用选项，软件项目对编程语言的选择通常可以归结为任意或不可言喻的——这是品味、习惯或直觉的问题。程序员兼散文家 Paul Graham 写道，一些程序员喜欢 Python 仅仅是因为他们喜欢它的外观，这并不是一个不合理的标准：“当你编程时，你花更多的时间阅读代码而不是编写代码。您可以像雕塑家制作粘土块一样推动源代码块。因此，一种使源代码变得丑陋的语言对于一个严格的程序员来说是令人发狂的，就像充满肿块的粘土对于雕塑家来说是令人发狂的一样。”

With so many options available, a software project’s choice of programming language often comes down to the arbitrary or the ineffable—a matter of taste or habit or gut sense. Programmer-essayist Paul Graham wrote that some coders favor Python simply because they like the way it looks—and that that’s not such an unreasonable criterion: “When you program, you spend more time reading code than writing it. You push blobs of source code around the way a sculptor does blobs of clay. So a language that makes source code ugly is maddening to an exacting programmer, as clay full of lumps would be to a sculptor.”

尽管这是一种信仰上的飞跃——你不应该使用脚本语言作为雄心勃勃的桌面软件应用程序的基础！——Kapor、Anderson 和他们的团队最终选择了 Python。感觉不错。这是对速度的赌注——语言本身将为 OSAF 程序员提供额外的速度，摩尔定律将为最终产品用户的机器提供额外的速度，以弥补 Python 本身可能带来的任何迟缓。

Although it was something of a leap of faith—you just weren’t supposed to use a scripting language as the basis for an ambitious desktop software application!—Kapor, Anderson, and their team finally settled on Python. It felt right. And it was a bet on speed—the extra speed the language itself would lend OSAF programmers, and the additional speed Moore’s Law would grant the machines of the eventual product’s users, to make up for any sluggishness it might derive from Python itself.

OSAF 的每个人都关心速度，因为 2002 年的大部分时间里进展都停滞不前。一旦更大规模的架构讨论开始，赫茨菲尔德就不再向 Vista 原型添加新功能，而是开始勾画新产品的地址簿或“联系人管理器”的外观。Parlante 已经从用户研究转向日历原型设计。Morgen Sagen 已经开始为名为 Hardhat 的项目创建一个自动构建系统，这是一个代码框架，可以帮助开发人员在进行更改后重新组装程序的构建块。每个人都渴望开始编写代码。

Speed was on everyone’s mind at OSAF, because progress through much of 2002 was halting. Hertzfeld, who had quit adding new features to the Vista prototype once the bigger architectural discussions kicked in, was beginning to sketch out what an address book or “contacts manager” for the new product might look like. Parlante had moved from user research into prototyping a calendar. Morgen Sagen had begun to create an automated build system for the project named Hardhat, a framework of code that would help the developers reassemble the program’s building blocks after they made changes. Everyone was itching to start writing code.

但到了秋天，OSAF 仍处于隐身模式。卡普尔是一位公众人物；硅谷的小道消息已经传开，说他在搞什么阴谋，但到底是什么，仍然是个谜。卡普尔不愿意在没有可行产品的情况下发布一个引起轰动的公告。那是典型的“蒸汽软件”，他在八十年代末期与他的公司 On Technology 一起走上了这条道路；它在由一位 Macintosh 专栏作家策划的 Vaporware 名人堂中获得了可疑的荣誉。另一方面，如果你打算创建开源软件，你就不能秘密地进行；你的项目需要公开，让感兴趣的志愿者可以找到它。当卡普尔的朋友、当时广受尊敬的《圣何塞水星报》科技专栏作家丹·吉尔莫 (Dan Gillmor) 敦促他上市时，他起初拒绝了，然后认为这将是一件好事，是让 OSAF 启动的“强制功能”，并且解决围绕该项目的一些挥之不去的不确定性。就像产品的名字一样。

But by the fall, OSAF was still in stealth mode. Kapor was a public figure; rumors had spread along the Silicon Valley grapevine that he was up to something, but what, exactly, remained a mystery. Kapor was loath to make a big-splash announcement without having a working product. That was classic “vaporware,” and he’d been down that road with his company On Technology in the late eighties; it had the dubious honor of a place in the Vaporware Hall of Fame curated by a Macintosh columnist. On the other hand, if you intended to create open source software, you couldn’t do it in secret; your project needed to be out in the open where interested volunteers could find it. When Kapor’s friend Dan Gillmor, then a widely respected technology columnist for the San Jose Mercury News, pushed him to go public, he resisted at first and then decided it would be a good thing, a “forcing function” to get OSAF in gear and resolve some of the lingering uncertainties surrounding the project. Like the product’s name.

软件行业有着为正在开发的产品使用代号的悠久传统。在业务的商业端，程序员通常选择这些占位符名称；随后，营销人员选择了最终的“运输”名称。在开源世界中，程序员通常有第一个和最后一个词，这就是为什么这么多开源产品的名称都是难以发音的技术双关语、深奥的参考资料或内部笑话。（Apache 是世界上使用最广泛的 Web 服务器的名称，这是一个双关语，意思是它是如何以零散或不完整的方式发展的。然后还有 Mozilla、Knoppix 和 Blojsom 等名称。）一般来说，知名度越高项目越大，在选择代号时就越要小心。微软在 2001 年认识到了这一点，当时 Hailstorm（该系统的暂称，该系统可以储存大量用户个人信息）成为批评者手中的大棒。

The software industry has a long tradition of using code names for products under development. In the commercial end of the business, the programmers typically choose these placeholder names; later, the marketers pick a final, “shipping” name. In the open source world, the programmers usually have the first and last words, which is why so many open source products have names that are unpronounceable technical puns, abstruse references, or inside jokes. (Apache, the name of the world’s most widely used Web server, is a pun based on how it grew in a piecemeal, or patchy, way. Then there are names like Mozilla, Knoppix, and Blojsom.) In general, the higher profile the project, the more care you have to take in picking a code name. Microsoft learned this in 2001 when Hailstorm, its working name for a system that would enable the stockpiling of troves of users’ personal information, became a cudgel in the hands of critics.

卡普尔不想浪费大量时间在 OSAF 项目的代号上争论不休，他设法一直推迟这个选择。与此同时，Morgen Sagen 正在为 OSAF 的工作构建一个在线家园，一种称为 CVS（并发版本系统）存储库的代码巢穴，允许开发人员“签出”代码块以对其进行处理，“签入”更改，并跟踪发生的一切。像 CVS 这样的版本跟踪系统使得分散在各地的程序员能够同时在同一个代码库上工作，而不会互相干扰。他们使开源开发成为可能。9 月的一天，Sagen 去 Kapor 说，为了建立 OSAF 的 CVS 存储库，他需要为新项目的文件目录命名。卡普尔思考了几秒钟，然后说道：“就叫钱德勒吧。”

Kapor didn’t want to waste a lot of time wrangling over the code name for OSAF’s project, and he managed to keep putting off the choice. Meanwhile, Morgen Sagen was building an online home for OSAF’s work, a kind of nest for code called a CVS (for Concurrent Versions System) repository that allows developers to “check out” chunks of code to work on them, “check in” changes, and track everything that happens. Version tracking systems like CVS had made it possible for far-flung groups of programmers to work simultaneously on the same code base without stepping on one another’s toes; they had made open source development possible. One day in September, Sagen went to Kapor and said that in order to set up OSAF’s CVS repository, he needed a name for the file directories for the new project. Kapor took a few seconds to think and then said, “Call it Chandler.”

“我喜欢读钱德勒悬疑小说。我一直在重读一些，”他后来解释道。采用一位神秘作家的名字意味着其他人的名字——哈米特？克里斯蒂？——可以为未来的 OSAF 项目起草。文学名称也具有与通常的技术术语不同的声望。以一位经典悬疑小说家的名字命名这个项目，也是对这个项目迄今为止的秘密状态的一种戏谑的认可。

“I like reading Chandler mysteries. I’d been rereading some,” he later explained. Adopting one mystery author’s name meant that others—Hammett? Christie?—could be drafted for future OSAF projects. A literary name, too, had a different sort of cachet than the usual techno-jargon. And naming the program for a classic mystery novelist would also playfully nod to the project’s till-then surreptitious status.

萨根担心大多数人不会想到这位小说家，而是想到电视剧《老友记》中的同名角色。但他并没有提出反对意见。钱德勒就是这样。

Sagen worried that most people wouldn’t think of the novelist but of the character from the television series Friends who had the same name. But he didn’t push his objection. Chandler it would be.





2002年10月20日，吉尔莫的水星新闻专栏向全世界介绍了钱德勒。OSAF 同时开设了一个网站，卡普尔开始撰写个人博客来记录该项目。正如卡普尔所希望的那样，上市确实迫使 OSAF 更清楚地说明钱德勒到底要做什么，将其模糊的愿望细化为硅谷倡导者所说的“电梯推销”——如果你碰巧遇到这种情况，你会脱口而出的简洁解释。幸运的是，你可以与一些你想赢得的资助者或专家一起乘坐电梯。Chandler 将成为一名跨平台、开源、点对点个人信息管理器 (PIM)，重点关注电子邮件和日历 — 所有这些都融入了 Lotus Agenda 的动态精神。这不完全是一个简单的原声摘要；而是一个简单的原声摘要。那个电梯最好有一些楼层可以行驶。但这足以让注意到这一消息的软件爱好者和开源爱好者兴奋不已。

On October 20, 2002, Gillmor’s Mercury News column introduced Chandler to the world. OSAF simultaneously opened a Web site, and Kapor began writing a personal blog to chronicle the project. As Kapor had hoped, going public did force OSAF to specify more clearly what exactly Chandler was going to be, refining its vague aspirations into what Silicon Valley initiates called an “elevator pitch”—the pithy explanation you’d blurt out if you happened to luck into an elevator ride with some funder or pundit you wanted to win over. Chandler would be a cross-platform, open source, peer-to-peer personal information manager (or PIM) with a heavy focus on email and calendars—all infused with the dynamic spirit of Lotus Agenda. It was not exactly a simple sound bite; that elevator had better have some floors to travel. But it was enough to excite the software enthusiasts and open source devotees who noticed the announcement.

米奇·卡普尔（Mitch Kapor）正在开发一款创新的“人际信息管理器”的消息震惊了极客们。从 Gillmor 的第一篇文章开始，新闻报道的范围不断扩大，其中包括来自 Slashdot 的链接，Slashdot 是网络上流量最大、最吵闹的程序员虚拟聚会场所。数百名外部人士在 OSAF 新公开的邮件列表中发表了他们的观点和愿望。大多数信件属于以下类别：

The word that Mitch Kapor was working on an innovative new “interpersonal information manager” hit the geek street with a jolt. Press coverage spread out in widening circles from Gillmor’s initial piece, including a link from Slashdot, the Web’s best trafficked and noisiest virtual hangout for programmers. Hundreds of outsiders posted their views and wishes to OSAF’s newly public mailing lists. Most of the missives fell into these categories:



我立即需要钱德勒。它在哪里？你的意思是你还没写？

I need Chandler immediately. Where is it? You mean you haven’t written it yet?

为什么不使用[这个或那个特定的]开源项目作为 Chandler [这个或那个元素]的基础？

Why aren’t you using [this or that particular] open source project as the basis for [this or that element] of Chandler?

我只会考虑使用提供这种极其具体的功能的 PIM，我已经使用了很多年并且离不开它。

I will only consider using a PIM that provides this extremely specific feature that I have been using for many years and can’t live without.

前景一片大好。微软太烂了。

Outlook blows. Microsoft sucks.



Slashdot 的标题是“米奇·卡普尔的前景杀手”，定下了宣传基调：卡普尔正在与盖茨较量。钱德勒会杀死 Outlook。开源；打倒微软！

Slashdot’s headline, “Mitch Kapor’s Outlook-Killer,” set the tone of the publicity: Kapor was taking on Gates. Chandler would slay Outlook. Up with open source; down with Microsoft!

这种反应是不可避免的，但却让卡普尔感到痛苦。他知道，攻击微软就是自找麻烦——这既是因为微软的产品根深蒂固，也是因为该公司长期以来在察觉到威胁时就会压制竞争对手。他自以为自己已经很清楚，他最初的目标市场不是 Outlook Exchange 的大型办公室，而是“信息密集型”个人用户和小公司。他曾表示，钱德勒的目标不是取代 Outlook 巨头，而是与其共存。但他低估了他的项目将如何被他自己的个人神话所框定。卡普尔与盖茨之间哪怕有一丝丝的恩怨情仇，都不可避免地会引起媒体的关注。

The reaction was inevitable, but it pained Kapor. He knew that attacking Microsoft was asking for trouble—both because Microsoft’s products are so deeply entrenched and because the company has a long record of squashing competitors when it perceives a threat. He thought he had been clear that his initial target market was not Outlook Exchange’s big offices but, rather, “information-intensive” individual users and small companies. Chandler, he had said, aimed not to supplant the Outlook behemoth but to coexist with it. But he had underestimated the way his project would be framed by his own personal mythology. The slightest hint of a Kapor-versus-Gates grudge match inevitably enthralled the media.

不过，卡普尔知道，钱德勒必须证明自己，不是通过向微软这条龙倾斜，而是通过自己的优点赢得用户。还有很长的路要走，而且还没有大量的代码，但迹象是有利的。一些非常聪明且经验丰富的人正在努力解决令他们着迷的问题。他们站在其他开源项目的肩膀上。什么能阻止他们？

Still, Kapor knew, Chandler would have to prove itself not by tilting at the Microsoft dragon but by winning users on its own merits. There was a long way to go, and there wasn’t a whole lot of code yet, but the signs were propitious. Some very smart and experienced minds were working to solve problems that fascinated them. They stood on the tall shoulders of other open source projects. What could stop them?

Gillmor 10 月 20 日的专栏报道称：“该软件日历部分的早期版本将于今年年底发布到网络上，整个软件的 1.0 版本预计于 2003 年底或 2004 年初发布。” 卡普尔在博客中写道：“我们将在今年年底之前首先发布代码供开发人员查看。这将是一个极其部分的阿尔法。乐观地说，我们可以在 2003 年底实现 1.0。悲观地说，这将是 2004 年。” 但是，他警告说，这是 OSAF 的“最初的标准反应”；他对此“从来没有完全满意”，而且“以钱德勒目前的状态，我们还不知道我们能走多快，也不知道我们需要多远才能发布第一个版本。”

Gillmor’s October 20 column reported: “An early version of the calendar part of the software should be posted on the Web by the end of this year, and version 1.0 of the whole thing is slated for the end of 2003 or early 2004.” Kapor wrote in his blog: “We will first put out code for developers to look at by the end of the year. It will be an extremely partial alpha. Optimistically, we could have a 1.0 by the end of 2003. Pessimistically, it will be 2004.” But, he cautioned, this was OSAF’s “original standard response”; he was “never entirely comfortable” with it, and “with Chandler in its current state, we don’t yet know how fast we’re going to be able to go, nor how far we have to get to the first release.”

事实证明，这些猜测有点乐观。

The guesses proved more than a tad optimistic.

第 4 章                           

CHAPTER 4                           

乐高乐园

LEGO LAND

[2002 年 11 月至 2003 年 8 月]

[NOVEMBER 2002–AUGUST 2003]

在科技行业的过山车周期中，2002 年的秋天代表着谷底的一次令人心悸的停顿。网络泡沫的繁荣即将结束。硅谷的购物中心式办公园区的停车场已成为无人区。9/11之后的经济已经屏住呼吸一年了，旧金山市中心店面贴着的“美国开门营业”的贴纸似乎在乞求反驳：是的，但是谁在买东西呢？

In the roller-coaster cycle of the technology industry, the fall of 2002 represented a stomach-fluttering pause at the bottom of the dip. The dot-com boom had just about finished going bust. The parking lots of Silicon Valley’s strip-mall-style office parks had become no-man’s-lands. The post-9/11 economy had been holding its breath for a year, and the “America Is Open for Business” stickers plastered on downtown San Francisco storefronts seemed to beg the retort: Yeah, but who’s buying?

这个科技行业的冰​​河时代导致大量程序员失业或就业不足。他们中的很多人已经转向开源项目，以此来磨练自己的技能，让自己的名字流传开来，同时满足他们可能有的任何编程欲望。这种过剩的闲置催生了大量的新软件，从小小的侧面努力到雄心勃勃的项目，当行业车轮再次转动时，这些项目将成长为新一代的初创公司。

This tech industry ice age had left legions of programmers un- or underemployed. A good number of them had turned to open source projects as a way to keep their skills honed and their names in circulation while scratching whatever programming itches they might have. This surplus idleness fathered a significant amount of new software, from little side efforts to ambitious projects that would grow, when the industry wheel turned once more, into a new generation of start-up companies.

OSAF 无疑从这个时机中受益：这是黑暗平原上的一盏明灯，它吸引了寻找项目的程序员。米奇·卡普尔（Mitch Kapor）一直认为该组织将依赖于带薪员工和无私的志愿者，而安迪·赫茨菲尔德（Andy Hertzfeld）已经成为后者的一个引人注目的例子。吉尔莫专栏之后的 OSAF 新闻报道一连串，让卡普尔的收件箱充满了鼓励和帮助。史蒂夫·乔布斯给卡普尔打电话——这是两人十年来的第一次谈话——邀请 OSAF 团队来苹果讨论他们如何合作。

OSAF certainly benefited from this timing: It was a bright light on a dark plain, and it beckoned to programmers looking for projects. Mitch Kapor had always figured that the organization would depend on both paid employees and altruistic volunteers, and in Andy Hertzfeld it already had one high-profile example of the latter. The flurry of OSAF news coverage that followed Gillmor’s column filled Kapor’s inbox with encouragement and offers of help. Steve Jobs called Kapor—it was the two men’s first conversation in a decade—inviting the OSAF team down to Apple to talk about how they might collaborate.

当 Lou Montulli 的名字出现在 OSAF 刚刚开放的“开发”邮件列表的电子邮件签名中时，Kapor 特别注意到了这一消息，该消息建议 OSAF 再次考虑 Mozilla 的工具包来构建其用户界面。Montulli 和他的朋友 Aleks Totic 看过 Slashdot 关于 OSAF 的文章；不久之后，他们与卡普尔取得了联系，讨论了为钱德勒做志愿者的事情。这两个年轻人在网络圈都很有名：托蒂克曾是伊利诺伊大学厄巴纳-香槟分校团队的一员，该团队开发了第一个流行的图形网络浏览器 Mosaic（他编写了 Macintosh 版本），然后带着他的作品离开了。 1994 年，作为 Netscape 创始团队的一员，Montulli 与硅谷的同事一起工作。蒙图利在堪萨斯大学就读时就编写了一个非常早期的纯文本 Web 浏览器，并被招募加入 Netscape 的初创团队。他最出名的身份可能是“cookie”的发明者，“cookie”是网站在浏览器中植入的一种备受诟病且经常被误解的文件，用于跟踪访问者及其从一个会话到下一个会话的数据。1995 年 8 月，当网景公司首次公开募股金额飙升，掀起了互联网热潮时，蒙图利和托蒂克像所有网景公司创始人一样发家致富。他们是喜欢一起工作的好朋友，在 Netscape 末日临近时他们都离开了，并帮助创立了 Epinions，一个雄心勃勃的电子商务网站；当该公司陷入经济衰退的漩涡时，他们离开了该公司。

Kapor took special note when Lou Montulli’s name turned up in the signature of an email to OSAF’s just-opened “dev” mailing list—a message suggesting that OSAF look again at Mozilla’s toolkit for building its user interface. Montulli and his pal Aleks Totic had seen the Slashdot article about OSAF; soon after, they got in touch with Kapor to talk about volunteering on Chandler. Both young men were famous in Web circles: Totic had been part of the group at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, that built Mosaic, the first popular graphic Web browser (he had written the Macintosh version), and then decamped with his colleagues for Silicon Valley as part of the founding team at Netscape in 1994. Montulli had written a very early text-only Web browser while a student at the University of Kansas and had also been recruited to join Netscape’s start-up crew. He is probably best known as the inventor of the “cookie”—the much-maligned and oft-misunderstood file that Web sites plant with a browser to track visitors and their data from one session to the next. When Netscape launched the Internet boom in August 1995, with a skyrocketing initial public offering, Montulli and Totic, like all the Netscape founders, made their fortunes. Good friends who liked working together, they both left Netscape as its end neared and helped found Epinions, an ambitious e-commerce site; they then left that company when it got sucked into the downturn’s maelstrom.

2002年，他们发现自己陷入了困境。卢主要生活在太浩湖并滑雪。亚历克斯也在项目之间。钱德勒听起来很酷。也许卡普尔需要一些帮助？

In 2002, they found themselves at loose ends. Lou was mostly living at Lake Tahoe and skiing. Aleks was between projects, too. Chandler sounded cool. Maybe Kapor wanted some help?

卡普尔知道，就像赫茨菲尔德和约翰·安德森一样，正如他所说，他是一个“老应用程序专家”。他一直使用计算机用户在自己的计算机上单独运行的程序。但钱德勒会有所不同：通过网络共享数据是其承诺的核心。蒙图利和托蒂克提供了程序员的视角，这些程序员花了近十年的时间来开发依赖互联网实现其关键功能的软件。卡普尔认为，这可能会派上用场。

Kapor knew that, like Hertzfeld and John Anderson, he was an “old applications guy,” as he put it. He had always worked with programs that computer users ran individually on their own computers. But Chandler was going to be different: Sharing data over a network was central to its promise. Montulli and Totic offered the perspective of programmers who had spent nearly a decade creating software that depended on the Internet for its critical functions. That, Kapor thought, was likely to come in handy.

托蒂克和蒙图利作为志愿者加入 OSAF 大约在同一时间，卡普尔开始招聘其他工作，随着该组织逐渐成为人们关注的焦点，充实了该组织的名册。该团队中有很多苹果校友，他们或许在卡普尔的愿景中发现了史蒂夫·乔布斯改变世界热情的回响。接替钱德勒产品经理职位的是 Chi-Chao Lam，他是一位经验丰富但仍很孩子气的硅谷企业家，曾在 Kaleida Labs（IBM 和 Apple 于 20 世纪 90 年代中期成立的不幸的合资企业）工作，随后创立了一家开创性的基于 Web 的公司。广告网络。长期担任 Macintosh 贸易记者和行业分析师的 Pieter Hartsook 签约负责 OSAF 的营销和公关工作。另外还有两名程序员加入了编码团队：斯坦福大学计算机科学系的应届毕业生 Jed Burgess 将与 John Anderson 密切合作开发 GUI。David McCusker 是一名程序员，曾在 Apple 和 Netscape 工作过，他受聘研究 Chandler 的数据存储方法。

Totic and Montulli joined OSAF as volunteers around the same time that Kapor began to hire for other jobs, filling out the organization’s roster as it moved into the spotlight. The team was heavy with Apple alumni, who perhaps found in Kapor’s vision an echo of Steve Jobs’s change-the-world fervor. Taking on the job of Chandler’s product manager was Chi-Chao Lam, a veteran but still boyish Silicon Valley entrepreneur who had worked at Kaleida Labs, the ill-fated mid-1990s joint venture between IBM and Apple, then founded a pioneering Web-based advertising network. Pieter Hartsook, a longtime Macintosh trade journalist and industry analyst, signed on to handle OSAF’s marketing and PR. And two more programmers joined the coding crew: Jed Burgess, a recent Stanford computer science graduate, would work closely with John Anderson on the GUI. David McCusker, a programmer who had done stints at Apple and Netscape, was hired to work on Chandler’s approach to storing data.

在软件抽象层的另一个版本中，软件开发人员经常谈论“前端”和“后端”。作为用户，您位于前面，前端是程序中与您打交道的部分，它提供窗口、对话框和鼠标指针，告诉您发生了什么，并为您提供输入和输出信息的方法。后端是前端事件和输入的结果所在，以便计算机能够理解、保存和检索它们。（在 Chandler 的原型中，Vista 是前端，Shimmer 是后端。）前端应该是优雅的、直观的、多功能的；前端应该是优雅的、直观的、多功能的；后端应该是隐形的、高效的、坚如磐石的。前端与人对话；后端与位对话。用《星球大战》的话来说，前端就是专横的 C3PO；后端是看不懂的R2D2。

In another version of software’s layers of abstraction, software developers often talk about “front ends” and “back ends.” You, the user, are in front, and the front end is the part of the program that deals with you—that offers windows and dialogues and mouse pointers, tells you what’s happening, and provides ways for you to input and output information. The back end is where the results of front-end events and inputs go so that the computer can make sense of them, save them, and retrieve them. (In Chandler’s prototype, Vista had been the front end, and Shimmer the back.) Front ends are supposed to be elegant, intuitive, versatile; back ends are supposed to be invisible, efficient, rock-solid. The front end talks to people; the back end talks to bits. In Star Wars terms, the front end is the butlerish C3PO; the back end is the unintelligible R2D2.

Kapor 对于他希望 Chandler 的前端做什么以及它将如何体现 Agenda 的灵魂有一个相对清晰的愿景。无论钱德勒的后端采取什么形式，都必须支持这一愿景。但那到底会是什么样的形式呢？当 OSAF 的程序员（尤其是凯蒂·帕兰特（Katie Parlante），她的日历是钱德勒作品中最远的）开始编写程序时，他们不断遇到未解决的问题：钱德勒存储库（程序的数据仓库）是否会将所有内容保存在 RDF 中？三倍”的方式萨根的微光原型？程序员如何保存他们用来构建 Chandler 的 Python 对象？存储库不能也存储这些吗？如果 Chandler 要支持点对点数据共享，存储库将如何管理它？如果您的 Chandler 存储库存储在家里的计算机上并且您想在工作中使用它怎么办？

Kapor had a relatively clear vision of what he wanted Chandler’s front end to do and how it would embody the soul of Agenda. Whatever form Chandler’s back end took would have to support that vision. But exactly what form would that be? As OSAF’s programmers—in particular Katie Parlante, whose calendar was the farthest along of Chandler’s pieces—struggled to begin writing the program, they kept bumping up against unresolved questions: Would the Chandler repository, the program’s storehouse of data, save everything in RDF “triples” the way Sagen’s Shimmer prototype had? How would the programmers save the Python objects they were constructing Chandler with? Couldn’t the repository store those, too? If Chandler was going to support peer-to-peer data sharing, how would the repository manage that? What if your Chandler repository was stored on a computer at home and you wanted to use it at work?

计划是什么？程序员们明白，在得到答案之前，任何重要的工作都无法进行。他们都陷入了困境，陷入了困境——用软件行业的首选术语来说，就是受阻。

What was the plan? The programmers understood that until they had answers, no significant work could proceed. They were all stuck, stymied—in the software business’s preferred term, blocked.

钱德勒所需的后端工作直接导致了一系列艰难的技术决策，而麦卡斯克很快发现自己处于困境的中心。McCusker 是一位热心的博主，他使用自己的名为 Treedragon 的网站来记录自己开发新编程语言的副业项目，在加入 OSAF 后的几天里，他在博客文章中充满了对技术电子邮件的热情、逐条回复。他从一位未透露姓名的开发人员那里发布了一封电子邮件，内容如下：

The back-end work Chandler needed led directly into a maze of tough technical decisions, and McCusker quickly found himself at the center of it. An enthusiastic blogger who used his Web site, named Treedragon, to chronicle his own side projects developing new programming languages, McCusker filled blog entries in the days after his start at OSAF with enthusiastic, point-by-point responses to technical emails. One email he posted from a developer whom he didn’t name read:



请不要搞砸并重新发明 Python 和 Zope [基于 Python 的项目] 开发人员已经创建的内容。Python 和 Zope 已经开发多年，这个工具箱中有一个伟大技术的宝库。钱德勒成功的关键在于重用，而不是重新发明这项工作。整合先前的成功，而不是重新发明它们。看看创建 Chandler 时需要编写多少代码。。。

Please don't blow it and reinvent what Python and Zope [a Python-based project] developers have already created. Python and Zope have been in development for years and there is a treasure trove of great technology in this tool chest. The key to making Chandler successful is in reusing, rather than reinventing this work. Integrate the prior successes instead of reinventing them. See how little code you need to write in creating Chandler . . .



McCusker 回答说：“我们希望尽可能地重用现有代码，而不是编写新代码。快速取得进展需要对开拓新的编码领域非常谨慎。”

McCusker replied, “We want to reuse existing code as much as possible rather than write new code. Making progress quickly involves being very reticent about forging out into new coding areas.”

但表达重用代码的普遍愿望是一回事，而致力于对现有代码的实际片段进行特定选择则完全是另一回事。每种选择都有优点和缺点。在越来越多的 OSAF 会议与会者中，每种方法都有支持者和批评者。没有人愿意做出错误的选择。在 11 月和 12 月的会议中，钱德勒团队努力达成难以达成的共识，最终在新年后的一场马拉松式会议中达到了顶峰。

But it was one thing to express a general wish to reuse code, and quite another one to commit to specific choices of actual pieces of existing code. Each alternative had attractions and drawbacks; each approach had advocates and critics among the growing circle of attendees at OSAF’s meetings. No one wanted to make the wrong choice. In meetings through November and December, culminating in a marathon right after the New Year, the Chandler team struggled toward an elusive consensus.

基于 RDF 的 Shimmer 存储库是 Morgen Sagen 专门构建的原型；它不能简单地连接到真正的钱德勒身上。此外，约翰·安德森从未接受过 RDF 宗教。整个 RDF 事业都以学术复杂性和不切实际而闻名。关于语义网的论文有很多，但可用的软件却不多。当一位又一位程序员了解 RDF 的世界时，每个人都得出了相似的结论：它“可怕”。

The RDF-based Shimmer repository was something Morgen Sagen had built expressly as a prototype; it couldn’t simply be hitched onto the real Chandler. Besides, John Anderson had never gotten the RDF religion. The whole RDF enterprise had a reputation for academic complexity and impracticality. There were lots of papers about the Semantic Web, but not a lot of working software. As one programmer after another had a look at the world of RDF, each came to a similar conclusion: It was “scary.”

安德森知道对钱德勒的用户界面进行编程需要花费多少工作量。他以前曾去过那里，并且了解保持这项工作易于管理是多么重要。这是最有可能造成无休止延误的区域。他对存储库的主要要求是让前端开发人员的工作变得更容易。他知道他们需要什么：一个“对象持久化”系统。Anderson 不想将 Chandler 的数据存储在 RDF 主谓宾“三重”格式中，而是希望将程序的数据和 Python 代码作为对象存储在一起（在术语“面向对象编程”的意义上），以便 Chandler 的编码人员可以轻松获取、操作并再次保存。

Anderson knew how much work programming Chandler’s user interface would be. He had been there before and understood how critical it was to keep that job manageable; it was the area most likely to cause endless delay. His chief requirement for the repository was to make things easier for the front-end developers. And he knew just what they needed: a system for “object persistence.” Rather than store Chandler’s data in the RDF subject-verb-object “triple” format, Anderson wanted the program’s data and Python code stored together as objects (in the “object-oriented programming” sense of the term) that Chandler’s coders could easily grab, manipulate, and save again.

当今计算机上最常见的数据库类型（例如 Oracle 非常成功的产品和日益流行的开源 MySQL）是“关系型”：它将信息存储在巨大的表中，这些表将数据分解为离散的单元，然后允许您构建复杂的查询以有用的方式将其组合起来，例如“显示从该日期起姓氏以“c”开头的所有条目，但不包括那些缺少街道地址的条目”之类的查询。关系数据库通常还通过使用“事务”模型来提供极高的可靠性，该模型记录对每一点数据的每一个更改，以便您可以在发生崩溃或数据损坏时始终重建信息。

The most common kind of database on today’s computers—such as Oracle’s hugely successful product and the increasingly popular open source MySQL—is “relational”: It stores information in vast tables that break data up into discrete units and then allow you to construct complex queries to combine it in useful ways—queries like “Show me all the entries from this date whose last names begin with ‘c’ but excluding those missing the street address.” Relational databases also typically provide great reliability by using a “transactions” model that logs every single change to every iota of data so you can always reconstruct your information in the event of a crash or data corruption.

获得“对象持久性”的最简单方法是使用另一种数据库，即对象数据库，该数据库不仅用于存储数据，还用于跟踪数据和与数据关联的代码之间的关系。这种方法可以让程序员的生活变得更轻松；它还往往会导致数据库速度变慢，有时甚至不太可靠。碰巧的是，Python 程序员社区已经创建了一个雄心勃勃且众所周知的对象数据库示例。它被称为 ZODB，即 Zope 对象数据库。麦卡斯克的匿名电子邮件通讯员提到了这一点。当时Python 的创建者Guido van Rossum 就职于生产它的公司。

The easiest way to get “object persistence” was to use a different kind of database, an object database, one that was designed not just to store data but also to keep track of the relationships between data and the code associated with the data. This approach could make life easier for programmers; it also tended to make for slower and sometimes less reliable databases. As it happened, the community of Python programmers had already created an ambitious and well-known example of an object database. It was called ZODB, for Zope Object Database. McCusker’s anonymous email correspondent had referred to it. At that time Python creator Guido van Rossum worked for the company that produced it.

安德森总结道，ZODB 是解决钱德勒问题的答案。起初，编写 Shimmer 并负责 Chandler 后端的 Sagen 并不同意，但他承认，他的经验更多的是为服务器编程，而不是为客户端（实际用户使用的程序）编程，并最终屈服于安德森的选择。

ZODB was the answer to Chandler’s problems, Anderson concluded. At first Sagen, who had written Shimmer and had been in charge of Chandler’s back end, didn’t agree, but he admitted that his experience was more in programming for servers than for clients—the programs that actual users employ—and eventually bowed to Anderson’s choice.

然而与此同时，卢·蒙图利和亚历克斯·托蒂奇开始参加 OSAF 的会议，并从完全不同的方向提供观察。Montulli 认为，如果 Chandler 要实现轻松点对点共享的承诺，那么它的构建就必须提高网络速度：您必须能够“通过线路”快速传递内容——编程简写穿过互联网等开放网络的通道。他为 Chandler 提出了一个愿景，将客户端及其用户界面与存储库分开。每个 Chandler 客户端都将使用互联网风格的协议访问存储库；他将其命名为 RAP，即存储库访问协议。RAP 是 Chandler 与存储库对话的方式，即使您的客户端和存储库都位于办公桌上的同一台计算机上。Montulli 认为，通过这一重大架构选择，您可以解决有关远程访问数据的所有问题，并且可以轻松共享数据。

Meanwhile, however, Lou Montulli and Aleks Totic had begun attending OSAF’s meetings and offering observations from an entirely different direction. If Chandler was going to fulfill its promise of easy peer-to-peer sharing, Montulli argued, it had to be built for speed across a network: You had to be able to hand stuff off quickly “over the wire”—programming shorthand for passage across an open network like the Internet. He laid out a vision for Chandler that separated the client and its user interface from the repository. Each Chandler client would access a repository using an Internet-style protocol; he named it RAP, for Repository Access Protocol. RAP was how Chandler would talk to the repository even if your client and repository both sat on the same computer on your desk. With that one big architectural choice, Montulli maintained, you’d resolve all the questions about remote access to your data, and you’d make sharing data easy.

对于 Kapor 来说，围绕远程访问和共享的问题变得更加紧迫，因为在 10 月份宣布 Chandler 的消息后，一个由大学首席技术官组成的工作组联系了他，引发了人们对 Chandler 的热情。该委员会名为通用解决方案小组（CSG），代表了二十多个机构，包括伯克利分校、麻省理工学院、哈佛大学、耶鲁大学和斯坦福大学。CSG 面临的问题是为校园提供廉价、开放、可靠的日历和电子邮件软件平台。一些成员认为，钱德勒可能就是这样的人。对于 OSAF 来说，这是一个有趣的机会；这也意味着钱德勒的程序员现在必须考虑一套全新的用例。最初的计划是将钱德勒的目标定位为“早期采用者”个人和“以信息为中心”的小型企业——他们的工作涉及处理大量电子邮件、约会和其他随机数据。现在，开发人员还考虑了分布在校园中的学生和教师——拥有不同移动用户群体的大型机构。

The questions surrounding remote access and sharing had become more urgent for Kapor because, in the flurry of enthusiasm for Chandler that followed its announcement in October, a working group of university chief technical officers contacted him. The committee, the Common Solutions Group, or CSG, represented two dozen institutions, including Berkeley, MIT, Harvard, Yale, and Stanford. CSG faced the problem of providing campuses with a cheap, open, reliable software platform for calendars and email. Chandler, some of its members thought, might be just the thing. It was an intriguing opportunity for OSAF; it also meant that Chandler’s programmers now had to consider a whole new set of use cases. The original plan was to target Chandler at “early adopter” individuals and small businesses that were “info-centric”—whose work involved dealing with a large volume of email, appointments, and other random data. Now the developers were also thinking about students and faculty spread across a campus—big institutions with diverse populations of mobile users.

安德森对蒙图利的 RAP 想法并不热心，但只要它不妨碍他最关心的问题：对象持久性，他就愿意同意。萨根完全回避了这场辩论。“我对自己有点不确定，”他后来解释道。周围都是有着显赫血统的程序员，他会想：“我知道什么？”

Anderson wasn’t enthusiastic about Montulli’s RAP idea, but he was willing to go along as long as it didn’t get in the way of his top concern: object persistence. Sagen ducked out of the debate completely. “I was feeling a little unsure of myself,” he later explained. Surrounded by programmers with imposing pedigrees, he would think, “What do I know?”

麦卡斯克坐在中间，试图弄清楚如何让每个人都满意，因为他所在的项目的要求成倍增加。他是一位经验丰富的杂耍演员。多年来，他的主页上一直刊登着一张他在海滩杂耍的照片——五个彩虹色的球从一只手划向另一只手。但钱德勒的设计师为他编制的不断增加的相互冲突的要求清单对他的灵活性造成了考验。“OSAF 人员想要的——全部愿望清单——都是不可能的，”他后来告诉我。

McCusker sat in the middle, trying to figure out how to keep everyone happy as the demands on his part of the project multiplied. He was an experienced juggler; for several years his home page featured a picture of him juggling at the beach—five rainbow-colored balls arcing from one hand to the other. But his dexterity was being taxed by the lengthening list of conflicting requirements that Chandler’s designers were compiling for him. “What the OSAF folks wanted—the entire laundry list of desires—was impossible,” he later told me.

对于任何程序员来说，这都是一个艰难的处境，即使是比麦卡斯克更顽固的程序员，因为他喜欢从多个角度看待问题。但同样明显的是，他在制定计划时遇到了困难，因为他在加入钱德勒团队后，在 OSAF 之外的生活几乎立即开始崩溃。他的婚姻破裂了，他变得沮丧，并遭受了重复性压力损伤的痛苦，迫使他离开键盘并使用语音识别听写系统。假期期间，他决定将自己的名字从大卫改为里斯，很快他也开始改变自己的外表：他让头发留长并染成金色。他开始涂口红。他在博客中表达了自己对“另类生活方式”的兴趣，不过他警告读者不要“错误地推测”：“几乎肯定你弄错了。不过，这不是我的问题，我也不会因为被误解而特别难过。另外，我碰巧认为模棱两可很有趣，我喜欢让你感到困惑。” 显然，他正在经历某种身份危机，无论他走到哪里，都无法帮助他解决钱德勒的存储库问题。

It would have been a tough position for any programmer, even one more bullheaded than McCusker, who enjoyed looking at problems from multiple perspectives. But it was also clear that he was having a hard time pulling a plan together because his life outside OSAF had begun to fall apart almost immediately after he joined the Chandler team. His marriage broke up, he grew depressed, and he came down with a miserable case of repetitive stress injury that forced him off the keyboard and onto a speech-recognition dictation system. Over the holidays he decided to change his first name from David to Rys, and soon he began to change his appearance, too: He let his hair grow long and dyed it blond. He began wearing lipstick. He blogged about his interest in an “alternative lifestyle,” though he warned his readers not to “speculate incorrectly”: “You almost certainly are getting something wrong. However, that’s not my problem, and I’m not particularly upset by being misunderstood. In addition, I happen to think ambiguity is funny, and I enjoy confusing you.” He was clearly going through an identity crisis of sorts, and wherever it was taking him, it wasn’t helping him solve Chandler’s repository problems.

OSAF 的环境低调而宽容，程序员们很快就适应了，训练自己使用 McCusker 的新绰号。大多数情况下，他们似乎并不关心他的外表或他想被称为什么，但他们确实希望就存储库做出一些决定，以便他们可以继续推进该计划的其余部分。当 OSAF 于 2002 年 10 月公开自我介绍时，卡普尔和他的团队养成了谈论钱德勒初稿“一月发布”的习惯。到一月初，由于很明显他们还没有任何形式的发布，他们转而谈论未注明日期的“首次公开发布”代码。

OSAF’s environment was low-key and tolerant, and the programmers quickly adapted, training themselves to use McCusker’s new moniker. Mostly, it seemed, they didn’t care about how he looked or what he wanted to be called, but they did want to get some decisions made about the repository so that they could move forward with the rest of the program. When OSAF had publicly introduced itself in October 2002, Kapor and his team got in the habit of talking about the “January release” of a first draft of Chandler. By early January, as it became obvious they were nowhere near any kind of release, they switched to talking about an undated “first public release” of code.





2003 年 1 月的一个星期四早上，下着雨，开发商们聚集在贝尔蒙特办公室。他们已经填满了主会议室的白板，因此他们搬进了前厅，这是一个堆满额外家具的空间。椅子不够，但两个蓝色的大塑料储物箱翻转过来，提供了酒吧凳式的栖息处。蒙图利坐在后面的一张椅子上，胡子已经留了几天了。在他旁边，托蒂奇把头埋在笔记本电脑里。安德森的头发花白，但脸色红润，他拉了一把椅子到门口。赫茨菲尔德把脚拉到座位上，交叉双腿。

It’s a rainy Thursday morning early in January 2003, and the developers have gathered at the Belmont office. They’ve already filled up the whiteboard in the main conference room, so they move into its antechamber, a space piled high with extra furniture. There aren’t enough chairs, but two big blue plastic storage bins, flipped on their sides, offer bar-stool-style perches. Montulli, sporting a few days’ growth of beard, sits on one at the back; next to him, Totic buries his head in a laptop. Anderson, graying but ruddy-faced, pulls a chair into the doorway. Hertzfeld pulls his feet up onto his seat and crosses his legs.

他们深入研究确保跨网络钱德勒不会落后的问题。安德森描述了一种可以“预取”一屏对象的设计，这意味着，如果您的屏幕上有一个包含 25 条消息的电子邮件收件箱，那么当您向下滚动页面时，程序将准备好显示接下来的 25 条消息。 。

They dive into the problem of ensuring that Chandler-across-a-network will not be a laggard. Anderson describes a design that would “prefetch” a screenful of objects, which means that if you had an email inbox on your screen with twenty-five messages, the program would be ready to show the next twenty-five if you scrolled down the page.

蒙图利建议，最好是在用户请求某种东西（更像是 Web 浏览器）时立即开始流式传输尽可能多的数据。“我们在 Netscape 做的最流行的事情，”他说，“就是在所有内容都输入之前就将页面呈现在屏幕上。” 当大多数人通过慢速调制解调器访问网络并咒骂它为“全球等待”时，这个简单的选择让网络感觉更快、响应更灵敏。蒙图利认为，钱德勒可以从这次经历中学习。

Montulli suggests that it would be better to start streaming as much data as possible as soon as the user asks for something—more like a Web browser. “The most popular thing we did at Netscape,” he said, “was to have the page render on the screen even before everything had come in.” That simple choice made the Web feel faster and more responsive at a time when most people were accessing it via slow modems and cursing it as the World Wide Wait. Chandler, Montulli argues, could learn from that experience.

然而，随着争论的进行，很明显他实际上是在提倡一些更基本的东西。他从来不会直接说：“让我们抛弃 ZODB”，但他暗示钱德勒不需要它，它只会妨碍你。

As the argument proceeds, though, it becomes evident that he is really advocating something more basic. He never comes right out and says, “Let’s dump ZODB,” but he implies that Chandler doesn’t need it, that it will only get in the way.

安德森认为蒙图利太过分了。“让我们回到第一个方面，”他说。“我们使用面向对象编程吗？”

Anderson feels that Montulli is going too far. “Let’s go back to square one,” he says. “Do we use object-oriented programming?”

“是的，”蒙图利回答。

“Yes,” Montulli answers.

“我们用Python吗？”

“Do we use Python?”

蒙图利点点头。托蒂奇一直保持沉默，他从屏幕上抬起头来发表意见。“只是不清楚 ZODB 是否正是钱德勒所需要的”，他用带着家乡贝尔格莱德口音的温和语气解释道。事实证明，ZODB 实际上只是一个对象持久层，位于名为 Berkeley DB 的较低级别开源数据库之上。Totic 认为，OSAF 的程序员需要研究 ZODB，弄清楚它是否适合他们的目的，并对其进行修改以使其适合他们的需要，他们可以直接在 Berkeley DB 之上构建自己的对象持久性代码。

Montulli nods. Totic, who has mostly kept quiet, looks up from his screen and weighs in. It’s just not clear that ZODB is exactly what Chandler needs, he explains in diffident tones, gently accented from his native Belgrade. ZODB, it turns out, is really just a layer for object persistence that sits on top of a lower level open source database called Berkeley DB. In the time it would take OSAF’s programmers to study ZODB, figure out whether it suited their purposes, and tinker with it to get it to fit, Totic figures, they could build their own object persistence code directly on top of Berkeley DB.

Anderson 的“我已经找到了完美的解决方案”与 Totic 的“我们自己也可以轻松完成”：这里再次出现了软件重用的典型困境。建造还是借用？事实上，每个软件项目迟早都会到达这个岔路口。（传统上完整的短语是“构建、购买或借用？”不过，从技术角度来看，“购买”和“借用”是相似的，是同一枚硬币的商业和开源方面。）世界充满了代码别人写过的。获取它并将其用于您的新项目不是很容易吗？那么，为什么这么多程序员浏览现有代码并权威地宣称他们可以自己完成，而且更快、更容易、更好呢？

Anderson’s “I’ve found the perfect solution” versus Totic’s “We could do it ourselves just as easily”: Here, once more, was the archetypal dilemma of software reuse. Build or borrow? Virtually every software project sooner or later arrives at this fork in the road. (The full phrase traditionally is “Build, buy, or borrow?” From a technical perspective, though, “buy” and “borrow” are similar, the commercial and open source sides of the same coin.) The world is full of code that someone else has written. Shouldn’t it be easy to grab it and use it for your new project? Why then do so many programmers glance at existing code and declare authoritatively that they could do it themselves, faster, easier, and better?





当人们梦想简化软件制作工作时，他们通常梦想标准化的插件部件。新西兰的两位学者詹姆斯·诺布尔 (James Noble) 和罗伯特·比德尔 (Robert Biddle) 有时以“后现代程序员”的名义一起写作，他们将这一愿景称为“乐高假说”：“未来，程序将由可重复使用的部件构建而成。软件部件将在全球范围内提供。软件工程将从平凡的编程中解放出来。” 从架子上取下一些部件，将它们组合在一起，然后就可以使用软件了，无需痛苦的编码！

When people dream of streamlining the work of making software, most often they dream of standardized plug-in parts. James Noble and Robert Biddle, two scholars in New Zealand who sometimes write together under the sobriquet The Postmodern Programmers, dub this vision the Lego Hypothesis: “In the future, programs will be built out of reusable parts. Software parts will be available worldwide. Software engineering will be set free from the mundane necessity of programming.” Pull some pieces off the shelf, snap them together, and presto—working software, with no painful coding!

那些试图走上这种乌托邦式编程愿景的程序员几乎总是发现这条路受阻。诺布尔和比德尔的研究发现了最重要的障碍之一。他们和两位同事检查了用面向对象技术构建的实际程序中使用的软件对象的广泛样本，发现这些构建块在任何方面都不像乐高。如果软件组件像乐高积木一样，那么它们就会很小、不可分割且可替代；他们之间的相似之处多于不同之处；它们将“仅与几个相邻的组件耦合”。但诺布尔和比德尔发现，实际程序中的组件在大小、功能以及与其他组件的连接数量方面存在巨大差异。它们“像分形一样无标度，但与乐高积木不同。” 当诺布尔和比德尔深入真实程序的背后时，他们观察到了他们所谓的“普遍异质性”：无论你看向何处，唯一不变的是没有什么是不变的。想象一下乐高积木，其中一些部分是半英寸长，另一些部分是半英里长；有些是由硬塑料制成的，有些是液体或气体；有些与熟悉的一排突出物卡在一起，有些则通过胶水、焊料或绳子连接。

Programmers who have tried to travel the road to this utopian vision of programming have almost always found it blocked. Noble’s and Biddle’s research identified one of the most significant obstacles. They and two colleagues examined a broad sample of software objects used in real programs built with object-oriented techniques and found that these building blocks weren’t Lego-like in any way. If software components were like Lego bricks, they’d be small, indivisible, and substitutable; they’d be more similar to one another than different; they’d be “coupled to only a few, neighboring components.” But Noble and Biddle found that the components in actual programs varied enormously in size, in function, and in their number of connections to other components.
