They were “scale-free, like fractals, and unlike Lego bricks.” When they peered under the hood of real programs, Noble and Biddle observed what they called “pervasive heterogeneity”: Everywhere you looked, the only constant was that nothing was constant. Imagine a Lego set in which some parts are a half-inch long and others are a half-mile long; some are made out of hard plastic and others are liquid or gas; some click together with the familiar rows of protrusions, and others connect via glue or solder or string.

难怪生产通用管理单元软件套件并不容易。然而，尽管屡屡失败，乐高梦想还是给现代编程的故事蒙上了长长的阴影。尽管存在所有障碍，每一代新一代程序员都确实找到了更好的借用而不是构建的方法。

No wonder it hasn’t been easy to produce a Universal Snap-In Software Kit. Yet despite repeated failures, the Lego dream has cast a long shadow across the story of modern programming. And for all the obstacles, each new generation of programmers does find better ways to borrow instead of build.

可重用代码的概念可以追溯到软件的远古时代，当时莫里斯·威尔克斯（Maurice Wilkes）（英国编程先驱，对自己一生的调试工作感到郁闷）和他在战后英国的同事定义了子例程：可以从程序中的任何位置都可以完成特定任务，并且在完成其任务后，会将控制权交还给程序中调用它的任何部分。威尔克斯几乎立即开始将子例程收集到库中，“以便每个用户都不必从底层开始。” 从那天起，大多数程序员也戴上了代码图书馆员的帽子。

The concept of reusable code dates back to software’s antediluvian roots, when Maurice Wilkes (the British programming pioneer who had the glum realization about his lifetime of debugging) and his colleagues in postwar Britain defined the subroutine: a chunk of code that could be invoked from anywhere in a program to accomplish a certain task and that, having finished its assignment, would hand the reins back to whichever part of the program had called it. Wilkes almost immediately began collecting subroutines into libraries—“in order that every user should not have to start from the bottom.” From that day on, most programmers have also worn the hat of code librarian.

但这些代码例程库通常仍然是孤岛。真正的标准化已经远离了这个领域。在软件领域，随处可见数十种相互竞争的标准。计算机系统中的每个差异点——您使用什么中央处理器芯片？哪个版本的操作系统？什么编程语言？什么数据格式？等等——为拼装乐高梦想提供了另一个失败点。正如多本软件工程书籍的作者罗伯特·格拉斯（Robert Glass）所说，程序员很久以前就解决了“小型重用”的问题，通过构建子例程库来自动完成苦差事。仍未解决的是“大规模重用”的问题，即制造真正有用和使用的大型可重用软件组件。“这不是意志问题，”格拉斯写道。“这甚至不是技能问题。这只是一个难以解决的问题，其根源在于软件多样性。”

But these libraries of code routines typically remain islands. True standardization has eluded the field; in software there are dozens of competing standards everywhere you look. Each point of differentiation in a computer system—what central processor chip are you using? what version of which operating system? what programming language? what data format? and so on—offers another point of failure for the snap-it-in Lego dream. As Robert Glass, the author of a number of books on software engineering, puts it, programmers long ago solved the problem of “reuse-in-the-small,” building libraries of subroutines to automate the drudgery out of their work. Still unsolved is the problem of “reuse-in-the-large,” making big reusable software components that are actually useful and used. “It is not a will problem,” Glass wrote. “It is not even a skill problem. It is simply a problem too hard to be solved, one rooted in software diversity.”

20 世纪 80 年代，一位名叫布拉德·考克斯 (Brad Cox) 的计算机科学家开始痴迷于用可重用部件构建程序的问题。他设计了 C 编程语言的扩展，称为 Objective-C，旨在简化可重用软件对象的生产。但当它没有流行起来时，他开始从经济而不是技术的角度来看待这个问题。1990 年，考克斯概述了一种构建和资助软件的新方法，程序员可以编码并出售小组件，供其他人组装成工作系统。

In the 1980s, a computer scientist named Brad Cox became obsessed with the problem of constructing programs out of reusable parts. He had designed an extension of the C programming language, called Objective-C, intended to streamline the production of reusable software objects. But when it didn’t catch on, he began to view the issue from an economic rather than a technical perspective. In 1990, Cox outlined a new approach to the building and funding of software in which programmers would code and sell small components for others to assemble into working systems.

考克斯认为，我们今天仍在以家庭作坊式的方式构建我们的软件。我们需要“将编程从单独的裁剪工艺转变为像制造这样的组织型企业。” 今天的软件开发人员就像殖民时代的枪匠，精心手工制作每一个螺母和螺丝。我们还没有实现工业革命的飞跃，从“像枪匠在铁棍上一样归档软件”到“商业上强大的可信、稳定组件存储库，其属性可以在标准目录中理解和列表，就像其他成熟工程的手册一样”域”。尽管计算机硬件行业所生产的技术极其复杂，但它还是实现了这一转变：具有螺丝刀水平技能的用户可以插入卡（电路板）以扩展计算机的功能，而无需了解卡上芯片的任何信息。同样，制造商可以利用现成的芯片来制造这些卡，而不必担心芯片制造商是如何生产它们的。为什么我们不能以同样的方式构建软件？

We are still building our software cottage-industry-style today, Cox argued. We need to “transform programming from a solitary cut-to-fit craft into an organizational enterprise like manufacturing.” Today’s software developer is like the colonial-era gunsmith, lovingly handcrafting every nut and screw. We haven’t yet made an industrial revolution leap from “filing away at software like gunsmiths at iron bars” to “commercially robust repositories of trusted, stable components whose properties can be understood and tabulated in standard catalogs, like the handbooks of other mature engineering domains.” The computer hardware industry, despite the enormous complexity of the technology it produces, had managed this transition: Users with screwdriver-level skills could plug in cards—circuit boards to extend a computer’s functions—without having to understand anything about the chips on the cards. Similarly, manufacturers can build those cards from off-the-shelf chips without worrying about how the chip maker produced them. Why can’t we build software the same way?

考克斯尝试过。他创立了一家名为 Stepstone 的公司，旨在“为 C 系统构建者提供可插入的芯片级软件组件”。但尽管取得了一些小成功，这种方法并没有取得成功。他后来写道：“坏消息是，这个实验表明，即使采用最先进的技术，设计和构建既有用又真正可重用的组件，并记录它们以便客户能够理解它们，将它们移植到源源不断的新硬件平台上，确保最近的增强或移植不会违反某些现有界面，并将它们推销给一种文化，这种文化的价值体系（如威廉斯堡枪匠）鼓励从首要原则”。

Cox tried. He founded a company called Stepstone aimed at “providing pluggable chip-level software components to C system builders.” But despite some small successes, the approach didn’t take off. He later wrote, “The bad news is that this experiment has shown that it is exceedingly difficult, even with state-of-the-art technologies, to design and build components that are both useful and genuinely reusable, to document them so customers can understand them, to port them to an unceasing torrent of new hardware platforms, to ensure that recent enhancements or ports haven’t violated some existing interface, and to market them to a culture whose value system, like the Williamsburg gunsmith, encourages building everything from first principles.”

互联网的兴起促使考克斯再次抨击这个问题。在他 1995 年出版的《Superdistribution》一书中，他概述了一个利用网络建立新型软件组件市场的计划。他指出，在当今的计算领域，一段代码几乎不可能被追踪到它何时被复制，但很容易追踪它何时被使用。那么为什么不编写可以自由复制但可以跟踪每次使用并相应收费的软件呢？假设我是一名开发人员，正在构建一个新的电子邮件程序。在我的构建过程中，我发现了一段有人编写的用于过滤垃圾邮件的代码，我决定将其合并。您可以免费获得我的软件的副本，但使用它时每月需要付费，当我收到您的费用时，我会将其中的一部分踢给垃圾邮件过滤器的作者。

The rise of the Internet led Cox to take another swipe at the problem. In his 1995 book, Superdistribution, he outlined a scheme for using the Net to build a new kind of market for software components. In computing today, he pointed out, it is nearly impossible for a piece of code to track when it is being copied, but it is easy for it to track when it is being used. So why not write software that can be freely copied but that tracks each use and charges accordingly? Say I’m a developer building a new email program. In the course of my construction I find a piece of code somebody wrote that filters spam, and I decide to incorporate it. You get a copy of my software for free but get charged each month to use it, and when I get your fee, I kick a portion of it over to the author of the spam filter.

考克斯希望“超级分发”能够刺激可靠软件组件的繁荣自动化市场的发展，但他的想法再一次没有流行起来。当今基于 Web 的软件服务（用户从不下载、接触或“拥有”正在运行的软件，而只是通过 Web 浏览器免费或支付适度费用来访问它）最接近超级分发和计量使用的世界。考克斯想象的软件组件。与此同时，程序员不再安装大量知道何时使用的代码并对其进行收费，而是倾向于免费开放源代码。

Cox hoped that “superdistribution” would create incentives for the evolution of a bustling automated market for reliable software components, but once more, his ideas did not catch on. Today’s Web-based software services—where the user never downloads, touches, or “owns” the running software but instead just accesses it through a Web browser for free or for a modest fee—come closest to the world of superdistribution and metered use of software components that Cox imagined. Meanwhile, programmers, instead of installing hunks of code that know when they’re being used and charge for it, have gravitated toward the open source free-for-all.

Cox 现在是一名居住在弗吉尼亚州马纳萨斯的顾问，他表示，虽然他每天都使用开源软件，并认为自己是一名 Linux 黑客，但他并不认为开源方法是解决软件重用问题的现实答案。“他们确实有一种经济模式，适合那些受声誉而非金钱驱动的人，”他说。“但大多数人的动机是如何支付抵押贷款。我更感兴趣的是如何动员大多数人来实现重用。”

Cox, now a consultant living in Manassas, Virginia, says that although he uses open source software daily and considers himself a Linux hacker, he doesn’t see the open source approach as a realistic answer to the problem of software reuse. “They do have an economic model that works for people that are motivated by reputation more than money,” he says. “But most folks are motivated by how to pay the mortgage. And I’m more interested in how to mobilize that majority to make reuse work.”





除了阻碍软件开发者进入他们承诺的乐高乐园的技术障碍和经济脱节之外，简单的人性有时也会阻碍他们的梦想。当然，正如埃里克·雷蒙德（Eric Raymond）所写，伟大的程序员会重写和重用。但程序员总是对自己的作者身份感到自豪，而告诉他们直接从架子上取下部分可能会惹怒他们。

Beyond the technical hurdles and economic disconnects that bar software developers from their promised Lego Land, simple human nature also sometimes stands in the dream’s way. Sure, great programmers rewrite and reuse, as Eric Raymond wrote. But programmers have always felt a certain pride of authorship, and telling them to just pull parts off the shelf can rub them the wrong way.

拉里·康斯坦丁（Larry Constantine）是 20 世纪 90 年代颇受欢迎的专栏《The Peopleware Papers》的作者，他对为什么程序员没有蜂拥而至考克斯的想法提供了一个务实的解释。“不幸的是，”康斯坦丁写道，“大多数程序员都喜欢编程。他们中的一些人宁愿编程也不愿吃饭或洗澡。他们中的大多数人更愿意削减代码，而不是追逐文档或搜索目录或试图找出其他愚蠢程序员的白痴工作。。。。在其他条件相同的情况下，程序员从头开始设计和构建，而不是回收。” 有时，软件开发人员会陷入“不是这里发明的”综合症，即对自己的技能和组织实力的信心导致对其他人创造的任何东西的不信任；有时他们只是不想花时间研究别人的工作，甚至不愿意四处看看其他人的工作是否适合他们的需要。康斯坦丁写道：“如果典型的程序员需要超过两分二十七秒才能找到某样东西，他们就会得出结论，它不存在，因此会重新发明它。”

Larry Constantine, author of a popular column in the 1990s called “The Peopleware Papers,” offered one pragmatic explanation for why programmers did not flock to Cox’s ideas. “Unfortunately,” Constantine wrote, “most programmers like to program. Some of them would rather program than eat or bathe. Most of them would much rather cut code than chase documentation or search catalogs or try to figure out some other stupid programmer’s idiotic work . . . . Other things being equal, programmers design and build from scratch rather than recycle.” Sometimes software developers fall prey to the “not invented here” syndrome, in which confidence in your own skills and your organization’s prowess leads to distrust of anything created by anyone else; sometimes they just don’t feel like taking the time to study someone else’s work or even to look around to see if anyone else’s work might suit their needs. “If it takes the typical programmer more than two minutes and twenty-seven seconds to find something,” Constantine wrote, “they will conclude it does not exist and therefore will reinvent it.”

开源开发和互联网的双重革命无疑已经开始改变这种习惯。Google 将查找许多东西的过程缩短到了连程序员两分二十七秒的注意力也能应付的持续时间。Perl 和 Python 等语言为程序员提供了大量代码来完成平凡但耗时的复杂任务，例如处理日期和时间或对文本片段进行排序。例如，综合 Perl 档案网络 (CPAN)（在我撰写本文时）托管着 4,359 位作者的 8,107 个“模块”；每个都可以在网上免费获得。

The twin revolutions of open source development and the Internet have certainly begun to change that habit. Google has shortened the process of finding many things to a duration that even the programmer’s two-minute-and-twenty-seven-second attention span can handle. And languages like Perl and Python offer programmers vast troves of code for accomplishing mundane but time-consumingly complex tasks, like processing dates and times or sorting pieces of text. For instance, the Comprehensive Perl Archive Network, or CPAN, hosts (as I write this) 8,107 “modules” by 4,359 authors; each is available for free on the Net.

这些程序组件的仓库可能是软件世界最接近乐高梦想的地方。然而，与最热心的贡献者所希望的相比，它们的使用率和用处仍然较少。同一类别中通常有数十种不同的选择以及这些选择的不同版本。可用代码的数量和每个代码包可以做的事情的数量是如此之大，以至于即使是老手有时也会忘记哪些是可用的；他们最终徒劳地寻找他们需要的东西，或者从头开始编写一些已经可以使用的功能。

These storehouses of program components are probably the closest the software world has come to the Lego dream. And yet they remain less used and less useful than their most ardent contributors might wish. There are often dozens of different choices and different versions of those choices in the same category. The volume of available code and the number of things each package of code can do are so great that even veterans sometimes forget what’s available; they end up hunting in vain for what they need or going off and writing some function from scratch that was already available in ready-to-use form.

Python 专家 Anthony Baxter 访问 OSAF 时，发表了有关构建名为 Shtoom 的互联网电话应用程序的演讲。处理音频需要代码具有良好的性能；它是“实时”的——您必须在数据传入时跟上声音，否则音频就会中断，因此您必须快速处理收到的数据。“原始 Python 几乎可以处理它，”巴克斯特说，但它只需要更多的简化或优化。Baxter 讲述了如何寻找不同的解决方案来解决这个问题：一个名为 Psyco 的特殊 Python 编译器、一个名为 Numeric 的数学处理器、一个名为 Pyrex 的工具，可将 Python 编译为 C 代码。

When Python expert Anthony Baxter visited OSAF, he gave a talk about building an Internet telephone application named Shtoom. Handling audio requires good performance from your code; it’s “real time”—you have to keep up with the sound as the data comes in or the audio will break up, so you have to process what you get fast. “Raw Python could almost handle it,” Baxter said, but it needed just a bit more streamlining or optimization. Baxter told of hunting around for different solutions to the problem: a special Python compiler called Psyco, a math processor called Numeric, a tool called Pyrex that compiled Python into C code.

然后他想起来：Python本身提供了一个名为“audioop”的模块，用于有效地操作音频数据。编程语言的标准发行版已经完全满足了他的需要！他应该知道这一点：他是最新版本 Python 的发布经理，是负责管理该程序语言及其包从开发和测试到最终发布的程序员。然而他完全忘记了他所寻求的工具的存在。

Then he remembered: Python itself offered a module called “audioop” for efficiently manipulating audio data. The standard distribution of the programming language already did exactly what he needed! He of all people should have known that: He was the release manager for the most recent version of Python, the programmer in charge of shepherding the program language and its packages through development and testing to final release. And yet he had completely forgotten about the existence of the tool he sought.

正如 Python 爱好者喜欢说的那样，电池确实包含在内。但有这么多电池，谁能跟踪所有电池呢？这个问题延伸到每一种语言和软件构建的每一个领域。编程专家沃德·坎宁安 (Ward Cunningham) 表示：“跟上图书馆的可用资源是信息过载的首要挑战。”

The batteries were indeed included, as Python devotees like to say. But with so many batteries, who could keep track of them all? The problem extends to every language and across every realm of software building. “Keeping up with what’s available in the libraries,” says programming expert Ward Cunningham, “is the number one information overload challenge.”

Sourceforge 是一个网络上的开源仓库，托管着超过 100,000 个项目的代码。很少有拥有大量用户的；其中很多都是单人操作。这里有一些程序可以完成您可能想用计算机完成的任何事情——从处理家庭视频到管理企业的书籍。但这似乎是一般程序员，尤其是开源程序员的天性，想要重新发明轮子。因此，如果您想在 Sourceforge 上找到视频转换程序，您有 190 个可供选择。程序员的这种倾向是根深蒂固的。很久以前，程序名称前面的短语“Yet Another”就成为一种承认，无论你在做什么，许多其他人之前已经做过了。还有 YABB（“又一个公告板”）和 YASSP（“又一个 Solaris 安全包”）和又一个 Bittorrent 客户端，等等。当两名斯坦福大学研究生创办雅虎时！1994 年，这个名字是“Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle”的缩写。

Sourceforge, an open source warehouse on the Web, hosts the code for more than 100,000 projects. Few have a large population of users; a good number of them are simply one-person operations. There are programs here for accomplishing just about anything you might want to do with a computer—from processing home videos to running a business’s books. But it seems to be in the nature of programmers in general, and open source programmers in particular, to want to reinvent the wheel. So if you are looking to find a video conversion program on Sourceforge, you have 190 to choose from. This penchant among programmers is deep-rooted; the phrase “Yet Another” prefixed to a program’s name long ago became a way of acknowledging that whatever you were doing, many others had already done it before. There’s YABB, “Yet Another Bulletin Board,” and YASSP, “Yet Another Solaris Security Package,” and Yet Another Bittorrent Client, and on and on. When two Stanford grad students started up Yahoo! in 1994, the name was a smart-alecky acronym for Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle.





如果米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 对钱德勒有任何把握，那就是他不希望该项目成为“又一个”——不是另一个 Outlook 克隆，不是另一个普通的个人信息管理器，不是另一个任何东西。钱德勒的全部目的是构建一些真正不同的软件，以满足您的需求。像 Outlook 这样的程序将电子邮件与任务、任务与约会、约会与笔记分开。他们可能会给你一个带有图标的小工具栏，允许你查看每种类型的数据，但你不能混合和匹配，你不能将一个数据与另一个数据关联起来，你不能将一个数据存储在多个地方，并且你无法毫不费力地将一种转变为另一种。在钱德勒，你存储的所有东西——电子邮件、地址、事件（约会）、待办事项和随机笔记——都只是一个“项目”，项目将被组织和显示，无论你多么高兴。

If Mitch Kapor was sure of anything about Chandler, it was that he didn’t want the project to be “Yet Another”—not yet another Outlook clone, not yet another garden-variety personal information manager, not yet another anything. The whole point of Chandler was to build something truly different, software that would bend to your needs. Programs like Outlook segregated emails from tasks and tasks from appointments and appointments from notes; they might give you a little toolbar with icons that allowed you to view each type of data, but you couldn’t mix and match, you couldn’t relate one to another, you couldn’t store one in more than one place, and you couldn’t effortlessly transform one into another. In Chandler, everything that you stored—email and addresses and events (appointments) and to-dos and random notes—was simply an “item,” and items would be organized and displayed however you damn well pleased.

传统程序将各种类型的信息隔离在 OSAF 的开发人员开始称之为“孤岛”的地方。钱德勒开发人员的战斗口号是：夷平筒仓！

Conventional programs segregated information of various types in what OSAF’s developers began to call “silos.” The Chandler developers’ battle cry was: Level the silos!

这并不是第一次发出这样的呼声。数字时代的特立独行者泰德·尼尔森 (Ted Nelson) 在 20 世纪 70 年代提出了计算机作为“梦想机器”和个人解放引擎的想法，并发明了“超文本”一词来描述带有嵌入式链接的写作，这些链接可以让你从一个地方跳转到另一个地方。（纳尔逊将今天的网络视为他更复杂的愿景的混蛋。）纳尔逊还创造了“交织性”这个词，作为信息孤岛忽视的复杂性的标签：“人们一直假装他们可以使事物变得深度分层、可分类和顺序化，当他们不能，”他说。“一切都深深地交织在一起。”

It was not the first time such a cry had been raised. Digital-age maverick Ted Nelson had propounded the idea of computers as “dream machines” and engines of personal liberation in the 1970s and invented the term hypertext to describe writing with embedded links that let you jump from one place to another. (Nelson views today’s Web as a bastardization of his more complex vision.) Nelson also coined the word intertwingularity as a label for the kind of complexity that informational silos ignore: “People keep pretending they can make things deeply hierarchical, categorizable and sequential when they can’t,” he said. “Everything is deeply intertwingled.”

然而，尽管它们遭受了如此多的蔑视，但筒仓——将一组特定的类似物品存放在一个且仅一个地方的离散容器——却顽固地存在着。现代计算的图形界面（GUI）是围绕物理世界的隐喻（桌面、文件和文件夹）发展起来的。在物理世界中，文件一次只能存在于一个地方。在计算机数据的虚拟世界中，理论上没有理由存在这种限制。当然，在靠近抽象层底部的某个地方，在计算机磁盘驱动器上的物理扇区中，该文件确实存在于一个位置。但在此基础上构建足够多的软件层，您可以通过多种方式将该文件呈现给用户，允许他们从任意多个不同的点访问该文件。他们可能会感激这一点。

For all the contempt heaped upon them, however, silos—discrete containers that hold a particular set of similar items in one and only one place—have stubbornly persisted. The graphical interface of modern computing, the GUI, had evolved around physical-world metaphors—desktops, files, and folders. And in the physical world a file could exist in only one place at a time. In the virtual world of computer data, there was theoretically no reason for this limitation. Of course, somewhere down near the bottom of the layers of abstraction, in the physical sectors on your computer’s disk drive, the file really does exist in a single place. But build enough layers of software on top of that reality, and you could present that file to users in multiple ways, allowing them to access it from as many different points as they wish. They might appreciate that.

然而，正如任何日常办公室工作人员所知，您在当今的计算中并不经常遇到这种自由。筒仓无处不在。一方面，我们的大脑有一种偏好，这是由它们在物理世界中的进化所塑造的，将物品视为驻留在一个地方。而且由于一段数据确实存在于计算机最底层的一个位置，因此在此基础上构建软件比尝试做不同的事情要容易得多。出错的可能性会更少。程序员的“心智模型”——他们心中关于程序各部分如何组合在一起、数据在哪里以及当用户查找或移动数据时会发生什么的图景——与用户的“心智模型”一致。

As any everyday office worker knows, however, you don’t often encounter such freedom in today’s computing. Silos are everywhere. For one thing, there’s that preference our brains have, shaped by their evolution in the physical world, for thinking of items as residing in a single place. And because a piece of data really does exist in a single place on the computer’s bottommost layers, it’s far easier to build software on that basis than to try to do something different. Less can go wrong. The programmers’ “mental model”—the picture they have in mind of how the program’s parts fit together, of where the data is and what should happen when the user looks for it or moves it—aligns with the users’.

筒仓很常见，因为它们简单、可靠且明确。它们还反映了数字计算固有的二进制性质，其中一个位被设置为 1 或 0、开或关、真或假。在这样的系统中建立模糊性，设计一种结构，让你可以把一个东西放在多个地方，这并不是不可能的。但你必须更加努力地工作——正如钱德勒团队所发现的那样。

Silos are common because they are simple, reliable, and unambiguous. They also reflect the inherent binary nature of digital computing, in which a bit is set at either one or zero, on or off, true or false. It is not impossible to build ambiguity into such a system, to design a structure that lets you put one thing in more than one place. But you have to work a lot harder—as the Chandler team was finding.

钱德勒的存储库必须支持灵活性、流动性和无孤岛性，在卡普尔和 OSAF 的其他人看来，这代表了议程的灵魂。它还必须支持钱德勒的点对点设计所需的那种网络同步。ZODB 足够吗？没有人能肯定地说。除非你自己编写一段代码，否则很难对一段代码充满信心地说出这样的话。

Chandler’s repository had to support the kind of flexibility and fluidity and silo-less-ness that represented, in Kapor’s mind and to everyone else at OSAF, the soul of Agenda. It also had to support the kind of over-the-network synchronization that Chandler’s peer-to-peer design demanded. Would ZODB be adequate? No one could say for sure. It was awfully hard to say such a thing with any confidence about a piece of code unless you had written it yourself.

这是程序员不断重新发现的可重用软件梦想的悖论之一：几乎总有一些你可以从货架上取下来的东西可以满足你的许多需求。但通常情况下，你需要做的、现成的代码无法处理的部分正是使你的新项目与众不同、独特、创新的部分——它们就是你首先构建它的原因。

Here is one of the paradoxes of the reusable software dream that programmers keep rediscovering: There is almost always something you can pull off the shelf that will satisfy many of your needs. But usually the parts of what you need done that your off-the-shelf code won’t handle are the very parts that make your new project different, unique, innovative—and they’re why you’re building it in the first place.





一月份的会议持续了好几个小时，围绕着是否使用ZODB的问题，却始终没有解决。午休后，卡普尔站在白板前，踩着跑鞋后跟弹跳，他的白衬衫开始从裤子里掉出来。他试图从讨论中沉淀出一些东西。

The January meeting goes on for several hours, circling the question of whether to use ZODB but never resolving it. After a lunch break, Kapor stands up at the whiteboard, bouncing on the heels of his running shoes, his white shirt beginning to climb out of his trousers. He tries to precipitate something from the discussion.

“我一直在思考为什么这这么难，”他开始说道，并开始在黑板上列出原因。他询问安德森是否过于专注于让程序员变得更容易，而牺牲了用户的利益。他开始概述存储库的要求：

“I’ve been thinking about why this is so hard,” he begins, and starts listing reasons on the board. He asks whether Anderson is focused too much on making it easy for the programmers at the expense of the users. He starts outlining requirements for the repository:



(1) 它必须让 Python 程序员的生活变得轻松。

(1) It has to make life easy for the Python programmers.

(2)它必须通过网络高效运行。

(2) It has to operate efficiently over a network.

(3)它需要能够处理非常大的单个数据项和非常大量的数据项。

(3) It needs to be able to handle very large individual data items and very large numbers of items.

(4) 它必须是可靠的，使用数据库“交易”。

(4) It has to be reliable, using database “transactions.”

(5)必须支持搜索和索引。

(5) It has to support searching and indexing.



卡普尔向列表中添加了更多项目，然后返回到顶部并在第一行上方写入：

Kapor adds several more items to the list, then goes back to the top and writes above the first line:



(0) 用户体验。

(0) User experience.



到最后，存储库还没有具体的计划，但每个人都有行动项目。John Anderson 将与 Lou Montulli 和 Aleks Totic 举行会议，并尝试为他们提供面向对象图形界面 (GUI) 编程的速成课程，以及为什么他认为“对象持久性”如此重要。Katie Parlante 将准备一份文档，概述哪种数据处理方法可以让 GUI 程序员的工作变得更轻松。Rys McCusker 将研究 ZODB，看看它能在多大程度上支持 Kapor 的要求列表。

At the day’s end there’s no concrete plan for the repository, but everyone has action items. John Anderson will hold a meeting with Lou Montulli and Aleks Totic and try to give them a crash course in object-oriented graphic interface (GUI) programming and why he believes “object persistence” is so critical. Katie Parlante will prepare a document outlining what approach to data would make life easier for the GUI programmers. And Rys McCusker will study ZODB and see how well it can support Kapor’s list of requirements.

“我注意到，”卡普尔说，“这些新任务与我们现在的开发计划完全不同。我相信他们会在未来的某个地方再次汇聚。”

“I note,” Kapor says, “that these new tasks completely diverge from what we now have on our development schedules. I’m confident that they’ll converge again somewhere down the line.”





整个 2003 年冬天，开发人员不断试探性地开始建造真正的钱德勒——试图离开原型世界，开始生成将构成最终程序基础的代码，尽管还处于萌芽阶段。Anderson 在 wxWidgets 和 wxPython 中模拟了第一个原始版本的用户界面。赫茨菲尔德快速设计了一个地址簿或联系人管理器。但在不知道程序如何存储数据的情况下，没有人愿意写太多；这感觉就像在你还没选好地基地点之前就把墙砌起来一样。一个正常运行的程序看起来仍然像海市蜃楼：无论开发人员召开了多少次会议，或者他们认为自己做出了多少决定，目标都没有更进一步。

Through the winter of 2003, the developers kept taking tentative stabs at commencing the construction of the real Chandler—trying to leave the world of prototypes and start producing code that would form the basis, however embryonic, of the final program. Anderson mocked up the first crude version of a user interface in wxWidgets and wxPython. Hertzfeld whipped up a quick rendition of an address book or contacts manager. But without knowing how the program would store its data, nobody wanted to write too much; it felt like throwing walls up before you had even picked a site for a foundation. A functioning program still seemed like a mirage: No matter how many meetings the developers held or how many decisions they thought they had made, the goal moved no closer.

部分问题在于，尽管卡普尔是钱德勒所有事情的最终仲裁者，但他觉得自己在存储库辩论中超出了自己的深度，并且不想决定一种方法而不是另一种方法。部分问题还在于，安德森虽然在技术偏好上强烈而明确，但既不对抗也不冲动，当人们提出问题和担忧时，他会花时间考虑。

Part of the problem was that although Kapor was the ultimate arbiter of all things Chandler, he felt out of his depth in the repository debate and didn’t want to dictate one approach over another. Part of the problem was also that Anderson, though strong and clear in his technical preferences, was neither confrontational nor impulsive, and when people raised questions and concerns, he took time to consider them.

但大多数情况下，每个人都在等待 Rys McCusker 开始构建存储库。与此同时，McCusker 认为 Chandler 已经被 Montulli 和 Totic 出轨了，他们倾向于低估项目已经做出的决定，比如选择 Python 和 ZODB。他后来反思道，如果他没有经历过这样的个人混乱，他可能会提出更有力的技术论据来反对他们；相反，他沮丧地看着他们的阻挠策略。就蒙图利和托蒂克而言，他们认为麦卡斯克无法胜任开发 OSAF 可以快速使用的东西的工作。Montulli 质疑整个对象持久化方法（他认为这更像是象牙塔的“白日梦”，而不是经过现场验证的编程技术）是否值得付出努力。

But mostly, everyone was waiting for Rys McCusker to start building the repository. McCusker, meanwhile, felt that Chandler had gotten derailed by Montulli and Totic, who tended to discount decisions the project had already made, like the choice of Python and ZODB. If he hadn’t been going through such personal turmoil, he reflected later, he might have mounted stronger technical arguments against them; instead, he watched in dismay at what he viewed as their obstructionist tactics. For their part, Montulli and Totic thought McCusker wasn’t up to the job of cranking out something that OSAF could use quickly. And Montulli questioned whether the whole object-persistence approach—which he viewed as more of an ivory-tower “pipe dream” than a field-proven programming technique—was worth the effort.

2月12日，麦卡斯克在博客中写道：“我还没有为钱德勒编写任何代码。我没有写过Python代码。我没有写过任何 C++ 代码。我根本没有检查源代码控制系统中的任何内容。”

On February 12, McCusker wrote in his blog: “I have not yet written any code for Chandler. I have written no Python code. I have written no C++ code. I have not checked anything at all into the source code control system.”

一月底，随着停滞感越来越强烈，赫茨菲尔德建议——无论有存储库还是没有存储库，即使他们还没有准备好向公众展示他们的代码——开发人员是时候开始组装代码了。他们各自独立开发的代码已成为里程碑版本。程序员开始定期将他们的代码存入 OSAF 的 CVS 存储库，该源代码控制系统跟踪代码的每次更改并允许“回滚”到任何以前的版本。

At the end of January, as the sense of stasis grew stronger, Hertzfeld had suggested that—repository or no repository, and even if they weren’t ready to show their code to the public—it was time for the developers to start assembling the code they had each been separately working on into milestone releases. The programmers began regularly depositing their code into OSAF’s CVS repository, the source-control system that tracked every change to the code and allowed “rollbacks” to any previous version.

因此，2003 年 2 月 20 日，OSAF 发布了第一个 Chandler 里程碑。不过，发布并不完全正确；这只是一个内部版本，仅供 OSAF 开发人员使用，不会公开。它被所有可能的免责声明围起来。那是“前阿尔法”。它的后端继续依赖 Sagen 的 Shimmer 原型。它看起来有点像网络浏览器，有后退和前进按钮。它提供了一个基本的日历和联系人管理器，因为凯蒂·帕兰特和安迪·赫茨菲尔德已经对它们进行了编码。

And so, on February 20, 2003, OSAF released the very first Chandler milestone. Release is not quite right, though; it was an internal release only, just for the OSAF developers, not to be made public. It was fenced around with every possible disclaimer. It was “pre-alpha.” It continued to rely on Sagen’s Shimmer prototype for the back end. It looked a little bit like a Web browser, with back and forward buttons. It offered a rudimentary calendar and contacts manager, because Katie Parlante and Andy Hertzfeld had coded them.

它没有做任何事情。但至少，自媒体首次为钱德勒吹响近四个月的号角以来，这件事至少让 OSAF 的每个人都松了口气，感到振奋。

It didn’t do much of anything. But it was something, at least, and after nearly four months since the media trumpets had first blown for Chandler, that gave everyone at OSAF some relief and a lift.

在程序员向自己发布这个版本的钱德勒的那天，我在喷泉边撞见了卡普尔。“我们正在做！” 他微笑着说道。“我们实际上是在开发软件！”

On the day the programmers released this version of Chandler to themselves, I bumped into Kapor by the water fountain. “We’re doing it!” he said with a smile. “We’re actually developing software!”





几个月前，当每个人都认为进展会更快时，卡普尔同意在 4 月份的 O'Reilly 新兴技术会议上发表有关钱德勒的演讲，这是一场专注于点对点软件和其他新技术的行业活动。现在很明显，没有机会在这次活动中及时完成钱德勒的新存储库。但这次会议仍然可以作为一个有用的最后期限，帮助推动开发人员为酝酿已久的首次公开发布做好准备。

Months earlier, when everyone thought progress would be swifter, Kapor had agreed to deliver a presentation about Chandler in April at the O’Reilly Emerging Technology Conference, an industry event focused on peer-to-peer software and other new technologies. Now it was clear there was no chance of finishing Chandler’s new repository in time for that event. But the conference could still serve as a useful deadline, helping to push the developers into gear for the long-brewing initial public release.

已经有更多可用的代码：除了 Parlante 的日历和 Hertzfeld 的地址簿之外，产品经理 Chao Lam 在业余时间制作了一个 Chandler“包裹”或附加程序，用于阅读博客文章的提要，称为 RSS 提要。他将其称为《早报》，取自中文“报纸”的意思。《早报》首次展示了钱德勒的“可扩展性”——该程序将超越传统的 PIM 世界（包括电子邮件、日历、任务和地址），并允许程序员编写扩展，以便用户可以在一个程序中组织各种信息。无筒仓计划。如果您读到一篇关于早报活动的博客文章，并想将其发送给朋友或将其添加到您的日历上，该怎么办？在钱德勒你就能做到这一点。无需剪切和粘贴，无需从一个程序切换到另一个程序。

There was already more code on tap: In addition to Parlante’s calendar and Hertzfeld’s address book, Chao Lam, the product manager, had whipped up in his spare time a Chandler “parcel,” or add-on program, for reading feeds of blog posts, known as RSS feeds. He called it Zaobao after the Chinese word for newspaper. Zaobao offered the first glimpse of Chandler’s “extensibility”—the idea that the program would go beyond the traditional PIM world of email, calendar, tasks, and addresses, and allow programmers to write extensions so that users could organize all sorts of information in one silo-less program. What if you read a blog post about an event in Zaobao and wanted to send it to a friend or turn it into an entry on your calendar? You’d be able to do it right in Chandler. No cut-and-paste, no switching from one program to another.

凉爽的！但仍然非常非常遥远。作品中还有其他一些新颖的功能：即使没有新的存储库，Hertzfeld 也找到了一种方法，通过采用名为 Jabber 的开源即时消息协议，在 Chandler 用户之间进行一些基本的共享。但大多数情况下，卡普尔和钱德勒的其他工作人员看到，公众看到的钱德勒的第一个版本不会太令人印象深刻。这在开源世界中很常见，其中的规范是一旦有代码就将其发布，并在可能吸引的任何志愿者的帮助下继续在公众视野中进行工作。但 OSAF 在首次宣布钱德勒的职位时就雄心勃勃地投入了资金。现在，六个月后，开发人员担心他们会让那些发送了令人鼓舞的信息和建议的邮件列表旁观者失望。

Cool! But still very, very far off. There were a few other novel features in the works: Even without a new repository, Hertzfeld had found a way to rig some rudimentary sharing between Chandler users by adopting an open source instant-messaging protocol called Jabber. But mostly, Kapor and the rest of the Chandler crew saw, the first version of Chandler that the public would glimpse was not going to be too impressive. That was common enough in the open source world, where the norm was to put code out as soon as you had any and keep working on it in full public view with the aid of any volunteers you might attract. But OSAF had put an ambitious stake in the ground when it first announced Chandler; now, six months later, the developers feared they were going to let down the throngs of mailing list onlookers who had sent in encouraging messages and suggestions.

在 3 月底的一次会议上，最近加入 OSAF 管理编程团队的 Michael Toy 宣称：“此版本的目标是证明 OSAF 内部有生命力。”

At a meeting late in March, Michael Toy, who had recently joined OSAF to manage the programming team, declared, “The goal of this release is to demonstrate that there is life inside OSAF.”

“智能生活，”安迪·赫茨菲尔德插话道。

“Intelligent life,” Andy Hertzfeld interjected.

“好吧，”玩具回答道。“只要它还活着并且有生长的迹象，它就不需要有用。”

“Right,” Toy responded. “It does not need to be useful as long as it’s living and showing signs of growing.”

“还有智力，”赫茨菲尔德重复道。

“And intelligence,” Hertzfeld repeated.





Chandler 0.1 作为第一个公开版本，于 2003 年 4 月 21 日下午 3:07 在 OSAF 的服务器上上线。米。太平洋时间。在二十四小时之内，它就被下载了一万五千次。

Chandler 0.1, as the first public release was labeled, went live on OSAF’s servers on April 21, 2003, at 3:07 P.M. Pacific time. Within twenty-four hours it had been downloaded fifteen thousand times.

它与第一个内部版本相比有了一些发展。您可以将约会添加到日历中，并将姓名和地址添加到联系人列表中。但它仍然很粗糙、缓慢，而且没什么用处。当你启动它时，打开的屏幕声明：“请理解，我们的底层数据库目前正在经历巨大的变化。我们现在使用的东西将来不会使用。这意味着”——此处文本变为红色——“你还不应该在 Chandler 中存储重要信息。”

It had evolved a bit from the first internal release. You could add appointments to the calendar, and names and addresses to the contact list. But it remained crude, slow, and not very usable for anything. When you started it up, the opening screen declared: “Please understand that our underlying database is undergoing massive changes at the moment. What we’re using now will not be what we use in the future. This means that”—here the text shifts to red—“you should not store important information in Chandler yet.”

卡普尔在他的博客中写道：“我一直将 Chandler 0.1 称为我们的‘超声波’释放：胎儿在子宫外无法存活，但如果你仔细观察，你可以看到细小的手臂和腿在周围挥舞，你可以相信它最终会变成一个真正的婴儿。”

Kapor wrote on his blog: “I’ve been referring to Chandler 0.1 as our ‘ultrasound’ release: the fetus won’t be viable outside the womb, but if you look closely you can see tiny arms and legs waving around and you can believe it’s going to turn into a real baby eventually.”





大约在 0.1 版本发布的同时，Kapor 将 Rys McCusker 叫到他的办公室，告诉他事情进展不顺利。钱德勒需要一个存储库，但他只是没有完成它。

Around the same time as the 0.1 release, Kapor called Rys McCusker into his office and told him that things weren’t working out. Chandler needed a repository, and he just wasn’t getting it done.

事实上，在上个月，麦卡斯克起草了最终的存储库设计，似乎消除了安德森和蒙图利所倡导的替代方法之间的差异。ZODB 的首席开发人员访问了 OSAF 进行了几天的咨询。关于 ZODB 如何与 Montulli 的存储库访问协议一起工作，存在一些挥之不去的问题，对 ZODB 的可靠性和效率的一些疑虑，以及一些对其代码很难让外人掌握的担忧。但至少有一个计划。

In the previous month, actually, McCusker had drawn up a final repository design that seemed to cut the difference between the alternative approaches that Anderson and Montulli had advocated. The lead developer for ZODB had visited OSAF for a couple of days’ consulting. There were some lingering questions about how ZODB would work with Montulli’s Repository Access Protocol, some qualms about ZODB’s reliability and efficiency, and some concerns that its code was hard for outsiders to grasp. But at least there was a plan.

尽管如此，在实际构建工作存储库方面进展甚微。考虑到麦卡斯克过去几个月生活中发生的一切，这也许并不奇怪。卡普尔告诉程序员，你几乎可以将他视为残疾案例。不管是什么原因，事情就是没有进展。

Still, there was little progress toward actually building a working repository. Given everything that had happened in McCusker’s life over the previous months, that was perhaps not surprising. You could almost think of his as a disability case, Kapor told the programmer. Whatever the cause, things just weren’t working out.

麦卡斯克回家后在他的博客上写道：“我不明白为什么我有时被描述为数据库专家，尽管我定期否认这样的描述。但我注意到我的继任者往往被描述为数据库专家，而我不知道我应该是这样的。一般来说，我做了很多管道工作，其中涉及在内存内部以及内存和辅助存储之间移动字节，这通常具有数据库的特征。但我不是数据库专家。”

McCusker went home and later posted on his blog: “I don’t understand why I am sometimes described as a database expert, despite the fact I disclaim such a description periodically. But I’ve noticed my replacement tends to be described as a database guru, and I had no idea that’s what I was supposed to be. I do a lot of plumbing in general, which involves moving bytes around inside memory and between memory and secondary storage, which typically has the character of a database. But an expert on databases I’m not.”

OSAF 现在开始寻找数据库专家。

An expert on databases was what OSAF now began seeking.





这是 2003 年 5 月 21 日，作为旨在驯服 Chandler 的“蛇”（这些看似无法解决的问题）的为期一周的系列会议的一部分，开发人员再次聚集在贝尔蒙特白板前讨论存储库。迈克尔·托伊主持。桌上出现了一张新面孔：Andi Vajda，他是前一天开始担任 OSAF 存储库开发人员的。

It’s May 21, 2003, and as part of the weeklong series of meetings aimed at taming Chandler’s “snakes,” problems that seemed beyond solution, the developers gather once more in front of the Belmont whiteboard to talk about the repository. Michael Toy presides. There’s one new face at the table: Andi Vajda, who started the day before as OSAF’s repository developer.

“这可能是这些会议中最长或最短的一次，”托伊开始说道。“我相信我们的 Chandler 数据存储解决方案有以下目标。” 他在黑板上画了一个轮廓：

“This has the potential for being the longest or the shortest of these meetings,” Toy begins. “I believe we have the following goals for our Chandler data storage solution.” He sketches an outline on the board:



(1)为程序员提供与用户一样革命性的数据模型。

(1) Provide programmers with as revolutionary a data model as users.

(2) 数据可以存在于任何地方。

(2) Data can live anywhere.

(3) 数据不会被损坏。

(3) Data is safe from corruption.

(4)数据获取快。

(4) Data is quick to get.

(5)数据可能很大。

(5) Data can be large.



蒙图利反对革命这个词；他认为这带有炒作的味道。赫茨菲尔德指出，按照第一点的措辞方式，你可以为两个群体提供一个平庸的解决方案，但仍然“满足”要求。

Montulli objects to the word revolutionary; he thinks it reeks of hype. Hertzfeld points out that the way the first point is phrased, you could get away with providing both groups with a mediocre solution and still “meet” the requirement.

卡普尔有点不耐烦了：“这太不符合逻辑了。”

Kapor gets a little impatient: “That’s logic-chopping.”

“我们之所以能走到今天，是因为我们有远大的目标，”托伊继续说道。“我们的部分困难在于没有平等地重视这些目标。但对于这份名单本身并没有任何分歧。最担心的是目标根本无法实现。我们确实有一个拟议的设计。它有一些洞。是时候讨论这些漏洞了，并确保我们有计划来填补这些漏洞，这样，只要我还活着，我们就不会再在数据这个词从我们嘴里说出来时翻白眼了。这是必须杀死的蛇。”

“We got here by having high goals,” Toy continues. “Part of our struggle is in not valuing the goals equally. But there’s no disagreement over the list itself. The biggest fear is that the goals are simply not meetable. We do have a proposed design. It’s got some holes. It’s time to talk about those holes and make sure we have plans to fill those holes so that never again, as long as I live, do we roll our eyes when the word data comes out of our mouths. This is the snake that must be killed.”

“在这次会议上，”赫茨菲尔德说，“我们杀死了蛇——我们不仅仅是制定杀死蛇的计划。”

“And in this meeting,” Hertzfeld says, “we kill the snake—we don’t just make plans to kill the snake.”

“是的，”玩具回答。

“Yes,” Toy answers.

“龙身上有很多剑。”

“The dragon has many swords in it.”

“还有一些勇敢的骑士的尸体走进了火焰。”

“There’s also some bodies of brave knights who walked into the flames.”

卡普尔插话道：“听着，我们已经根据里斯的工作制定了一个临时计划，可以满足我们的要求。安迪昨天刚到这里，需要一些时间才能在虚线上签名。但我们不应该重新从第一原则开始。”

Kapor cuts in. “Look, we already have a provisional plan based on Rys’s work that will meet our requirements. Andi, having just got here yesterday, is going to want some time before he signs in blood on the dotted line. But we shouldn’t be starting from first principles all over again.”

程序员们开始讨论一直困扰着存储库问题的一系列问题：如何使存储库在网络上高效工作——例如，当您尝试加载 MP3 格式的歌曲等大文件时？您将如何保证存储库的安全？您将如何在存储库之间共享或保持家庭和办公室 Chandler 同步（开发人员有时将此问题称为“同步”，有时称为“复制”）？如果您想将“Chandler 本地数据”（Chandler 本身存储的信息）与来自其他程序的数据（例如电子邮件或地址）混合在一起怎么办？

The programmers begin to discuss the series of issues that had always hovered over the repository problem: How would you make a repository work efficiently across the Net—say, when you were trying to load a large file like a song in MP3 format? How would you keep repositories secure? How would you share between repositories or keep a home and office Chandler in sync (the developers sometimes referred to this issue as “synchronization” and other times as “replication”)? What if you wanted to mix “Chandler-native data” (information stored by Chandler itself ) with data—say, email or addresses—from other programs?

玩具在白板上的空间不足。“让我们将复制和外部数据视为目前我们还没有设计的东西，我们注定要这样做。”

Toy runs out of space on the whiteboard. “Let’s just identify replication and foreign data as things that, right now, we don’t have a design for, that we’re doomed on.”

卡普尔疲倦地揉着眼睛。“ Mah nishtanah halailah hazeh，”他引用了逾越节仪式上的问题。“正如他们所说，这个夜晚与其他夜晚有何不同？我多次踏入这部电影。今天是土拨鼠日。这有什么不同？

Kapor rubs his eyes wearily. “Mah nishtanah halailah hazeh,” he quotes the ritual Passover question. “How is this night different from all other nights, as they say? I’ve stepped into this movie at multiple points. It’s Groundhog Day. How is this different?”





卡普尔问题的答案就在他的对面。那年春天早些时候，Andi Vajda 接受了 OSAF 的面试，当时 Chandler 开发人员开始寻找编写该程序电子邮件组件的人。他的采访并没有让他们惊叹，但他们把他的名字记录在案。当他们需要雇用一名程序员来构建存储库时，Michael Toy 认为他可能是一个不错的选择。

One answer to Kapor’s question sat across the room from him. Andi Vajda had interviewed at OSAF earlier that spring when the Chandler developers had begun to look for someone to write the program’s email component. His interviews didn’t wow them, but they kept his name on file. When they needed to hire a programmer to build the repository, Michael Toy thought he might be a good match.

瓦伊达是个头脑灵活、情绪激动的人，眨眼时眨眼，说话带有奥地利家庭和法国青年时期的口音。和 OSAF 的几乎所有其他程序员一样，他在高中时就开始玩电脑了。毕业时，他已经破解了学校小型机的操作系统。“基本上，”他后来告诉我，“我所学到的关于操作系统、多任务处理、内存使用、硬盘驱动器、文件系统布局的所有知识都可以追溯到这些。当我在大学再次了解到它时，它已经是旧闻了。我想，‘是的，我以前见过这个。’”

Vajda is a bullet-headed, intense man with a twitchy blink and an accent marked by an Austrian family and a youth spent in France. Like just about every other programmer at OSAF, he had started playing with computers in high school. By the time he had graduated, he had hacked open the operating system for the school’s minicomputer. “Basically,” he later told me, “everything I’ve learned about operating systems, multitasking, memory usage, hard drives, file system layout, all of these things go back to that. When I learned it again in college, it was old news. I thought, ‘Yeah, I’ve seen this before.’”

当 Toy 向 Vajda 概述 OSAF 的存储库困境时，他又经历了一次“是的，我以前见过这个”的时刻。他在人工智能行业为一家名为 IntelliCorp 的公司工作了近十年，使用该领域流行的动态编程语言 Lisp。在 IntelliCorp 和后来的另外两家公司，他负责创建支持软件对象的灵活存储和检索的“动态对象系统”。

When Toy outlined OSAF’s repository quandary to Vajda, he had another “Yeah, I’ve seen this before” moment. He had spent nearly a decade working in the artificial intelligence industry for a company named IntelliCorp, using the dynamic programming language favored in that field, Lisp. At IntelliCorp and later at two other companies he had been responsible for creating “dynamic object systems” that supported the flexible storage and retrieval of software objects.

“这就是我的全部意义。如果你不给我一个对象系统，我会在某个地方放一个，因为我需要一个。这一切都可以追溯到 Lisp。来到 OSAF，我说，啊，这是另一个。他们需要一个动态的对象系统。我已经这样做过好几次了。。。。这并不是说，哦，这将是一个巧妙的研究项目，我很聪明，我可以解决这个问题。我已经想通了很多了。”

“This is what I’m all about. If you don’t give me an object system, I’ll put one someplace, because I need one somewhere. It all goes back to Lisp. Coming to OSAF, I said, Ahh, it’s another one of those. They need a dynamic object system. I had already done this several times . . . . It wasn’t like, oh, this is going to be a neat research project, I’m smart, I can figure this out. I’d figured out a lot of it already.”

软件行业有数十年关于“牛仔程序员”的传说，即抵制规则、喜欢独处、喜欢在边缘工作的程序员。对于很多管理者来说，牛仔程序员是一场噩梦；对于很多程序员来说，他们是英雄。尽管安迪·瓦伊达（Andi Vajda）并不完全符合陈词滥调，但不可否认的是，他构建钱德勒存储库的方法有一些牛仔风格。他说，他的目标很简单：“让我们让这些人摆脱困境。”

There are decades of lore in the software industry about the “cowboy coder,” the programmer who resists rules, prefers solitude, and likes to work on the edge. To a lot of managers, cowboy coders are a nightmare; to a lot of programmers, they are heroes. Though Andi Vajda didn’t perfectly fit the cliché, there was something undeniably cowboyish about his approach to building Chandler’s repository. His goal, he said, was simple: “Let’s get these people unstuck.”





对于 Vajda 来说，5 月 21 日的“消灭存储蛇”会议是对 OSAF 关于如何存储钱德勒数据的长期争论的即时回顾。他大部分时间都在听，但时不时也会伸出手来。

For Vajda the May 21 meeting to slay the repository snake is serving as a sort of instant recap of the long debate at OSAF over how to store Chandler’s data. He mostly listens, but every now and then he shows his hand.

“钱德勒的核心，”托伊说，“数据不会按层次结构自行组织。”

“The heart of Chandler,” Toy says, “is that data does not organize itself hierarchically.”

“哦，”瓦伊达打断道。“它会。当你一无所有时，你需要从某个地方开始。你需要一个根。”

“Oh,” Vajda interrupts. “It will. When you have nothing, you need to start somewhere. You need a root.”

“从用户界面的角度来看，”Katie Parlante 说，“没有主要的层次结构。”

“From the UI’s perspective,” Katie Parlante says, “there’s no primary hierarchy.”

“但必须有一个你开始的地方，”瓦伊达重复道。也许它只是出于内务管理的目的，也许它对机器很重要但对用户来说是隐藏的，但 Vajda 非常确定：如果没有某种层次结构，你就不会构建一个稳定的数据存储。

“But there has to be something where you start,” Vajda repeats. Maybe it’s only for housekeeping purposes, maybe it’s important to the machine but is hidden for the user, but Vajda is quite sure: You’re not going to build a stable data store without some sort of hierarchy.

第二天，瓦伊达上台发言，开始构思他的想法，以摆脱存储库停滞状态。他宣称，最重要的是就钱德勒“数据模型”达成一致——程序将用于存储数据的确切结构的定义。一旦设置完毕，他就可以开始构建存储库。

The next day Vajda takes the floor and begins diagramming his idea for a way to move past the repository standstill. The most important thing, he declares, is to get agreement on the Chandler “data model”—the definitions of the exact structures the program will use to store data. Once that’s set, he can go off and start building a repository.

在接下来的几周里，一个小组——Vajda、Anderson、Parlante 和最近加入该项目的志愿者 Brian Skinner——每天开会并就某些事情达成一致。他们重申，钱德勒数据模型的核心是“项目”。项目实际上可以是任何东西——对于用户来说，它可能是电子邮件、便笺或约会的特定实例；但它也可以代表程序本身机制的一部分，例如“某种”项目的定义（“电子邮件”或“便笺”或“约会”）。项目将以历史悠久的面向对象的方式形成继承层次结构。因此，如果一组项目中的每一个都被定义为某种“类型”的实例（例如，如果它们都是电子邮件），那么它们都将继承“电子邮件类型”项目的特征。所有项目都将存储在存储库中。

For the next few weeks a small group—Vajda, Anderson, Parlante, and Brian Skinner, a volunteer who had recently joined the project—met daily and agreed on certain things. The heart of Chandler’s data model would, they reaffirmed, be the “item.” An item could be virtually anything—to a user it might be a particular instance of an email, a note, or an appointment; but it could also represent part of the machinery of the program itself, like the definition of a “kind” of item (“email” or “note” or “appointment”). Items would, in time-honored object-oriented fashion, form a hierarchy of inheritance. Therefore, if each one of a group of items was defined as an instance of a certain “kind”—if they were all emails, for example—they would all inherit the characteristics of the “email kind” item. And all items would be stored in the repository.

这个选择让钱德“以项目为中心”，有几个含义。其中之一是，它决定性地将该程序移出了 RDF 的世界，当 Morgen Sagen 编写其第一个存储库时，Chandler 就出生在 RDF 世界中。在RDF中，数据存储的主要单位是“属性”；一个 Chandler 项目可能包含许多不同的属性（对于一封电子邮件，典型的属性可能是日期、发件人、主题行、正文等）。开发人员有时会说，更典型的面向对象项目方法与 RDF 基于属性的技术之间的区别就像物理领域之间的区别：项目就像原子；项目就像原子；项目就像原子；项目就像原子；项目就像原子。属性就像亚原子粒子。与原子水平以下的量子世界一样，开发人员担心基于 RDF 的数据存储会不稳定且不可预测。

This choice, to make Chander “item-centric,” had a couple of implications. One was that it moved the program decisively away from the world of RDF, where Chandler was born back when Morgen Sagen wrote its first repository. In RDF, the primary unit of data storage is an “attribute”; one Chandler item could contain lots of different attributes (for an email, typical attributes might be date, sender, subject line, body text, and so on). The difference between a more typical object-oriented item approach and RDF’s attribute-based technique, the developers sometimes said, was like the difference between realms of physics: Items were like atoms; attributes were like subatomic particles. And as with the quantum world below the atomic level, the developers feared that an RDF-based data store would be unstable and unpredictable.

决定让 Chandler 的存储库以项目为中心的另一个重大后果是，它让 Vajda 可以自由地选择或离开 ZODB。只要他能够保证 Anderson 和其他 Chandler 程序员能够使用该存储库来维护他们的 Python 代码和 Chandler 数据之间的关系，他如何安排这件事的发生并不重要。Vajda 并不倾向于使用 ZODB；他认为使用 ZODB 所依赖的同一较低级数据库 Berkeley DB 会更快、更简单、更好，并在其上编写自己的代码。这几乎正​​是 Lou Montulli 和 Aleks Totic 预测 OSAF 最终会做的事情。

The other big consequence of the decision to make Chandler’s repository item-centric was that it left Vajda free to take or leave ZODB. As long as he could guarantee that Anderson and the other Chandler programmers would be able to use the repository to maintain the relationships between their Python code and Chandler’s data, it didn’t really matter how he arranged for that to happen. And Vajda wasn’t leaning toward using ZODB; he figured it would be faster, simpler, and better to use the same lower-level database that ZODB relied on, the Berkeley DB, and write his own code on top of it. This was pretty nearly what Lou Montulli and Aleks Totic had predicted OSAF would end up doing.

“我什至从未看过 ZODB，”Vajda 后来回忆道。“时间压力很大。我可以重用 ZODB，但需要花一些时间来学习它。或者我可以重用我过去在动态对象系统方面的经验，然后只做一个。那是更快的路线。否则，我必须去解构 ZODB，弄清楚它是如何工作的，然后将 Chandlerness 映射到它上面。

“I never even took a look at ZODB,” Vajda later recalled. “There was intense time pressure. I could reuse ZODB, but it would take me a while to learn it. Or I could reuse my past experience in dynamic object systems and just do one. That was the faster route. Otherwise, I’d have to go and deconstruct ZODB, figure out how it does things, and then map Chandlerness onto it.

“而且对存储库也有很多严格的要求；它必须进行共享和复制。我确信我们可以使用 ZODB 来完成这些任务，但如果我能完全控制，我可以更快、更好、更适合 Chandler 的需求。ZODB 的另一件事是，它是 Python。如果明天我们需要 Python 以外的东西，我们就会被淘汰。我喜欢灵活地设计东西，这样如果需求发生变化或发生我们没有预料到的变化，我们可以扭转局面并说它也能做到这一点。

“And also there were a lot of steep requirements on the repository; it was going to have to do sharing and replication. I’m sure we could do them with ZODB, but if I’m in full control, I can do them quicker and maybe better, more appropriately for Chandler’s needs. Another thing with ZODB was, it’s Python. If tomorrow we need something that’s not Python, we’re hosed. I like to design stuff nimbly so that if the requirements change or something changes that we didn’t expect, we can turn it around and say it can do that, too.

“这不是一个政治决定。它甚至不是一个不是在这里发明的东西。这是一种生存决定。我们说过我们现在需要一些非常快的东西。我知道该怎么做。佐德布？我不需要它。”

“It wasn’t a political decision. It wasn’t even a not-invented-here thing. It was sort of a survival decision. We said we need something really quick, now. I know how to do this. ZODB? I don’t need it.”

掌握了 Chandler 数据模型的基本设计后，Vajda 就做好了准备。六月中旬，他前往法国与家人和亲戚一起度过了一个月。当他回来时，他已经开始建造钱德勒的资料库。在接下来的几个月里，他将完成“第一版”或版本。它仍然缺少很多部分，但它有一个可用的顶层或 API——程序员开始编写在存储库中实际存储和检索项目的 Chandler 代码所需的关键命令和数据定义。

With the fundamental design of the Chandler data model in hand, Vajda was ready. In mid-June he left to spend a month in France with his family and relatives. By the time he returned, he had built the beginnings of Chandler’s repository. Over the next couple of months he would finish the “first rev,” or version. It was still missing a lot of its parts, but it had a usable top layer, or API—the key commands and data definitions the programmers needed to begin writing Chandler code that actually stored and retrieved items in the repository.





电影《侏罗纪公园》中有一个简短的场景，夹在狂暴的霸王龙的画面之间，除非您是一名计算机程序员，否则可能不会给您留下太多印象。小女孩女主人公正坐在恐龙狂奔主题公园控制室的电脑屏幕前，试图弄清楚如何打开安全系统。她看了一秒钟，然后惊呼道：“这是一个 Unix 系统。我知道这个！” 至少在接下来的九十秒里，这一天被拯救了。

There’s a brief scene in the movie Jurassic Park, sandwiched between tableaux of a rampaging Tyrannosaurus rex, that probably didn’t make much of an impression on you unless you’re a computer programmer. The little girl heroine is sitting in front of a computer screen in the control room of the dinosaurs-run-amok theme park, trying to figure out how to turn on a security system. She looks at it for a second and then exclaims, “This is a Unix system. I know this!” The day is saved, at least for the next ninety seconds.

全世界观众中的程序员为她欢呼——不仅仅是因为这部电影向大学黑客和企业数据中心青睐的操作系统致敬。他们欢呼的另一个原因是，他们都有过类似的顿悟时刻——当一些紧急或棘手的问题突然成为焦点，成为熟悉、平易近人、易于管理的问题时，他们就意识到了这一点。我知道这个问题。我以前来过这里。我可以用这个。

Programmers in audiences all over the world cheered her—and not just because of the movie’s tip of the hat to the operating system favored by university hackers and corporate data centers. They also cheered because they had all had similar eureka moments—instants of recognition when some urgent or intractable problem flashes into focus as something familiar, approachable, and manageable. I know this problem. I’ve been here before. I can work with this.

Andi Vajda 出现在 OSAF，环顾四周，经历了这样的时刻，然后开始编写代码。他一下子就驳回了数月来关于 ZODB 的争论。插入式乐高零件并不能解决这个问题。他确信他可以自己建造它，而且更好更快。然后他就出发并实现了这一目标。有点鲁莽了。不可否认，这也是令人振奋的。它将 Chandler 团队从软件时代的低迷中拉了出来，回到了渐进式进步的世界。

Andi Vajda showed up at OSAF, looked around, experienced such a moment, and began writing code. In a trice he dismissed months of wrangling over ZODB. A plug-in Lego part wasn’t going to cut it. He was certain he could build it himself, better and faster. And he went off and made it happen. It was a little brash. It was also undeniably galvanizing. It pulled the Chandler team out of its software-time doldrums and back into the world of incremental progress.

OSAF 的其他开发人员还需要一段时间才能知道 Vajda 的信心是否有根据。但至少他们有了一个存储库的雏形。至少他们没有被困住。

It would be some time before the other developers at OSAF could know whether Vajda’s confidence was warranted. But at least they had the beginnings of a repository. At least they were unstuck.

第 5 章                           

CHAPTER 5                           

管理狗和极客

MANAGING DOGS AND GEEKS

[2003 年 4 月至 8 月]

[APRIL–AUGUST 2003]

这条消息很神秘：

The message was cryptic:



1'WQE

1'WQE



2003 年夏天的一天早上，在 OSAF，这些角色出现在我的屏幕上。我没有输入它们。钱德勒做到了——钱德勒是一只狗，它跑进了一个会议，我正在做笔记，他把鼻子戳到了我的键盘上。我很惊讶，但我不能说我很惊讶。钱德勒是米奇·卡普尔的两只拉布拉多犬之一，而拉布拉多犬则在办公室里占据着主导地位。

One morning at OSAF in the summer of 2003, those characters appeared on my screen. I did not type them. Chandler did—Chandler the dog, that is, who had run into a meeting where I was taking notes and poked his snout onto my keyboard. I was startled, but I can’t say I was surprised. Chandler was one of Mitch Kapor’s two labradoodles, and the labradoodles had the run of the office.

钱德勒（Chandler）和科斯莫（Cosmo），牛奶咖啡色，不可抑制，是名副其实的办公室圈子里的顶尖狗——其中包括西吉（Siggy），一只活泼的白色比熊犬，总是在寻找崇拜者；佩妮（Petunia），一只摇摇晃晃、抽鼻子的英国斗牛犬，会坐在主人的办公桌旁守护；波特，一只巧克力拉布拉多犬，总是在寻找食物；还有至少十几只旋转的犬类模型。OSAF 于 2003 年 7 月从贝尔蒙特搬到霍华德街的挖掘点，该挖掘点适合养狗。这让 OSAF 以及共享办公空间的相关企业的许多狗主人感到高兴。不养狗的人有时看起来像少数人，但并不总是那么兴奋。

Chandler and Cosmo, café-au-lait-colored and irrepressible, were the top dogs in a veritable office pound—including Siggy, a skittery white bichon frise, always looking for admirers; Petunia, a waddling, snuffling English bulldog who would sit guard by her owner’s desk; Porter, a chocolate Labrador who was always on the prowl for chow; and a rotating canine cast of at least a dozen more. The Howard Street digs that OSAF had moved to from Belmont in July 2003 were dog-friendly. That elated the many dog owners at OSAF and the related enterprises that shared the office space. Non–dog owners, who sometimes seemed like a minority, were not always quite as thrilled.

当时，拉布拉多犬（拉布拉多犬和标准贵宾犬的杂交品种）正处于成为流行品种的风口浪尖。它们是很好的宠物：“它们与其他狗相处得很好，”一份描述称。“非常聪明、善于交际且快乐。快速学习不寻常或特殊的任务。活跃，有时有点滑稽。如果不遵守纪律，可能会试图智取主人。”

At that time labradoodles—a cross between a Labrador and a standard poodle—were right on the cusp of becoming a trendy breed. They made fine pets: “They get along well with other dogs,” one description reported. “Extremely clever, sociable, and joyful. Quick to learn unusual or special tasks. Active, a little comical at times. Can attempt to outsmart their owners if undisciplined.”

钱德勒是否不守纪律？好吧，他有时会在地毯上留下几码长的湿迹。一天下午，他选择了办公室的一个角落交押金；不久之后，楼下招聘公司的老板想知道是什么东西滴到了她的桌子上。钱德勒和科斯莫时不时地会在办公室的圆形平面图周围追逐，进出大会议室，OSAF 的开发人员可能正在那里讨论程序架构的一些细节。如果房间的入口被堵住，狗就会像攻城锤一样扑向双门。

Was Chandler undisciplined? Well, he would sometimes leave his mark in yards-long wet trails across the carpet. One afternoon he chose a corner of the office for a deposit; not long after, the owner of the recruiting firm on the floor below wondered what was dripping onto her desk. Every now and then Chandler and Cosmo would lead a chase around the office’s circular floor plan, into and out of the big meeting room where OSAF’s developers might be hashing out some fine point of program architecture. If the room’s entrance was blocked, the dogs would hurl themselves at the double doors like battering rams.

最重要的是，有狗在身边很有趣。他们让这个地方变得温暖起来，在幸福的无知中嬉戏，而这些协议、接口和数据模型却在附近人类的脑海中。但随着 OSAF 的员工不断壮大​​并占据更大的空间，对狗/程序员共存的自由放任方式就出现了问题。需要某种管理结构。在 OSAF 人力资源经理的主持下，成立了一个特别的“狗利益集团”委员会来处理此事。

Mostly, it was fun to have the dogs around. They warmed up the place a bit, frolicking in blissful ignorance of the protocols and interfaces and data models that were on the minds of the nearby human beings. But as OSAF’s staff grew and occupied a larger space, a laissez-faire approach to dog/ programmer coexistence became problematic. Some sort of management structure was needed. A special “dog interest group” committee formed, under the aegis of OSAF’s human resources manager, to deal with the matter.

这是不可避免的权衡：狗的主人，包括老板，都希望他们的狗在身边。程序员需要集中注意力。但一些程序员喜欢和他们的狗一起工作，而另一些程序员则觉得这种干扰令人厌烦。对狗友好的工作场所是一个优势，但前提是狗主人对狗的越轨行为和事故负责。

There were inevitable trade-offs: Dog owners, and that included the boss, wanted to have their dogs around. Programmers needed to concentrate. But some of the programmers loved to work with their dogs around, while others found the distraction irksome. A dog-friendly workplace was a plus, but only if dog owners took responsibility for their dogs’ escapades and accidents.

狗兴趣小组承诺每两周举行一次会议，并设立专门的匿名“狗频道”电子邮件地址，用于报告狗的不当行为。一些办公空间被正式指定为无狗区。

The dog interest group undertook to hold biweekly meetings and set up a special anonymous “dog channel” email address for reporting dog misbehavior. Some office spaces were officially designated as dog-free zones.

权衡并不容易。但是，如果不做出一些艰难的选择，你怎么能指望完成任何事情呢？

The trade-offs weren’t easy. But how could you expect to accomplish anything without making some hard choices?





从这个新生的软件项目中获得了自己的名字后，钱德勒狗将继续在一系列威廉·韦格曼风格的肖像中，将他深情的面孔出现在钱德勒程序的连续版本的启动屏幕上：安全帽（警告——施工区），钱德勒穿着实验室外套（“现在可以在实验中使用”），钱德勒的脸出现在日历上（程序的日历有效！）。狗不可避免地成为了软件项目的吉祥物和象征。

Having acquired his name from the nascent software project, Chandler-the-pooch would go on to lend his soulful face to the start-up screen of successive editions of Chandler-the-program in a sequence of William Wegman–style portraits: Chandler in a hard hat (warning—construction zone), Chandler in a lab coat (“now experimentally usable”), Chandler’s face on a calendar (the program’s calendar works!). The dog inevitably became mascot and symbol for the software project.

快速学习不寻常或特殊的任务。如果不守纪律，可能会试图智取主人。拉布拉多还是程序员？将“所有者”称为“经理”，其重叠程度是惊人的。通常，当人们用动物的角度讨论管理程序员的问题时，比较的不是狗训练，而是“放牧猫”。人们普遍认为，程序员是顽固的个人主义者。重复和卷起的报纸并不能解决这个问题。他们需要哄、抚摸，需要追老鼠，需要打虫子。

Quick to learn unusual or special tasks. Can attempt to outsmart their owners if undisciplined. Labradoodle or programmer? Say “managers” for “owners,” and the overlap is striking. Typically, when people discuss the problem of managing programmers in animal terms, the comparison is not to dog training but rather to “herding cats.” Programmers, the stereotype goes, are stubborn individualists. Repetition and rolled-up newspapers aren’t going to do the job; they need coaxing and stroking, mice to chase, and bugs to swipe.

狗管理和软件管理的共同点是不可避免的权衡。当你选择把一个目标放在首位时——一只遵守纪律的小狗？一个赶在最后期限前完成任务的程序员？——你发现你必须牺牲其他东西。在软件世界中，出现的大多数选择都归结为一种特别令人心碎的三向权衡。乐观者称之为质量三角；对于悲观主义者来说，这是不可能的三角形。不管怎样，这通常都是坏消息。

What dog management and software management share is the inevitability of trade-offs. When you choose to place one goal foremost—a disciplined pup? a deadline-meeting coder?—you find you must sacrifice something else. In the software world, most of the choices that arise boil down to one particularly heartbreaking three-way trade-off. Optimists call it the quality triangle; to pessimists it’s the impossible triangle. Either way, it’s usually bad news.

我第一次从一位名叫丹·谢弗（Dan Shafer）的资深软件开发人员和作家那里听到了这个原则，他在早期加入沙龙，试图让我们雄心勃勃但天真的记者团队跟上技术速度。当我们对 Table Talk（我们在软件正常运行之前草率打开的在线会议系统）的工作速度感到困惑时，他会靠在椅子上，揉揉他的佛肚，说：“有一个古老的系统。”说：我可以为你做的又快又便宜或者好。任选两个。”

I first heard this principle from a veteran software developer and author named Dan Shafer who had come on board Salon in the early days to try to bring our ambitious but naive crew of journalists up to technical speed. When we scratched our heads about how slow work was going on Table Talk, an online conferencing system we had rashly opened before the software was working right, he would lean back in his chair, rub his buddha belly, and say, “There’s an old saying: I can make it for you fast, cheap, or good. Pick any two.”

你不可能在任何工程领域长期工作而不遇到这个痛苦的公式，但它是在软件世界中，具有无限可塑的形式，难以衡量的成本，以及类似绝望的感觉。随着时间的推移，质量三角已经完全发挥作用。就像商业上的所有坏消息一样，它会招致管理者的抵制，他们决心证明他们的组织可以成为规则的例外。他们可以拥有一切——好、快、便宜。

You can’t labor long in any engineering realm without encountering this painful formula, but it is in the world of software, with its infinitely plastic form, its difficult-to-measure costs, and its Slough-of-Despond-like sense of time, that the quality triangle has fully come into its own. And like all bad news in business, it invites pushback from managers determined to prove that their organizations can be the exception to the rule. They can have it all—good, fast, and cheap.

程序员喜欢网格。以下是如何绘制质量三角形的选择：

Programmers love grids. Here is how one might map out the quality triangle’s choices:





但这个网格只提供了一个非此即彼的画面，一组绝对的二元权衡。在实践中，管理者面临的更像是一个带有链接滑块的混合板。您决定多花一点钱，将成本杠杆从“便宜”调整为“昂贵”？您会发现，这将使质量杠杆远离“蹩脚”而更接近“完美”。如果您还想提高速度，则必须进一步提高成本或再次降低质量。

But this grid offers only an either-or picture, a set of absolute binary trade-offs. In practice, what managers face is more like a mixing board with linked sliders. You’ve decided to spend a little more money, easing the Cost lever over from “cheap” to “expensive”? That, you’ll find, will nudge the Quality lever a bit farther from “crappy” and closer to “perfect.” If you want to increase the speed as well, you’ll have to push Cost even higher or push Quality back again.

但是，只有当项目组织得足以对有关成本、进度、功能或质量的决策作出可预测的响应时，经理才能坐在控制台前移动这些滑块。通常，管理软件开发的工作更为原始——努力从虚无中唤起秩序，回答诸如“我们从哪里开始？”之类的问题。以及“我们如何知道我们什么时候完成了？”，以及将顽固的团队的能量集中到一个共同的目标上。

But a manager gets to sit down at that console and move those sliders around only if a project is organized enough to respond predictably to decisions about cost and schedule and features or quality. Frequently, the work of managing software development is more primordial—an effort to summon order from a void, to answer questions like “Where do we begin?” and “How do we know when we’re done?,” and to marshal the energies of a refractory group toward a shared target.





有一天，OSAF 的一些狗身上涂了一些抗跳蚤粘液。它们的主人在狗的背上贴了小纸条警告：“已经进行了跳蚤治疗——不要抚摸我！”

One day some of the OSAF dogs got coated with some antiflea goop. Their owners attached little paper notes to the dogs’ backs warning: “Treated for fleas—don’t pet me!”

卡普尔路过，读了其中一张纸条，笑了。“如果人们也能做到这一点，那不是很好吗？” 他开玩笑说。“佩戴‘我今天脾气暴躁’之类的标语。“我一直很糟糕。” 这将消除人际关系中的所有模糊性。我完全赞成！”

Kapor passed by, read one of the notes, and smiled. “Wouldn’t it be great if people could do that, too?” he joked. “Wear signs like ‘I’m grumpy today.’ ‘I’ve been bad.’ It would take all the ambiguity out of human relations. I’m all for it!”





2002年3月冬天，关于钱德勒后防线的争论没过多久，卡普尔就确信他需要聘请一名经理。需要制定时间表。需要做出决定，然后坚持下去。需要采用、调整或发明流程。他在博客中写道：“我们已经太大了，无法使用‘瓦肯思维融合’方法进行工作。”

It wasn’t long into the tangled arguments over Chandler’s back end in the winter of 2002–3 that Kapor became convinced he needed to hire a manager. Schedules needed to be drawn up. Decisions needed to be made—and then made to stick. Processes needed to be adopted, adapted, or invented. He wrote on his blog, “We are already too large to work using the ‘Vulcan mind-meld’ methodology.”

卡普尔本人并不想要这份工作；他不认为自己会特别擅长。作为高级程序员和软件架构师，约翰·安德森（John Anderson）在一定程度上填补了这一角色，但他对于承担具体的管理任务缺乏信心：制定时间表，试图让程序员满足这些时间表，决定现在做什么以及什么要推迟到以后。他更喜欢沉思，而不是热衷，可能不是承担此类责任的最佳人选。而且，无论如何，他忙于制定技术决策和编写代码。

Kapor didn’t want the job himself; he didn’t think he would be especially good at it. As senior programmer and software architect, John Anderson had been partly filling this role, but he was diffident about assuming the nuts-and-bolts management tasks: drawing up schedules, trying to get programmers to meet those schedules, deciding what to do now and what to put off until later. He was more ruminative than gung-ho and might not be the best person for such responsibilities. And, anyway, he had his hands full making technical decisions and writing code.

2002 年底的圣诞假期期间，卡普尔在他的博客上发布了标题为“制定设计决策：一些原则”的文章。清单上的第一项是：“实施必须按顺序进行。在承诺推迟某些功能之前，这不是一个真正的项目。一次性做所有事情不是一个选择。”

Over the Christmas holidays at the end of 2002, Kapor posted to his blog under the heading “Making Design Decisions: Some Principles.” The first item on the list read: “Implementation must be sequenced. It’s not a real project until commitments are made to defer some capabilities. Doing everything at once is not an option.”

“一切”都很多。作为该项目最初发布的一部分，发布到 OSAF 网站上的功能摘要列出了分为 5 个类别的 36 个独立功能。仅电子邮件列表就包含十七个功能。其中一些功能（例如“通过全文索引进行快速搜索”、“附件内联查看”和“用户定义的视图、规则和过滤器”）是任何电子邮件程序的标准功能，尽管提供起来不一定简单。其他的——例如“用户脚本功能”、“在多个文件夹中归档消息”和“邮件的透明加密和身份验证”——代表了复杂的创新；它们要么以前从未尝试过，要么从未令人满意地交付。

“Everything” was a lot. The feature summary posted to the OSAF Web site as part of the project’s original unveiling listed thirty-six separate features grouped into five categories. The email list alone contained seventeen features. Some—such as “fast searching via full-text indexing,” “in-line viewing of attachments,” and “user-defined views, rules, and filters”—were standard for any email program, although not necessarily simple to provide. Others—such as “user-scripting capabilities,” “filing of messages in multiple folders,” and “transparent encryption and authentication of mail”—represented complex innovations; they had either never been tried before or never been delivered satisfactorily.

Kapor 和 OSAF 曾表示，Chandler 将允许用户以点对点模式轻松灵活地共享信息，无需依赖服务器，并同步程序及其数据的多个副本（例如，在家庭和工作之间） 。但钱德勒还需要为用户的重要信息提供安全保障。

Kapor and OSAF had said that Chandler would allow users to share information easily and flexibly in peer-to-peer mode, without relying on a server, and to synchronize multiple copies of the program and its data (for instance, between home and work). But Chandler also needed to offer security for users’ vital information.

它可以两者兼得吗？

Could it do both?

卡普尔和 OSAF 承诺，有一天，钱德勒将成为一名功能齐全的个人信息管理员，一个可以处理电子邮件、日历、地址、待办事项列表和随机笔记的 PIM。它还将是一个“可扩展的开发者平台”，向程序员发出开放式邀请，让他们改编 Chandler 来组织各种事物，包括音乐、照片、博客文章以及阳光下的任何其他事物。

Kapor and OSAF had promised that one day, Chandler would be a full-featured personal information manager, a PIM that handled email, calendar, addresses, to-do lists, and random notes. It would also be an “extensible developer platform,” giving programmers an open-ended invitation to adapt Chandler to organize all sorts of things, including music, photos, blog postings, and anything else under the sun.

两者皆可吗？

Could it be both?

钱德勒的开发人员将在开源模式下运作，他们的程序在公开场合一点一点地“迭代”构建。但卡普尔还决心制作一个看起来不错、运行速度快、感觉正确的程序。

Chandler’s developers were going to operate in open source mode with their program built “iteratively,” bit by bit, in public. But Kapor was also determined to produce a program that looked good, worked fast, and felt right.

他们可以两者兼得吗？

Could they do both?

随处可见，只有权衡。

Nothing but trade-offs, everywhere you looked.

在新经理到来之前，该项目无法推迟所有这些选择。这可能需要几周甚至几个月的时间。“在此期间，我们不能等待一位骑着白马的骑士到来，”卡普尔在给他的团队的一份备忘录中写道。他准备亲自解决一些权衡问题。随着存储库争论的拖延，他已经做出了一个重大选择：他将提前加载 Chandler 的基本 PIM 功能，例如电子邮件和日历，并搁置“开发者平台”功能，即 Chandler 的开放式功能允许程序员调整它来组织各种东西。这令人失望。毕竟，正是这些非常类似于议程的特征让钱德勒充满了兴奋，并为在线社区带来了活力。但他们必须等待。正如 Kapor 所说，OSAF 不会试图同时做所有事情并不可避免地失败，而是会尝试专注于开发一个良好的 PIM，其中包含一些比竞争对手“明显更好”的“杀手级功能”，从而“让采用变得有价值”。将其放在他的“做出设计决策”帖子中。

The project couldn’t put all these choices off until the arrival of the new manager. That could take weeks or even months. “In the interim, we mustn’t be waiting for a knight to ride in on a white horse,” Kapor wrote in a memo to his team. And he was ready to resolve some of the trade-offs himself. As the repository debate dragged on, he had already made one big choice: He would front-load Chandler’s basic PIM functions, like email and calendars, and put on hold the “developer platform” features, the open-ended aspects of Chandler that would allow programmers to adapt it for organizing all kinds of stuff. This was disappointing; after all, those were the very Agenda-like traits that had infused Chandler with excitement and charged up the online community. But they would have to wait. Instead of trying to do everything at once and inevitably failing, OSAF would try to focus on producing a good working PIM—with a handful of “killer features” that were “radically better” than the competition to “make adoption worthwhile,” as Kapor put it in his Making Design Decisions posting.

但即使将选项范围缩小到几个杀手级功能，OSAF 仍然有一个广阔的选择范围，并且可能会迷失方向。卡普尔发布了这份“候选杀手级功能”列表：强大、透明的安全性；代理架构；议程式的灵活性；[在这里添加你最喜欢的]。” 最后的空白是对现实的让步——钱德勒的计划还有很长的路要走——以及灵活性的声明，以及如果出现一个伟大的新想法，决心抓住机会的声明。这也是一扇敞开的门，各种延误都可能进入其中。

But even narrowing the options to a few killer features still left OSAF with a wide-open field of choices to make, and maybe get lost in. Kapor posted this list of “killer feature candidates”: “sharing; robust, transparent security; agent architecture; Agenda-like flexibility; [add your favorite here].” The final blank was a concession to reality—Chandler’s planning still had a long way to go—and a statement of flexibility, of determination to seize the opportunity if a great new idea should come along. It was also an open door into which all manner of delays might walk.





寻找 OSAF 软件开发经理的工作并不顺利。尽管这样的工作具有权威性，但它并不是许多程序员渴望从事的工作。有些人从《呆伯特》漫画的世界中汲取灵感——其中的倒刺针对的是典型的、白痴的“尖头发老板”（PHB，喜欢缩写的程序员对这个人物的称呼）——并积极抵制整个概念，视任何以经理头衔为障碍的人。（一位程序员在程序员网站上发帖，疲倦地写道，“我的痛苦的名字是……经理。”）其他人接受良好管理的价值，但对自己承担这项工作的前景感到尖叫。

The search for OSAF’s software development manager did not go quickly. Although such a job carries authority, it is not one that many programmers aspire to fill. Some take their cue from the world of the Dilbert comic strip—with its barbs aimed at the archetypal, moronic “pointy-haired boss,” or PHB, as acronym-loving programmers came to refer to the figure—and actively resist the whole concept, viewing anyone who takes the title of manager as an obstacle. (One programmer posting on a coders’ site wearily put it, “The name for my pain is . . . managers.”) Others accept the value of having good management but run screaming from the prospect of taking on the job themselves.

随着搜寻的进行，卢·蒙图利和亚历克斯·托蒂奇提出了一个来自网景时代的名字。迈克尔·托伊 (Michael Toy) 是硅谷图形公司 (Silicon Graphics) 的一批员工之一，当克拉克决定创办一家新企业（后来成为网景公司）时，这些员工随其创始人吉姆·克拉克 (Jim Clark) 一起离开。在这个重新定义软件开发规范的时代，他带领公司的编程团队经历了几次浏览器大战的超高速周期，为新版本的快速发布建立了新基准。在评估软件开发经理时，他拥有真正唯一重要的资格：业绩记录。

As the hunt dragged on, Lou Montulli and Aleks Totic suggested a name from their Netscape days. Michael Toy had been one of a band of employees at Silicon Graphics who left with its founder, Jim Clark, when Clark decided to start a new venture that would turn into Netscape. He had led the company’s programming team through several hyperspeed cycles of the browser wars in an era that redefined the norms for software development, establishing new benchmarks for fast releases of new versions. He had what really was the only qualification that mattered when evaluating a software development manager: a track record.

Toy 是加利福尼亚州利弗莫尔人，从他在加州大学圣克鲁斯分校和伯克利分校的学生时代开始，他就一直在编程，在那里他与人合作编写了早期龙与地下城风格的电脑游戏经典《Rogue》。他为大学校园基于 Unix 的小型机构建了 Rogue，几年后他惊讶地发现它变得如此受欢迎。当 IBM PC 和 Macintosh 在 20 世纪 80 年代初和中期席卷整个行业时，Toy 和一些朋友创办了一家公司，将 Rogue 移植到新机器上。

Toy, a native of Livermore, California, had been programming all his life, from his student days at University of California–Santa Cruz and Berkeley, where he cowrote Rogue, an early Dungeons-and-Dragons–style computer game classic. He had built Rogue for the college campus’s Unix-based minicomputers and was surprised to find, a few years later, how popular it had become. When first the IBM PC and then the Macintosh took the industry by storm in the early and mid-1980s, Toy and some friends started a company to port Rogue to the new machines.

“当我在高中写出第一个计算机程序时，世界上所有其他的事情似乎就没那么有趣了，”他回忆道。“分解问题、向计算机解释、看着计算机按照你的指令去做的过程真的很有意义。当我大学毕业时，感觉就像——这是我从程序员那里听到的一个常见的故事——那些傻瓜付钱给我做我本来可以免费做的事情，如果他们知道的话。” 他停了下来，面无表情。“这种情况今天仍在继续。”

“Once I had written my first computer program in high school, then all other things in the world seemed a lot less interesting,” he recalls. “There was something really rewarding about the process of breaking problems down, explaining to the computer, watching the computer do what you told it to do. When I got out of college, it felt like—this is a common story I hear from programmers—the fools were paying me money to do what I would have done for free if only they had known.” He pauses, deadpan. “That still continues today.”

尽管网景的任何早期员工最终都获得了丰厚的奖金，但这些奖励不足以让其团队团结起来。当公司被微软（以及它自己的错误）所窒息时，托伊离开了，并暂时退出了软件业务。2003 年初，他并不完全确定自己想回来，但 OSAF 的机会符合他梦想工作清单上的每一项：“我喜欢开发数百万人将使用的软件的想法，它将出现在每个人的桌面。我认为浏览器在某种程度上未能兑现其承诺，因为浏览器说处理信息唯一有趣的事情就是查看它。。。。但事实证明，一旦你有了浏览器，你的下一步就是组织和交流信息，而浏览器永远不会发现这个有趣的问题，即使它立即变得明显，这将是交易。因此，自 1995 年半以来，我一直有兴趣去解决这个问题。但我不知道匆忙完成一份蹩脚工作的压力。如果我们有一些奢侈来做得更好，那就太好了，对吧？如果能开源那就太好了。”

Though any early employee of Netscape ended up with a financial jackpot, those rewards weren’t enough to hold its team together. Toy left as the company’s suffocation by Microsoft (and its own mistakes) began to look inevitable, and took a break from the software business. In early 2003, he wasn’t entirely sure he wanted to return, but the opportunity at OSAF fit every item on his dream job checklist: “I like the idea of working on software that millions of people will use, that will be on everyone’s desktop. I think that the browser failed in its promise in a certain way, because a browser says that the only thing interesting to do with information is to look at it . . . . But it turns out that as soon as you have the browser, your next step is to organize and communicate information, and browsers never picked up that interesting problem even when it became obvious right away that that was going to be the deal. And so it’s the problem that, since 1995 and a half, has been interesting to me to go solve. But I don’t know about the pressure to do a crappy job in a hurry. It’d be nice if we had some luxury to do a better job, right? And it’d be great to do it open source.”

托伊警告卡普尔，他觉得自己不太擅长人事方面的工作——教练、绩效评估等。卡普尔告诉他不要担心。他们会在这些事情上合作。

Toy warned Kapor that he felt he wasn’t very good at the personnel side of the job—coaching, performance reviews, and the like. Kapor told him not to worry; they’d work together on that stuff.

Toy 于 2003 年 3 月成立。他与刻板印象中的尖头老板截然相反。他把长发留在脑后，扎成马尾辫。他流露出一种忧郁的谦虚。他在网络上的个人主页上有一幅他自己的画，他是《绿野仙踪》中的稻草人，在会议上，他有时会打断他所监督的人，提出诸如“为我的小大脑再说一遍”或“让迈克尔更聪明”之类的要求。在他的个人博客上，他质疑自己的自由主义基督教信仰，在他在 OSAF 开设的新博客上，他发表了对管理程序员过程的想法。他的 OSAF 博客名为 Blogotomy，上面有这样一段铭文：“从程序员到经理的转变通常被描述为‘进行脑白质切除术’。” 这是一本由一个现在幸福快乐的转变者写的日记。”

Toy started in March 2003. He was the polar opposite of the stereotypical Pointy-Haired Boss. He kept his hair long in back, pulled into a ponytail. He exuded a glum modesty. His personal home page on the Web featured a painting of himself as the Scarecrow from The Wizard of Oz, and in meetings he sometimes interrupted the people he supervised with requests like “Say that again for my small brain” or “Make Michael smarter.” On his personal weblog he interrogated himself about his liberal Christian faith, and on the new blog he started at OSAF, he posted thoughts on the process of managing programmers. His OSAF blog, titled Blogotomy, carried this epigraph: “The transition from programmer to manager is often described as ‘getting the lobotomy.’ Here is a journal written by a now blissfully happy transformed individual.”

在他为一家名为“Undignified Labs”（一家为基督教音乐家提供的时髦录音室）的副业所维护的网站上，他发表了以下关于自己的声明：“迈克尔是你最不想打电话来帮助你粉刷房子的人，但是如果你想拆的话先打电话。”

On the Web site he maintained for a side venture called Undignified Labs—a funky recording studio for Christian musicians—he posted the following statement about himself: “Michael is the last person you would want to call to help you paint your house, but the first to call if you want to tear it down.”

OSAF 这两件事都没有做；如果说有什么不同的话，那就是它仍在努力浇筑房子的地基。托伊到达后需要完成的第一件事就是确定开发时间表。4 月份的 O'Reilly 会议为 Chandler 的 0.1（发音为“dot-one”）版本设定了最后期限；此后，团队所拥有的只是一份冗长的功能列表和几个月的开放时间，直到最终的 1.0（“one-dot-oh”）版本发布。

OSAF was doing neither of those; if anything, it was still trying to pour its house’s foundations. One of the first things Toy needed to accomplish when he arrived was to nail down a development schedule. The O’Reilly conference in April set a deadline for the 0.1 (pronounced “dot-one”) release of Chandler; after that, all the team had was a lengthy feature list and an open expanse of months leading to an eventual 1.0 (“one-dot-oh”) release.

卡普尔决定以雷蒙德·钱德勒在洛杉矶地区设定谜团的地点来命名不同版本的钱德勒。（为什么不使用钱德勒小说的名称？那么他们就会被贴着“长眠不醒”标签的产品所困。）因此，钱德勒 1.0——针对个人用户的初始全功能版本——将被称为 Canoga。该计划的第一个版本是为 OSAF 在大学领域的新合作伙伴设计的，名为 Westwood。更遥远的钱德勒 2.0，代号为帕萨迪纳，将专注于构建软件，以便其他公司可以为中小型企业定制它。

Kapor had decided to name the different versions of Chandler after locations in the Los Angeles area where Raymond Chandler set his mysteries. (Why not use the names of Chandler novels? Then they’d be stuck with a product labeled The Big Sleep.) So Chandler 1.0—an initial, full-featured version aimed at individual users—would be referred to as Canoga. A first version of the program intended for OSAF’s new partners in the university world would be called Westwood. And a more distant Chandler 2.0, code-named Pasadena, would concentrate on building out the software so other companies could customize it for small- and medium-sized businesses.

Chandler 1.0、Canoga 曾承诺在 2003 年底推出。但当时是春天，OSAF 甚至还没有确定其后端的基本架构。对于卡普尔的程序员来说，正如托伊在他的博客上所写的那样，感觉就像“我们试图立足的地面仍然在冷却”。他们怎么可能在这样的最后期限前完成任务呢？

Chandler 1.0, Canoga, had been promised by the end of 2003. But it was spring, and OSAF hadn’t even settled on the basic architecture of its back end. For Kapor’s programmers, as Toy would write on his blog, it felt like “the ground on which we are trying to stand is still cooling.” How could they possibly meet such a deadline?

玩具知道，只有一种方法可以尝试：制定一个时间表并开始尝试遵循它。

There was only one way to try, Toy knew: Make a schedule and start trying to follow it.





已故商业哲学家彼得·德鲁克写道：“管理是关于人的。它的任务是使人们能够共同发挥作用，使他们的优势发挥作用，而使他们的劣势变得无关紧要。” 我们习惯于将管理视为带有科学光泽的商学院技术的应用：对生产力和投资回报率的统一衡量。德鲁克的定义听起来非常软弱。他可能谈论的是管弦乐队指挥或舞台导演。但是，在强调管理艺术而非科学、人类领域而非数量维度时，德鲁克——他首先发明了知识工作者一词，然后对其含义提供了宝贵的见解——试图提醒我们，数字只是一个起点。管理，而不是其最终目标。

“Management,” wrote Peter Drucker, the late business philosopher, “is about human beings. Its task is to make people capable of joint performance, to make their strengths effective and their weaknesses irrelevant.” We’re accustomed to thinking of management as the application of business school techniques that carry a scientific sheen: uniform measurements of productivity and metrics of return-on-investment. Drucker’s definition sounds awfully squishy; he could be talking about an orchestra conductor or a stage director. But in emphasizing the art of management over the science, the human realm over the quantitative dimension, Drucker—who first invented the term knowledge worker and then offered invaluable insights into its implications—was trying to remind us that numbers are only a starting point for management, not its ultimate goal.

软件项目管理中固有的一个巨大讽刺是，尽管程序员使用的材料具有数字精度，但编写软件的企业却独特地抵制测量。几十年来，编程经理一直在努力寻找一种合理的方法来衡量其领域的生产力。对于工作程序员来说，一天的努力的最终产品是代码，而软件生产力最明显的衡量标准是编写的代码行数。但这是一种令人不满意的措施，有时甚至是彻头彻尾的欺骗性措施。正如 Noble 和 Biddle 在研究可重用软件对象时发现的那样，一行代码并不统一。生成的代码量与程序的完成状态、其质量或其对用户的最终价值之间不存在可靠的关系。

One great irony inherent in the management of software projects is that despite the digital precision of the materials programmers work with, the enterprise of writing software is uniquely resistant to measurement. Programming managers have struggled for decades to find a sensible way to gauge productivity in their field. The end product of a day’s effort for the working programmer is code, and the most obvious yardstick of software productivity is the number of lines of code written. But it is an unsatisfying and sometimes even downright deceptive measure. Just as Noble and Biddle had found with their study of reusable software objects, there is nothing uniform about a line of code.
