There is no reliable relationship between the volume of code produced and the state of completion of a program, its quality, or its ultimate value to a user.

安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 讲述了他在苹果公司早期的一个相关故事，讲述了他的导师比尔·阿特金森 (Bill Atkinson)，一位传奇的软件创新者，创建了 Quickdraw 和 Hypercard。阿特金森负责苹果公司 Lisa 电脑（麦金塔电脑的前身）的图形界面。当 Lisa 团队的经理建立了一个系统，要求工程师在每周结束时填写一份表格，报告他们编写了多少行代码时，阿特金森感到愤怒。“他认为代码行是衡量软件生产力的愚蠢标准，”赫茨菲尔德在他对麦金塔历史的描述《硅谷革命》中写道。“他认为他的目标是编写尽可能小、尽可能快的程序，而代码行度量只会鼓励编写草率、臃肿、损坏的代码。”

Andy Hertzfeld tells a relevant tale from the early days at Apple about his mentor Bill Atkinson, a legendary software innovator who created Quickdraw and Hypercard. Atkinson was responsible for the graphic interface of Apple’s Lisa computer (a predecessor of the Macintosh). When the Lisa team’s managers instituted a system under which engineers were expected to fill out a form at the end of each week reporting how many lines of code they had written, Atkinson bridled. “He thought that lines of code was a silly measure of software productivity,” wrote Hertzfeld in his account of Macintosh history, Revolution in the Valley. “He thought his goal was to write as small and fast a program as possible, and that the lines of code metric only encouraged writing sloppy, bloated, broken code.”

在阿特金森第一次被要求填写新的管理表格的那一周，他刚刚完成了部分 Quickdraw 代码的重写，使其更加高效和快速。新版本比旧版本少了2000行代码。报告什么？他写下了数字-2000。

The week that he was asked to fill out the new management form for the first time, Atkinson had just completed rewriting a portion of the Quickdraw code, making it more efficient and faster. The new version was 2000 lines of code shorter than the old one. What to report? He wrote in the number -2000.

如果计算代码行数是危险的，那么软件生产力的其他常见指标也同样不可靠。您可以尝试跟踪程序功能或“功能点”，但它们很少被整齐地划分为类似难度或大小的单元；你最终会对某个特定功能何时完成做出非常主观的决定。您可以尝试追踪错误数量，通过跟踪减少总体错误数量的进度来衡量生产力。但有时发现错误是一项重要的工作，可以让您更接近完成工作，即使它会增加错误数量。而且错误修复所需的时间差异很大，因此您的团队可能需要几周的时间才能将列表从一百个未解决的错误减少到十二个，却发现最后十几个每周都顽固地抵制修复。此外，无论你采用哪种不可靠的标准，你最终都会面临 Frederick Brooks 在《人月神话》中所报告的令人不安的事实：不同程序员的生产力差异很大，经常相差十倍之多。因此，猜测如何为项目配备人员可能与估计需要多长时间一样令人沮丧。

If counting lines of code is treacherous, other common metrics of software productivity are similarly unreliable. You can try to track program features or “function points,” but they rarely divide neatly into units of similar difficulty or size; you end up making highly subjective calls about when a particular feature is done. You can try to chase bug numbers, measuring productivity by tracking progress in reducing the overall bug count. But sometimes finding bugs is essential work that brings you closer to finishing the job, even as it boosts the bug count. And bugs vary widely in the amount of time required to fix them, so your team might take a couple of weeks to whittle a list down from one hundred open bugs to twelve, only to find that the final dozen stubbornly resist a fix week after week. Furthermore, whichever unreliable yardstick you grab, you wind up facing the uncomfortable truth that Frederick Brooks reported in The Mythical Man-Month: Productivity varies wildly from one programmer to the next, frequently by as much as a factor of ten. So guessing how to staff a project can be as frustrating as estimating how long it will take.

大多数软件经理都清楚地意识到这些困难，最终都会即兴发挥。有一个需要完成的事情的列表，细分为一系列任务，并且有一些方法可以跟踪哪些任务（或多或少）已完成。充分意识到软件时间的危险和悖论，经理仍然希望个别程序员尝试估计（或至少 SWAG（进行愚蠢的、疯狂的猜测））每个剩余任务将花费多长时间。然后，经理将把所有这些信息集中到一个地方，估计项目的完成时间，如果结果表明软件在下一个千年之前无法准备好（通常会发生这种情况），则开始进行权衡。

Most software managers, well aware of these difficulties, end up improvising. There is a list of what needs to be done, subdivided into a series of tasks, and there is some method of keeping track of which of those tasks is (more or less) completed. Fully aware of the perils and paradoxes of software time, the manager will still expect individual programmers to try to estimate—or at least SWAG (take a Silly, Wild-Assed Guess)—how long each remaining task will take. The manager will then assemble all this information in one place, estimate a completion time for the project, and—if, as typically happens, the result suggests that the software will not be ready before the next millennium—start making trade-offs.





管理技术项目的非正式方法在惠普以“四处走动管理”的概念实现了其最著名的化身，后来汤姆·彼得斯 (Tom Peters) 的《追求卓越》(In Search of Excellence)使这一概念得以普及。这种严格的方法要求管理人员离开办公室，到他们的办公室拜访工人，并与他们交谈。“怎么样了？” 听起来可能不是最深入或最分析性的探究路线，但通过徘徊（或走动）进行管理在其方式上是革命性的：它表明，对于管理者来说，钻研账本并不重要，重要的是他们走出去观察什么他们的员工实际上正在做。它非常重视人类的观察和接触。

The informal approach to managing technical projects achieved its most famous incarnation at Hewlett-Packard with the concept of “management by wandering around,” which was later popularized by Tom Peters’s In Search of Excellence. This rigorous methodology requires managers to leave their offices, visit workers in their dens, and chat them up. “How’s it going?” may not sound like the most incisive or analytical line of inquiry, but management by wandering (or walking) around was revolutionary in its way: It suggested that it was less important for managers to pore over ledgers than for them to get out and observe what their employees were actually doing. It placed a premium on human observation and contact.

但是，MBWA（科技行业的缩写商很快就把这个想法称为“MBWA”）并没有很好地转化为软件领域：这项工作对于四处游荡的管理人员来说根本不可见。没有人比瓦茨·汉弗莱 (Watts Humphrey) 更实事求是地表达这一困难。瓦茨·汉弗莱 (Watts Humphrey) 是一位软件管理大师，他在 Frederick Brooks 离开后的 20 世纪 60 年代领导了 IBM 软件团队，后来在卡内基创建了软件工程学院-梅隆并创立了一整套字母汤的软件开发方法。

But MBWA, as the tech industry’s acronym-mongers soon dubbed the idea, doesn’t translate well to the software realm: The work is simply not visible to the wandering managerial eye. No one has expressed this difficulty with more matter-of-fact precision than Watts Humphrey—a high priest of software management who led the IBM software team in the 1960s after Frederick Brooks’s departure, and then went on to found the Software Engineering Institute at Carnegie-Mellon and to father a whole alphabet soup’s worth of software development methodologies.

汉弗莱认为：“随着制造业、军队和传统硬件的发展，经理们可以走过车间、战场或实验室，看看每个人都在做什么。如果有人做错了事或者效率低下，经理只要观察几分钟就可以看出。然而，对于一个软件开发团队来说，你无法仅仅通过观看来判断他们在做什么。您必须询问他们或仔细检查他们生产的产品。需要一个非常警觉且知识渊博的经理才能告诉软件开发人员在做什么。如果你告诉他们做其他事情或采用新的做法，你就没有简单的方法来判断他们是否真的按照你告诉他们的方式工作。”

“With manufacturing, armies, and traditional hardware development,” Humphrey argues, “the managers can walk through the shop, battlefield, or lab and see what everybody is doing. If someone is doing something wrong or otherwise being unproductive, the manager can tell by watching for a few minutes. However, with a team of software developers, you cannot tell what they are doing by merely watching. You must ask them or carefully examine what they have produced. It takes a pretty alert and knowledgeable manager to tell what software developers are doing. If you tell them to do something else or to adopt a new practice, you have no easy way to tell if they are actually working the way you told them to work.”

所有这些盲点意味着“经理无法判断项目的进展情况”。经理就不能直接问球队吗？汉弗莱表示：“大多数开发人员都会很乐意告诉他们的经理他们在工作中的立场。” “问题在于，根据当前的软件实践，开发人员比管理者更不知道自己的立场。”

All these blind spots mean that “the manager cannot tell where the project stands.” Can’t the manager just ask the team? “Most developers would be glad to tell their managers where they stood on the job,” according to Humphrey. “The problem is that, with current software practices, the developers do not know where they stand any more than the managers do.”





汉弗莱的观点令人沮丧，但至少是脚踏实地的。如何测量看不见的东西？当一个团体的成员不知道自己的立场时，你如何判断一个团体的进步？

Humphrey’s perspective is discouraging, but at least it‘s down-to-earth. How can you measure what you can’t see? How can you judge a group’s progress when its members don’t know where they stand?

但在当今的商业世界中，在对软件项目的表现普遍不满的背后，隐藏着一种更深层次的焦虑——担心问题的根源可能不在于管理技术的失败，而在于人们所做的事情的本质。工作。对于许多高管，甚至对于他们在销售或公司其他部门的同事来说，程序员通常似乎属于完全不同的物种。与他们沟通非常困难。他们无法对通常的奖励/惩罚刺激做出反应。他们是极客，也是一个问题。

But in much of the business world today there lies, beneath the wide dissatisfaction with how software projects perform, a deeper anxiety—a fear that the root of the problem may lie not in failures of management technique but in the very nature of the people doing the work. To many executives, and even to their coworkers in sales or other parts of a company, programmers often seem to belong to an entirely different species. Communicating with them is frustratingly hard. They fail to respond to applications of the usual reward/punishment stimuli. They are geeks, and they are a problem.

大约十年前，“极客”这个词开始普遍使用，用来形容那些发现与计算机建立关系比与其他人建立关系更容易的人。书呆子这个以前很受欢迎的词，带有浓重的高中派系和口袋保护者的味道。极客的词源可以追溯到几个世纪前（这个词的变体甚至出现在莎士比亚的《第十二夜》和《辛白林》中）；“傻瓜”或“傻瓜”的最初含义在二十世纪初期被定位在马戏团的杂耍表演中，在那里你可以付费观看极客吃昆虫或咬掉鸡头。随着个人电脑在 20 世纪 90 年代成为美国商业和文化的中心舞台，需要帮助连接互联网或安装新打印机的技术新手开始寻求他们能找到的最近的“电脑极客”的帮助——至少在没有帮助的情况下首先，用他们的脸来称呼他们。极客（Geek），就像酷儿和其他对局外人群体的强烈标签一样，一开始只是一种诽谤，后来才被其目标广泛接受，作为自豪的象征。

Roughly a decade ago the word geek came into common usage to describe the kind of person who finds it easier to have relationships with computers than with other human beings. Nerd, the previously favored term, reeked too heavily of high school cliques and pocket protectors. The etymology of geek goes back centuries (a variant of the word even appears in Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night and Cymbeline); the original meaning of “fool” or “simpleton” became localized in the early twentieth century to the circus sideshow, where you could pay to see the geek eat insects or bite off a chicken’s head. As the personal computer moved to center stage of American business and culture in the 1990s, technical neophytes needing help connecting to the Internet or installing a new printer began seeking the help of the nearest “computer geek” they could find—without, at least at first, referring to them as such to their faces. Geek, like queer and other highly charged labels for outsider groups, began as a slur and only later was broadly embraced by its targets as a token of pride.

您可以通过行话文件（也称为新黑客词典）的连续版本来追踪“极客”一词的演变，它是由《大教堂与集市》的埃里克·雷蒙德 (Eric Raymond) 策划的程序员语言和知识纲要。早期版本将极客定义为“以吃（电脑）虫子为生的人——一个不合群、恶臭、脸色苍白的偏执狂，具有奶酪刨丝器的所有个性。” 最近，这个定义开始于更高的自尊：“极客：选择专注而不是从众的人；一个追求技能（尤其是技术技能）和想象力的人，而不是主流社会接受度的人。”

You can trace the evolution of the word geek through successive editions of the Jargon File, also known as the New Hacker’s Dictionary, a compendium of programmer language and lore curated by Eric Raymond of “The Cathedral and the Bazaar.” Early editions defined geek as “one who eats (computer) bugs for a living—an asocial, malodorous, pasty-faced monomaniac with all the personality of a cheese grater.” More recently the definition begins on a note of higher self-esteem: “Geek: A person who has chosen concentration rather than conformity; one who pursues skill (especially technical skill) and imagination, not mainstream social acceptance.”

当极客向受人尊敬的方向转变时，极客也加入了进来。作者尼尔·史蒂芬森 (Neal Stephenson) 在 2005 年《纽约时报》的一篇专栏文章中解释道：“极客研究某件事意味着让自己沉浸在其细节中，达到一种明显不正常的程度，并享受其中的乐趣。” 真正的极客有能力对几乎所有事情都感到极客——甚至是厨房清理。一位名叫 Merlin Mann 的生产力软件爱好者，于 2004 年创建了一个名为 43 Folders 的博客，该博客很快成为程序员的最爱，他曾为他正在阅读的一本名为《Home Comforts》的书写了一封情书：“我的蜥蜴大脑中有些疯狂的褶皱最让人兴奋的是关于如何洗碗的九页详细信息。。。。我想，我那个非常整洁（并且无限耐心）的女朋友可能已经接受了这样一个事实：我只有在涉及某种带有图表和文档的奇特系统时才会对某件事真正感兴趣。”

As geek mutated its way toward respectability, it was joined by geek out. Author Neal Stephenson explained in a 2005 New York Times op-ed: “To geek out on something means to immerse yourself in its details to an extent that is distinctly abnormal—and to have a good time doing it.” True geeks have a capacity to geek out on almost anything—even kitchen cleanup. An enthusiast of productivity software named Merlin Mann, who in 2004 started a blog called 43 Folders that quickly became a cult favorite among programmers, once composed a love letter to a book he was reading called Home Comforts: “Some deranged fold of my lizard brain gets most turned on by nine detailed pages on how to wash your dishes . . . . I think my wonderfully tidy (and endlessly patient) girlfriend has probably resigned herself to the fact that I only get really interested in something when it involves some kind of fancy system with charts and documentation.”

虽然并非所有极客都是程序员，也并非所有程序员都是极客，但这两个群体之间的重叠足够彻底，以至于他们的共同身份被认为是理所当然的。在程序员中，极客有很多细分：有 Linux 极客和 Mac 极客、标准极客和脚本极客、数据库极客和加密极客，每个极客都有自己的亚文化参考点。极客的社会范围也相当广泛，从典型的保守的工程师（喜欢削尖铅笔和清晰定义人际互动）到典型的不扣扣子的黑客，他有着反重力的头发和反抗秩序的本能。他们的共同点是对专业知识的热情，以及与缺乏这种热情的每个人之间的麻烦关系——往好了说是笨拙，往坏了说是敌对。您的意思是您不知道如何配置家庭网络？对于每个极客都会很乐意为您做这件事，然后向您展示六种根据您的需要进行调整的方法，而另一个极客会厉声说道：“只是 RTFM，伙计！” 他看着你，没有解释就转身走开，让你通过谷歌发现你刚刚被告知要阅读该死的手册。

While not all geeks are programmers and not all programmers geeks, the overlap between the two groups is thorough enough that their shared identity is assumed as a matter of course. Among programmers, geekery has a host of subclassifications: There are Linux geeks and Mac geeks, standards geeks and scripting geeks, database geeks and crypto geeks, each with their own subcultural reference points. The social spectrum of geekdom is fairly wide as well, stretching from the stereotypically buttoned-down engineer, who likes his pencils sharpened and his human interactions neatly defined, to the stereotypically unbuttoned hacker, with his gravity-defying hair and order-defying instincts. What they all share is a passion for specialized knowledge and a troubled relationship—at best clumsy, at worst hostile—with everyone who lacks that passion. You mean you don’t know how to configure your home network? For every geek who will gladly do it for you and then show you six ways to tweak it should you so desire, there is another who will snap, “Just RTFM, dude!” at you and turn away without explaining himself, leaving you to discover via Google that you’ve just been told to read the fucking manual.

只要程序员在幕后默默无闻地从事他们神秘的工作，与他们交谈或获得答案的困难就没有多大关系。但随着计算机进入每个教室和每个家庭，各行各业的企业开始围绕定制软件重塑其流程，极客管理的不干涉方法变得越来越难以容忍。程序员发现自己拥有首席信息官之类的头衔，坐在会议室里或与媒体交谈。与外界的交流是一种痛苦，但绝妙的孤立已不再是一种选择。

As long as programmers pursued their arcane labors in back-room obscurity, it didn’t matter much that they were hard to talk to or get answers from. But as computers moved into every classroom and every home, and businesses of every stripe began to reshape their processes around custom-built software, the hands-off approach to geek management became less and less tolerable. Programmers found themselves with titles like Chief Information Officer, sitting in boardrooms or talking to the press. Communication with outsiders was a pain, but splendid isolation was no longer an option.

为什么极客和非极客不能和平相处？国防采办大学最近进行的一项名为“信息技术团队的人力动态”的研究试图深入了解 77 个团队中 600 名 IT 专业人员（主要是程序员及其经理）的想法。研究人员使用观察、自我报告和各种调查等六种评估方法，发现 IT 专业人员的性格构成与一般人群有很大不同：

Why can’t geeks and nongeeks just get along? One recent study by the Defense Acquisition University called “The Human Dynamics of Information Technology Teams” tried to get inside the heads of six hundred IT professionals (mostly programmers and their managers) in seventy-seven teams. Using a half dozen means of assessment, including observation, self-reporting, and a variety of surveys, the researchers found that the personality makeup of IT pros differs substantially from that of the general population:



超过四分之三 (77%) 的样本表示偏好思考型决策，只有 23% 的人更喜欢感觉型决策。这明显高于一般人群，这些偏好之间的差距通常是均匀的。正如他们所说的那样，思考者通常更喜欢逻辑、客观、客观的决策，注重因果关系和客观性带来的清晰度（问题第一，人第二）。

More than three quarters (77 percent) of our sample reported a preference for thinking decision-making, with only 23 percent preferring feeling decision-making. This is significantly higher than in the general population, where the split between these preferences is generally even. Thinkers, as they are termed, generally prefer logical, objective, impersonal decision-making, focused upon cause-effect relationships and the clarity that comes from objectivity (problem first, people second).

接受调查的 IT 专业人员中有 41% 表示自己是内向的思考者（内向和思维偏好的结合），几乎是普通人群百分比的两倍。内向的思考者通常更喜欢单枪匹马的工作方式，常常回避团队、协作努力以及支持这种结构的培训。这个群体最不可能与他人进行人际交往和联系，并且可能会避免与同事建立信任和开放的个人桥梁。

Forty-one percent of the IT professionals surveyed reported being introverted thinkers (combination of introversion and thinking preferences), nearly twice the percentage in the general population. Introverted thinkers often prefer a lone-gun approach to work, often avoiding teams, collaborative efforts, and the training that support such structures. This group is least likely to engage and connect interpersonally with others, and may avoid creating personal bridges of trust and openness with colleagues.



当大多数程序员的同事得知他们的程序员同事更有可能是理性的孤独者时，这并不会让他们感到惊讶。“很多人觉得与信息技术专业人士沟通只是比与死者沟通稍微困难一点，”博思艾伦咨询公司分析师艾比·麦克内斯（Abby Mackness）进行了人类动力学研究，她在向一群人介绍研究结果时开玩笑说。国防承包商员工和顾问。

It would hardly surprise most programmers’ coworkers to learn that their coder colleagues are more likely to be rational-minded loners. “A lot of people feel that communicating with the information technology professional is just slightly harder than communicating with the dead,” Abby Mackness, an analyst with Booz Allen Hamilton who conducted the Human Dynamics study, joked as she presented its results to a crowd of defense contractor employees and consultants.

在这个谱系的最极端，程序员的行为特征——避免目光接触、难以阅读肢体语言、沉迷于技术奥秘——模糊了一种被称为阿斯伯格综合症的疾病的症状列表。阿斯伯格症被定义为一种轻度自闭症，但与更严重的自闭症不同的是，患有阿斯伯格症的人通常智商很高，并且可以独立生活。从 20 世纪 90 年代开始，阿斯伯格症和自闭症的发病率总体呈上升趋势，在硅谷的发病率尤其急剧上升。2001 年，史蒂夫·西尔伯曼 (Steve Silberman) 在《连线》杂志上发表了一篇题为“极客综合症”的专题文章，研究了为什么这些病症（科学家认为这些病症具有很高的遗传成分）可能如此集中在程序员的后代中。正如西尔伯曼所写：

At the extreme end of the spectrum, the behavioral profile of the programmer—avoiding eye contact, difficulty reading body language, obsession with technical arcana—blurs into the symptom list of a malady known as Asperger’s syndrome. Asperger’s is defined as a mild form of autism, though unlike the more severely autistic, people who have it often have high IQs and can function on their own. Beginning in the 1990s, the rates of both Asperger’s and autism, which had been rising in general, took an especially steep jump in Silicon Valley. A 2001 Wired magazine feature by Steve Silberman titled “The Geek Syndrome” examined why these conditions, which scientists believe have a high genetic component, might be concentrated so heavily among the offspring of programmers. As Silberman wrote:



自闭症患者的思维在物理世界中笨拙且容易被淹没，但他们却在数学、符号和代码的虚拟领域中翱翔。。。。硅谷是一个自我选择的社区，充满热情的聪明人从世界各地迁移到这里，让智能机器更智能地工作。苦力劳动的具体细节和实用性吸引了高功能自闭症患者的偏好。然而，建造这样的飞地的隐性成本可能潜伏在过去十年中几乎所有主要自闭症基因研究的结果中。研究人员一次又一次地得出结论，自闭症的 DNA 脚本可能不仅由典型自闭症患者的亲属遗传，而且还由那些仅表现出几种典型自闭症行为的人遗传。。。。令人不寒而栗的可能性是，现在发生的事情首次证明，赋予轻微自闭症成年人某些特殊天赋的基因——正是这些能力使他们成为我们技术未来的梦想家和建筑师——能够给人类带来瘟疫。下一代最优秀的头脑。

Clumsy and easily overwhelmed in the physical world, autistic minds soar in the virtual realms of mathematics, symbols, and code . . . . The Valley is a self-selecting community where passionately bright people migrate from all over the world to make smart machines work smarter. The nuts-and-bolts practicality of hard labor among the bits appeals to the predilections of the high-functioning autistic mind. The hidden cost of building enclaves like this, however, may be lurking in the findings of nearly every major genetic study of autism in the last ten years. Over and over again, researchers have concluded that the DNA scripts for autism are probably passed down not only by relatives who are classically autistic, but by those who display only a few typically autistic behaviors . . . . The chilling possibility is that what’s happening now is the first proof that the genes responsible for bestowing certain special gifts on slightly autistic adults—the very abilities that have made them dreamers and architects of our technological future—are capable of bringing a plague down on the best minds of the next generation.



无论自闭症发病率上升的原因是什么——无论是硅谷正在通过近亲繁殖的极客进行大规模实验，还是无关的因素造成——自闭症特征和极客性格之间的相似之处都令人不安。编程部落的一些观察家认为，为了与他们必须指导的机器进行更密切的交流，许多程序员已经切断了自己与人性的联系。但阿斯伯格症/自闭症的相似之处表明，更有可能的是，这些程序员本身已经被编程为能够听到与人类波长一样或更好的机器频率。这可以帮助他们编写有效的代码并设计有效的算法。但这使他们在理解如何塑造程序以实现人类用户的目标方面处于一些不利地位。当涉及到与非极客的其他人进行简单交流时，这也会给他们带来麻烦。

Whatever the cause of the rising autism rates—whether Silicon Valley is conducting a vast experiment by inbreeding geeks or unrelated factors are responsible—there is something unsettling about the parallels between the autistic profile and the geek personality. Some observers of the programming tribe have suggested that in order to commune more closely with the machines they must instruct, many programmers have cut themselves off from aspects of their humanity. But the Asperger’s/autism parallel suggests that, more likely, those programmers were themselves already programmed to hear machine frequencies as well as or better than human wavelengths. That can help them write effective code and design efficient algorithms. But it puts them at some disadvantage in understanding how to shape a program so it accomplishes its human user’s goals. It also sets them up for trouble when it comes to the simple need to communicate with anyone else who isn’t also a geek.





大约在 Frederick Brooks 撰写《人月神话》的同时，那个时代的另一位程序员 Gerald Weinberg 写了一本名为《计算机编程心理学》的书。这是利用人类学家和心理学家的工具来研究新兴学科的首次尝试。温伯格发现的一件事是，尽管程序员以独来独往着称，但他们确实需要有机会互相交谈——环境越非正式越好。

Around the same time that Frederick Brooks was writing The Mythical Man-Month, another programmer of that era, Gerald Weinberg, wrote a book titled The Psychology of Computer Programming. It was the first attempt to study the burgeoning new discipline with the tools of the anthropologist and psychologist. One of the things Weinberg found was that despite their reputation as loners, programmers really needed the chance to talk to one another—the more informal the setting, the better.

温伯格讲述了一个大学计算中心的传奇故事，有一天，官员们决定将自动售货机从公共区域移走。聚集在那里的学生们太吵闹了：必须做点什么。在机器被运走后的几天里，通常可以轻松处理工作量的中心服务台人员发现自己陷入了困境。队伍一直延伸到门外。然而其他一切都没有改变。学生数量、课程和作业数量相同。该中心的经理最终指派了一名社会学研究生去采访等待服务台建议的人群。研究结果提出了当今商业学者所说的“饮水机效应”的早期实例：

Weinberg recounts the saga of a university computing center where bureaucrats decided one day to remove the vending machines from a common area. The students who gathered there got too rowdy: Something Had to Be Done. In the days after the machines were carted off, the center’s help desk personnel, who normally could handle their workload with ease, found themselves swamped. The lines stretched out the door. Yet nothing else had changed; there were the same number of students, courses, and assignments. The center’s manager finally assigned a sociology grad student to interview the crowd waiting for help desk advice. The findings presented an early instance of what today’s business scholars call the “watercooler effect”:



学生到达计算中心时的典型行为是拿起他的输出并走向咖啡机。在那里，他一边喝着咖啡，一边可以第一眼看到这个节目，也可以把它展示给周围可能站着的朋友们。由于大多数学生的问题都是相似的，因此他很有可能在自动售货机上找到知道他的程序出了什么问题的人。通过这种非正式的组织，正式的咨询机制被分流，其负担减轻到可以合理处理的水平。

The typical behavior of a student when he arrived at the computing center was to pick up his output and head for the coffee machine. There, while sipping coffee, he could have a first look at the program and also show it to his buddies who might be standing around. Since most of the student problems were similar, the chances were very high that he could find someone who knew what was wrong with his program right there at the vending machines. Through this informal organization, the formal consulting mechanism was shunted, and its load was reduced to a level it could reasonably handle.



温伯格评论道，关键在于“非正式机制总是存在的，在不了解它们的情况下改变事物是危险的，以免破坏一些你无法以类似成本替换的平稳操作系统。” 自温伯格写作以来的几十年里，管理者们已经从笨拙地破坏这种非正式机制转变为笨拙地试图鼓励它们。办公室设计师已经开始有目的地设计一些空间，以促进温伯格大学管理人员在寻求秩序时试图平息的喧嚣。但在同一时间跨度内，程序员已经远远超出了架构师和经理的范围：他们发明了大量用于保持彼此联系的技术，通过多种新类型的工具来协调团队工作，从而扩展了软件宇宙。

The point, Weinberg commented, was that “informal mechanisms always exist and it is dangerous to change things without understanding them, lest you derange some smoothly operating system which you will not be able to replace at similar cost.” In the decades since Weinberg’s writing, managers have gone from clumsily wrecking such informal mechanisms to clumsily trying to encourage them. Office designers have begun purposefully including spaces intended to foster the hubbub that Weinberg’s university administrators sought to squelch in their quest for order. But in the same time span, programmers have gone far beyond architects and managers: They have invented a profusion of technologies for staying in touch with one another, extending the software cosmos with multiple new genres of tools for coordinating a team’s work.

这些工具有时统称为“群件”，包括即时消息传递系统、聊天室、错误跟踪器、源代码版本控制和古老的电子邮件列表。当 OSAF 开始工作时，博客和维基这两个较新的想法首次受到欢迎。每种类型的软件都可以轻松地将输出输入不同的渠道：例如，每次有人签入新的代码补丁时，您的源代码控制系统都可以向邮件列表弹出一封电子邮件。在不知不觉中，您已经拥有数十个频道需要掌握，而留在循环中很容易占用您一天的大部分时间。

These tools, sometimes collectively referred to as “groupware,” include systems for instant messaging, chat rooms, bug trackers, source code version control, and the venerable email list. As OSAF began its work, two newer ideas, blogs and wikis, were enjoying their first flush of popularity. Each type of software can easily feed output into a different channel: Your source code control system, for example, can pop off an email message to a mailing list each time someone checks in a new code patch. Before you know it, you have dozens of channels to stay on top of, and staying in the loop can easily eat up much of a workday.

在编程的早期，团队在纸质活页夹（称为项目工作簿）中分享他们的知识，围绕这些活页夹发展了协调更新的复杂流程。（布鲁克斯的《人月神话》用了很多篇幅来讨论这些仪式。）但是，一旦程序员能够脱离纸质文件，他们就这么做了。最初的数字群件是 Doug Engelbart 的 NLS，它是 1960 年代的模板，适用于随后个人计算革命中展开的许多内容。群件的每次新迭代都代表了恩格尔巴特引导概念的又一次尝试——使用计算工具来提高开发计算工具的效率。

In the early days of programming, teams shared their knowledge on paper, in loose-leaf binders known as project workbooks, around which evolved complex processes of coordinating updates. (Brooks’s Mythical Man-Month devotes many pages to these rituals.) But as soon as programmers could move off paper, they did. The original digital groupware was Doug Engelbart’s NLS, the 1960s-era template for so much of what would unfold in the personal computing revolution to follow. Each new iteration of groupware has represented another stab at Engelbart’s notion of bootstrapping—using the tools of computing to improve the effectiveness of developing computing tools.

在 OSAF，这种现象的镜像逻辑几乎是痛苦地生动的：当 OSAF 的程序员苦苦思索协调他们工作的不同方案时，他们会感叹，如果他们拥有 Chandler 本身，那么构建 Chandler 会容易得多，这将成为他们的一种令人遗憾的仪式。 。

At OSAF the mirror logic of this phenomenon was almost painfully vivid: As OSAF’s programmers wrestled with different schemes for coordinating their work, it would become a rueful ritual for them to exclaim how much easier it would be to build Chandler if only they had Chandler itself.

一些观察家推测，程序员之所以热衷于寻求面对面交流的替代方案，是因为他们厌恶坐在房间里面对面地交谈（FTF）。不可否认的是，典型的极客不喜欢管理层强制召开的会议，因为这些会议会拖延并削减实际编码时间。但事实上，程序员隐士的刻板印象只适用于程序员群体中相对较小的一部分。典型的程序员喜欢空谈。多种群件的激增并不是因为程序员想要避免彼此谈论他们的工作（FTF），而是因为他们无法对此闭嘴。如今，他们的同事常常处于不同的时区；在典型的开源项目中，它们可能永远不会共享相同的物理位置（“肉空间”）。为了完成任何事情，他们必须想方设法随时从彼此那里获得答案，在团队中广泛传播这些答案，并为将来保留这些答案的记录。

Some observers have speculated that the avidity with which programmers pursue alternatives to in-person communication is a direct function of their aversion to sitting in a room and actually talking to one another face-to-face (FTF). It is undeniable that the typical geek dislikes management-mandated meetings that drag on and cut into actual coding time. But in fact the stereotype of the programmer as hermit applies only to a relatively small slice of the programmer population. The typical programmer loves to talk shop. Multiple species of groupware have proliferated not because programmers want to avoid talking with one another about their work FTF but because they can’t shut up about it. More often than not, their colleagues today are in different time zones; in the typical open source project they may not ever share the same physical location (“meatspace”). In order to get anything done, they have had to find ways to get answers from one another at all hours, to spread those answers widely among their team, and to keep a record of those answers for the future.





沃德·坎宁安 (Ward Cunningham) 在创建现在被称为维基 (wiki) 的工具时并不想发明什么大东西；他只是想发明一些伟大的东西。他只是想让自己的工作变得更轻松一些。作为一名资深程序员，也是神秘的面向对象编程艺术的学生，在 20 世纪 90 年代初期，他是模式语言运动的早期狂热参与者，该运动是软件开发人员将建筑哲学家 Christopher Alexander 的思想应用到他们的工作。亚历山大的书《模式语言》通过观察成功建筑中的常见元素或模式得出了一种构造语法。软件模式语言的人们旨在将相同的方法应用于编程。20 世纪 90 年代中期，当 Web 突然出现时，他们召开了一次会议，Cunningham 给会议留下了一项任务：构建一个超文本存储库，程序员可以用它在 Web 上共享他们的软件模式。

Ward Cunningham was not looking to invent something big when he created the tool now known as the wiki; he was simply trying to make his own work a little easier. A veteran programmer and student of the arcane art of object-oriented programming, in the early 1990s he was an early and avid participant in the pattern language movement, an effort on the part of software developers to apply the ideas of architectural philosopher Christopher Alexander to their work. Alexander’s book A Pattern Language derived a sort of grammar of construction by observing common elements or patterns in successful buildings. The software pattern–language people aimed to apply the same approach to programming. In the mid-1990s, they held a conference just as the Web burst into view, and Cunningham left it with an assignment: to build a hypertext repository that programmers could use to share their software patterns on the Web.

十年后，他讲述了第一个维基是如何诞生的故事：

A decade later he told the story of how the first wiki came into existence:



我想，好吧，我正在运行这个存储库，将您的模式以文本文件形式发送给我，我将运行一个小脚本，然后将它们转换为 HTML [网页编码所用的语言]。我制定了简单的规则，比如空行意味着一个新段落，诸如此类。令我惊讶的是，向我发送文件的人甚至无法遵守这些简单的规则。我对这件事已经有了三个模式文档，并且已经厌倦了。所以我制作了一个提交文件的表格。

I figured, OK, I’m running this repository, send me your patterns in a text file and I’ll run a little script, and I’ll turn them into HTML [the language in which Web pages are coded]. I made simple rules, like a blank line means a new paragraph, and stuff like that. And I was amazed at how people who sent me files couldn’t follow even those simple rules. I was three pattern documents into this thing, and getting pretty tired of it already. So I made a form for submitting the documents.



但人们会提交一份文件，然后在发布后纠缠坎宁安对页面进行更改。因此，他在每个页面的底部添加了一个按钮，上面写着“编辑此页面”。你不需要密码。任何人都可以按下它并开始编辑。“它是如此简单，我有点不好意思向人们展示它，”他曾经说道。“这么简单的事情真的有用吗？”

But people would submit a document and then pester Cunningham to make changes in the page after it was posted. So he added a button at the bottom of every page that simply read “Edit this page.” You didn’t need a password. Anyone could press it and start editing. “It was so simple, I was a little embarrassed to show it to people,” he once said. “Could something so simple really work?”

坎宁安添加了一个变化：如果您的页面包含用大写字母书写的单词（一种现在称为 CamelCase (ItMakesWordsLookLikeThis) 的样式），那么软件会在数据库中查找这些单词。如果该名称的页面已存在，则该单词将自动链接到该页面；如果没有，它会创建一个存根，一个页面的空模板，等待有人填写。并且由于 wiki 软件存储了每个页面的每个版本 - 跟踪人们所做的所有更改，就像程序员的源代码控制一样系统做到了——如果有人做了不受欢迎的更改，您可以轻松地将页面回滚到之前的状态。

Cunningham added one twist: If your page included words written with capital letters inside them—a style now known as CamelCase (ItMakesWordsLookLikeThis)—the software would look up those words in a database. If a page already existed by that name, the words would automatically be linked to the page; if not, it would create a stub, an empty template for a page, waiting for someone to fill it in. And since the wiki software stored every version of each page—tracking all the changes people made, much as programmers’ source code control systems did—you could easily roll a page back to a previous state if someone made unwelcome changes.

坎宁安的开创性维基百科——波特兰模式存储库，在十多年的时间里发展到了大约三万页。它激发了整个维基运动。（这个奇特的名字源自坎宁安在一次旅行中窥探到的夏威夷语中的“快速”一词。）它最著名的后代是志愿者创建的维基百科，通过任何选择贡献的人的公开添加和修改，已经发展成为网络上最广为人知和使用的参考资源。与此同时，小公司纷纷涌现，试图将 wiki 方法应用于商业。多年来，企业一直致力于建立内部网（供员工共享信息的内部网站），但他们的努力往往在官僚主义和复杂性的重压下崩溃。Wiki 似乎为通往基于网络的协作的乐土提供了一条快速而肮脏的捷径。

Cunningham’s pioneering wiki, the Portland Pattern Repository, grew over a decade to about thirty thousand pages. It inspired a whole wiki movement. (The fanciful name derives from a Hawaiian word for “quick” that Cunningham spied on a trip.) Its most celebrated offspring, the volunteer-built Wikipedia, has evolved, via open additions and emendations from anyone who chooses to contribute, into one of the Web’s most widely known and used reference resources. Meanwhile, small companies sprang up to try to adapt the wiki approach to business. For years enterprises had labored to build intranets—internal Web sites for employees to share information—but their efforts tended to collapse under the weight of bureaucracy and complexity. Wikis seemed to offer a quick-and-dirty shortcut to the promised land of Web-based collaboration.





当迈克尔·托伊到达时，钱德勒的船员已经开始遭受通讯信道过载的困扰。当 Kapor 于 2002 年 10 月推出 OSAF 时，它在现有的私人邮件列表之上开放了四个公共邮件列表。卡普尔和其他几个人开设了自己的博客。开发人员每天通过互联网中继聊天（IRC）共享一个聊天室；每天的 IRC 记录均被存储并可供搜索。程序员使用 CVS 源代码控制系统来存储他们的代码并检查对其的更改，而不会中断彼此的工作。他们使用 Bugzilla 来跟踪发现的错误和修复的错误。一月份，OSAF 开设了一个公共维基来分享笔记、研究和想法。

The Chandler crew had already begun to suffer from communication channel overload by the time Michael Toy arrived. When Kapor unveiled OSAF in October 2002, it opened up four public mailing lists on top of an existing private one. Kapor and several others had started their own blogs. Every day the developers shared a chat room via Internet Relay Chat (IRC); each day’s IRC transcript was stored and searchable. The programmers used the CVS source code control system to store their code and check in changes to it without disrupting one another’s work. They had Bugzilla to track bugs noticed and bugs fixed. And in January, OSAF opened a public wiki for sharing notes, research, and ideas.

从实践和哲学的角度来看，卡普尔坚信透明度。他认为，OSAF 的工作和流程应该尽可能开放地接受公众监督，这既是因为 Chandler 作为开源项目的命运需要这样做，也是因为开放感觉是正确的。除了招聘和最敏感的人事问题外，程序员和经理们在公众面前讨论了大部分决定。事实证明，这并不像传统企业实践所暗示的那么困难。最终，事实证明，实现开放比实现秩序和连贯性更不是问题。

From both a practical and a philosophical standpoint, Kapor strongly believed in transparency. OSAF’s work and process ought to be as open to public scrutiny as feasible, he reasoned, both because Chandler’s destiny as an open source project required it and because openness simply felt right. The programmers and managers hashed out most decisions, other than hiring and the most sensitive personnel matters, in full public view. That didn’t turn out to be as difficult as traditional corporate practice might suggest. In the end, achieving openness proved less of a problem than achieving order and coherence.

几乎从钱德勒维基打开虚拟大门的那一天起，就有人抱怨它。一些 OSAF 开发人员发现在框中输入文本的界面很笨拙，并拒绝使用 wiki 作为公共工作区。其他人则如此热衷于它，以至于他们的每日笔记很快变得难以处理。每个人都同意维基百科的随处添加页面机制导致了混乱：新用户不知道从哪里开始，而普通用户则很难找到他们以前访问过的材料。

Almost from the day the Chandler wiki opened its virtual doors, there were gripes about it. Some of the OSAF developers found the type-your-text-in-a-box interface clumsy and resisted using the wiki as a common workspace. Others took to it so avidly that their volume of daily notes quickly grew unwieldy. Everyone agreed that the wiki’s just-add-a-page-anywhere mechanism led to a mess: Newcomers didn’t know where to begin, and regular users had trouble finding material they had previously visited.

驯服 wiki 的任务首先落到了 Kaitlin “Ducky” Sherwood 身上，她是一名程序员和电子邮件管理专家，加入 OSAF 的目的是帮助塑造 Chandler 的电子邮件方法并组织项目文档（所有有助于程序员和用户理解程序的内容）。结构和特点）。舍伍德通过将 wiki 划分为用于官方文档的 Chandler 部分、用于会议记录和程序员日常日志的 Journal 部分以及一个名为 The Jungle 的无政府主义、随心所欲的“沙箱”区域来解决这个问题。钱德勒团队借用了编码领域的一个动词，将 wiki 重组的过程称为“wiki 重构”。对于程序员来说，重构意味着重写一段代码，使其更简洁、更清晰、更易于阅读，而不改变其实际功能。重构常常被比作园艺；它永远不会完成。

The task of taming the wiki first fell to Kaitlin “Ducky” Sherwood, a programmer and email management expert who had joined OSAF to help shape Chandler’s approach to email and organize the project’s documentation (all the material that would help programmers and users understand the program’s structure and features). Sherwood attacked the problem by dividing the wiki into a Chandler section for official documents, a Journal section for meeting notes and programmers’ daily logs, and an anarchic, anything-goes “sandbox” area called The Jungle. Borrowing a verb from the realm of coding, the Chandler team referred to the process of wiki reorganization as “wiki refactoring.” To programmers, refactoring means rewriting a chunk of code to make it briefer, clearer, and easier to read without changing what it actually does. Refactoring is often compared to gardening; it is never finished.

2003 年中，Sherwood 大力推动重构 Chandler wiki，一年后，开发人员也提出了同样的抱怨：如何轻松辨别哪些页面代表最新信息，哪些页面已过时？您如何获得 wiki 上所有内容的简单概述？它的目录在哪里？如果博客和邮件列表的结构过于依赖纯粹的时间顺序，那么维基的无政府主义格式只会让太多的用户不知所措。

A year after Sherwood’s big push to refactor the Chandler wiki in mid-2003, the developers had the same complaints: How could you easily tell which pages represented the most up-to-date information and which were obsolete? How could you get a simple overview of everything on the wiki? Where was its table of contents? If blogs and mailing lists relied too heavily on pure chronology for their structure, the wiki’s anarchic format simply left too many users at sea.





尽管 OSAF 部署了多种工具，Toy 发现这些工具并没有为他作为开发经理提出的最重要的问题提供答案：每个程序员在过去一周完成了什么，接下来的任务是什么？一些开发人员在 wiki 页面上发布注释；其他人则将偶尔的消息匆忙发送到邮件列表中。其他人则在博客上发帖。没有一个地方可以查询该项目的状态概况。

Despite the multiple tools OSAF had deployed, Toy found they didn’t provide him with answers to the most important questions he had as development manager: What had each programmer accomplished in the past week, and what task was next? Some of the developers were posting notes on wiki pages; others were dashing off the occasional message to a mailing list; others were posting to blogs. There was no one place to turn for an overview of the project’s status.

玩具不想通过添加另一个工具来解决问题。在 Netscape，他们也使用 Bugzilla 来跟踪非错误修复工作。由于它是专门为跟踪错误而设计的，因此对于一般任务管理来说并不理想，但是，他认为，这比在 OSAF 团队已经考虑的系统中添加另一个系统要好。

Toy didn’t want to solve the problem by adding yet another tool. At Netscape they had used Bugzilla to track non-bug-fixing work as well. Since it was designed specifically for tracking bugs, it wasn’t ideal for general task management, but, he decided, it was better than adding yet another system to the ones OSAF’s team already had to mind.

一些程序员对 Bugzilla 非常满意。其他人则发现通过基于网络的表单输入任务时感到恼火和烦恼。约翰·安德森尤其抵制这种做法。他抱怨说，他可以花一整天的时间将任务输入 Bugzilla，却永远无法完成任何编码。对于 OSAF 的非程序员来说，他们也需要定期提供工作更新，Bugzilla 尤其不友好。

Some of the programmers were perfectly happy with Bugzilla. Others found it irritating and chafed at the time it took to enter their tasks via its Web-based forms. John Anderson, in particular, resisted the approach; he could spend all day entering his tasks into Bugzilla, he complained, and never get any coding done. And for the nonprogrammers at OSAF who also needed to provide regular updates on their work, Bugzilla was especially unfriendly.

在六个月的时间里，Bugzilla 一直是 OSAF 的官方项目管理工具，但随着使用它的意愿越来越低，Morgen Sagen 开始为团队开发一个自行开发的 Status Manager，这是一个基于 Web 的工具，可以简化输入任务和查看任务的过程按人、按项目、按时间和按状态排序。当 Sagen 最终于 2003 年 11 月推出该新工具时，它在开发人员中引起了巨大反响。如果他们无法使用 Chandler 本身来组织他们的工作，那么状态管理器是一个很好的权宜之计。

For six months Bugzilla remained OSAF’s official project management tool, but as willingness to use it grew increasingly sporadic, Morgen Sagen began working on a homegrown Status Manager for the team—a Web-based tool that would streamline the process for entering tasks and viewing them sorted by person, by project, by time, and by status. When Sagen ultimately unveiled the new tool in November 2003, it was a big hit among the developers. If they couldn’t use Chandler itself to organize their work, the Status Manager was a good stopgap.

尽管如此，Sagen 花在构建 Status Manager 上的时间（就像 Ducky Sherwood 花在清理 wiki 上的几周时间一样）并没有花在构建 Chandler 上。

Still, the time Sagen had spent building the Status Manager—like the weeks Ducky Sherwood devoted to weeding the wiki—was time not devoted to building Chandler.





在《人月神话》中，布鲁克斯将巴别塔称为“人类的第二项重大工程事业”（继方舟之后）和“第一次工程惨败”。布鲁克斯宣称，巴贝尔的管理者拥有现代管理顾问所希望的所有“成功的先决条件”，包括明确的使命、人力、材料、充足的时间和充足的技术。巴别塔失败是因为它的建造者“无法互相交谈；因此他们无法协调。当协调失败时，工作就会陷入停滞。”

In The Mythical Man-Month, Brooks identified the Tower of Babel as “man’s second major engineering undertaking” (after the Ark) and “first engineering fiasco.” Babel’s managers, Brooks declared, had all the “prerequisites for success” a modern-day management consultant could wish for, including a clear mission, manpower, materials, plenty of time, and adequate technology. Babel failed because its builders “were unable to talk with each other; hence they could not coordinate. When coordination failed, work ground to a halt.”

在软件管理中，协调不是事后的想法或附属事项；而是一种协调。这是工作的核心，决定使用什么工具和方法可以决定项目的成败。但在管理这些工具时偏离轨道是一个强大的诱惑。当“让我们自己建造吧！”的呼声响起时 一出现，极客们都乐得集会欢呼。麻省理工学院的一幅著名的（也许是杜撰的）涂鸦抓住了这一点：“我宁愿编写程序来帮助我编写程序，而不是编写程序。” 同样，亚伯拉罕·林肯有句名言：“给我六个小时砍一棵树，我会用前四个小时磨斧头。” 这一原则已被纳入商业建议手册《高效人士的七个习惯》中，它吸引了每个程序员对工具制造的热情。但如果它本身成为目的，它就会把组织得最好的项目推入深渊。发明 Java 的编程大师 James Gosling 在他的博客中讨论了这种偏好：

In software management, coordination is not an afterthought or an ancillary matter; it is the heart of the work, and deciding what tools and methods to use can make or break a project. But getting sidetracked in managing those tools is a potent temptation. When the cry of “Let’s build it ourselves!” arises, geeks are all too happy to rally and cheer. A celebrated (and perhaps apocryphal) bit of graffiti from MIT captures this: “I would rather write programs to help me write programs than write programs.” Similarly, there is a saying attributed to Abraham Lincoln: “Give me six hours to chop down a tree, and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe.” This principle, which found its way into the business advice manual The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, appeals to every programmer’s passion for toolmaking. But if it becomes an end in itself, it can drive the best-organized project into a ditch. James Gosling, the programming guru who invented Java, discussed this predilection in his blog:



有一些阴暗面：人们谈论最多的一个是，真正完成磨斧头并重新开始砍伐是很重要的。通常，构建工具比实际完成手头的工作有趣得多。

There are a couple of dark sides: The one that people talk about most is that it’s important to actually finish sharpening the axe and get back to chopping. Often tool building is far more fun than actually doing the job at hand.

但对我来说，“斧头磨利”的一个大问题是它是递归的，有点像异形悖论：你花前三分之二的时间来完成实际在工具上工作的任务。但使用工具本身就是一项涉及工具的任务：要磨利斧头，您需要磨刀石。因此，您需要花费三分之二的磨刀时间才能找到一块好的磨刀石。但在此之前，您需要花时间寻找合适的石头。在此之前，您需要前往巴芬岛的北海岸，您听说那里有最好的磨刀石。但要到达那里，您需要建造一个狗拉雪橇。。。。

But for me, the big problem with “axe sharpening” is that it’s recursive, in a Xeno’s paradox kinda way: You spend the first two thirds of the time allotted to accomplishing a task actually working on the tool. But working on the tool is itself a task that involves tools: To sharpen the axe, you need a sharpening stone. So you spend two-thirds of the sharpening time coming up with a good sharpening stone. But before you can do that you need to spend time finding the right stone. And before you can do that you need to go to the north coast of Baffin Island where you’ve heard the best stones for sharpening come from. But to get there, you need to build a dog sled . . . .

塞诺悖论得到了解决，因为虽然它是一个无限和，但它是指数衰减值的无限和。在这种情况下就没有这样的运气了。工具构建工作变得越来越大，你很快就会忘记你开始做的事情。

Xeno’s paradox is resolved because while it is an infinite sum, it’s an infinite sum of exponentially decaying values. No such luck in this case. The tool building jobs just get bigger, and you pretty quickly can lose sight of what it was you started to do.



程序员对这种现象使用的另一个术语是“ yak-shaving”，在埃里克·雷蒙德的行话文件中定义为“看似毫无意义的活动，但实际上是解决问题所必需的，而这个问题解决了一个问题，经过几级递归，解决了你真正的问题”正在努力。”

Another term programmers have applied to this phenomenon is yak-shaving, defined in Eric Raymond’s Jargon File as a “seemingly pointless activity which is actually necessary to solve a problem which solves a problem which, several levels of recursion later, solves the real problem you’re working on.”

程序员总是能够证明任何个人磨斧头或剃牦牛毛的行为是“确实必要的”。其中一些确实是。软件经理很难决定什么时候磨斧子或剃牦牛已经脱离了项目的最初目标，并把程序员从他们快乐的工具管理中带回主要任务。

Programmers will always be able to justify any individual act of axe-sharpening or yak-shaving as “actually necessary.” Some of them certainly are. It is the hard lot of the software manager to decide at what point the axe-sharpening or yak-shaving has lost touch with a project’s original goal and to summon the programmers back from their happy tool-tending sidetracks to the primary task.





OSAF 在 4 月份发布了 Chandler 0.1，并在 5 月份的大部分时间里召开了一系列杀蛇会议。Michael Toy 现在面临的紧急决定是如何安排 0.2 版本的发布。他们是否应该选择一组目标功能，并在这些功能全部编码并运行后宣布发布完成？或者他们应该设定一个确定的日期并声明截至该日期有效的程序部分，无论结果如何，都是 Chandler 0.2？Toy 的本能偏好是后者——“时钟驱动的发布”或“按日期发布里程碑”。毕竟，这仍然是一个 alpha 产品；没有人使用它或可以使用它。如果你没有选择一个明确的日期并坚持下去，你就会冒着让钱德勒 0.1 进入加时赛的那种失误的风险。

OSAF had released Chandler 0.1 in April and spent much of May in a series of snake-slaying meetings. The urgent decision Michael Toy now faced was how to schedule the 0.2 release. Should they pick a target set of features and declare the release done when those features were all coded and working? Or should they set a firm date and declare that the portions of the program that worked as of that date, whatever they turned out to be, were Chandler 0.2? Toy’s instinctual preference was the latter choice—“clock-driven release” or “milestone by date.” After all, this was still an alpha product; no one was using it or could use it. And if you didn’t pick a line-in-the-sand date and stick to it, you risked the sort of slippage that had carried Chandler 0.1 into extra innings.

Toy 和 Kapor 最终同意 OSAF 将遵循时钟驱动的季度发布时间表。已经是六月了。Chandler 0.2 将于 9 月份到期。随着 Andi Vajda 的加入，存储库终于开始整合起来。程序员们把他们的工具排成一排，把他们的斧子磨利了。

Toy and Kapor finally agreed that OSAF would follow a clock-driven schedule of quarterly releases. It was already June; Chandler 0.2 would be due in September. With Andi Vajda on board, the repository was finally beginning to come together. The programmers had their tools lined up, their axes sharpened.

钱德勒所缺少的只是一个完成的设计。

All that was missing from Chandler was a finished design.

第 6 章                           

CHAPTER 6                           

完成设计

GETTING DESIGN DONE

[2003 年 7 月至 11 月]

[JULY–NOVEMBER 2003]

一天深夜，在我为本书做研究的过程中，当我深入了解软件系统可能出错的所有不同方式时，我对自己说：“别做个白痴。备份你的工作。”

Late one night in my research for this book, as I plunged deeper into an awareness of all the different ways a software system can go awry, I said to myself, “Don’t be an idiot. Back up your work.”

所以我制定了一个后备计划。第一步是将我的劳动成果收集到一个大文件夹中：图书项目。我在办公室电脑和家里保存的所有文件、我所有的网址、采访笔记和午夜笔记都被放进了图书项目中。

So I devised a backup plan. The first step was to gather the fruits of my labor into one big folder: Book Project. Into Book Project went all my saved files from my office computer and home, all my Web addresses and interview notes and midnight jottings.

那里！但现在 Book Project 本身被埋藏在文件夹层次结构中的三层以下。那很不方便。我将在这个文件夹中度过我工作生活的很大一部分一段时间，所以我想把它移到一个更方便的地方。我打开了一个资源管理器窗口（Microsoft Windows 中文件导航的基本工具），并找到了 Book Project。我用鼠标点击了它，按住鼠标按钮，开始将文件夹拖到——

There! But now Book Project itself was buried three levels down in a folder hierarchy. That was inconvenient. I was going to be spending a good part of my work life in this folder for some time, so I wanted to move it to a handier spot. I opened up an Explorer window, the basic tool for file navigation in Microsoft Windows, and found Book Project. I clicked on it with my mouse, held down the mouse button, and began to drag the file folder to—

嗯，具体在哪里？我没有考虑清楚这一点。这很重要。有太多的选择。我需要时间！

Well, where, exactly? I hadn’t thought this through. It was important. There were too many options. I needed time!

我将鼠标指针拖离屏幕并释放按钮——根据对其他程序如何工作的一些感觉记忆，假设此操作将使文件夹像橡皮筋一样弹回到它开始的位置。

I dragged the mouse pointer off the screen and released the button—assuming, based on some sense-memory of how other programs worked, that this action would make the folder snap like a rubber band back to where it started.

它没。必须预见到此类事件的 Windows 程序员做出了不同的假设。如果您将文件夹拖离屏幕，他们会认为您希望它消失。

It did not. The Windows programmers who’d had to anticipate such an event assumed something different. If you dragged a folder off the screen, they figured you wanted it to disappear.

图书项目消失了。所有的。已删除。

Book Project was gone. All of it. Deleted.

我木然地盯着屏幕。那是怎么发生的？

I stared numbly at the screen. How did that happen?

好的，不用惊慌。检查垃圾箱；它一定在里面。再次拖出来就可以了。

Okay, no need to panic. Check the Trash; it must be in there. Just drag it out again.

不在那里。

Not there.

图书项目不再存在。它不再是了。这是一个以前的文件夹。

Book Project was no more. It had ceased to be. It was an ex-folder.

我的脉搏加速了。我的太阳穴一阵阵抽痛。我的一个独立的头脑思考着这一讽刺：所有对软件开发的研究都被软件错误破坏了！但我的其余部分却充满了肾上腺素。

My pulse raced. My temples throbbed. One detached sliver of my mind pondered the irony: All that research into software development wrecked by a software mistake! But the rest of me was an adrenaline-infused mess.

我开始在网络上疯狂研究取消删除实用程序。我以前从来不需要一个。然后我愣住了。我记得，如果您需要恢复已删除的文件，您不想以任何可能导致计算机向硬盘写入新内容的方式使用计算机。新文件可能会覆盖您尝试恢复的文件的残余内容。

I started furiously researching undelete utilities on the Web. I’d never needed one before. Then I froze. If you need to recover deleted files, I remembered, you don’t want to use your computer in any way that might cause it to write new stuff to your hard disk. The new files might write over the remnants of the ones you were trying to recover.

终于，我平静下来，脑海里响起了一个小声音：撤消。

Finally, I calmed myself, and a little voice in my head piped up: Undo.

正确的。当然。撤消。我查看了资源管理器中的“编辑”菜单。它就在那里——我的救星。单击“撤消”，我的图书项目宝贝就回来了，安全地在文件夹树中的巢穴中。

Right. Of course. Undo. I looked under the Edit menu in Explorer. There it was—my savior. One click on Undo, and my Book Project baby was back, safe in its nest in the folder tree.

我停顿了一分钟，默默地感谢那些使这次恢复成为可能的 Windows 程序员，尽管他们很可能就是那些让我陷入灾难的人。然后我就去睡觉了。

I paused a minute to give silent thanks to the Windows programmers who had made this recovery possible—even though they were probably the same ones who had set me up for disaster. Then I went to sleep.





创建最终用户应用软件（供凡人使用的软件）意味着预测人类行为和机器反应的无数组合。电脑屏幕有几十万个像素；用户可以随时单击其中任何一个，并且程序必须知道要做什么。事实证明，疯狂的用户所做的事情比最优秀的程序员所能想象的还要多。

Creating end-user application software—software intended for use by mere mortals—means anticipating myriad combinations of human actions and machine reactions. A computer screen has hundreds of thousands of pixels; a user can click on any of them at any time, and a program must know what to do. It turns out there are more things under the sun that crazy users do than even the best programmers can possibly imagine.

各种各样的惯例已经发展起来，以帮助驯服和组织这片可能性的海洋，比如单击和双击之间的区别，或者“焦点”的概念——屏幕中在前台活动的部分。（例如，在典型的电子邮件程序中，您的焦点可能位于屏幕中央的新消息列表上，但是如果您单击显示邮件文件夹列表的侧面板，您会将焦点切换到该屏幕元素，这就是您的鼠标点击和击键将被输入的地方。）但这些都是惯例，而不是自然法则；他们没有任何与生俱来的东西。它们随着一代又一代软件的出现和消失而不断发展。正如生物进化一样，旧系统的碎片有时会作为新系统的产物而幸存下来。

All sorts of conventions have evolved to help tame and organize this sea of possibilities, like the difference between single clicking and double clicking, or the idea of “focus”—the part of the screen that is active in the foreground. (In the typical email program, for instance, your focus might be on the list of new messages at the center of the screen, but if you click on the side panel that displays a list of your mail folders, you switch focus to that screen element, and that is where your mouse clicks and keystrokes will be fed.) But these are conventions, not laws of nature; there is nothing innate about them. They evolve as generations of software come and go. And just as in biological evolution, fragments of an older system sometimes survive as artifacts in a new one.

任何在命令行界面时代学习使用计算机的人都明白一个简单的概念，即大多数时候计算机不会“读取”您键入的输入，直到您在末尾按“回车”键。一条线。这是一种反射；我们甚至不考虑它。因此，当我在大约十年前向父母介绍网络时，我向他们展示了如何在浏览器顶部的栏中输入任何网址。然而，当他们尝试时，什么也没发生。我忘了告诉他们，“完成后按‘回车’。” Web 浏览器是一个鼠标和窗口、GUI 风格的程序，但地址栏是命令行时代的一点遗迹，带有一套旧的习惯和行为。

Anyone who learned to use computers in the days of the command-line interface understands the simple notion that most of the time the computer isn’t going to “read” the input you type until you hit the “enter” key at the end of a line. It is a reflex; we don’t even think about it. So when I introduced my parents to the Web nearly a decade ago, I showed them how they could type any Web address into the bar at the top of the browser. When they tried, though, nothing happened. I had forgotten to tell them, “Hit ‘enter’ when you’re done.” The Web browser is a mouse-and-windows, GUI-style program, but that address bar is a little vestige of the command-line era, carrying an old set of customs and behaviors with it.

默认情况下，通常是程序员最终试图弄清楚程序应该如何对用户输入和机器状态的数千种可能组合中的每一种做出反应。但他们并不总是能够很好地设身处地为用户着想并想象什么是有意义的。他们的大部分工作时间都花在处理数字细节上，他们的反应能力已经在他们构建的系统的习惯中得到了训练。他们认为理所当然的概念对于非程序员来说往往是完全陌生的；用户的假设可能对他们来说很陌生。（程序员经常依赖的一种解决方法是“妈妈测试”，其中假定无知的父母充当假设的用例，有时甚至是真正的豚鼠。）

By default, it is usually programmers who end up trying to figure out how a program should react to each of the thousands of possible combinations of user inputs and machine states. But they are not always well equipped to put themselves in a user’s shoes and imagine what will make sense. They spend the bulk of their working hours wrestling with digital minutiae, and their reflexes have already been trained in the customs of the systems they build. Concepts they take for granted are often entirely alien to nonprogrammers; users’ assumptions may well be foreign to them. (One work-around that programmers often rely on is the “mom test,” in which the presumed-to-be-clueless parent serves as a hypothetical use case or sometimes an actual guinea pig.)

除此之外，程序员的工作就是想象极端的可能性和不可能的场景。如果您正在保存工作时停电怎么办？当用户将计算机时钟设置为年份A时，日历会发生什么情况。D . 2099？（Microsoft Windows 允许您做到这一点，当数百万人使用像 Windows 这样的软件时，迟早有人会做出该软件允许的所有可能不太可能的选择。）程序员将这些情况称为边缘情况，并且它们通常是虫子隐藏的地方。经过训练后，程序员对哪些情况真正重要的务实、直觉意识可能会变得生疏。他们在边缘花费了太多的脑力，以至于忽视了中心。

Beyond that, it is the programmer’s job to imagine extreme possibilities and unlikely scenarios. What if the power goes out while you’re in the middle of saving your work? What happens to a calendar when the user has set his computer’s clock to the year A.D. 2099? (Microsoft Windows allows you to do this, and when millions of people use a piece of software like Windows, sooner or later someone will end up making every possible unlikely choice that the software allows.) Programmers call these edge cases, and they are often where bugs hide. Trained to imagine them with exhaustive thoroughness, programmers’ pragmatic, gut-sense awareness of which cases really matter can get rusty. They spend so much brainpower out on the edge that they lose sight of the center.

如果程序员不是做出共同构成软件程序设计的决策的最佳人选，那么谁是呢？

If a programmer isn’t the best person to make the decisions that collectively constitute a software program’s design, then who is?





Mitch Kapor 一直对软件设计的细节充满热情，从最广泛的哲学问题到最平凡的安装和完成细节（让应用程序看起来和感觉适合用户）。将软件设计建立为一个独立的职业一直是他近二十年来的事业之一。

Mitch Kapor has always been passionate about the nuts and bolts of software design, from the broadest philosophical questions to the most mundane details of fit and finish (getting an application to look and feel right to a user). Establishing software design as a discrete profession has been one of his causes for nearly two decades.

1990年，在计算机行业名人聚集的PC论坛上，卡普尔首次发表了他的《软件设计宣言》正文。

In 1990, at the PC Forum gathering of computer industry luminaries, Kapor first delivered the text of his “Software Design Manifesto.”



没有人为可怜的用户说话。在这个问题上有一个沉默的阴谋。。。。撇开表面，你会发现人们不好意思说他们发现这些设备很难使用。他们认为错是他们自己。。。。我认识的每个人（包括我）每周至少都会有一次把那台令人恼火的机器扔出窗外的冲动。。。。软件可用性的缺乏和程序设计的糟糕是这个行业的秘密耻辱。。。。什么是要做？计算专业人员本身应该负责创造积极的用户体验。也许要采取的最重要的概念举措是认识到设计（作为编程的对应部分）在计算机工件创建中的关键作用。计算行业中最重要的社会演变是为软件设计师创造一个用户体验倡导者的角色。

No one is speaking for the poor user. There is a conspiracy of silence on this issue . . . . Scratch the surface and you’ll find that people are embarrassed to say they find these devices hard to use. They think the fault is their own . . . . Everyone I know (including me) feels the urge to throw that infuriating machine through the window at least once a week . . . . The lack of usability of software and the poor design of programs are the secret shame of the industry . . . . What is to be done? Computing professionals themselves should take responsibility for creating a positive user experience. Perhaps the most important conceptual move to be taken is to recognize the critical role of design, as a counterpart to programming, in the creation of computer artifacts. And the most important social evolution within the computing professions would be to create a role for the software designer as a champion of the user experience.



卡普尔认为，软件设计不仅仅是在程序员的代码上悬挂吸引人的图形的问题。这是想象用户需求并设计软件结构来满足这些需求的基本创造性行为。正如建筑师为施工团队绘制蓝图一样，软件设计师也应该创建软件工程师工作所需的平面图和立面图。追溯到古罗马，卡普尔建议将建筑理论家维特鲁威的良好设计原则应用到软件中：坚固——结构合理，没有错误；商品——“程序应该适合其预期目的”；喜悦——“使用该程序的体验应该是一种愉快的体验。”

Software design, Kapor argued, was not simply a matter of hanging attractive graphics atop the programmers’ code. It was the fundamental creative act of imagining the user’s needs and devising structures in software to fulfill those needs. As the architect draws up blueprints for the construction team, so the software designer should create the floor plans and elevation views from which software engineers would work. Reaching back to ancient Rome, Kapor proposed applying to software the architecture theorist Vitruvius’s principles of good design: firmness—sound structure, no bugs; commodity—“A program should be suitable for the purposes for which it was intended”; delight—“The experience of using the program should be a pleasurable one.”

卡普尔的许多宣言在今天听起来可能是不言而喻的，但他关于设计师应该带头创建软件的主张仍然存在争议。一些程序员看不起设计和设计师的想法，并且非常确定他们是程序外观和行为的最佳仲裁者。其他人则相信代码至上，认为您无法真正抽象地理解软件的形状或工作方式。因此，“设计优先”（也称为 Big Design Up Front，或 BDUF）行不通。因此，最好让程序快速启动并运行，然后根据用户反馈对其进行改进。

A lot of Kapor’s manifesto may sound self-evident today, but his assertion that designers should take the lead in creating software remains controversial. Some programmers look down on the very idea of design and designers, and are quite certain they are the best arbiters of how their programs should look and behave. Others believe in the primacy of code, feeling that you can’t really understand anything about the shape or workings of a piece of software in the abstract. Therefore, “Design first” (also known as Big Design Up Front, or BDUF) can’t work. So it’s better to get a program up and running fast and then refine it in response to user feedback.

卡普尔从未坚持认为设计必须与编码分开并在编码之前进行。“在实施设计的过程中，会出现新的信息，这很多时候会改变原来的设计，”他的宣言宣称。“如果设计和实施都在不漏水的隔间中进行，则可能会酿成灾难，因为完善和变更的自然过程被阻止了。”

Kapor never maintained that design had to happen separate from and before coding. “During the course of implementing a design, new information will arise, which many times will change the original design,” his manifesto declared. “If design and implementation are in watertight compartments, it can be a recipe for disaster because the natural process of refinement and change is prevented.”

卡普尔本人一直是 OSAF 的首席设计师，但那里的每个人都有某种形式的设计信仰。赫茨菲尔德对可用性的奉献近乎痴迷。这是与他的一次罕见的交流，没有导致诸如“用户不会明白这一点”或“让用户决定”之类的观察。

Kapor himself had always been the lead designer at OSAF, but everyone there had some form of the design religion. Hertzfeld’s dedication to usability verged on the obsessive. It was a rare exchange with him that didn’t lead to an observation like “The user isn’t going to get that” or “Let the user decide.”

但到了 2003 年夏天，OSAF 仍然没有为钱德勒制定出完整的设计方案；该方案更多地是一套原则、愿望和承诺，而不是一批蓝图。部分问题在于卡普尔和他的团队在聘请设计师时遇到了困难。他们需要一个具有良好图形意识、了解界面设计并能够与程序员密切合作的人。卡普尔的标准非常严格。他们只是还没有找到合适的人。

But by the summer of 2003, OSAF still did not have a fully worked out design for Chandler; the program remained more a set of principles and aspirations and commitments than a batch of blueprints. Part of the problem was that Kapor and his team had had trouble hiring a designer. They needed someone with a good graphic sense who also understood interface design and could work closely with programmers. Kapor’s standards were exacting. They simply hadn’t found the right person yet.

但确定钱德勒的设计也很困难，因为这样做意味着要解决该项目的雄心和技术现实之间的困难权衡。如果没有确定的设计，就很难做出坚定的技术选择；如果没有技术路线图，就很难确定设计。这项工作不断遇到这个先有鸡还是先有蛋的问题，这让 OSAF 团队的大部分人都感到沮丧。

But it was also hard to nail down Chandler’s design because doing so meant resolving difficult trade-offs between the program’s ambitions and technical realities. Making firm technical choices was hard in the absence of a settled design, and settling on a design was hard in the absence of a technical roadmap. The work kept bumping into this chicken-and-egg problem, and it cast a pall of discouragement over much of the OSAF team.

网景公司的孩子卢·蒙图利（Lou Montulli）和亚历克斯·托蒂奇（Aleks Totic）对缓慢的节奏感到沮丧，他们逐渐放弃了六个月前自愿参与的项目。蒙图利后来将他离开的决定解释为性格不合：“我是一个相当具有破坏性的人。我喜欢快速推动变革。在整个组织中，人们希望采取更加谨慎、缓慢的软件开发方法，这对我来说并不合适。” Totic 将精力转向一个新项目，采用日益流行的开源开发工具包 Eclipse 来与 Python 配合使用。蒙图利回到太浩湖策划新的创业项目。

Disheartened by the slow pace, Lou Montulli and Aleks Totic, the Netscape kids, drifted away from the project they had volunteered for six months before. Montulli later explained his decision to leave as a case of a bad personality fit: “I’m a fairly disruptive person. I like to push change fairly rapidly. Throughout the organization, people wanted to take a much more cautious, slow approach to software development, which didn’t feel right to me.” Totic turned his energies toward a new project, adapting an increasingly popular open source development toolkit called Eclipse to work with Python. Montulli returned to Lake Tahoe to plot new start-up ventures.





2003 年 7 月，当 Andi Vajda 开始挖掘 Chandler 存储库的基础时，Mitch Kapor 与 John Anderson、Andy Hertzfeld 以及后来的 Michael Toy 建立了一个非正式工作组，以制定构建 Chandler 用户界面的计划。钱德勒的作品（或包裹）的制作工作，就像凯蒂·帕兰特的日历一样，已经陷入停滞。该程序缺少一个关键部分，即一个在不同时期被称为“大表”、“汇总表”或“超级小部件”的结构，即显示您的电子邮件收件箱或任务列表的程序部分或简短摘要或摘要形式的日历事件。

In July 2003, as Andi Vajda began digging the foundations for the Chandler repository, Mitch Kapor established an informal working group with John Anderson, Andy Hertzfeld, and later Michael Toy to hash out a plan for building Chandler’s user interface. Work on the pieces—or parcels—of Chandler, like Katie Parlante’s calendar, had reached a standstill. The program was missing a key part, a structure that was at various times called “the big table,” “the summary table,” or “the superwidget”—the piece of the program that would present your email inbox or your list of tasks or calendar events in a brief digest or summary form.

必须有人站出来开始编写超级小部件的代码。赫茨菲尔德为 Vista 原型编写了此类界面的一个版本，但他认为对于真正的钱德勒来说，这项工作属于约翰·安德森。安德森同意了。但他不想太深入地研究代码，直到他确信自己理解 Kapor 希望超级小部件如何工作，并且直到 Chandler 的主要贡献者就构建它的正确方法达成共识。对于如何去做，他有自己的一些想法。

Someone had to step forward and begin coding the superwidget. Hertzfeld had written a version of such an interface for the Vista prototype, but he felt that for the real Chandler the job belonged to John Anderson. Anderson agreed. But he didn’t want to plunge too deeply into the code until he was confident that he understood how Kapor wanted the superwidget to work and until Chandler’s key contributors had reached a consensus on the proper approach to building it. And he had some ideas of his own about how it should be done.





“问题是，”米奇·卡普尔（Mitch Kapor）在一系列漫长的会议中说道，“我们如何安排事情的顺序，以避免在任何有用的事情发生之前花费无限的时间？”

“The question is,” said Mitch Kapor, deep in the middle of a long meeting in a series of long meetings, “How do we sequence things to avoid spending an infinite amount of time before anything useful happens?”

“只有当你陷入循环时，它才是无限的，”赫茨菲尔德回答道。

“It’s only infinite if you’re stuck in a loop,” Hertzfeld replied.





随着对话开始，卡普尔、安德森和赫茨菲尔德决定，用户和程序员将主要通过他们所谓的“钱德勒文档”与钱德勒合作。与文字处理文档一样，Chandler 文档会存储数据，但与电子表格文档一样，它也是一种模板，存储处理该数据的代码和规则。与构成卡普尔职业生涯基石的软件创新领域——电子表格一样，钱德勒的文件将把通常保留给熟练程序员的权力——扩展程序功能和用途的能力——直接交到日常人员手中。用户。

As the conversations started, Kapor, Anderson, and Hertzfeld decided that both users and programmers would work with Chandler primarily through what they began to call “Chandler documents.” Like a word processor document, a Chandler document would store data, but like a spreadsheet document, it would also be a kind of template, storing code and rules for handling that data. And as with spreadsheets, the field of software innovation that formed the cornerstone of Kapor’s career, Chandler documents would put the kind of power normally reserved to skilled programmers—the ability to extend the functions and uses of the program—directly into the hands of everyday users.

随着对文档的新关注，该小组的讨论开始被称为文档架构会议。这些会议整个夏天都会举行，有时每周举行三到四次下午的会议。尽管他们的目标是解决悬而未决的问题，以便安德森可以开始编写超级小部件，但他们发现很难缩小讨论的焦点。考虑到人们假设与钱德勒一起完成任务的方式，就会转向对代理的讨论，这是安迪·赫茨菲尔德长期以来对自动化、半自主软件例程的愿景，这些例程将为用户处理例行任务。关于用户应该对钱德勒在屏幕上的外观和布局有多少精细控制的争论很快就会变成一场关于移动设备上的钱德勒或通过网络访问钱德勒的混战。每一次讨论似乎都回到了这样一个想法：钱德勒可能会通过采用或改编 Mozilla 的某些部分而从某种程度上受益，这一想法在理论上被抛弃了，但仍然令人痛苦。

With the new focus on documents, the group’s discussions began to be known as Document Architecture meetings. They happened throughout the summer, sometimes for three or four all-afternoon meetings a week. Though their goal was to resolve open issues so that Anderson could start writing a superwidget, they found it difficult to narrow the focus of their talks. A consideration of the ways people might hypothetically accomplish tasks with Chandler would take a left turn into a discussion of agents, Andy Hertzfeld’s long-held vision of automated, semi-autonomous software routines that would handle routine tasks for the user. A debate over how much fine control users should have over the look and layout of Chandler on screen would quickly turn into a free-for-all about Chandler on mobile devices or Chandler access over the Web. And every discussion seemed to wind up back at the idea, theoretically discarded but still gnawing, that Chandler might somehow benefit by adopting or adapting parts of Mozilla.

自安德森首次审查并拒绝 Mozilla 的工具以来，已经过去了近一年的时间。1998 年 Netscape 开放其代码时，Mozilla 的工具是从 Netscape 的软件演变而来的。从那时起，前 Netscape 员工的涌入——从 Totic、Montulli 到 Toy——使得“我们应该再看看 Mozilla 吗？” 变成常规的 OSAF 克制。但真正让这个问题重新成为人们关注的焦点的是米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 作为 Mozilla 基金会主席的新角色。

It had been nearly a year since Anderson first examined and rejected Mozilla’s tools, which had evolved out of Netscape’s software when Netscape opened up its code in 1998. Since then, the influx of former Netscape employees—from Totic and Montulli to Toy—had made “Should we look at Mozilla again?” into a regular OSAF refrain. But what really brought the question back into the spotlight was Mitch Kapor’s new role as chairman of the Mozilla Foundation.

最初，Mozilla 的核心程序员大多在 Netscape 的工资单上工作，当 Netscape 1998 年被美国在线收购时，他们成为了 AOL 的员工。到 2003 年，这意味着他们成为时代华纳的员工，这家媒体集团在互联网繁荣的鼎盛时期与美国在线合并，后来后悔了这一举动。在科技低迷的低迷时期，AOL 高管开始问：再告诉我一次，为什么我们要付钱给一群程序员来赠送代码？Mozilla 的未来看起来越来越不确定。

Originally, Mozilla’s core programmers mostly held jobs on Netscape’s payroll, and when Netscape got bought by America Online in 1998, they became AOL employees. By 2003 that meant they were employees of Time Warner, the media conglomerate that had merged with AOL at the height of the dot-com boom and later came to regret the move. Deep in the doldrums of the tech downturn, AOL executives began asking: Tell me again why we’re paying a bunch of programmers to give away code? The future of Mozilla looked increasingly uncertain.

Kapor 已经通过 Mitchell Baker 与 Mozilla 建立了联系，Mitchell Baker 自 2002 年底以来一直在 OSAF 兼职。 Baker 是另一位 Netscape 资深人士，在 Netscape 浏览器的开源过程中发挥了核心作用：她编写了许可协议， Netscape 代码已发布。随着对 Mozilla 的支持逐渐冷淡，AOL 于 2001 年解雇了她，但她继续作为志愿者帮助领导 Mozilla 项目。Kapor 邀请她加入 OSAF，并利用她的开源经验帮助他的组织围绕 Chandler 建立一个开发人员社区。她还让卡普尔了解 Mozilla 在 AOL 内部的地位日益不稳定。

Kapor already had one connection with Mozilla through Mitchell Baker, who had been working at OSAF part-time since late 2002. Another Netscape veteran, Baker had played a central role in the open sourcing of the Netscape browser: She wrote the license under which the Netscape code was released. AOL, as its support for Mozilla grew cold, had laid her off in 2001, but she continued to help lead the Mozilla Project as a volunteer. Kapor asked her to join OSAF and use her open source experience to help his organization build a community of developers around Chandler. She also kept Kapor apprised of Mozilla’s increasingly precarious position inside AOL.

2003 年 5 月，Kapor 和 AOL 高管 Ted Leonsis 在一次行业会议上的一次偶然会面产生了一个让所有人都满意的解决方案：AOL 将剥离整个 Mozilla 业务，但不会不帮助资助一个新的非营利基金会（200 万美元）两年多）将接管 Mozilla 关键人员的工资并继续该项目的工作。卡普尔额外投入了 30 万美元并同意担任该基金会的主席。

In May 2003, a chance meeting between Kapor and AOL executive Ted Leonsis at an industry conference led to a solution that left everyone happy: AOL would divest itself of the entire Mozilla operation, but not without helping fund a new nonprofit foundation (with $2 million over two years) that would take over the payroll for key Mozilla personnel and carry on the project’s work. Kapor kicked in an additional $300,000 and agreed to serve as the foundation’s chairman.

由于 Chandler 开发人员仍未获得太多关注，而 Kapor 现在已在 Mozilla 担任正式职务，Kapor 认为再次关注 Mozilla 是有意义的。他认为，至少有一个“大综合”的机会。

Since the Chandler developers still hadn’t gained much traction and Kapor now had a formal role with Mozilla, Kapor suggested it made sense to look at Mozilla again. There was, he felt, at least an opportunity for a “grand synthesis.”





2003 年 7 月下旬的一个下午，文档架构小组聚集在 OSAF 霍华德街办公室的小会议室里。安德森打开他最喜欢的个人信息管理器——方格纸笔记本。赫茨菲尔德有一本带有红丝带书签的分类帐式的书。卡普尔旁边放着一本黄色便笺簿。玩具是唯一一个带有笔记本电脑的玩具。每个人都从新办公室的厨房区拿了一块披萨。

One afternoon in late July 2003, the document architecture group gathers in the small conference room at OSAF’s Howard Street office. Anderson opens his preferred personal information manager—a graph paper notebook. Hertzfeld has his, a ledger-style book with a red ribbon bookmark. Next to Kapor lies a yellow legal pad. Toy is the only one with a laptop computer. Everyone has grabbed a slice of pizza from the kitchen area of the new office.

赫茨菲尔德迫不及待地想推动钱德勒前进，他提出了一个激进的想法：他指出，Mozilla 的结构已经可以将其他程序作为插件纳入其中。为什么不将 Chandler 本身打造为一个大型 Mozilla 插件呢？当然，他承认，会有问题。基于浏览器的设计肯定需要对钱德勒的目标进行大量重新思考。但依赖浏览器的界面将为程序员节省大量自己构建新界面的劳动力。

Hertzfeld, impatient to move Chandler along, proposes a radical idea: Mozilla, he points out, is already structured to incorporate other programs as plug-ins. Why not build Chandler itself as one big Mozilla plug-in? Of course, he admits, there’d be problems. A browser-based design would certainly require a lot of rethinking of Chandler’s goals. But relying on the browser’s interface would save the programmers enormous amounts of the labor involved in building a new interface themselves.

“我们还有很多工作要做。如果能绑上一些助推火箭就太好了，”他说。

“There’s so much work ahead of us. It would be great to strap on some booster rockets,” he says.

Michael Toy 经常亲自提出 Mozilla 选项，但这一次他提出了警告。“互联网发明已经四万年了，我们仍然没有办法让愚蠢的人创建有用的网站。对于非 Web 的事物来说，Web 浏览器并不是一个很好的界面。看起来我们在开始步行之前就已经背上了一个很糟糕的背包。”

Michael Toy had often brought up the Mozilla option himself, but this time he raises cautions. “It’s been forty thousand years since the invention of the Internet, and we still don’t have a way for dumb people to make Web sites that are useful. And a Web browser is not a very good interface to something that is not the Web. It just seems like we’d be strapping a bad backpack on before we start walking.”

安德森说，将 Mozilla 与 OSAF 已经开始使用的 wxWidgets 工具进行比较，是一个令人沮丧的苹果和橘子练习。“我感觉自己就像在冰山之巅随意漫游。”

Comparing Mozilla with the wxWidgets tools that OSAF has already begun using, Anderson says, has been a frustrating apples-and-oranges exercise. “I feel like I’m randomly roaming around the top of an iceberg.”

卡普尔站起来，走到白板前，画了一个简单的矩形布局，并开始给它们贴上标签。“这是屏幕。这些矩形内的某些区域肯定会有这些丰富的小部件，其中有复杂的用户交互，并且与数据模型相关。桌子。轮廓。不同的看法。这就是我们的特殊风味。我们知道我们将会拥有这些东西。这些东西都得摆出来。而且您还有其他标准 GUI 内容 — 装饰性文本、按钮和控件。那么问题来了，这从何而来？” 他指着自己写布局的地方——基本部件集。“我们的记录计划是这来自 wxWidgets。还有一个问题：这需要多少工作量？”

Kapor gets up, goes to the whiteboard, sketches a simple layout of rectangles, and begins to label them. “Here’s the screen. Certain areas sitting inside these rectangles are definitely going to have these rich widgets where there’s sophisticated user interaction and it’s tied to the data model. Tables. Outlines. Different views. That’s our special flavor. We know we’re going to have those things. These things have to be laid out. And you’ve got other standard GUI stuff—ornamental text and buttons and controls. So the question is, where does this come from?” He points to a spot where he’s written layout—base widget set. “Our plan of record is this comes from wxWidgets. And there’s a question: How much work will that be?”

安德森说道：“目前，尺寸调整器将是进行布局的最简单方法。” （Sizer 代码是 wxWidgets 工具包用来在屏幕上布置窗口形状的基本方法。）

Anderson speaks up: “Right now, sizers would be the simplest way to do layout.” (Sizer code is the basic means the wxWidgets toolkit uses to lay out window shapes onscreen.)

“事实证明，这对人们来说比建立网页要困难一个数量级，”赫茨菲尔德反对道。

“This is proven to be an order of magnitude harder for people to do than putting up Web pages,” Hertzfeld objects.

“我对尺寸测定器的一个担忧是它们是二维的，”托伊说。“CSS [层叠样式表，现代 Web 浏览器使用的布局规范格式] 可让您将事物置于事物之上。”

“One of my concerns about sizers is that they’re two-dimensional,” Toy says. “CSS [Cascading Style Sheets, the layout specification format that modern Web browsers use] lets you put things on top of things.”

当他们谈话时，Kapor 在黑板上写着：sizer 框架足够灵活吗？富有表现力？

As they talk, Kapor is writing on the board: Is sizer framework sufficiently flexible? Expressive?

“使用 Mozilla 的部分想法是它可以免费为您提供一些布局表现力，”卡普尔说。

“Part of the idea of using Mozilla was that it might give you for free some of the expressiveness in layout,” Kapor says.

“很多人觉得 CSS 非常令人畏惧，”Anderson 说。

“A lot of people find CSS pretty daunting,” Anderson says.

“你需要用户友好的编辑器，”卡普尔说。“这些的缺失是偶然的还是根本的？”

“You’d need user-friendly editors,” Kapor says. “Is the absence of those contingent or fundamental?”

“Michael 的观点是，”Anderson 回答道，“从根本上来说，为 CSS 制作一个好的 GUI 是很困难的。”

“Michael’s opinion,” Anderson replies, “is that it’s fundamentally hard to make a good GUI for CSS.”

“我们可能只是武断地决定不解决丰富的文档问题，”托伊说。“我能感觉到它就像一个黑洞。”

“It might be that we just arbitrarily decide not to solve the rich document problem,” Toy says. “I can feel that as a black hole.”

卡普尔再次写道：要解决丰富文档问题的哪一部分？

Kapor writes again: What part of the rich document problem to solve?

会议中的每位参与者都曾在某一时刻承认自己有一种“挥手”的感觉——只是泛泛而谈，没有严格研究细节。最大的挥手似乎围绕着术语“文档”本身的含义。

At one point or another, each of the participants in the meeting had admitted feeling a sense that they were “handwaving”—talking in generalities without rigorously working out details. The biggest wave of the hands seemed to surround the meaning of the term document itself.

“你能把整个应用程序做成一个文档吗？” 卡普尔问道。

“Could you do a whole app as a document?” Kapor asks.

“你可以将其作为一组文件来完成，”赫茨菲尔德说。

“It’s could you do it as a set of documents,” Hertzfeld says.

“钱德勒是一份文件吗？” 玩具问道。

“Is Chandler a document?” Toy asks.

赫茨菲尔德回答道：“我们讨论过，对话是文件吗？它们是投影到窗口中的基础文档的一部分吗？或者它们是一个单独的文件？”

Hertzfeld replies, “We talked about, are dialogues documents? Are they part of the base document projected into a window? Or are they a separate document?”

“然后，”Anderson 补充道，“还有镶边”（应用程序窗口周围的框架，用户可以在其中打开菜单、操作滚动条等）。

“Then,” adds Anderson, “there’s also the chrome” (the frame surrounding the application windows where users open menus, manipulate scrollbars, and so forth).

“有自由意志吗？” 卡普尔开玩笑。“有很多问题，但考虑到它们具有形而上学的成分，我宁愿推迟它们，直到我们濒临死亡。”

“Is there free will?” Kapor jokes. “There are lots of questions, but given that they have a metaphysical component, I prefer to defer them till we’re at death’s door.”

这四个人开始讨论基于 Mozilla 的 Chandler 如何提供一个简单的功能，例如“进度条”，一个逐渐填满的空条，为用户提供某些任务进度的实时指示，例如接收任务的进展情况。大堆电子邮件。这种实时更新的动态界面元素是我们在大多数日常程序中认为理所当然的功能。这可能是像 Mozilla 这样的面向 Web 的平台的延伸，它被设计为以静态屏幕的形式显示从服务器传送的数据。基于 Mozilla 的 Chandler 需要基于 Javascript 来实现这样的功能，Javascript 是一种专门用于在网页中嵌入程序代码的编程语言。（HTML 是发布网页的基本语言，实际上根本不是一种编程语言；它只是告诉浏览器在屏幕上显示什么内容。）

The four men begin to talk about how a Mozilla-based Chandler might provide a simple feature like a “progress bar,” an empty bar that gradually fills up, giving the user a real-time indication of progress made on some task like receiving a big pile of email messages. This sort of dynamic interface element, which updates in real time, is the kind of feature we take for granted in most everyday programs. It might be a stretch for a Web-oriented platform like Mozilla, which was designed to display data in static screenfuls delivered from a server. A Mozilla-based Chandler would need to base such a feature on Javascript, a programming language meant specifically for embedding program code inside Web pages. (HTML, the basic language for publishing Web pages, isn’t really a programming language at all; it just tells a browser what to show on screen.)

“您在 Web 应用程序中永远不会看到这种情况，因为客户端在一秒钟内只能与服务器进行几次往返，”Kapor 说。“我想要一种信心，我们将拥有一流的方法来做到这一点。对我来说，这是整个 PC 与 Web 的核心。你每秒只能与服务器进行这么多次往返，否则你的性能就会受到影响。”

“You never see this in a Web application because the client can only make a few round trips to the server in a second,” Kapor says. “I want a sense of confidence that we’ll have a first-class way to do this. To me this is at the heart of the whole PC-versus-Web thing. You can have only so many round trips to the server per second or your performance gets clobbered.”

披萨是冷的。讨论花费了一个下午的时间。Kapor 表示，他希望与 Mozilla 的首席架构师（他在 Netscape 创建了 Javascript）Brendan Eich 为该小组安排一次会议。

The pizza is cold. The discussion has consumed the afternoon. Kapor says he wants to set up a meeting for the group with Brendan Eich, Mozilla’s lead architect (at Netscape he’d created Javascript).

“如果说我们与 Mozilla 的整合有巨大的优势，那么它的程度对于我们来说还太微妙，无法识别。但我想看看这是否值得进行对话，”他总结道。“是大手术吗？双肺和心脏移植是彻底且可行的。如果是换头的话，那就没什么好谈的了。”

“If there is a huge advantage in us integrating with Mozilla, it’s at a level too subtle for us to identify yet. But I want to see whether it’s a worthwhile conversation,” he concludes. “Is it major surgery? A double lung and heart transplant is radical and possible. If it’s a head transplant, it’s not worth talking about.”

卡普尔告诉他的同事，无论你做什么，都不要让这成为一个阻碍问题。并在一个月内解决。

Whatever you do, Kapor tells his colleagues, don’t let this become a blocking issue. And settle it within a month.





一个月后，问题确实得到解决。文档架构小组放弃了在 Mozilla 之上构建 Chandler 的想法，并决定坚持其最初的计划。该术语文件仍然难以捉摸，并且随着工作重点缩小到钱德勒布局引擎的具体细节，而不是“钱德勒的布局是什么？” 但是“钱德勒将使用什么工具，程序员将如何操纵它们？”——他们为自己的工作想出了一个新标签。他们正在研究的系统被称为 CPIA（他们将其发音为“棕褐色”），意为“钱德勒演示和交互架构”。

A month later the issue was indeed resolved. The document architecture group abandoned the idea of building Chandler on top of Mozilla and decided to stick to its original plan. The term document remained elusive, and as the focus of the work narrowed to the nuts and bolts of Chandler’s layout engine—not “What will the layout of Chandler be?” but “What tools will lay out Chandler, and how will the programmers manipulate them?”—they came up with a new label for their work. The system they were laboring over would be called CPIA (they pronounced it like the color sepia) for “Chandler Presentation and Interaction Architecture.”

CPIA 将构建在 wxWidgets 之上，但其目标是将 Chandler 的 Python 代码包装到称为“块”的包中，这些包将连接到每个 wxWidgets 元素。在遥远的未来，我们的想法是，CPIA 块将使非程序员可以通过简单地将预先存在的块连接在一起来轻松构建 Chandler 的新功能。从更近的角度来看，CPIA 块将使 OSAF 的程序员更容易构建 Chandler。该程序会将其块作为数据存储在 Chandler 存储库本身中。从理论上讲，这种“数据驱动”的设计可以更容易地改变块的行为；您无需编写新的程序代码，只需对数据进行更改并存储即可。

CPIA would be built on top of wxWidgets, but its goal was to wrap Chandler’s Python code into packages called “blocks” that would be connected to each wxWidgets element. In the distant future, the idea was, CPIA blocks would make it easy for nonprogrammers to build new additions to Chandler by simply hooking preexisting blocks together. On a closer horizon, CPIA blocks would make it easier for OSAF’s programmers to build Chandler in the first place. The program would store its blocks as data in the Chandler repository itself. This “data-driven” design would theoretically make it easier to change the behavior of a block; instead of writing new program code, you could just make and store a change in the data.

CPIA 是乐高乐园可重用软件部件梦想的一个具体实例。CPIA 设计文档在 wiki 上经过了数月的演变，宣称：“块的设计目的是像乐高积木一样组合在一起。” 对于 John Anderson 来说，CPIA 背后的想法构成了一个更好的编程模型的长期愿景。有了钱德勒，他就有机会实现这个梦想。卡普尔与这个梦想同步。在我早期的一次采访中，他描述了他用拼装乐高零件“从上到下，从里到外”建造钱德勒的愿景。

CPIA was a specific instance of the Lego Land dream of reusable software parts. The CPIA design document, which evolved on the wiki over many months, declared, “Blocks are designed to fit together like Lego blocks.” For John Anderson the ideas behind CPIA constituted a long-held vision of a better model for programming. With Chandler he had a chance to make that dream real. Kapor was in sync with this dream; in an early interview with me, he had described his vision of building Chandler out of snap-together Lego parts, “top to bottom, inside out.”

对于程序员来说，乐高概念具有不可抗拒的引力。但 OSAF 团队并没有拿起别人的乐高积木并开始将积木拼凑在一起；而是将它们拼凑起来。他们最终会从头开始制作自己的一套，一次一个定制的块。

For programmers, the Lego concept had an irresistible gravitational tug. But the OSAF team didn’t grab someone else’s Lego set and begin snapping blocks together; they would end up fabricating their own set from scratch, one custom-made block at a time.

商业哲学家彼得·德鲁克（Peter Drucker）提供了一个关于工作的寓言：

Peter Drucker, the business philosopher, offers a parable about work:



管理会议上最喜欢的一个故事是三个石匠被问到他们在做什么。第一个回答说：“我正在谋生。” 第二个继续敲着锤子，说道：“我的切石工作是全国最好的。” 第三个人抬起头来，眼里闪烁着梦幻般的光芒，说道：“我正在建造一座大教堂。”

A favorite story at management meetings is that of the three stonecutters who were asked what they were doing.
