The first replied, “I am making a living.” The second kept on hammering while he said, “I am doing the best job of stonecutting in the entire country.” The third one looked up with a visionary gleam in his eyes and said, “I am building a cathedral.”

当然，第三个人才是真正的“管理者”。第一个人知道他想从工作中得到什么并设法做到这一点。他可能会“付出公平的一天的工作，换取公平的一天的报酬”。

The third man is, of course, the true “manager.” The first man knows what he wants to get out of the work and manages to do so. He is likely to give a “fair day’s work for a fair day’s pay.”

问题出在第二个人身上。做工很重要，。。。但总有一种危险是，真正的工人、真正的专业人士会相信自己正在取得一些成就，而实际上他只是在抛光石头或收集脚注。

It is the second man who is a problem. Workmanship is essential, . . . but there is always a danger that the true workman, the true professional, will believe that he is accomplishing something when in effect he is just polishing stones or collecting footnotes.



卡普尔将 CPIA 工作称为“基础设施投资”。但它看起来很像磨斧头或剃牦牛毛。安德森和他的同事“只是在抛光石头”吗？没有办法提前知道。

Kapor called the CPIA work an “infrastructure investment.” But it looked suspiciously like axe-sharpening or yak-shaving. Were Anderson and his colleagues “just polishing stones”? There was no way to know in advance.





八月的一个下午，安迪·赫茨菲尔德和约翰·安德森坐在霍华德街办公室的一间小会议室里。他们谈论赫茨菲尔德对代理人的想法。他们谈论“上下文”，这是围绕相关用户活动组组织钱德勒数据的新概念。他们谈论了安德森在组装灵活的界面构建套件方面取得的进展。然后他们互相看着对方。

Andy Hertzfeld and John Anderson are sitting in a tiny conference room at the Howard Street office one August afternoon. They talk about Hertzfeld’s ideas for agents. They talk about “contexts,” a new notion of organizing Chandler data around related groups of user activities. They talk about Anderson’s progress in assembling a flexible interface-building kit. Then they look at each other.

“当我们推进实施时，我会很兴奋，”赫茨菲尔德说。“我自己的风格是，我实施得太早了。但也许这会让这里的团体平均水平变得正确。”

“I’ll be excited when we’re moving forward on implementing,” Hertzfeld says. “My own style is, I implement too soon. But maybe that will cause the group average here to come out right.”

“开始之前，我会尝试在脑子里盘算所有的棋步，”安德森回答道。

“I try to play all the chess moves in my head before I start,” Anderson answers.

赫茨菲尔德笑了。“比尔·阿特金森曾经说过我，一切都是‘准备，开火，瞄准！’”

Hertzfeld laughs. “Bill Atkinson used to say about me, everything was ‘Ready, fire, aim!’”

“我通常自己完成大部分项目，”安德森说。“我不太擅长将其分解，以便很多人可以一起工作。”

“I’ve typically done most of a project by myself,” Anderson says. “I haven’t been as good at splitting it up so that lots of people could work on it together.”

甚至，赫茨菲尔德问道，在 Next？

Even, Hertzfeld asks, at Next?

“当我在那里担任经理时，我并没有编写代码。当你是完成五分之一工作的五个人之一时，情况就非常不同了。我要么已经完成了大部分工作，要么一直在管理它。”

“When I was a manager there, I wasn’t writing code. It’s very different when you’re one of five people doing one fifth of the work. I’ve either done the bulk of it or been managing it.”

安德森停顿了一下。通风系统呼呼作响。“而且我有一点完美主义倾向。” 他合上笔记本，站了起来。“我现在真正想做的就是继续努力！”

Anderson pauses. The ventilation system whirs. “And I have a little bit of a perfectionist thing.” He closes his notebook and gets up. “What I really want to do now is go work on this!”





在软件世界中，集成意味着采用一组本身可以正常工作的代码，并将其连接到程序中其他可以正常工作的现有部分。集成点通常是软件项目遇到大麻烦的地方。单独工作的代码块在被要求一起工作时往往会犹豫不决；它们无法正确连接在一起，发送无法解释的消息，或者顽固地拒绝启动或停止。（这是程序员的产品有时模仿人类创造者的多种方式之一。）

In the world of software, integration means taking a body of code that works fine by itself and connecting it to the other existing parts of a program that have in turn been working fine. The integration point is typically where a software project hits big trouble. Chunks of code that worked well enough separately often balk when asked to work together; they fail to hook together correctly, send messages that can’t be interpreted, or stubbornly refuse to start or stop. (This is one of the many ways in which programmers’ products sometimes mimic their human creators.)

钱德勒现在正朝着这样一个整合点迈进。当 CPIA 的齿轮在后台启动时，Michael Toy 开始推动 Chandler 的开发人员沿着他那年夏天早些时候制定的轨道走向“时钟驱动的版本”：计划于 9 月下旬发布 Chandler 0.2。OSAF 已经习惯于每周或每两周发布 Chandler 的新里程碑，但“点发布”意味着更大的事件。因此，随着 0.2 版本的日期越来越近，开发人员开始尝试将他们一直在从事的工作（例如 Andi Vajda 的新存储库和 Andy Hertzfeld 在代理方面的工作）进行起来，并将其添加到 Chandler 代码的主干中。

Chandler was now rolling toward one such integration point. While the CPIA gears cranked up in the background, Michael Toy began pushing Chandler’s developers down the tracks he had laid out earlier that summer toward a “clock-driven release”: Chandler 0.2, scheduled for late September. OSAF was already in the practice of releasing new milestones of Chandler every week or two, but a “dot release” was meant to be a larger event. So as the date for 0.2 drew closer, the developers began to try to take the work they had been pursuing on their own—like Andi Vajda’s new repository and Andy Hertzfeld’s work on agents—and add it to the main trunk of Chandler code.

如今，大多数项目都采用持续集成的理念：程序员始终将最新代码签入代码树的主干，每个人都有责任确保他们的新添加内容不会妨碍工作。后来，OSAF 最终实现了更高水平的持续集成，但对于 0.2，这个过程更像是软件开发分析师所说的“大爆炸集成”：所有程序员最后都尝试集成他们的代码，然后一切休息。

Most projects today embrace the idea of continuous integration: The programmers always keep their latest code checked in to the main trunk of the code tree, and everyone is responsible for making sure that their new additions haven’t thrown a spanner in the works. Later on, OSAF would end up achieving a higher level of continuous integration, but for 0.2 the process was more like what software-development analysts call “big-bang integration”: all the programmers try to integrate their code at the end, and everything breaks.

托伊知道其中的危险，但他认为他们已经集体承诺每三个月发布一个版本的钱德勒，并且应该在截止日期前完成。尽管 Vajda 在新存储库上的工作几乎已准备好进行集成，但日程表中没有足够的时间将其全部包含在 0.2 中。只是为赫茨菲尔德的代理商准备了一些支持技术框架。CPIA 刚刚处于蓝图阶段。

Toy knew the dangers, but he felt they had made a collective commitment to release a version of Chandler every three months and ought to meet that deadline. Though Vajda’s work on the new repository was nearly ready for integration, there wasn’t quite enough time in the schedule to include it all in 0.2. Only some of the supporting technical framework for Hertzfeld’s agents was ready. CPIA was barely in the blueprint stage.

但最后期限就是最后期限，所以开发团队做了必须做的事情来准备钱德勒的新公开版本。在“代码冻结”日期之后，他们停止检查与新功能相关的任何代码，而是专注于修复突出的错误并为该版本创建一些文档（为其他开发人员和用户提供解释材料）。

But a deadline was a deadline, so the development team did what it had to in order to prepare a new public release of Chandler. After the “code freeze” date, they stopped checking in any code related to new features, focusing instead on fixing outstanding bugs and creating some documentation (explanatory material for other developers and users) for the release.

Chandler 0.2 于 2003 年 9 月 25 日发布，距 OSAF 首次向全世界宣布 Chandler 已近一年。它在云层下到达。少数下载并试用它的用户惊讶地发现它的功能实际上甚至比 Chandler 0.1 还要少。它就像一座建筑的外壳，被毁坏了，只部分重建。

Chandler 0.2 was unveiled on September 25, 2003, close to a year after OSAF had first announced Chandler to the world. It arrived under a cloud. The few users who downloaded it and tried it out were surprised to see that it actually did even less than Chandler 0.1 had. It was like the shell of a structure that had been gutted and only partially rebuilt.

开发人员，尤其是 Vajda，感到沮丧。“Chandler 0.2 即将发布，我恳求您不要下载它，”Michael Toy 9 月 19 日在他的博客中写道。“我是认真的。不要下载它，不要告诉你的朋友，不要在 Slashdot 帖子中添加下载页面的链接。” Toy 思考了尝试正式发布此类未完成工作的明智之举：“在开发周期的早期，当这个东西还没有作为我信任的应用程序运行一次时，突然发布它似乎是错误的。担心软件发布带来的所有小细节。然而，没有临时截止日期的工作可能会导致在编码可能性的土地上漫无目的地徘徊。”

The developers, particularly Vajda, felt frustrated. “Chandler 0.2 is about to ship, and I beg you not to download it,” Michael Toy wrote in his blog on September 19. “I’m serious. Don’t download it, don’t tell your friends about it, don’t add links to the download page to a Slashdot posting.” Toy mused about the wisdom of even trying for a formal release of such unfinished work: “This early in the development cycle, when the thing has yet to work even once as an application I would trust with my data, it seems wrong to suddenly be worried about all the little details that a software release brings out. And yet working without interim deadlines can lead to a lot of aimless wandering through the land of coding possibilities.”

在发布前一周的开发者会议上，Ducky Sherwood 问道：“我们要为 0.2 举办一场聚会吗？”

At a developers’ meeting a week before the release, Ducky Sherwood asked, “Are we going to have a party for 0.2?”

“也许是一场觉醒，”玩具回答。

“A wake, perhaps,” Toy answered.

“默哀片刻，”卡普尔建议道。

“A moment of silence,” Kapor suggested.





10 月 2 日，开发人员聚集在一起进行 0.2 的事后分析。出了什么问题？下次他们应该采取哪些不同的做法？

On October 2, the developers gathered for a postmortem on 0.2. What had gone wrong? What should they do differently next time around?

Morgen Sagen 认为 0.2 确实可以被标记为另一个临时里程碑。“点版本应该有新功能。”

Morgen Sagen suggested that 0.2 really could have been labeled as just another interim milestone. “A dot release should have new features.”

“当时钟停止时，我们一半在一个世界，一半在另一个世界，”安德森说。

“We were half in one world, half in another when the clock stopped,” Anderson said.

布莱恩·斯金纳说话了。“有些功能没有加入，但有很多功能加入了。现在我们已经有了我们将要使用的存储库。”

Brian Skinner spoke up. “Some features didn’t make it in, but a ton of features did. And we have the repository now that we’re going to live with.”

开发商纷纷提出批评。当 Chandler 的架构的大部分内容仍在不断变化时，是否值得停止并修复错误？当钱德勒的大部分功能都不起作用时，他们怎么可能想到“适应并完成”呢？他们是否祈祷能在 2004 年 12 月之前（还有 15 个月）实现 Chandler 1.0（Canoga）发布的目标日期？

One after another the developers offered a critique. Was it worthwhile to stop and fix bugs when so much of Chandler’s architecture was still in flux? How could they even think of “fit and finish” when so much of Chandler wasn’t even working? And did they have any prayer of reaching what was now their target date for a release of Chandler 1.0, Canoga, by December 2004, which was fifteen months away?

托伊在白板上用要点记录了每一条批评。

Toy registered each criticism with a bullet point on the whiteboard.

“我们要说的一件事是，我们真的相信发布版本有目标，”托伊说。“0.2 确实没有目标。它有效果，但没有取得任何成果。这没什么大不了的。没有举办派对，因为没有什么值得庆祝的。”

“One of the things we’re saying is, we’re really wired to believe that releases have goals,” Toy said. “And 0.2 really had no goal. It had effects, but it didn’t achieve anything. It was a nonevent. There was no party because there was nothing to celebrate.”

OSAF 再也不会发布像 0.2 那样令人沮丧的版本，部分原因是它从困境中吸取了教训，部分原因是该组织再也不会完全按照时间计划发布版本。未来的每个版本都将围绕一组功能作为目标，其时间表将根据需要进行演变（阅读：延长）。这次经历并没有影响钱德勒的工作，但确实留下了一种组织上的伤痕。

OSAF would never again have a release quite as gloomy as 0.2, partly because it learned from its woes and partly because the organization would never again plan a release totally by the clock. Each future release would take shape around a set of features as goals, and its schedule would evolve (read: lengthen) as necessary. The experience didn’t derail work on Chandler, but it did leave a kind of organizational scar.

卡普尔从 0.2（该死的布鲁克斯定律）得出的结论之一是，如果 OSAF 希望在合理的时间内达到 1.0，就需要更多员工。在 0.2 事后分析中，几位新面孔已经坐在了桌子旁，更多的面孔很快就会出现。海基·托伊沃宁 (Heikki Toivonen) 是一位沉默寡言的芬兰人，曾是 Mozilla 项目的长期贡献者，最近成为 Netscape 的员工，他加入公司是为了关注钱德勒的安全。斯图尔特·帕门特 (Stuart Parmenter) 也来自 Netscape，他曾是 Netscape 的常驻神童。在高中时，在 Netscape 决定向开源世界发布其浏览器代码后不久，他就成为了 Mozilla 的志愿者贡献者。当他十八岁的时候，他离开了佐治亚州的家，搬到了硅谷，并在 Netscape 工作，直到 AOL 关闭了浏览器团队。在 OSAF，他开始与赫茨菲尔德合作开发特工。

One of the conclusions Kapor drew from 0.2—Brooks’s Law be damned—was that OSAF was going to need more hires if it had any hope of reaching 1.0 in a reasonable amount of time. Several new faces already sat around the table at the 0.2 postmortem, and more would soon be on the way. Heikki Toivonen, a taciturn Finn who had been a longtime Mozilla Project contributor and, most recently, a Netscape employee, had come on board to focus on Chandler’s security. Stuart Parmenter came from Netscape, too, where he’d been the resident wunderkind. While in high school he had become a volunteer contributor to Mozilla, not long after Netscape decided to release its browser code to the open source world. When he turned eighteen, he left his Georgia home, moved to Silicon Valley, and worked at Netscape until AOL shut down the browser team. At OSAF he started working with Hertzfeld on agents.

另一位新来者是一位名叫尹咪咪的年轻女子，她安静地坐着，聆听着会议上的集体自我批评。她的头衔是UI（用户界面）设计师。她是一名音乐和舞蹈专业的学生，​​在耶鲁大学读本科时，她通过为学生健康服务设计时事通讯和网站赚钱。1999 年，当她在互联网繁荣的鼎盛时期毕业时，她搬到了湾区，在一家电子商务公司工作，并在工作中学习了界面和信息设计。在泡沫后的低迷时期，她把时间花在纽约的编舞项目和西海岸的设计工作上。最近，她担任 Microsoft 的承包商，负责 MSN 在线服务的重新设计。

The other newcomer, a young woman named Mimi Yin, sat quietly, taking in the meeting’s collective self-criticism. Her title was UI (user interface) designer. A student of music and dance, she had earned money as a Yale undergraduate by designing newsletters and Web sites for the student health service. When she graduated in 1999 at the height of the dot-com boom, she moved to the Bay Area to work for an e-commerce company and learned interface and information design on the job. During the post-bubble downturn, she split her time between choreography projects in New York and design jobs on the West Coast. Most recently she had been a contractor for Microsoft, working on a redesign of the MSN online service.

2003年3月，她曾接受过OSAF的一次面试，但没有结果。她很敏锐且多学科，但她的一些面试官认为，她可能对这份工作还有些陌生。秋天，赵林再次叫她进来。“我猜他们还没有找到他们一直在寻找的神奇人物，”她想。

She had interviewed once with OSAF in March 2003, but nothing came of it. She was sharp and multidisciplinary but, some of her interviewers felt, maybe a little green for the job. In the fall, Chao Lam called her up to come in again. “I guess they haven’t found the magical person they’ve been looking for,” she thought.





Yin 的到来恰逢 2003 年 10 月钱德勒 0.3 周期的开始，使设计过程重新进入高速运转。一个新的设计小组成立了：Kapor、Hertzfeld、Chao Lam、Ducky Sherwood、Brian Skinner 和 Yin。他们开始每周三个下午开会，对钱德勒的一些中心思想进行新的探讨，比如消除数据孤岛。Yin 能够在白板或 wiki 上快速绘制草图来说明头脑风暴的想法，这有助于固定讨论并阐明隐藏的问题。

Yin’s arrival, coinciding with the start of the Chandler 0.3 cycle in October 2003, kicked the design process back into high gear. A new design group formed: Kapor, Hertzfeld, Chao Lam, Ducky Sherwood, Brian Skinner, and Yin. They began to meet three afternoons a week, taking new runs at some of the central ideas of Chandler—like the elimination of data silos. Yin’s ability to whip up quick sketches on the whiteboard or the wiki to illustrate brainstorming ideas helped moor the discussions and elucidate hidden problems.

OSAF 灵活的日程安排让 Yin 可以在大多数早上参加舞蹈课，然后参加下午的会议，并在她想要的任何时候发布 wiki 页面。她开始在公共场合大声思考，以惊人的速度向维基“丛林”区域添加新页面，并使用驼峰式标题来传达他们的集思广益意图：

OSAF’s flexible schedule allowed Yin to take dance classes most mornings, then come in for afternoon meetings—and post wiki pages anytime she wanted. She began thinking aloud in public, adding new pages to the wiki “Jungle” area at a furious pace, with CamelCase titles that broadcast their brainstorming intent:



属性袋

BagsOfAttributes

PIMParadigmShift102003

PIMParadigmShift102003

UI 应如何紧密地映射到数据模型

HowCloselyTheUIShouldMapToTheDataModel

平衡点找到了真正正确的基础知识意味着什么

BalancingPointFoundWhatDoesItMeanToGetTheBasicsReallyRight

我们陷入了怎样的混乱

WhatKindOfMessHaveWeGottenOurselvesInto



在 OSAF 开始工作后不久，尹参加了生产力教练戴维·艾伦 (David Allen) 举办的为期一天的研讨会，他的书《Getting Things Done》在程序员中建立了近乎狂热的地位。卡普尔认识艾伦——他们都对个人组织计划有着浓厚的兴趣——而且艾伦已经访问过 OSAF 一次，展示了他的原则的摘要版本（被粉丝称为 GTD）。但尹是 OSAF 的人，他会系统地研究 GTD 的想法如何帮助塑造钱德勒。

Soon after starting work at OSAF, Yin attended a daylong seminar given by David Allen, a productivity coach whose book Getting Things Done was establishing near-cult status among programmers. Kapor knew Allen—they shared an avid interest in personal organization schemes—and Allen had already visited OSAF once to present a digest version of his principles (known as GTD to fans). But Yin was the person at OSAF who would take a systematic look at how the ideas in GTD might help shape Chandler.

《把事情做好》表明，现代生活和工作让我们在精神上被许多未完成的任务所困扰：我们周围等待处理的实物、需要回复或归档的传入电子邮件、我们应该处理的文件和出版物阅读我们向其他人承诺我们会做的事情。这堆“开环”共同构成了艾伦所说的我们的“东西”。GTD 提出，我们可以不再对自己的东西感到不知所措，而是通过创建一个“可信系统”来掌控它——无论是纸质的还是数字的，都没关系。

Getting Things Done suggests that modern life and work leave us mentally beset by a host of incomplete tasks: physical objects lying around us waiting to be dealt with, incoming emails that need to be answered or filed, documents and publications that we’re supposed to read, things we’ve promised other people we will do. This heap of “open loops” collectively constitutes what Allen calls our “stuff.” GTD proposes that we can stop feeling overwhelmed by our stuff and take charge of it by creating a “trusted system”—on paper or digitally, it doesn’t matter.

我们将自己的东西放入这个系统中，这样我们就不必担心它。通过该系统，我们为每个项目定义了具体的“下一步行动”。通过这个系统，我们最终可以实现武术爱好者艾伦所说的“心如止水”——摆脱焦虑引起的超负荷和“哦，该死，我还忘记做什么？”的痛苦感觉。

Into this system, we place our stuff so that we don’t have to worry about it. With the system, we define concrete “next actions” for each of our projects. From the system, we can ultimately achieve what Allen, a martial arts devotee, calls “mind like water”—freedom from anxiety-inducing overload and that gnawing sense of “Oh, shit, what else have I forgotten to do?”

GTD 的一个核心原则要求定期投入一定的时间来处理您的收件箱，也就是说，考虑您倾倒到系统中的每一点内容并决定下一步如何处理它们。艾伦建议，如果你能在两分钟或更短的时间内完成需要完成的事情，那就去做吧。否则，决定是否将其归档、丢弃、推迟或分类为下一步操作的特定项目的一部分。

One central GTD principle calls for committing a certain amount of time regularly to processing your inbox—that is, considering each bit of stuff you have dumped into your system and deciding what to do with it next. If you can do what needs to be done in two minutes or less, Allen advises, just do it. Otherwise, decide if it’s something to file, discard, defer, or classify as part of a particular project with a next action.

在 Kapor 的祝福和鼓励下，Mimi Yin 开始考虑 Chandler 如何充当 GTD 式的物料处理系统。卡普尔（Kapor）明确表示，他不希望钱德勒（Chandler）与 GTD 的联系过于狭窄，但随着设计小组在 2003 年秋季进入密集工作季节，它定期回到艾伦的想法中寻找灵感。特别是，Yin 提出了“仪表板”界面的概念，帮助 Chandler 用户处理大量传入的电子邮件和其他项目，而不必决定每个人的最终命运。Yin 的仪表板是一种新型收件箱，它将向用户呈现按过去、现在和未来组织的从上到下的项目流。较旧的内容将从屏幕顶部退入存储区域；推迟的和未来安排的项目将移出屏幕底部的视图；所有需要处理的事情都将在中心等待用户的关注。Yin 的仪表板想法属于面向时间线的界面的传统，就像 David Gelernter 的 Lifestreams 项目一样，该项目提出了时间顺序作为信息管理的组织原则。但它融合了钱德勒对筒仓平衡的承诺和大卫艾伦的把事情做好的原则，以提出一些独特的东西。

With Kapor’s blessing and encouragement, Mimi Yin began to consider how Chandler might function as a GTD-style system for stuff processing. Kapor was clear that he didn’t want Chandler to be too narrowly tied to GTD, but as the Design Group entered a season of intensive work in fall 2003, it periodically returned to Allen’s ideas for inspiration. In particular, Yin emerged with the concept of a “dashboard” interface to help Chandler users process a torrent of incoming emails and other items without having to decide each one’s ultimate fate. Yin’s dashboard was a new kind of inbox that would present users with a top-to-bottom flow of items organized by past, present, and future. Older stuff would recede off the top of the screen into a storage area; deferred and future-scheduled items would get moved out of view at the bottom of the screen; and everything that needed to be processed would await the user’s attention in the center. Yin’s dashboard idea belonged to a tradition of time-line-oriented interfaces, like David Gelernter’s Lifestreams project, that proposed chronology as the organizing principle for information management. But it mixed in Chandler’s commitment to silo-leveling and David Allen’s getting-things-done principles to come up with something unique.

OSAF 本身在完成任务时也遇到了一些麻烦，但如果有人注意到其中的讽刺意味，这一观察结果从未出现在博客文章或维基页面中。当 Yin 开始认真设计 Chandler 的用户界面时，《Getting Things Done》中的一项观察可能感觉特别相关：“事情很少会因为缺乏时间而陷入困境。他们陷入困境是因为他们的行为尚未被定义。” Yin 的到来首次为 OSAF 提供了一个全职工作是询问和回答有关 Chandler 用户界面的问题并对其进行定义的人。一方面，这意味着尽管设计组尚未与程序员分享其输出，但软件开发人员最终感到可供他们使用的充实设计可能很快就会出现。另一方面，当尹赶上钱德勒之前的工作（布鲁克斯定律在设计方面发挥作用）并开始贡献重要的新想法时，设计组本身的成员发现自己又回到了最初的原则。

OSAF itself was having its share of trouble getting things done, but if anyone there noticed the irony, the observation never made it into a blog post or wiki page. As Yin began the spadework of designing Chandler’s user interface, one observation in Getting Things Done might have felt especially relevant: “Things rarely get stuck because of lack of time. They get stuck because the doing of them has not been defined.” Yin’s arrival furnished OSAF for the first time with someone whose full-time job was to ask and answer questions about Chandler’s user interface and define it. On the one hand, this meant that even though the Design Group was not yet sharing its output with the programmers, the software developers finally felt that a fleshed-out design for them to work from might be coming soon. On the other hand, as Yin caught up with the previous work on Chandler (Brooks’s Law in action on the design side) and began contributing big new ideas, the members of the Design Group itself found themselves back at first principles.

钱德勒一次又一次地回到了第一点。在早期的头脑风暴会议中，Kapor 和 Morgen Sagen 重点关注 RDF 方法。关于如何设计一个能够在网络上良好运行的灵活存储库的无休止的争论。文档架构探索的扩展时代。现在，OSAF 团队再次提出基本问题：人们如何组织信息？创新的软件工具如何帮助他们？

Over and over Chandler had returned to square one. There were the early brainstorming sessions in which Kapor and Morgen Sagen had fastened on the RDF approach. The interminable debates over how to design a flexible repository that would work well on a network. The extended era of document architecture explorations. Now, once again, OSAF’s team was asking basic questions: How do people organize information? And how can an innovative software tool help them?





这对安迪·赫茨菲尔德来说实在是太难以忍受了，他对钱德勒缺乏动力的不耐烦终于达到了顶峰。一段时间以来，他对这个项目的感觉越来越差。首先，正如他后来向我解释的那样，他发现在员工中担任志愿者很困难，即使是为卡普尔这样他喜欢的人工作。“他们不知道是否应该依靠你。而且因为你没有得到报酬，所以缺乏控制。” 他还觉得尹的做法太抽象、太学院派，两人始终没有合拍。

It was too much for Andy Hertzfeld, whose impatience with Chandler’s lack of momentum finally came to a head. He had been feeling steadily worse about the project for some time. First of all, as he later explained to me, he had been finding it hard to work as a volunteer among employees—even working for someone he liked as much as Kapor. “They don’t know whether to count on you or not. And because you’re not getting paid, there’s a lack of control.” He also felt that Yin’s approach was too abstract, too academic, and the two never clicked.

但真正的问题只是速度。“我是那种喜欢到处乱扔避雷针的开发者。要制作一个出色的项目，中心必须至少有一个人为它注入活力。以一种凶猛的方式。而这正是所欠缺的。” 今年早些时候的某个时候，由于对钱德勒的行动缓慢感到沮丧，他为钱德勒制作了一个基本的地址簿“包裹”：“我只是设计了它并写了一些东西。没有进行所有的讨论。我编写代码的方式是，你雕刻它，你得到尽可能好的东西，并且随着你的学习，一切都会改变。但你会爬上这个阶梯来了解你的问题。每个问题都是独特的，所以你必须了解每个问题，然后做一些事情并获得更好的视角。从这个有利的角度来看，你可以决定把它扔掉。代码很便宜。但它通常会告诉你下一步该做什么。”

But the real problem was just plain speed. “I’m the kind of developer who likes to throw lightning rods around. To make a great program, there’s got to be at least one person at the center who is breathing life into it. In a ferocious way. And that was lacking.” At one point earlier in the year, frustrated by how slowly Chandler was moving, he had cranked out a basic address book “parcel” for Chandler: “I just designed it and wrote something. There wasn’t all the discussion. My way of writing code is, you sculpt it, you get something as good as you can, and everything’s subject to change, always, as you learn. But you climb this ladder of learning about your problem. Every problem’s unique, so you have to learn about each problem, and you do something and get a better vantage point. And from that vantage point you can decide to throw it out. Code is cheap. But often it tells you what to do next.”

但地址簿从未集成到 Chandler 代码的主树中。事实上，不久之后，卡普尔就决定不再强调钱德勒的地址簿；他不再强调钱德勒的地址簿。有一天，该程序可能会包含一个功能，但该功能现在的优先级较低。因此，赫茨菲尔德决定在参加夏季的文档架构马拉松比赛时，集中精力充实他对钱德勒代理的想法。

But the address book never got integrated into the main tree of Chandler code. In fact, before too much longer, Kapor had decided to deemphasize Chandler’s address book; someday the program might include one, but the feature now had low priority. So Hertzfeld decided to concentrate on fleshing out his idea for agents in Chandler while he participated in the summer’s Document Architecture marathons.

秋天，他和妻子去夏威夷度了一个月的假期。当他回来时，设计小组开始的讨论让他大吃一惊。在他看来，他们似乎忽略了文档架构会议上的所有工作——所有精心定义的词汇，所有仔细绘制的块和屏幕草图——并且从头开始。令人困惑的是，这似乎正是卡普尔想要的。

In the fall, he left for a monthlong vacation in Hawaii with his wife. When he returned, the discussions the Design Group had begun left him flabbergasted. It seemed to him that they were ignoring all the work from the Document Architecture meetings—all the painstakingly defined vocabularies, all the careful sketches of blocks and screens—and were starting from scratch. Bafflingly, that seemed to be what Kapor wanted.

“当我告诉米奇这件事时，他说，‘好吧，我正在尝试一些不同的东西。我们必须回来重新调整事情。但等一下！他们已经在建造它了！所以我认为米奇已经抛弃了 CPIA。我错了，他没有。但我就是不明白。我认为米奇对 CPIA 及其结果有点不满意，尽管他煽动了它，所以他想要一些新的想法。但是，伙计，这让我感觉那东西只是在转圈。我仍然对米奇怀有无限的敬意，但他只是在那里失去了我。”

“When I told Mitch about it, he said, ‘Well, I’m trying something different. We’ll have to come back and realign things.’ But wait a second! They’re already building it! So I assumed that Mitch had thrown out CPIA. I was wrong, he didn’t. But I just didn’t get it. I think Mitch was a little unsatisfied with CPIA and how it turned out, even though he instigated it, so he wanted some fresh thinking. But, man, it made me feel like the thing was just circling. I still have infinite respect for Mitch, but he just lost me there.”

随着赫茨菲尔德在 2003 年下半年从 OSAF 撤回一些精力，他开始了自己的一个新项目：在一个名为 Folklore.org 的网站上，他构建了一个小软件工具，借用了博客和 wiki 的各个方面，以帮助群体人们贡献和分享故事。然后他开始发布他在苹果公司帮助制造第一台麦金塔电脑时的故事。故事越来越多，网站也越来越大。然后，计算机书籍出版商 Tim O'Reilly（他的公司专门从事开源开发手册，顺便说一句，他也是 OSAF 的董事会成员）看到了 Folklore.org，并建议赫茨菲尔德将这些故事写成一本书。

As Hertzfeld withdrew some energy from OSAF in the latter part of 2003, he began a new project on his own: At a Web site called Folklore.org, he built a little software tool that borrowed aspects of both blogs and wikis to enable groups of people to contribute and share stories. Then he began posting tales from his days at Apple when he helped build the first Macintosh. The stories piled up, and the site grew. Then computer book publisher Tim O’Reilly, whose company specialized in open source development manuals and who, incidentally, sat on OSAF’s board, saw Folklore.org and proposed that Hertzfeld turn the tales into a book.

赫茨菲尔德同意了。他现在有六个月的期限来提交手稿。除了一些建议和偶尔的社交访问之外，他在 OSAF 的工作就结束了。

Hertzfeld agreed. He now had a six-month deadline to turn in a manuscript. Aside from a little advice and an occasional social visit, his work at OSAF was over.





从 2003 年夏天开始，微软位于华盛顿州雷德蒙德的总部开始源源不断地传来有关代号为 Longhorn 的下一版本 Windows 世界的戏谑的报道。计算机行业远程预警系统媒体的读者了解到，Longhorn 绝对会令人难以置信。它将配备一个极其美丽且速度惊人的新图形系统，称为 Avalon。它将提供一个非常强大且前所未有的多功能新网络系统，称为 Indigo。其核心是一个极其灵活和创新的新文件系统，称为 WinFS。

Beginning in the summer of 2003, a steady flow of reports began emanating from Microsoft’s Redmond, Washington, headquarters, with teasing glimpses into the world of the next version of Windows, code-named Longhorn. Longhorn, readers of the computer industry’s distant-early-warning-system press learned, was going to be absolutely incredible. It would feature a stupendously beautiful and stunningly fast new graphics system called Avalon. It would provide a remarkably powerful and unprecedentedly versatile new networking system called Indigo. And at its heart would lie an astonishingly flexible and innovative new file system called WinFS.

在采访中，比尔盖茨宣扬了 Longhorn 的可能性。他为此做出的承诺听起来与卡普尔为钱德勒设定的目标非常相似，包括致力于打破将不同类型的信息彼此隔离的孤岛。WinFS 文件系统甚至允许您将同一文件存储在多个位置！

In interviews, Bill Gates trumpeted Longhorn’s possibilities. And the promises he was making for it sounded remarkably similar to the goals Kapor had set for Chandler, including the focus on breaking down the silos that lock different kinds of information away from one another. The WinFS file system would even allow you to store the same file in more than one place!

“将文件从这台机器转移到这台机器，获取电子邮件、日历——这很痛苦，”盖茨告诉《今日美国》。“假设你有一个工作日历和一个家庭日历。协调您家人的日程安排并确定哪些活动应该同时安排在两个家庭中真的很容易吗？Longhorn 使您的信息可以轻松地显示在任何设备上。它使浏览该信息变得容易。。。。如果我今天对某人说你如何在你的电脑上跟踪股票、电影、音乐、餐馆，你可以做到，但这是非常痛苦的，非常手动。该系统对你在典型生活中处理的所有事情并没有这种天生的理解。你去电脑上获取指示，得到这个有趣的网页，然后你可能只是将其打印出来。存储它、在离线时拥有它的想法——无论如何，其中很多事情仍然相当复杂。因此，Longhorn 是对用户界面的改变，以统一许多不同的东西。”

“Moving your files from this machine to this machine, getting your email, your calendar—it’s painful,” Gates told USA Today. “Say you have a work calendar and a family calendar. Is it really easy to coordinate your family’s schedule and see which events should be on both ones? Longhorn makes it easy for your information to show up on any device. It makes it easy to navigate that information . . . . If I said to somebody today how on your PC do you keep track of stocks, movies, music, restaurants, you can do it, but it’s pretty painful, pretty manual. The system doesn’t have this innate understanding of all the things you deal with in typical life. You go and get directions on the computer, you get this funny Web page, and you probably just print the thing out. The idea of storing that, having it when you’re offline—anyway a lot of these things are still pretty complex. So Longhorn is a change of the user interface to unify a lot of things that have been disparate.”

微软还没有愚蠢到指定 Longhorn 的可用日期。该公司延迟交付承诺的 Windows 升级的记录是出了名的糟糕。但长角牛的鼓声提醒卡普尔和 OSAF 的每个人，他们交付钱德勒的时间越长，他们的项目改变世界的机会就越小。

Microsoft hadn’t yet been foolish enough to specify the date on which Longhorn would be available. The company’s record of delays in delivering promised upgrades to Windows was notoriously bad. But the Longhorn drumbeat was a reminder to Kapor and everyone at OSAF that the longer they took in delivering Chandler, the less chance their project would have of changing the world.

距离 Kapor 提出 Chandler 1.0 将在 2003 年底前准备就绪已经过去一年了，现在甚至在 2004 年底的最后期限前完成任务看起来也很困难。他开始与 Chao Lam 密切合作，试图优先考虑钱德勒冗长的功能列表。钱德勒曾承诺解决许多广泛的领域——电子邮件、日历、任务、联系人、共享、同步、搜索、安全、代理——而每个领域又都有一长串的子功能。Chao Lam 将所有内容整理成一系列电子表格，随后将其移至 wiki，他和 Kapor 开始决定什么应该先处理，什么应该等待。

It had been a year since Kapor had suggested that Chandler 1.0 would be ready by the end of 2003, and now even meeting an end-of-2004 deadline looked tough. He began working intensively with Chao Lam to try to prioritize Chandler’s lengthy feature list. Chandler had promised to tackle a lot of broad areas—email, calendars, tasks, contacts, sharing, synchronization, search, security, agents—and each of those areas in turn had a long list of subfeatures. Chao Lam organized everything into a series of spreadsheets that were later moved onto the wiki, and he and Kapor began to decide what should go first and what should wait.

卡普尔的注意力越来越多地转向招聘。夏末，他在自己的博客上写道：“几个月来，我们的员工人数一直稳定在 12 人左右。。。。我们的计划要求最大规模超过 30 座，以便在未来两年半内完成卡诺加 (Canoga) 和韦斯特伍德 (Westwood)。” 但找到合适的开发人员并不容易，而且将他们整合到 OSAF 中也需要时间。他写道：“我们平均每月只能吸纳两名或偶尔三名新员工，而不会造成比我认为可取的更多混乱和破坏。”

Kapor’s attention turned more and more toward hiring. At the end of the summer he had posted to his blog: “Our head count has been fairly flat for some months at about 12 . . . . Our plans call for a maximum size of over 30 in order to complete Canoga and Westwood in the next two and a half years.” But finding the right developers wasn’t easy, and integrating them into OSAF took time. “We can only absorb, on average, two or perhaps occasionally three new people per month without creating more chaos and disruption than I deem advisable,” he wrote.

10 月，迈克尔·托伊向卡普尔提出了一份令人惊讶的辞职报告。一些朋友正在创办一家新的软件公司，以简化呼叫中心的业务，允许工作人员在家中接听电话，并将其全部转移到网络上。他们为他提供了担任副总统的机会。尽管他曾认为 OSAF 是一份梦想的工作，但他惊讶地发现自己被这份工作所吸引。

In October, Michael Toy presented Kapor with a surprise resignation. Some friends were starting a new software venture to streamline the business of call centers, allowing workers to take calls from their homes, and move it all to the Web. They had offered him the chance to be a vice president. Though he had thought of OSAF as a dream job, he was surprised to find himself drawn to the job offer.

尽管托伊的自我贬低言论似乎一直是他性格中可爱的一部分——一周他公开发布的任务清单上写着：“继续我更有针对性地尝试与那些据称我通过担任经理来帮助他们的人交谈”——但事实却变成了这样。老实说，他觉得自己做得不太好。后来他向我解释了他的决定。

Although Toy’s self-disparaging comments had always seemed an endearing part of his personality—one week the task list he publicly posted read, “Continue in my more focused attempt to talk to people who I am allegedly helping by being their manager”—it turned out that he honestly felt he hadn’t been doing a very good job. He explained his decision to me later.

“米奇·卡普尔（Mitch Kapor）每年花费数百万美元，并且不想为小细节承担责任。他想找到一个人来确保他的钱花得值。这是我无法提供的详细程度。以及我无法提供的保证程度。米奇非常耐心地说：“我会帮助你在这些事情上做得更好。” 所以我对自己所处的位置没有任何抱怨。但最终，我只是被要求提供一项我不太擅长的服务。

“Mitch Kapor is spending millions of dollars a year and does not want to have responsibility for little details. He wants to find someone to make sure his money is being well spent. And that’s a level of detail that I could not provide. And a level of assurance that I could not provide. Mitch was really patient in just saying, ‘I will help you get better at these things.’ So I have no complaints about the position I was in. But in the end, I was just being asked to provide a service that I wasn’t very good at.

“然后我坦白承认我严重偏向于：让我们发布一些东西并将其放在人们手中并快速从中学习。与确保我们正在做的事情能够持续十年或十五年相比，这更有趣，更有趣，而且我认为这是一种更好的做事方式。看起来钱德勒正试图在建筑上非常健全，并且几乎无限地愿意推迟事物的出现，以便拥有良好的建筑。这是米奇的钱，所以他可以以任何他想要的方式进行权衡。这种放慢脚步的意愿可能会在未来得到巨大的回报。但对于想要下周发布软件的人来说真的很难。”

“And then I frankly admit that I am heavily biased toward: Let’s ship something and put it in people’s hands and learn from it quickly. That’s way more fun, way more interesting, and, I think, a much better way to do things than to be sure that what we’re doing is going to last for ten or fifteen years. It looks like Chandler is trying to be very architecturally sound and to be almost infinitely willing to delay the appearance of the thing in order to have good architecture. It’s Mitch’s money, so he can make that trade-off any way he wants. And it could be that that willingness to go slow is going to pay off hugely in the future. But it’s really hard for someone who wants to ship software next week.”





托伊的离开井然有序，关系也很好——他十一月的大部分时间都在 OSAF 处理未解决的问题——但这让卡普尔陷入了困境。上一次花了几个月的时间才找到合适的开发经理。这一次，巧合的是，卡普尔立刻就找到了一位强有力的候选人。他面试得很好并接受了一份工作，但几天后回电说抱歉，他的配偶不会搬到湾区。

Toy’s departure was orderly and on good terms—he spent most of November at OSAF tying up loose ends—but it left Kapor in a quandary. The last time around it had taken months to find the right development manager. This time, by coincidence, Kapor found a strong candidate immediately. He interviewed well and accepted an offer but then called back a couple of days later to say sorry, his spouse would not move to the Bay Area.

就在 OSAF 开始关注钱德勒的设计并开始现实地考虑其优先事项时，长期寻找经理的前景让卡普尔感到困扰。他宣布，他们将继续寻找，但他们不会让空椅子阻碍他们的进展。越来越明显的是，如果 OSAF 坚持最初的三个月、时钟驱动的发布时间表并试图在 2003 年 12 月底之前完成 Chandler 0.3，那么它不会比 0.2 更令人满意。但开发人员在安德森的一些新 CPIA 模块落实到位方面取得了进展，设计会议富有成效，卡普尔认为生产一个显示出明显进展的 0.3 比满足时钟规定的最后期限更重要。

The prospect of a prolonged search for a manager, just as OSAF was beginning to get traction on Chandler’s design and to get realistic about its priorities, troubled Kapor. They would keep searching, he announced, but they weren’t going to let the empty chair impede their progress. It was becoming clear that if OSAF stuck to the original three-month, clock-driven release schedule and tried to finish Chandler 0.3 by the end of December 2003, it would be no more satisfying than 0.2. But the developers were making headway toward putting some of Anderson’s new CPIA blocks into place, the design meetings were productive, and Kapor decided it was more important to produce an 0.3 that showed visible progress than to meet the clock-imposed deadline.

Toy 在 OSAF 的最后几周，Katie Parlante 获得了新的权力和新头衔：Chandler 软件架构师，与 John Anderson 的头衔相匹配。随着 Toy 的离开，Kapor 决定将 OSAF 的开发工作分为三个组：设计、存储库和应用程序（应用程序），其中 OSAF 的大部分程序员将致力于构建 Chandler 前端。Parlante 在 Apps Group 正式成立之前就已经悄然开始组织该团队，他将负责管理这个核心团队。

In Toy’s last weeks at OSAF, Katie Parlante received new authority and a new title, Chandler software architect, matching John Anderson’s. With Toy’s departure, Kapor decided to structure OSAF’s development effort into three groups: Design, Repository, and Apps (applications), where the bulk of OSAF’s programmers would labor to build the Chandler front end. Parlante, who had quietly begun organizing the Apps Group before it had even been formally constituted, would run this core team.

至于开发工作的整体管理，卡普尔宣布，虽然搜索继续取代玩具，但他将亲自承担这项工作。

As for overall management of the development effort, Kapor announced that while the search continued to replace Toy, he would take on the job himself.

“我将比 OSAF 历史上任何时候都更加关注开发细节，”他告诉他的员工。“希望这将是一项增值活动，而不是一项减值活动。”

“I will be focused on development details more than at any previous time in OSAF history,” he told his staff. “Hopefully, that will be a value-added and not a value-subtracted activity.”





到目前为止，我知道，任何读过这本书的软件开发人员都可能绝望地把它扔到房间的另一边，心想：“停止疯狂吧！他们犯了书中的每一个错误！”

By now, I know, any software developer reading this volume has likely thrown it across the room in despair, thinking, “Stop the madness! They’re making every mistake in the book!”

我想，很多程序员也在想，“我永远不会那样做。” 我会做得更好。”

A good number of those programmers, I imagine, are also thinking, “I’d never do that. I’d do better.”

他们中的少数人甚至可能是对的。

A handful of them might even be right.

在旁听 OSAF 的工作一年后，我也发现自己在想：“他们什么时候开始工作？他们要花多长时间？有什么事耽搁了？” 软件时代的熵阻力已经开始发挥作用，似乎没有什么能够加速它。

After a year of sitting in on OSAF’s work, I, too, found myself wondering, “When are they going to get going? How long are they going to take? What’s the holdup?” Software time’s entropic drag had kicked in, and nothing seemed able to accelerate it.

难道钱德勒团队看不到他们已经偏离了道路有多远吗？在项目进程的每一次转折中，卡普尔都会坦率地承认，如果他事先知道后来学到的东西，他的进展将会有所不同。然后他会叹口气，耸耸肩，说：“事后看来总是二十二十”，然后继续工作。

Couldn’t the Chandler team see how far off the road they had driven? At every twist of the project’s course, Kapor would freely admit that he would have proceeded differently if he had known before what he later learned. Then he would sigh, shrug, say, “Hindsight is always twenty-twenty,” and get back to work.

在软件史上，钱德勒令人失望的步伐并不是例外，而是常态。在这一领域，记录表明，每个司机都会找到不同的方式冲出道路，但迟早他们都会掉进沟里。

In the annals of software history, Chandler’s disappointing pace is not the exception but the norm. In this field, the record suggests that each driver finds a different way to run off the road, but sooner or later nearly all of them end up in a ditch.

如果你是那些确信自己可以做得更好的程序员之一，问问自己在上一个项目中有多少次你发现自己在想，“是的，我知道我们可能应该这样做”——其中“这个”是以下任何一个：软件领域的最佳实践准则——“但这是一种特殊情况。我们是一个独特的案例。” 正如安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 所说：“不存在所谓典型的软件项目。每个项目都是不同的。”

If you are one of those programmers who are certain they could do better, ask yourself how many times on your last project you found yourself thinking, “Yes, I know that we probably ought to do this”—where “this” is any of the canon of best practices in the software field—“but it’s a special situation. We’re sort of a unique case.” As Andy Hertzfeld put it, “There’s no such thing as a typical software project. Every project is different.”

2004 年 6 月，Linux Times发表了对 Linux 仁慈独裁者 Linus Torvalds 的采访。

In June 2004, Linux Times published an interview with Linus Torvalds, Linux’s Benevolent Dictator.

“您对开始从事大型开源项目的人有什么建议吗？” 采访者开始说道。

“Do you have any advice for people starting to undertake large open source projects?” the interviewer began.

“任何人都不应该开始承担大型项目，”托瓦兹厉声说道。“你从一个微不足道的小项目开始，永远不要指望它会变得很大。如果你这样做，你就会过度设计，并且通常会认为它比当前阶段可能的更重要。或者，更糟糕的是，您可能会被您设想的工作规模吓跑。因此，从小事做起，考虑细节。不要考虑一些大局和花哨的设计。如果它不能解决一些相当紧迫的需求，那么它几乎肯定是过度设计的。”

“Nobody should start to undertake a large project,” Torvalds snapped. “You start with a small trivial project, and you should never expect it to get large. If you do, you’ll just overdesign and generally think it is more important than it likely is at that stage. Or, worse, you might be scared away by the sheer size of the work you envision. So start small and think about the details. Don’t think about some big picture and fancy design. If it doesn’t solve some fairly immediate need, it’s almost certainly overdesigned.”

托瓦尔兹没有提到钱德勒的名字，但任何熟悉该项目的人读到他的话都会忍不住看到其中的相似之处，而任何参与该项目的人听到这些话无疑都会皱起眉头。

Torvalds didn’t mention Chandler by name, but anyone familiar with the project who read his words couldn’t help seeing the parallels, and anyone working on the project who heard them would doubtless have winced.

然而，即使你采纳了托瓦兹的建议——即使你从小事做起，控制自己的野心，考虑细节，并且从来没有梦想过大局——托瓦兹说，即使如此，你也不应该计划取得快速进步。

Yet even if you took Torvalds’s advice—even if you started small, kept your ambitions in check, thought about details, and never, ever dreamed of the big picture—even then, Torvalds said, you shouldn’t plan on making fast progress.

“不要指望在任何短时间内取得巨大成就，”他宣称。“我从事 Linux 工作已有 13 年了，而且我预计还会从事相当长的一段时间。如果我期望做这么大的事情，我就永远不会开始。”

“Don’t expect to get anywhere big in any kind of short time frame,” he declared. “I’ve been doing Linux for thirteen years, and I expect to do it for quite some time still. If I had expected to do something that big, I’d never have started.”

第7章                           

CHAPTER 7                           

详细视图

DETAIL VIEW

[2004 年 1 月至 5 月]

[JANUARY–MAY 2004]

大雨打在霍华德街大会议室的窗户上。树荫已落下；投影仪发出嗡嗡声。这是 OSAF 的第一个“演示日”，发生在 2004 年 1 月一个阴沉的早晨，所有的目光都集中在 Jed Burgess 散落在房间后墙上的桌面上。

Hard rain pelts the window of the big conference room on Howard Street. The shade is down; a projector is humming. It is the first ever “demo day” at OSAF, on a gloomy January morning in 2004, and all eyes are on Jed Burgess’s desktop splashed across the room’s back wall.

约翰·安德森讲话时，伯吉斯开始介绍钱德勒。这需要令人痛苦的整整一分钟。安德森的喋喋不休填补了等待的时间：“你会注意到，我们的发布不是很迅速。” 最后，窗口开始出现。

Burgess starts Chandler as John Anderson talks. It takes an agonizing full minute. Anderson’s chatter fills the wait: “Our launches are not very zippy, you’ll notice.” Finally, windows begin to appear.

“这是新的存储库查看器，”Anderson 说道，屏幕上充满了一行行括号变形的 XML 数据。“它完全位于我们的新架构之上。”

“This is the new repository viewer,” Anderson says, as the screen fills with line after line of bracket-inflected XML data. “It’s completely on top of our new architecture.”

对于外行来说，这个准系统的图像似乎不会给人留下太深刻的印象，但房间里的观察者却全神贯注。他们明白，Chandler 的这个小工作组件（从存储库检索一组数据并将其原始显示给用户）是由 OSAF 自己的部件组装而成的，是他们精心打造的“新世界”的构建块。在过去的几个月里构思和建造。

To a layman the barebones image wouldn’t seem terribly impressive, but the observers in the room are rapt. They understand that this one little working component of Chandler—which retrieves a set of data from the repository and displays it, raw, to the user—has been assembled from OSAF’s own parts, building-blocks from the “new world” they have painstakingly conceived and constructed over the past months.

“CPIA 块最酷的功能之一是它几乎都是数据和很少的代码，”Anderson 说。“这与过去开发用户界面的方式有很大的不同。我们正在转向一种模型，其中这些 UI 元素主要是您可以检查的数据。” 换句话说，用户在 Chandler 屏幕上看到的所有内容（每个窗口、按钮和菜单）都表示为 Chandler 自己的存储库中的一段数据。

“One of the coolest features about a CPIA block is that it’s almost all data and very little code,” Anderson says. “That’s a pretty large departure from the way user interfaces were developed in the past. We’re moving to a model where these UI elements are mostly data that you can inspect.” In other words, everything the user sees on Chandler’s screen—every window and button and menu—is represented as a piece of data in Chandler’s own repository.

“那么你能即时做出这些改变吗？” 米奇·卡普尔问道。

“So can you make these changes live, on the fly?” Mitch Kapor asks.

“是的，你不必编写代码，”安德森回答道。只需更改数据，您在屏幕上看到的内容就会改变。

“Yes, you don’t have to write code,” Anderson answers. Just alter the data, and what you see on screen will change.

“即使在这个水平上，这也是一场胜利，”卡普尔说。

“Even at this level, that’s a win,” Kapor says.

演示日似乎正在发挥作用。认识到 0.2 版本发布期间团队的萎靡不振，Kapor 决定在每周例会上留出时间，让程序员互相展示他们的工作，带领大家回顾他们最近取得的微小进展。当两打与会者为安德森和伯吉斯鼓掌时，房间里充满了一种轻松的感觉。

Demo day seems to be working. Recognizing the malaise that had descended upon the team during the 0.2 release, Kapor decided to set aside time at their weekly meetings for the programmers to show their work to one another, walking the crowd through the small increments of progress they have recently made. As the two dozen attendees of the meeting applaud Anderson and Burgess, there’s a sense of buoyancy in the room.

接下来，摩根·萨根 (Morgen Sagen) 描述了他为自动测试钱德勒而组装的新系统。现在他的桌子下放着三台电脑，每台电脑都运行该程序的 Windows、Mac 和 Linux 版本。在这些盒子上运行的脚本不断地寻找钱德勒代码的新“签入”；每次开发人员检查源代码存储库的更改或添加时，这些计算机都会对其进行测试，以确保它没有“破坏构建”——新的更改与所有现有的 Chandler 代码相结合，没有“破坏构建”。导致最终的编程组合未能通过 Sagen 的一项或多项测试。这并不能确保更改没有错误（远非如此），但它是防止程序损坏和编程错误的第一道防线。

Next up, Morgen Sagen describes the new system he has assembled for automatically testing Chandler. Three computers now sit under his desk, one each for the Windows, Mac, and Linux versions of the program. Scripts running on these boxes constantly look for new “check-ins” of Chandler code; each time a developer checks in a change or addition to the source code repository, these computers test it to make sure that it hasn’t “broken the build”—that the new changes, combined with all the existing Chandler code, haven’t caused the resulting programming assemblage to fail one or more of Sagen’s tests. This doesn’t ensure that the changes are bug-free—far from it—but it’s a first line of defense against program breakage and programming error.

三台哨兵计算机将测试的输出发送到一个名为 Tinderbox 的程序，该程序将结果发布到一个网页，其中包含三个图表，不断显示构建的当前状态。绿色表示通过测试；橙色表示一项测试失败；红色表示整个构建失败。任何地方的开发者和好奇的旁观者都可以公开访问该页面。（您现在可以在 http://builds.osafoundation.org/tinderbox/Chandler/status.htm 检查项目的构建状态。）

The three sentinel computers send the output of their tests to a program called Tinderbox, which publishes the results to a Web page with three graphs that constantly display the current state of the build. Green means it passed the test; orange means one test failed; red means the entire build failed. The page is publicly accessible to developers and curious onlookers anywhere. (You can check the project’s build status right now at http://builds.osafoundation.org/tinderbox/Chandler/status.htm.)

下一个演示由 OSAF 开发团队的最新成员 Ted Leung 进行。梁曾在苹果公司从事牛顿手持设备软件的工作；后来，在 IBM，他帮助完成了 XML 数据标准的一些早期工作。在互联网泡沫破灭期间，他成为 Apache 开源项目的主要参与者。Chandler 最初的公告引起了他的注意，他开始关注该项目，并以他的昵称“sprout”出现在 OSAF 的互联网中继聊天 (IRC) 频道上。他住在班布里奇岛，与西雅图隔普吉特湾相望。只要 OSAF 是一个“面对面”的运作方式，员工需要在同一个物理空间见面和工作，他就认为工作是不可能的。但 Kapor 明白，“真正的”开源项目需要通过互联网协调来自遥远的编码人员的贡献，并决定是时候改变 OSAF 的方法了。Leung 从他的 Apache 工作中已经知道如何进行“分布式开发”；卡普尔邀请他加入 OSAF 并在家工作，并每隔几个月访问一次旧金山母舰。

The next demo is by Ted Leung, the latest addition to the OSAF development crew. Leung had worked at Apple on software for the Newton handheld device; later, at IBM, he had helped with some of the early work on the XML data standard. During the dot-com bust he had become a key participant in the Apache open source project. The original announcement of Chandler caught his eye, and he began following the project, showing up on OSAF’s Internet Relay Chat (IRC) channel under his handle, “sprout.” He lived on Bainbridge Island, across Puget Sound from Seattle; as long as OSAF was a “face-time” operation where employees were expected to meet and work in the same physical space, he figured a job was out of the question. But Kapor understood that “real” open source projects drew on contributions from far-flung coders coordinated across the Internet and decided it was time to change OSAF’s approach. Leung already knew how to do “distributed development” from his Apache work; Kapor invited him to join OSAF and work from home, with a visit to the San Francisco mother ship every few months.

今天，Leung 将演示他进行的一些测试，以了解 Chandler 存储库处理大量数据的能力。作为一名专注的博主，他设计了一个程序，可以将 RSS 格式的 20 兆字节的博客文章加载到 Chandler 中，从而创建 11000 个 Chandler 项目。只有一个问题：当 OSAF 办公室的一位同事在屏幕上运行演示时，Leung 通过电话接通，而电话链路只工作了一半：他可以听到旧金山的声音，但旧金山听不到他的声音。因此，他通过将自己的解释输入到 IRC 聊天室中来对演示进行旁白，该聊天室投射在墙上，他的同事可以在其中阅读。

Today Leung is going to demo some tests he has rigged to see how well the Chandler repository can handle large quantities of data. A dedicated blogger, he devised a program that would load twenty megabytes of blog posts in RSS format into Chandler, creating eleven thousand Chandler items. There’s only one problem: While a colleague at the OSAF office runs the demo on screen, Leung is patched in by phone, and the phone link is only half working: He can hear San Francisco, but San Francisco can’t hear him. So he narrates the demo by typing his explanations into the IRC chat room, which is projected on the wall, where his colleagues can read them.

卡普尔立刻对电话技术的迟钝感到沮丧，并对解决方法的巧妙性印象深刻，他慢慢地左右摇头。“这必须是第一次。”

Kapor, at once frustrated by the balkiness of the phone technology and impressed by the ingenuity of the work-around, shakes his head slowly from side to side. “This has to be a first.”

安迪·瓦伊达 (Andi Vajda) 是当天演示名单上的最后一名。他展示了 Leung 的更多存储库压力测试，然后将主题转向全文索引。他走到白板前，开始解释。如果用户要能够搜索他们的 Chandler 数据，该程序将需要为其用户存储库中的每一位文本建立索引。碰巧的是，已经有一个名为 Lucene 的优秀开源文本搜索工具，Chandler 可以将其纳入其中。但有一个问题：Lucene 是用 Java 编写的；Chandler 基于 Python。如何整合它们？

Andi Vajda is last on the day’s demo roster. He shows a bit more of Leung’s repository stress tests, then switches the subject to full-text indexing. He walks over to the whiteboard and begins to explain. If users are going to be able to search their Chandler data, the program will need to index every bit of text in its user’s repository. As it happens, there’s already a great open source text-search tool called Lucene, and Chandler could incorporate it. But there’s a hitch: Lucene is written in Java; Chandler is based on Python. How to integrate them?

“我必须做一些杂技，”瓦伊达说，脸上浮现出自豪的微笑。他继续描述他们，把房间里的非程序员远远抛在后面。通过一个名为 gcj 的开源编译器和另一个名为 SWIG（简化包装器和接口生成器）的工具来编译和“包装”Java 代码的长链结束后，Lucene 可以愉快地与 Python 和 Chandler 存储库一起使用。然后，Vajda 在 2.5 MB 的文本文件（1992 年 CIA 世界报告）上演示了代码。对于该程序对大约 300,000 个单词的文档进行索引，总共需要 1.3 秒，这比 Chandler 执行任何操作所需的时间都快。

“I had to do a certain amount of acrobatics,” Vajda says, a proud smile stealing onto his face. He goes on to describe them, leaving the nonprogrammers in the room far behind. At the end of a long chain of compiling and “wrapping” the code from Java through an open source compiler called gcj and another tool called SWIG (for Simplified Wrapper and Interface Generator), Lucene could happily work with Python and the Chandler repository. Vajda then demonstrates the code on a 2.5 megabyte text file—a 1992 CIA World Report. For the program to index the document’s approximately 300,000 words, it takes all of 1.3 seconds—faster than Chandler, at that point, would take to do just about anything.

当瓦伊达带领同事们完成他精心策划的巴洛克式代码转换时，他的眼睛闪闪发亮，眼皮在颤动。当他提到他在平安夜熬夜完成这个项目时，这听起来不像是抱怨；相反，他是在抱怨。显然他玩得太开心了。

As Vajda walks his colleagues through the baroque transformations of code he has orchestrated, his eyes shine and his eyelids flutter. When he mentions that he stayed up to the wee hours on Christmas Eve to finish the project, it doesn’t sound like a complaint; evidently he’d been having way too much fun.

演示结束后，卡普尔站了起来，显然很兴奋。“我们的一些基础设施投资已开始获得回报。” 他宣布他们已经删除了新开发经理的招聘信息。“我只是一个控制狂，我还没准备好放弃这份工作，”他开玩笑说。但很明显，迈克尔·托伊离职后出现的结构正在发挥作用。进展正在发生。代码正在编写中。在开发团队的各个角落，你甚至可以到处感受到弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯所说的“忙碌”的紧迫感。

At the end of the demos, Kapor gets up, visibly stoked. “Some of our infrastructure bets are beginning to pay off.” He announces that they’ve removed the job posting for a new development manager. “I’m just a control freak, and I wasn’t ready to give up the job,” he jokes. But it’s clear that the structure that emerged in the wake of Michael Toy’s departure is working. Progress is taking place. Code is getting written. And here and there, in corners of the development team, you could even sense a little of that quality of urgency that Frederick Brooks called “hustle.”





OSAF 于 2004 年 2 月 26 日发布了 Chandler 0.3。新版本包含了 CPIA 的工作版本和更成熟的存储库，但它基本上仍然无法使用——只有外部软件开发人员感兴趣，他们可能对 Kapor 和他的团队的进展感到好奇到。但 OSAF 周围的气氛却与 0.2 相反：在办公室的厨房区域举行了 T 恤签名和小型巧克力蛋糕庆祝活动，一些 OSAF 的老前辈，如 Lou Montulli 和 Aleks Totic 也现身加入欢呼声。程序员们觉得他们有一些吸引力。

OSAF released Chandler 0.3 on February 26, 2004. The new release incorporated a working version of CPIA and a more mature repository, but it remained essentially unusable—of interest only to outside software developers who might be curious about what Kapor and his team were up to. But the mood around OSAF was the opposite of 0.2: There was a T-shirt signing and a little chocolate cake celebration around the kitchen area of the office, and some OSAF old-timers, like Lou Montulli and Aleks Totic, showed up to join the cheers. The programmers felt they had some traction.

这一进展还意味着，Apps Group 中的开发人员此前一直满足于让设计团队按照自己的节奏工作，但他们开始渴望为 Chandler 的外观和行为制定更彻底、最终的路线图。当人们看到实际构建程序的真实用户界面时——不是原型或权宜之计，而是真实的东西，使用真实的存储库和 Chandler 团队在过去一年里辛苦发明的架构——程序员的渴望信息变得显而易见。

The progress also meant that the developers in the Apps Group, who had been content up to this point to let the design team work at its own pace, began to get itchy for a more thorough and final roadmap of how Chandler should look and behave. As the prospect came into view of actually building the program’s real user interface—not a prototype or a stopgap but the real thing, using the real repository and the architecture that the Chandler team had laboriously invented over the past year—the programmers’ hunger for information grew palpable.

他们需要细节。他们需要蓝图。他们需要规范——这个词对编程工作如此重要，随着时间的推移，它除了第一个音节之外的所有内容都被去掉了，变成了简洁的、不可简化的规范。

They needed details. They needed blueprints. They needed specifications—a word so vital to the work of programming that over time it has shed all but its first syllable, becoming the terse, irreducible specs.





如果您看过精彩的重金属模仿电影《This Is Spinal Tap》，您可能会记得这样一个场景：这支衰弱的乐队试图用一首带有凯尔特媚俗色彩的夸张的巨石阵主题歌曲来重振其事业。当中心装饰品从天花板下降到一圈跳舞的侏儒时，首次亮相就搁浅了：巨石阵拱门的复制品只有一英尺半高。

If you’ve seen the brilliant heavy-metal parody movie This Is Spinal Tap, you might recall the scene in which the washed-up band tries to revive its career with a bombastic Stonehenge-themed number festooned with Celtic kitsch. The debut runs aground when the centerpiece descends from the ceiling to land in a circle of dancing midgets: The replica of a Stonehenge arch is a puny foot and a half high.

“我不认为问题在于乐队瘫痪了， ”主唱在酒店房间事后向经理抱怨道。“我认为问题出在舞台上的巨石阵纪念碑有被矮人压碎的危险！”

“I do not, for one, think that the problem was that the band was down,” the lead singer complains to the manager in a hotel room postmortem. “I think the problem was a Stonehenge monument on the stage that was in danger of being crushed by a dwarf!”

问题的根源是什么？一个糟糕的规格。一天深夜，吉他手奈杰尔·图夫内尔 (Nigel Tufnel) 在一家咖啡店绘制的餐巾纸背面草图上，一个额外的撇号将一块十八英尺的巨石变成了一场十八英寸的闹剧。

The root of the problem? A bad spec. On the back-of-a-napkin sketch drawn by guitarist Nigel Tufnel at a coffee shop late one night, an extra apostrophe had transformed an eighteen-foot megalith into an eighteen-inch farce.

“我的工作就是按照乐队的创意元素要求我做的事情，”经理抗议道。“奈杰尔给了我一张画，上面写着十八英寸。”

“It’s my job to do what I’m asked to do by the creative element of the band,” the manager protests. “Nigel gave me a drawing that said eighteen inches.”

“但你并不像他那么困惑，是吗？” 歌手回答道。“像奈杰尔一样困惑不是你的工作。”

“But you’re not as confused as him, are you?” the singer answers. “It’s not your job to be as confused as Nigel.”

当经理质问布景设计师时，她很愤怒。她从公文包里拿出餐巾：“看，看。这就是我被要求做的。十八英寸。就在这儿。已经明确了！”

When the manager confronts the set designer, she’s indignant. She pulls the napkin out of her briefcase: “Look, look. This is what I was asked to do. Eighteen inches. Right here. It’s specified!”





但这是在规范中的！或者，它不在规范中！这些呼喊是每个遇到障碍的软件项目不可避免的重复内容。编写规范是一份为程序员提供大量详细说明的文档，对于任何软件构建企业​​来说都是必要的步骤，因为产品的最终用户与程序员不是同一个人。该规范将需求（软件开发人员的客户提出的一组目标或愿望）转化为程序员需要遵循的详细行进命令。例如，对于个人财务软件产品，要求听起来像这样：必须支持多个信用卡账户的分类账。需要能够从银行下载帐户信息。规范实际上会详细说明该程序如何满足这些要求。视觉规范详尽地详细说明了每个屏幕的外观、按钮和菜单的位置、字体和颜色，以及当文本过多而无法容纳在一行中时会发生什么情况。交互规范记录了程序如何响应用户的每次单击、拖动和键入字符。

But it was in the spec! Or, It wasn’t in the spec! These cries are the inevitable refrain of every software project that has hit a snag. Writing the spec, a document that lays out copiously detailed instructions for the programmer, is a necessary step in any software building enterprise where the ultimate user of the product is not the same person as the programmer. The spec translates requirements—the set of goals or desires the software developer’s customers lay out—into detailed marching orders for the programmer to follow. For a personal finance software product, for instance, requirements would sound like this: Must support ledgers for multiple credit card accounts. Needs to be able to download account information from banks. The specs would actually spell out how the program fulfills these requirements. Visual specs exhaustively detail how each screen looks, where the buttons and menus are, typefaces and colors, and what happens when there is too much text to fit in a line. Interaction specs record how a program behaves in response to the user’s every click, drag, and typed character.

规范是程序员的圣经，通常，程序员是原教旨主义者：规范的话就是法律。出于本性和职业需求，程序员也都是注重字面意义的。因此，规范的创建需要谨慎和谨慎：你需要小心你的愿望，就像在童话故事中一样。（永生？别忘了指定永葆青春！）

The spec is the programmer’s bible, and, typically, the programmer is a fundamentalist: The spec’s word is law. Programmers are also, by nature and occupational demand, literal-minded. So the creation of specs calls for care and caution: You need to be careful what you wish for, as in a fairy tale. (Everlasting life? Don’t forget to specify eternal youth as well!)

计算机领域最古老的笑话之一讲述了一位困惑的用户拨打支持热线抱怨虽然手册上说“按任意键开始”，但他在任何地方都找不到“任何”键。这个笑话对不幸的无知用户嗤之以鼻，但新手的误解实际上反映了程序员大师所擅长的那种皮卡尤恩的上下文无关阅读。正如其名称所示，规格应该通过纯粹详尽的特异性来弥合人类混乱和机器精度的领域。程序员不能有任何含糊之处，也不能进行猜测。但这种努力不可避免地是不完美的。部分原因是规范的作者是人类，而且编写规范的语言也是人类的。但这也是因为制定“完美规范”（确定并指定程序使用和行为的每种可能场景）的努力将被证明是无限的劳动；你永远不会完成规范编写并开始编码。

One of the oldest jokes in computing tells of the flummoxed user who calls a support line complaining that although the manual says, “Press any key to begin,” he can’t find the “any” key anywhere. The joke looks down its nose at the hapless ignoramus user, but the novice’s misunderstanding actually mirrors the sort of picayune context-free readings that are the specialty of master programmers. Specs, as their name indicates, are supposed to bridge the realm of human confusion and machine precision through sheer exhaustive specificity. The programmer is to be left with no ambiguities, no guesswork. But the effort is inevitably imperfect. In part that’s because the specs’ authors are human, and the language they are written in is human. But it’s also because the effort to produce a “perfect spec”—one that determined and specified every possible scenario of a program’s usage and behavior—would prove an infinite labor; you’d never finish spec writing and start coding.

在实践中，人类的不耐烦和市场的需求共同导致规格不足成为常态。在 OSAF，问题不在于知道规范何时完成，而在于弄清楚如何开始规范。尽管团队有了新的动力，但仍然存在一些复杂的领域，用 OSAF 老前辈的术语来说就是“蛇”。

In practice, human impatience and the market’s demands conspire to make underspecification the norm. And at OSAF the problem wasn’t knowing when specs were finished but, rather, figuring out how to get them started. Despite the new feeling of momentum on the team, a few complex areas remained, in the terminology of OSAF old-timers, snakes.

共享信息是钱德勒最重要的功能之一，但每次设计团队面对这个主题时，它都会陷入未解决的问题的循环中，或者用项目管理的语言来说，“开放问题”。一个用户如何发起与另一个用户的共享？具体可以分享什么？单个项目？整个物品的集合？集合的特定视图或屏幕布局？当用户想要共享某些项目但不想共享其他项目时，钱德勒将如何处理“权限”？如果某些共享允许共享者对共享项目进行更改，而其他共享则不允许，共享者将如何做出选择？如果两个用户共享一个项目，并且他们都在离线时更改了该项目，那么当他们重新上线并尝试同步他们的更改时，Chandler 将如何解决冲突？然后是最棘手的共享问题：“链共享”。如果我与您分享一个项目，您可以与第三人分享吗？她可以再分享一次吗？当第三、四或五号共享者对共享项目进行更改时会发生什么？它是否会沿着共享线路一路传播回来？这个问题的另一个名称是“n 路同步”——同步一段数据的一些未知 (n) 个版本。

Sharing information was to be one of Chandler’s most important features, but every time the design team confronted the subject, it got stuck in a loop of unresolved questions or, in the language of project management, “open issues.” How would one user initiate a share with another? What exactly could be shared? A single item? A whole collection of items? A particular view or screen layout of a collection? How would Chandler handle “permissions” when a user wanted to share some items but not others? If some shares allowed the sharee to make changes in the shared item and others didn’t, how would the sharer make that choice? If two users share an item and they both alter the item when they’re offline, how would Chandler resolve the conflict when they go back online and it tries to synchronize their changes? And then there was the thorniest sharing problem of all: “chain sharing.” If I share an item with you, can you share it with a third person? Can she share it again? What happens when sharee number three or four or five makes a change in a shared item? Does it propagate all the way back down the sharing line? Another name for this problem was “n-way sync”—synchronizing some unknown (n) number of versions of a piece of data.

一开始是一个简单的要求——“用户应该能够轻松地共享信息”——很快就变成了一大堆困难。有一段时间，只是说“让我们推迟这些讨论吧”，但每个人都知道，最终这些问题将不得不经过讨论。

What started as a simple requirement—“Users should be able to share information easily”—very quickly mushroomed into a cloud of difficulties. For a while it worked to just say, “Let’s defer those discussions,” but everyone knew that eventually they would have to be hashed out.

共享并不是唯一的麻烦点。围绕钱德勒的收藏或物品组的方法，仍然存在许多悬而未决的问题。在某些方面，集合就像桌面界面中熟悉的文件夹一样——一组事物的容器——但在其他方面，它们将是新颖的。项目可以同时存在于多个集合中。有些集合是基于规则的。您只需告诉 Chandler 创建一个集合，例如，其中包含出现您业务合作伙伴姓名的所有项目，程序就会自动使其保持最新状态。通过这些方式，钱德勒管理信息的方法将从苹果公司用于管理数字音乐收藏的 iTunes 软件中汲取灵感，该软件提供了自己的这些功能版本。但卡普尔还想确保钱德勒允许任意排除和包含项目。在他最喜欢的例子中，他可能希望基于规则的音乐收藏包含鲍勃·马利的任何曲目，但忽略他讨厌的特定现场录音。iTunes 不会让你这样做。

Sharing wasn’t the only trouble spot. There remained a host of open issues surrounding Chandler’s approach to collections, or groups of items. In some ways collections were meant to be like the familiar folders of the desktop interface—containers for groups of things—but in other ways they were going to be novel. Items could exist simultaneously in many collections. Some collections would be rule-based. You’d simply tell Chandler to create a collection that, say, contained all items in which your business partner’s name appeared, and the program would automatically keep it up to date. In these ways, Chandler’s approach to managing information would draw inspiration from Apple’s iTunes software for managing digital music collections, which offered its own version of these features. But Kapor also wanted to make sure that Chandler would allow for arbitrary exclusion and inclusion of items. In his favorite example, he might want a rule-based music collection to include any track by Bob Marley—but to leave out one particular live recording that he detests. iTunes won’t let you do that.

“第一次，”卡普尔在一次讨论中解释道，“当我设计议程时，当我说我们希望有由规则定义的集合，但也有你只想任意将某些内容放入组中的情况时，我得到了巨大的阻力。这就像我违反了计算机科学的一些根深蒂固的禁忌。确实，有很多非常奇怪的案例。但我们不能因为认为人们会害怕而忽略某些功能。那么你就永远不会发明弹力绳。”

“The first time around,” Kapor explained during one discussion, “when I was designing Agenda, when I said we would want to have collections defined by rules but also have situations where you just wanted to put something in a group arbitrarily, I got enormous pushback. It was like I was violating some deep taboo of computer science. And it’s true, there are a lot of very squirrelly cases. But we can’t leave out features just because we think people will be afraid of them. Then you never invent the bungee cord.”

但为了让 Chandler 能够处理 Kapor 的 Bob Marley 排除案例，OSAF 的设计团队有很多事情需要弄清楚：用户究竟如何创建此类集合并指定包含和排除？钱德勒会如何储存它们？您如何确保人们不会对从集合中排除某个项目与从 Chandler 中完全删除该项目之间的区别感到困惑？所有这些不同类型的集合将如何显示在 Chandler 界面中？

But in order for Chandler to be able to handle Kapor’s Bob Marley Exclusion Case, OSAF’s design team had a lot to figure out: How exactly would the user create such collections and specify the inclusions and exclusions? How would Chandler store them? How could you make sure that people didn’t get confused about the difference between excluding an item from a collection and deleting the item entirely from Chandler? How would all these different types of collections show up in the Chandler interface?

然后出现了被称为“项目可变性”或“多态性”的问题。钱德勒的使命是消除其他个人信息管理系统为将一种信息与另一种信息隔离而建立的孤岛。电子邮件、日历事件、待办任务和笔记都将在一个巨大的信息池中游泳，用户可以根据需要进行访问。但是，用户究竟如何接收收到的有关聚会的电子邮件并将其转换为日历上的约会，或者将同事发来的电子邮件转换为待办事项列表上的任务？该电子邮件会消失还是保留在您的电子邮件集中？你最终会得到两件物品还是一件？

Then there was the problem that came to be known as “item mutability” or “polymorphism.” Chandler’s destiny was to level the silos that other personal information management systems built to segregate one kind of information from another. Emails and calendar events and to-do tasks and notes would all swim in a big informational pool that users could dip into as needed. But how exactly would a user go about taking, say, an incoming email about a party and turning it into an appointment on the calendar—or transforming an email from a colleague into a task on a to-do list? Would the email disappear or remain in your email collection? Would you end up with two items or one?

当设计团队的成员努力解决这些问题时，卡普尔提醒他们一条编程格言（广泛归因于个人计算先驱艾伦·凯）：简单的事情应该简单；简单的事情应该简单；简单的事情应该简单。复杂的事情应该是可能的。卡普尔希望钱德勒易于使用；他还希望它能够解决一些著名的硬软件问题。现在，他和他的团队深陷权衡的泥潭，试图让这一切顺利进行。

As the members of the design team struggled to get their heads and hands around these questions, Kapor reminded them of a programming maxim (widely attributed to personal computing pioneer Alan Kay): Simple things should be simple; complex things should be possible. Kapor wanted Chandler to be simple to use; he also wanted it to solve some famously hard software problems. Now he and his crew were hip-deep in the mire of trade-offs, trying to make it all work.

2004 年 4 月的一天，Chao Lam 向 Mimi Yin 发送了一篇文章的链接，该文章是他在一位名叫 Clay Shirky 的博客文章中找到的，作者是一位在线交流动态的资深评论员。Shirky 写了一篇关于他对 Christopher Alexander 的一篇旧文章的重新发现的文章，Christopher Alexander 是一位哲学家兼建筑师，他的“模式”概念在编程世界中引起了轰动。1965 年题为“城市不是一棵树”的文章分析了规划社区的缺陷，指出它们通常被设计为“树结构”。“只要我们有一个树结构，就意味着在这个结构中，任何单元的任何部分都不会与其他单元连接，除非通过该单元作为一个整体的媒介。这种限制的严重性是难以理解的。这有点像一个家庭的成员没有自由结交家庭以外的朋友，除非整个家庭建立了友谊。”

One day in April 2004, Chao Lam sent Mimi Yin a link to an article that he had found in a blog posting by a writer named Clay Shirky, a veteran commentator on the dynamics of online communication. Shirky had written about his rediscovery of an old article by Christopher Alexander, the philosopher-architect whose concept of “patterns” had inspired ferment in the programming world. The 1965 article titled “A City Is Not a Tree” analyzed the failings of planned communities by observing that typically they have been designed as “tree structures.” “Whenever we have a tree structure, it means that within this structure no piece of any unit is ever connected to other units, except through the medium of that unit as a whole. The enormity of this restriction is difficult to grasp. It is a little as though the members of a family were not free to make friends outside the family, except when the family as a whole made a friendship.”

用亚历山大的术语来说，有机增长的真实城市以及人类关系的真实结构被布置为“半格子”。半格子是比树更松散的结构；它在一定程度上仍然是分层的，但允许子集重叠。为什么建筑设计和规划的社区总是以“树结构”告终？亚历山大认为，半格子更复杂，更难以想象，我们不可避免地会倾向于更容易掌握的树。但这种“每个头脑简单的人都会把同名的东西放在同一个篮子里的狂热”导致城市设计受到人为的限制和沉闷。“当我们从树木的角度思考时，我们正在用生命城市的人性和丰富性来换取概念的简单性，而这种概念的简单性只对设计师、规划者、管理者和开发商有利。每当城市的一部分被撕掉，并用一棵树取代以前存在的半格子时，这座城市就向分裂迈进了一步。”

Real cities that have grown organically—and real structures of human relationships—are instead laid out as “semi-lattices,” in Alexander’s terminology. A semi-lattice is a looser structure than a tree; it is still hierarchical to a degree but allows subsets to overlap. Why do architectural designs and planned communities always end up as “tree structures”? Alexander suggests that the semi-lattice is more complex and harder to visualize and that we inevitably gravitate toward the more easily graspable tree. But this “mania every simpleminded person has for putting things with the same name into the same basket” results in urban designs that are artificially constrained and deadening. “When we think in terms of trees, we are trading the humanity and richness of the living city for a conceptual simplicity which benefits only designers, planners, administrators, and developers. Every time a piece of a city is torn out, and a tree made to replace the semi-lattice that was there before, the city takes a further step toward dissociation.”

Yin 读了 Alexander 的文章——通过 Clay Shirky 的博客和 Chao Lam 的电子邮件到达她的路径，似乎说明了这篇文章关于复杂互连的观点——并立即将其想法应用到了 Chandler 的设计中。她为 Chandler 浏览器精心设计了这款浏览器，该浏览器大致受到 iTunes 的启发；它将允许用户通过混合和匹配（或“切片和切块”）从三列选择中导航其存储库中的项目（例如，您可能有第一列仅选中“电子邮件”，第二列则选中一组所选名称，第三个带有日期范围）。

Yin read the Alexander piece—the path it took to reach her, via Clay Shirky’s blog and Chao Lam’s email, seemed to illustrate the article’s point about complex interconnection—and immediately applied its ideas to Chandler’s design. She emerged with an elaborate design for a Chandler browser that was loosely inspired by iTunes; it would allow users to navigate the items in their repository by mixing and matching (or “slicing and dicing”) from three columns of choices (for instance, you might have a first column with only “emails” checked, a second with a set of selected names, and a third with a date range).

浏览器的设计引起了长时间的讨论，但没有赢得任何快速的共识。在试图为钱德勒的信息想象一种不同的、层次较少的结构时，尹一头扎进了这样一个现实：层次结构深深地嵌入到软件的本质及其创建者的思维中。正如亚历山大所说，城市可能不是一棵树，但今天几乎每个计算机程序实际上都是一棵树——代码行的层次结构。在软件世界中，树随处可见——从许多程序用户界面左侧窗格中无处不在的文件夹树，到文件系统和数据库的深层组织，再到开发人员管理他们编写的代码的系统。

The browser design occasioned lengthy discussion but did not win any kind of fast consensus. In trying to imagine a different, less hierarchical structure for Chandler’s information, Yin was smacking headfirst into the reality that hierarchies are embedded deep in the nature of software and in the thinking of its creators. A city may not be a tree, as Alexander said, but nearly every computer program today really is a tree—a hierarchical structure of lines of code. You find trees everywhere in the software world—from the ubiquitous folder trees found in the left-hand pane of so many program’s user interfaces to the deep organization of file systems and databases to the very system by which developers manage the code they write.

“树”是开发人员检查其工作的源代码目录的非正式名称。如果一个团队需要在不影响同事工作的情况下独立完成程序的一部分，他们就会形成一个与“树干”分开的新“分支”。稍后，当他们想要将其工作与其余代码重新集成时，新分支将与主干合并。当 OSAF 的新 Tinderbox 之类的测试系统报告该项目一切顺利时，程序员们松了口气，说“树已经绿了”。

“The tree” is the informal name for the directory of source code where developers check in their work. If a group needs to work on a part of the program on their own without disrupting the work of their colleagues, they form a new “branch” of the tree, separate from the “trunk.” Later, when they want to reintegrate their work with the rest of the code, the new branch is merged with the trunk. When a testing system like OSAF’s new Tinderbox reports that all is well with the project, the programmers say with some relief that “the tree is green.”

因此，远离树木可能并不那么简单。无论如何，尹的浏览器也感觉与应用程序团队开发人员的直接问题和需求脱节。他们距离实施类似的事情还有很长的路要走。他们面临的下一个重大障碍是实施钱德勒的“细节视图”。钱德勒屏幕分为四个基本区域。顶部是传统的镶边区域（菜单、工具栏等）。左侧有一个侧边栏，用于列出和组织项目集合。中心，即主要区域，将分为两个独立的部分：一个汇总表（“大表”，在 2003 年的大部分时间里一直是一个绊脚石）和一个详细视图。摘要将列出项目（电子邮件、日历事件、用户放入 Chandler 的任何内容）；当用户突出显示摘要中的某个项目时，详细信息视图将显示有关该项目的所有内容。

So getting away from trees might not be so simple. In any case, Yin’s browser also felt disconnected from the immediate problems and needs of the apps team developers. They were miles away from being able to implement anything like it. One of the next big hurdles they faced was implementing Chandler’s “detail view.” The Chandler screen was to be organized into four basic areas. Across the top a traditional area for chrome (menus, toolbars, and such). At the left a sidebar for listing and organizing collections of items. The center, the main area, would split into two separate parts: a summary table (the “big table” that had been a stumbling block through much of 2003) and a detail view. The summary would list items (emails, calendar events, anything the user put into Chandler); when the user highlighted an item in the summary, the detail view would show everything about that item.

这种结构对于传统的 PIM 和电子邮件程序来说已经足够熟悉了，但是在弄清楚如何设计和构建每个元素方面仍然需要做大量的工作。摘要观点虽然远未完成，但正在向前推进。细节视图现在成为最大的障碍。这不仅仅是编目和列出与某个项目相关的所有文本的问题；钱德勒的筒仓平衡野心意味着开发人员也面临着一些新问题。勾勒出这个视图将包含和显示什么以及不包含什么的简单行为，成为决策的焦点——卡普尔喜欢称之为强制函数。创建详细视图、将这些选择转化为一段功能代码的工作落在了 OSAF 最新程序员 Donn Denman 的肩上。

This structure was familiar enough from traditional PIMs and email programs, but there was still a ton of work in figuring out exactly how to design and build each element. The summary view, though far from complete, was moving along. The detail view now loomed as the biggest hurdle. It wasn’t just a matter of cataloging and listing all the text associated with an item; Chandler’s silo-leveling ambitions meant that the developers faced some novel questions as well. The simple act of sketching what this view would contain and show, and what it wouldn’t, became a focal point for decisions—what Kapor liked to call a forcing function. The job of creating the detail view, turning those choices into a functioning piece of code, fell on the shoulders of OSAF’s newest programmer, Donn Denman.





有些程序员在乌云中行走，好像他们必须修复的每一个错误都在他们的心灵上留下了伤疤。其他人看起来除了破解代码之外他们什么都不想做。Donn Denman 是第二种程序员。

Some programmers walk around in a dark cloud, as if every single bug they’ve ever had to fix has left a scar on their psyches. Others look like there’s nothing they would rather be doing than hacking out code. Donn Denman is the second kind of programmer.

“当我年轻的时候，我喜欢拼图，”当我问丹曼为什么从事他的工作时，他告诉我。“我真的很喜欢拼图，比如串珠拼图。即使现在我也可以花上几个小时来解开一个设计精良的谜题——试图弄清楚如何让戒指摆脱缠结，弄清楚它是如何工作的，尽管这似乎是不可能的。

“When I was young, I loved puzzles,” Denman told me when I asked why he had gone into his line of work. “I really had a passion for puzzles, like stringing bead puzzles. I can spend hours even now with a puzzle if it’s well designed—trying to figure out how to get the ring free from the tangle, figuring out how it works even though it seems impossible.

“我在学校也喜欢数学。我认为这类事情对我很有吸引力，因为当我做对了时，我知道我做对了。在数学中，你通常可以回答问题，然后向后推算，看看它是否是正确的答案。

“I also liked mathematics in school. I think those sorts of things appealed to me because when I got it right, I knew I got it right. In mathematics you can often answer the problem and then work it backward to see if it’s the correct answer.

“对于一个没有错误的程序来说也是如此——你可以看到你的成功——而生活中的许多其他事情都是主观的，你不知道自己是否成功。这引起了我当时的不安全感。此外，我真的很喜欢能够创造新事物、构建事物、拆开事物、了解它们是如何工作的以及修复事物。我觉得现在客观奖励对我来说已经不那么重要了。我年纪大了，我更有自信了，我不需要那种反馈。但能够创造东西、看到事情发生、建造东西——这仍然很有趣。”

“The same is true with a program that works if it doesn’t have bugs—you can see your success—whereas so many other things in life are subjective, and you don’t know if you were successful or not. That appealed to my insecurity at the time. Also, I really enjoy being able to create new things, building things, taking things apart, seeing how they work, and fixing things. I think the objective reward is less important to me now. I’m older, I have more self-confidence, I don’t need that feedback. But being able to create stuff, see things happen, build things—that’s still a lot of fun.”

丹曼在俄亥俄州黄泉市长大，这里是安提阿学院的所在地，他的父亲是该学院的一名教授，他就读于该学院。1979 年，他大学一毕业就加入了苹果公司，工作地点就在安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 对面的一个小隔间里。在这家年轻的公司里，他发现了一种反叛精神，这让他想起了安条克的反文化精神。丹曼一直痴迷于创建系统，让很少或没有编程经验的人能够在计算机上自动化工作。在那个时代，Basic 就是此类工作的工具。在 Apple，他致力于将 Basic 版本从 Apple II 移植到新的 Apple III。

Denman grew up in Yellow Springs, Ohio, home of Antioch College, where his father was a professor and which he attended. He had gone to work for Apple right out of college in 1979, in a cubicle right across from Andy Hertzfeld. At the young company he found a rebel spirit that reminded him of Antioch’s countercultural ethos. Denman’s obsession has always been with creating systems that allow people with little or no programming experience to automate their work on a computer. In that era, Basic was the tool for such work. At Apple he worked on porting a version of Basic from the Apple II to the new Apple III.

然后赫茨菲尔德招募他加入 Macintosh 团队，他的工作再次是为新计算机编写 Basic，其方法利用了 Mac 革命性的图形界面。“我们有相当多的时间，”丹曼回忆道，“我对如何从下往上构建一个新的 Basic 有了一些想法。我正在取得进展，但无法真正限制该项目并对其进行管理，以按时完成并随第一台 Mac 一起发布。”

Then Hertzfeld recruited him for the Macintosh team—where his job was, again, to write Basic for the new computer, with an approach that took advantage of the Mac’s revolutionary graphic interface. “We had quite a bit of time,” Denman recalled, “and I had these ideas of how to build a new Basic from the bottom up. I was making progress but unable to really put limits on the project and manage it to get it done on time and ship with the initial Mac.”

Denman 继续致力于 MacBasic 的开发，但在它准备就绪之前，微软发布了自己的基于 Macintosh 的 Basic，苹果程序员认为它的性能较差，并且与 Mac 新设计的集成度较差。与此同时，苹果与微软就Apple II 上运行的Basic 的授权协议即将续签。比尔·盖茨知道苹果迫切需要新的许可证，作为回报，微软要求苹果关闭丹曼的 MacBasic。苹果以一美元的价格将代码卖给了微软。

Denman kept working on MacBasic, but before it was ready, Microsoft had released its own Macintosh-based Basic—one that the Apple programmers felt was inferior and poorly integrated with the Mac’s new design. Meanwhile, Apple’s deal with Microsoft to license the Basic that ran on the Apple II was up for renewal. In return for a new license, which Bill Gates knew Apple badly wanted, Microsoft demanded that Apple shut down Denman’s MacBasic. Apple sold the code to Microsoft for a dollar.

正如 Andy Hertzfeld 在他的 Folklore.org 网站上讲述的那样，“当 Donn 发现 MacBasic 已被取消时，他心碎了。他的经理告诉他，“它已被无限期搁置”，并指示他销毁源代码和所有副本，但拒绝回答唐恩关于发生了什么的问题。那天晚些时候，唐恩骑着摩托车疯狂骑行，结果撞坏了车，回到家时浑身擦伤，但没有受到任何真正的伤害，除了他已经受到重创的自尊心。”

As Andy Hertzfeld tells the story on his Folklore.org site, “When Donn found out that MacBasic had been canceled, he was heartbroken. His manager told him, ‘It’s been put on hold indefinitely,’ and instructed him to destroy the source code and all copies, but refused to answer Donn’s questions about what was going on. Later that day Donn went for a wild ride on his motorcycle and crashed it, returning home scraped up but with no real damage, except to his already battered ego.”

“我投入了很多时间和精力，它就像我的孩子一样，”丹曼向我回忆道。“我两岁的孩子被夺走了。我想我花了十年或二十年的时间才克服这个问题。” 最终，他留在了苹果公司并致力于 AppleScript，这是另一个面向非程序员的系统。他最终在公司九十年代中期陷入困境时离开了公司，并走出了科技行业的泡沫，致力于开发数字有线电视传输系统（即机顶盒）的软件。泡沫的波动并没有让他变得富有，但让他有足够的钱来休息一段时间。他喜欢在自己的时间里修补自己的项目，但是当赫茨菲尔德开始告诉他有关钱德勒的事情时，他的眼睛亮了起来。他一直渴望回归自己的​​热情：为所面临的编程挑战编写脚本系统。卡普尔的项目听起来只是门票。

“I had put so much time and effort in, it was like my baby,” Denman recalled to me. “My two-year-old had been taken from me. I think it took me ten or twenty years to get over that.” Ultimately, he stayed at Apple and worked on AppleScript, another system for nonprogrammers. He finally left the company during its mid-nineties tailspin and rode out the tech industry bubble working on software for the digital cable TV delivery systems known as set-top boxes. The bubble’s gyrations didn’t make him rich but left him with enough money to take some time off. He enjoyed tinkering with his own projects on his own time, but when Hertzfeld started telling him about Chandler, his eyes lit up. He had been itching to return to his passion: scripting systems for the programming challenged. Kapor’s project sounded like just the ticket.

Denman 于 2004 年 4 月加入 Apps Group，并与 Katie Parlante 坐下来讨论该做什么。详细视图分配似乎是他深入研究 Chandler 代码并了解 CPIA 特性的好方法。他将是第一个认真使用 CPIA 的程序员，但他并没有参与发明它，他提出的问题将有助于完善它。

Denman joined the Apps Group in April 2004 and sat down with Katie Parlante to figure out what to work on. The detail view assignment seemed like a good way for him to dive into the Chandler code and learn the idiosyncrasies of CPIA. He would be the first programmer to make serious use of CPIA who hadn’t had a hand in inventing it, and the questions he asked would help refine it.

但为了构建详细视图的工作初稿，丹曼需要一个规范来工作。而且好像也没有。Mimi Yin 有一堆 wiki 页面和细节视图各方面的粗略“线框”草图，但随着设计团队的会议不断提出有关共享、收藏和项目可变性的新问题，它们也在不断演变。丹曼意识到他必须与设计师协商并开始编写自己的规格。因此，从五月份开始，丹曼、尹以及赵林几乎每天都在霍华德街的一间小会议室里见面——每个会议室都没有窗户，只够容纳三四个人，一张桌子，还有一张满墙的墙。白板。一小时后房间就会升温，干记号笔的烟雾会变得令人窒息，但团队决心解决未解决的问题，为丹曼开始编码扫清道路。

But in order to build a working first draft of the detail view, Denman needed a spec to work from. And there didn’t seem to be one. Mimi Yin had a pile of wiki pages and rough “wire-frame” sketches of aspects of the detail view, but they were in constant evolution as the design team’s meetings kept throwing up new questions about sharing and collections and item mutability. Denman realized he would have to confer with the designers and start writing his own specs. So in May, Denman and Yin, along with Chao Lam, began to meet almost daily in one of Howard Street’s little meeting rooms—each a windowless space just big enough for three or four people, a table, and a wall-to-wall whiteboard. The rooms would heat up after an hour, and the dry-marker fumes would get stifling, but the group was determined to motor through the open issues and clear a way for Denman to start coding.

尹解释了对物品的最新思考。大多数 PIM 程序要求用户在创建新项目时预先决定它是什么：您正在创建一封新电子邮件吗？日历事件？待办任务？相反，钱德勒会让你坐下来，开始写笔记，然后再决定它是什么类型的。就像人体未分化的干细胞一样，音符在生命开始时就具有向不同方向生长的潜力。这种设计的目的是将信息输入程序的基本行为从禁锢的孤岛中解放出来。它还为 Yin 针对物品可变性问题提出的解决方案腾出了空间：用户用来指定物品“善意”的机制将被称为标记。

Yin explained the latest thinking on items. Most PIM programs required users to decide up front, when they created a new item, what it was: Were you creating a new email? A calendar event? A to-do task? Chandler would instead let you sit down, start typing a note, and decide later what kind of item it was. Like the human body’s undifferentiated stem cells, notes would begin life with the potential to grow in different directions. This design aimed to liberate the basic act of entering information into the program from the imprisoning silos. It also made room for Yin’s proposed solution to the item mutability problem: The mechanism users would employ to specify the “kind-ness” of an item would be called stamping.

假设您输入了一条注释（关于会议的几句话），然后想将该会议添加到日历中。您可以将注释标记为事件。Chandler 的详细信息视图将添加可让您指定日期和时间的字段；你的通用笔记现在是一个事件。稍后，如果您想邀请同事参加会议，您可以记下相同的注释并将其标记为电子邮件。“收件人”字段和主题行将出现在详细视图中。您需要填写并单击“发送”按钮。
