Say you had typed a note—a couple of sentences about a meeting—and then wanted to put the meeting on the calendar. You would stamp the note as an event. Chandler’s detail view would add fields that let you specify a date and a time; your generic note was now an event. Later, if you wanted to invite a colleague to the meeting, you could take the same note and stamp it as an email. A “to” field and a subject line would appear in the detail view. You would fill it out and click on a “send” button.

冲压是一个绝妙的主意，但它提出的问题几乎和它回答的问题一样多。你能在一张纸条上取消标记吗？如果您这样做了，与您删除的善意相关的信息（例如日历事件上的日期）会怎样？当您在一张便条上盖章，然后查看“所有”集合（钱德勒存储库中每种类型的所有项目的列表）时，您看到一两个副本吗？

Stamping was a nifty idea, but it raised almost as many questions as it answered. Could you unstamp a note? And if you did, what happened to the information associated with the kind-ness you had removed (like the dates on a calendar event)? When you stamped a note and then looked at the “all” collection (a list of all the items of every kind in your Chandler repository), did you see one copy or two?

尹开始制作详细的草图，丹曼仔细检查了草图，并不断地问她问题：这个标签是什么意思？这个功能是如何工作的？设计师有很多解释要做。

Yin started producing detailed sketches, and Denman looked them over, peppering her with questions: What does this label mean? How does this feature work? The designer had a lot of explaining to do.





这是五月的一个下午，丹曼正在努力确定详细视图中首次运行的规格。他和尹开始填写白板一角的最后一块空白区域。

It is a May afternoon, and Denman is struggling to finalize a spec for the first run at the detail view. He and Yin begin filling up the last bare patch in the corner of a whiteboard.

“我需要某种方式来显示某件商品何时是新的，但我还没有弄清楚，”尹说。

“I need some way to show when an item is new, and I haven’t figured it out yet,” Yin says.

“这是什么？” 丹曼指着细节视图顶部附近的一个小头图标。尹解释说，这是为了分享。用户单击该按钮即可将项目发送给其他人。她大声地想知道该图标是否属于电子邮件项目，因为电子邮件项目有自己的发送控件。“但如果电子邮件变成了一项任务，那么你就会想要它。” 丹曼在笔记本上划痕。尹停顿了一下，转身离开黑板，说道：“这些东西让我做噩梦。”

“What is this?” Denman points to an icon of a little head that sits near the top of a detail view drawing. It’s for sharing, Yin explains. It’s what a user would click on to send an item to someone else. She wonders aloud whether the icon would belong on an email item at all, which would have its own controls for sending. “But if the email was turned into a task, then you’d want it.” Denman scratches in his notebook. Yin pauses, turns away from the board, and says, “These are the things that give me nightmares.”

“好吧，”丹曼抬起头来，“我会帮助你克服困难。我们将构建所​​有这些的一个子集，看看什么有效。因此，至少对于 0.4，我们可以说我们根本没有小头。”

“Well”—Denman looks up—“I’m going to help you slog through it. We’ll build a subset of it all and see what works. So for 0.4, at least, let’s say we don’t have the little heads at all.”

“不，”尹回答道。“你需要头脑；否则，就没有共享。”

“No,” Yin replies. “You need the heads; otherwise, there’s no sharing.”

“所以假设没有共享。” 丹曼微笑着。他可能是在开玩笑；他可能不会。

“So let’s say there’s no sharing.” Denman smiles. He might be joking; he might not.

尹将所有白板笔记复制到电子邮件中，以记录他们的讨论和决定。它提醒人们，电子邮件如何成为众多计算机用户事实上的各种信息仓库，并且提醒人们，大多数电子邮件程序在执行这一角色方面表现得多么糟糕，其糟糕的搜索功能和对附加文件的死板管理。正如 OSAF 开发人员一直说的那样，“我们真的可以使用 Chandler 来实现这一点。”

Yin copies all the whiteboard jottings into an email to record their discussion and decisions. It’s a reminder of how email has become the de facto warehouse for all kinds of information for so many computer users—and of how badly most email programs perform that role, with their lousy search capabilities and brain-dead management of attached files. As the OSAF developers kept saying, “We could really use Chandler for this.”

“我将再花一周的时间来计划，然后希望我能开始实施阶段，”丹曼说。他补充道，“我在新工作中仍然很开心！”——半微笑着，这表明这种乐趣显然是一种半杯满或空的事情，而他正在积极选择全景。

“I’m going to take one more week to plan, and then hopefully I’ll begin the implementation phase,” Denman says. He adds, “I’m still having fun in my new job!”—with a half smile that suggests the fun is decidedly a half-glass-full-or-empty sort of thing, and he’s actively choosing the full view.

“这里的感觉很像早期的苹果公司，”一天下午，丹曼在冲压工作中对我说道。“这是我很高兴在这里工作的原因之一。确实感觉我们可以改变世界——尽管我们在这里不是这么说的，当然，在苹果，我们一直这么说！”

“The feeling here is a lot like Apple in the early days,” Denman says to me one afternoon during the stamping work. “That’s one of the reasons I’m excited to be working here. It really does feel like we could change the world—though that’s not what we’re saying here, and at Apple, of course, we were saying that all the time!”





冲压旨在为计算机桌面引入一种富有成效的模糊性，更接近地反映人们的思维方式。即使对于发明它的设计师来说，这也不是一个简单的概念。对于必须让它发挥作用的开发人员来说，这甚至更加棘手。计算机程序使用筒仓和树以及类似的明确结构，因为它们有助于保持数据有序并减少混乱。如果一个项目属于一个组，则它不属于另一个组；如果它生活在一根树枝上，它就不会生活在另一根树枝上。

Stamping aimed to introduce a kind of productive ambiguity to the computer desktop that more closely mirrored the way people think. It was not a simple concept even for the designers who had invented it; for the developers who had to make it work, it was even trickier. Computer programs used silos and trees and similar unambiguous structures because they helped keep data organized and limited confusion. If an item belonged to one group, it did not belong to another; if it lived on one branch of a tree, it did not live on another.

人类的语言更加宽容：一个词可以表示不止一件事。这种灵活性提供了深刻的细微差别和美感；它是诗歌的基础。但当您尝试构建软件时，它只会带来麻烦。当 OSAF 的开发人员努力将 Chandler 的创新（例如冲压）从草图转变为功能代码时，他们一再发现自己因含糊不清而陷入困境。他们最终会一遍又一遍地使用相同的词语来描述不同的事物。

Human language is more forgiving: One word can mean more than one thing. This flexibility provides a deep well of nuance and beauty; it is a foundation of poetry. But it leads only to trouble when you are trying to build software. As OSAF’s developers struggled to transform the innovations in Chandler, such as stamping, from sketch to functioning code, they repeatedly found themselves tripped up by ambiguity. Over and over they would end up using the same words to describe different things.

拿走物品。对于设计师来说，Chandler 中的项目是用户认为是基本数据的任何内容。一封电子邮件。日历上的事件。任务或注释。但钱德勒存储库的后端世界也有物品，它的物品与前端的物品有微妙但本质上的不同。存储库项目是存储在 Chandler 数据库中的一条信息，事实上，您需要许多这样的存储库项目来向 Chandler 的用户提供单个用户项目（例如电子邮件）：用户项目的每个属性 - 主题行、发送日期、发件人地址等等——是一个单独的存储库项目。在钱德勒发展的不同时期，出现了解决这个问题的建议——“消除”项目一词的歧义。也许术语“用户项”始终可以大写。（当人们记得这样做时，这对书面材料有帮助，但在对话中则没有帮助。）也许可以采用一种或另一种类型的项目的另一个术语。（但其中一些提议，比如事情，甚至更加模糊，并且没有一个提议得到落实。）

Take item. To the designers an item in Chandler was anything a user thought of as a basic piece of data. A single email. An event on a calendar. A task or a note. But the back-end world of the Chandler repository also had items, and its items were subtly but substantially different from the front end’s items. A repository item was a single piece of information stored in Chandler’s database, and in fact you needed many of these repository items to present a user of Chandler with a single user item like an email: Each attribute of the user item—the subject line, the date sent, the sender’s address, and so on—was a separate repository item. At different times in Chandler’s evolution, proposals arose to resolve this problem—to “disambiguate” the word item. Maybe the term user item could always be capitalized. (This helped in written material, when people remembered to do it, but not in conversation.) Maybe another term for one or the other type of item could be adopted. (But some of those proposed, like thing, were even more ambiguous, and none of the proposals stuck.)

钱德勒的世界里充满了这种词的重叠。设计团队一直使用术语“数据模型”来指代用户将遇到的数据类型定义列表以及与该数据类型关联的所有属性。例如，数据模型将指定每个注释都有“创建日期”、“作者”和“正文”。但对于开发人员来说，数据模型指的是一组不同的、更具技术性的定义，他们用来在代码级别存储和检索数据。用开发人员的话说，设计团队所说的数据模型实际上是内容模型。

The Chandler universe was rife with this sort of word overlap. The design team kept using the term data model to refer to the list of definitions of data types that the user would encounter along with all the attributes associated with that data type. For example, the data model would specify that every note had a “date created,” an “author,” and a “body text.” But to the developers, data model referred to a different, more technical set of definitions that they used to store and retrieve data at the level of their code. What the design team called the data model was really, in the developers’ vocabulary, the content model.

然后就是计划任务这个词的问题。在设计领域，计划任务是指用户待办事项列表中分配了日期和时间的项目。但对于开发人员来说，计划任务是钱德勒自己被告知在特定时间执行的任务，例如下载电子邮件或检查共享信息的更改。或者考虑术语“事件通知”。对于设计师来说，这意味着告诉用户新邮件已到达；对于开发人员来说，事件是代码对象状态的一些变化，例如窗口关闭或菜单项的单击，而通知意味着将该变化的消息发送到其他代码对象。

Then there was the problem with the term scheduled task. In the design world a scheduled task meant an item on a user’s to-do list that had a date and time assigned to it. But for the developers a scheduled task was something that Chandler itself had been told to perform at a particular time, such as download email or check for changes in shared information. Or consider the term event notification. For the designers this meant things like telling the user that new mail had arrived; for the developers an event was some change in the status of a code object, like a window closing or a click on a menu item, and notification meant sending news of that change to other code objects.

卡普尔会观察到这些小小的语言列车残骸并感到不寒而栗。“我们需要说一种语言，”他会说。“我们都应该说钱德勒语。我们必须修复词汇。”

Kapor would observe these little linguistic train wrecks and shudder. “We need to speak one language,” he would say. “We should all speak Chandlerese. We have to fix the vocabulary.”

最后，布莱恩·斯金纳挺身而出，试图做到这一点。Skinner 作为志愿者加入 OSAF，并在 Vajda 刚刚尝试启动存储库时帮助 Andi Vajda 和 Katie Parlante 理清了数据模型的微妙之处。现在，Skinner 是一名全职 OSAF 程序员，他擅长向设计师解释开发人员对话以及与开发人员进行设计对话。当小组互相交谈时，他常常是负责整理语言的人。他提议，为什么不在维基上建立一个钱德勒词汇表呢？它将为项目周围的所有术语提供一个单一的、权威的、但易于修改的参考点。它实际上可以让每个人都达成共识。

Finally, Brian Skinner stepped forward to try to do just that. Skinner had joined OSAF as a volunteer and helped Andi Vajda and Katie Parlante sort out the subtleties of the data model back when Vajda was just trying to get the repository started. Now a full-time OSAF programmer, Skinner had a knack for explaining developer-speak to the designers and design-talk to the developers. When the groups talked past each other, he was often the one to sort out the language. Why not, he proposed, set up a Chandler glossary on the wiki? It would provide a single, authoritative, but easily amended reference point for all the terminology floating around the project. It could literally get everyone on the same page.

斯金纳拿起武器对抗模棱两可的海洋。他制作了数十页词汇表。他建立了一个系统，可以从维基百科的其他部分链接到它们。

Skinner took up arms against the sea of ambiguity. He produced dozens of glossary pages. He built a system for linking to them from the rest of the wiki.

这是一次英勇的努力，但似乎并没有多大作用。一方面，这些术语的使用变化速度比他的维基编辑跟上的速度还要快。更重要的是，开发人员已经被电子邮件、错误报告和 wiki 页面淹没，他们似乎并没有太多关注术语表，而且这些页面也变得萎靡不振，大部分都未被阅读。

It was a heroic effort, but it didn’t seem to make much difference. For one thing, usage of the terms continued to change faster than his wiki editing could keep up. More important, the developers, who were already drowning in emails and bug reports and wiki pages, didn’t seem to pay much attention to the glossary, and the pages languished, mostly unread.

斯金纳参与的另一次命名工作的结果可能预示着该术语表的徒劳。OSAF 的霍华德街总部有六间会议室，卡普尔认为给它们起个名字会很有用，这样就不用说“我们在唐恩办公桌拐角处的小会议室见面”，你可以只需说出房间的名称即可。OSAF 举办了一场竞赛并向员工征集建议。斯金纳建议使用来自想象中的地方的名字；他赢得了比赛，并捐出了 150 美元的奖金，资助他的同事在街边的爱尔兰酒吧 Kate O'Brien's 度过欢乐时光。

The glossary’s futility might have been foreshadowed by the outcome of another naming effort in which Skinner participated. OSAF’s Howard Street headquarters had a half-dozen conference rooms, and Kapor decided that it would be useful for them to have names, so that instead of saying, “Let’s meet in the little conference room around the corner from Donn’s desk,” you could just say the room’s name. OSAF held a contest and solicited proposals from the staff. Skinner suggested using names from imaginary places; he won the contest and ponied up his $150 prize to fund a happy hour for his colleagues at Kate O’Brien’s, the Irish bar down the street.

这些奇特的名字——两个主要会议室是阿瓦隆和阿卡迪亚——抓住了 OSAF 的精神，想象新世界是这里的集体待办事项之一。直到后来，每个人都意识到让最常用的房间的名称以同一个字母开头是多么糟糕的主意：没有人能记住哪个是哪个。

The fanciful names—the two main conference rooms were Avalon and Arcadia—captured the spirit at OSAF, where imagining new worlds was on the collective to-do list. It was only later that everyone realized what a bad idea it was to have the names of the most frequently used rooms start with the same letter: No one could ever remember which was which.





在一幅漫画中，你可以在不止一个程序员的网站上找到——而且，我敢打赌，在世界各地的软件公司的小隔间的墙上——呆伯特，这个世界上最受欢迎的受压迫的极客，对他的主管（著名的尖头发老板）说，或 PHB），“我们仍然有太多的软件故障。我们会错过我们的发货日期。” PHB回复：“将故障列表移至‘未来发展’栏并发送。” 在最后一个窗口中，PHB 对自己感到满意，他想：“这项工作的 90% 就是弄清楚如何称呼东西。”

In a cartoon that you can find on more than one programmer’s Web site—and, I would bet, on the walls of cubicles in software companies everywhere—Dilbert, the world’s favorite downtrodden geek, says to his supervisor (the celebrated Pointy-Haired Boss, or PHB), “We still have too many software faults. We’ll miss our ship date.” The PHB replies, “Move the list of faults to the ‘future development’ column and ship it.” In the final window, the PHB, pleased with himself, thinks: “Ninety percent of this job is figuring out what to call stuff.”





正如极客喜欢说的那样，程序员为其抽象所采用的名称“不平凡”。在软件中，标签和名称很重要；它们是你抓东西的把手。

The names programmers adopt for their abstractions are, as geeks like to say, “nontrivial.” In software, labels and names matter; they are the handles by which you grab things.

婴儿通过将声音与可见的物理对象联系起来来扩展他们的词汇量，超越“妈妈”和“爸爸”；我们指向某物并重复它的名字。教孩子们理解更抽象的单词的含义要困难得多。我们试图用一个词来解释另一个词，或者我们讲一个故事。

Infants expanding their vocabulary beyond “Mama” and “Dada” learn by associating sounds with visible physical objects; we point to something and repeat its name. Teaching children the meaning of more abstract words is a lot harder; we try to explain one word in terms of another, or we tell a story.

除了用户界面的窗口和文本之外，软件的大多数元素都是无形且不可见的。没有什么可指出的。所以谈论它们出乎意料地困难。这就是白板在任何使用软件的空间中如此具有标志性存在的原因之一。它提供了一个画布，用于展示复杂程序的抽象过程，使人们能够指出他们正在谈论的内容。

Beyond the windows and text of a user interface, most elements of software are incorporeal and invisible. There is nothing to point to. So talking about them is unexpectedly difficult. This is one reason the whiteboard is such an iconic presence in any space where software is labored over; it provides a canvas for laying out the abstract processes of a complex program in ways that allow people to point to what they’re talking about.

程序员在新程序中面临的首要任务之一是为程序将使用的变量和对象选择标签。变量是程序在计算机内存中留出一个位置来放置一些信息的方式。稍后，它将能够通过寻址（通过调用其名称）来检索该信息，即变量的值。

One of the first tasks a programmer faces with a new program is choosing labels for the variables and objects the program will use. A variable is a program’s way of setting aside a spot in the computer’s memory where it can put some information. Later, it will be able to retrieve that information, the variable’s value, by addressing it—by calling out its name.

机器内存要求变量名和内存地址之间一一对应。相比之下，人类的记忆是层次丰富且重叠的。它的密度和无边界性激发了预感并激发了直觉。但大脑的这一功能却成为了数字机器中的一个缺陷。如果由于错误或不良的编程习惯，两个程序尝试使用计算机内存中的同一位置来存储变量，则肯定会出现不可预测且不稳定的结果（计算机通常会死机或崩溃）。软件厌恶歧义。

Machine memory demands a one-to-one correspondence between variable name and memory address. Human memory, by contrast, is richly layered and overlapping; its density and boundarylessness fuels hunches and sparks intuition. But this feature of the brain becomes a bug in the digital machine. If, thanks to errors or bad programming practices, two programs try to use the same location in the computer’s memory to store a variable, unpredictable and unstable results are guaranteed (the computer will usually freeze or crash). Software abhors ambiguity.

人类仍然比计算机更有能力从上下文中读取线索并找出模糊信号最可能的含义。但如果我们期望计算机能够理解我们，我们通常必须事先解决任何歧义。不要要求计算机（即使是擅长手写识别的计算机）来区分潦草的字母“O”和零。（老式计算机终端过去常常打印出带有斜线的零，以帮助区分。）“消歧”一词在计算文化需要发明它之前并不存在。

Human beings remain far more capable than computers of reading clues from contexts and teasing out the most likely meaning of an ambiguous signal. But if we expect computers to understand us, we typically have to sort out any ambiguities beforehand. Don’t ask a computer, even one adept at handwriting recognition, to distinguish between a scribbled letter “O” and a zero. (Old-fashioned computer terminals used to print out zeros with a slash through them to help make the distinction.) The word disambiguate did not exist before the culture of computing needed to invent it.

因此，当程序员坐下来执行几乎符合圣经的行为来命名程序的所有变量时，他们必须致力于保持含义清晰和离散。许多开发人员都在“让我们假设. 。。” 粗略原型设计阶段从通用替代名称foo和bar 开始。这些标签的起源存在争议，尽管它们很可能源自旧军队缩写词 FUBAR（搞砸了或弄脏了，无法识别/修复/理性/救赎）。但迟早，这些无意义的占位符必须让位给能够传达信息的真实变量名称，例如 AccountHolderID 或 LastDateModified。

When programmers sit down to perform the almost biblical act of naming all of a program’s variables, they must therefore aim to keep meanings clear and discrete. Many developers in the “let’s suppose that . . . ” stage of rough prototyping begin with the all-purpose stand-in names foo and bar. The origin of these labels is in dispute, though most likely they derive from the old army acronym FUBAR (Fucked Up—or Fouled Up—Beyond All Recognition/Repair/Reason/Redemption). Sooner or later, though, these meaningless placeholders must give way to real variable names that communicate things, like AccountHolderID or LastDateModified.

精心选择的名称可以避免“命名空间冲突”或“冲突”的混乱——使用的术语在一种上下文中表示一种事物，但在另一种上下文中表示另一种事物。维基发明者沃德​​·坎宁安（Ward Cunningham）甚至建议程序员在办公桌上放一本同义词库。他在 2004 年的一次演讲中指出，如何选择名字很重要，“因为人们会读这些名字。他们的第一个猜测是，你知道，这个物体就是它所说的那样。但通常情况并不完全像它所说的那样。” 当程序员开始工作时，名称的含义是一回事，一旦修复了一千个错误，名称就会变得不同。坎宁安敦促程序员回去修改他们的名字，但承认大多数人都懒得这么做。

Carefully chosen names avoid the confusion of “namespace clashes” or “collisions”—the use of a term that means one thing in one context but something else in another. Wiki inventor Ward Cunningham even suggests that programmers keep a thesaurus on their desks. How you choose names matters, he argued in a 2004 talk, “because people read these names. And their first guess is that, you know, the object is what it says it is. But usually it isn’t quite what it says it is.” Names that meant one thing when the programmer’s work began end up meaning something different once a thousand bugs have been fixed. Cunningham urged programmers to go back and fix their names—but admitted that most don’t bother.

对变量和软件对象命名的严格性的追求几乎与计算机编程本身一样古老。早期，计算机内存中的可用空间非常少，优秀的程序员学会通过缩写变量名来节省空间。将某些内容命名为memloc而不是存储位置确实很重要，特别是当变量的名称可能在程序代码中重复数百次时。

The quest for rigor in the naming of variables and software objects is almost as old as computer programming itself. In the early days, there was so little space available in the computer’s memory that good programmers learned to conserve it by abbreviating their variable names. It really made a difference to name something memloc rather than memory location, particularly when a variable’s name might be repeated hundreds of times in a program’s code.

最著名、也是最臭名昭著的变量命名方案是匈牙利表示法。它的名字来源于其发明者查尔斯·西蒙尼 (Charles Simonyi) 的母语，但也来自于它所产生的往往神秘且难以发音的标签，西蒙尼在微软的同事认为这些标签看起来有点陌生。在匈牙利表示法中，程序员在每个变量名称后附加一个前缀，为任何阅读代码的人提供关于变量类型的重要线索。西蒙尼作为施乐公司的研究员开发了有史以来第一个图形界面文字处理器，后来成为 Microsoft Word 之父，现在是世界上使用最广泛的书写软件，他的匈牙利符号惯例成为微软的内部风格。多年来，匈牙利语的捍卫者认为它有助于提高代码的可读性，但其批评者却坚持认为它将代码变成了官样文章。后来加入 OSAF 的 Netscape 程序员 Alec Flett 在邮件列表中贡献了这段戏仿：

The most famous, and infamous, scheme for naming variables is Hungarian notation. It takes its name from the native language of its inventor, Charles Simonyi, but also from the often cryptic and unpronounceable labels it produces, which Simonyi’s colleagues at Microsoft thought looked vaguely foreign. In Hungarian notation, the programmer appends a prefix to every variable name that gives anyone reading the code important clues about what sort of variable it is. Simonyi, who had developed the first ever graphic-interface word processor as a researcher at Xerox, became the father of Microsoft Word, now the world’s most widely used writing software, and his Hungarian notation convention became the house style at Microsoft. Over the years, Hungarian’s defenders have argued that it helps make code readable, but its detractors have maintained that it turns code into gobbledygook. Alec Flett, a Netscape programmer who later joined OSAF, contributed this parody to a mailing list:



prepBut nI vrbLike adj匈牙利语！q什么是艺术The adjBig nProblem？

prepBut nI vrbLike adjHungarian! qWhat's artThe adjBig nProblem?



鉴于命名约定的目的是为了使编写代码的行为更加清晰，它遭受了源自西蒙尼为解释它而写的第一篇论文中的严重歧义，这似乎是残酷的讽刺。事实证明，匈牙利表示法有两种不同的含义。构建 Microsoft Windows 的程序员所使用的匈牙利语（后来被称为“Systems Hungarian”）与 Simonyi 最初向 Word 程序员颁布的匈牙利语（今天的坚持者称之为“Apps Hungarian”）不同。当 Simonyi 说变量应该根据“类型”进行标记时，系统匈牙利人将他解释为大多数编程语言要求您为变量选择的“类型”（整数、浮点、字符串）。但Apps Hungarian，真正的匈牙利语，在更宽松、更日常的意义上意味着“类型”，鼓励您传达有关每个变量的更多信息，这些信息可能对程序员阅读代码实际上有用。

Given that the point of the naming convention was to add clarity to the act of writing code, it seems cruelly ironic that it suffered from a critical ambiguity originating in the first paper that Simonyi wrote to explain it. Hungarian notation, it turns out, means two different things. The Hungarian the programmers who built Microsoft Windows used, which came to be known as Systems Hungarian, was not the same Hungarian Simonyi had originally promulgated to the programmers of Word, which sticklers today call Apps Hungarian. When Simonyi said variables should be labeled according to “type,” the Systems Hungarian people interpreted him to mean the same sort of “type” that most programming languages required you to choose for your variable (integer, floating-point, string). But Apps Hungarian, true Hungarian, meant “type” in a looser, more everyday sense, encouraging you to communicate more information about each variable that might actually be useful to a programmer reading the code.

在此过程中，微软热心的项目经理误解了、忽视或驳回了西蒙尼的意图。结果，匈牙利人不得不——借用开源程序员这个词来形容一个遭受分裂的项目——分叉。所以你可能用匈牙利语编码，我也可能用匈牙利语编码，我们的代码可能永远不会连接。

Somewhere along the line, Microsoft’s zealous program managers had misunderstood, or ignored or dismissed, Simonyi’s intent. As a result, Hungarian had—to borrow the word open source programmers apply to a project that has suffered a schism—forked. So you could be coding in Hungarian and I could be coding in Hungarian and our code might never connect.





从程序员到机器、从程序员到程序员、从程序到用户，明确地传达抽象是软件开发中最具挑战性的需求。程序员和非程序员如何避免巴别塔惨败？有些代码编写者已经非常精细地磨练了自己以极其精确的语法直接与机器对话的能力，以至于他们失去了简单的、设身处地为他人着想的同理心，而这种同理心是维持人类对话的基础。追踪。如果你把这样的程序员派到与他们的同事一起的房间里，并告诉他们在就词汇达成一致之前不要出来，你可能再也见不到他们了。

Communicating abstractions unambiguously—from programmer to machine, from programmer to programmer, and from program to user—is the single most challenging demand of software development. How can programmers and nonprogrammers avoid a Tower-of-Babel fiasco? There are some writers of code who have so finely honed their ability to talk directly to the machine in its unforgivingly precise syntax that they have lost the simple, put-yourself-in-the-other-person’s-shoes empathy that keeps human conversation on track. If you were to send such programmers to a room with their colleagues and tell them not to come out until they have agreed on a vocabulary, you might never see them again.

OSAF 的开发人员通常属于程序员中社交能力较强的一端，但他们仍然经常遇到“同一个词，不同含义”的问题。如果你真的很幸运，你可能会遇到一两个富有想象力、有耐心、愿意倾听的开发人员，他们可能会在产品开发或设计方面找到志同道合的人，他们在一起可能会消除足够多的模糊不清的问题。 -术语灌木丛，以揭示一些共同点并解决一些难题。在 OSAF，类似的事情发生了，Donn Denman 和 Mimi Yin 挤在一起讨论细节视图规范的细节，讨论每个小图标和交互，直到他们到达 Denman 可以开始编码的程度。

OSAF’s developers were typically on the more socially skilled end of the programmer spectrum, and still they constantly tripped over the “same word, different meaning” problem. If you’re really lucky, you might get a developer or two with imagination, a patient temperament, and a willingness to listen who might find a kindred spirit on the product development or design side, and together they might clear away enough of the ambiguous-terminology underbrush to bare some common ground and resolve some hard questions. At OSAF something like that happened as Donn Denman and Mimi Yin huddled to hash out the minutiae of the detail view spec, talking over each little icon and interaction until they got to the point where Denman could begin coding.





五月底的一天，丹曼把尹拉到办公桌前，指着屏幕上排列的有色矩形。去掉文字标签，你可能看到的是蒙德里安的作品。他们开始讨论如何为“项目对话”功能设计界面，该功能允许用户向共享项目添加简短注释。然后尹停下来，盯着丹曼的屏幕。“等一下。你的意思是这是直播？”

One day at the end of May, Denman pulled Yin over to his desk and pointed to an arrangement of tinted rectangles on his screen. Strip out the text labels, and you might have been looking at a Mondrian. They started discussing how to shape the interface for a feature called “item conversations,” which would allow users to append brief notes to a shared item. Then Yin stopped and stared at Denman’s screen. “Wait a second. You mean this is live?”

“是的，在钱德勒，”丹曼回答道。

“Yeah, it’s in Chandler,” Denman answered.

“凉爽的！我以为这只是一个图像。”

“Cool! I thought it was just an image.”

“不。我喜欢在这里看到东西！首先，我得到一个总体布局，然后开始进行连接，以便字段是真实的，并且按钮开始执行操作。”

“No. I love seeing stuff up here! First I get a general layout and then I start wiring things up so that the fields are real and the buttons start to do things.”

一周后，丹曼在周四的会议上向 OSAF 全体工作人员展示了同一屏幕。“这些是占位符，”他说。“这并不是真正构建的东西的演示；它只是一个演示。” 这是要构建的东西的演示。在一段时间内，我们会遇到一些有效但看起来不正确的东西，或者看起来正确但不起作用的东西。”

A week later Denman showed the same screen to the entire OSAF staff at the Thursday meeting. “These are placeholders,” he said. “This isn’t really a demo of stuff that’s built; it’s a demo of stuff that’s to be built. For a while we’ll have this mishmash of things that work but don’t look right, or things that look right but don’t work.”

在接下来的一个月里，Denman 与存储库程序员 Andi Vajda 和 Ted Leung 合作，找出了如何扩展存储库的功能以使标记成为可能。Yin 和设计团队将大部分工作重点放在他们认为最有可能的标记情况上：传入的电子邮件被标记为日历事件或任务；普通便笺会被标记为电子邮件、日历事件或任务。但程序员总是在考虑“边缘情况”，并且不可避免地，Denman 和他的同事构建的用于实现标记的系统最终成为一种通用解决方案 - 旨在允许您将任何类型的项目作为任何其他项目进行标记种类。他们设计了一个新概念，称为“混合类”。混合类型定义了与类型相关的一组属性；对于任务，它们可能包括“优先级”和“完成状态”。如果您有一个电子邮件项目并将其标记为任务，那么存储库现在只需将这组新属性添加到电子邮件已有的属性中（例如“发件人”和“主题行”）。不可避免地会出现“命名空间冲突”：简单的属性“日期”在电子邮件上下文中可能意味着一件事（收到日期），而在任务上下文中可能意味着另一件事（截止日期或完成日期）。如果您的老板向您发送了一封有关与客户会面的电子邮件，并且您将其标记为日历事件，则该电子邮件的“谁”（您的老板）与该事件的“谁”（客户）不同。钱德勒的后端可以消除这些日期和人物的歧义，但程序仍然必须选择向用户显示哪一个。丹曼的方法并没有解决所有这些问题，只是足以让某些东西运行起来。

For the next month Denman worked with Andi Vajda and Ted Leung, the repository programmers, and figured out how to expand the repository’s capabilities to make stamping possible. Yin and the design team had focused most of their work on what they saw as the most likely cases of stamping: An incoming email gets stamped as a calendar event or a task; a plain note gets stamped as an email, a calendar event, or a task. But programmers are always thinking about “edge cases,” and, inevitably, the system Denman and his colleagues built to implement stamping ended up as a generalized solution—one intended to allow you to stamp an item of any kind as an item of any other kind. They devised a new concept called the “mix-in kind.” A mix-in kind defined a set of attributes associated with a kind; for a task they might include “Priority” and “Done Status.” If you had an item that was an email and you stamped it as a task, the repository would now simply add this new set of attributes to those the email already had (like “sender” and “subject line”). There were, inevitably, “namespace collisions”: The simple attribute “date” could mean one thing in the context of an email (date received) and another in the context of a task (date due or date completed). If your boss sends you an email about a meeting with a client, and you stamp that as a calendar event, the “who” for the email (your boss) is different from the “who” for the event (the client). Chandler’s back end could disambiguate those dates and whos, but the program would still have to pick which one to display to the user. Denman’s approach didn’t solve all these problems, just enough of them to get something running.

7 月初，Denman 和一些 Apps Group 开发人员聚集在阿卡迪亚（或者是 Avalon？）的投影仪周围，对 Denman 的冲压工作进行代码审查。代码审查一词可以指任何事物，从非正式的监控端聊天到涉及多层代码检查的长达数周的官僚主义挑战。OSAF 一直采取相当宽松的方法，但开发人员最近都同意以进行更多代码审查为目标；冲压足够新颖和复杂，使其看起来是引起注意的不错选择。

In early July, Denman and a few Apps Group developers gathered around the projector in Arcadia (or was it Avalon?) for a code review of Denman’s stamping work. The term code review can mean anything from an informal monitor-side chat to a weeks-long bureaucratic gantlet involving multiple layers of code inspection. OSAF had always taken a fairly loose approach, but the developers had recently all agreed to aim for more code reviews; stamping was sufficiently novel and complex to make it seem like a good choice for the attention.

丹曼概述了“混合”的概念，并回顾了一些棘手的案例。“当我们收到电子邮件时，重要的日期是收到的日期。当我们将其标记为事件时，重要的日期是事件的日期。所以我设置了一个 hack 来解决这个问题。” 他向下滚动屏幕，投影仪显示出新的代码块。“抱歉，这件事太曲折了。” 更多代码滚滚而来。“自己的阶级发生了变化。我在这里添加了一个存储库提交[存储数据的状态]，这样我们就会记住我们有这种新的类型。。。。如果我能弄清楚我的新类型是什么，我就会分配它。否则，我会使用 Andi 的 mix-ins。” 屏幕上的下一个 Python 块定义了 NewStampedKind。“这是一种粗糙的黑客代码，基本上是为了查看是否已经存在一种与混合后现在组装的属性相匹配的类型。”

Denman outlined the concept of “mix-ins” and reviewed some of the tricky cases. “When we receive an email, the date that’s important is the date it’s received. When we stamp it as an event, the date that’s important is the date of the event. So I’ve put in a hack to deal with this.” He scrolled down the screen, and the projector displayed new chunks of code. “I’m sorry this is so tortuous.” More code rolled by. “Self’s class has changed. I threw in a repository commit [storing the data’s state] here so we’d remember we have this new kind . . . . If I can figure out what my new kind is, I assign it. Otherwise, I use Andi’s mix-ins.” The next chunk of Python on screen defined NewStampedKind. “This is crufty hack code that basically looks to see if there’s already a kind that matches the bunch of attributes that are now assembled after the mix-in.”

我无法假装听懂丹曼所说的一切。作为局外人参与代码审查就像偷听任何专业的行话；你总是无法说出问题的症结所在。尽管如此，我还是明白丹曼的代码通过让钱德勒变得更加灵活来解决了冲压问题。现在，它可以简单地通过查看项目的属性集来识别项目的种类，并且可以将项目转换为新的种类，而不会丢失项目先前存在的任何属性数据。

I couldn’t pretend to follow everything Denman was saying. Sitting in on a code review as an outsider is like eavesdropping on specialist shoptalk of any stripe; you can’t always tell what the crux of the matter is. Still, I understood that Denman’s code had tackled the stamping problem by making Chandler a little nimbler; it could now identify an item’s kind simply by looking at its set of attributes, and it could transform the item into a new kind without losing any of the attribute data from the item’s previous existence.

我也理解丹曼认为结果还需要做很多工作。

I also understood that Denman felt the result still needed a lot of work.

丹曼说完后，约翰·安德森抬起头来。“我需要一些时间让它在我的脑海中滚动。很棒，但看起来很复杂。我的直觉告诉我们我们可以解决这个问题。”

John Anderson looked up as Denman finished. “I need some time to let it roll around in my head. It’s great, but it seems complicated. My intuition says we could get around this.”

这种方法很复杂，但它有一个压倒性的优点：一周后——距离丹曼开始在 OSAF 工作大约十周——冲压开始发挥作用。这可能只是第一次，可能会遇到一些障碍，但它已经启动并正在运行。丹曼在下周四的员工会议上演示了它。

The approach was complex, but it had one overriding virtue: One week later—about ten weeks from the time Denman had started at OSAF—stamping was working. It might only have been a first pass and might have had some snags, but it was up and running. Denman demoed it at the next Thursday staff meeting.

“这非常简单明了，”他说，点击着他仍然是新的细节视图。“现在我们可以在盖章时更改物品的类型。” 他在《钱德勒》中展示了一张贴有“神奇食谱”标签的纸条。“这从一个注释开始。您可以通过按小任务按钮来决定将其设为任务。您可以看到一些属性现在已经更改，现在有请求者和被请求者字段。我们现在可以标记三样东西：任务、日历项和邮件对象，并且您可以将这些东西组合起来。理论上，当出现新类型的内容项时，您也可以对它们进行标记。您可以在照片上标记“邮寄”，它将获得邮件属性，然后您可以邮寄它。

“It’s pretty simple and straightforward,” he said, clicking around his still new detail view. “Now we can change the kind of an item when we stamp it.” He displayed a note in Chandler labeled Fantastic Recipe. “This starts out as a note. You can decide to make it a task by pressing the little task thing. And you can see that some of the attributes have now changed, it now has requester and requestee fields. There are three things we can stamp now: a task, a calendar item, and a mail object—and you can have combinations of these things. In theory, when new kinds of content items show up, you can stamp them, too. You could stamp a photo with ‘mailness,’ it will get mail attributes, and you can mail it.

“这是一个基本概念——事物可以发生同样的变化。大部分工作不是我做的。这是存储库中的 Andi。该项目不会更改其 ID。这是同一个物体，但它已经进化了。当您更改类型时，它会四处查找是否有与该类型匹配的属性。如果找到它们，就会应用它们。如果它找不到任何匹配的东西，它就会动态创建一个新的类型。”

“This is a fundamental concept—that things can change in kind. I’m not doing most of the work. It’s Andi in the repository. The item doesn’t change its ID. It’s the same object, but it has evolved. When you change a kind, it goes and looks around to find if there are attributes that match the kind. If it finds them, it applies them. If it can’t find anything that matches, it creates a new kind on the fly.”

演示在一片掌声中结束，卡普尔微笑着发言。除了共享之外，踩踏也是 OSAF 道路上最大的蛇。就算不是直接斩杀，现在显然已经得到了很好的控制。筒仓正在倒塌！但他们还有很长的路要走。

The demo ended in a burst of applause, and Kapor, smiling, spoke up. Aside from sharing, stamping had been the biggest snake in OSAF’s road. If not slain outright, it was plainly well under control now. The silos were toppling! But they still had far to go.

“整个用户界面都有与冲压相关的功能——我们可能已经实现了其中的百分之一，”卡普尔说。“当我们实现这一目标时，它将成为与所有其他 PIM 真正不同的功能之一。东西会进来，你点击它们，它们就会出现在正确的地方。这将是一个不同的水平，人们会说，当然，这就是它应该如何运作！为什么不是一切都这样呢？我们的成功将取决于我们为人们重构问题的能力。”

“There are stamping-related features throughout the UI—we’ve implemented maybe one percent of them,” Kapor said. “When we pull this off, it will be one of the really distinctive features from all other PIMs. Things will come in, you’ll click on them, and they’ll show up in the right place. It will be a different level, and people will say, of course, that’s how it should work! Why doesn’t everything work that way? Our success will be measured by how well we reframe the question for people.”





最近，卡普尔重新提出了一些更私人的问题：他对 OSAF 的忠诚度有多深？他想在那里做什么工作？

Recently, Kapor had reframed some more personal questions: How deeply was he committed to OSAF? And what job did he want there?

自 2003 年 11 月 Michael Toy 离职以来，他不仅担任产品愿景的守护者和 Agenda 灵魂的保护者，而且还担任设计和开发的实际经理。一开始，当他的团队摆脱了 0.2 的低迷并获得更多关注时，他发现这个角色令人振奋。但随着时间的推移，工作量不断扩大，特别是新的开发人员突然加入该项目。布莱恩·基尔希 (Brian Kirsch) 是一位兼职音乐家的年轻程序员，他签约编写钱德勒的电子邮件代码。David Surovell 是一位苹果资深人士，他致力于为 Chandler 改进 wxWidgets 的各个方面，特别是在 Mac 方面。开源日历标准领域的领导者 Lisa Dusseault 将与 Katie Parlante 共同管理不断壮大的程序员队伍。

Since Michael Toy’s departure in November 2003, he had been serving not only as keeper of the product vision and protector of the soul of Agenda, but also as the hands-on manager of design and development. At the beginning, as his team broke out of the 0.2 doldrums and got more traction, he found the role invigorating. But as the months progressed, the volume of work kept expanding, particularly with new developers joining the project at a clip. Brian Kirsch, a young programmer who moonlighted as a musician, signed on to write Chandler’s email code. David Surovell, an Apple veteran, would work on improving aspects of wxWidgets for Chandler, particularly on the Mac side. And Lisa Dusseault, a leader in the world of open source calendar standards, would share managing the growing crew of programmers with Katie Parlante.

需要卡普尔出席的会议越来越多，他在这些会议上的呼气声也越来越大、越来越频繁。他会用手做出“T”表示“暂停”的手势。“对不起。我正在经历缓冲区溢出，”他承认，房间里的每个极客都明白他的意思：有更多的事情向我袭来，我无法应对。他不是那种会发脾气的老板。这使他与大多数其他科技行业巨头区分开来（比尔·盖茨的脾气是传奇，史蒂夫·乔布斯的脾气也是传奇）。在 OSAF 的三年里，我只听到他提高嗓门几次，然后总是迅速道歉。但到了 2004 年春天，他的耐心明显消失了。

The number of meetings at which Kapor’s presence was required grew, and his audible exhalations at those meetings grew louder and more frequent. He would make a “T” for “time-out” sign with his hands. “Sorry. I’m experiencing buffer overflow,” he would confess, and every geek in the room understood what he meant: There’s more coming at me than I can handle. He wasn’t the sort of boss to lose his temper; that set him apart from most other tech industry titans (Bill Gates’s tantrums are the stuff of legend, and so are Steve Jobs’s). In my three years at OSAF, I heard him raise his voice only a handful of times, always followed by a swift apology. But in the spring of 2004 his patience was plainly fraying.

与此同时，2004 年选举周期的加快也将他的注意力转移到了其他方向。自由党对击败乔治·W·布什总统的希望很高——受到新兴在线社区、博客和 MoveOn 等组织新生的组织和筹款力量的鼓舞。卡普尔喜欢从长远的角度看待“数字民主”的前景，但他情不自禁地陷入了当下的精神：他创建了一个名为 Of、By 和 For 的新政治团体博客，并帮助推出了一个新的开源软件名为 CivicSpace 的在线社区组织项目，无论选举结果如何，其软件都会继续存在。

At the same time his attention was being pulled in other directions by the revving up of the 2004 election cycle. Liberal hopes for defeating President George W. Bush were high—stoked by the nascent organizing and fund-raising power of emerging online communities, blogs, and organizations like MoveOn. Kapor liked to take the long view on prospects for “digital democracy,” but he couldn’t help getting caught up in the moment’s spirit: He started a new political group blog called Of, By and For, and helped launch a new open source project for online community organizing called CivicSpace, whose software would live on, whatever the election’s outcome.

很长一段时间以来，卡普尔和他在 OSAF 的许多同事一样，养成了每天花几分钟查看 wiki 上最近变化的习惯。要查看这些内容，您可以访问网页、通过电子邮件发送列表或通过 RSS 源接收信息。该系统并不完美，它会报告有人是否完全修改了页面或只是更改了逗号的更新，但这是跟上不断扩大和日益分散的钱德勒团队的合理方式。然而，到了 5 月中旬，随着变化的步伐加快，Donn Denman 在详细视图方面的工作使 wiki 中充满了一页又一页的规范详细信息，Kapor 突然感到不知所措。

For a long time Kapor, like many of his colleagues at OSAF, had made it a custom to spend a few minutes each day reviewing recent changes on the wiki. To see these you could visit a Web page, have a list emailed to you, or receive the information via an RSS feed. The system wasn’t perfect—it would report an update whether someone had totally revised a page or just altered a comma—but it was a reasonable way to keep up with the expanding and increasingly far-flung Chandler team. In mid-May, though, as the pace of changes picked up and Donn Denman’s work on the detail view filled the wiki with page after page of specification details, Kapor suddenly felt overwhelmed.

他创办 OSAF 的部分原因是他相信开源的理想，但也因为在担任风险投资家之后，他意识到设计软件是他的使命。然而，随着钱德勒的日程安排越来越陷入软件时代，其完成日期像沙漠海市蜃楼一样逐渐消失，外界和内部人士都想知道他对保持该项目的进展有多大的决心。

He had started OSAF partly because he believed in the ideals of open source, but also because, after his stint as a venture capitalist, he realized that designing software was his calling. Yet as Chandler’s schedule grew more and more mired in software time, its completion date receding like a desert mirage, outsiders and insiders alike wondered how committed he was to keeping the project going.

当卡普尔于 2002 年 10 月宣布建立 OSAF 时，他自己拨出了 500 万美元来支持该项目。2003年，该基金会获得了梅隆基金会和Common Solutions Group（大学技术部门联盟）的额外支持，总额达275万美元。随着名册不断增加（到 2004 年 5 月大约有 20 名员工，计划增加到 30 名员工），这笔钱将持续一段时间，但不会永远持续下去。

When he announced OSAF in October 2002, Kapor had earmarked $5 million of his own money to support it. In 2003, the foundation received additional support from the Mellon Foundation and the Common Solutions Group, a coalition of university technology departments, totaling $2.75 million. With a growing roster (roughly two dozen by May 2004, and a plan to staff up to thirty), that money would last a while longer, but not forever.

现金通常是软件行业的最终约束，是将项目从软件时代的虫洞中拉回现实的限制。但卡普尔有很多。如果 OSAF 需要更多，每个人都认为他会提供——只要他对钱德勒保持热情。科技专家埃丝特·戴森 (Esther Dyson) 曾开玩笑说，卡普尔上世纪九十年代初的公司 On Technology 是“含着金汤匙出生的”。OSAF 的勺子或许只是镀银的，但对于一个开源项目来说，任何形式的继承都是不寻常的。

Cash is typically the software industry’s ultimate constraint, the limit that yanks projects out of software time’s wormhole back to reality. But Kapor had plenty of it. If OSAF needed more, everyone assumed he would provide it—as long as he remained enthusiastic about Chandler. Esther Dyson, the technology pundit, had once joked that Kapor’s company from the early nineties, On Technology, was “born with a silver spoon in its mouth.” OSAF’s spoon, perhaps, was merely silver-plated, but for an open source project, any kind of inheritance was unusual.

当人们直接询问卡普尔对 OSAF 的承诺时，他会回答：“这就是我余生想做的事情。” 他还指出，他和妻子刚刚签署了一项新的长期租约，将他们的联合业务扩大到霍华德街大楼的二楼，为 OSAF 的发展提供了空间，也为他们想要纳入旗下的其他组织提供了空间。

When people asked Kapor directly about his commitment to OSAF, he would answer, “This is what I want to do for the rest of my life.” And he would point to the new long-term lease he and his wife had just signed expanding their combined operation to a second floor in the Howard Street building, providing room for OSAF to grow and space for other organizations they wanted to take under their wings.

但毫无疑问他遇到了危机。他的工作乐趣已经消失：“就像水一夜之间变成了冰，”他后来告诉他的员工。“相变。” 他不会放弃，但他必须做点什么。他和他的妻子商量了这件事。她有一个想法：为什么不要求 OSAF 的其他经理重新设计你的工作呢？

But there was no question he had hit a crisis. The fun had drained out of his work: “It was like water turning to ice overnight,” he later told his staff. “A phase change.” He wouldn’t quit, but he had to do something. He talked it over with his wife. She had an idea: Why not ask the rest of the managers at OSAF to redesign your job?

5 月 18 日，就在每周二例行经理会议之前，卡普尔发送了一封主题为“其他问题”的电子邮件：

On May 18, right before the regular weekly Tuesday managers’ meeting, Kapor sent around an email with the subject line “Additional issue”:



我爱 OSAF。我致力于其长期成功。我们将在 4 楼再移动 10,000 英尺。

I love OSAF. I'm committed to its long-term success. We're taking another 10,000 feet on the 4th floor.

我们正处于该项目的拐点。我能感觉到。现在发生了很多事情，在现有员工的基础上增加了许多富有成效的新员工，并且真正专注于制作可工作的产品，以至于我以前的掌控一切的方法现在完全不够了。新的管理方法是必要的。

We're at an inflection point in the project. I can feel it. There's so much going on now with the addition of many productive new people to existing staff and a real focus on making a working product that my old methods of staying on top of things are now totally inadequate. New management methods are necessary.

。。。现在是时候重新设计我的工作了。我需要你的帮助。显然我做出了一些重要的贡献，但也有一些方面我不是进行某些管理的最佳人选。我妨碍了，或者根本没有带来最好的技能。我想做正确的事。我需要一些帮助。我的感情不会受到伤害。

. . . Now it's time to redesign my job. I need your help. There are obviously major things I've contributed but there are also ways I'm not the best person to do some of the management. I get in the way or am simply not bringing the best skill set. I want to do the right thing. I need some help. My feelings won't be hurt.



卡普尔要求小组在没有他的情况下开会并向他提出一项提案。紧张的几个小时后，他们有了一个计划：米奇应该成为一名全职领导者，而不是一名亲力亲为的经理。他应该“授权”他的经理，给予他们更多自主决策的权力。他们不需要出去雇用一名开发经理，但他们还想做出其他改变来改善组织的结构。Parlante 已经承担了重大工程决策的“架构协调员”的新职责。丽莎·杜索现在将负责开发工作的详细规划和日程安排。

Kapor asked the group to meet without him and present him with a proposal. Several intense hours later they had a plan: Mitch should become more of a full-time leader and less of a hands-on manager. He should “empower” his managers, giving them more authority to make decisions on their own. They didn’t need to go out and hire a single development manager, but there were other changes they wanted to make to improve the organization’s structure. Parlante had already assumed a new mantle as “architecture coordinator” for big engineering decisions; Lisa Dusseault would now take on the detailed planning and scheduling of the development work.

卡普尔很高兴。当同事们向他提出自己的想法时，他对他们说：“我们的意见非常一致。” 一周后，他向全体员工宣布了这个计划，坐在他习惯的座位上，用一个小卷垫垫住他受伤的背部，他的 PowerBook 在他灰白的头发和胡须上投射出凉爽的蓝色光芒。

Kapor was pleased. “We’re in violent agreement,” he told his colleagues when they presented him with their ideas. A week later he announced the plan to the whole staff, seated in his customary perch, a small rolled cushion for his bad back, his PowerBook casting a cool blue glow on his gray hair and beard.

“你应该预料到组织结构将继续定期发展，”他告诉他们，他的眼睛在房间里扫视。“最大的挑战是，我们必须在不失去激情的情况下限制和塑造我们的雄心水平。我晚上失眠的问题是，我们在这方面做得怎么样？我们希望在不剥削人力资源的情况下尽快取得进展。怎样才能走得更快又不杀人呢？如何在不失去设计完整性的情况下围绕项目建立社区？我们如何才能从良性独裁转向更小团体的民主？

“You should expect that the organizational structure is going to continue to evolve periodically,” he told them, his eyes roaming the room. “The big challenge is, we have to constrain and mold our ambition level without losing the spark. The stuff I lose sleep over at night is, how are we doing on this? We want to make progress as fast as possible without exploiting human resources. How do you move faster without killing people? How do you build a community around the project without losing design integrity? And how do we get on an arc that moves from benign dictatorship to more small-group democracy?

“为了完成我们现在需要做的事情，我们已经采取了更多而不是更少的结构。除了我们的透明度之外，它感觉就像一个传统的软件开发项目——我认为，这是必然的。我们如何理解这是一个阶段？这样随着时间的推移，我们就不会陷入困境，但我们实际上有一个项目，参与者本身有更多的参与和更大的自决权？把它作为一个意图提出来是很有用的，这样当我们做出下一步该做什么的重大决定时，我们就会牢记这一点。”

“We’ve moved to more structure, not less, in order to do what we need to do now. Other than our transparency, it feels like a conventional software development project—I think, of necessity. How do we understand that this is a phase? So that over time we’re not dug into a hole, but we actually have a project where there is greater involvement, greater self-determination on the part of the participants themselves? Putting it out there as an intention is useful so that when we make big decisions about what to do next, we have this in mind.”





“米奇享有很高的声誉，”当我问安迪·赫茨菲尔德为什么他认为钱德勒花了这么长时间时，他告诉我。“他不想让鸡蛋沾到脸上。因此，我们比一个十七岁的孩子更加谨慎，因为他所拥有的只是他的代码。我们倾向于非常非常小心。”

“Mitch has a big reputation,” Andy Hertzfeld told me when I asked him why he thought Chandler was taking so long. “He doesn’t want to get egg on his face. So we’re a little more cautious than if it was a seventeen-year-old, where all he’d have is his code. We have a tendency to be very, very careful.”

但卡普尔还没有证明自己吗？我问。埃里克·雷蒙德 (Eric Raymond) 曾说过，开源程序员的动力来自于对同行荣耀的渴望。卡普尔已经多次成名。这难道不应该让他更容易冒险吗？

But hadn’t Kapor proven himself? I asked. Eric Raymond had said that open source programmers were driven by a hunger for glory among their peers. Kapor had made his name many times over already. Shouldn’t that make it easier for him to take risks?

“不，他还需要更多的荣耀，”赫茨菲尔德回答道。“作为设计师，我们都需要更多的荣耀——以证明我们可以设计出另一个伟大的东西。每个第一次获得成功的人，尤其是在年轻的时候，都会想：是运气，还是技巧？嗯，两者都有一点。如果你能再做一件真正伟大的事情，那就向世界展示了一些东西。”

“No, he still needs more glory,” Hertzfeld responded. “We all need more glory as designers—to show we can design another great thing. Everybody who has a first success, especially when it’s young, wonders: Was it luck, or was it skill? Well, it’s a little of both. If you can do another really great one, it shows the world something.”





当观察家对钱德勒进展缓慢表示怀疑时，卡普尔会扬起猫头鹰般的眉毛并评论道：“如果不坚持不懈，我什么都不是。” 毕竟，他仍然经常听到人们渴望放弃 Microsoft Outlook 和 Exchange 程序，并用更好、更灵活和可靠的程序取而代之。就在他的经理为他重新设计工作的那一周，就在阵亡将士纪念日周末之前，支持他妻子的非营利组织公平竞争环境研究所的 Microsoft Exchange 服务器遭遇了灾难性的崩溃。LPFI 工作人员连续三天丢失了电子邮件和日程安排。

When observers expressed skepticism to him about Chandler’s slow progress, Kapor would lift his owlish brows and comment, “I am nothing if not persistent.” After all, he still heard regularly and frequently from people eager to ditch their Microsoft Outlook and Exchange programs and replace them with something better, more flexible and reliable. The very week his managers were redesigning his job for him, just before Memorial Day weekend, the Microsoft Exchange server that supported his wife’s nonprofit, the Level Playing Field Institute, had suffered a catastrophic melt-down. For three days the LPFI staff lost its email and schedules.

钱德勒感觉好像要花很长时间一样。但卡普尔坚信坚持就会有回报。

It felt as if Chandler was taking forever. But Kapor was determined that persistence would pay off.

第 8 章                           

CHAPTER 8                           

白板上的便利贴

STICKIES ON A WHITEBOARD

[2004 年 6 月至 10 月]

[JUNE–OCTOBER 2004]

在微软，就像在许多严肃的软件公司一样，长期以来，“吃自己的狗粮”是企业的当务之急。不，比尔·盖茨并没有欺负他的员工；他只是在欺负他的员工。该短语意味着软件开发人员必须自己使用他们正在构建的产品。（这个用法的起源可以追溯到旧电视时代，当时洛恩·格林（Lorne Greene）会向阿尔波兜售，大喊这东西太棒了，他把它喂给了自己的狗。）

At Microsoft, as at many serious software companies, there has long been a corporate imperative to “eat your own dogfood.” No, Bill Gates is not hazing his employees; the phrase means that software developers must themselves use the products they are in the process of building. (The origins of the usage extend back to olden TV times when Lorne Greene would hawk Alpo by exclaiming that the stuff was so great, he fed it to his own pooches.)

一位微软开发经理曾在一篇博客文章中对此进行了如下解释：“Dogfooding . 。。这是我们在内部非常积极地做的事情，以帮助消除服务器版本中的最后几个生产错误。我们发现，在您自己的测试版软件之上运行您的工资单、电子邮件、源代码控制和健康福利系统可以成为在开发周期早期提高产品质量的一种高度激励的方式。;-)”

Here is how one Microsoft development manager once explained it in a blog posting: “Dogfooding . . . is something we do internally pretty aggressively to help chase out the last few production bugs in a server release. We’ve found that running your payroll, email, source control, and health benefits system on top of your own beta software can be a highly motivating way to drive quality into the product early in the development cycle.;-)”

在 OSAF，狗在大厅里漫步，旗舰产品上也挂着一张狗脸，“狗食”这个词感觉恰到好处；正如米奇·卡普尔所说，它具有“积极的内涵”。随着 2004 年上半年 Chandler 的工作缓慢推进，Kapor 和他的团队逐渐坚信，取得更好进展的关键是改进他们的软件，使其能够自己开始使用——让 Chandler 能够进行测试。 。

At OSAF, where dogs roamed the halls and a canine face festooned the flagship product, the term dogfooding felt just right; it had, as Mitch Kapor put it, “positive connotations.” As work on Chandler plodded forward in the first half of 2004, Kapor and his team became steadily more convinced that the key to making better progress was to improve their software to the point where they could begin using it themselves—to make Chandler dogfood-able.

“dogfooding”一词可能普遍与微软联系在一起，但这种做法的历史却悠久得多。在施乐传奇的帕洛阿尔托研究中心，现代个人计算机于 20 世纪 70 年代发明，“我们使用我们构建的东西”是研究团队负责人鲍勃·泰勒 (Bob Taylor) 的座右铭。这个公式只是道格·恩格尔巴特（Doug Engelbart）的引导的变体。引导的目标是加快反馈循环，以便今天您可以使用昨天发明的工具为明天构建一个更好的工具；相比之下，dogfooding 的目标更为温和和务实，即通过让开发人员深入研究产品的缺陷来加速错误发现和修复。

The term dogfooding may be popularly associated with Microsoft, but the practice is far older. At Xerox’s legendary Palo Alto Research Center, where modern personal computing was invented in the 1970s, “We use what we build” was the motto of research team leader Bob Taylor. And that formulation was simply a variation on Doug Engelbart’s bootstrapping. The goal of bootstrapping was to rev up a feedback loop so that today you would use the tool you invented yesterday to build a better one for tomorrow; dogfooding, by contrast, had the more modest and pragmatic aim of speeding up bug-finding and bug-fixing by shoving developers’ noses into their products’ flaws.

卡普尔（Kapor）在进行内部测试时总是想到一个特定的客户：他自己。他需要一个日历，让他和他的助手 Esther Sun 能够进行更改并保持两份副本同步。钱德勒的“读写点对点共享”愿景在一定程度上是为了支持这一用例而制定的。他们尝试过使用苹果的 iCal；事实证明，它相当擅长以只读方式共享一个日历中的信息（本质上是将其发布以供更广泛的消费），但它不够灵活，无法赋予两个人“读写”权限。

Kapor always had one particular customer in mind for dogfooding: himself. He needed a calendar that would allow both him and his assistant, Esther Sun, to make changes and keep their two copies synchronized. Chandler’s vision of “read-write peer-to-peer sharing” was concocted, in part, to support this use case. They had tried using Apple’s iCal; it turned out to be reasonably good at sharing the information from one calendar in a read-only way—essentially publishing it for wider consumption—but it simply wasn’t flexible enough to give two people “read-write” privileges.

如果 Chandler 想要成为测试工具，它必须提供 Kapor 和 Sun 可以共享的日历。这意味着钱德勒关于直观、多功能信息共享的广泛承诺成为现实。但共享的东西仍然是钱德勒团队一年前给它贴上的标签：一条蛇。设计团队还没有解决困扰它的无数开放性问题，程序员仍然不知道如何构建它。

If Chandler was going to be dogfood-usable, it had to provide a calendar that Kapor and Sun could share. That meant making Chandler’s broad promise of intuitive, versatile information-sharing real. But sharing very much remained what the Chandler team had labeled it a year before: a snake. The design team hadn’t nailed the myriad open issues that plagued it, and the programmers still didn’t know how they were going to build it.

根本没有太多清晰的路标——可以借鉴的成功系统的例子。卡普尔离开后，由雷·奥齐 (Ray Ozzie) 在卡普尔的老公司开发的 Lotus Notes 就是其中之一，但它依赖于重量级服务器，而 OSAF 致力于无服务器、点对点方法。在 Lotus 之后，Ozzie 继续构建了一个名为 Groove 的新共享和协作系统（Kapor 是早期投资者）。Groove 是一个真正的点对点系统，它解决了该设计中的许多最棘手的问题，包括保持用户数据同步和维护安全性（对于 Groove 在 9 年后越来越多地服务的军事客户来说，这是一个至关重要的问题） /11时代）。但 Groove 是仅限 Windows 的软件，OSAF 致力于让 Mac 和 Linux 用户平等共享。

There simply weren’t many clear road signs—examples of successful systems to work from. Lotus Notes, developed by Ray Ozzie at Kapor’s old company after Kapor left, was one, but it relied on a heavyweight server, and OSAF was committed to a server-free, peer-to-peer approach. After Lotus, Ozzie had gone on to build a new sharing and collaboration system called Groove (Kapor was an early investor). Groove was a true peer-to-peer system, and it had solved many of the thorniest problems of that design—including keeping users’ data in sync and maintaining security (a critical matter for the military customers Groove increasingly served in the post-9/11 era). But Groove was Windows-only software, and OSAF was committed to allowing Mac and Linux users to share on an equal footing.

他们越深入地研究共享问题，OSAF 的每个人就越开始怀疑他们是否给自己强加了太多相互冲突的要求。也许有人曾经构建过能够在多个计算平台上无缝共享信息而不依赖服务器的软件，这是有原因的。也许这只是不切实际。也许 OSAF 需要重新考虑其计划。

The further they delved into the problem of sharing, the more everyone at OSAF began to wonder whether they had imposed one too many conflicting requirements on themselves. Maybe there was a reason nobody had ever built software that seamlessly shared information across multiple computing platforms without relying on servers. Maybe it just wasn’t practical. Maybe OSAF needed to rethink its plans.





丽莎·杜索（Lisa Dusseault）就是这样认为的。Dusseault 于 2004 年 3 月加入 OSAF，并开始与 Katie Parlante 分担管理开发人员的工作。几周之内，他们将日益笨重的应用程序团队一分为二：重组后的应用程序组将继续构建 Chandler 的 GUI（前端界面），而新的服务团队将专注于存储库之上的 Chandler 层但在 GUI 之下——电子邮件传输和共享机制等功能——与幕后的其他软件进行交互。

That was how it looked to Lisa Dusseault. Dusseault had joined OSAF in March 2004 and began sharing the job of managing the developers with Katie Parlante. Within a few weeks they split the apps team, which was growing unwieldy, in two: The reconstituted Apps Group would continue to build Chandler’s GUI, the front-end interface, while the new services team would focus on the layers of Chandler above the repository but below the GUI—functions like email transport and sharing mechanisms—that interacted with other software behind the scenes.

杜索是一位聪明、有条理、热情的加拿大年轻人，措辞准确，副业是空手道和编织，并对互联网标准的深奥领域充满热情。九十年代初，作为一名大学生，她曾在微软实习，并于 1996 年刚从学校毕业就去那里担任项目经理。当时，微软正忙着剥离 Windows 的核心，构建互联网接入和 Web 浏览器。功能融入其软件的核心。（这一努力后来成为该公司与美国司法部反垄断斗争的核心问题。）Dusseault 参与了多个不同的服务器项目，其中包括 Microsoft Exchange Server 的早期版本，该项目后来困扰了 Mitch Kapor 的周末。

Dusseault was a bright, methodical, enthusiastic young Canadian with precise diction, sidelines in karate and knitting, and a passion for the abstruse realm of Internet standards. As a college student in the early nineties, she had interned at Microsoft and went to work as a program manager there straight out of school in 1996. At that time, Microsoft was busy ripping out the guts of Windows to build Internet access and Web browser features into the heart of its software. (The effort would later serve as a central issue in the company’s antitrust battle with the U.S. Department of Justice.) Dusseault worked on several different server projects, including early versions of the Microsoft Exchange Server that would later bedevil Mitch Kapor’s weekends.

杜索的到来标志着 OSAF 的多项第一。她是第一位加入该项目的成熟的微软资深人士。她于 2000 年离开了这家软件巨头，因为新老板的幻想破灭了（“他是退伍军人，在需要知道的基础上运作”），并在一家小型初创公司管理了几年开发工作。她也是钱德勒团队中第一位对互联网标准世界拥有大量第一手经验的成员，这是一个松散的官僚机构，负责管理网络工程标准的批准——广泛商定的、开放的、记录齐全的协议，允许任何人构建兼容的软件。作为在 Microsoft 工作的一部分，Dusseault 开始参与标准委员会的工作并参加标准委员会的上级组织互联网工程任务组 (IETF) 的会议。

Dusseault’s arrival marked a number of firsts for OSAF. She was the first full-fledged Microsoft veteran to join the project. She had left the software giant in 2000, disillusioned by a new boss (“he was ex-military and operated on a need-to-know basis”), and had managed development at a small start-up company for several years. She was also the first member of the Chandler team with much firsthand experience of the Internet standards world, a loose bureaucracy that governs the approval of network engineering standards—widely agreed upon, open, well-documented protocols that allow anyone to build compatible software. As part of her job at Microsoft, Dusseault had started participating in the work of standards committees and attending meetings of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), the parent organization of the standards committees.

在 IETF，Dusseault 参与了一项名为 WebDAV（基于 Web 的分布式创作和版本控制）的新标准的工作，这是 Web 基本协议的扩展，正如其官方网站所解释的那样，“允许用户协作编辑并管理远程 Web 服务器上的文件。” 2002 年，她担任 WebDAV 工作组主席并撰写了一本有关该主题的书。

At the IETF, Dusseault got involved in work on a new standard called WebDAV (for Web-based Distributed Authoring and Versioning), an extension to the basic protocol of the Web that, as its official Web site explains, “allows users to collaboratively edit and manage files on remote Web servers.” By 2002 she was chairing the WebDAV working group and writing a book on the subject.

对于许多程序员来说，标准领域是无休止的草案修订、通过邮件列表进行的扳手腕以及令人疯狂的缓慢进展的沼泽，这使得普通软件开发看起来就像印地 500 强一样。（大型软件公司早在很久之前就因实施新标准而臭名昭著）编纂它们的草案已获得批准。）但杜塞尔热切地进入了这个世界，尽管它的步伐充满流沙。

To many programmers the realm of standards is a swamp of endless draft revisions, arm wrestling via mailing list, and maddeningly slow progress that makes garden-variety software development look like the Indy 500. (Big software companies are notorious for implementing new standards long before the drafts that codify them have won approval.) But Dusseault took avidly to this world despite its quicksand pace.

“我认为我做这一切的原因是我看起来比大多数人都长一点。我看到了生命周期，”她说。“大多数人习惯的时间范围是一年。这对于软件开发人员来说是一件好事。正在编写您预计五年内都不会使用的代码？很难知道如何正确地做这件事。一年可能太长了。因此，当他们采用事件视界并进入标准工作时，工作组需要两年的时间来完成考虑草案的过程，至少，然后再花六个月的时间来批准它——然后你可能还没有完成整个事情，你刚刚完成了框架，现在你必须做下一部分。它看起来太长了，太可笑了。您的事件范围必须为五年。五年之后，你才能真正指出一些有用的东西。”

“I think the reason I do all this is that I look a little bit longer than most people. I see the life cycles,” she says. “The time frame most people are used to having is one year. And that’s a good thing for software developers. Working on code that you don’t envision being used for five years? It’s so hard to know how to do it right. One year is probably even too long. So when they take that event horizon and go into standards work, and it takes the working group two years to go through the process of considering the draft, minimum, then another six months to approve it—and then you’ve probably not done the whole thing, you’ve just done the framework, now you have to do the next part of it. It just seems ridiculously overlong. You have to have an event horizon of five years. It’ll be five years before something useful comes of this that you can really point to.”

这并没有让杜塞尔感到困惑。“在标准领域，我发现了一群胸怀大志的技术人员。他们没有考虑明年夏天的发布或将于下周修复的错误。他们正在考虑改变已经存在十五年的标准，比如电子邮件，或者发明他们希望存在二十五年的新标准。”

That didn’t throw Dusseault. “In the standards world, I found a collection of techies who were thinking big. They weren’t thinking about the release next summer or the bug due to be fixed next week. They were thinking about altering standards that had already existed for fifteen years, like email, or inventing new standards that they hoped would exist for twenty-five years.”

杜索说，要做到这一点，你必须更像城市规划者一样思考。“谈论电子邮件系统：它是一个不断变化的软件片段、实际服务器、人们的帐户和一切的集合，具有显着的稳定性。这是一种近乎自然的系统，当然不是由任何人设计的。它的各个部分被设计并安装到位，然后变形。所以我的方法的一个重要部分是，每当你部署一个新的系统时，一定要考虑五年或十年后你是否会后悔——是否可以扩展它、替换它。”

To do that, Dusseault says, you have to think more like a city planner. “Talk about the email system: It’s an ever changing collection of pieces of software and actual servers and people’s accounts and everything, with remarkable stability. It’s one of those almost natural systems that certainly didn’t get designed by anybody. Pieces of it got designed and put in place and then morphed. So a big part of my approach is, whenever you’re putting into place a new piece of a system, always look at whether you’re going to regret it in five or ten years—whether you can extend it, replace it.”

到达 OSAF 后不久，Dusseault 就在午餐时间为同事们提供了有关 WebDAV 的教程。她将其描述为“隐形协议”：它内置于 Microsoft Windows（作为 Web 文件夹）和 Apple 的 Macintosh OSX 中，并且在许多需要提供某种形式的远程共享和文档编辑的软件包中使用。但它并不为人所知。“人们选择 WebDAV 并使用它是因为它看起来不错。它适合。你不需要过多地拉动和推压它，就能让它完成你想要做的事情。”

Soon after her arrival at OSAF, Dusseault gave her colleagues a lunchtime tutorial about WebDAV. She described it as a “stealth protocol”: it’s built into both Microsoft Windows (as Web Folders) and Apple’s Macintosh OSX, and it is used inside many software packages that need to provide some form of remote sharing and editing of documents. But it’s not well known. “People pick up WebDAV and use it because it looks right. It fits. You don’t need to pull and push on it too much to make it work for what you’re trying to do.”

WebDAV 的工作原理是扩展 HTTP（Web 服务器和浏览器用于相互通信的协议），添加允许用户编辑远程服务器上的文件的新命令。在指定这些扩展时，WebDAV 的创建者解决了导致 Chandler 的开发人员在尝试实现共享时抓狂的几个问题。例如，WebDAV 具有内置的冲突解决机制，决定当两个不同的用户尝试在同一文档中同时进行更改时会发生什么情况。或者，您可以通过“锁定”从一开始就避免冲突，“锁定”允许用户编辑文档，以确保在工作完成并保存更改之前没有其他人可以访问该文档。

WebDAV works by extending HTTP—the protocol that Web servers and browsers use to talk to each other—adding new commands that allow users to edit files on a remote server. In specifying these extensions, WebDAV’s creators had dealt with several of the problems that had caused Chandler’s developers to tear their hair out as they tried to implement sharing. For instance, WebDAV had built-in mechanisms for conflict resolution—deciding what happens when two different users try to make simultaneous changes in the same document. Or you could avoid conflict in the first place through “locking,” which allows a user editing a document to make sure that no one else has access to it until the work is done and the changes are saved.

如果 WebDAV 能做到，为什么钱德勒却这么难？钱德勒的点对点方法意味着没有中央服务器可以成为开发人员带着某种轻率的敬意所说的“真理之源”。WebDAV 的服务器存储文档，知道文档发生了什么，并且可以向多个用户协调有关其状态的消息。在分散的点对点方法下，文档的多个副本可能会激增，而没有主副本可供用户依赖，也没有权限可以求助。

If WebDAV could do it, why was it so hard for Chandler? Chandler’s peer-to-peer approach meant there was no central server to be what developers call, with a kind of flip reverence, “the source of truth.” WebDAV’s server stored the document, knew what was happening to it, and could coordinate messages about its status to multiple users. Under a decentralized peer-to-peer approach, multiple copies of a document can proliferate with no master copy for users to rely on, no authority to turn to.

没有“真相来源”，生活会变得更加困难。对于程序员和其他人来说，规范权威可能很方便。它使您不必自己弄清楚如何解决困境。在 OSAF 工作了几周后，杜塞尔确信通向钱德勒共享的点对点之路很可能是一条死胡同。无论如何，该项目迄今为止的努力几乎没有什么可展示的。“没有任何有效的点对点代码，”她后来告诉我。“但这就像，我们正在做点对点的工作。我们必须。我们说过我们会的。我们决定这么做。”

Life is harder without a “source of truth.” For programmers as for other human beings, a canonical authority can be convenient. It rescues you from having to figure out how to adjudicate dilemmas on your own. After just a few weeks at OSAF, Dusseault became convinced that the peer-to-peer road to Chandler sharing was likely to prove a dead end. The project had little to show from its efforts to date anyway. “There wasn’t any working peer-to-peer code,” she later told me. “But it was like, we’re doing peer-to-peer. We have to. We said we would. We decided to.”

程序员总是将他们先前存在的热情和专业知识带到新问题上。在最坏的情况下，这可能会导致“当你有锤子时，一切看起来都像钉子”的不匹配；这充其量意味着当你把新人带入一个项目时，你可以免费搭乘他们的木马。无论是哪一种，从 Dusseault 走进 OSAF 大门的那一刻起，钱德勒似乎很有可能最终会以某种方式使用 WebDAV。事实上，加入该项目后不久，Dusseault 就开始悄悄游说 Chandler 的“共享交通”采用一种新方法——WebDAV 方法。

Programmers always bring their preexisting enthusiasms and expertise to a new problem. At worst this can lead to mismatches of the “when you have a hammer, everything looks like a nail” variety; at best it means that when you bring new people into a project, you get a free ride on their hobbyhorses. Whichever it was, from the moment Dusseault walked in the door at OSAF, it seemed a good bet that Chandler would end up using WebDAV somehow. And in fact, soon after joining the project, Dusseault began quietly lobbying for a new approach to Chandler’s “sharing transport”—a WebDAV approach.

这意味着使用服务器，这对 OSAF 来说是一个大转变。卡普尔花了一些时间才适应这个想法。钱德勒未来的某个地方一直有一台服务器用于该程序的韦斯特伍德版本，该版本旨在用于大学校园。但卡普尔知道，为钱德勒的第一版（他们称之为卡诺加）配备服务器是一个真正的妥协，可能看起来像是一个塌方。局外人可能会失望；OSAF 开发人员可能会抵制。但如果 Chandler 愿意支持共享（而且它必须这样做），WebDAV 就有一个压倒性的优势：它已经发挥作用了。

That would mean using a server, a big about-face for OSAF. It took Kapor some time to get used to the idea. There had always been a server somewhere in Chandler’s future for the Westwood edition of the program, the version intended for use on university campuses. But Kapor knew that going with a server for the first edition of Chandler, the one they had been calling Canoga, was a real compromise and might look like a cave-in. Outsiders would be disappointed; OSAF developers might resist. But if Chandler was ever going to support sharing—and it had to—WebDAV had one overwhelming advantage: It already worked.

无论如何，卡普尔正在重新思考点对点的优点。在 6 月份的一次会议上，他正式向员工宣布采用基于服务器的共享设计，他解释说：“我的观点发生了重大变化。有一种边疆理想主义，虽然用意良好，但对我来说并不实际。问题在于赋予人们权力。这与基础设施无关。也许我们需要一个强大的公共服务器基础设施来让人们做他们想做的事情。我和OSAF最初的立场是，电很好，所以每个人都应该有自己的发电厂！不知不觉中，我一直认为用户授权在某种程度上意味着无服务器或轻服务器环境。现在我认为这实际上是错误的。”

Kapor was rethinking the merits of peer-to-peer anyway. At a June meeting where he formally announced the adoption of a server-based sharing design to his staff, he explained, “I’ve had a significant change of point of view. There was a kind of frontier idealism that was well intentioned but not practical on my part. The issue is about empowering people. It’s not about the infrastructure. Maybe we need a robust public infrastructure of servers to let people do what they want to do. My and OSAF’s original position was, electricity is good, therefore everyone should have their own power plant! Unconsciously, I always imagined that user empowerment somehow meant a server-free or server-light environment. Now I think that’s actually wrong.”

几周后，他详细阐述道：“这实际上是一个棘手的问题。许多开源领域的思想领袖都重视自由和主动性，而这些价值观与美国边疆的自给自足神话紧密相连——独自出去，只管去做。虽然对此有很多话要说，但事实证明，开源和互联网的现实比狭隘的自由主义 P2P 道德更具协作性。”

A few weeks later he elaborated: “This actually turns out to be a deeply charged issue. So many of the people who are thought leaders in open source value freedom and initiative, and those values have been very tied up with this American frontier myth of self-sufficiency—going out on your own and just doing it. And while there’s a lot to say for that, it turns out that the reality of open source and the Internet is much more collaborative than the narrow libertarian P2P ethic.”

至少对于一些 Chandler 开发人员来说，点对点不是一种意识形态或宗教，但它是他们所签署的愿景的主要部分，并且他们已经编写的一些代码旨在支持它。因此，向开发团队推销新方法是很棘手的。存储库开发人员 Andi Vajda 特别抵制。

For at least some of the Chandler developers, peer-to-peer wasn’t an ideology or a religion, but it was a major part of the vision they had signed up for, and some of the code they had already written was designed to support it. So selling the new approach to the development team was tricky. Andi Vajda, the repository developer, was especially resistant.

“我们必须选择一条前进的道路，”凯蒂·帕兰特在六月的一次会议上解释道。“我们无法同时完成所有的事情，”杜塞尔说。

“We have to choose a path forward,” Katie Parlante explained at a meeting in June. “We can’t do all the neat stuff at once,” Dusseault said.

但瓦伊达反对说，运行服务器意味着要求用户将数据交给其他人。“我不使用.Mac。我不使用 Gmail。我不信任第三方处理我的数据。无论如何，对我来说，这不再像分享了。这更像是你在发布这些东西。”

But running a server meant asking users to hand their data over to somebody else, Vajda objected. “I don’t use .Mac. I don’t use Gmail. I don’t trust a third party with my data. Anyway, to me it’s not like sharing anymore. It’s more like you’re publishing this stuff.”

Vajda 一直在构建 Chandler 存储库，着眼于支持存储库之间的直接同步和共享。在他看来，这是该项目的基本要求。卡普尔一直表示，他希望钱德勒让用户能够轻松地在工作机器上存储一组数据，在家用机器上存储一组数据，并保持两个副本同步。

Vajda had been building the Chandler repository with an eye to supporting direct repository-to-repository syncing and sharing. As he saw it, this was a basic requirement of the project. Kapor had always said that he wanted Chandler to make it easy for users to store one set of data on a work machine and one on a home machine, and keep the two copies in sync.

“如果你不做点对点的事情，米奇就取消了使用钱德勒作为最终用户的一个理由，”瓦伊达当天晚些时候告诉我。“所以这很令人沮丧。情况会变得更糟，因为会有更多这样的事情——更多的事情我们会说，‘哦，这太难了。我们最好放弃它。最终，他们是对的，因为交付一些尚未完成但可用的东西比等待十年直到完全完成要好。初衷是好的。但愿景正在遭受痛苦，这令人沮丧。有了这个新的服务器，钱德勒变得更大了。人们没有意识到这一点。他们认为，啊，这更容易。这比存储库共享可以为他们做的事情更简单。。。。也许我错了。当我明白原因时，我喜欢犯错。那太棒了！我会学到一些东西。但我有点担心，因为这个项目只是变大了，而不是变小了。”

“Mitch has just taken away one reason to use Chandler as an end user if you don’t do the peer-to-peer stuff,” Vajda told me later that day. “So that’s frustrating. And it’s going to get worse because there will be more of these—more things where we say, ‘Oh, this is too hard. We’d better give up on it.’ Ultimately, they’re right, because it’s better to ship something that’s not done but that’s usable than wait ten years until you’re completely done. The intent is good. But the vision is suffering, and that’s frustrating. With this new server thing, Chandler just got bigger. People don’t realize that. They think, Ah, it’s easier. It’s simpler than what repository sharing could do for them . . . . Maybe I’m wrong. I love to be wrong when I understand why. That’s great! I’ll learn something. But I’m a little worried, because the project just got bigger, not smaller.”





根据基于 WebDAV 的新计划，当 Chandler 用户决定共享项目集合（例如日历）时，Chandler 会将该集合复制到 WebDAV 服务器。“共享者”将登录到该服务器并有权访问日历 - 读取或更改它。服务器将确保所有更改都会传播回共享者。还有很多悬而未决的问题：我如何让你知道我想与你分享？服务器如何控制对不同用户数据的访问？您将如何终止股份？但最大的问题是“钱德勒性格”。

Under the new WebDAV-based plan, when a Chandler user decided to share a collection of items, like a calendar, Chandler would copy that collection over to a WebDAV server. The “sharee” would log in to that server and have access to the calendar—to read it or change it. The server would make sure that all changes would then propagate back to the sharer. There were still lots of unanswered questions: How would I let you know I wanted to share with you? How would the server control access to different users’ data? How would you go about terminating a share? But the biggest question was the one of “Chandlerness.”

钱德勒的物品不仅仅是一些文字。它们是具有一组属性的软件对象，这些属性定义了它们是什么、它们属于什么集合以及它们如何相互关联。WebDAV 旨在协调网页和类似文本文档上的协作。当 Chandler 项目导出到 WebDAV 服务器时会发生什么情况？他们能保留钱德勒风格吗？需要多少额外的工作？

Chandler items weren’t simply little bits of text. They were software objects with sets of attributes that defined what they were, what collections they belonged to, and how they related to one another. WebDAV had been designed to coordinate collaboration on Web pages and similar text documents. What would happen to the Chandler items when they got exported to the WebDAV server? Could they retain their Chandlerness? How much extra work would it take?

回答这些问题的唯一方法就是开始研究代码。与此同时，Lisa Dusseault 已经在开发一个名为 CalDAV 的新项目，该项目将扩展 WebDAV，使其能够更智能地处理日历。如果 Chandler 使用 CalDAV，并且 CalDAV 成为其他日历软件支持的标准，那么 Chandler 用户最终可能会与使用其他日历程序的人共享他们的日历。最终，Dusseault 和 Parlante 可以创建一组进一步的 WebDAV 扩展（称为 ChanDAV），这将允许 WebDAV 处理 Chandler 生成的所有动态、流动数据。

The only way to answer those questions was to begin to play around with the code. Meanwhile, Lisa Dusseault was already working on a new project, labeled CalDAV, that would extend WebDAV to make it smarter about handling calendars. If Chandler used CalDAV, and CalDAV emerged as a standard that other calendar software supported, Chandler users could end up sharing their calendars with people using other calendar programs. Eventually, Dusseault and Parlante could see creating a further set of WebDAV extensions—call it ChanDAV—that would allow WebDAV to handle all the dynamic, fluid data generated by Chandler.

目前，任务更简单：设置一个 WebDAV 服务器供 OSAF 开发人员使用，并编写将 Chandler 项目来回发送到服务器的代码。其余的愿景，包括 CalDAV 和 ChanDAV 以及更多尚未命名的 DAV，仍然遥遥无期。

For now, the task was simpler: Set up a WebDAV server for OSAF’s developers to use, and write the code that would send Chandler items back and forth to the server. The rest of the vision, with CalDAV and ChanDAV and further DAVs yet unnamed, remained far down the road.

但有了切合实际的共享计划，人行道上发出嘶嘶声的蛇就少了。

But with a realistic plan for sharing in place, there was one fewer snake hissing on the pavement.





那是 2004 年 6 月下旬的一个星期一下午。Chao Lam 和 Lisa Dusseault 走进 Mitch Kapor 阳光普照的办公室，围坐在靠近门的一张小圆桌旁。卡普尔加入了他们。他们的议程是：规划 Canoga，即 Chandler 的最终 1.0 版本，这似乎仍然是一个遥远的高峰。

It’s a Monday afternoon late in June 2004. Chao Lam and Lisa Dusseault step into Mitch Kapor’s sunlight-flooded office and sit down around a small round table near the door. Kapor joins them. Their agenda: planning for Canoga, the eventual 1.0 release of Chandler, which still seems like a distant peak to scale.

最近，OSAF 的管理人员和开发人员又经历了土拨鼠之日的重演。他们从显示器上抬起头，环顾四周，发现距 Chandler 0.3 发布已经过去了四个月，所以他们不可能在日程安排的三四个月内发布 0.4。现在，卡普尔、林和杜塞尔正在评估这一最新的下滑对他们的长期计划意味着什么。

Recently, the managers and developers at OSAF have been experiencing another Groundhog Day repeat. They poked their heads up from their monitors, looked around, and realized that four months had passed since the release of Chandler 0.3, so there was no way they were going to release 0.4 in the three or four months allotted by their schedule. Now Kapor, Lam, and Dusseault are assessing what this latest slippage means for their long-term plans.

“我们是功能驱动还是日程驱动？” 杜索问道。

“Are we feature-driven or schedule-driven?” asks Dusseault.

“两者都必须有一点，”林说。

“It has to be a little bit of both,” Lam says.

“在现实世界中，两者总是兼而有之，”卡普尔表示同意。“如果两者都是其中之一，那就是病态的。我们的计划是功能方面占主导地位。当然，我们会以迭代的方式进行修剪和调整。它就像一个双星系统，其中一个比另一个更大。它们都影响彼此的轨道。

“In the real world, it’s always some of both,” Kapor agrees. “It’s pathological if it’s all one or the other. Our plan is that the feature side is dominant. Of course we’ll trim and adjust in iterative fashion. It’s like a binary star system in which one is bigger than the other. They both influence each other’s orbits.

“此时此刻我正被狗粮所驱使。我宁愿早点得到一些可用的东西。反对这样做的理由是，它可能会冒在特定时间点发布一些不太有趣的东西的风险。但“半条面包总比没有好。”的说法抵消了这种批评。”

“I’m being driven by dogfood at this point. I’d rather get something that is usable sooner. The argument against doing that is, it risks releasing something that’s not all that interesting at a particular point in time. But that criticism is outweighed by ‘half a loaf is better than none.’”

他们开始审查 Lam 已将其纳入 Excel 的潜在 Canoga 功能列表。其中充满了开发人员尚未开始处理的重大项目，例如从 Chandler 导入和导出数据以及打印和“版本控制”（跟踪用户所做的更改以便他们可以撤消它们）。当他们考虑每一个额外的话题时，房间里的能量似乎逐渐消失。

They begin reviewing the list of potential Canoga features that Lam has wrangled into Excel. It’s full of major projects that the developers haven’t even begun to tackle—things like importing and exporting data from Chandler and printing and “versioning” (keeping track of changes that users make so that they can undo them). As they consider each additional topic, the energy seems to sap out of the room.

“当我到达这里时，我立即发现共享是一座冰山，因为这是我非常熟悉的领域，”杜塞尔说。“还有其他一些地方我不太熟悉，不知道水下是否还有另一座冰山。”

“When I got here, I immediately identified sharing as an iceberg because it was an area I was really familiar with,” Dusseault says. “There are other areas where I’m not familiar enough to know whether there’s another iceberg under the water.”

“你就不能制定一个最好的、没有冰山的时间表吗？” 卡普尔问道。

“Couldn’t you do a best-case, no-icebergs schedule?” Kapor asks.

即便如此，在 Chandler 中构建一整套功能也需要时间，Dusseault 回答道：你能做的事情是有限的，以加快速度，如果你雇佣了太多新程序员，布鲁克斯定律就会发挥作用。

Even then, building a full set of features into Chandler is going to take time, Dusseault answers: there’s only so much you can do to accelerate things, and if you hire too many new programmers, Brooks’s Law will kick in.

“确实如此，”卡普尔承认。“这是‘无论如何，生孩子都需要九个月’的古老原则。”

“That’s true,” Kapor admits. “It’s the old ‘It takes nine months to make a baby, no matter what’ principle.”

“我认为卡诺加是一到两年后的事，”杜索说。“至少。”

“I think Canoga is one to two years from now,” Dusseault says. “At least.”

卡普尔缓缓地长叹了一口气。“这说明了什么？”

Kapor lets out a long, slow sigh. “What informs that?”

“让我害怕的事情有很多。我知道的事情并不难，但只是很辛苦。我将其与 Exchange Server 发布两年前的功能模糊程度以及随后削减的功能进行了比较。”

“The number of things that scare me. And things that I know aren’t hard but are just a lot of slogging. I’m comparing it to how fuzzy the features felt on Exchange Server when it was two years before shipping, and then how many features they cut.”

“这就是卡诺加，”卡普尔说。他像一声长而无声的口哨一样通过嘴唇吹气，闭上眼睛，双手捂住嘴。一阵长时间的沉默。他半心半意地挑战杜塞尔的逻辑：“很难比较进展的速度。我们有新人刚刚开始工作，他们首先致力于解决电子邮件和 WebDAV 问题。0.4之后作品的性格发生了变化。。。”。

“And that’s just Canoga,” Kapor says. He blows air through his lips like a long, silent whistle, closes his eyes, and clasps his hands to his mouth. There’s a long silence. He makes a halfhearted effort to challenge Dusseault’s logic: “It’s hard to compare what the rate of progress is going to be. We have new people just starting out now who are working on solving email and the WebDAV piece to start with. The character of the work changes after 0.4 . . . .”

“但我还有凯蒂团队未来四个月的计划，”杜塞尔回答道。“所有偏好对话和打印对话都需要时间。你只需要费力地通过它们。”

“But I also have Katie’s team’s plan for the next four months,” replies Dusseault. “All the preferences dialogues and the printing dialogues—they take time. You just have to slog through them.”

卡普尔放弃了，继续前进。“下一个问题是，我们什么时候发布可用的狗粮版本？”

Kapor gives up, moves on. “The next question is, when do we have the usable dogfood release?”

“Dogfood 从很小的规模开始，由几个专注的人开始。”

“Dogfood starts really small with a couple of dedicated people.”

“我的预感是，如果我们真的专注于狗粮，那么我们还需要六个月的扎实工作。我确信这会涉及一系列痛苦的决定。”

“My hunch would be another six months of solid work if we really focused on dogfood. I’m sure it would involve a bunch of painful decisions.”

“0.4 后又六个月了？” 杜梭问道，他的表情恭敬地说，我不这么认为！

“Another six months after 0.4?” Dusseault asks, with a look that says, respectfully, I don’t think so!

“是的。到 9 月份，我们可以在 CSG 会议（大学联盟）上就明年 5 月份的可狗食内容说些什么？”

“Yeah. What can we say by September for the CSG meeting [the university consortium] about what’s dogfoodable by next May?”

杜索凝视着窗外，眺望霍华德街对面。“当人们询问这么大的数字时，工程师所做的传统事情就是编造它们。”

Dusseault gazes out the window, out across Howard Street. “When people ask for numbers that far out, the traditional thing that engineers do is make them up.”

在这样的会议中，我通常坐在一边，不引人注目地做笔记。但现在卡普尔转向我，开玩笑说：“斯科特将这一章命名为现实主义开始。”

In meetings like this one, I usually sit off to the side, unobtrusively taking notes. But now Kapor turns to me and jokes, “Scott is naming this chapter Realism Sets In.”

我点头微笑，心想，又到了软件时代了。

I nod and smile, and think, It’s software time all over again.





11:34    危险品 >    你知道对外部开发人员真正有帮助的是 chandler 组件/包及其各种稳定性状态的图表
11:34    凯蒂 >    危险品：当然，我们甚至可以在下周安排类似的事情。。。
11:36    危险品 >    那太好了，变化如此之多，而且很难知道什么是不变的
11:36    凯蒂 >    危险品：伙计，一切都在变化！


——摘自 Chandler IRC 聊天频道，2004 年 7 月 14 日

—From the Chandler IRC chat channel, July 14, 2004



OSAF 之外的一些人定期出现在 IRC 频道上，关注该项目并向核心开发人员询问问题。在极少数情况下，钱德勒团队甚至收到了来自外部开发人员的补丁——纠正某些问题的小段代码。Chandler 仍然是开源的，因为它的源代码是公开的，对其进行的工作也是公开的，但 OSAF 仍然没有很多集市式的志愿者贡献来推动其工作。“人们似乎对我们非常有耐心，”Ted Leung 在他的博客中写道，“我希望一旦我们达到半可用状态，他们的耐心就会转化为积极的支持和贡献。”

A handful of people outside OSAF showed up regularly on the IRC channel to follow the project and ask the core developers questions. On rare occasions the Chandler crew had even received patches—small bits of code correcting some problem—from outside developers. Chandler remained open source in the sense that its source code was public, as was the work taking place on it, but OSAF still didn’t have many bazaar-style volunteer contributions propelling its work. “People seem to be extraordinarily patient with us,” Ted Leung wrote on his blog, “and I hope that their patience will turn into active support and contribution once we get to a semi-usable state.”

内部开发人员继续进行他们的工作。David Surovell 全职致力于对应用程序团队所需的 wxWidgets 组件进行修复和改进。他甚至在修复 John Anderson 在 0.1 版本发布时提出的臭名昭著的“闪烁”错误方面取得了一些进展。事实证明，钱德勒运行的三个操作系统中的每一个都有不同的问题，与每个系统如何处理屏幕上图像的“双缓冲”有关——一种在窗口中准备视觉内容的方法。一种离屏握笔，这样它们就可以在用户点击需要时显示。

The inside developers kept at their spadework. David Surovell was working full-time on making fixes and improvements to the wxWidgets components that the apps team needed. He even made some headway toward fixing the infamous “flicker” bug that John Anderson had filed back in the days of the 0.1 release. It turned out to be a different issue on each of the three operating systems under which Chandler ran, having to do with how each system handled “double buffering” of the images on the screen—a way of preparing the visual contents of a window in a kind of off-screen holding pen so that they’re ready to display the moment the user’s clicks require it.

与此同时，Donn Denman 正在连接细节视图并开始冲压工作。电子邮件专家 Brian Kirsch 将一个名为 Twisted 的基于 Python 的开源框架集成到 Chandler 中。Twisted 处理许多不同类型的网络，并且可以处理 Chandler 发送和接收电子邮件的大部分幕后业务。John Anderson 正忙于“重构”CPIA 块的代码，使其更加紧凑和高效。

Meanwhile, Donn Denman was wiring up the detail view and getting stamping to work. Brian Kirsch, the email specialist, had integrated a Python-based open source framework called Twisted into Chandler. Twisted handled many different kinds of networking and could take care of much of the behind-the-scenes business of sending and receiving emails for Chandler. And John Anderson was busy “refactoring” the code for CPIA blocks to make it more compact and efficient.

“例如，”他在一天的员工会议上说道，“这个存储库视图有 121 行，现在是 85 行。”

“For instance,” he said, showing the staff meeting one day, “this repository view was 121 lines, now it’s 85.”

“因此，衡量您编写的代码行数是一个棘手的指标，”卡普尔指出。“我们刚刚完成了 36 行代码。”

“So the metric of how many lines of code you write is a tricky one,” Kapor pointed out. “We’ve just done negative 36 lines of code.”

两名新员工的加入承诺将推动 OSAF 在其开发过程中走向更加结构化和纪律化的方向。7月，Netscape和其他硅谷公司的资深人士Aparna Kadakia成为OSAF的QA（质量保证）经理，并开始致力于为Chandler建立更全面的测试计划。八月，希拉·穆尼 (Sheila Mooney)——一名程序员转型为经理，曾为一家医疗软件公司负责项目，此前曾在微软从事多媒体工作——加入了 Chao Lam 的产品管理部门，并受命认真编写更正式的内容。以及钱德勒不同方面的详细规格。
