Two new additions to the staff promised to move OSAF toward more structure and discipline in its development process. In July, Aparna Kadakia, a veteran of Netscape and other Silicon Valley companies, became OSAF’s QA (quality assurance) manager and began to work on setting up a more thorough testing program for Chandler. And in August, Sheila Mooney—a programmer turned manager who had run projects for a medical software company and, before that, had worked on multimedia at Microsoft—joined Chao Lam on the product management side with a mandate to get serious about writing more formal and detailed specifications for different aspects of Chandler.

尽管如此，0.4 版本计划的主要功能仍然存在很大的漏洞，而且已经是 8 月份了。Stuart Parmenter 在 0.4 版本中承担了通过 WebDAV 进行基本共享的工作，他还有很长的路要走。约翰·安德森（John Anderson）会取得进步，然后会因为他所谓的“老鼠洞”问题而浪费整整几周的时间。时钟在滴答作响；0.3 版本发布已经六个月了。0.4 计划要求在 9 月初冻结功能，然后是一段时间的错误修复和文档记录，最后在 10 月底完成。卡普尔、帕兰特和杜塞尔都知道他们已经错过了测试目标。

Still, there were big holes in the major features planned for the 0.4 release, and it was already August. Stuart Parmenter, who had taken on the job of getting rudimentary sharing via WebDAV working for 0.4, had a long way to go. John Anderson would make progress and then lose whole weeks to problems he referred to as “ratholes.” And the clock was ticking; it was six months since the 0.3 release. The 0.4 schedule called for a feature freeze in early September, then a period of bug fixing and documentation, and a late October completion date. Kapor, Parlante, and Dusseault all knew that they had missed their dogfood target.

几个月来，他们一直致力于跟踪各个开发人员为代码的每两周里程碑版本发布的任务和时间表。这有助于推动钱德勒前进吗？很难说。但他们知道这需要花费很多时间。

For several months they had been working to track tasks and schedules by individual developer for each two-week milestone release of the code. Was it helping to propel Chandler forward? Hard to say. But they knew it was taking a lot of their time.





“‘未完成’的差距相当大，”卡普尔在 8 月 10 日的一次审查会议上说道，当时经理们正在列出一长串最新里程碑目标，包括已实现和未实现的目标。“我们的目标是成为更好的预测者。”

“The ‘not done’ gap is pretty substantial,” Kapor says at a review meeting on August 10 as the managers run down the long list of the latest milestone’s targets, met and unmet. “The goal is to be better forecasters.”

“让我暂时唱反调吧，”帕兰特说。“始终满足计划并不重要，重要的是取得高进度并了解自己所处的位置。如果我们淡化计划以便更多地实现我们的目标，那么我们的雄心就会减弱，我们完成的工作也会减少。”

“Let me be the devil’s advocate for a moment,” Parlante says. “Always meeting plan is less important than having a high rate of progress and knowing where you’re at. If we water down the plan so that we meet our goals more, that could make us less ambitious, and we’d get less done.”

“人们不善于估计已完成的百分比，”杜索建议。“他们在剩下的日子里表现得更好。”

“People are bad at estimating the percent that’s done,” Dusseault suggests. “They’re better at days remaining.”

卡普尔小心翼翼地说：“让我强调一下，追踪这一切的目的是为了能够协调，而不是赞扬或责备。”

Kapor says carefully, “Let me underscore that the point of tracking all this is to be able to coordinate, not to praise or blame.”

“当前进程的更多内容不会帮助斯图尔特完成任务，”杜塞尔说。“这并不能解决未完成的问题。”

“More of the current process isn’t going to help Stuart finish,” says Dusseault. “It won’t fix the not-doneness.”

“你可能会陷入的陷阱之一，”帕兰特说，“工程师说‘我已经完成了！’ 然后阿帕纳和设计团队看着它并说，‘你在说什么？’”换句话说，该功能可能“有效”，但存在大量错误，而且界面与设计完全不同，并且仍然存在堆积如山的劳动力。

“One of the pitfalls you can fall into,” Parlante says, “is the engineers say ‘I’m done!’ And then Aparna and the design team look at it and say, ‘What are you talking about?’” In other words, the feature may “work,” but there are tons of bugs, and the interface is nothing like the design, and a mountain of labor remains.

特德·梁（Ted Leung）通过会议室电话亭参加这些会议，他说：“写下这些东西的目的是，我们正在努力引导。如果没有一些信息，你就无法做到这一点。问题是，我们需要多少信息？”

Ted Leung, who patches into these meetings over a conference room phone pod, speaks up: “The point of writing this stuff down is, we’re trying to steer. You can’t do that without some information. The question is, how much information do we need?”

“我正在努力降低一点不耐烦的程度，”卡普尔说。“不是一个混蛋。即使我们承认有些事情没有完成，我们也需要有空间对所取得的成就感到满意。否则，我们就只能把头伸进烤箱，然后打开煤气。”

“I’m trying to notch up the impatience level just a little bit,” Kapor says. “Without being a jerk. There needs to be room to feel good about what was accomplished even as we accept that some things didn’t get done. Otherwise, we’ll just stick our heads in the oven and turn on the gas.”

这些会议的惯例是逐个团队进行报告——应用程序、服务、存储库。在其他小组的麻烦账目之后，梁的关于储存库工作的报告——两​​个正在进行中的小项目，都按计划进行，并不令人惊讶——让人松了一口气。卡普尔注意到了。

The custom in these meetings is to report team by team—apps, services, repository. After the troubled accounts of the other groups, Leung’s report on the repository work—two small projects under way, both on schedule, nothing surprising—comes as a relief. Kapor takes note.

“所以有趣的是，在项目的早期，我们花了无数的时间来处理存储库，让每个人都参与其中，有时会让事情一次痛苦地停止几个月。现在，我们正在尝试做所有以前从未做过的其他事情，但遇到了障碍。但它已经在堆栈中向上移动了。我认为记住这一点很有帮助。

“So it is interesting how, earlier in the project, we spent endless amounts of time agonizing over the repository, involving everyone, sometimes bringing things to an agonizing halt for months at a time. Now we’re trying to do all these other things that we’ve never done before and hitting roadblocks. But it’s moved up the stack. I think it’s helpful to remember that.

“对于我作为一名软件设计师来说，如果你能想象出一个功能并且它会神奇地出现，那就太好了。但现在我们正身处地狱。我们有很多好的设计想法，我们会定期拿出来拍摄。

“For me as a software designer, it would be great if you could imagine a feature and it would just appear magically. But right now we’re in hell. We have so many good design ideas that we’ll be taking out and shooting—regularly.

“好消息是，上次我在 On Technology 尝试类似的事情时，在我们走到这一步之前我已经将其关闭了。这次我决心要推出。”

“The good news is, the last time I tried something like this, which was at On Technology, I had shut it down before we got this far. This time I’m committed to launching.”





与此同时，在以北八百英里的地方，一场平行的软件时代戏剧正在上演。自 2003 年夏天以来，微软一直在大肆宣传其新的 Longhorn 操作系统，但令人惊讶的是，随着 2004 年的进展，该公司开始控制 Longhorn。到了夏天，微软宣布新版本的 Windows 直到 2006 年底才会推出，并且不会包含许多它在前一年自豪地吹捧的功能，包括听起来非常相似的奇特的新 WinFS 文件系统钱德勒的无孤岛数据方法。

Meanwhile, eight hundred miles to the north, a parallel software-time drama was playing out. Microsoft had been ballyhooing its new Longhorn operating system since the summer of 2003, but—big surprise!—the company began reining Longhorn in as 2004 progressed. By summer, Microsoft let it be known that the new version of Windows would not be available until late 2006 and would not contain many of the features it had touted so proudly the year before—including the fancy new WinFS file system that had sounded so similar to Chandler’s siloless approach to data.

但是，当 Longhorn 和 Chandler 都下滑时，网络世界正在发生翻天覆地的变化：新一代的软件产品正在出现，具有基于网络浏览器的界面，极客爱好者们兴高采烈地宣称，与前辈不同，它们并不糟糕。 。4 月 1 日，极其成功的搜索引擎 Google 推出了一项名为 Gmail 的新的基于网络的电子邮件服务。这一举动出乎意料，以至于愚人节的发布日期导致许多观察家认为这一公告是一个恶作剧。但这是真实的。虽然 Gmail 引起的轰动主要集中在 Google 提供的前所未有的 1GB 免费邮箱上，但该服务的真正创新在于其“将所有内容转储到一个地方”的信息管理方法。您不必将邮件分类到文件夹中，而只需保留一大堆邮件；Gmail 会智能地对线程进行排序，并帮助您使用出色的搜索工具找到内容，这是 Google 的强项。

But while both Longhorn and Chandler slipped, a sea change was under way in the Web world: A new generation of software products was emerging with Web-browser-based interfaces, and, unlike their predecessors, geek enthusiasts gleefully declared, they did not suck. On April 1, Google, the phenomenally successful search engine, had unveiled a new Web-based email service called Gmail. It was so unexpected a move that the April Fool’s launch date caused many observers to dismiss the announcement as a prank. But it was real. And while much of the stir around Gmail centered on the unprecedentedly large one-gigabyte size of the free mailboxes Google was handing out, the service’s real innovation lay in its “dump everything in one place” approach to information management. Instead of sorting your mail into folders, you would just keep one big pile of mail; Gmail would intelligently sort the threads and help you find things with a great search tool, which is Google’s forte.

谷歌以钱德勒式的方式，对至少一组信息孤岛采取了撬棍。它还提供了一个备用界面，依靠一些巧妙的编程技术，它比大多数基于 Web 的程序更快地响应用户的点击。对于您选择执行的每一个操作，Gmail 不再需要浏览器与服务器交换消息。（这个问题在 Mitch Kapor 不将 Chandler 构建为基于 Web 的应用程序的理由中占有重要地位。）它使 Web 浏览器的工作方式更像 Chandler 所希望的那种“富客户端”应用程序。它正在缩小桌面应用程序和 Web 应用程序之间的差异。

Google had, in Chandleresque fashion, taken a crowbar to at least one set of information silos. It also provided a spare interface, which responded more quickly to a user’s clicks than most Web-based programs by relying on some ingenious programming techniques. Gmail cut out the need for the browser to trade messages with the server for every single action you chose to perform. (That problem had figured prominently in Mitch Kapor’s rationale for not building Chandler as a Web-based application.) It made the Web browser work a little more like the kind of “rich client” application Chandler was going to be. It was whittling down the difference between desktop applications and Web applications.

Gmail 并不是唯一展示这种魔法的产品，后来它以缩写 AJAX（异步 Javascript 和 XML）而闻名。较小的服装公司也在表演类似的炫酷技巧。Flickr 是一家位于不列颠哥伦比亚省温哥华的小公司的产品，它在一项新的基于网络的服务中实现了同样的速度和乐趣，该服务允许人们共享数码照片。由芝加哥一家名为 37 Signals 的小型设计公司开发的 Basecamp 在基于 Web 的工具中提供了类似的功能，用于小组项目管理。

Gmail wasn’t the only product to show off such wizardry, which later became known by the acronym AJAX (for asynchronous Javascript and XML); smaller outfits were performing similar cool tricks. Flickr, the product of a small company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, achieved the same kind of speed and delight in a new Web-based service that allowed people to share digital photos. And Basecamp, developed by a little Chicago design firm called 37 Signals, offered similar features in a Web-based tool for small-group project management.

此类产品并没有立即占领大众市场，但它们赢得了热情的早期采用者的拥抱——极客和技术作家在博客中对它们赞不绝口，并帮助激发了全新一代软件正在崛起的感觉。卡普尔一直着眼长远——这是一种应对科技行业变幻无常的时尚的健康方法——但他知道钱德勒并不是在真空中成长的，它的成功取决于它承诺提供一种明显更好的信息组织方法。

Such products didn’t instantly seize a mass market, but they won the embrace of enthusiastic early adopters—geeks and technology writers who raved about them in their blogs and helped spark the sense that a whole new generation of software was on the rise. Kapor had always taken the long view—a healthy approach for dealing with the technology industry’s fickle fads—but he knew that Chandler wasn’t growing in a vacuum and that its success depended on its promise of a markedly better approach to organizing information.

与我交谈过的几位友好的 OSAF 观察员更直率地表达了这种担忧：如果钱德勒不赶快行动，就有可能变得无关紧要。

Several friendly observers of OSAF that I talked to expressed the fear more bluntly: If Chandler didn’t hurry up, it risked being irrelevant.





9 月 7 日，凯蒂·帕兰特 (Katie Parlante)、丽莎·杜索 (Lisa Dusseault)、赵林 (Chao Lam) 和希拉·穆尼 (Sheila Mooney) 在一整天的会议结束后聚集在一起，召开他们所谓的“粗磨计划会议”。

On September 7, Katie Parlante, Lisa Dusseault, Chao Lam, and Sheila Mooney gather at the end of a long day of meetings for what they’re calling a “kibble planning session.”

“Kibble”是 Chandler 团队为其产品的第一个可狗食版本所采用的非正式名称 - 还不是 Canoga，而是他们每天都可以使用的软件版本。里面到底会是什么？需要多长时间？他们将如何到达那里？

“Kibble” is the informal name the Chandler team has adopted for their product’s first dogfoodable release—not yet Canoga but a version of the software that they can use themselves every day. What exactly will be in it? How long is it going to take? And how will they get there?

两周后，卡普尔和林将在大学联盟 CSG 会见 OSAF 的支持者。他们想要一个清晰的计划来呈现。林通过电子邮件向他的同事发送了一份巨大的电子表格，其中详尽地汇编了钱德勒的整套功能，然后将它们分解为需要完成才能使其发挥作用的数十个单独任务。

In two weeks, Kapor and Lam are set to meet with OSAF’s backers at CSG, the university consortium. They want a clear plan to present. Lam has emailed his colleagues an enormous spreadsheet that exhaustively compiles Chandler’s entire set of features and then breaks them down into the scores of individual tasks that need to be completed to get them to work.

这是一份令人眼花缭乱的文件。四个人围坐在大会议桌旁，盯着笔记本电脑屏幕上的网格。

It is an eye-glazing document. The four sit around the big conference table and stare at the grids on their laptop screens.

“审查这些东西需要多长时间？” 杜梭问道。“需要接下来整整两周吗？”

“How much time will it take to review this stuff?” Dusseault asks. “Will it take the entire next two weeks?”

“你还有其他选择吗？” 帕兰特回答道。

“Do you have an alternative?” Parlante replies.

杜索思考电子表格的行和列。“我们需要某种方式来了解版本有多大，将功能放入相似大小的桶中。这种格式并不能真正让我们比较事物。我们拥有的唯一真实数据点是我们在过去的版本中能够实现的目标。

Dusseault ponders the spreadsheet’s rows and columns. “We need some way of understanding how big a release is, of putting features in similar size buckets. This format doesn’t really allow us to compare things. The only real data point we have is how much we were able to achieve in past releases.

“我们可以做的一件事是，”她建议，“将所有内容都放在便利贴上，其中每个注释代表大致均匀的粒度。” 一张便利贴就代表了一个开发人员一两个月的时间。他们将按“点释放”方式将笔记放在墙上。然后他们就能一目了然地知道自己每一轮计划完成多少，是否现实。

“One thing we could do,” she suggests, “is put it all on stickies, where each note represents roughly even granularity.” One Post-it note would represent one or two months of a single developer’s time. They would lay the notes out on the wall organized by “dot release.” Then they could see at a glance how much they had planned to accomplish in each round and whether they were being realistic.

“白板上的便签？” 希拉·穆尼说道。“我以前也这么做过。在我上一份工作中，我们所做的一切都是这样的。”

“Stickies on a whiteboard?” Sheila Mooney says. “I’ve done that before. We did everything that way at my last job.”

有那么一刻，他们似乎要把这个练习安排在另一次会议上——时间是下午 5:00之后。米。已经。但杜塞尔却跑出去，带着一堆便利贴回来。她清理了房间前面长白板的左侧三分之一，并在上面画了四个垂直列，分别标记为 0.4、0.5、0.6 和 0.7。然后，她又画了两条水平线，将列分为顶部、中间和底部，分别对应 OSAF 的三个开发组（应用程序、服务和存储库）。

For a minute it seemed like they’re going to schedule that exercise for yet another meeting—it’s after 5:00 P.M. already. But instead Dusseault runs out and returns with a pile of Post-it pads. She clears the left third of the long whiteboard at the front of the room and draws four vertical columns on it, labeled 0.4, 0.5, 0.6, and 0.7. Then she draws two more horizontal lines, dividing the columns into top, middle, and bottom, corresponding to each of OSAF’s three development groups—apps, services, and repository.

杜索、帕兰特和穆尼开始在便利贴上做标记并将其粘贴到白板上。他们商讨名称、位置以及是否将一些特别困难的任务分成两张便签。“核心版本控制是否太大了？” “搜索应该是一两个音符吗？”

Dusseault, Parlante, and Mooney start marking up stickies and affixing them to the whiteboard. They confer about names, placement, and whether to divide some extra-difficult tasks into two stickies. “Is core versioning too big an item?” “Should search be one or two notes?”

黑板上充满了刻有黑色记号笔的黄色便签簇。少量蓝色代表后端任务，即不涉及任何用户界面工作的编程作业。少数紫色代表涉及项目基础设施的工作，例如源代码控制系统和构建系统。

The board fills up with clusters of yellow stickies inscribed with black markers. A smaller number of blue ones represent back-end tasks—programming jobs that don’t involve any user interface work. A smattering of purple ones stand for work involving the project’s infrastructure, like the source code control system and the build system.

十五分钟之内，他们就写完了五十个音符。到了半小时，已经突破一百了。

Within fifteen minutes they have fifty notes up. By the half-hour mark it’s pushing one hundred.

穆尼回头一笑：“科技在起作用！”

Mooney turns around with a grin: “Technology at work!”

当经理们按照 Lam 的清单工作时，他们能够划掉一些已经被取消或推迟的功能，或者根本不需要实现 Dogfood 的想法，比如 Mimi Yin 提出的“鱼眼视图”，这会将信息的呈现集中在最相关的项目或“项目对话”上，用户可以将其附加到共享项目上，类似于即时消息的小注释。他们放弃的每一项功能都意味着至少少一个或更多的便签纸。但到最后他们仍然有 138 个音符：27 个低于 0.4；27 个低于 0.4；27 个低于 0.4。45 低于 0.5；33 低于 0.6；0.7 及以上为 33。

As the managers work from Lam’s list, they’re able to cross off a number of features that had already been canceled or postponed or that simply aren’t necessary to achieve dogfood—ideas like a “fisheye view” that Mimi Yin had proposed, which would concentrate the presentation of information on the most relevant items, or “item conversations,” little instant-message-like annotations that users could append to shared items. Each feature they drop means at least one fewer sticky note or maybe more. But by the end they’ve still got 138 notes: 27 under 0.4; 45 under 0.5; 33 under 0.6; and 33 for 0.7 and beyond.

他们从会议桌上拉开椅子，坐在粘满粘糊糊的木板前，凝视着。

They pull chairs over from the conference table, sit in front of the sticky-laden board, and stare.

Mooney 说道：“特别令人难过的是 0.4 桶”——代表当前版本即将完成的工作——“里面的东西最少。” 与此同时，0.5桶已满。

Mooney speaks up: “It’s particularly sad that the 0.4 bucket”—the one representing work completed on the nearly finished current release—“has the least things in it.” Meanwhile, the 0.5 bucket is overflowing.

“我们希望 0.5 比 0.4 短，”Dusseault 说。“所以看起来我们的粗磨计划至少还需要三个 0.4 秒。0.4 花了我们八个月的时间。”

“And we intended 0.5 to be shorter than 0.4,” Dusseault says. “So it looks like our kibble plan will take at least three more 0.4s. And 0.4 has taken us eight months.”

“我不认为它们都是同类比较，”帕兰特反对道。“有新人消化。有一个相当长的规划阶段。”

“I don’t think they’re all apples-to-apples comparisons,” Parlante objects. “There was new people digestion. There was a pretty long planning phase.”

“根据我们正在努力做的事情，我仍然认为两年的粗磨并不是不合理的，”杜索说。

“I still think two years for kibble is not unreasonable, based on what we’re trying to do,” Dusseault says.

林抬起手中的下巴。“我认为米奇认为是明年的某个时候。”

Lam lifts his chin from his hands. “I think Mitch has the idea that it’s sometime next year.”

“我想，如果我们说需要两年时间来完成所有这些工作，我们将开始从我们所谓的粗磨食品中削减一些东西，”杜塞尔回答道。“别忘了，粗磨就是我们所说的。”

“I assume if we say it’s two years to do all that, we’re going to start cutting some things out of what we call kibble,” Dusseault replies. “Don’t forget, kibble is whatever we say it is.”

“最大的指导原则是，至少我们 OSAF 内部可以日常使用它，”Lam 说。

“The biggest guiding principle is that at least we ourselves within OSAF can use it day to day,” says Lam.

“那么有些事情我们不需要做。就像 PDA 同步一样——与移动设备（个人数字助理）同步。

“Then some of that we don’t need to do. Like PDA sync”—synchronization with mobile devices (Personal Digital Assistants).

“这取决于您是否是 PDA 用户。”

“That depends if you’re a PDA user or not.”

“对于这些贴纸来说，至少需要两年。”

“Two years is a minimum for this number of stickies.”

“你还假设我们在这方面没有做得更好。”

“You’re also assuming we don’t get better at it.”

“但是你并没有提高每个程序员的生产力。记住神话般的人月。还要记住，由于我们需要维护更多代码，因此需要修复的错误数量也会增加。”

“But you don’t get increased productivity per programmer. Remember The Mythical Man-Month. Also remember the increased number of bugs to fix as we have more code to maintain.”

穆尼说：“我们还招聘了多少新员工？”

Mooney says, “We also have how many new people we’re hiring?”

“我不希望任何人认为我们可以通过招聘来加快 0.5 的速度，”Dusseault 说。“那将是一个错误。我想象您添加的人员将承担增加的维护工作。我发现很难解释其中任何一个，所以我希望它们能够相互抵消。”

“I don’t want anyone to think that we can make 0.5 come in any faster by hiring,” Dusseault says. “That would be a mistake. I was imagining that the people you’re adding would be covering the increased maintenance. I find it hard to account for either of those, so I’m kind of hoping that they cancel each other out.”

“如果我们以两倍的速度招聘怎么办？” 林问道。

“What if we were hiring at twice the rate?” Lam asks.

“在第一年，这会让我们放慢速度，”杜索说。“甚至两年。” 三年了，一切开始有了回报。”

“Over the first year it would slow us down,” Dusseault says. “Two years, even. Three years, it starts to pay off.”

“那就刮一下吧。” 林微笑。“好的。嗯，这很有用。至少我们有一个数字。”

“Then scratch that.” Lam smiles. “Okay. Well, this was useful. At least we have a number.”

Lam 和 Dusseault 正在重演一场典型的对话：产品经理和开发经理之间的拉锯战。它发生在无数软件项目的无数会议室中。事情总是这样的：

Lam and Dusseault were reenacting an archetypal dialogue: the tug-of-war between product manager and development manager. It has occurred in countless meeting rooms at countless software projects. It always goes like this:



产品经理：太长！我们就不能动作快一点吗？
开发经理：这就是需要多长时间。
产品经理：我们就不能做得更好吗？
开发经理：如果我们真的很好，我们可以知道需要多长时间，但我们无法改变它。


两年磨一磨。如果他们削减功能并降低视野，那就更少了。

Two years to kibble. Less, if they cut features and lower their sights.

他们同意林将向卡普尔通报这一消息。没有人指望他会高兴地迎接它。

They agree that Lam will break the news to Kapor. No one expects him to greet it with joy.

当它们列队出来时，穆尼在白板顶部用大写字母写道：请勿擦除。

As they file out, Mooney writes, in big capital letters at the top of the whiteboard: DO NOT ERASE.





周四，当 OSAF 工作人员聚集在一起参加下一次“全体会议”时，一大堆便签纸仍然覆盖着白板的一端。顶部有一丛黄色音符，下面有一条较细的蓝色音符，偶尔散落着一些紫色音符，它看起来有点像旧版《太空入侵者》视频游戏的屏幕，但没有底部可以拾取的枪目标行。不容错过。它需要解释。

On Thursday, as the OSAF staff assembles for the next “all-hands” meeting, the swarm of sticky notes still covers one end of the whiteboard. With a thicket of yellow notes along the top, a thinner band of blue ones below, and an occasional purple one scattered about, it looks a bit like the screen of an old Space Invaders video game, minus the gun at the bottom to pick off the rows of targets. It can’t be missed. It demands explanation.

会议开始时，卡普尔向董事会挥手。“这代表了最复杂、最先进的长期工程管理工具。” 笑声在房间里荡漾。“这也代表着一种成就。这是一个有用的练习，可以开始划分出主要的工作块，让我们快速消化。好消息是该流程现已存在。相关工作正在进行中。但显然，我们需要严格消除非必要的功能，以便在合理的时间内达到我们想要的目标。”

Kapor waves his hand toward the board as the meeting begins. “This represents the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art, long-term engineering management tool.” Laughs ripple through the room. “It also represents an accomplishment. It’s a useful exercise to start blocking out the major chunks of work to get us to kibble. The good news is that the process now exists. Work is being done on it. But it certainly appears that we need to be rigorous about eliminating nonessential features in order to get where we want to be in a reasonable amount of time.”

接下来，Chao Lam 回顾了可能成为“尽快粗磨”新推动的牺牲品的产品功能列表：联系人管理（您的地址簿）。即时通讯。Mimi Yin 的类似 iTunes 的浏览器。日历中的月份视图。在 Chandler 中将电子邮件附件视为真实项目。

Next, Chao Lam reviews a list of product features that may become casualties of the new push for “kibble sooner”: Contact management (your address book). Instant messaging. Mimi Yin’s iTunes-like browser. The month view in the calendar. Treating email attachments as real items in Chandler.

“它们就像我的小狗，”卡普尔说。“这感觉就像把其中一些放在架子上一样。”

“These are like my puppies,” Kapor says. “This feels like putting some of them on the shelf.”

房间里一片寂静。很难说程序员们是因为现实主义的出现而松了一口气，还是因为削减了多少而感到失望。

The room is silent. It’s hard to tell whether the programmers are relieved that, well, realism has set in—or disappointed at how much has been axed.

“可以公平地说，我们真正想做的一些创新将在第一个版本中消失。我们贪多嚼不烂。该产品将比我们最初希望的更加普通，并且与其前身更加相似。另一方面，仍然有超过临界数量的重要新功能：仪表板视图、摆脱孤岛和共享。我们声称正在做新的有趣的事情仍然站得住脚。要缩小范围以尽快推出产品将是一项挑战。”

“It would be fair to say that some of the innovation we really wanted to do will slip out of the first release. We bit off more than we could chew. The product is going to be more vanilla than we had originally hoped and more similar to its predecessors. On the other hand, there’s still more than a critical mass of important new features: the dashboard view, getting away from silos, and sharing. Our claim to be doing new interesting stuff will still stand up. It’s just going to be challenging to get things narrowed down enough to get a product out sooner rather than later.”

在当月晚些时候向 OSAF 小型董事会做的演讲中，卡普尔回顾了钱德勒为何迟到的一系列解释：他们低估了该项目雄心勃勃的成本。事实证明，建立一个工程组织比预期的要困难。开发“富客户端”软件在任何地方都很困难——“不仅仅是我们。” 就个人而言：“我知道的比我想象的要少。或者说我已经生锈了。”

In a presentation to OSAF’s small board of directors later that month, Kapor reviewed a set of explanations for why Chandler was so late: They had underestimated the cost of the project’s big ambitions. It had proved harder than expected to build an engineering organization. Developing “rich client” software was hard everywhere—“It’s not just us.” And on the personal side: “I knew less than I thought. Or I was rusty.”

没有人可以指责卡普尔回避了最不愉快的领导力考验——坦白承认失败和失误。但他有一种方法来承认挫折，而不让它们使他脱轨或士气低落。他泰然自若地接受了便利贴会议上的坏消息。他不会为他的员工粉饰粉饰。不管怎样，他们太聪明了，不适合粗鲁的旋转。但他以一种现实的乐观态度来描述这一切——让我们一睹二十年前将小莲花打造成成功巨人所需的品质。

No one could accuse Kapor of ducking the least pleasant test of leadership—coming clean about failures and failings. But he had a way of acknowledging setbacks without letting them derail or demoralize him. He had taken the bad news from the stickies meeting in stride. He wouldn’t sugarcoat it for his staff; they were too smart for crude spin anyway. But he framed it with a kind of reality-tempered optimism—offering a glimpse of the qualities it must have taken two decades before to build little Lotus into a successful giant.





开发经理和卡普尔在下周讨论了他们的选择。Kapor 对每个后续版本都需要长达 0.4 八个月的假设提出了质疑，并开始提出替代方案。一个想法是完全放弃 Canoga 1.0 版本的想法。相反，开发人员将一心一意地致力于发布可狗食的粗磨版本，一旦经过 OSAF 和其他勇敢的灵魂的现场测试，就可以将其改进为令人尊敬的 Chandler 1.0。然后他们将前往以大学为中心的 Westwood 发行版。

The development managers and Kapor debated their options over the next week. Kapor challenged the assumption that each subsequent release would take as long as 0.4’s eight months and began to lay out alternative scenarios. One idea was to drop the idea of a Canoga 1.0 release entirely. Instead, the developers would work single-mindedly toward the dogfoodable kibble release, which could be refined into a respectable Chandler 1.0 once it had been field-tested by OSAF and brave souls beyond. Then they would march on to the university-focused Westwood release.

另一个重要想法是推迟实施电子邮件的严肃工作，并专注于构建可用的日历。赵林在一份题为“令人发指的问题”的备忘录中首次提出了这一点，并引起了愤怒。用杜塞尔的话来说，感觉好像“把愿景破坏得太远了”。Parlante 指出，生产可狗食的 Chandler 所需的大部分工作只是使应用程序足够稳定以供使用，无论他们以什么顺序构建 PIM 功能块（日历、电子邮件、任务、和注释）。

The other big idea was to postpone serious work on implementing email and concentrate on building a usable calendar. Chao Lam first proposed this in a memo titled Outrageous Questions, and it raised hackles. It felt as if, in Dusseault’s words, it might be “gutting the vision too far.” Parlante pointed out that much of the work needed to produce a dogfoodable Chandler lay in simply making the application stable enough to use, and that had to be done regardless of what order they built the chunks of the PIM functionality (calendar, email, tasks, and notes).

但卡普尔认为，推迟在 Chandler 中构建电子邮件可以帮助他们更快地交付工作软件，这是正确的优先事项。因此，他们在便利贴板上画了一条新线，将制作有效日历所需的所有任务与其他任务分开，并开始了一个后来被称为“便利贴重构”的过程——揭开并重新粘贴便条。

But Kapor argued that postponing building email into Chandler could help them deliver working software sooner, and that was the right priority. So they drew a new line across the stickies board to separate all the tasks required to produce a functioning calendar from everything else, and began a process that came to be known as “stickie refactoring”—unpeeling and repasting notes.

在 2005 年底之前，他们在一年左右的时间里可以完成多少工作以生产出可工作的粗磨版本？

How much could they accomplish in a year or so to produce a working kibble release by the end of 2005?

杜塞尔指着白板上的线上方区域，即 0.5、0.6 和 0.7 标题下的仅日历功能：“这里、这里和这里我们一年内可以做的事情。还有一些这样的。” 这是 Chandler 的其他功能中仅日历线下方的一桶。

Dusseault pointed to the above-the-line areas on the whiteboard, the calendar-only features under the 0.5, 0.6, and 0.7 headings: “The stuff that’s here, here, and here we can do in a year. And also some of this.” This was one bucket of the rest of the Chandler features below the calendar-only line.

在 9 月 16 日举行的下一次全体会议上，卡普尔制定了新计划：禁止卡诺加。狗食或半身像。首先是日历功能。“好消息是，人们越来越乐观地认为我们可以在 2005 年底之前交付一些有意义的东西。这项工作仍在进行中。说我们有工作计划是错误的。但这是我们的假设。”

At the next all-hands meeting, on September 16, Kapor laid out the new program: No Canoga. Dogfood or bust. Calendar features first. “The good news is, there’s a growing optimism that we can ship something meaningful by the end of 2005. It’s still a work in progress. It would be a mistake to say we have a working plan. But that’s our hypothesis.”

这个消息并没有让房间里的任何人感到震惊，但仍然发人深省。还有很长的路要走。但至少第一次，他们可以看到他们有一个基于现实的计划，植根于与他们在代码中实现一项功能实际花费多长时间的记录有某种关系的估计。他们不再基于希望和声明进行“自上而下”的计划；他们根据经验和证据进行“自下而上”的计划。

The news was hardly a shock to anyone in the room, but it was sobering nonetheless. There was still so far to go. But for the first time, at least, they could see they had a plan grounded in reality, rooted in estimates that bore some relationship to the record of how long it actually took them to implement a feature in code. They were no longer planning “top down,” based on hopes and pronouncements; they were planning “bottom up,” based on experience and evidence.

在这一时期的所有调整中，卡普尔一直在 OSAF 之外的一种现象中找到安慰：Mozilla 项目通过其 Firefox 浏览器取得了成功。Firefox 是旧版 Mozilla 软件的精简版、现代化版本，是从 Netscape 的废墟中发展而来的，计划于当年秋天晚些时候发布 1.0 版。但即使在预发布版本中，它每周的下载量也达到了 100 万次，并赢得了好评如潮。它是免费的开源软件。它是从一个轨迹与钱德勒惊人相似的项目中诞生的。Mozilla 最初在极客精英中大肆宣扬和热情，但随后多年陷入黑洞，失去了一些关键开发人员的忠诚，并被广泛淘汰。Mozilla 似乎一次又一次地错失良机。有了 Firefox，它的船终于来了。

Through all the sail-trimming in this period, Kapor had been finding solace in a phenomenon entirely outside OSAF: the rising tide of success that the Mozilla Project had found with its Firefox browser. Firefox, a streamlined, modernized version of the old Mozilla software that had evolved from the ashes of Netscape, had a 1.0 release scheduled for later that fall. But even in its prerelease version it was logging a million downloads a week and winning rave reviews. It was free open source software. And it had emerged out of a project whose trajectory eerily resembled Chandler’s. Mozilla had begun with great fanfare and enthusiasm among the geek elite and then dropped into a black hole for years in which it lost the allegiance of some key developers and was widely written off. Over and over again, it seemed, Mozilla had missed the boat; with Firefox, its ship finally came in.

前 Netscape 律师米切尔·贝克 (Mitchell Baker) 作为行政人员和经理的努力帮助 Mozilla 度过了黑暗的岁月，并继续担任 OSAF 的社区顾问。当钱德勒开发者会议试图消化卡普尔关于他们的日程安排的令人沮丧的消息时，她说道：“在 Mozilla 项目的早期阶段，也有过类似的讨论。但这是相当不正常的。我们损失了很多时间，其中一些是因为技术，但大部分是因为无法将管理（当时是 Netscape 的管理）与关键的工程力量联系起来。”

Mitchell Baker, the former Netscape lawyer whose efforts as an administrator and manager helped keep Mozilla alive through its dark years, had continued to serve as a kind of community adviser to OSAF. As the meeting of Chandler developers tried to digest the discouraging news from Kapor about their schedule, she spoke up: “In the early phases of the Mozilla Project, there were discussions similar to this. But it was pretty dysfunctional. We lost a lot of time, some of it to the technology but a lot of it to the inability to get management—which in those days was Netscape management—connected with the key engineering forces.”

“你是如何走上正确道路的？” OSAF 的营销人员 Pieter Hartsook 问道。

“How did you get on the right path?” Pieter Hartsook, OSAF’s marketing guy, asked.

Baker 谈到了 Mozilla 开发人员决定从头开始重写浏览器的“布局引擎”，即在屏幕上绘制网页的代码。这一选择花费了该项目多年的时间，而且外界也经常批评它。尽管如此，她说，“做出布局决定才是关键——即使它可能是错误的。然后找出有效的工程流程。第三件事是，只要取得足够的进展，就能做出一些基本上有效的东西。”

Baker talked about the Mozilla developers’ decision to rewrite from scratch the browser’s “layout engine,” the code that draws Web pages on screen. The choice cost the project years, and outsiders often criticized it. Still, she said, “just making that layout decision was key—even if it might have been the wrong one. And then figuring out an engineering process that worked. And then the third thing was, just getting far enough along to have something that basically works.”

卡普尔点点头。“这听起来很熟悉吗？”

Kapor nodded. “Does this sound familiar?”

“就像我参与过的每个软件项目一样，”约翰·安德森带着宿命般的微笑说道。

“Like every software project I’ve ever worked on,” John Anderson said with a fatalistic smile.





OSAF 仍然是一个令人愉快的工作场所。午餐很好，工作时间很人性化，气氛也非常好。但延误和裁员对员工造成了一些损失。布莱恩·斯金纳 (Brian Skinner) 在夏初休假，对缓慢的进度感到沮丧，并因自己从未能够在该项目中开辟出属于自己的一块而感到沮丧。他决定不再回来。随着秋天的到来，斯图尔特·帕门特 (Stuart Parmenter) 宣布他也将离开，加入 Oracle 赞助的一个开源日历项目。大约在同一时间，赵林决定减少参与。他会继续留在钱德勒，但想探索再次创办自己的公司。希拉·穆尼 (Sheila Mooney) 接任项目经理一职。不久之后，达基·舍伍德决定回到学校攻读计算机科学学位。

OSAF remained a congenial workplace. The lunches were good, the hours were humane, and the atmosphere was unfailingly nice. But delay and retrenchment took some toll on the staff. Brian Skinner had gone on leave at the start of the summer, frustrated by the slow pace and discouraged that he had never been able to carve out a piece of the project to call his own. He decided not to return. As the fall progressed, Stuart Parmenter announced he was going to leave, too—to join an open source calendaring project that Oracle was sponsoring. Around the same time Chao Lam decided to scale back his involvement; he would keep his hand in Chandler but wanted to explore starting up his own company again. Sheila Mooney stepped into his role as project manager. Soon after, Ducky Sherwood decided to go back to school for a computer science degree.

在项目漫长的生命周期的起起落落中激励程序员及其经理是一门神秘的艺术。尽管 OSAF 发生了很多人员流动，但钱德勒周围似乎仍然有足够的吸引力来吸引人才。但让他们充满活力的并不是日历上相对平凡的工作。

Motivating programmers and their managers through the ups and downs of a project’s long life cycle is a mysterious art. For all the turnover at OSAF, there still seemed to be enough magnetism around Chandler to hold talented people. But it wasn’t the relatively mundane work on the calendar that kept them charged up.

钱德勒一直过着双重生活：在一个愿景中，它是一个供用户管理信息的软件应用程序，在另一个愿景中，它是一个“应用程序框架”或“平台”，是开发人员可以不断添加很酷的新东西的基础。由于 Kapor 和 OSAF 团队逐渐勉强地接受了他们无法同时完成所有事情，因此他们选择将应用程序放在第一位。“软件更快可用！” 他们从经验中知道，这可能是明智的选择。但他们仍然梦想建立更大的平台——一个开放式的、改变世界的工具，通过添加正确的代码，可以组织和连接各种不同的数据。

Chandler had always led a double life: In one vision it was a software application for users to manage information, and in the other it was an “application framework” or “platform,” a foundation on which developers could keep adding cool new stuff. Since Kapor and the OSAF team had gradually and grudgingly come to accept that they couldn’t do everything at once, they had chosen to put the application first. “Working software sooner!” They knew from experience that this was probably the smart choice. But they still dreamed about building the bigger platform—the open-ended, world-changing tool that, with the right additions of code, could organize and connect all sorts of disparate data.

丽莎·杜塞尔 (Lisa Dusseault) 对将钱德勒 (Chandler) 连接到 CalDAV 感到兴奋，使其能够与更广泛的日历软件进行互操作。Donn Denman 即将开始为期六个月的陪产假，但当他回来时，他渴望开始在 Chandler 中构建脚本功能，最终允许非程序员实现自动化。Andi Vajda 已经将他所做的将 Python 和 Lucene 搜索引擎集成到 OSAF 旗下名为 PyLucene 的新开源项目中进行了剥离，他梦想将 Chandler 存储库转变为比其他项目更独立的软件或许能够使用。

Lisa Dusseault was fired up about hooking Chandler to CalDAV, making it interoperable with a wider universe of calendar software. Donn Denman was about to start a six-month paternity leave, but when he got back, he was eager to begin building a scripting function into Chandler that would eventually allow nonprogrammers to automate it. Andi Vajda, who had already spun off the work he had done to integrate Python and the Lucene search engine into a new open source project under the OSAF umbrella named PyLucene, dreamed of turning the Chandler repository into a more independent piece of software that other projects might be able to use.

在 Denman 展示他的工作冲压代码的同一次会议上，Morgen Sagen 向工作人员展示了另一个演示。他想为他的家人创建一个照片博客（照片网络日记），并且对可用的软件不满意，因此他“决定使用 Python 来创建自己的软件”，他解释道。他需要一个数据库来存储照片。以及 Web 服务代码。“我意识到，等一下！我知道哪个项目已经做到了这一切？” （现在已合并到 Chandler 中的 Twisted 网络代码附带了自己的 Web 服务器。）

At the same meeting where Denman showed off his working stamping code, Morgen Sagen presented another demo to the staff. He had wanted to start a photo blog—a Web diary of photographs—for his family and wasn’t happy with the available software, so he “decided to roll my own with Python,” he explained. He needed a database to store the photos. And Web-serving code. “And I realized, Wait a second! What project do I know that already does all this?” (The Twisted networking code that was now incorporated in Chandler came with its own Web server.)

因此，当他的同事全神贯注地观看时，萨根展示了他的新照片博客（充满了他年幼孩子的照片的页面），该博客建立在 Chandler 之上，照片存储和组织在 Chandler 应用程序内，但发布在网络上供任何人查看。

So as his colleagues watched, rapt, Sagen showed his new photo blog—pages filled with pictures of his young children—built on top of Chandler, with the photos stored and organized inside the Chandler application but published on the Web for anyone to see.

这本身并没有什么特别的。而且它仍然是粗糙的、未完成的。但对于这群人来说，它是对他们一直在努力实现的未来的诱人预览，而这个未来仍然令人痛苦地遥远。

It was nothing extraordinary in itself. And it was still crude and unfinished. But for this group of people it served as a tantalizing preview of a future they had been working toward—one that still felt painfully distant.

有人问：“你做这件事花了多长时间？”

Somebody asked, “How long did it take you to do this?”

“大约两个小时，”萨根回答道。

“About two hours,” Sagen replied.

第9章                           

CHAPTER 9                           

方法

METHODS









还记得质量三角——时间、金钱、功能或质量吗？到 2004 年秋天，也就是钱德勒首次公开宣布加入的两年后，OSAF 在其三个方面的表现都不是特别好。快速地？几乎不。便宜的？几百万美元，但到目前为止，还没有什么可展示的。好的？这还有待观察。

Remember the quality triangle—time, money, and features or quality? By the fall of 2004, two years after the first public announcement of Chandler, OSAF wasn’t faring especially well on any of its three sides. Fast? Hardly. Cheap? Several million dollars and, so far, not much to show. Good? That remained to be seen.

当 Chandler 0.4 于 2004 年 10 月 26 日发布时，第一周大约有 1000 人下载了它，而在最初的 24 小时内就有 15000 人匆忙查看 Chandler 0.1。当您启动最新的工作时，它开始看起来更像是一个真正的软件应用程序，并且它内置了一些新功能，如果您愿意挖掘，您可以测试它们。它第一次具有部分工作的详细视图，您可以标记项目以将其从一种类型更改为另一种类型。

When Chandler 0.4 was released on October 26, 2004, about one thousand people downloaded it the first week compared with the fifteen thousand who had rushed to check out Chandler 0.1 in the first twenty-four hours. The latest work in progress was beginning to look a little more like a real software application when you started it up, and it had some new functions built into it that you could test if you were willing to dig. It had a partially working detail view for the first time, and you could stamp items to change them from one type to another.

但对于基本的日常任务——发送或接收电子邮件、存储日历信息和组织笔记——Chandler 的表现仍然不够好，任何人都无法尝试使用它。它甚至不能被自己的程序员吃掉。启动花了很长时间，而且经常崩溃。

But for basic everyday tasks—sending or receiving email, storing calendar information, and organizing notes—Chandler still didn’t work well enough for anyone to try to use it. It wasn’t even dogfoodable by its own programmers. It took forever to start up, and it crashed a lot.

难怪下载数量下降了。至少现在，世界已经向前发展了。许多曾为该项目的启动欢呼雀跃的局外人只是放弃了它，一些以前的参与者认为它已经迷失了方向。“在这一点上，对我来说，这看起来就像一场彻底的火车失事，”0.4 发布后不久，当我与安迪·赫茨菲尔德 (Andy Hertzfeld) 交谈时，他遗憾地摇着头说道。

No wonder the download numbers were down. For now at least, the world had moved on. Many outsiders who had cheered the project’s launch simply gave up on it, and some former participants felt it had lost its way. “It looks like a complete train wreck to me at this point,” Andy Hertzfeld said, ruefully shaking his head, when I talked to him soon after 0.4’s unveiling.

但 OSAF 第一次对这次发布感到平静。在此之前的几周，情况与疯狂相反。经理和 QA 人员（其中一人）有条不紊地审查了 Bugzilla 中未解决的错误列表，并对它们进行了“分类”：这个本周得到修复；这个已经修复。那是微不足道的。我们将把这个押注到下一个版本；这个问题是真正的“阻碍因素”，必须予以修复。应用程序团队（负责 Chandler 的用户界面方面，需要修复最多的错误）有条不紊地缩减了列表。设计团队早在 0.4 完成之前就开始计划 0.5，而那些不热衷于 bug 的开发人员也开始致力于他们的 0.5 项目。

But for the first time there was a sense of calm at OSAF surrounding the release. The weeks leading up to it were the opposite of frantic. The managers and QA staff (of one) methodically reviewed the list of open bugs in Bugzilla and “triaged” them: This one’s getting fixed this week; that one’s trivial. This one we’ll punt to the next release; that one is a bona fide “blocker” that must be fixed. The apps team—which was responsible for the aspect of Chandler, its user interface, that had the most bugs to fix—methodically whittled down the list. The design team began planning 0.5 well before 0.4’s completion, and the developers who weren’t hip deep in bugs began working on their 0.5 projects.

OSAF 可能还没有可以向世界提供的产品。但它还有其他东西：一个过程的开始，一种可能引导其实现这一目标的工作方法。

OSAF may not yet have had a product to deliver to the world. But it had something else: the beginnings of a process, a working methodology that might carry it toward that goal.

呃，等一下，你可能会说。他们已经干了两年了，没有流程？这并不完全正确。OSAF 有很多流程，也许太多了，而且这些流程有时看起来就像钱德勒的代码一样流动且可以修改。但在 0.4 的八个月里发生了一些变化；该项目最终减少了即兴创作，并开发了一些可以信赖的结构组织机制，无需每隔几个月重建一次，也无需为每个新版本重新启动引擎。

Uh, wait a minute, you may well say. They had been working for two years without a process? That’s not exactly true. OSAF had plenty of processes, maybe too many, and the processes sometimes seemed as fluid and open to revision as Chandler’s code. But something changed during the eight months of 0.4; the project finally cut down on improvisation and developed some structure—organizational machinery that could be counted on to roll forward without having to be rebuilt every few months or needing its engine restarted for each new release.

从钱德勒成立之初起，卡普尔就一直坚持努力制定诚实、现实的计划和时间表，但在会议时间表方面，该项目的记录却很糟糕。它可靠地平均每六个月发布一次，但其计划仍然假设发布可以在三到四个月内完成。也许部分问题在于，在软件开发中，就像在所有事情中一样，计划对未来看得越远，就越危险。正如丽莎·杜索所说，“你必须意识到，无论你当前的计划是什么，如果放眼一年，它可能真的很糟糕。”

From the earliest days of Chandler, Kapor had been adamant about trying to draw up plans and schedules that were honest and realistic, and yet when it came to meeting schedules, the project had a poor record. It was reliably averaging one release every six months, yet its plans continued to assume releases could be finished in three or four. Part of the problem, perhaps, was that in software development, as in all things, plans get dodgier the farther into the future one looks. As Lisa Dusseault put it, “You have to be aware that whatever your current plan is, if it’s looking a year out, it probably really sucks.”

在遇到这种令人沮丧的现实时，钱德勒与大多数软件项目没有什么不同。一群软件开发人员随着时间的推移一起开发一系列项目的情况很少见。在这一点上，他们不太像运动队、军事单位或乐团，而更像是专业人士的力量，他们聚集起来制作一部电影，然后分散并重新组合以拍摄下一部电影。因此，虽然个体程序员和经理可能拥有丰富的经验和过去对他们很有帮助的技术知识，但每次他们与新团队开始一个新项目时，他们很可能最终会按下重置按钮并必须从首要原则出发设计一个工作流程。

In encountering this discouraging reality, Chandler was no different from the great majority of software projects. It’s rare for a group of software developers to work together on a series of projects over time; in this they are less like sports teams or military units or musical ensembles and more like the forces of pros who assemble to make a movie and then disperse and recombine for the next film. So, while individual programmers and managers may carry with them a wealth of experience and knowledge of techniques that served them well in the past, each time they begin a new project with a new team, they are likely to end up pressing the reset button and having to devise a working process from first principles.

由于成功的流程很难弄清楚——即使公司或团队想出了一个流程，他们通常也缺乏重复使用它的机构记忆——软件行业发明了一整套“方法论”。将它们视为冻干流程，软件成功的秘诀。有些程序员对它们非常信赖——有时一次一个，有时则混杂。许多其他人对他们独特的才能应该屈服于任何程序束缚的想法嗤之以鼻。

Since a successful process is tough to figure out—and even after companies or teams come up with one, they usually lack the institutional memory to reuse it—the software profession has invented a whole host of “methodologies.” Think of them as freeze-dried processes, recipes for software success. Some programmers swear by them—sometimes one at a time, sometimes promiscuously. Many others look down their noses at the very idea that their unique talents should submit to any procedural yoke.

从行业的早期开始，一种或另一种方法的倡导者就承诺，它本身就是按时、按预算、更少错误地交付软件项目的关键。这种一刀切的说法的问题在于，没有一种方法可以适用于广泛的软件项目。对于供数百万消费者使用的产品（旧的收缩包装软件市场）有意义的东西可能对于为在一家公司内部使用而编写的软件来说没有意义。供整个政府机构使用的程序对其开发人员的要求与音频后期制作等专业产品不同。在个人计算机上使用的软件与在手机或嵌入式电子设备（汽车或安全系统内运行的系统）中使用的软件不同。最佳实践的处方不提供补充。银子弹不会重新装弹。

From the earliest days of the industry, advocates of one or another methodology have promised that it alone holds the key to bringing software projects in on time, on budget, and with fewer bugs. The problem with this one-size-fits-all rhetoric is that no one approach could possibly work across the wide range of software projects. What makes sense for a product destined for use by millions of consumers (the old shrink-wrapped software market) probably doesn’t make sense for software written to be used internally at one company. A program destined for use by an entire government agency makes different demands on its developers than a specialty product for, say, audio postproduction. Software for use on personal computers is a different beast from software for use in cell phones or embedded electronics—the systems that run inside cars or security systems. Prescriptions for best practices don’t offer refills. Silver bullets won’t reload.





当我关注着钱德勒断断续续的进展，看着项目的机器发出嘎吱声和咳嗽声时，我不断回想起我自己对软件时间的经历的反应：事情不可能总是这样。一定有人已经弄清楚了这个问题。某处有一张地图，上面有一条离开软件时间焦油坑的路径。

As I followed Chandler’s fitful progress and watched the project’s machinery sputter and cough, I kept circling back to the reactions I’d had to my own experiences with software time: It can’t always be like this. Somebody must have figured this stuff out. Somewhere there is a map with a path out of the software-time tar pit.

我开始寻找答案，拿起灯笼，在软件历史和分析的走廊里徘徊，敲门问：“有没有人可以诚实地说他知道更好的软件制作方法？”

I began to hunt for answers, picking up a lantern and wandering the corridors of software history and analysis, knocking on doors and asking, “Is there anyone who can honestly say he knows a better way to make software?”

我的探索始于 20 世纪 60 年代，在这个时代，软件的创建者首先将他们的系统思维转向他们的领域和他们自己。1968 年，Edsger Dijkstra 在ACM Communications上发表了一篇简短的文章，标题是“Go To Statement Shouldered Harmful”。在当时的许多主流编程语言中，例如 Fortran 和 Basic，计算机按顺序移动经过编号的指令语句列表，并且程序员可以使用称为 GOTO 的语句从序列中的一个点跳转到另一个点。就像电影剪辑师进行跳接一样，GOTO 只是简单地删除程序正在开发的一个故事情节，然后选择另一个故事情节。它将控制无条件地从程序中的一个点移交给另一个点，不考虑任何其他因素——既不考虑不同变量的值，也不考虑程序及其数据的状态。

My search started with the 1960s, the era in which the creators of software first turned their systematic minds to their field and themselves. In 1968, Edsger Dijkstra published a brief piece in Communications of the ACM with the puckish title “Go To Statement Considered Harmful.” In many of the dominant programming languages of the era, like Fortran and Basic, the computer moved sequentially through a list of numbered instruction statements, and the programmer could jump from one point in the sequence to another using a statement called GOTO. Like a film editor making a jump cut, GOTO simply dropped one story line that a program was developing and picked up another. It handed off control from one point in a program to another unconditionally, taking nothing else into account—neither the values of different variables nor the state of the program and its data.

“现在的 go to 语句太原始了，”Dijkstra 写道。“这太过分了，让一个人的计划变得一团糟。”

“The go to statement as it stands is just too primitive,” Dijkstra wrote. “It is too much an invitation to make a mess of one’s program.”

在六七十年代，许多程序员接受了邀请，并制造出了混乱的软件，这些软件后来被称为“意大利面条代码”。Dijsktra 和其他理论家开始设想一种更加模块化的编程风格，他们受到启发，“结构化编程”方法论的倡导者提出了一系列实践来消除程序化的瘟疫。结构化编程有几个相互竞争的流派；Dijsktra 的中心思想是将程序编写为子单元的集合，每个子单元只有一个入口点和一个出口点。Dijkstra 写道，程序可以被想象成不是一堆面条，而是一条“由单个珍珠串成的项链”，其简单性和清晰度不仅减少了出错的可能性，而且增加了程序员理解自己的作品的可能性。

In the sixties and seventies, many programmers accepted that invitation and made messes—confused tangles of software that came to be known as “spaghetti code.” Taking their cue from Dijsktra and other theorists who had begun to envision a more modular style of programming, advocates of a methodology known as “structured programming” proposed a set of practices to banish the plague of procedural pasta. There were several competing schools of structured programming; in Dijsktra’s, the central idea was to compose a program as a collection of subunits, each of which had only a single point of entry and a single point of exit. The program, Dijkstra wrote, could then be envisioned not as a pile of noodles but as a “necklace strung from individual pearls,” whose simplicity and clarity not only reduced the likelihood of error but increased the possibility that programmers could understand their own handiwork.

结构化编程以防御性蹲伏的方式提供建议，试图保护易犯错误的程序员免受自身缺陷的影响。“作为一个迟钝的人，我的脑袋很小，我最好学会忍受它，尊重我的局限性并给予充分的信任，”迪杰斯特拉写道。在获得计算机界的诺贝尔奖图灵奖后，他将 1972 年的演讲命名为“谦卑的程序员”，他的文章充满了对“可怜的程序员”的怜悯和对人类动物“无能为力”的哀叹。

Structured programming offered its recommendations from a defensive crouch, trying to protect fallible programmers from their own flaws. “As a slow-witted human being I have a very small head, and I had better learn to live with it and to respect my limitations and give them full credit,” Dijkstra wrote. On winning the Turing Award, computing’s Nobel, he titled his 1972 lecture “The Humble Programmer,” and his writing is full of swells of pity for the “poor programmer” and lamentations over the human animal’s “inability to do much.”

结构化编程的具体指令将很快被编入新一代编程语言的设计和语法中。随着程序员设计出新的方法来隔离、“模块化”和“封装”软件的移动部分，其更广泛的要求——“每个程序层都应该被自己理解”——在接下来的几十年里推动了一项又一项创新。彼此之间（以可重复使用的乐高组件为终极目标）。但与即将到来的每一项创新一样，结构化编程并没有帮助完善当时的软件。相反，它为未来更雄心勃勃的软件奠定了坚实的基础，这些程序将找到结构化编程无法想象的新方法来失败。

The specific injunctions of structured programming would quickly be codified in the design and syntax of new generations of programming languages. Its broader imperative—that “each program layer is to be understood all by itself”—has driven one innovation after another in subsequent decades as programmers have devised new ways to isolate, “modularize,” and “encapsulate” the moving parts of software from one another (with the dream of reusable Lego components as its ultimate grail). But like each of those innovations to come, structured programming didn’t help perfect the software of its day; instead, it laid a solid foundation for more ambitious software to come, and those programs would find new ways to fail that structured programming couldn’t imagine.

事实证明，与改进组织人员及其工作的方式相比，改进代码的组织方式简直是小菜一碟。随着整个六七十年代该行业的糟糕记录一直令人沮丧，新软件方法论的支持者将注意力转向了企业人性化的一面。特别是，当他们应对大型项目搁浅的趋势时，他们开始专注于改进规划流程。随着时间的推移，他们分成了两个阵营，提出了相反的建议。就像开源项目的贡献者闹翻一样，他们也分叉了。

It turned out that improving how you organize code was a cakewalk compared with improving how you organize people and their work. As the industry’s poor record held its depressing course through the sixties and seventies, the proponents of new software methodologies turned their attention to the human side of the enterprise. In particular, as they grappled with the tendency for large-scale projects to run aground, they began to focus on improving the process of planning. And, over time, they split into two camps with opposite recommendations. Like open source projects whose contributors have a falling out, they forked.

一所学校在审视规划时表示：“好的规划如此宝贵，却很难制定，你需要更努力地规划，规划更长的时间，规划更详细的规划，然后再规划！” 计划直到你无法再计划为止——然后再计划更多。” 另一所学校的本质是，“计划是不可能的，结果也是无用的，所以你应该放弃。顺其自然！编写代码，听取反馈，与客户合作，并随时进行更改。这是你唯一可以信赖的计划。” 坦率地说，我有些夸张，但这种分歧是真实存在的，大多数软件开发人员和管理人员都会因为自然倾向或痛苦的经历而偏向这一方或另一方。

One school looked at planning and said, “Good plans are so valuable and so hard to make, you need to plan harder, plan longer, plan in more detail, and plan again! Plan until you can’t plan any further—and then plan some more.” The other school said, essentially, “Planning is so impossible and the results are so useless that you should just give up. Go with the flow! Write your code, listen to feedback, work with your customers, and change it as you go along. That’s the only plan you can count on.” I’m exaggerating, plainly, but the divide is real, and most software developers and managers fall by natural inclination or bitter experience on one side of it or the other.

严格的项目管理大师瓦茨·汉弗莱 (Watts Humphrey) 提出了“必须”。计划。更多的！” 论点：“除非开发人员计划并跟踪他们的个人工作，否则该工作将是不可预测的。此外，如果开发人员个人工作的成本和进度是不可预测的，那么他们团队的工作的成本和进度也将是不可预测的。当然，当项目团队的工作不可预测时，整个项目也是不可预测的。简而言之，只要个体开发者不规划和跟踪他们的个人工作，他们的项目就会不可控、难以管理。”

Watts Humphrey, the guru of disciplined project management, lays out the “Must. Plan. More!” argument: “Unless developers plan and track their personal work, that work will be unpredictable. Furthermore, if the cost and schedule of the developers’ personal work is unpredictable, the cost and schedule of their teams’ work will also be unpredictable. And, of course, when a project team’s work is unpredictable, the entire project is unpredictable. In short, as long as individual developers do not plan and track their personal work, their projects will be uncontrollable and unmanageable.”

另一方面，当代管理学之父彼得·德鲁克（Peter Drucker）说道：“大多数关于知识工作者任务的讨论都是从规划工作的建议开始的。这听起来非常有道理。它唯一的问题是它很少起作用。计划始终停留在纸面上，始终保持良好的意愿。它们很少转化为成就。”

On the other hand, here is Peter Drucker, the father of contemporary management studies: “Most discussions of the knowledge worker’s task start with the advice to plan one’s work. This sounds eminently plausible. The only thing wrong with it is that it rarely works. The plans always remain on paper, always remain good intentions. They seldom turn into achievement.”

德鲁克于 1966 年发表了这些话。碰巧的是，那时年轻的瓦茨·汉弗莱 (Watts Humphrey) 正在接管 IBM 软件管理的大权。

Drucker published those words in 1966. As it happened, that was just about the time that a young Watts Humphrey was taking over the reins of software management at IBM.





IBM 正试图为其新一代 System/360 大型机计算提供 OS/360 操作系统，这一惨败激发了 Frederick Brooks 在《人月神话》中的开创性写作。在接受管理 OS/360 团队的工作之前，Brooks 已经迈出了 IBM 的大门；他要离开去北卡罗来纳大学建立一个新的计算机科学系。正如 Humphrey 所说，尽管 Brooks 出色地领导了 360 编程团队完成了概念和设计阶段，但他在想法实现之前就离开了，而在他离开后，该项目陷入了“严重的麻烦”。

IBM was in the middle of trying to deliver OS/360, an operating system for its new System/360 generation of mainframe computing—the fiasco that inspired Frederick Brooks’s seminal writing in The Mythical Man-Month. Before accepting the job of running the OS/360 team, Brooks already had one foot out IBM’s door; he was leaving to found a new computer science department at the University of North Carolina. As Humphrey tells it, although Brooks had ably led the 360 programming team through the concept and design phase, he departed before the ideas were implemented, and after he left, the project got into “serious trouble.”

严重问题：打滑。延迟。修改后的时间表再次推迟。还有更多的延迟。IBM 最终交付了 System/360 硬件，但没有全新的操作系统。这又花了整整一年的时间。

Serious trouble: Slippage. Delay. Revised schedules that slipped again. And more delay. IBM eventually delivered the System/360 hardware without the full new operating system. That took an entire extra year.

Humphrey 在一份简短的回忆录中写道，当 1966 年 1 月接管 IBM 软件部门时，他对公司的状况感到震惊。

When Humphrey took over the IBM software organization in January 1966, he was stunned by its state, he wrote in a brief memoir.



我的首要任务是找出工作的进展情况。。。。在我访问的每个实验室中，我都会向管理层询问他们的计划和时间表。除了非正式的笔记或备忘录之外，没有人有任何其他东西。当我询问经理们对管理软件的最佳方式的看法时，他们都说他们会在开始开发之前制定计划。当我问他们为什么不这样做时，他们的回答是没有时间。这分明是无稽之谈！正确的完成工作的方法无疑是最快、最便宜的方法。很明显，这些管理者不是在管理，而是在做出反应。他们承受着巨大的压力，有太多的事情要做，他们只能做那些运输代码明确要求的事情。除了眼前的危机之外，一切都被推迟了。我的结论是，这种情况确实是我的错，而不是他们的错。只要我允许他们在没有计划的情况下宣布和发货产品，他们就会继续这样做。

My first need was to find out where the work stood . . . . In each laboratory I visited, I asked management for their plans and schedules. No one had anything other than informal notes or memos. When I asked for the managers’ views on the best way to manage software, they all said they would make a plan before they started development. When I asked why they did not do this, their answer was that they did not have time. This was clearly nonsense! The right way to do the job was undoubtedly the fastest and cheapest way. It was obvious that these managers were not managing but reacting. They were under enormous pressure and had so much to do they could only do those things that were clearly required for shipping code. Everything but the immediate crisis was deferred. I concluded that the situation was really my fault, not theirs. As long as I permitted them to announce and ship products without plans, they would continue to do so.



Humphrey 还发现，即使软件团队没有计划或资源来交付产品，IBM 的营销部门仍然在发布产品。于是他去找了他的老板。“我告诉他，既然所有的交货时间表都没有任何价值，我打算取消它们。接下来，我会指导所有软件经理为每个项目制定计划。从那时起，我们不会宣布、交付或资助编程项目，直到我的办公桌上首先有了一份记录在案并签署的开发计划。。。。实验室花了大约六十天的时间才制定出第一个计划。这个团队以前从未制定过交货时间表，但在接下来的两年半里没有错过任何一个日期。”

Humphrey also found that IBM’s marketing division was announcing products even when the software teams had no plans or resources to deliver them. So he went to his boss. “I told him that since all the delivery schedules were not worth anything anyway, I intended to cancel them. Next, I would instruct all the software managers to produce plans for every project. From then on, we would not announce, deliver, or fund programming projects until I first had a documented and signed-off development plan on my desk . . . . It took the laboratories about sixty days to produce their first plans. This group, who had never before made a delivery schedule, did not miss a date for the next two and a half years.”

Humphrey 在 IBM 执行日程安排方面取得的成功基于两个原则： 计划是强制性的。计划必须切合实际。它们必须是“自下而上”的，源自致力于实现这些目标的程序员的经验和知识，而不是“自上而下”，由执行命令或营销愿望强加。

Humphrey’s success at enforcing schedule discipline at IBM stood on two principles: Plans were mandatory. And plans had to be realistic. They had to be “bottom-up,” derived from the experience and knowledge of the programmers who would commit to meeting them, rather than “top-down,” imposed by executive fiat or marketing wish.

20 世纪 80 年代，Humphrey 从 IBM 退休，并想知道自己下一步要做什么。正如他后来告诉商业周刊的那样， “我女儿说服我去参加一个关于承诺的研讨会。研讨会上有人谈论做出“令人震惊的承诺”，比如消除世界饥饿。因此，我做出了一个令人震惊的承诺：当我离开 IBM 时，我将改变世界上软件的开发方式。这肯定比坐在海滩上更好。”

In the 1980s, Humphrey retired from IBM and wondered what he would do next. As he later told Business Week, “My daughter persuaded me to go to a seminar on commitment. At the seminar there was talk about making an ‘outrageous commitment,’ like stamping out world hunger. So I made an outrageous commitment that when I left IBM, I was going to change the way software was developed in the world. It certainly beats sitting on the beach.”

汉弗莱与卡内基梅隆大学软件工程研究所 (SEI) 联手，该研究所是五角大楼于 1984 年成立的，旨在提高用纳税人的钱购买的日益庞大的软件系统的质量。在SEI，Humphrey 和他的同事创建了能力成熟度模型（CMM）作为判断软件开发组织质量的一种标准。

Humphrey joined forces with the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) at Carnegie Mellon University, an outfit the Pentagon had founded in 1984 to try to improve the quality of the increasingly vast software systems it was buying with taxpayers’ money. At SEI, Humphrey and his colleagues created the Capability Maturity Model (CMM) as a kind of yardstick for judging the quality of software development organizations.

CMM 为编程团队提供了一个攀爬的五级阶梯。您可以用余生阅读所有描述 CMM 原理的文档，但 Humphrey 在 1997 年提供的非正式描述提供了一个简单的草图：

The CMM provides a five-step ladder for programming teams to climb. You could spend the rest of your life reading all the documents that describe CMM principles, but the informal description that Humphrey provided in 1997 offers a simple sketch:



处于 1 级的组织基本上不会做太多事情。在第 2 级，他们正在做一些规划、跟踪、配置管理，他们发出一些关于质量保证之类的声音。3 级组织开始定义流程——它们如何工作、如何完成工作、可培训的事情。在第 4 级，他们使用测量值。他们有一个框架来实际跟踪和管理他们所做的事情，一些统计上可跟踪的东西。5 级组织有一个持续改进的流程。

An organization at Level 1 is basically not doing much of anything. At Level 2, they’re doing some planning, tracking, configuration management, they make some noises about quality assurance, that kind of stuff. A Level 3 organization begins to define processes—how they work, how they get things done, trainable things. At Level 4 they’re using measurements. They have a framework for actually tracking and managing what they do, something statistically trackable. Level 5 organizations have a continuously improving process.



CMM 最适合作为国防部衡量承包商组织能力的工具。它在商业软件世界和蓬勃发展的个人计算机软件行业中的吸引力较小。时至今日，如果你在大多数小型软件公司提到CMM，你会得到茫然的眼神。在那些关注过 CMM 的程序员和经理中，最常见的批评是它缺乏人情味和官僚主义，并且带来了沉重的、抑制创新的负担。在 1994 年的一篇题为“CMM 的不成熟”的文章中，软件质量专家 James Bach 着手揭穿 CMM：

The CMM served best as a tool for the Defense Department to measure the organizational prowess of contractors. It found less traction in the commercial software world and the burgeoning personal computer software industry. To this day if you mention the CMM in most small software companies, you will receive blank stares. Among those programmers and managers who have paid some attention to the CMM, the most common criticism is that it’s impersonal and bureaucratic and imposes heavy, innovation-stifling burdens. In a 1994 article titled “The Immaturity of CMM,” software quality expert James Bach set out to debunk the CMM:



CMM崇尚过程，却忽视人。。。。创新本身根本不会出现在 CMM 中，并且仅由 5 级建议。。。。CMM 专注于可预测性，却对创新的动态一无所知。。。。由于 CMM 不信任个人贡献，不了解培育非线性创意所需的条件，并且满足于将它们埋藏在受限制的上层建筑之下，因此在 CMM 规模上达到 2 级很可能会扑灭点燃公司的唯一火焰首先。

The CMM reveres process, but ignores people . . . . Innovation per se does not appear in the CMM at all, and it is only suggested by level 5 . . . . Preoccupied with predictability, the CMM is profoundly ignorant of the dynamics of innovation . . . . Because the CMM is distrustful of personal contributions, ignorant of the conditions needed to nurture non-linear ideas, and content to bury them beneath a constraining superstructure, achieving level 2 on the CMM scale may very well stamp out the only flame that lit the company to begin with.



至少部分作为对此类投诉的回应，汉弗莱和 SEI 设计了 ​​CMM 的两个续集。最初的方法主要旨在帮助大型组织改进软件进度和质量；后续产品——团队软件流程（TSP）和个人软件流程（PSP）——在较小的范围内针对这些问题。TSP 和 PSP 批评“专制管理风格”，鼓励个人开发者和小团队通过负责规划和质量控制、共享信息以及根据需求变化“动态重新平衡”工作量来掌握自己的命运。汉弗莱的一篇演讲提供了这些直率且有说服力的要点：

At least in part as a response to such complaints, Humphrey and the SEI devised two sequels to the CMM. The original methodology aimed chiefly to help very large organizations improve software schedules and quality; the follow-ups—the Team Software Process (TSP) and Personal Software Process (PSP)—targeted these problems on a smaller scale. TSP and PSP criticize “autocratic management styles” and encourage individual developers and small teams to seize control of their own destiny by taking responsibility for planning and quality control, sharing information, and “dynamically rebalancing” their workloads as needs change. One Humphrey presentation offered these bluntly persuasive bullet points:



我们都为组织工作。

We all work for organizations.

这些组织需要计划。

These organizations require plans.

除非你是独立富有的人，否则你必须按计划工作。

Unless you are independently wealthy, you must work to a schedule.

如果你自己不制定时间表，别人就会替你制定时间表。

If you don’t make your own schedules, somebody else will.

然后那个人就会控制你的工作。

Then that person will control your work.



CMM、TSP 和 PSP 均从制造质量专家 W. Edwards Deming 的思想中汲取灵感，戴明认为质量不应该是事后的想法，而应该融入到生产过程的每个阶段。在软件中，这意味着 CMM 敌视“编码和修复”传统，即程序员生产充满错误的产品，测试人员发现错误，然后程序员返回并修复它们。“在所有现代技术中，”汉弗莱说，“软件是唯一一个在产品投入测试之前不考虑质量的领域。然而，这不是工程师的错，因为这就是他们接受培训和管理的方式。”

The CMM, TSP, and PSP all drew inspiration from the ideas of manufacturing quality expert W. Edwards Deming, who argued that quality should not be an afterthought but ought to be built into every stage of a production process. In software this means the CMM is hostile to the “code and fix” tradition, where programmers produce bug-filled products, testers find bugs, and then programmers go back and fix them. “In all of modern technology,” Humphrey says, “software is the only field that does not consider quality until products are put into test. It’s not the engineers’ fault, however, since this is how they’ve been trained and how they are managed.”

正如戴明的思想早在其祖国美国受到关注之前就已被战后日本汽车工业所接受一样，CMM 在国外也赢得了最狂热的追随者，特别是在印度蓬勃发展的软件行业，该行业的公司发现达到特定的 CMM 水平让海外客户放心，他们可以信赖外包工作。但 CMM 及其相关方法尚未对美国的商业软件或桌面计算领域产生重大影响。

Just as Deming’s ideas were embraced by the postwar Japanese auto industry long before they won attention in his native United States, so the CMM has won its most avid following abroad—particularly in India’s burgeoning software industry, where companies find that achieving a particular CMM level reassures overseas customers that they can be trusted with outsourced work. But the CMM and its related methodologies have yet to make a major dent in the world of business software or desktop computing in the United States.

2000 年出版的一本名为《软件阴谋：为什么软件公司推出有缺陷的产品、它们如何伤害你以及你能做些什么》的书认为这是一个丑闻。既然这些方法被证明可以产生更好的结果，为什么不是每个软件团队都使用它们，而每个客户都需要它们呢？作者马克·米纳西 (Mark Minasi) 将责任大肆归咎于自我放纵的程序员、短视的公司以及过于愿意容忍粗制滥造和错误的公众。

A 2000 book titled The Software Conspiracy: Why Software Companies Put Out Faulty Products, How They Can Hurt You, and What You Can Do About It argues that this is a scandal. Since these methods are proven to produce better results, why doesn’t every software team use them and every customer demand them? Author Mark Minasi spreads the blame liberally to self-indulgent programmers, shortsighted companies, and a public too willing to tolerate shoddiness and bugs.

Minasi 和其他 CMM 倡导者坚持认为，业界知道在预算范围内按时生产高质量软件的答案。它只是太胖了，太笨了，而且懒得拥抱它。他们可能是对的。另一方面，他们的论点认为软件制造商面临的最大挑战是减少产品中的错误数量。根据汉弗莱的说法，在一个典型的经验丰富的程序员的工作中，每七到十行代码就会发现一个错误；SEI 研究表明，CMM 和相关方法可大幅减少这些数字。

Minasi and other CMM advocates maintain that the industry knows the answer to producing high-quality software on time and under budget. It’s just too fat, dumb, and lazy to embrace it. They could be right. On the other hand, their arguments assume that the biggest challenge facing the makers of software is to reduce the number of bugs in their products. In the work of a typical experienced programmer, according to Humphrey, you’ll find one bug for every seven to ten lines of code; the CMM and related methods, SEI studies show, reduce these numbers dramatically.

在 CMM、TSP 和 PSP 的语言中，借用工厂管理的术语，错误被称为“缺陷”，而缺陷是由工人“注入”的——就好像产品开始于某种柏拉图式的完美状态，然后被疯狂的工人将装满虫子的注射器注射到它的血液中而腐化。这些方法强调一旦遇到错误就立即消除，因为根据伯姆定律，在开发过程中越晚修复错误，成本就越高。

In the language of the CMM, TSP, and PSP, borrowed from the terminology of factory management, bugs are called “defects,” and defects are “injected” by workers—as if the product begins in some Platonic state of perfection and is then corrupted by mad-eyed workers shooting bug-filled syringes into its bloodstream. These methods emphasize squashing bugs as soon as they are encountered because, according to a principle known as Boehm’s Law, the later in the development process you fix a bug, the more it costs to do so.

“首先修复错误”是一个很好的原则，大多数程序员都会同意这从根本上来说是一条正确的道路——原则上。但无论程序员出于何种目的开始，他们的代码总是会出现错误，因为编写代码的过程（用软件开发词汇中最流行的词之一来说）就是“迭代”。你写一次东西就可以开始；你一次又一次地检查它——你迭代——以改进它。如果你坚持认为它从一开始就是完美的，那么你永远无法通过第一行。在实践中，“先修复错误”的效果很好，直到等待成品的人们变得不耐烦为止。然后，在争先恐后地交付可工作的（即使不完美的）代码时，该原则就被抛在了一边。

“Fix bugs first” is a fine principle, and most programmers will agree that it is fundamentally the way to go—in principle. But whatever intentions programmers start with, their code is always born with bugs because the process of writing it is, to use one of the most popular words in the software development vocabulary, “iterative.” You write something once so you can get started; you go over it again and again—you iterate—to improve it. If you insisted that it be perfect right out of the gate, you’d never get past the first line. In practice, “fix bugs first” works fine until the people who are waiting for the finished product grow impatient. Then the principle falls by the wayside in a scramble to deliver working, if imperfect, code.

除此之外，还有错误，还有错误。如果您扫描任何活跃的软件项目维护的错误列表，您会发现从引人注目的问题到琐碎的一切。错误对用户的重要性、发现它们的难易程度以及修复它们的难易程度各不相同。每个错误列表都代表了苹果和橘子比较的大量练习。

Beyond that, there are bugs and there are bugs. If you scan the bug list that any active software project maintains, you’ll find everything from showstoppers to trivialities. Bugs vary enormously in how much they matter to the user, how hard they are to find, and how hard they are to fix. And every bug list represents a vast exercise in apples-and-oranges comparison.

软件错误的编年史中记载了数量虽少但仍令人震惊的严重灾难。1962 年 7 月发射后五分钟，水手一号航天器偏离了航线，飞行控制中心将其炸毁，以防止其坠毁在有人居住的地区。问题？其制导控制程序中缺少连字符。1996 年 6 月，欧洲航天局耗资 5 亿美元的阿丽亚娜 5 号无人火箭在升空 40 秒后爆炸，原因是控制其制导系统的软件存在缺陷。（它试图将 64 位变量转换为 16 位变量，但数字太高，缓冲区溢出，系统冻结。）从 1985 年到 1987 年，一台名为 Therac-25 的放射治疗机提供了大量 X 射线。由于软件缺陷，六名患者服用了过量的射线。1991 年海湾战争期间，美国爱国者导弹连未能成功击中来袭的飞毛腿导弹；敌方导弹击中美军军营，造成 28 人死亡。调查发现，该软件的计算存在缺陷，随着时间的推移，缺陷会越来越严重，在连续使用一百个小时后，爱国者的计算结果相差甚远，根本无法开火。

The annals of software bugs feature a small but still alarming number of dramatic disasters. Five minutes after its launch in July 1962, the Mariner 1 spacecraft veered off course, and flight control blew it up to prevent it from crashing in inhabited areas. The problem? A missing hyphen in its guidance control program. In June 1996, the European Space Agency’s $500 million unmanned Ariane 5 rocket exploded forty seconds after liftoff because of a bug in the software that controlled its guidance system. (It tried to convert a 64-bit variable to a 16-bit variable, but the number was too high, a buffer overflowed, and the system froze.) From 1985 to 1987 a radiation therapy machine named the Therac-25 delivered massive X-ray overdoses to a half-dozen patients because of software flaws. During the 1991 Gulf War, a battery of American Patriot missiles failed to fire against incoming Scud missiles; the enemy missile hit a U.S. barracks, leaving twenty-eight dead. Investigations found that the software’s calculations had a defect that compounded over time, and after one hundred hours of continuous use, the Patriot’s figures were so far off, it simply didn’t fire.

这些故事和类似的故事数量很少，不会引发媒体狂热或政治骚动，但它们提醒我们我们对程序员工作质量的依赖。对于每一个致命错误的例子，都有一千个导致财产损失或财务损失的错误实例。软件问题被归咎于停电、航班延误和机场关闭、银行账户混乱、汽车召回以及几乎所有其他你能想象到的混乱和不便。

These and similar stories are few enough in number not to spark a media frenzy or a political ruckus, but they serve as cautionary reminders of our dependence on the quality of programmers’ work. And for every example of a fatal bug there are a thousand instances of bugs that cause property loss or financial damage. Software problems have been blamed for blackouts, airline delays and airport closings, bank account foul-ups, auto recalls, and virtually every other kind of snafu and inconvenience you can imagine.

但这些造成灾难的缺陷并不是“每十行代码就有一个”错误；而是“每十行代码就有一个”错误。如果是的话，任何软件系统都无法工作。虽然计算错误显然是一项有价值的练习（总比不计算要好），但它往往会将关键的系统故障和微小的缺陷归为一类。它还最终鼓励程序员完善现有产品而不是构建新产品。这很好——除非你关心的是构建新的东西。

But these disaster-causing flaws are not the “one per every ten lines of code” bugs; if they were, no software system could possibly work. While counting bugs is plainly a valuable exercise—it’s better than not counting them—it tends to throw critical system failures and picayune flaws into the same bucket. It also ends up encouraging programmers to perfect existing products rather than build new things. Which is fine—unless building something new is what you care about.





在 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代，美国军方将 CMM 和软件工程研究所的其他字母汤视为改进所需软件的宝贵工具。但在世纪之交，随着五角大楼的软件规划者思考大规模的、未来派的新武器计划，并面临 9/11 事件后军事承诺的压力，他们开始担心，即使有了这些方法的帮助，新系统所需的软件增长速度快于程序员的跟上速度。

In the 1980s and ’90s, the U.S. military embraced CMM and the rest of the Software Engineering Institute’s alphabet soup as valuable tools for improving the software it needed. But at the turn of the millennium, as the Pentagon’s software planners pondered massive and futuristic new weapons programs and faced the pressures of post-9/11 military commitments, they began to worry that even with the help of these methodologies, the size of the software the new systems required was growing faster than programmers could keep up.

2004 年，在盐湖城举行的五角大楼年度软件开发会议上，空军装备司令部工程和技术管理总监乔恩·奥格 (Jon Ogg) 阐述了军方当今面临的“软件分歧困境”。在过去的五十年里，典型军事系统中的代码量增加了一百倍。例如，一架 20 世纪 60 年代的喷气式战斗机可能有 5 万行代码，而新型联合攻击战斗机将需要 500 万行代码。与此同时，在同一时间段内，程序员的平均生产力仅增加了一倍。奥格说，这意味着我们已经看到“现在开发一种能力所需的人月努力”增加了五十倍。

In a 2004 talk at the Pentagon’s annual software development conference in Salt Lake City, Jon Ogg, director of engineering and technical management at the Air Force Materiel Command, laid out what he called the “software divergence dilemma” that the military faces today. In the past fifty years, the amount of code in a typical military system has increased a hundredfold. For instance, a 1960s-era jet fighter might have had fifty thousand lines of code, whereas the new Joint Strike Fighter will demand five million. Meanwhile, in that same span of time, the average productivity of programmers has only doubled. That means we’ve seen the “person-months of effort now required to develop a capability” increase by a factor of fifty, Ogg said.

在同一次活动中，成本估算领域的先驱、伯姆定律之父、南加州大学软件工程教授巴里·伯姆 (Barry Boehm) 更简洁地说：“国防部需要的软件数量呈指数级增长，你永远无法在有限的时间内完成它。”

At the same event, Barry Boehm—professor of software engineering at the University of Southern California, a pioneer in the field of cost estimation, and the father of Boehm’s Law—put it more succinctly: “The amount of software the Department of Defense needs is growing exponentially, and you’ll never get it done in a finite amount of time.”

面对这种困境，军方的软件供应商在其最重要的客户五角大楼的鼓励下，开始尝试不那么传统的方法。他们并不孤单。在 CMM 和相关方法论在这些国防承包商中扎根的同一年里，一种替代传统正在外部世界中不断发展，这种传统直接源自程序员的经验，他们知道自己的流程已被破坏并渴望找到更好的方法。

Confronted with this dilemma, the military’s software suppliers, encouraged by their most important customer, the Pentagon, have begun to experiment with less traditional approaches. They’re not alone. During the same years that the CMM and related methodologies were taking root among these defense contractors, an alternative tradition was evolving in the world outside, emerging directly from the experience of programmers who knew that their process was broken and yearned to find a better way.

这一运动的一个主要根源在于“模式社区”的工作，这些软件开发人员受到建筑哲学家克里斯托弗·亚历山大 (Christopher Alexander) 工作的启发。在八十年代末和九十年代初，面向对象编程的兴起及其极其复杂的抽象，将许多程序员推向了他们理解的极限。软件模式运动的领导者包括维基发明者沃德​​·坎宁安（Ward Cunningham）和一位名叫肯特·贝克（Kent Beck）的程序员，他们为他们设想了一种新的生命线，一种不那么规范的软件方法论。他们没有制定最佳实践的固定原则，而是以简短的叙述方式记录了自己的经验。“面对这类问题，”他们会说，“我们发现这种编程模式很有用。” 模式运动将软件开发视为一门手艺。正如资深计算专栏作家布赖恩·海斯（Brian Hayes）所写，它认为“程序员就像木匠或石匠——通过经验获得并通过传统和学徒传承的知识体系的管理者。”

One taproot of this movement lay in the work of the “Patterns community,” the software developers inspired by the work of the architectural philosopher Christopher Alexander. In the late eighties and early nineties, the rise of object-oriented programming, with its dauntingly complex abstractions, was pushing many programmers to the limits of their comprehension. The software patterns movement, whose leaders included wiki inventor Ward Cunningham and a programmer named Kent Beck, imagined a new kind of lifeline for them, a less prescriptive approach to software methodology. Instead of laying down fixed principles of best practices, they recorded their experiences in brief narratives. “Faced with this kind of problem,” they would say, “we’ve found this pattern of programming to be useful.” The patterns movement approached software development as a craft; it held, as veteran computing columnist Brian Hayes wrote, that “programmers are like carpenters or stonemasons—stewards of a body of knowledge gained by experience and passed along by tradition and apprenticeship.”

像坎宁安和贝克这样的模式倡导者将实践实用性带到了一个迫切需要它的领域。例如，为了降低面向对象编码的复杂性，坎宁安和贝克建议程序员通过在桌子上布置索引卡（每个软件对象一个）来设计新程序。“它们的优点是便宜、便携、容易获得和熟悉，”他们写道。“我们对物理移动卡片的价值感到惊讶。当学习者拿起一个物体时，他们似乎更容易识别它，并准备从它的角度处理设计的其余部分。正是这种物理互动的价值导致我们抵制纸牌的计算机化。”

Patterns advocates like Cunningham and Beck brought hands-on practicality to a field that desperately needed it. For instance, to tame the complexity of object-oriented coding, Cunningham and Beck proposed that programmers design a new program by laying out index cards—one per software object—on a table. “These have the advantages that they are cheap, portable, readily available, and familiar,” they wrote. “We were surprised at the value of physically moving the cards around. When learners pick up an object, they seem to more readily identify with it and are prepared to deal with the remainder of the design from its perspective. It is the value of this physical interaction that has led us to resist a computerization of the cards.”

模式运动为个体程序员提供了一种新的思维方式来解决问题并为同事的利益提炼他们的知识。但这并没有帮助他们弄清楚如何协调大型项目的工作。

The patterns movement gave individual programmers a new way of thinking about solving problems and of distilling their learning for their colleagues’ benefit. But it did not go far toward helping them figure out how to coordinate their work on larger projects.

几十年来，典型项目的组织遵循“瀑布模型”。瀑布方法（该标签首次出现于 1970 年）将项目划分为一系列有序的离散阶段，例如需求定义、设计、实现、集成、测试和部署。一个阶段将在下一阶段开始之前完成。这一切在纸面上似乎合乎逻辑，但在实践中几乎总是会导致延误、混乱和灾难。一切都花了很长时间，而且没有任何进展。程序员要么无所事事，等待需求，要么在得到需求之前放弃并开始设计工作和编码。“预先进行大设计”导致了严重的延迟，而“大爆炸集成”——分别编写主要代码块，然后在项目接近尾声时将它们全部放在一起——导致了系统崩溃。当成品到达时，时间已经过去了很长时间，程序旨在解决的问题不再重要，新的问题迫切需要解决方案。

For decades the organization of the typical project followed the “waterfall model.” The waterfall approach—the label first surfaced in 1970—divided a project into an orderly sequence of discrete phases, like requirements definition, design, implementation, integration, testing, and deployment. One phase would finish before the next began. This all seemed logical on paper, but in practice it almost invariably led to delay, confusion, and disaster. Everything took forever, and nothing worked right. Programmers would either sit idle, waiting for the requirements, or give up and start design work and coding before they got the requirements. “Big design up front” led to big delays, and “big-bang integration”—writing major chunks of code separately and then putting them all together near the end of the project—caused system collapse. By the time the finished product arrived, so much time had passed that the problems the program aimed to solve no longer mattered, and new problems clamored for solutions.

瀑布模型逐渐获得了它应得的坏名声。在八十年代中期，Boehm 定义了一种称为“螺旋模型”的替代方案，它将开发分解为六个月到两年的“迭代”——迷你瀑布，致力于更快地生成工作代码，并允许从使用结果中获得反馈部分完成的产品以指导下一次迭代。这种螺旋式增长成为了大规模政府外包软件开发领域的标准，其中一个典型项目的“采购周期”可能长达十年。

The waterfall model gradually acquired the bad reputation it deserved. In the mid-eighties, Boehm defined an alternative known as the “spiral model,” which broke development down to “iterations” of six months to two years—mini-waterfalls dedicated to producing working code faster and allowing feedback from use of the resulting partially completed product to guide the next iteration. The spiral became standard in the realm of large-scale government-contracted software development, where a typical project’s “acquisition cycle” might span as long as a decade.

然而，对于不断加速的商业软件世界来说，它仍然太慢了。九十年代，软件行业的方法论爱好者打着快速应用程序开发（RAD）的旗号，承诺通过快速原型设计、更积极的迭代周期以及依赖让计算机本身处理的新工具来加速成品软件的交付。一些编程的更平凡的任务。RAD 帮助软件公司更加灵活地工作。但在它开始占据主导地位后不久，网络就出现了，它再次加剧了该行业对速度的渴望，达到了互联网时代的疯狂节奏。

For the accelerating world of commercial software, however, it was still too slow. In the nineties, the software industry’s methodology devotees adopted the banner of Rapid Application Development (RAD), which promised to speed up the delivery of finished software through quick prototyping, more aggressive iteration cycles, and reliance on new tools that let the computer itself handle some of programming’s more mundane tasks. RAD helped software companies work more nimbly. But soon after it began to take hold, along came the Web, which ratcheted up the industry’s hunger for speed yet again, to the manic pace of Internet time.

九十年代快速出现的新方法有利于适应项目的不断变化，而不是试图预测和控制其结果，被称为“轻量级方法论”。这使他们有别于 CMM 领域那些埋头苦干的“重量级人物”，但这无助于将他们推销给商界领袖。听起来很软弱。2001 年，包括坎宁安和贝克在内的该领域的 17 位领导者聚集在犹他州的一个滑雪胜地，试图在他们相关但不同的方法中找到共同点。参加该活动的软件测试方法专家 Brian Marick 写道：“研讨会的部分目的...... 。。的目标是找到“轻量级流程”一词的替代品。人们感觉这句话“我是一个轻量级的！” 不知何故没有传达正确的信息。”

The fast new approaches of the nineties, which favored adapting to a project’s constant change over trying to predict and control its outcome, came to be called “lightweight methodologies.” That distinguished them from the plodding “heavyweights” of the world of the CMM, but it didn’t help sell them to business leaders; it sounded wimpy. In 2001, a group of seventeen leaders in the field, including Cunningham and Beck, gathered at a Utah ski resort to try to find common ground among their related but diverse approaches. Brian Marick, an expert in software testing methodologies who participated in the event, wrote: “Part of the purpose of the workshop . . . was to find a replacement for the term ‘lightweight processes.’ People felt that saying ‘I’m a lightweight!’ somehow didn’t get the right message across.”

会议为该运动找到了一个更阳刚的名字——敏捷软件开发——并制定了一份宣言，全文如下：

The meeting found a more virile name for the movement—Agile Software Development—and produced a manifesto that reads in its entirety:



我们通过实践并帮助他人开发软件，从而发现更好的软件开发方法。

We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it.

通过这项工作，我们认识到：

Through this work we have come to value:



流程和工具上的个体和交互

Individuals and interactions over processes and tools

工作软件胜过全面的文档

Working software over comprehensive documentation

客户协作胜过合同谈判

Customer collaboration over contract negotiation

响应变化而不是遵循计划

Responding to change over following a plan



也就是说，虽然右侧的项目有价值，但我们更看重左侧的项目。

That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more.



在一个理论文档容易出现缩写词过大和官僚主义臃肿的领域，敏捷宣言以其简洁明了而著称。但“敏捷开发”更多的是共享价值观的保护伞，而不是具体流程的路线图。自宣言发布以来，各种相关但不同的敏捷方法蓬勃发展。其中之一是 Scrum，将项目划分为三十天的“冲刺”，并强调每天召开会议以确保工作步入正轨。不过，迄今为止最流行的敏捷方法是极限编程（或 XP，不要与 Windows XP 操作系统混淆）。

In a field whose theoretical documents are prone to acronym overkill and bureaucratic bloat, the Agile Manifesto is remarkable for its brevity and simplicity. But “agile development” was more of an umbrella for shared values than a roadmap of specific processes. A variety of related but distinct agile methodologies have flourished since the manifesto’s publication. One, Scrum, divides projects into thirty-day “sprints” and emphasizes daily meetings to keep work on track. The most popular species of agile methodology by far, though, is Extreme Programming (or XP, not to be confused with the Windows XP operating system).

Kent Beck 在 20 世纪 90 年代提出了极限编程背后的想法，同时为克莱斯勒提供有关如何拯救脱离轨道的薪资自动化项目的咨询。这个故意挑衅的名字听起来像是需要购买大量高价体育用品，事实上贝克将“极限运动”对运动员的奉献精神和勇气与极限编程对程序员的要求进行了比较。但极限编程的标签主要是指它采用一组广泛接受的方法，然后将它们推向极限。

Kent Beck developed the ideas behind Extreme Programming in the 1990s while consulting for Chrysler on ways to rescue a payroll automation project that had run off the rails. The intentionally provocative name sounds like something that involves the purchase of a lot of high-priced sporting goods, and in fact Beck has drawn comparisons between the sort of dedication and courage “extreme sports” require in athletes and the demands Extreme Programming places on coders. But Extreme Programming’s label mostly refers to the way it adopts a set of widely accepted methods and then pushes them to their limits.

XP 的创建者之一罗恩·杰弗里斯 (Ron Jeffries) 曾经说过：“我们采用了最优秀的程序员已经做过的所有这些做法，并将刻度盘一直调到 10”。测试重要吗？然后让开发人员在编写代码之前编写测试。开发团队与客户交谈是否有好处？然后让客户随时回答开发人员的问题。让开发人员始终成对工作，而不是定期进行代码审查，以便从编写代码的那一刻起，每一行代码都会有多个眼睛在关注。最重要的是，接受客户的需求以及软件的目标将不断变化的事实，并组织您的项目以“拥抱变化”。
