“We were taking all these practices that the best programmers already did and turning the dials all the way up to 10” is how Ron Jeffries, one of XP’s creators, once put it. Is testing important? Then have developers write their tests before they write their code. Is it good for the development team to talk with the customer? Then keep the customer on hand to answer the developers’ questions. Instead of periodic code reviews, have developers work in pairs all the time so that every line of code has more than one set of eyes on it from the moment it is written. Above all, accept that the customer’s requirements, and thus the software’s goals, are going to keep changing, and organize your project to “embrace change.”

XP 向软件开发世界引入了一些新的、有时甚至是奇怪的词汇。它要求将项目分解为“故事”。每个故事都代表客户向开发人员提出的一个功能请求，并以叙述方式解释程序应该做什么。程序员开始编写“故事”。如果它满足了客户的需求，他们就完成了并为下一个故事做好了准备。在 XP 激进的渐进主义下，不存在“预先的大设计”。编码几乎立即开始。这吸引了许多程序员，他们渴望开始编写代码，但往往因冗长的设计过程而受阻。XP 授予忘记编写详细规范和代码文档的许可证也很受欢迎。

XP introduced a new and sometimes strange vocabulary to the software development world. It mandated breaking projects down into “stories.” Each story represents a feature request that the customer lays out for the developers in a narrative that explains what the program should do. The programmers go off and code the “story.” If it does what the customer wants, they’re done and ready for the next story. Under XP’s radical incrementalism, there is no “big design up front.” Coding starts almost immediately. This appeals to many programmers, whose itch to start cranking out code is often thwarted by lengthy design processes. The license XP grants to forget about writing detailed specifications and documentation of code is also popular.

但程序员经常发现其他一些 XP 原则难以遵循，尤其是“You Aren't Gonna Need It”（即 YAGNI）的战斗口号。YAGNI 采用即时制造方法，在客户下订单之前，工厂不会收集零件来制造产品，并将其应用于知识产品的世界。该原则建议：“始终在实际需要时实施，而不是在预见到需要时实施。” 换句话说：您的会议安排程序有一天可能需要支持不同时区的用户，但如果您的公司现在只有一个办公室，那么可能需要等待。对于编程部落的习惯性磨刀者来说，这是一个实用但痛苦的建议。

But programmers often find some other XP tenets difficult to follow, especially the rallying cry of You Aren’t Gonna Need It, or YAGNI. YAGNI takes the just-in-time manufacturing method, in which factories don’t collect the parts to build a product until a customer places an order, and applies it to the world of knowledge goods. The principle advises, “Always implement things when you actually need them, never when you just foresee that you need them.” In other words: Your meeting-scheduling program may someday need to support users in different time zones, but if your company has only one office right now, that can probably wait. This is practical but painful counsel for the habitual axe sharpeners of the programming tribe.

传统观点认为，敏捷开发和 XP 最适合由经验丰富的编码人员组成的小型团队。尽管 XP 在整个软件行业甚至少数为五角大楼编写代码的团队中都找到了热情的皈依者，但如果您试图遵守其所有要求，那么它是一项要求很高的纪律。这促使一些程序员只挑选那些他们认为合适的规则。批评者认为，XP 经常成为懒惰的编码人员忽视规范、文档、计划以及“重量级”流程的所有其他繁重负担所要求的纪律的借口。用一位开源专家的话说，XP 很快就会沦为一种“快速交付垃圾”的手段。

Conventional wisdom holds that agile development and XP are best for small teams of experienced coders. Though XP has found enthusiastic converts in pockets all over the software industry and even on a handful of teams writing code for the Pentagon, it’s a demanding discipline if you try to obey all of its mandates. That tempts some programmers to cherry-pick only those rules they find congenial. Critics have argued that XP often serves as an excuse for lazy coders to ignore the discipline demanded by specifications, documentation, planning, and all the other onerous burdens of “heavyweight” process. XP can quickly decay into a means to, in the phrase of one open source expert, “Deliver Crap Quickly.”

有一次，我在沙龙面试一位求职者时，很抱歉地描述了当时我们技术运作混乱的状况。

Once, while interviewing a job candidate at Salon, I apologetically described the state of disarray of our technical operation at the time.

“啊，”受访者带着外交般的微笑说道。“那么你正在使用敏捷方法！”

“Ahhh,” said the interviewee with a diplomatic smile. “Then you’re using agile methodology!”





威拉德：

WILLARD:

他们告诉我，你完全疯了，而且你的方法不健全。

They told me that you had gone totally insane and that your methods were unsound.

库尔兹：

KURTZ:

是我的方法不好吗？

Are my methods unsound?

威拉德：

WILLARD:

我没看到。。。任何方法都可以，先生。

I don’t see . . . any method at all, sir.



-现代启示录

—Apocalypse Now



任何一直在该领域工作的开发人员都会承认，三十年软件历史中的一系列方法论使该领域变得更加丰富，并为程序员提供了有用的新工具和思考其工作的方式。但找到真正认同某种特定方法的开发人员或团队并不容易。2004 年，宾夕法尼亚州的两位软件工程教授进行了一项研究，对各行业的 200 名软件团队负责人进行了有关开发实践的调查。该研究的作者写道，“我们感到震惊和失望，因为我们发现最主要的做法根本没有——三分之一的调查参与者报告了这种做法（如果可以这样称呼的话）。”

Any developer who has been around the block will admit that the cavalcade of methodologies over three decades of software history has left the field richer and given programmers useful new tools and ways of thinking about their work. But finding a developer or team that actually subscribes to a particular methodology isn’t easy. A 2004 study by two Pennsylvania software-engineering professors quizzed two hundred software team leaders in a cross-section of industries about their development practices. The study’s authors wrote of “the shock and disappointment we felt at finding that the most dominant practice was none at all—a practice (if it can be called such) reported by a full third of the survey participants.”

震惊和失望！许多软件开发人员仍然是叛逆者，他们喊着“别把我围起来”。但许多其他人，即使在抵制标签和炒作的同时，也悄悄地接受并推广了多年来不同方法论推荐的许多技术。“如果没有一些系统的实践，这些事情就很难做到，”他们会说。

Shock and disappointment! Many software developers are still rebels, crying, “Don’t fence me in.” But many others, even while resisting the labels and the hype, quietly embrace and promote many of the techniques that different methodologies have recommended through the years. “This stuff is too hard to do without some systematic practices,” they’ll say.

乔尔·斯波尔斯基（Joel Spolsky）就属于这一组。作为一名前微软项目经理，他负责 Excel 的工作，这款 Microsoft Office 电子表格在 90 年代初从 Mitch Kapor 的 Lotus 1-2-3 手中夺取了第一名，并一直保持着这一地位。当斯波尔斯基离开微软创建自己的小型软件公司时，他创办了一个名为 Joel on Software 的网站，在那里他发表了充满务实建议的有趣尖酸文章。下面是其中的一个：

Joel Spolsky is in this group. A former Microsoft project manager, he worked on Excel, the Microsoft Office spreadsheet that seized first place from Mitch Kapor’s Lotus 1-2-3 in the early nineties and has held it ever since. When Spolsky left Microsoft to found his own small software company, he began a Web site called Joel on Software, where he publishes entertainingly tart essays full of pragmatic advice. Here is a taste of one:



如果你有一点常识，你应该问：“数据在哪里？如果我要转向密集编程，我希望看到证据证明花在狗窝和鸟笼上的额外钱将在提高程序员自尊心方面得到回报。给我看看硬数据！”

If you have even the slightest bit of common sense, you should ask: “Where’s the data? If I’m going to switch to Intense Programming I want to see proof that the extra money spent on dog kennels and bird cages is going to pay for itself in increased programmer self-esteem. Show me hard data!”

当然，我们没有。。。。

And, of course, we have none . . . .

你无法诚实地比较两个软件团队的生产力，除非他们试图在完全相同的环境下与完全相同的人类个体构建完全相同的东西，而这些个体已经被以某种方式克隆，因此他们第一次不会学到任何东西本实验 。。。。

You can’t honestly compare the productivity of two software teams unless they are trying to build exactly the same thing under exactly the same circumstances with the exact same human individuals, who have been somehow cloned so they don’t learn anything the first time through the experiment . . . .

我们没有任何数据。你可以向我们提供有关 X 方法论如何起作用或不起作用的轶事，但你无法证明它起作用时不仅仅是因为团队中某个非常非常优秀的程序员，而且你可以'我无法证明，当它失败时，不仅仅是因为公司正处于破产的过程中，而且每个人都士气低落，根本无法采取任何行动，尽管伊伦担任主席。

We don’t have any data. You can give us anecdotes left and right about how methodology X worked or didn’t work, but you can’t prove that when it worked it wasn’t just because of one really, really good programmer on the team, and you can’t prove that when it failed it wasn’t just because the company was in the process of going bankrupt and everybody was too demoralized to do anything at all, Aeron chairs notwithstanding.



斯波尔斯基对他所谓的“Big-M 方法论”持高度怀疑态度。他在另一篇文章中写道：“谨防方法论。它们是让每个人达到令人沮丧但还过得去的绩效水平的好方法，但与此同时，它们也让那些对施加在他们身上的限制感到恼火的更有才华的人感到恼火。对我来说很明显，一个有才华的厨师不会乐意在麦当劳制作汉堡，正是因为麦当劳的规则。”

Spolsky is highly skeptical of what he calls “Big-M methodologies.” In another essay he writes: “Beware of Methodologies. They are a great way to bring everyone up to a dismal but passable level of performance, but at the same time, they are aggravating to more talented people who chafe at the restrictions that are placed on them. It’s pretty obvious to me that a talented chef is not going to be happy making burgers at McDonald’s, precisely because of McDonald’s rules.”

当斯波尔斯基写下这句话几年后，当我采访他时，他的蔑视并没有消失。“方法论的真正目标，”他说，“是卖书，而不是真正解决任何人的问题。” 斯波尔斯基表示，“方法论的关键问题在于，如果由聪明人（发明方法论的人）实施，它们就会发挥作用。由笨蛋实施，他们只会遵循他们给出的指示，不会做任何事情，所以它们不会起作用。无论如何，大多数开发人员不会阅读有关软件开发的书籍，不会阅读有关软件开发的网站，甚至不会阅读 Slashdot。因此，无论我们如何继续写下去，他们永远不会明白这一点。

When I interviewed Spolsky several years after he had written that, he hadn’t lost any of his disdain. “The real goal of a methodology,” he said, “is to sell books, not to actually solve anybody’s problem.” According to Spolsky, “The key problem with the methodologies is that, implemented by smart people, the kind of people who invent methodologies, they work. Implemented by shlubs who will not do anything more than following instructions they are given, they won’t work. Anyway, the majority of developers don’t read books about software development, they don’t read Web sites about software development, they don’t even read Slashdot. So they’re never going to get this, no matter how much we keep writing about it.

“即使在今天，当我环顾四周时，尽管这一切都在网络上，并且您可以购买一百万本关于如何管理的书籍，您可以阅读一百万本关于如何使您的软件项目顺利运行的内容，但您仍然会看到硅谷的那些老角色，现在应该更了解了，因为这是他们的第三家公司，犯了同样的错误，做同样的错误事情，做出同样愚蠢的假设。”

“Even today, as I look around, even though it’s all on the Web, and there’s a million books you can buy about how to manage, there’s a million things you can read about how to make your software project work well, you still see the same old characters in Silicon Valley, [who] should know better by now, because it’s their third company, making the same mistakes, doing the same things wrong, making the same silly assumptions.”

斯波尔斯基确实有自己的某种方法论：他将其称为“乔尔测试”，并根据自己的经验和“集体智慧”将其作为一套快速而简单的原则来提供，以判断开发组织是否具有它一起行动——“没有头痛的 CMM”。乔尔测试提出以下十几个问题：

Spolsky does have his own sorta-kinda methodology: He calls it the Joel Test and offers it as a sort of quick-and-dirty set of principles, based on his own experience and “collective wisdom,” to judge whether a development organization has its act together—“CMM without the headaches.” The Joel Test asks the following dozen questions:



您使用源代码管理吗？

Do you use source control?

你能一步完成构建吗？

Can you make a build in one step?

您进行日常构建吗？

Do you make daily builds?

你有错误数据库吗？

Do you have a bug database?

在编写新代码之前你会修复错误吗？

Do you fix bugs before writing new code?

您有最新的时间表吗？

Do you have an up-to-date schedule?

你有规格吗？

Do you have a spec?

程序员的工作环境安静吗？

Do programmers have quiet working conditions?

您是否使用金钱能买到的最好的工具？

Do you use the best tools money can buy?

你们有测试人员吗？

Do you have testers?

新候选人在面试时会写代码吗？

Do new candidates write code during their interview?

你们进行走廊可用性测试吗？

Do you do hallway usability testing?



“12 分是完美的，”斯波尔斯基写道，“11 分是可以接受的，但 10 分或更低，你就会遇到严重的问题。事实是，大多数软件组织的运行分数为 2 或 3，他们需要认真的帮助，因为像 Microsoft 这样的公司全职运行分数为 12。”

“A score of 12 is perfect,” Spolsky wrote, “11 is tolerable, but 10 or lower and you’ve got serious problems. The truth is that most software organizations are running with a score of 2 or 3, and they need serious help, because companies like Microsoft run at 12 full-time.”

当然，微软是历史上最成功的软件公司，经常会损失数十亿美元的利润。无论它在做什么都值得关注。另一方面，与商业竞争对手或构建企业软件的大量内部开发人员相比，微软也同样容易出现进度延迟和被忽视的错误。如果微软在乔尔测试中表现出色，为什么它仍然存在问题？“我认为微软现在正处于高级阵痛中，在纪律方面一切都 100% 正确，只是不再生产人们想要购买的具有任何一致性水平的产品，”斯波尔斯基说。“这个过程过度了。。。。现在，任何微软产品的发布都需要十六个月的时间。他们确实无法快速驾驶那艘船。他们在 SP2 [Windows XP Service Pack 2] 上花费了大约一年的时间。他们这样做是件好事，但出于安全原因，几乎所有的工作都是清理、维护、追赶。

Microsoft is, of course, the most successful software company in history, routinely throwing off billions of dollars in profits. Whatever it’s doing is worth some attention. On the other hand, Microsoft is no less prone to late schedules and overlooked bugs than its commercial competitors or the legions of in-house developers who build corporate software. If Microsoft aces the Joel Test, why does it still have problems? “I think Microsoft is now well in the advanced throes of getting everything 100 percent right in terms of the discipline and just no longer producing products people want to buy with any level of consistency,” Spolsky says. “The process is overtuned . . . . Now it’s gotten to the point where it takes sixteen months to get out any release of any Microsoft product. They really can’t steer that ship very fast. They spent something like a year on SP2 [Windows XP Service Pack 2]. It’s a good thing they did that, but it’s almost all cleanup, maintenance, catch-up, for security reasons.

“这就是军队所说的疲劳。在军队中，疲劳是你为保持装备良好工作状态所做的一切：擦亮鞋子、刷牙、确保你做好准备、所有子弹都是干净的、枪里没有沙子。这就是所谓的疲劳，对于一个步兵来说，每天大约需要两个小时。这就是一切，但不是你真正想做的事情。微软现在已经达到了 80%、90% 的疲劳程度。”

“It’s what the army calls fatigue. Fatigue is everything in the army that you do to keep your equipment in good working condition: polishing your shoes, brushing your teeth, making sure that you’re ready and that all your bullets are clean and there’s no sand in your gun. It’s all called fatigue, and it takes about two hours a day for an infantry guy. And it’s everything but the actual thing you’re trying to do. Microsoft has now got to the point where it’s like 80 percent, 90 percent fatigue.”

斯波尔斯基的步兵比喻来自亲身经历：他在以色列长大并在那里服役。但这种比较出现了很多。软件开发人员经常被描绘成在激烈的企业斗争中进行死亡行军的步兵。他们承担任务，并在瞬息万变的环境和战争迷雾般的可见性下努力完成任务。他们经常表现出宿命论和毅力的结合，这是历史上战场老兵的标志。

Spolsky’s foot soldier analogy comes from firsthand experience: He grew up in Israel and served in the military there. But the comparison comes up a lot. Software developers are frequently portrayed as foot soldiers on death marches in pitched corporate battles. They take on missions and struggle to accomplish them under rapidly shifting circumstances and fog-of-war-style visibility. And they frequently develop that combination of fatalism and perseverance that has marked battlefield veterans throughout history.

在我参加的五角大楼软件会议上，我听到一位名叫大卫·库克的个人软件流程培训师解释了方法论纪律的目的，其中一部分是鼓舞士气的演讲，一部分是存在主义的布道。

At the Pentagon software conference I attended, I listened to a Personal Software Process trainer named David Cook explain the purpose of methodological discipline in terms that were one part pep talk and one part existential sermon.

“你的软件改变的可能性有多大？” 库克用快活的声音问道。“噢，百分之一百。它将会存在十年。您将需要修改它的次数超出您的想象。你必须针对不同的硬件和软件环境进行更改，更改语言 3 次，并经历 4 次人员更替。你要做的就是尽你所能地努力保持质量，这样十年后你还能有所收获。

“What are the odds your software is going to change?” Cook asked in a jovial blare. “Oh, 100 percent. It’s going to be around for ten years. You’re going to have to modify it more times than you can imagine. You’re gonna have to change it for different hardware and software environments, change languages three times, and go through four personnel turnovers. What you have to do is fight as hard as you can to keep quality up so that ten years from now you have something left.

“就像，当你把软件抓到手里时，它就是沙子。当你站在这里尽你所能时，沙子开始从你的手指间渗漏。十年后，只剩下几粒沙子，而这就是你所需要处理的一切。你的工作就是尽可能地握紧你的手。”

“It’s like, when you grab the software in your hands, it’s sand. And as you stand here doing the best you can, sand starts leaking between your fingers. Ten years from now there’s a few grains of sand left, and that’s all you have to work with. Your job is to keep your hands as tight as possible.”





尽管存在困难——尽管存在复杂性、延迟和不可预测的变化——但许多软件确实以某种方式被编写、交付并最终被使用。有时候，甚至还不错。它很少会真正做出一些新的、有价值的事情。在少数情况下，它可以按计划实现所有这些目标。

Despite the odds—despite complexity and delay and unpredictable change—a lot of software somehow does get written and delivered and, finally, used. Occasionally, it’s even good. Rarely, it actually does something new and valuable. And in a handful of cases, it achieves all of that on schedule.

在那些罕见的情况下，成功往往是钢铁般的克制的副产品——在每次限制项目范围的挑战时坚定地做出并大声重申的选择。在你发现软件成功案例的地方，你总是会发现善于说“不”的人。就像一位故意将调色板限制为一种颜色的艺术家，一位选择写十四行诗而不是自由诗的诗人，或者选择为一个小型产品利基市场提供服务的制造商一样，成功的程序员之所以能够蓬勃发展，是因为（而不是无视）限制。 。有时，这些限制是环境的产物——预算少、期限紧迫、目标有限。有时，它们是由经验丰富的开发人员或经理自己强加的，他们经历了惨痛的教训，学会了避免开放式（用软件术语来说是“无限制”）项目。不管怎样，与其说“小就是美”，不如说“大就是危险”。

Very often, in those rare cases, success is a by-product of iron-willed restraint—a choice firmly made and vociferously reasserted at every challenge to limit a project’s scope. Where you find software success stories, you invariably find people who are good at saying no. Like an artist who deliberately limits his palette to one color, a poet who chooses to write a sonnet instead of free verse, or a manufacturer who chooses to serve one small product niche, the successful programmer thrives because of, not in spite of, constraints. Sometimes those constraints are the product of circumstance—small budgets, tight deadlines, limited goals. Sometimes they are self-imposed by experienced developers or managers who have learned the hard way to shun open-ended—in software talk, “unbounded”—projects. Either way, the perspective is less “small is beautiful” than “big is dangerous.”

一家名为 37 Signals 的芝加哥小公司是这种拥抱极限方法的典型代表。37 Signals 最初是一家网页设计咨询公司，最初只是为了满足自己的需求而涉足软件开发。它构建了一些内部工具来管理项目。然后它需要一种与客户沟通的方式，因此它向他们开放了部分系统。正如公司创始人兼总裁杰森·弗里德 (Jason Fried) 所解释的那样，在他们意识到这一点之前，他们就具备了开发基于 Web 的应用程序的能力。经过四个月的努力，他们将软件变成了一项名为 Basecamp 的服务。它于 2004 年 2 月推出，很快成为 Google 的 Gmail 和 Flickr 等新型、丰富的基于 Web 的应用程序中的领导者。

A tiny Chicago-based company named 37 Signals is the poster child for this limit-embracing approach. 37 Signals began as a Web design consulting firm and branched out into software development at first simply to meet its own needs. It built some internal tools to manage projects. Then it needed a way to communicate with clients, so it opened up parts of its system to them. Before they knew it, as company founder and president Jason Fried explains it, they had the makings of a Web-based application. With four months more work, they turned their software into a service called Basecamp. Launched in February 2004, it quickly became a leader in the parade of new, rich, Web-based applications like Google’s Gmail and Flickr.

Basecamp 是这家只有少数员工的公司在一年多的时间里推出的一系列值得注意的极简主义产品中的第一个产品。接下来是 Ta-da List，用于保存和共享待办事项（以及任何其他类型）列表。几个月后，Backpack 出现了，它允许用户保存和共享笔记和文件。每款产品都坚固、易于使用且经过精心设计，并且每款产品通常都提供了少量的新变化。例如，背包有一些简洁的电子邮件功能。您可以向自己发送电子邮件提醒，正如许多其他服务和程序所允许的那样，但您也可以从另一台计算机或手机等移动设备向您的每个背包网页发送电子邮件，并且将显示电子邮件的文本在页面上。

Basecamp was the first in a series of noteworthy minimalist products that this company with only a handful of employees rolled out in little over a year. Next came Ta-da List, for saving and sharing to-do (and any other kind of ) lists. A few months after that came Backpack, which allows users to save and share notes and files. Each product was solid, easy to use, and carefully designed, and each typically offered a small number of new twists. Backpack, for instance, had some neat email capabilities. You could send email reminders to yourself, as lots of other services and programs allowed, but you could also send email to each of your Backpack Web pages from another computer or a mobile device like a cell phone, and the text of the email would appear on the page.

我开始使用 Backpack 来存储本书的随机研究笔记，当我在 2004 年秋天的一次技术会议上遇到 Fried 时，我问他 37 Signals 是如何在如此短的时间内开发出如此多有用的软件的。他是他的方法的热情传播者——他的公司举办了一个名为“Basecamp 的制作”的研讨会，将其原理提炼成 PowerPoint 演示文稿——并让我在酒店里用 45 分钟概述了他的方法大堂。

I started using Backpack to store random research notes for this book, and when I bumped into Fried at a technology conference in the fall of 2004, I asked him how 37 Signals managed to crank out so much useful software in such a short time. He is a passionate proselytizer for his approach—his company offers a workshop, “The Making of Basecamp,” that distills its principles into a PowerPoint presentation—and obliged me with a forty-five-minute overview of his methodology right there in the hotel lobby.

一方面，37 Signals 只有一名开发人员，因此它避免了整个布鲁克斯定律的泥潭，就像 Mitch Kapor 在 Lotus 1-2-3 的原始作品中所做的那样，该作品主要由一个程序员 Jonathan Sachs 编写。开发人员之间的协调根本不是问题。这位孤独的程序员，一位名叫大卫·海涅迈尔·汉森（David Heinemeyer Hansson）的年轻天才，住在丹麦，这似乎并不重要。弗里德说，在大多数公司，这种地理上的分离会被视为一个可怕的问题，但时差实际上意味着他们只有几个小时的重叠时间来讨论事情，因此他们会有效地利用它，然后开发人员可以编码平静无间。

For one thing, 37 Signals had only one developer, so it avoided the whole Brooks’s Law quagmire—just as Mitch Kapor had in his original work on Lotus 1-2-3, which was mostly written by a single programmer, Jonathan Sachs. Coordination among developers simply wasn’t an issue. It didn’t even seem to matter that the lone programmer, a young whiz named David Heinemeyer Hansson, lived in Denmark. At most companies, Fried said, this geographical separation would be viewed as a terrible problem, but the time difference actually meant that they had only a few hours’ overlap to talk things over, so they would use it efficiently and then the developer could code in peace without interruption.

根据 37 Signals 的说法，约束是你的朋友。“限制是打造出色产品的关键，”弗里德说。“它们是创造力发生的原因。如果有人说你拥有世界上所有的钱来建造你想要的任何东西，它可能永远不会被发布。就给我一个月的时间！”

Constraints, according to 37 Signals, are your friends. “Constraints are key to building a great product,” Fried said. “They’re what makes creativity happen. If someone said you have all the money in the world to build whatever you want, it would probably never be released. Give me just a month!”

37 Signals 能够快速开发优质软件的另一个关键在于它对基于 Web 的应用程序的关注。一切都通过网络浏览器进行，因此程序可以在任何可以运行浏览器的操作系统下的任何类型的计算机上运行。增量更改可以轻松地滚动到运行该服务的服务器上，而无需用户下载和安装新的升级。Hansson 还热衷于使用 Ruby（一种动态的面向对象编程语言）。它与 Python 类似，但不太为人所知，它加快并简化了 Hansson 的工作。最后，37 个信号方法避免了编写规范的仪式；相反，工作从用户将看到的网页的详细模型开始。这些页面设计成为规格。弗里德说，他的团队花费数小时讨论显示在其中的每个单词、按钮和框的情况并不罕见。

Another key to 37 Signals’ ability to produce good software fast lay in its focus on Web-based applications. Everything worked through the Web browser, so the programs would work on any kind of computer under any operating system that could run a browser. Incremental changes could be rolled in easily on the server that ran the service, without users having to download and install new upgrades. Hansson was also keen on working with Ruby, a dynamic object-oriented programming language. Similar to Python but less widely known, it sped up and simplified Hansson’s work. Finally, the 37 Signals approach shunned the ritual of writing up specs; instead, the work begins with detailed mock-ups of the Web pages that users will see. These page designs become the specs. Fried said it’s not uncommon for his team to spend hours debating each word and button and box displayed on them.

37 Signals 的初衷是创建一些小程序，而不是构建一个雄心勃勃的新平台或应用程序框架。但在构建 Basecamp 的过程中，Hansson 编写了一些有用且创新的代码，这些代码简化了所有 Web 应用程序在存储和检索数据过程中必须执行的基本工作。Basecamp 推出后，他和 37 Signals 决定将这项工作作为一个名为 Ruby on Rails 的开源平台发布。Rails（后来被称为 Rails）使编写 Web 应用程序变得更加容易，部分原因是限制了程序员的选择。“灵活性被高估了。限制正在释放，”汉森说。Rails 已经为 AJAX 风格的界面增强做好了准备，这使得这些基于 Web 的程序能够与桌面程序进行可靠的竞争。

37 Signals set out to create some small programs, not to build an ambitious new platform or application framework. But in the course of building Basecamp, Hansson had written some useful and innovative code that streamlined and simplified the basic chores that all Web applications had to perform in the course of storing and retrieving data. After Basecamp’s launch, he and 37 Signals decided to take that work and release it as an open source platform called Ruby on Rails. Rails, as it came to be called, made writing Web applications easier, in part by limiting the programmer’s options. “Flexibility is overrated. Constraints are liberating,” Hansson says. And Rails was ready-made for the AJAX-style interface enhancements that were making those Web-based programs credible competition to their desktop equivalents.

正如 37 Signals 从 Basecamp 代码中提取了 Rails 框架一样，它从 Basecamp 经验中提取了设计理念，并用一系列方便的格言编码：“更少的软件”。“默认说不。” “找到合适的人。” “不要打造半途而废的产品，而要打造半成品。” 这些是为通过演示幻灯片快速消费而设计的流行语，但它们共同构成了一种连贯的软件开发方法——称之为实用极简主义。它可能无法满足激励如此多程序员的改变世界的渴望。你可以批评它是野心受挫的表现。它似乎不太适用于那些除了做大之外别无选择的项目。正如程序员喜欢说的那样，它“无法扩展”。

Just as 37 Signals had extracted the Rails framework from the Basecamp code, it extracted a design philosophy from the Basecamp experience, encoded in a handy series of aphorisms: “Less software.” “Say no by default.” “Find the right people.” “Don’t build a half-assed product, build half a product.” These are buzz phrases designed for quick consumption via presentation slides, but together they constitute a coherent approach to software development—call it pragmatic minimalism. It may not satisfy the yen to change the world that motivates so many programmers. You could criticize it as an indication of chastened ambitions. It doesn’t seem to apply very well to projects that simply have no choice but to be big. As programmers like to say, it “doesn’t scale.”

但根据 37 Signals 迄今为止的记录，它有一个很好的建议：以它自己的小方式，它似乎确实有效。类似的方法在一家规模更大、知名度更高的软件公司取得了前所未有的成功，甚至可以说是具有一定可信度的、改变世界的成功。谷歌在短短几年内就成长为价值数十亿美元的庞然大物，并开始挑战微软，它遵循的软件开发理念听起来非常像贾森·弗里德的：小团队为每个新项目临时组建，在紧迫的期限内工作，并且推出了针对性较强的基于网络的产品，然后根据用户反馈和现场经验逐步改进这些产品。谷歌还告诉其程序员将五分之一的工作时间用于个人项目。这些“20% 的时间”劳动的成果可能会变成很酷的新产品——也可能不会。别担心，公司让员工放心了。快去挠痒痒吧！

But based on the 37 Signals track record to date, it has one great recommendation: In its own little way it does seem to work. A similar approach has found unprecedented success—even, you could say with some credibility, world-changing success—at a much larger and more celebrated software company. Google, which in a handful of years had grown into a billion-dollar behemoth and begun to challenge Microsoft, followed a software development philosophy that sounded remarkably like Jason Fried’s: Small teams assembled ad hoc for each new project, worked on tight deadlines, and rolled out narrowly focused Web-based products, which they then improved incrementally based on user feedback and field experience. Google also told its programmers to devote one-fifth of their work time to personal projects. The fruits of these “20 percent time” labors might turn into cool new products—or not. Don’t worry, the company reassured its people. Go forth and scratch your itches!

谷歌因建立了一种工程师的天堂而赢得了声誉，在那里算法称霸，程序员发号施令。那些有幸受雇于 Googleplex 的人（包括 Andy Hertzfeld 和 Python 的 Guido van Rossum，两人均于 2005 年加入 Google）找到了一个暂时摆脱了软件时代停滞状态的工作环境。谷歌也有一些不成熟的产品，但没有人会质疑其成功的价值——从最初的搜索引擎到基于关键字的广告业务以及广受欢迎的免费电子邮件服务。

Google was gaining a reputation for having built a sort of engineers’ paradise where algorithms ruled the roost and coders called the shots. Those lucky enough to be employed at the Googleplex—including Andy Hertzfeld and Python’s Guido van Rossum, both of whom joined Google in 2005—found a working environment that, for a spell, had escaped the stasis of software time. Google had its share of half-baked products, but no one would dispute the value of its successes—from its original search engine to its keyword-based advertising business and its popular free email service.

务实的极简主义对谷歌很有帮助。但现在，它是一家非常成功的上市公司，面临着保持增长步伐和寻找新收入来源的新压力。对许多人来说，谷歌似乎正在单枪匹马地吹大硅谷新泡沫。如果它能够在这种情况下坚持自己的方法论，找出如何在不变得更慢、更愚蠢的情况下发展壮大的方法，那么它将在软件行业的历史上证明是独一无二的。

Pragmatic minimalism had served Google well. But now it was a phenomenally successful public company facing new pressures to keep up the pace of growth and find new sources of revenue. To many it looked like Google was single-handedly inflating a new Silicon Valley bubble. If it could stick to its methodology under such circumstances, figuring out how to grow bigger without getting slower and dumber, it would prove unique in the history of the software industry.





我不能说我对寻找更好的软件制作方法的追求非常成功。虽然我不认为方法论兜售者是万金油推销员——他们每个人都报告了软件制造商可以学习的来之不易的经验教训——但他们不可避免地是向后看的。他们为当今困扰行业的问题提供解决方案，但在下一波问题崩溃时却无法提供太多帮助，这就是为什么每个新的十年似乎都会带来一系列新的方法。

I can’t say that my quest to find better ways of making software was very successful. While I don’t think the methodology peddlers are snake oil salespeople—they each report hard-earned lessons that software makers can learn from—they are inevitably backward-looking. They provide solutions for problems that beset their industry today but can’t offer much help when the next wave of problems crashes down, which is why each new decade seems to bring a new bundle of methodologies.

但在某些情况下，方法论才是真正的答案。这是商业思想家尼古拉斯·卡尔 (Nicholas Carr) 2003 年 5 月在《哈佛商业评论》上发表的一篇臭名昭著的文章中提出的场景，题为“IT 并不重要”。卡尔表示，他们的产品（整个信息技术或 IT）已经变得无关紧要，这激怒了硅谷大批有远见的人和技术高管。就像黑格尔哲学家弗朗西斯·福山（Francis Fukuyama）在柏林墙倒塌和苏联解体时宣称“历史的终结”一样，卡尔也认为，从本质上讲，软件的历史已经结束了。我们知道软件是什么，它有什么作用，以及如何在商业世界中部署它，所以除了点上i并引入重量级方法来完善它之外，别无选择。

But there is one set of circumstances under which methodologies really are The Answer. This is the scenario presented by a business thinker named Nicholas Carr in a notorious May 2003 article in the Harvard Business Review titled “IT Doesn’t Matter.” Carr infuriated legions of Silicon Valley visionaries and technology executives by suggesting that their products—the entire corpus of information technology, or IT—had become irrelevant. Like Francis Fukuyama, the Hegelian philosopher who famously declared “the end of history” when the Berlin wall fell and the Soviet Union imploded, Carr argued, essentially, that software history is over, done. We know what software is, what it does, and how to deploy it in the business world, so there is nothing left but to dot the i’s and bring on the heavyweight methodologies to perfect it.

通过与铁路和电力等前几代“颠覆性技术”进行比较，卡尔认为计算机和软件首先为有远见的早期采用者提供了抓住比较优势的机会。但现在，他说，它们已经成为商品。它们很重要——你不能忽视它们，否则你就会落后于竞争对手——但它们不会“使个别公司以有意义的方式将自己与竞争对手区分开来”。在企业战略和商业竞争的宏大游戏中，它们根本不重要。它们已经变成了无聊的基础设施——仅仅是管道。

Drawing comparisons from previous generations of “disruptive technologies” like railroads and electricity, Carr argued that computers and software had at first offered farsighted early adopters an opportunity to seize comparative advantage. But now, he said, they have become commodities. They are important—you can’t neglect them, or you’ll fall behind the competition—but they won’t “enable individual companies to distinguish themselves in a meaningful way from their competitors.” In the grand game of corporate strategy and business competition, they simply don’t matter. They’ve become boring infrastructure—mere plumbing.

卡尔文章的煽动性标题引起了可预见的愤怒，但只要您将 IT 视为一组固定的功能和能力，他的论点就非常有意义。只要您事先知道您期望软件为企业完成的事情（会计、工作流程自动化、库存管理等等）不会改变，并且您的竞争对手正在使用软件，IT“并不重要”完成同一组事情。

The inflammatory title of Carr’s article raised predictable hackles, but his argument made eminent sense as long as you viewed IT as a fixed set of functions and capabilities. IT “doesn’t matter” as long as you know in advance that the things you expect software to accomplish for a business—accounting, workflow automation, inventory management, you name it—are not going to change and that your competition is using software to accomplish the same set of things.

但在企业投入大量资金的所有资本货物中，软件是唯一易变的。占据大公司CTO和CIO生活的“客户关系管理”和“企业资源规划”的庞大软件包可能既麻烦又昂贵。但它们仍然——就像 Dan Bricklin 和 Mitch Kapor 在 25 年前向世界推出的小电子表格一样——由“思想内容”（回忆 Frederick Brooks 的术语）组成。因此，当人们决定将其用于某些新目的时，使用的每一个软件都会发生变化。一旦你引入新的员工调查系统，某人的脑海中就会突然灵光乍现：嘿，为什么我们不能将同一个系统变成一个安排公司聚会的工具呢？所需要的只是一些调整！当他们这样做的时候，也许开发团队会以一种巧妙的方式为我构建我的音乐收藏的目录。然后我们就可以对聚会上的音乐进行投票！

But of all the capital goods in which businesses invest large sums, software is uniquely mutable. The gigantic software packages for “customer relationship management” and “enterprise resource planning” that occupy the lives of the CTOs and CIOs of big corporations may be cumbersome and expensive. But they are still—just as much as the little spreadsheets that Dan Bricklin and Mitch Kapor introduced to the world a quarter century ago—made of “thought-stuff” (to recall Frederick Brooks’s term). And so every piece of software that gets used gets changed as people decide they want to adapt it for some new purpose. No sooner do you introduce a new system for employee surveys than the lightbulb goes off over somebody’s head: Hey, why can’t we turn the same system into a tool to schedule our company parties? All it will take is a few tweaks! And while they’re at it, maybe the development team will build in a nifty way for me to catalog my music collection. Then we could vote on the music at the parties!

我们是否已经发现并部署了该软件提供的所有有用性（是的，还有所有无聊之处）？相信这一点不仅显得傲慢，而且对最近的计算历史一无所知。例如，到了 20 世纪 80 年代中期，商业分析师认为整个个人计算机行业已经成熟且已经过时，而此时新一波的 Macintosh 和 Windows 风格的图形界面系统正在兴起。九十年代初，微软开始主导个人电脑软件行业，传统观点认为整个行业正在整合，但互联网即将将其推向新的方向。2000 年和 2001 年，随着互联网泡沫的破灭，许多观察家准备宣布整个基于网络的软件行业已经消亡并封棺，但谷歌就在转角处成长并帮助孕育了全新的在线浪潮。企业。

Have we already discovered and deployed all the usefulness—and, yes, all the frivolousness, too—that software offers? To believe so seems not only arrogant but actively ignorant of recent computing history. By the mid-1980s, for instance, business analysts were writing off the entire personal computer industry as mature and over the hill, just as the new wave of Macintosh and Windows-style graphic interface systems was building. In the early nineties, Microsoft was beginning to dominate the PC software industry, and the conventional wisdom was that the entire business was consolidating—yet the Internet was about to kick it in new directions. In 2000 and 2001, with the collapse of the Internet bubble, many observers were ready to declare the entire Net-based software industry dead and seal the coffin, but right around the corner Google was growing and helping to gestate a whole new wave of online businesses.

那些押注科技行业不会有任何新鲜事的人一次又一次地输光了。相信我们已经知道软件的所有可能用途，就等于假设我们已经拥有的程序可以满足我们所有的需求，并且人们将不再寻求更好的东西。

Over and over, those who have bet that there can be nothing new under the technology industry sun have lost their shirts. To believe that we already know all the possible uses for software is to assume that the programs we already possess satisfy all our needs and that people are going to stop seeking something better.

《软件阴谋》的马克·米纳西（Mark Minasi）等对软件缺陷的愤怒批评者和尼古拉斯·卡尔（Nicholas Carr）等软件行业持怀疑态度的分析师都分享了这些历史终结的眼罩。如果你相信我们已经知道我们想要从软件中得到的一切，那么很自然地相信，通过足够的努力和规划，我们可以完善它——这就是我们应该投入精力的地方。甚至不要去想新的功能和新奇的想法；将每个人的精力集中在减少每个产品的错误列表上，直到我们历史上第一次可以说大多数软件都处于良好状态。微软实际上已经尝试过这一点。在一系列令人尴尬的病毒爆发之后，2003 年，该公司一度停止了大部分新产品开发工作，并投入大量编程人员来修复 Windows 安全漏洞。随着 XP Service Pack 2 的出现，Windows 的安全性得到了提高，但这并没有阻止人们发明新的病毒来困扰它。

Irate critics of software flaws like The Software Conspiracy’s Mark Minasi and skeptical analysts of the software business like Nicholas Carr share these end-of-history blinders. If you believe that we already know everything we want from software, then it’s natural to believe that with enough hard work and planning, we can perfect it—and that’s where we should place our energies. Don’t even think about new features and novel ideas; focus everyone’s energies on whittling down every product’s bug list until we can say, for the first time in history, that most software is in great shape. Microsoft has actually tried this. After a series of embarrassing virus outbreaks, for a time in 2003 it stopped most work on new products and committed much of its programming workforce to fixing Windows security holes. With the resulting XP Service Pack 2, Windows security improved, but that didn’t stop people from inventing new viruses to plague it.

这种“停止世界”的心态有时是有道理的，特别是当已经广泛使用的有缺陷的软件迫切需要修复时。但大多数情况下，这是无关紧要的：它忽略了为什么我们仍然对我们所依赖的软件不满意的全部要点。用户可能会因错误而烦恼，软件开发人员可能会因无法完善其工作而感到失望，而管理人员可能会因计划的不可靠性而感到沮丧。但归根结底，最重要的是一个简单的事实：软件并不按照我们想象的方式工作，并且在它按照我们想象的方式工作之前，不值得尝试去完善。

This stop-the-world mentality occasionally makes sense, particularly when flawed software that is already widely used cries out for fixing. But mostly, it is what’s irrelevant: It misses the whole point of why we are still dissatisfied with the software we depend on. Users may be annoyed by bugs, and software developers may be disappointed by their inability to perfect their work, and managers may be frustrated by the unreliability of their plans. But in the end, none of that matters as much as the simple fact that software does not work the way we think, and until it does, it is not worth trying to perfect.





有一天，在 OSAF 吃午饭时，约翰·安德森承认，有时他认为，如果我们能挥动一根魔杖，将计算机内存的大小倒退十年，软件会更容易编写，而且会得到更好的结果。

Over lunch one day at OSAF, John Anderson confessed that he sometimes thinks software would be easier to write and would come out better if we could wave a wand and turn the clock back a decade with regard to the size of a computer’s memory.

“利用今天的工具和流程，加上昨天的内存限制，我们确实可以做得更好，”他说。

“With today’s tools and processes, but with yesterday’s memory limitations, we could really do a much better job,” he said.

“但是你只是说，让我们为软件的野心设定一个上限，”我反对道。“让我们开发出功能更少的软件。”

“But then you’re just saying, let’s set an upper limit on the ambition of software,” I objected. “Let’s have software that does less.”

“嗯，是的，”他回答道，“它的作用可能会少一些，但缺陷也会少一些。”

“Well, yes,” he answered, “it might do less, but it would have fewer flaws.”





只要我们不断要求软件完成新事物并解决新问题，修复今天的错误仍然无法保护我们免受明天的崩溃。尽管当您想要重复成功时，软件方法非常有用，但只有当您有一个开始时，您才能重现结果。如果您正在探索未知领域，最佳实践可能会帮助您更快地前进，但它们不会指引您到达目的地。

As long as we keep asking software to accomplish new things and solve new problems, fixing today’s bugs still won’t protect us from tomorrow’s crashes. And although software methodologies are very helpful when you want to repeat a success, you can reproduce an outcome only if you have one to start with. If you are exploring unknown territory, best practices might help you move a little more quickly, but they’re not going to point you to your destination.

人们经常将软件开发与建筑行业进行比较，但这种类比在一方面是不成立的。即使我们已经学会了如何建造建筑物来解决特定问题（例如为家庭提供庇护，或为病人的治疗提供适当的空间），我们仍然需要继续建造更多的此类建筑物。无论我多么喜欢你的房子，我自己都无法拥有它。你已经住在那里了，如果我想要同样的东西，我还得再建一个。软件不是这样工作的；一旦我们知道如何编写一个程序来平衡支票簿或显示网页，该程序的每个额外副本都无需花费任何成本即可生成，并且假设您支付了所有费用，您所付出的代价就是奖励设计该程序的人，不是为了构建你的副本。因此，一旦有人编写了一个程序来完成您需要它做的事情，购买该软件总是比从头开始构建软件更便宜。

Software development is often compared to the construction industry, but the analogy breaks down in one respect. Even after we have learned how to build structures to solve particular problems—sheltering a family, say, or providing an appropriate space for the treatment of sick people—we still need to keep building more of those structures. However much I may like your house, I can’t have it myself. You’re already living there, and if I want the same thing, I still have to build another one. Software doesn’t work that way; once we know how to write a program to balance a checkbook or display a Web page, each additional copy of the program costs nothing to produce, and the price you pay, assuming you pay at all, is to reward the people who devised it, not to construct your copy. Therefore, once somebody has written a program that does what you need it to do, it’s always cheaper to buy that software than build something from scratch.

然而，我们一次又一次地发现我们需要或想要的东西与可用的东西完全不同，以至于我们别无选择，只能编写新代码。例如，在沙龙，在九十年代末，我们意识到我们需要自动化我们发布文章的方式。当时最流行的内容管理软件是一个名为 Vignette 的大软件包，其价格标签为六位数。该公司的一位销售人员参观了我们的办公室并描述了其数百个有用的功能。不幸的是，我们不需要其中的大多数。但有一些我们确实需要的东西，而维涅特却无法做到。所以我们聘请了一些程序员来编写我们自己的系统。

Time and time again, however, we find that what we need or want is just different enough from what’s available that we have no choice but to write new code. At Salon, for instance, in the late nineties we realized we needed to automate the way we published articles. The most popular software for content management at the time was a big package called Vignette, which had a six-figure price tag. A salesman from the company visited our offices and described its hundreds of useful features. Unfortunately, we had no need for most of them. But there was a handful of things we really did need, and Vignette couldn’t do them. So we hired some programmers to write our own system instead.

由于每个关于软件的作家迟早都会以自己的名义提出一条法律，所以现在是我谦虚地介绍罗森伯格定律的时候了：软件很容易制作，除非你想让它做一些新的事情。当然，还有一个推论：唯一值得开发的软件就是能够做新事情的软件。

Since every writer about software sooner or later ends up offering a law under his own name, the time has come for me, with all due humility, to present Rosenberg’s Law: Software is easy to make, except when you want it to do something new. And then, of course, there is a corollary: The only software that’s worth making is software that does something new.





“软件只是管道”的论点引起了几乎本能的“是的，但是”反应。管道满足有限且明确的需求；我们很久以前就设定了要求（热水、饮用水、不漏水、厕所不堵塞），即使创新者试图改变这些要求——电子马桶座圈，有人吗？——这些改变往往无法实施。

The argument that “software is just plumbing” evokes an almost instinctive “Yes, but” reaction. Plumbing fulfills a limited and well-defined set of needs; we set the requirements a long time ago (hot water, drinking water, no leaks, clog-free toilets), and even when innovators try to change them—electronic toilet seats, anyone?—the changes often fail to take hold.

到目前为止，在其短暂但漫长的历史中，软件完全不是这样的。

So far, in its brief but lengthening history, software is nothing like that.

最先进软件的批评者经常抱怨我们仍处于这项技术的“修补引擎”阶段。在汽车发展的早期，您的车辆在到达目的地之前很可能会发生故障，因此如果您希望到达目的地，您必须是一名业余机械师。同样，今天的计算机用户通常必须是业余程序员，学习如何像机器一样思考，这样他们就可以解决在尝试完成工作时遇到的大量问题。最终，汽车变得更加可靠，控制装置变得标准化，而且你不必成为一个痴迷的业余爱好者来驾驶。我们仍在等待，但按照这一推理，总有一天，软件也会发生类似的情况。

Critics of the software state-of-the-art often complain that we are still in the “tinker with the engine” phase of this technology. In the early days of automobiles, the odds were good that your vehicle would break down before reaching its destination, so you had to be an amateur mechanic if you expected to get anywhere. Similarly, today’s computer users must often be amateur programmers, learning to think more like the machine so they can fix the raft of problems they encounter when they try to get work done. Eventually, cars got more reliable, the controls got standardized, and you didn’t have to be an obsessive hobbyist to do your driving. We are still waiting, but one of these days, this line of reasoning goes, something similar will happen with software.

这是一个公平的论点。也许有一天我们会实现这一目标，软件真的会变得像你的管道或汽车一样——我们可以按照惯例制造、不假思索地使用，并期望永远不会改变。但如果以过去为鉴的话，我们更有可能会继续期待软件能够做新的、不同的事情。十年前的汽车将在下一个十年变成飞行汽车，然后是潜艇！我们将欢迎甚至要求这些转变。

It’s a fair argument. Maybe someday we will get there, and software really will become just like your plumbing or your car—something we can manufacture according to routines, use without thinking, and expect never to change. But if the past is any guide, it’s far more likely that we will keep expecting software to do new and different things. The car of one decade will turn into a flying car the next—then a submarine! And we will welcome, even demand, those metamorphoses.

第10章                           

CHAPTER 10                           

工程师和艺术家

ENGINEERS AND ARTISTS









在软件工程会议上聚集的专家小组提出了以下一些评论：

From a panel of experts assembled at a conference on software engineering, here are some comments:

“毫无疑问，我们是用落后的技术生产软件的。”

“We undoubtedly produce software by backward techniques.”

“特别令人担忧的是大型软件似乎不可避免的错误，因为先进的硬件软件系统的故障可能是生死攸关的问题。”

“Particularly alarming is the seemingly unavoidable fallibility of large software, since a malfunction in an advanced hardware-software system can be a matter of life and death.”

“我们建造系统就像莱特兄弟建造飞机一样——建造整个系统，将其推下悬崖，让它坠毁，然后重新开始。”

“We build systems like the Wright brothers built airplanes—build the whole thing, push it off the cliff, let it crash, and start over again.”

“大型软件的生产已经成为管理层的一个恐惧项目。就声誉而言，它往往是一个无利可图的沼泽地，成本高昂且永无休止。”

“Production of large software has become a scare item for management. By reputation it is often an unprofitable morass, costly and unending.”

“如果我们至少可以预先限制完成软件任务所需的工作量和成本，那么规模问题就不会那么可怕了。。。。没有任何理论可以让我们计算出软件的大小、性能或复杂性的限制。在许多情况下，甚至无法以逻辑严密的方式指定软件产品应该做什么或应该如何做。”

“The problems of scale would not be so frightening if we could at least place limits beforehand on the effort and cost required to complete a software task . . . . There is no theory which enables us to calculate limits on the size, performance, or complexity of software. There is, in many instances, no way even to specify in a logically tight way what the software product is supposed to do or how it is supposed to do it.”

“我认为指定一个完全没有歧义的系统可能是不可能的，如果我们使用自然语言，比如英语，当然是这样。”

“I think it is probably impossible to specify a system completely free of ambiguities, certainly so if we use a natural language, such as English.”

“有人认为，任何软件系统如果不能由四五个人在一年内完成，就永远无法完成。”

“Some people opine that any software system that cannot be completed by some four or five people within a year can never be completed.”

这些严峻的观点听起来很熟悉，但我遗漏了一个细节：这不是最近举行的会议。我引用的每一个字，以及数千个类似的字，都可以在 1968 年软件工程峰会的记录中找到——这是北约组织的第一次此类活动，当时其成员国都在凝视着他们刚刚开始的事情称之为“软件危机”。

These grim perspectives sound familiar, but I left out one detail: This wasn’t a recent conference. Every word I have quoted, and thousands more like them, can be found in the proceedings of a 1968 summit on software engineering—the first event of its kind, organized by NATO as its member nations stared into the eyes of what they had just begun to call “the Software Crisis.”

在IBM的OS/360灾难和其他有问题的大型软件项目之后，仍在全球冷战中角逐的北约伙伴认为，软件开发已成为一个紧迫的国际问题。他们在德国加米施（一个僻静的巴伐利亚滑雪胜地）聚集了数十名最优秀的人才，并要求他们提供有关软件可靠性、质量控制、成本控制和调度等主题的一些见解——这些主题是我们今天在笼统短语下提到的主题“软件工程。”

After IBM’s OS/360 disaster and other problematic large-scale software projects, the NATO partners, still jousting in a global Cold War that had extended its competition into outer space, decided that software development had become an urgent international problem. They gathered dozens of their best minds in Garmisch, Germany, a secluded Bavarian ski resort, and asked them for some insight on the subjects of software reliability, quality control, cost control, and scheduling—the topics we refer to today under the catchall phrase “software engineering.”

在那次会议之后的几十年里，软件和工程这两个词已经紧密地融合在一起，就像政府和官僚机构或者快餐和食品一样。在大型公司和小型初创企业中，任何能够编写快速脚本以实现自动化的员工都会被授予软件工程师的头衔。并非所有人都对此感到高兴。2003 年，得克萨斯州的一些程序员在名片上自称为软件工程师，收到了该州专业工程师委员会的勒令函，该委员会极力保护这一标签的使用。但尽管有这些官僚的后卫行动，这个术语已经变得普遍，很少引起人们对建筑结构和建筑规范之间的相似性是否有意义的疑问。

In the decades since that conference, these two words, software and engineering, have become fused at the hip, like government and bureaucracy or fast and food. At vast corporations and tiny start-ups alike, any employee who can throw together a quick script to automate something is given the title of software engineer. Not everyone is happy about this. In 2003, some programmers in Texas who referred to themselves as software engineers on their business cards received cease-and-desist letters from the state’s Board of Professional Engineers, which jealously protects use of the label. But despite such bureaucratic rearguard actions, the term has become universal, only rarely raising questions about whether the parallel between building structures and building code makes sense.

这在 1968 年还不是定局。当加米施组织者将他们的活动命名为软件工程会议时，他们“完全接受了这个术语……”。。。组织这次会议报告的英国软件专家布赖恩·兰德尔 (Brian Randell) 表示，“这只是表达了一种需求，而不是现实”。“‘软件工程’这个词是故意选择的，因为它具有挑衅性，暗示软件制造需要基于理论基础和实践学科的类型，而这些都是已建立的工程分支的传统类型。” 与会者打算规划如何将混乱的软件领域置于工程学的科学影响之下；这是一个愿望，而不是一个成就。

That was not a foregone conclusion in 1968. When the Garmisch organizers named their event a conference on software engineering, they “fully accepted that the term . . . expressed a need rather than a reality,” according to Brian Randell, a British software expert who organized the conference’s report. “The phrase ‘software engineering’ was deliberately chosen as being provocative, in implying the need for software manufacture to be based on the types of theoretical foundations and practical disciplines, that are traditional in the established branches of engineering.” The conference attendees intended to map out how they might bring the chaotic field of software under the scientific sway of engineering; it was an aspiration, not an accomplishment.

然而，在 1968 年的会议与次年在罗马举行的继任会议之间，显然发生了一些事情，这次会议让与会者充满热情和兴奋。第二次聚会旨在关注软件工程的具体技术。“与第一次会议不同。。。在罗马，已经有一种轻微的倾向，好像这个主题（软件工程）已经存在一样，”兰德尔在后来的事件回忆录中写道。软件工程一词几乎在一夜之间从“挑衅”演变为既成事实。

Yet something apparently happened in the interval between the 1968 conference, which left participants enthusiastic and excited, and its successor in Rome the following year. The second gathering aimed to focus on specific techniques of software engineering. “Unlike the first conference . . . in Rome there was already a slight tendency to talk as if the subject [software engineering] already existed,” Randell wrote in a later memoir of the events. The term software engineering had almost overnight evolved from a “provocation” to a fait accompli.

在最初的会议报告中，兰德尔写道，罗马会议“与其前任几乎没有相似之处。面对共同问题时的紧迫感并不像在加米施那样明显。相反，至少在编辑看来，参与者不同部分之间缺乏沟通成为一个主要特征。最终，这种沟通差距的严重性，以及意识到这只是现实世界情况的反映，导致差距本身成为讨论的主要话题。”

In the original conference report, Randell wrote that the Rome event “bore little resemblance to its predecessor. The sense of urgency in the face of common problems was not so apparent as at Garmisch. Instead, a lack of communication between different sections of the participants became, in the editors’ opinions at least, a dominant feature. Eventually the seriousness of this communications gap, and the realization that it was but a reflection of the situation in the real world, caused the gap itself to become a major topic of discussion.”

罗马出现的分歧，以及关于是否需要建立国际软件工程学院的争论，导致一位参与者，一位名叫汤姆·辛普森 (Tom Simpson) 的 IBM 程序员写了一篇题为“杰作工程”的讽刺作品。辛普森设想在1500年召开一次会议，试图将艺术杰作的制作“科学化”，试图明确《蒙娜丽莎》的创作标准，并建立一个研究所来促进更高效地制作伟大的画作。

The divisions that arose in Rome, along with a debate about the need for an international software engineering institute, led one participant, an IBM programmer named Tom Simpson, to write a satire titled “Masterpiece Engineering.” Simpson imagined a conference in the year 1500 trying to “scientificize” the production of art masterpieces, attempting to specify the criteria for creation of the Mona Lisa, and establishing an institute to promote the more efficient production of great paintings.



他们着手为杰作工作者配备一些更高效的工具，帮助他们创作杰作。他们发明了电动凿子、自动油漆管挤压器等。。。。产量仍未达到令人满意的水平。。。。在研究所花了两周的时间来计算一组画家每天产生的笔触数量，然后立即应用这一标准来评估其他画家的企业价值。如果一个画家每天不能交出二十笔画，那么他的生产力显然很低。遗憾的是，这些知识上的进步似乎都没有对杰作的制作产生任何真正的影响，因此，最后，该小组认为基本困难显然是管理问题。一名更聪明的学生（L. 达芬奇）立即晋升为该项目的经理，负责为组织的其他部分采购颜料、画布和画笔。

They set about equipping the masterpiece workers with some more efficient tools to help them create masterpieces. They invented power-driven chisels, automatic paint tube squeezers and so on . . . . Production was still not reaching satisfactory levels . . . . Two weeks at the Institute were spent in counting the number of brush strokes per day produced by one group of painters, and this criterion was then promptly applied in assessing the value to the enterprise of the rest. If a painter failed to turn in his twenty brush strokes per day he was clearly underproductive. Regrettably none of these advances in knowledge seemed to have any real impact on masterpiece production and so, at length, the group decided that the basic difficulty was clearly a management problem. One of the brighter students (by the name of L. da Vinci) was instantly promoted to manager of the project, putting him in charge of procuring paints, canvases and brushes for the rest of the organisation.



辛普森对罗马会议工作的恶搞很犀利：“几百年后，”他写道，“有人可能会在这个地方挖掘出我们的录音带，并发现我们同样可笑。” 会议组织者向兰德尔和报告的其他作者施压，要求将其从会议议程中删除，这对会议组织者来说是非常痛苦的。（几年后，兰德尔将其发布在网络上。）“杰作工程”在勾勒出中心断层线方面再无先见之明，这条断层线标志着软件危机及其解决方案的所有后续讨论——在那些将软件制造视为一种解决方案的人之间。科学的过程，易于不断改进，甚至可能是完美的，而那些将其视为主要创造性努力的人，可能会为了提高效率而进行调整，但永远不会像发条一样运行。

Simpson’s spoof of the Rome conference’s work had teeth: “In a few hundred years,” he wrote, “somebody may unearth our tape recordings on this spot and find us equally ridiculous.” It was sufficiently painful to the conference organizers that they pressured Randell and the other authors of the report to remove it from the proceedings. (Years later Randell posted it on the Web.) “Masterpiece Engineering” could not have been more prescient in laying out the central fault line that has marked all subsequent discussions of the Software Crisis and its solutions—between those who see making software as a scientific process, susceptible to constant improvement, perhaps even perfectible, and those who see it as a primarily creative endeavor, one that might be tweaked toward efficiency but never made to run like clockwork.

北约软件工程会议的两份长达 130 页的报告几乎预示了随后四个十年中软件领域占据的所有主题、想法和争议。参与者记录了他们对大规模软件开发的缓慢步伐和不确定结果的沮丧，并提出了许多自那时起流行和过时的补救措施： 小团队。“在设计过程的早期就收到了用户的反馈。” “现在就做一些小而有用的事情。” “使用标准：应该很容易解释。”

The two 130-page reports of the NATO software engineering conferences foreshadow virtually all the subjects, ideas, and controversies that have occupied the software field through four subsequent decades. The participants recorded their frustration with the lumbering pace and uncertain results of large-scale software development and advocated many of the remedies that have flowed in and out of fashion in the years since: Small teams. “Feedback from users early in the design process.” “Do something small, useful, now.” “Use the criterion: It should be easy to explain.”

乔治·桑塔亚纳（George Santayana）的格言“那些不记得过去的人注定会重蹈覆辙”在这里适用。人们很容易建议所有程序员及其经理都必须阅读这些北约报告。但是，正如 Joel Spolsky 所说，大多数程序员对自己的学科了解不多。这让他们陷入了自我无知的无限循环中。

George Santayana’s dictum that “those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it” applies here. It’s tempting to recommend that these NATO reports be required reading for all programmers and their managers. But, as Joel Spolsky says, most programmers don’t read much about their own discipline. That leaves them trapped in infinite loops of self-ignorance.





我们倾向于认为艺术劳动和科学劳动是截然不同的事业，但事实上它们形成了更多的范围。科学和艺术以不同的比例共同保管着大多数创造和洞察力的作品；“杰作工程师”列奥纳多·达·芬奇也许是最著名的提醒者。但软件领域长期以来一直受到过多的绝对主义者的诅咒，他们坚持认为解决所有问题的方法在于消除所有人类的不精确性并将其隔离在纯科学领域。在最极端的情况下，这种观点的支持者要求我们对我们的程序进行数学证明；只有被“证明正确”的程序才能被视为完成。我还没有发现很多实践程序员认为这种方法有多大价值。（正如我们将在下一章中看到的，无论如何这在理论上都是不可能的。）

We tend to think of the labors of art and those of science as distinctly separate endeavors, but in fact they form more of a spectrum. In varying proportions, science and art share custody of most works of creation and insight; “masterpiece engineer” Leonardo da Vinci is perhaps the most famous reminder of that. But the software field has long been cursed with an over-abundance of absolutists who insist that the solution to all its problems lies in ridding it of all human imprecision and sequestering it in the realm of pure science. At their most extreme, proponents of this view demand that we subject our programs to mathematical proofs; only programs that have been “proven correct” can be considered finished. I have not found many practicing programmers who see much value in this approach. (And as we will see in the next chapter, it may well be theoretically impossible anyway.)

当然，工程学就是弥合艺术与科学之间的鸿沟。工程学通常被定义为应用科学原理来满足人类需求。但它也为这些科学原理带来了创造力，将它们从原始的抽象中拖入我们的挫折和需求的妥协宇宙中。这个词源自（通过中世纪法语）同一个拉丁语词根，它赋予我们“聪明才智”，指的是巧妙地制造事物的能力。今天，我们以多种方式使用“工程”一词，并将其与其他词结合起来表示一系列分支学科：机械工程、土木工程、电气工程、结构工程、化学工程等。软件工程似乎只不过是这个列表中的后来者。为什么这个概念如此有问题？

Engineering is, of course, all about bridging the gulf between art and science. Engineering is often defined as the application of scientific principles to serve human needs. But it also brings creativity to bear on those scientific principles, dragging them out of pristine abstraction into the compromised universe of our frustrations and wants. The word derives (via a detour through medieval French) from the same Latin root that gave us ingenious and refers to the ability to make things skillfully. Today we use the term engineering in diverse ways, and we yoke it to other words to denote an array of subdisciplines: mechanical engineering, civil engineering, electrical engineering, structural engineering, chemical engineering, and so on. Software engineering seems no more than a latecomer to this list. Why is the concept so problematic?

正如我们所看到的，软件有时会让人感觉很棘手，因为它是看不见的。我们看不到的事物很难想象，而我们看不到的高度复杂的事物则很难沟通。但隐形并不是唯一的问题。我们看不到电、磁或重力，但我们可以出于大多数实际目的可靠地预测它们的行为。然而，仅仅让一个软件表现一致以便诊断问题通常仍然是我们力所不及的。

As we have seen, software sometimes feels intractable because it is invisible. Things that we can’t see are difficult to imagine, and highly complex things that we can’t see are very difficult to communicate. But invisibility isn’t the only issue. We can’t see electricity or magnetism or gravity, but we can reliably predict their behavior for most practical purposes. Yet simply getting a piece of software to behave consistently so that you can diagnose a problem often remains beyond our reach.

这是一个关于软件工程的笑话，您可以在数十个互联网幽默档案中找到它。（阿尔卑斯山的背景甚至可能是对北约在加米施聚会的致敬。）

Here is a joke about software engineering that you can find in dozens of Internet humor archives. (The Alpine setting might even be an homage to the NATO gathering at Garmisch.)



一名软件工程师、一名硬件工程师和一名部门经理正在前往瑞士参加会议的途中。他们正沿着陡峭的山路行驶，突然汽车刹车失灵了。汽车几乎失控地在路上倾斜，撞上防撞栏，直到奇迹般地沿着山坡停了下来。车上的乘客虽然受到了震动，但没有受伤，但现在遇到了一个问题：他们被困在半山腰的一辆没有刹车的汽车里。他们要做什么？

A Software Engineer, a Hardware Engineer, and a Departmental Manager were on their way to a meeting in Switzerland. They were driving down a steep mountain road when suddenly the brakes on their car failed. The car careened almost out of control down the road, bouncing off the crash barriers, until it miraculously ground to a halt scraping along the mountainside. The car’s occupants, shaken but unhurt, now had a problem: They were stuck halfway down a mountain in a car with no brakes. What were they to do?

“我知道。”部门经理说道。“让我们开个会，提出愿景，制定使命宣言，定义一些目标，并通过持续改进的过程找到关键问题的解决方案，然后我们就可以上路了。”

“I know,” said the Departmental Manager. “Let’s have a meeting, propose a Vision, formulate a Mission Statement, define some Goals, and by a process of Continuous Improvement find a solution to the Critical Problems, and we can be on our way.”

“不，不，”硬件工程师说。“这将花费太长的时间，而且，这种方法以前从未奏效过。我随身带着我的瑞士军刀，我很快就能拆下汽车的制动系统，找出故障，修复它，然后我们就可以上路了。”

“No, no,” said the Hardware Engineer. “That will take far too long, and, besides, that method has never worked before. I’ve got my Swiss Army knife with me, and in no time at all I can strip down the car’s braking system, isolate the fault, fix it, and we can be on our way.”

“好吧，”软件工程师说，“在我们采取任何行动之前，我认为我们应该将汽车推回到路上，看看是否会再次发生。”

“Well,” said the Software Engineer, “before we do anything, I think we should push the car back up the road and see if it happens again.”



如果你向程序员报告错误，她会做的第一件事就是问，“你重复了这个问题吗？”——意思是，你能可靠地让它再次发生吗？如果答案是肯定的，那么战斗就成功了一半。如果不是，大多数时候程序员只会耸耸肩，并将其归咎于硬件故障或宇宙射线。

If you report a bug to a programmer, the first thing she will do is ask, “Have you duplicated the problem?”—meaning, can you reliably make it happen again? If the answer is yes, that’s more than half the battle. If it is no, most of the time the programmer will simply shrug her shoulders and write it off to faulty hardware or cosmic rays.

“‘软件工程’在某种程度上是一个矛盾的说法，”七八十年代曾在著名的施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心工作的软件资深人士 L. Peter Deutsch 说道。“在拥有物理学之前，很难拥有真正的工程学，而且对于软件来说，根本没有任何接近物理学的东西。”

“‘Software engineering’ is something of an oxymoron,” L. Peter Deutsch, a software veteran who worked at the fabled Xerox Palo Alto Research Center in the seventies and eighties, has said. “It’s very difficult to have real engineering before you have physics, and there isn’t anything even close to a physics for software.”





其他学科的学生有时被认为有“物理学嫉妒”，因为正如计算先驱艾伦·凯所说，物理学家“研究宇宙的绝对基础，他们用严肃的数学来做到这一点。” 寻找“软件的物理学”已经成为软件研究人员长达数十年的追求。如果我们能够发现软件运行的可靠原理，我们就可以超越当今鲁布·戈德堡式程序的压倒性复杂性，并通过设计摆脱软件时代的泥潭。有一天，我们会发现自己身处一个软件根本不需要编程的世界。

Students of other kinds of science are sometimes said to have “physics envy,” since, as computing pioneer Alan Kay has put it, physicists “deal with the absolute foundations of the universe, and they do it with serious math.” The search for a “physics for software” has become a decades-long quest for software researchers. If we could only discover dependable principles by which software operates, we could transcend the overpowering complexity of today’s Rube Goldberg–style programs and engineer our way out of the mire of software time. One day we could find ourselves in a world where software does not need to be programmed at all.

对于许多追求这一目标的人来说，共同的目标是“自动软件”的想法——非程序员可以创建的软件，用计算机可以理解的简单英语命令。这个梦想诞生于计算机时代的黎明之际，当时海军少将格蕾丝·霍珀和她的同事发明了编译器。“霍珀相信编程不一定是一项艰巨的任务，”她的官方海军传记草图报道道。“她相信程序可以用英语编写，然后翻译成二进制代码。” Hopper 设计的 Flow-Matic 语言成为 Cobol 的根源之一，Cobol 是一种面向业务的编程语言，在世纪之交仍在广泛使用。

For many on this quest, the common grail has been the idea of “automatic software”—software that nonprogrammers can create, commands in simple English that the computer can be made to understand. This dream was born at the dawn of the computer era when Rear Admiral Grace Hopper and her colleagues invented the compiler. “Hopper believed that programming did not have to be a difficult task,” her official Navy biographical sketch reports. “She believed that programs could be written in English and then translated into binary code.” Flow-Matic, the language Hopper designed, became one of the roots of Cobol, the business-oriented programming language that was still in wide use at the turn of the millennium.

霍珀的编译器比用机器语言的零和一的二进制代码进行编程有了巨大的进步，它为未来的每一个软件进步奠定了基础。但指出用 Cobol 或自发明以来的任何其他编程语言编写与用英语编写仍然相去甚远，这并不是对她的工作的诽谤。同样，Fortran 的发明者希望他们的突破性语言能够“几乎消除编码”，但他们却亲眼目睹了自己的杰作因粗糙和笨拙而受到诅咒。

Hopper’s compiler was a vast advance over programming in machine language’s binary code of zeros and ones, and it provided a foundation for every software advance to come. But it is no slur on her work to point out that writing in Cobol, or any other programming language since invented, is still a far cry from writing in English. Similarly, the inventors of Fortran, who hoped that their breakthrough language might “virtually eliminate coding,” lived to see their handiwork cursed for its crudity and clumsiness.

然而，实际上消除编码的梦想以多种形式得以延续，催生了新的缩写词，例如按字母顺序排列的藻类绽放。统一建模语言 (UML) 提供了抽象词汇（方框、斑点和箭头），用于独立于特定编程语言的图表和设计软件。模型驱动开发 (MDD) 和模型驱动架构 (MDA) 是围绕 UML 构建的开发方法的术语。有一种“生成式编程”，其中最终的软件产品不是手工编写的，而是由生成器（实际上是另一个程序）生成的。还有一个新的流行语“软件工厂”，它在亨利·福特式的自动化软件构建过程的隐喻旗帜下混合和匹配了其中一些概念。

Yet the dream of virtually eliminating coding has survived in several forms, breeding new acronyms like an alphabetical algae bloom. There is the Unified Modeling Language, or UML, which provides an abstract vocabulary—boxes, blobs, and arrows—for diagramming and designing software independent of specific programming languages. There is Model Driven Development (MDD) and Model Driven Architecture (MDA), terms for approaches to development built around the UML. There is “generative programming,” in which the final software product is not written by hand but produced by a generator (which is actually another program). And there is a new buzzphrase, “software factories,” which mixes and matches some of these concepts under the metaphoric banner of automating the software building process Henry Ford–style.

当今最引人注目的实现消除编码梦想的努力是由施乐和微软的现代文字处理软件的发明者查尔斯·西蒙尼（Charles Simonyi）领导的，我们已经认识了他，他是匈牙利符号之父。多年来，西蒙尼一直在微软领导一个他称之为“意向编程”的领域的研究。2002 年，他离开了让他成为亿万富翁的公司，并资助了一家新企业 Intentional Software，目标是将研究成果转化为现实世界的产品。

The highest-profile effort today to realize a version of the dream of eliminating coding is led by Charles Simonyi, the inventor of modern word processing software at Xerox and Microsoft, whom we have already met as the father of Hungarian notation. For years Simonyi led research at Microsoft into a field he called “intentional programming.” In 2002, he left the company that had made him a billionaire and funded a new venture, Intentional Software, with the goal of transforming that research into a real-world product.

西蒙尼是一位衣冠楚楚、迷人的男人，他的声音中仍带着一丝他十几岁时逃离匈牙利的痕迹。他正在胸怀大志。他和地球上的任何人一样意识到软件困难的漫长而令人遗憾的历史。“据我们所知，软件是数字丰富的瓶颈，”他说。摩尔定律推动计算机芯片和硬件呈指数曲线增长，速度和效率不断提高，但软件却步履维艰，无法跟上。

Simonyi—a dapper, engaging man whose voice still carries a trace of Hungary, which he fled in his teens—is thinking big. He is as aware of the long, sorry history of software’s difficulties as anyone on the planet. “Software as we know it is the bottleneck on the digital horn of plenty,” he says. Moore’s Law drives computer chips and hardware up an exponential curve of increasing speed and efficiency, but software plods along, unable to keep up.

在西蒙尼看来，麻烦的根源之一是我们期望程序员做太多事情。我们要求他们成为从非程序员那里提取知识的专家，以便弄清楚要构建什么；然后我们要求他们成为将这些愿望传达给计算机的专家。“软件设计有两个含义，”他说。“一个是设计我们正在尝试实现的工件。另一个是纯粹的软件工程，使该工件得以诞生。我相信这是两个不同的角色——主题专家和软件工程师。”

In Simonyi’s view, one source of the trouble is that we expect programmers to do too much. We ask them to be experts at extracting knowledge from nonprogrammers in order to figure out what to build; then we demand that they be experts at communicating those wishes to the computer. “There are two meanings to software design,” he says. “One is designing the artifact we’re trying to implement. The other is the sheer software engineering to make that artifact come into being. I believe these are two separate roles—the subject matter expert and the software engineer.”

Intentional Software 旨在“增强”“主题专家”的能力，即了解软件使用领域的人，无论是空中交通、医疗保健还是冒险游戏。西蒙尼希望为这些主题专家提供一套工具，他们可以使用这些工具以计算机可以理解的结构化方式解释他们的意图和需求。Intentional Software 的系统将让非程序员专家定义一系列问题，例如，对于医院管理程序，他们可能会以一种方式对所有“参与者”、他们的“角色”、需要执行的任务以及所有其他细节进行分类。机器可读的格式。然后，这组定义、该模型将被输入到生成器程序中，生成最终产品软件。程序员仍然需要为主题专家构建工具和编写生成器。但是，一旦这项工作完成，非程序员就可以修改他们的模型并对软件进行更改，而无需“向程序员提出谦虚的请求”。看，妈妈，没有编码！

Intentional Software intends to “empower” the “subject matter experts”—the people who understand the domain in which the software will be used, whether it is air traffic or health care or adventure gaming. Simonyi wants to give these subject matter experts a set of tools they can use to explain their intentions and needs in a structured way that the computer can understand. Intentional Software’s system will let the nonprogrammer experts define a set of problems—for a hospital administration program, say, they might catalog all the “actors,” their “roles,” tasks that need to be performed, and all other details—in a machine-readable format. That set of definitions, that model, is then fed into a generator program that spits out the end-product software. There is still work for programmers in building the tools for the subject matter experts and in writing the generator. But once that work is done, the nonprogrammers can tinker with their model and make changes in the software without ever needing to “make a humble request to the programmer.” Look, Ma, no coding!

在一篇描述 Intentional 工作的文章中，科技记者克莱尔·特里斯特拉姆 (Claire Tristram) 提供了这样的类比：“这就像建筑师能够绘制蓝图，具有建造其所描绘的结构的神奇属性，甚至，如果蓝图被修改，重建重新构建结构。”

In an article describing Intentional’s work, technology journalist Claire Tristram offers this analogy: “It’s something like an architect being able to draw a blueprint that has the magical property of building the structure it depicts—and even, should the blueprint be amended, rebuilding the structure anew.”

西蒙尼的梦想是自动化软件开发过程中的复杂性，这是该领域的长期思考者的共同梦想。他的非凡之处在于，他拥有将其推向现实的坚定决心和财力。“有人曾经问我应该用什么语言来编写一个百万行的程序，”西蒙尼在 2005 年告诉一位采访者。“我问他为什么必须编写一个百万行的程序。他有百万行的问题吗？大英百科全书有一百万行——二十卷，每卷一千页。商业实践或管理问题包含如此多的细节，这几乎是不可想象的。” 事实上，西蒙尼认为，你应该只处理一万行“问题描述”和另外一万行生成器代码——总共两万行更易于管理，其中包含那百万行的“等效信息内容”——线怪物。

Simonyi’s dream of automating the complexity out of the software development process is a common one among the field’s long-range thinkers. He is unusual in having the singlemindedness and the financial resources to push it toward reality. “Somebody once asked me what language should be used to write a million-line program,” Simonyi told an interviewer in 2005. “I asked him how come he has to write a million-line program. Does he have a million-line problem? A million lines is the Encyclopedia Britannica—twenty volumes of a thousand pages each. It’s almost inconceivable that a business practice or administrative problem would have that much detail in it.” Really, Simonyi argues, you should be dealing with maybe only ten thousand lines of “problem description” and another ten thousand lines of code for the generator—a much more manageable twenty thousand total lines containing the “equivalent information content” of that million-line monstrosity.

作为一个年轻人，西蒙尼领导了 Bravo 的开发，这是第一个文字处理程序，它以程序员现在所说的 WYSIWYG 方式运行（“所见即所得”，发音为“wizzy wig”）。今天，我们理所当然地认为，我们在计算机屏幕上创建的文档（其字体、大小和图像）在打印出来时看起来是一样的。但在 20 世纪 70 年代中期，这是一场革命。

As a young man, Simonyi led the development of Bravo, the first word processing program that functioned in what programmers now call WYSIWYG fashion (for “what you see is what you get,” pronounced “wizzy wig”). Today we take for granted that a document we create on the computer screen, with its type fonts and sizes and images, will look the same when we print it out. But in the mid-1970s, this was a revolution.

在某种程度上，西蒙尼的意向软件试图将所见即所得原则应用到编程本身的行为中。但西蒙尼对他的发明将塑造的勇敢的新软件世界的热情描述留下了一个未解答的核心问题：意向软件是否会为主题专家提供一种灵活的方式来直接向机器表达他们的需求，或者是否会要求非程序员专家服从创建超详细的机器可读模型的枷锁？它是软件进化阶梯的一次飞跃，还是只是一种自动化需求规范的奇特方式？它能帮助计算机更好地理解人类，还是会迫使人们更像计算机一样进行交流？西蒙尼很乐观。但截至撰写本文时，Intentional Software 尚未推出其产品，因此很难说。

Simonyi’s Intentional Software is, in a way, an attempt to apply the WYSIWYG principle to the act of programming itself. But Simonyi’s enthusiastic descriptions of the brave new software world his invention will shape leave a central question unanswered: Will Intentional Software give the subject matter experts a flexible way to express their needs directly to the machine—or will it demand that nonprogrammer experts submit themselves to the yoke of creating an ultra-detailed, machine-readable model? Is it a leap up the ladder of software evolution or just a fancy way to automate the specification of requirements? Can it help computers understand people better, or will it just force people to communicate more like computers? Simonyi is bullish. But as of this writing, Intentional Software has yet to unveil its products, so it’s hard to say.





我们已经看到，软件是一个分层的东西，每一层都为上面和下面的层转换信息和过程。在这层堆栈的底部是带有纯二进制 1 和 0 的机器。位于顶层的是人类，他们构建和使用这些层。西蒙尼的意向软件本质上只是在机器和我们之间多了一层。

Software, we’ve seen, is a thing of layers, with each layer translating information and processes for the layers above and below. At the bottom of this stack of layers sits the machine with its pure binary ones and zeros. At the top are the human beings, building and using these layers. Simonyi’s Intentional Software, at heart, simply proposes one more layer between the machine and us.

软件的层是其本质，也是推动该领域进步的动力，但它们有一个持续存在的弱点。他们泄漏。例如，许多版本的 Microsoft Windows 的用户都对蓝屏死机现象感到厌倦。您正在某个软件应用程序（例如 Web 浏览器或 Microsoft Word）中工作，突然间，您的屏幕突然变成蓝色，并且您会看到上面有一些白色文本，内容如下：

Software’s layers are its essence, and they are what drive progress in the field, but they have a persistent weakness. They leak. For instance, users of many versions of Microsoft Windows are wearily familiar with the phenomenon of the Blue Screen of Death. You are working away inside some software application like a Web browser or Microsoft Word, and suddenly, out of nowhere, your screen turns blue and you see some white text on it that reads something like this:



0167:BFF9DFFF 处发生致命异常 0E。当前的应用程序将被终止。

A fatal exception 0E has occurred at 0167:BFF9DFFF. The current application will be terminated.



看着屏幕的单色外观和块状字体，资深用户可能会觉得他们已经回到了计算机时代。有些人甚至可能会理解，该消息对“致命异常”的令人震惊的引用意味着程序遇到了无法恢复的错误并已崩溃，或者神秘的十六进制（以 16 为基数）数字描述了计算机内存中的确切位置事故发生了。这些信息对于大多数用户来说没有任何价值。他们所使用的应用程序的舒适、熟悉的界面已经消失了；更深层次的抽象——在本例中是Windows“外壳”或较低级别的控制程序——已经像倾斜的基岩层一样从较新的地质地层中伸出并进入阳光。（蓝屏死机虽然令人困惑，但它实际上代表了较早期版本的 Windows 的一大进步，因为它有时允许用户关闭有问题的程序并继续工作。在蓝屏之前，一个 Windows 程序的崩溃几乎总是拿下整台机器及其所有程序。）

Eyeing the screen’s monochrome look and the blockish typeface, veteran users may sense that they have been flung backward in computer time. Some may even understand that the message’s alarming reference to a “fatal exception” means that the program has encountered a bug it cannot recover from and has crashed, or that the cryptic hexadecimal (base 16) numbers describe the exact location in the computer’s memory where the crash took place. None of the information is of any value to most users. The comfortable, familiar interface of the application they were using has vanished; a deeper layer of abstraction—in this case, the Windows “shell” or lower-level control program—has erupted like a slanted layer of bedrock poking up through more recent geological strata and into the sunlight. (Perplexing as the Blue Screen of Death is, it actually represented a great advance from earlier versions of Windows since it sometimes allows the user to shut down the offending program and continue working. Before the blue screen, the crash of one Windows program almost always took down the entire machine and all its programs.)

乔尔·斯波尔斯基 (Joel Spolsky) 在一篇题为《抽象泄漏定律》的文章中写道，“从某种程度上来说，所有不平凡的抽象都是有泄漏的。抽象失败。有时一点，有时很多。有泄漏。事情出了问题。” 对于用户来说，这意味着有时您的计算机会以奇怪、令人困惑的方式运行，有时您会想将其扔出窗外，正如米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 在他的软件设计宣言中所说的那样。对于程序员来说，这意味着将一些低级计算复杂性捆绑在一起并将其封装在一个新的、更易于操作的抽象中的新工具和想法是伟大的，但仅限于它们被破坏之前。然后，所有隐藏的复杂性都会重新渗透到他们的工作中。理论上，方便的新顶层可以让程序员忘记它下面的混乱；在实践中，程序员仍然需要理解这种混乱，因为最终他会陷入其中。斯波尔斯基写道：

In an essay titled “The Law of Leaky Abstractions,” Joel Spolsky wrote, “All non-trivial abstractions, to some degree, are leaky. Abstractions fail. Sometimes a little, sometimes a lot. There’s leakage. Things go wrong.” For users this means that sometimes your computer behaves in bizarre, perplexing ways, and sometimes you will want to, as Mitch Kapor said in his Software Design Manifesto, throw it out the window. For programmers it means that new tools and ideas that bundle up some bit of low-level computing complexity and package it in a new, easier-to-manipulate abstraction are great, but only until they break. Then all that hidden complexity leaks back into their work. In theory, the handy new top layer allows programmers to forget about the mess below it; in practice, the programmer still needs to understand that mess, because eventually he is going to land in it. Spolsky wrote:



抽象并没有真正简化我们的生活，正如它们本来的目的那样。。。。泄漏抽象定律意味着，每当有人想出一种新的、令人惊叹的代码生成工具，该工具应该让我们变得如此高效时，你会听到很多人说：“先学习如何手动完成，然后再学习如何手动完成它。”使用 wzzy 工具可以节省时间。” 代码生成工具假装抽象出某些东西，就像所有抽象一样，会发生泄漏，而有效处理泄漏的唯一方法就是了解抽象是如何工作的以及它们正在抽象什么。因此，抽象可以节省我们工作的时间，但不能节省我们学习的时间。。。。所有这些都意味着，矛盾的是，即使我们拥有越来越高水平的编程工具和越来越好的抽象，成为一名熟练的程序员却变得越来越难。

Abstractions do not really simplify our lives as much as they were meant to . . . . The law of leaky abstractions means that whenever somebody comes up with a wizzy new code-generation tool that is supposed to make us all ever-so-efficient, you hear a lot of people saying, “Learn how to do it manually first, then use the wizzy tool to save time.” Code-generation tools that pretend to abstract out something, like all abstractions, leak, and the only way to deal with the leaks competently is to learn about how the abstractions work and what they are abstracting. So the abstractions save us time working, but they don’t save us time learning . . . . And all this means that paradoxically, even as we have higher and higher level programming tools with better and better abstractions, becoming a proficient programmer is getting harder and harder.



因此，尽管“我们多年来创建的抽象确实使我们能够处理软件开发中新的复杂性，而这些是我们在十年或十五年前不必处理的”，尽管这些工具“让我们非常快地完成大量工作，”斯波尔斯基写道，“突然有一天，我们需要找出抽象泄漏的问题，而这需要两周时间。”

So even though “the abstractions we’ve created over the years do allow us to deal with new orders of complexity in software development that we didn’t have to deal with ten or fifteen years ago,” and even though these tools “let us get a lot of work done incredibly quickly,” Spolsky wrote, “suddenly one day we need to figure out a problem where the abstraction leaked, and it takes two weeks.”

抽象泄漏定律解释了为什么我采访过的许多程序员在听到关于意向编程或其他类似的超越软件复杂性的想法的描述时都会怀疑地翻白眼。这并不是说他们不欢迎在抽象阶梯上再迈出一步；而是他们不欢迎在抽象阶梯上再迈出一步。但他们担心，无论他们在梯子上爬得多高，他们总是需要在梯子上跑来跑去，而梯子越高，行程就越长。

The Law of Leaky Abstractions explains why so many programmers I’ve talked to roll their eyes skeptically when they hear descriptions of Intentional Programming or other similar ideas for transcending software’s complexity. It’s not that they wouldn’t welcome taking another step up the abstraction ladder; but they fear that no matter how high they climb on that ladder, they will always have to run up and down it more than they’d like—and the taller it becomes, the longer the trip.





如果您与程序员谈论抽象层足够长的时间，您几乎肯定会听到“乌龟一直向下”这句话。它引用了史蒂芬·霍金在他的畅销书《时间简史》的开头所用的一个流行的——显然是杜撰的或至少来源不确定的——轶事：

If you talk to programmers long enough about layers of abstraction, you’re almost certain to hear the phrase “turtles all the way down.” It is a reference to a popular—and apparently apocryphal or at least uncertainly sourced—anecdote that Stephen Hawking used to open his popular book A Brief History of Time:



一位著名科学家（有人说是伯特兰·罗素）曾经做过一次关于天文学的公开讲座。他描述了地球如何绕太阳公转，以及太阳如何绕着称为银河系的庞大恒星集合的中心公转。讲座结束时，教室后面的一位小老太太站起来说：“你告诉我们的都是垃圾。世界其实就是巨龟背上的一块平板。” 科学家露出了优越的笑容，回答道：“乌龟站在什么上面？” “你很聪明，年轻人，非常聪明，”老太太说。“但一路下来都是海龟！”

A well-known scientist (some say it was Bertrand Russell) once gave a public lecture on astronomy. He described how the earth orbits around the sun and how the sun, in turn, orbits around the center of a vast collection of stars called our galaxy. At the end of the lecture, a little old lady at the back of the room got up and said: “What you have told us is rubbish. The world is really a flat plate supported on the back of a giant tortoise.” The scientist gave a superior smile before replying, “What is the tortoise standing on?” “You’re very clever, young man, very clever,” said the old lady. “But it’s turtles all the way down!”



对于宇宙学家来说，这个故事是谈论终极起源问题的一种有趣的方式。对于程序员来说，它有不同的含义：它提供了一种谈论内部一致的系统的方式。比如说，“从头到尾的对象”或“从头到尾的 XML”的软件产品具有统一的性质，不需要复杂而麻烦的内部转换。

For cosmologists the tale is an amusing way to talk about the problem of ultimate origins. For programmers it has a different spin: It provides a way of talking about systems that are internally coherent. Software products that are, say, “objects all the way down” or “XML all the way down” have a unified nature that doesn’t require complex and troublesome internal translation.

但对于像我一样断奶的苏斯博士文集的人来说，“一路下来的海龟”还有另一个联想：它让人想起《海龟耶特尔》的经典故事，其中一只海龟王爬到了海龟顶上。海龟塔让他可以观察他王国的广阔范围。最后，堆中最低的乌龟打嗝，国王和堆中其余的乌龟一起下来。耶特尔的道德观是——好吧，道德观有很多。对于程序员来说，教训可能是海龟堆或抽象层即使是一小部分的失败也不能很好地响应。用软件世界的不满者中非常流行的一个词来说，它们是脆弱的。当受到压力时，它们不会弯曲，而是会断裂。

But for anyone weaned, as I was, on the collected works of Dr. Seuss, “turtles all the way down” has yet another association: It recalls the classic tale of “Yertle the Turtle,” in which a turtle king climbs atop a turtle tower so he can survey the vast extent of his kingdom. Finally, the lowliest turtle in the stack burps, and down comes the king, along with the rest of the turtles in the pile. The moral of Yertle is—well, there are plenty of morals. For a programmer the lesson might be that stacks of turtles, or layers of abstractions, don’t respond well to the failure of even one small part. They are, to use a word that is very popular among the software world’s malcontents, brittle. When stressed, they don’t bend, they break.

“如果建筑商按照程序员构建程序的方式建造房屋，那么第一只啄木鸟的出现就会摧毁文明，”计算机程序员心理学的先驱杰拉尔德·温伯格(Gerald Weinberg)曾经写道。水手一号的建造者了解到，如果漏掉一个连字符，你的火箭就会失控。

“If builders built houses the way programmers built programs, the first woodpecker to come along would destroy civilization,” Gerald Weinberg, the pioneer of computer programmer psychology, once wrote. Leave out a hyphen, the builders of Mariner 1 learned, and your rocket goes haywire.

对于 UML 的支持者 Charles Simonyi 和许多其他软件乐观主义者来说，梦想在今天的海龟堆栈中添加另一个新层就足够了。他们指出，这就是该领域过去一直发展的方式，那么为什么不继续前进呢？但当今软件世界还有其他批评者，他们的诊断更为全面。在他们看来，问题出在堆栈本身。脆弱来自于我们对一堆不可靠概念的依赖。整个编程领域过去曾经历过一次或多次错误的转变。他们说，现在是重新开始的时候了。

For Charles Simonyi, the proponents of the UML, and many other software optimists, it is enough to dream of adding another new layer to today’s stack of turtles. That’s how the field has always advanced in the past, they point out, so why not keep going? But there are other critics of today’s software universe whose diagnosis is more sweeping. In their view, the problem is the stack itself. The brittleness comes from our dependence on a pile of unreliable concepts. The entire field of programming took one or more wrong turns in the past. Now, they say, it’s time to start over.





艾伦·凯 (Alan Kay) 坐在笔记本电脑前，面前是挤满了人。他正在展示一张幻灯片。幻灯片展示了两张照片，通过代表时间流逝的上升曲线连接。在曲线的末端，右上方的照片显示了一座倒塌的桥梁，其标题写着：“你终于在这里学到了…… ” 。。”; 在曲线的起点，正在建造的同一座桥梁的左下角照片带有标题“。” 。。您需要在这里了解什么。”

Alan Kay sits in front of a laptop before a packed crowd. He is showing a slide. The slide presents two photos connected by an ascending curve representing the passage of time. At the curve’s end, the top right photo, which shows a collapsed bridge, has a caption that reads, “You finally learn here . . . ”; at the start of the curve, the bottom left photo of the same bridge being built bears the caption, “ . . . what you needed to know here.”

凯是个人电脑发展的核心人物之一，他并没有提供事后诸葛亮的教训。他将他的幻灯片命名为“什么是后期装订？” 并回答如下问题：“晚绑定就是能够更早地进行更改。”

Kay, one of the central figures in the development of the personal computer, isn’t offering a lesson in the power of hindsight. He has named his slide “What is late binding?” and answered the question as follows: “Late binding is being able to make the changes earlier.”

后期绑定是计算机科学中的一个术语，指的是编程语言为程序员提供更大灵活性的能力。后期绑定程序可以在运行时即时更改；您甚至可以构建它们，以便它们在运行时改变自己。虽然当今一些流行的编程语言（某种程度上是 Java，更大程度上是 Python（钱德勒的语言））被认为具有后期绑定性质，但现代软件大厦的大部分底层的核心语言是 C 和 C++ ， 不要。凯认为，它们中没有一个能够实现真正的后期绑定系统的承诺——即使是非程序员也可以轻松操纵的系统，其缺陷很容易修复，而且它们的命运就是进化。Kay 说，要找到体现后期绑定动态能力本质的更灵活的语言，你必须追溯到几十年前——Lisp，人工智能研究员 John McCarthy 在 20 世纪 50 年代发明的“列表处理器”语言，以及 Smalltalk，这种语言是凯本人于七十年代在施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心构思出来的。
