Late binding is a term in computer science that refers to programming languages’ capacity to provide programmers with more flexibility. Late-bound programs can be changed on the fly, while they’re running; you can even build them so that they change themselves while they’re running. While some of the popular programming languages of today—Java to some degree, Python (Chandler’s language) to a greater degree—are considered to have a late-binding nature, the core languages underlying much of the edifice of modern software, C and C++, do not. And none of them, according to Kay, fulfills the promise of true late-binding systems—systems that can be so easily manipulated, even by nonprogrammers, that their flaws are simple to repair and their destiny is to evolve. To find nimbler languages that embody the essence of late-binding dynamic power, Kay says, you have to go back decades—to Lisp, the “list processor” language invented by artificial intelligence researcher John McCarthy in the 1950s, and to Smalltalk, the language Kay himself conceived at Xerox’s Palo Alto Research Center in the seventies.

相反，今天的程序员仍然受制于“编译周期”。当他们做出改变时，他们必须等待系统消化它。首先，他们通过编译器运行新代码，然后重新启动程序以查看更改是否达到了目标。如今更快的计算机缩短了编译周期，但你仍然可以发现程序员到处咒骂它。钱德勒团队也不例外。尽管 Python 提供了后期绑定方法的一些优点，但他们用来构建图形用户界面的工具依赖于 C++；即使 Chandler 本身不需要重新编译，程序员仍然面临着修复和重新启动的循环。您必须等待三十甚至六十秒才能启动程序，然后才能看到代码更改的结果。这些秒加起来就是很长的等待时间。

Instead, today’s programmers remain in the thrall of the “compile cycle.” When they make a change, they have to wait for the system to digest it. First, they run the new code through the compiler, and then they restart the program to see whether the change achieved its goal. Today’s faster computers have shortened the compile cycle, but you can still find programmers cursing it everywhere. The Chandler team was no exception. Even though Python offered some of the advantages of the late-binding approach, the tools they were using to build their graphic user interface depended on C++; and even when Chandler itself didn’t need to be recompiled, the programmers still faced a cycle of fix-and-restart. You had to wait thirty or even sixty seconds for the program to launch before you could see the results of a change in the code. Those seconds added up to a lot of waiting time.

凯谦虚的身材似乎与他思想的广泛范围成反比，近年​​来，他像一个留着小胡子的矮个子耶利米一样在计算领域漫游，谴责最先进的技术，哀叹该领域所采取的错误转变。过去四分之一个世纪，并呼吁听众放弃堕落的道路并重新开始。“我们只是还不知道如何开发软件，”他说。“计算机人员对自己所取得的成就比应有的更加满意。。。。人们不明白还有其他选择。我们需要比现在好数百倍的软件。”

Kay’s modest stature seems inversely related to the broad scope of his ideas, and in recent years he has roamed the terrain of the computing field like a diminutive, mustachioed Jeremiah, denouncing the state of the art, bemoaning the wrong turns the field has taken in the last quarter century, and calling on listeners to forsake their fallen ways and start afresh. “We just don’t know how to do software yet,” he says. “Computer people are way more self-satisfied with what they have accomplished than they should be . . . . People don’t understand that there are alternatives. We need software that’s factors of hundreds better than it is.”

七十年代，Kay 在施乐帕洛阿尔托研究中心 (Xerox PARC) 创造了“面向对象编程”这一术语，发明了重叠窗口界面的概念，并试图实现他 1968 年对 Dynabook 的愿景——他梦想成为终极笔记本电脑。童年想象力的游乐场。此后的几十年里，他看到硬件行业逐渐提供与他的想法相似的计算工具，而在他看来，软件领域却停滞不前。

At Xerox PARC in the seventies, Kay coined the term “object-oriented programming,” invented the concept of the overlapping windows interface, and tried to realize his 1968 vision of the Dynabook—an ur-laptop that he dreamed could serve as the ultimate playground for childhood imaginations. In the decades since, he watched the hardware industry gradually deliver computing tools that resembled his ideas—while the software field, in his view, stagnated.

凯在谈论软件时喜欢使用历史类比。“如果你看看今天的软件，”他在 2004 年告诉一位采访者，“它肯定是某种工程——但这是那些没有拱门概念的人所做的那种工程。今天的大多数软件都非常像埃及金字塔，有数百万块砖块相互堆叠，没有结构完整性，只是通过暴力和数千名奴隶完成的。”

Kay loves to use historical analogies when he talks about software. “If you look at software today,” he told an interviewer in 2004, “it’s certainly engineering of a sort—but it’s the kind of engineering that people without the concept of the arch did. Most software today is very much like an Egyptian pyramid with millions of bricks piled on top of each other, with no structural integrity, but just done by brute force and thousands of slaves.”

凯说，你可以用这种方式构建大型产品，但它“无法扩展”。最终，数量需要质量的改变。在一种规模上有效的设计在另一种规模上却失败了。在 1997 年 Smalltalk 二十五周年纪念演讲中，Kay 阐述了这一论点的逻辑。“你可以用任何东西建造一个狗窝，”他宣称，但是当你将它扩大一百倍时，你就会遇到麻烦：质量的指数增长速度快于力量的增长速度。

You can build big things this way, Kay says, but it “doesn’t scale.” Ultimately, quantity demands a change in quality; the design that works at one scale fails at another. In a 1997 talk on the twenty-fifth anniversary of Smalltalk, Kay walked through the logic of this argument. “You can make a doghouse out of anything,” he declared, but when you enlarge it by a factor of one hundred, you’re in trouble: Mass increases exponentially faster than strength.



当你将某物炸毁一百倍时，它就会变弱一百倍。如果你试图用这种方式建造一座大教堂，它只会倒塌成一堆瓦砾。最流行的回应是，这就是我们一直以来想要做的：在上面放更多垃圾，用石灰石覆盖它，然后说，是的，我们真的想做金字塔，而不是哥特式大教堂。我认为这解释了当今现代操作系统的大部分结构。。。。或者，您可以提出一个新概念，就像多年前开始对复杂结构感兴趣的人们所做的那样。他们称之为建筑——字面意思是成功拱门的设计和建造。简单材料之间不明显的非线性相互作用，为您提供不明显的协同作用和材料的大量倍增。

When you blow something up by a factor of one hundred, it gets weaker by a factor of one hundred. If you try to build a cathedral that way, it just collapses into a pile of rubble. The most popular response is to say, well that was what we were trying to do all along: put more garbage on it, plaster it over with limestone, and say, yes, we were really trying to do pyramids, not Gothic cathedrals. That I think accounts for much of the structure of modern operating systems today . . . . Or, you can come up with a new concept, which the people who started getting interested in complex structures many years ago did. They called it architecture—literally, the designing and building of successful arches. Non-obvious, non-linear interaction between simple materials that gives you non-obvious synergies and a vast multiplication of materials.



凯说，当他告诉人们沙特尔大教堂的高耸尖塔所需的物理材料比帕台农神庙更少时，人们感到很惊讶。“它全部由空气和玻璃组成，巧妙地组织在一个美丽的结构中，使整体比任何部分都更加完整。” 凯认为，今天的软件学科实际上已经处于中世纪的某个阶段——“我们不必建造金字塔，我们可以建造哥特式大教堂，用更少的材料建造更大的结构”——但商业软件世界仍然停留在金字塔模式。

People are amazed, Kay said, when he tells them that the towering spires of Chartres Cathedral required less physical material than the Parthenon. “It’s all air and glass, cunningly organized in a beautiful structure to make the whole have much more integrity than any of its parts.” Kay maintains that the software discipline today is actually somewhere in its Middle Ages—“We don’t have to build pyramids, we can build Gothic cathedrals, bigger structures with less material”—but that the commercial software world remains stuck in pyramid mode.

然而，他并不建议任何人在大教堂停留。他相信，可能存在真正的计算科学；我们只是还没有发现它。“有一天，”他说，“我们将发明软件工程，我们都会过得更好。” 他认为，这些发现和发明将从细胞生物学中获取线索。他说，最终我们需要停止编写软件，转而学习如何开发它。凯坚持认为，我们认为我们的计算系统过于复杂，难以管理，但一位经常处理具有多个数量级移动部件的系统的生物学家会对它们有不同的看法。对于这样的观察者来说，“像计算机这样的东西不可能被认为是特别复杂、特别大或者特别快。慢、小、笨——这就是计算机的本质。”

He is not suggesting, however, that anyone stop at cathedrals. There can be a real science of computing, he believes; we just haven’t discovered it yet. “Someday,” he says, “we’re going to invent software engineering, and we’ll all be better off.” And those discoveries and inventions will take their cues, he thinks, from cellular biology. Ultimately, he says, we need to stop writing software and learn how to grow it instead. We think our computing systems are unmanageably complex, but a biologist—who regularly deals with systems that have many orders of magnitude more moving parts—would see them differently, Kay maintains. To such an observer, “Something like a computer could not possibly be regarded as being particularly complex or large or fast. Slow, small, stupid—that’s what computers are.”

Kay 最初对面向对象编程（OOP）的愿景比将代码组织成可重用例程的想法更宏伟，而软件行业最终接受了这一想法。Kay 风格的 OOP 旨在彻底重新思考我们软件世界的一个基础：当今程序与数据、过程代码与存储信息几乎普遍分离。相反，想象一个系统，其中信息和解释或操纵它所需的代码一起在一个包中传输，就像细胞带着它的 DNA 包一样。

Kay’s original vision for object-oriented programming—or OOP, which he pronounces like “oops” without the “s”—was grander than just the idea of organizing code into reusable routines, which the software industry ultimately embraced. Kay-style OOP aimed for a total rethinking of one foundation of our software universe: today’s near-universal separation of program from data, procedural code from stored information. Instead, imagine a system in which the information and the code needed to interpret or manipulate it travel together in one bundle, like a cell traveling with its packet of DNA.

20 世纪 60 年代初，Kay 作为一名年轻程序员在空军工作时，首次观察到了这种计算方法。在一个将数据从一台 Burroughs 大型计算机传输到另一台计算机的系统中，他注意到穿孔卡将存储信息的记录与读取信息所需的程序交错在一起。20 世纪 70 年代，在 Xerox PARC，他围绕这一原则设计了 Smalltalk。这个名字故意很谦虚，“这是对‘印欧神灵理论’的反应，在该理论中，系统被命名为宙斯、奥丁和托尔，但几乎没有做任何事情。我认为 Smalltalk 是一个无害的品牌，如果它做了任何好事，人们都会感到惊喜。”

Kay first observed such an approach to computing while he was working in the air force as a young programmer in the early 1960s. In a system for transporting data from one Burroughs mainframe computer to another, he noticed that the punch cards interleaved records of stored information with the procedures required to read the information. In the 1970s, at Xerox PARC, he designed Smalltalk around this principle. The name was deliberately modest, “a reaction against the ‘Indo-European god theory’ where systems were named Zeus, Odin, and Thor, and hardly did anything. I figured that Smalltalk was so innocuous a label that if it ever did anything nice, people would be pleasantly surprised.”

Kay 在一篇有关 Smalltalk 历史的论文中写道：

In a paper on the history of Smalltalk, Kay wrote,



用计算机术语来说，Smalltalk 是计算机本身概念的递归。每个 Smalltalk 对象都是对计算机全部可能性的递归，而不是将“计算机东西”划分为比整体弱的东西（例如编程语言的常用工具数据结构、过程和函数）。因此，它的语义有点像通过一个非常快的网络将成千上万台计算机连接在一起。

In computer terms, Smalltalk is a recursion on the notion of [the] computer itself. Instead of dividing “computer stuff” into things each less strong than the whole—like data structures, procedures, and functions which are the usual paraphernalia of programming languages—each Smalltalk object is a recursion on the entire possibilities of the computer. Thus its semantics are a bit like having thousands and thousands of computers all hooked together by a very fast network.



凯所说的结果是“一种更加生物学的方案，受保护的通用细胞仅通过可以模仿任何所需行为的消息进行交互。”

The result is what Kay calls “a more biological scheme of protected universal cells interacting only through messages that could mimic any desired behavior.”

如果您在理解这个概念时遇到困难，请不要感到太难过。您与几代程序员在一起。令 Kay 沮丧的是，Smalltalk 最激进的创新从未在软件市场取得重大进展，而在 90 年代占据计算主流的面向对象编程在他看来是一种混蛋。（“我创造了面向对象这个术语，”他说，“我可以告诉你，我脑子里没有 C++。”）将过程和数据捆绑在类似单元格的可移植对象中并不在大多数程序员的议程上。 。但对于日常用户来说，这个世界有一些诱人之处，在这个世界中，您再也不必担心从一个程序或系统切换到另一个程序或系统时丢失数据，或者担心特定文档无法从一个程序传输或计算机到另一个。在凯的世界里，一个物体会“带着它需要的所有东西旅行”。

If you are having trouble fathoming this concept, don’t feel too bad. You’re in the company of several generations of programmers. To Kay’s dismay, Smalltalk’s most radical innovations never made great headway in the software marketplace, and the kind of object-oriented programming that took over the computing mainstream in the nineties is, in his view, a bastardization. (“I made up the term object-oriented,” he says, “and I can tell you, I did not have C++ in mind.”) Bundling procedures and data in cell-like portable objects isn’t on most programmers’ agendas. But for the everyday user there is something seductive about a world in which you would never again have to worry about losing your data when switching from one program or system to another, or fear that a particular document won’t make the trip from one program or computer to another. In Kay’s world, an object would “travel with all the things it needs.”

自从在帕洛阿尔托研究中心取得突破性创新以来的几十年里，凯似乎基本上放弃了向习惯迟钝的成年程序员进行劝说，而是将精力集中在向年轻人展示他的想法的力量上。除此之外，在过去的十年里，他还致力于 Squeak 的开发，这是面向儿童的 Smalltalk 的最新开源版本。凯的逻辑是，由于我们仍在尝试发现软件工程的基础知识，所以让我们让下一代尝尝替代方案。

In the long decades since his breakthrough innovations at PARC, Kay seems to have mostly given up proselytizing among habit-dulled adult programmers and instead focused his energy on demonstrating the power of his ideas to youngsters. Among other things, for the last decade he has labored on Squeak, a latter-day, open source incarnation of Smalltalk for children. Since we are still trying to discover the basics of software engineering, Kay’s logic goes, let’s give the next generation a taste of alternatives.

在计算领域，变化是不可避免的。因此，凯认为，我们设计的系统应该让我们从这些变化中学习并利用它们。“在帕洛阿尔托研究中心，我们的想法是，既然你永远不会两次踏入同一条河流，那么你想让用户界面成为的第一件事就是一个学习环境——一个可以通过多种方式探索的东西，一个会随着时间的推移而改变的东西。使用此环境的用户的生命周期。” 换句话说，当用户从计算机中学习新事物时，他们可以自行更改计算机以利用他们所学到的知识。和道格拉斯·恩格尔巴特一样，凯希望计算机及其用户能够共同形成一个积极的反馈循环，即人类大脑的引导。

In computing, change is inevitable; therefore, according to Kay, the systems we design should let us learn from those changes and leverage them. “At PARC, our idea was, since you never step in the same river twice, the number one thing you want to make the user interface be is a learning environment—something that’s explorable in various ways, something that is going to change over the lifetime of the user using this environment.” In other words, as users learn new things from the computer, they can change it themselves to take advantage of what they’ve learned. Like Douglas Engelbart, Kay hoped that computers and their users would together form a positive feedback loop, a bootstrapping of the human brain.





凯是那种特立独行的人，他在自己的领域受到了许多人的尊敬，但只是有选择性地追随。然而现代软件开发的其他核心人物也和他一样抱怨软件行业已经走上了根本性的错误方向。早在 1978 年，Fortran 之父 John Backus 就表达了类似的观点。

Kay is the kind of maverick who has been honored by many in his field but only selectively followed. Yet other central figures in the development of modern software share his complaint that the software profession has taken a fundamental wrong turn. As early as 1978, John Backus, the father of Fortran, was expressing parallel views.

巴科斯认为，编程源于数学家约翰·冯·诺依曼 (John von Neumann) 的思想，他在 20 世纪 40 年代计算的黎明时期设计了顺序执行指令的“存储程序”的基本结构。但这些想法已经成为一种束缚。“冯·诺依曼语言不断地让我们陷入地址计算和单个单词的单独计算的泥沼中，”他写道。“虽然像 Fortran 及其后继者这样的语言从冯·诺依曼计算机的概念中发展出来也许是自然且不可避免的，但不幸的是，此类语言已经主导了我们的思维二十年。不幸的是，因为对它们的长期熟悉将使我们很难理解和采用新的编程风格，而这些风格有一天将提供更强大的智力和计算能力。”

Programming, Backus argued, had grown out of the ideas of John von Neumann, the mathematician who, at the dawn of computing in the 1940s, devised the basic structure of the “stored program” of sequentially executed instructions. But those ideas had become a straitjacket. “Von Neumann languages constantly keep our noses pressed in the dirt of address computation and the separate computation of single words,” he wrote. “While it was perhaps natural and inevitable that languages like Fortran and its successors should have developed out of the concept of the von Neumann computer as they did, the fact that such languages have dominated our thinking for twenty years is unfortunate. It is unfortunate because their long-standing familiarity will make it hard for us to understand and adopt new programming styles which one day will offer far greater intellectual and computational power.”

我们今天所知道的整个软件工程大厦是波将金村的门面吗？我们需要从头开始吗？

Is the entire edifice of software engineering as we know it today a Potemkin village facade? Do we need to start over from the ground up?

今天，这一观点的直言不讳的倡导者是贾伦·拉尼尔 (Jaron Lanier)，这位计算机科学家在 20 世纪 90 年代初虚拟现实技术短暂热潮期间，作为虚拟现实大师，他留着辫子的肖像短暂地印在了大众的想象中。拉尼尔说，我们已经陷入了将计算领域的任意发明视为“天灾”的陷阱。

Today, one vocal advocate of this view is Jaron Lanier, the computer scientist whose dreadlocked portrait was briefly imprinted on the popular imagination as the guru of virtual reality during that technology’s brief craze in the early 1990s. Lanier says that we have fallen into the trap of thinking of arbitrary inventions in computing as “acts of God.”

“当你了解计算机科学时，”拉尼尔在 2003 年的一次采访中说道，“你了解文件就好像它是自然元素，就像光子一样。这是一种危险的心态。即使你真的对此无能为力，并且你现在真的无法在没有文件的情况下编写软件，但不要让你的大脑被迷惑仍然很重要。你必须记住什么是人类发明，什么不是。”

“When you learn about computer science,” Lanier said in a 2003 interview, “you learn about the file as if it were an element of nature, like a photon. That’s a dangerous mentality. Even if you really can’t do anything about it, and you really can’t practically write software without files right now, it’s still important not to let your brain be bamboozled. You have to remember what’s a human invention and what isn’t.”

软件领域感觉很像电影《土拨鼠之日》，拉尼尔今天说——“总是有同样的想法，一遍又一遍”——因为我们相信现有的计算框架是唯一可能的。“计算机科学的一大耻辱”是，即使硬件加速了，软件却无法改进。然而，程序员们变得自满了，认为不令人满意的现状是不可改变的。

The software field feels so much like the movie Groundhog Day, Lanier says today—“It’s always the same ideas, over and over again”—because we believe the existing framework of computing is the only one possible. The “great shame of computer science” is that, even as hardware speeds up, software fails to improve. Yet programmers have grown complacent, accepting the unsatisfactory present as immutable.

Lanier 在 2003 年一篇关于“高难度软件”问题的文章中提出了对编程现状的批评——这种软件就像古希腊无法解开的高难度结：

Lanier laid out this critique of the present state of programming in a 2003 essay on the problem of “Gordian software”—software that is like the impossible-to-untie Gordian knot of classical Greece:



如果你观察软件的趋势，你会看到摩尔定律的可怕模仿。大型软件项目的费用、扩展过程中落后于进度的比率、大型项目失败并必须放弃的比率以及由于不可预测的软件问题而造成的金钱损失都在急剧增加。在所有你可以花很多钱的事情中，唯一你预计会经常失败的事情就是软件和医药。这并非巧合，因为它们是我们作为一个社会试图创造的两种最复杂的技术。尽管如此，软件的情况在某种程度上似乎不太可原谅，因为从直觉上看，尽管它最近变得越来越复杂，但它仍然以比生物学低得多的混乱程度存在。既然我们自己制造它，我们应该能够知道如何设计它，这样它就不会变得如此混乱。

If you look at trends in software, you see a macabre parody of Moore’s Law. The expense of giant software projects, the rate at which they fall behind schedule as they expand, the rate at which large projects fail and must be abandoned, and the monetary losses due to unpredicted software problems are all increasing precipitously. Of all the things you can spend a lot of money on, the only things you expect to fail frequently are software and medicine. That’s not a coincidence, since they are the two most complex technologies we try to make as a society. Still, the case of software seems somehow less forgivable, because intuitively it seems that as complicated as it’s gotten lately, it still exists at a much lower order of tangledness than biology. Since we make it ourselves, we ought to be able to know how to engineer it so it doesn’t get quite so confusing.



拉尼尔总结道：“计算机科学基础中的一些东西从根本上来说是歪斜的。”并继续将这些问题追溯到计算诞生之初“所使用的电气通信设备的隐喻”。这些设备都“集中于通过电线发送信号”，或者后来通过以太网发送信号：电报、电话、收音机和电视。此后的所有软件系统，从第一个简单的机器语言例程到当今浩瀚的互联网，都是“对巨大的电报线的模拟”。信号根据发送者和接收者事先商定的协议沿着这些电线传输。

“Some things in the foundations of computer science are fundamentally askew,” Lanier concluded, and proceeded to trace those problems back to “the metaphor of the electrical communications devices that were in use” at the dawn of computing. Those devices all “centered on the sending of signals down wires” or, later, through the ether: telegraph, telephone, radio, and TV. All software systems since, from the first modest machine-language routines to the teeming vastness of today’s Internet, have been “simulations of vast tangles of telegraph wires.” Signals travel down these wires according to protocols that sender and receiver have agreed upon in advance.

传说亚历山大大帝最终拔出宝剑将其劈成两半，解决了这个棘手的问题。拉尼尔提出了一种类似大胆的替代方案来替代纠结的思维和意大利面条式的代码。和艾伦·凯一样，他从自然世界中汲取灵感。“如果你对一个程序做一个小小的改变，它可能会导致程序的功能发生巨大的变化。如果自然按照这种方式运作，宇宙就会一直崩溃。” 相反，生物系统是“容错”和稳态的。当你打扰它们时，它们往往会恢复到原来的状态。

Legend has it that Alexander the Great finally solved the problem of the Gordian knot by whipping out his sword and slicing it in two. Lanier proposed a similarly bold alternative to tangled-wire thinking and spaghetti code. Like Alan Kay, he drew inspiration from the natural world. “If you make a small change to a program, it can result in an enormous change in what the program does. If nature worked that way, the universe would crash all the time.” Biological systems are, instead, “error-tolerant” and homeostatic; when you disturb them, they tend to revert to their original state.

拉尼尔提议尝试创建与其他程序相关的程序，以及与我们的身体与世界联系的方式，而不是从电报时代继承的严格协议。“我们的神经系统所知道的世界不是基于单点测量，而是基于表面。换句话说，我们的环境不一定事先与我们的身体在时间语法上达成一致。我们的身体是一个与世界接触的表面。例如，我们的视网膜可以同时看到多个光点。” 为什么不围绕人类用来与现实交互的相同模式识别原理来构建软件呢？基于概率而不是确定性？它是否“试图成为一个更好的猜测者，而不是一个完美的解码器”？

Instead of rigid protocols inherited from the telegraph era, Lanier proposed trying to create programs that relate to other programs, and to us, the way our bodies connect with the world. “The world as our nervous systems know it is not based on single point measurements but on surfaces. Put another way, our environment has not necessarily agreed with our bodies in advance on temporal syntax. Our body is a surface that contacts the world on a surface. For instance, our retina sees multiple points of light at once.” Why not build software around the same principle of pattern recognition that human beings use to interface with reality? Base it on probability rather than certainty? Have it “try to be an ever better guesser rather than a perfect decoder”?

这些想法帮助机器人领域在近几年取得了进展，多年来，传统方法试图将完美的世界模型一点点痛苦地下载到我们的机器中，但多年来却遭遇了令人沮丧的失败。“当你不再强调协议并关注表面上的图案时，你就会进入一个近似而不是完美的世界，”拉尼尔写道。“使用协议时，您往往会陷入要么全有要么全无的走钢丝行为，至少在设计的某些方面要完美遵守。相比之下，模式识别假设不断存在微小错误，并且不介意它们。”

These ideas have helped the field of robotics make progress in recent times after long years of frustrating failure with the more traditional approach of trying to download perfect models of the world, bit by painful bit, into our machines. “When you de-emphasize protocols and pay attention to patterns on surfaces, you enter into a world of approximation rather than perfection,” Lanier wrote. “With protocols you tend to be drawn into all-or-nothing high-wire acts of perfect adherence in at least some aspects of your design. Pattern recognition, in contrast, assumes the constant minor presence of errors and doesn’t mind them.”

拉尼尔将这个想法称为“表型软件”（将其定义为“表面的相互作用”）。他欣然承认，他对本质上“相互关注”的项目的愿景是“非常不同、激进、奇怪和高风险的”。在表型软件中，人机界面（程序与我们通信的方式）将与程序用于与其他程序通信的界面相同——“机器和人以相同的方式访问组件”——而且，他承认，乍一看效率很低。但他坚持认为，这是一种更好的方式来“利用摩尔定律的恩惠”，利用我们每年从为计算机提供动力的芯片中获得的额外速度，而不是我们现在把它花在臃肿、容易出现故障的程序上。

Lanier calls this idea “phenotropic software” (defining it as “the interaction of surfaces”). He readily grants that his vision of programs that essentially “look at each other” is “very different and radical and strange and high-risk.” In phenotropic software, the human interface, the way a program communicates with us, would be the same as the interface the program uses to communicate with other programs—“machine and person access components on the same terms”—and that, he admits, looks inefficient at first. But he maintains that it’s a better way to “spend the bounty of Moore’s Law,” to use the extra speed we get each year from the chips that power computers, than the way we spend it now, on bloated, failure-prone programs.

拉尼尔认为，软件的一个大问题是程序员从编写小程序开始，然后学习该级别的原理和实践。然后他们发现，随着这些项目扩展到当今最大项目的庞大规模，他们所学到的一切都不再起作用。“当程序变得不再很小时，它们的脆弱性就成为最突出的特征，软件工程就变成了西西弗斯式的。”

The big problem with software, according to Lanier, is that programmers start by making small programs and learn principles and practices at that level. Then they discover that as those programs scale up to the gargantuan size of today’s biggest projects, everything they have learned stops working. “The moment programs grow beyond smallness, their brittleness becomes the most prominent feature, and software engineering becomes Sisyphean.”

在拉尼尔看来，编程职业受到了某种心理创伤的困扰，这是每个软件开发人员在学习诀窍时都会重述的一种从纯真和优雅中集体堕落的现象。在计算的早期，孤独的创新者可以用英勇的闪电发明整个类型的软件。1963 年获得博士学位。例如，伊万·萨瑟兰 (Ivan Sutherland) 在麻省理工学院的论文中编写了一个名为 Sketchpad 的小型程序（按照今天的标准），并一手发明了整个计算机图形领域。“小程序很容易编写，也很有趣，”拉尼尔说。“如果仍然处于可以编写革命性小程序的时代，这不是很好吗？放弃它是痛苦的。那个小戏剧在我们每个人身上一次又一次地重复。我们在自己的生活和教育中重温计算机科学的整个历史。我们开始编写小程序——“Hello World”，或者其他任何东西。每个人都有一次美妙的经历。他们开始喜欢上电脑。他们做了一些了不起的小事。怎样才能走出初恋的阴影呢？它为你余下的职业生涯奠定了基础。然而，当你扩大规模时，一切都会退化。”

In Lanier’s view, the programming profession is afflicted by a sort of psychological trauma, a collective fall from innocence and grace that each software developer recapitulates as he or she learns the ropes. In the early days of computing, lone innovators could invent whole genres of software with heroic lightning bolts. For his 1963 Ph.D. thesis at MIT, for example, Ivan Sutherland wrote a small (by today’s standards) program called Sketchpad—and single-handedly invented the entire field of computer graphics. “Little programs are so easy to write and so joyous,” Lanier says. “Wouldn’t it be nice to still be in an era when you could write revolutionary little programs? It’s painful to give that up. That little drama is repeated again and again for each of us. We relive the whole history of computer science in our own lives and educations. We start off writing little programs—‘Hello World,’ or whatever it might be. Everyone has a wonderful experience. They start to love computers. They’ve done some little thing that’s just marvelous. How do you get over that first love? It sets the course for the rest of your career. And yet, as you scale up, everything just degenerates.”

拉尼尔的“Gordian Software”文章在 Edge.org 网站上引发了猛烈的批评，该网站是约翰·布罗克曼 (John Brockman) 面向未来科学家的沙龙。丹尼尔·丹尼特指责拉尼尔“对一个可能会扩大规模、也可能不会扩大规模的玩具模型抱有幻想”。但拉尼尔并不担心。他说，他对软件的批评是一个终生研究项目的一部分，该项目旨在利用计算机使人们能够相互塑造愿景，这是一种他称之为“后符号沟通”的交流，并将其比作梦——一种“有意识的、清醒的——国家的、有意的、共同的梦想。”

Lanier’s “Gordian Software” article provoked a firestorm of criticism on the Edge.org Web site, John Brockman’s salon for future-minded scientists. Daniel Dennett accused Lanier of “getting starry-eyed about a toy model that might—might—scale up and might not.” But Lanier is unfazed. He says his critique of software is part of a lifelong research project aimed at harnessing computers to enable people to shape visions for one another, a kind of exchange he calls “post-symbolic communication” and likens to dreaming—a “conscious, waking-state, intentional, shared dream.”

他的动机既是理论上的，也是个人的。他认为，抽象地讲，解决软件的“扩展问题”可以帮助我们解决许多其他问题。“人类面临的根本挑战是理解复杂性。这是生物学和医学的挑战。这是社会、经济方面的挑战。这是所有的艺术，所有的科学。无论你走什么样的智力道路，你都会一次又一次陷入这样或那样的复杂性障碍。因此，这种理解软件的过程（通常称为软件的粗糙性）在某种意义上是应对另一项挑战的主要基础理论方法，也是最重要的普遍挑战。所以我认为这是非常核心、非常深入的——如果我们能够取得任何进展的话。”

His motivation is at once theoretical and personal. In the abstract, he argues, solving software’s “scaling problem” could help us solve many other problems. “The fundamental challenge for humanity is understanding complexity. This is the challenge of biology and medicine. It’s the challenge in society, economics. It’s all the arts, all of our sciences. Whatever intellectual path you go down, you come again and again into a complexity barrier of one sort or another. So this process of understanding software—what’s often called the gnarliness of software—is in a sense the principal underlying theoretical approach to this other challenge, which is the most important universal one. So I see this as being very central, cutting very deep—if we can make any progress.”

更个人而言，拉尼尔的追求是出于他对整个计算领域停滞不前的“厌恶”。在 2004 年 ACM 会议上的一次演讲中，他指着自己的笔记本电脑，仿佛它侮辱了他一样，并使用了与米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 二十年前在《软件设计宣言》中完全相同的形象，大声说道：“我只是厌倦了这些愚蠢的事情！我每天都想把这个东西扔出窗外！太糟糕了！我被烦恼所驱使。现在已经三十年了。这是荒唐的。”

More personally, Lanier’s quest is driven by his “disgust” with what he sees as the stagnation of the entire computing field. At a speech at an ACM conference in 2004, he pointed to his laptop as if it had insulted him and—using exactly the same image that Mitch Kapor had two decades before in the “Software Design Manifesto”—exclaimed: “I’m just sick of the stupidity of these things! I want to throw this thing out the window every day! It sucks! I’m driven by annoyance. It’s thirty years now. This is ridiculous.”





与大多数激进的新想法一样，我们无法提前知道拉尼尔的表型软件是否会证明是突破还是脚注。今天，除了一些令人着迷的原型之外，它仍然是令人畏惧的抽象。但即使作为一个理论纲要，它也有助于提醒我们，软件艺术的当前状态并不是一成不变的——它的挫折是人类选择的产物，而不是自然法则的产物。拉尼尔的诊断为思考软件危机的永久状态构建了一个基本的划分。我们是否应该“面对现实”并假设该领域的唯一进步将是渐进式的——对现有模型进行适度的改进？或者我们应该寻找革命性的新范式、快刀斩乱麻的大胆举措？我们应该修补我们的软件以寻求小的改进，还是像火星人一样关注它，正如拉尼尔所写，火星人可能“无法区分麦金塔电脑和空间加热器”？

As with most radical new ideas, there is no way to know in advance whether Lanier’s phenotropic software will prove a breakthrough or a footnote. Today, outside of a handful of fascinating prototypes, it remains dauntingly abstract. But even as a theoretical outline it helps remind us that the current state of the software art is not etched in stone—that its frustrations are a product of human choices, not laws of nature. And Lanier’s diagnosis frames a basic division in thinking about the permanent state of software crisis. Should we “get real” and assume that the only advances in the field will be incremental—modest improvements refining existing models? Or should we be hunting for revolutionary new paradigms, bold strokes that cut the Gordian knot? Should we be tinkering with our software in search of small improvements or eyeing it like Martians, who, as Lanier wrote, might not “be able to distinguish a Macintosh from a space heater”?

在这个时代，研究资金大量涌入量子计算（它用量子力学代替当今的二进制电位，使用原子和光子来存储量子位或量子位）和遗传编程（旨在通过将自然选择原理应用于计算问题的随机生成的解决方案池来“增长”而不是编写程序）。但对于这种激进的创新是否会渗透到日常用户并使软件时代的瘴气成为我们有生之年的过去，人们还没有达成共识。

These questions are not purely academic in an era when research money is pouring into experimental fields like quantum computing (which substitutes quantum mechanics for today’s binary electrical bits, using atoms and photons to store quantum bits, or qubits) and genetic programming (which seeks to “grow” rather than write programs by applying the principles of natural selection to pools of randomly generated solutions to computing problems). But there is no consensus as to whether any such radical innovation will filter down to everyday users and make the miasma of software time a thing of the past in our lifetimes.

栅栏的两边都可以找到智能的声音。罗伯特·布里彻 (Robert Britcher) 在他的《软件的极限》中将悲观的观点发挥到了悲剧性的极限。他认为，过去半个世纪的软件遗产已经成为我们无法摆脱的沉重负担。他写道：“我们陷入了由一百、一万、然后数百万计算理论家、实践者和用户创造的进化模式。” “不会有重新开始。”

Intelligent voices can be found on both sides of this fence. Robert Britcher, in his The Limits of Software, takes the pessimistic view to its tragic limit. The past half century’s software legacy has become a crushing burden we cannot ever expect to escape, he believes. “We are stuck with the evolutionary pattern created by a hundred, then ten thousand, then millions of computing theoreticians and practitioners and users,” he wrote. “There will be no starting over.”

Frederick Brooks 告诉我们不要再寻找灵丹妙药：软件的复杂性不是可去除的品质，而是一种“基本属性”。尽管如此，他仍为“逐步、付出巨大努力”取得渐进进展留下了空间。就像医学界在接受细菌理论时牺牲了神奇补品的前景一样，程序员也必须放弃包治百病的希望，并接受“必须对清洁纪律进行持久、不懈的护理”。

Frederick Brooks tells us to give up hunting for a silver bullet: Software’s complexity is not a removable quality but an “essential property.” Still, he leaves room for incremental progress made “stepwise, at great effort.” Like the medical profession, which sacrificed the prospect of magical tonics when it embraced the germ theory, programmers must abandon hope for cure-alls and accept that “a persistent, unremitting care [has] to be paid to a discipline of cleanliness.”

其他人则坚持根本性改革或革命的梦想。麻省理工学院计算机科学家 Gerald Jay Sussman 写道：“计算机科学陷入了严重的麻烦……。。。。这个问题是结构性的。这不是一个复杂性问题。它不会通过某种形式的模块化来解决。我们需要新的想法。我们需要一套新的工程原理，可以用来有效地构建灵活、稳健、可进化和高效的系统。”

Others hold on to the dream of fundamental reform or revolution. MIT computer scientist Gerald Jay Sussman wrote: “Computer science is in deep trouble . . . . This problem is structural. This is not a complexity problem. It will not be solved by some form of modularity. We need new ideas. We need a new set of engineering principles that can be applied to effectively build flexible, robust, evolvable, and efficient systems.”





软件历史上最伟大的文献之一是 David Lorge Parnas 于 1985 年发表的一组简短的论文。单调的标题“战略防御系统的软件方面”没有暗示引发它的争议。帕纳斯是一位计算机科学先驱和国防软件工程方面的长期专家，他曾在一个计算机科学家小组中任职，该小组的目的是为战略防御计划 (SDI) 提供建议，该计划是罗纳德·里根总统提出的导弹防御计划（俗称“星球大战”）。帕纳斯过去曾为军队做过很多工作，并不是下意识的和平主义者。但 1985 年 6 月，他辞去委员会职务，宣称永远无法构建 SDI 所需的软件。

One of the great documents of software history is a brief set of essays by David Lorge Parnas published in 1985. The drab title, “Software Aspects of Strategic Defense Systems,” offers no hint of the controversy that birthed it. Parnas, a computer science pioneer and longtime expert on defense software engineering, served on a panel of computer scientists convened to provide advice on the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), President Ronald Reagan’s proposal for a missile defense program, colloquially known as Star Wars. Parnas had done plenty of work for the military in the past and was no kneejerk peacenik. But in June 1985, he resigned from the committee, declaring that the software required by SDI could never be built.

帕纳斯认为，《星球大战》注定要失败，因为当时的软件工程技术和未来可以想象的技术都无法满足该计划的要求。Parnas 极其精确地解释了为什么我们无法指望生产出一个可用的 SDI 系统，无论我们是依赖效率低下且存在缺陷的传统软件开发，还是新的编程语言和技术，或者软件工程库所承诺的任何灵丹妙药。 ——自动编程、人工智能或数学“程序验证”。

Star Wars, Parnas argued, was doomed, because neither the software engineering techniques of the time nor those imaginable in the future could ever meet the program’s requirements. With devastating precision, Parnas explained why we could not expect to produce a working SDI system whether we relied on conventional software development, with its inefficiency and bugs, or new programming languages and techniques, or any of the silver bullets promised by the software engineering arsenal—automatic programming, artificial intelligence, or mathematical “program verification.”

就其本质而言，导弹防御计划永远无法在实际工作条件下进行适当的测试；在第一次“实地运行”时，它必须可靠、有效地工作，以保护数百万人的生命。帕纳斯写道，任何了解编程本质的人都不会信任这样的系统。“描述当今大多数项目中使用的编程方法的最简单方法是一位老师向我提供的，他正在解释他如何教授编程。“像计算机一样思考，”他说。他指导学生首先思考计算机必须首先做什么，然后把它写下来。然后他们会思考计算机接下来要做什么，并以这种方式继续，直到他们描述了计算机要做的最后一件事。事实上，这就是我被教导的编程方式。” 帕纳斯说，这种方法在小型、简单的程序上效果很好。“我们认为它有效，因为它适用于我们编写的第一个程序。” 然后我们引入复杂的循环、分支和变量。更雄心勃勃的计划涉及多个并发进程。“我们必须记住的数量越来越多。。。。最终，我们犯了一个错误。”

By its very nature, a missile defense program could never be properly tested under actual working conditions; on its very first “field run,” it would have to work reliably and effectively to protect millions of lives. No one who understands the nature of programming would ever trust such a system, Parnas wrote. “The easiest way to describe the programming method used in most projects today was given to me by a teacher who was explaining how he teaches programming. ‘Think like a computer,’ he said. He instructed his students to begin by thinking about what the computer had to do first and to write that down. They would then think about what the computer had to do next and continue in that way until they had described the last thing the computer would do. This, in fact, is the way I was taught to program.” The method, Parnas said, works well on small, simple programs. “We think that it works because it worked for the first program that we wrote.” Then we introduce complex loops and branches and variables. More ambitious programs involve multiple concurrent processes. “The amount we have to remember grows and grows . . . . Eventually, we make an error.”

如果“按照计算机执行的顺序思考问题”是程序员的工作方式，但这样做最终超出了他们的能力范围，那么我们怎么会得到任何可以工作的软件呢？“编程是一种反复试验的工艺，”帕纳斯写道。“人们编写程序时并不期望它们第一次就会正确。” 他们犯错误，然后改正错误。他们测试并修复。他们迭代。

If “thinking things out in the order that the computer will execute them” is how programmers work, yet doing so is ultimately beyond their capability, how is it that we end up with any working software at all? “Programming is a trial-and-error craft,” Parnas wrote. “People write programs without any expectation that they will be right the first time.” They make mistakes, and they correct them. They test and fix. They iterate.

人们编写程序。这句话值得暂停一下。人们编写程序。尽管该领域热衷于建筑和桥梁建设等隐喻，并涉足生物学或物理学的替代模型，但今天的编程行为仍然是一种写作行为——逐个字符、一个字一个字、一行一行地输入。让程序员通过操作屏幕上的图标和图形来创建软件的工具有着悠久的历史，有时甚至是成功的（在 20 世纪 90 年代的一段时间内，Visual Basic 等工具赢得了惊人的流行）。但这些通常作为位于相同旧的基于文本的代码之上的快捷方式层，迟早，为了解决任何真正困难的问题，程序员最终都会深入到该代码中。

People write programs. That statement is worth pausing over. People write programs. Despite the field’s infatuation with metaphors like architecture and bridge-building and its dabbling in alternative models from biology or physics, the act of programming today remains an act of writing—of typing character after character, word after word, line after line. Tools that let programmers create software by manipulating icons and graphic shapes on screen have a long and sometimes successful history (for a time in the 1990s, one such tool, Visual Basic, won phenomenal popularity). But these have generally served as layers of shortcuts sitting on top of the same old text-based code, and sooner or later, to fix any really hard problems, the programmer would end up elbow-deep in that code anyway.

人们编写程序。

People write programs.

Bill Joy 是他这一代最杰出的程序员之一。他编写了 Unix 的大部分免费伯克利版本，设计了早期互联网的一些关键基础，并帮助创建了 Java。离开他共同创立的太阳微系统公司后，他试图写一本书。但 2003 年，他告诉《纽约时报》，他将搁置该项目。编写供编译器解释或供计算机执行是一回事；编写供编译器解释或供计算机执行是一回事。为别人写作实在是太难了。“通过代码，”他说，“计算机会告诉你它是否理解你写的内容。写散文要困难得多。也就是说，如果你想被理解的话。”

Bill Joy is one of the leading programmers of his generation; he wrote much of the free Berkeley version of Unix, devised some of the critical underpinnings of the early Internet, and helped create Java. After leaving Sun Microsystems, which he had cofounded, he attempted to write a book. But in 2003 he told the New York Times that he was putting the project aside. It was one thing to write for the compiler to interpret or the computer to execute; writing for other people was simply too hard. “With code,” he said, “the computer tells you if it understands what you write. It’s much harder to write prose. That is, if you want to be understood.”

编程是一种创意写作吗？乍一看，这个想法似乎很奇怪。任何涉及复杂数学和符号逻辑的学科似乎都与诗歌和自我表达不同。然而，编程领域可以从写作领域学到很多东西，Richard Gabriel 认为，他是 Lisp 和面向对象编程领域的资深人士，现在是 Sun 的杰出工程师。“我的观点是，我们应该像培训诗人和艺术家等创意人才一样培训开发人员。人们可能会说，“嗯，这听起来真的很疯狂。” 但是，人们在接受培训（例如获得诗歌美术硕士学位）时会做什么？他们研究伟大的诗歌作品。我们在软件工程学科中这样做吗？不。您不会查看优秀软件的源代码。或者看看优秀软件的架构。你不看他们的设计。你没有研究伟大软件设计师的生活。所以你不会研究你想要构建的东西的文献。”

Is programming a kind of creative writing? The notion seems outlandish at first blush. Any discipline that involves complex mathematics and symbolic logic does not seem to share the same cubbyhole with poetry and self-expression. Yet the programming field could learn much from the writing world, argues Richard Gabriel, a veteran of the Lisp and object-oriented programming worlds who is now a Distinguished Engineer at Sun. “My view is that we should train developers the way we train creative people like poets and artists. People may say, ‘Well, that sounds really nuts.’ But what do people do when they’re being trained, for example, to get a master of fine arts in poetry? They study great works of poetry. Do we do that in our software engineering disciplines? No. You don’t look at the source code for great pieces of software. Or look at the architecture of great pieces of software. You don’t look at their design. You don’t study the lives of great software designers. So you don’t study the literature of the thing you’re trying to build.”

造成这种情况的原因之一在于计算机行业对其自身的历史缺乏兴趣。但加布里埃尔认为，更大的原因是当今使用的许多软件无法研究；由于商业原因，其代码被锁定。（毫不奇怪，加布里埃尔是开源运动的信徒。）

One reason for this lies in the computing profession’s lack of interest in its own history. But a bigger reason, Gabriel argues, is that much of the software in use today can’t be studied; its code is locked away for commercial reasons. (Unsurprisingly, Gabriel is a believer in the open source movement.)



就好像所有作家都有自己的私人“公司”，只有梅尔维尔公司的人才能读《白鲸》，而海明威公司的人才能读《太阳照常升起》。你能想象在这种情况下发展出丰富的文学作品吗？在这种情况下，既不可能有文学课程，也不可能有写作教学方法。我们期望人们在这种背景下学习编程？

It is as if all writers had their own private “companies” and only people in the Melville company could read Moby-Dick and those in Hemingway’s could read The Sun Also Rises. Can you imagine developing a rich literature under these circumstances? There could be neither a curriculum in literature nor a way of teaching writing under such conditions. And we expect people to learn to program in exactly this context?



加布里埃尔对编程作为创造性写作这一概念的热情并不纯粹是抽象的；它是一种创造性的写作。20 世纪 90 年代，他从自己的职业生涯中休息了三年，获得了创意写作硕士学位，并每天写一首诗。他发现，我们对那些想成为作家和诗人的学生要求的工作比那些立志成为软件开发人员的学生要求的工作更多：他们必须与导师一起学习，他们必须在研讨会上展示自己的作品以供同行定期批评，并且他们被期望对同一作品进行多次修改。“我认为我们需要为此感到羞耻，”加布里埃尔说。“我们提出的计算机教育是一场闹剧。”

Gabriel’s enthusiasm for the notion of programming as creative writing is not purely abstract; in the 1990s, he took three years off from his career to get an MFA in creative writing and to write a poem a day. He discovered that we ask more work of students who want to become writers and poets than of those who aim to become software developers: They must study with mentors, they must present their work for regular criticism by peers in workshops, and they’re expected to labor over multiple revisions of the same work. “I think we need to be ashamed of this,” Gabriel says. “What we put forward as computer education is a farce.”

加布里埃尔是他所在领域的激进分子——“过去五十年来我们在软件领域所做的一切都应该被彻底删除，”他说。大多数程序员不太可能涌向 MFA 课程。大多数人可能会像比尔·乔伊一样，觉得为一台电脑的读者写作比为一群人写作更舒服。

Gabriel is a radical in his field—“Everything we’ve done in software for the last fifty years should be literally deleted,” he says. Most programmers are not likely to flock to MFA programs. Most probably feel, like Bill Joy, more comfortable writing for an audience of a single computer than for a crowd of human beings.

然而，在过去的十年里，软件行业发生了一些非同寻常的事情：程序员开始在网站和博客上亲自、专心、大量地写作，倾诉他们的灵感和挫折、他们的见解和技巧、恐惧和梦想。这个过程始于互联网早期的邮件列表和新闻组发帖中。但直到世纪之交和互联网泡沫破裂之后，当许多程序员发现自己有了额外的空闲时间时，它才稳步加速并达到临界质量。并非所有这些内容都是重要的，也不是所有程序员都会阅读它。然而，它正在改变这个领域——即使不是伟大软件作品的经典，至少也创造了围绕日常编程实践的非正式文献。网络本身已经成为杰拉尔德·温伯格（Gerald Weinberg）在《计算机编程心理学》中所写的自动售货机排列的公共休息室的分布式版本：一个非正式但重要的场所，供程序员分享他们的专业知识和基比特。这也是一个开放的论坛，他们可以在其中继续思考、辩论并重新定义他们所做工作的性质。

And yet something extraordinary happened to the software profession over the last decade: Programmers started writing personally, intently, voluminously, pouring out their inspirations and frustrations, their insights and tips and fears and dreams, on Web sites and in blogs. It is a process that began in the earliest days of the Internet, on mailing lists and in newsgroup postings. But it has steadily accelerated and achieved critical mass only since the turn of the millennium and the bursting of the dot-com bubble when a lot of programmers found themselves with extra free time. Not all of this writing is consequential, and not all programmers read it. Yet it is changing the field—creating, if not a canon of great works of software, at least an informal literature around the day-to-day practice of programming. The Web itself has become a distributed version of the vending-machine-lined common room that Gerald Weinberg wrote about in The Psychology of Computer Programming: an informal yet essential place for coders to share their knowhow and kibitz. It is also an open forum in which they can continue to ponder, debate, and redefine the nature of the work they do.





工科还是文学？科学还是艺术？对于该领域的许多人来说，试图解决编程的双重身份危机仍然是几十年来的痴迷，但今天我们似乎并没有比北约第一次在加米施聚集其伟大思想并要求他们解决这个问题时更接近。软件危机。也许问题是无解的。或者也许这根本不是问题，而只是编程作为人类活动的独特性的体现。

Engineering or literature? Science or art? Trying to resolve programming’s dual-identity crisis has remained a decades-long obsession for many in the field, yet we don’t appear to be any closer today than we were when NATO first gathered its great minds in Garmisch and asked them to solve the Software Crisis. Maybe the problem is insoluble. Or maybe it isn’t a problem at all but, rather, simply a manifestation of the uniqueness of programming as a human activity.

你可以在唐纳德·高德纳 (Donald Knuth) 的生活和工作中找到支持这一结论的重要证据。唐纳德·高德纳是程序员、教师，也是一系列被广泛视为其职业圣经的书籍的作者。在这些书中，Knuth 探讨了编程的数学基础：算法的本质，抽象的指令序列，当我们要求计算机对数据进行排序或搜索数组或进行其他重复性活动时，它们构成了计算机执行的中心活动的基础。这些书代表了高德纳一生的工作。自 1968 年第一本出版以来，已经出版了三本，另外两本正在准备中，另外两本正在计划中。它们与技术书籍行业大量出版的《本月 17 秒编程语言风格》手册截然相反。它们不适合胆小的人。

You can find significant evidence supporting such a conclusion in the life and work of Donald Knuth—programmer, teacher, and author of a series of books that are widely viewed as the bibles of his profession. In these books, Knuth explores the mathematical fundamentals of programming: the essence of algorithms, the abstract sequences of instructions that form the basis for the central activities computers perform when we ask them to sort data or search an array or conduct some other repetitious activity. These volumes represent Knuth’s life work. Three have been published since the first came out in 1968, two more are in preparation, and another two are planned. They are the polar opposite of the Learn This Month’s Flavor of Programming Language in 17 Seconds manuals that the technical books industry churns out. They are not for the faint of heart or mind.

然而，对于那些能够追随他们的行家来说，这些对计算上数学上最精确、概念上最稀有领域的探索绝不是枯燥的。他们充满了人性。他们以一种只能称为优雅的方式将对细节的热情和对富有表现力的形状的关注结合起来。

And yet for those adepts who can follow them, these explorations of computing’s most mathematically precise, conceptually rarefied regions are anything but arid. They are suffused with humanity. They combine passion for detail and attention to expressive shape in a way that can only be called elegant.

高德纳选择将他的书命名为《计算机编程的艺术》，而不是《计算机编程的科学》。他花了一生的时间向他的同事解释这个标题，定义他所说的编程一门艺术的含义。在 1974 年图灵奖演讲“计算机编程作为一门艺术”中，他将“艺术”一词的使用追溯到中世纪晚期和文艺复兴时期，当时“艺术意味着由人类智力设计的东西，而不是源自自然或本能的活动。 ” 假设人类的人工制品和自然的产物之间存在分歧，那么任何与计算有关的东西无疑都属于艺术。还有什么比这些逻辑机器更人造的呢？

Knuth chose to name his books The Art of Computer Programming—not The Science of Computer Programming. He has spent a lifetime explaining the title to his colleagues, defining what he means when he calls programming an art. In his 1974 Turing Award lecture, “Computer Programming as an Art,” he traced usage of the word art back to the late Middle Ages and Renaissance when “art meant something devised by man’s intellect, as opposed to activities derived from nature or instinct.” Assuming a divide between the artifacts of humankind and the products of nature, anything having to do with computing falls unquestionably on the side of art. What could be more artificial than these machines of logic?

今天，我们习惯于将艺术与科学区分开来，而不是与自然。高德纳坦言，计算属于这条线的两端，但很明显他的热情所在。“作为教育家和作家，我工作的主要目标是帮助人们学习如何编写漂亮的程序。。。。我的感觉是，当我们准备一个节目时，它可以像作诗或作曲一样。。。。有的节目优雅，有的节目精致，有的节目闪闪发光。我的主张是，编写宏伟的程序、崇高的程序、真正宏伟的程序是可能的！”

Today we’re accustomed to distinguishing art not from nature but from science. Knuth readily admits that computing falls on both sides of that line, but it is plain where his passion lies. “The chief goal of my work as educator and author is to help people learn how to write beautiful programs. . . . My feeling is that when we prepare a program, it can be like composing poetry or music . . . . Some programs are elegant, some are exquisite, some are sparkling. My claim is that it is possible to write grand programs, noble programs, truly magnificent ones!”

高德努斯和弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯一样，都是一位宗教人士（他也是管风琴的爱好者）。五年来，他一直在神圣职业的魔咒下，以一种痴迷的纯粹精神，致力于撰写和出版《计算机编程艺术》系列。他不断修改自己的著作，以跟上该领域的变化，并且他向报告其中错误的任何人提供 2.56 美元（“十六进制美元”）的奖励。他的整个职业生涯都在斯坦福大学度过，现在他是斯坦福大学的名誉教授，偶尔会在写书的过程中休息一下去演讲。但他的传记中包括一次离开象牙塔的伟大旅程，一次进入编程的实际世界的旅程，这使得他在计算机编程艺术方面的工作近十年脱轨。

Knuth is, like Frederick Brooks, a religious man (he is also a devotee of the pipe organ). He has pursued the writing and publication of his Art of Computer Programming series across five decades with the obsessional purity of someone under the spell of a divine vocation. He is continually revising his volumes to keep up with changes in the field, and he famously offers a reward of $2.56 (“one hexadecimal dollar”) to anyone who reports an error in them. He has spent his entire career at Stanford, where he is now a professor emeritus and occasionally takes a break from labors on his book to lecture. But his biography includes one great departure from the ivory tower, a trip into the practical world of programming that derailed his work on The Art of Computer Programming for nearly a decade.

在 20 世纪 70 年代末，正如 Knuth 讲述的那样，他开始注意到正在出版的新技术书籍——数学和科学教科书，以及任何需要呈现复杂符号符号的书籍——看起来很糟糕。出版业正在经历从“热排版”时代到“冷排版”时代、从重金属弹头到软件驱动排版的伟大转变。大量资金被投资于新的基本设备，科学家和数学家的需求并不是优先考虑的事情。因为他“无法忍受写看起来不好看的书”，所以 Knuth 开始编写一个软件工具来编写和出版精美的技术书籍。

In the late 1970s, as Knuth tells the story, he began to notice that the new technical books being published—math and science texts, any books that needed to present complex symbolic notation—looked terrible. The publishing industry was going through its great transition from the era of “hot type” to “cold type,” from heavy metal slugs to software-powered typesetting. Large sums were being invested in new basic equipment, and the needs of scientists and mathematicians were not a priority. Because he “couldn’t stand to write books that weren’t going to look good,” Knuth set out to write a software tool for writing and publishing beautiful technical books.

他预计需要一年的时间。相反，花了​​将近十个小时。

He expected it to take a year. Instead, it took almost ten.

Knuth 在软件时代获得了自己的第一手经验。最终，他还创建了一些程序——排版系统 TeX 和名为 Metafont 的字体设计程序——这些程序成为了该领域的全球标准。它们是免费的，并且多年来经过大量忠实且熟练的用户的稳步改进和调试，成为开源方法的先驱示例。您今天读到的大多数呈现复杂科学或数学符号的书籍很可能是使用 Knuth 的工具编写和排版的。

Knuth got his own firsthand experience of software time. Ultimately, he also created programs—the typesetting system TeX and a font design program called Metafont—that became the global standard in their field. Free, and steadily improved and debugged over the years by a large population of devoted and skilled users, they stand as pioneering examples of the open source approach. Most books you read today that present complex scientific or mathematical symbols are likely to have been written and typeset using Knuth’s tools.

高德努斯多年来从虚无缥缈的理论世界进入混乱的实践领域，这让他更加尊重他的编程同事在战壕中所面临的障碍。他一直对他的数学家同行对寻找证明程序“正确性”的数学证明的热情持怀疑态度。他曾经在给一位同事的信中说过一句俏皮话，这已成为该领域的传奇：“当心上述代码中的错误；我只是证明了它的正确性，并没有尝试过。”

Knuth’s years-long detour from the airy world of theory into the messy realm of practice left him with an enhanced respect for the obstacles his programming colleagues in the trenches faced. He had always held a skeptical view of his fellow mathematicians’ enthusiasm for the idea of finding mathematical proofs that demonstrate programs’ “correctness.” In one quip that has become a legend in the field, he once wrote to a colleague, “Beware of bugs in the above code; I have only proved it correct, not tried it.”

他在 TeX 和 Metafont 方面的工作使 Knuth 得出了与 Bill Joy 完全相反的结论：他宣称，编写软件比写书“困难得多”。

His work on TeX and Metafont led Knuth to draw precisely the opposite conclusion from Bill Joy: Writing software is “much more difficult” than writing books, he declared.



这么多年，我在计算机排版的实际问题上潜心研究，得到了哪些经验教训？最重要的教训之一也许是软件很难这一事实。从现在开始，我将对我遇到的每一个成功的软件工具更加尊重。在过去的十年中，我惊讶地发现为 TeX 和 Metafont 编写程序比我所做的所有其他事情（例如证明定理或写书）要困难得多。好的软件的创建需要比其他事情更高的准确性标准，并且需要比其他智力任务更长的注意力。

What were the lessons I learned from so many years of intensive work on the practical problem of setting type by computer? One of the most important lessons, perhaps, is the fact that SOFTWARE IS HARD. From now on I shall have significantly greater respect for every successful software tool that I encounter. During the past decade I was surprised to learn that the writing of programs for TeX and Metafont proved to be much more difficult than all the other things I had done (like proving theorems or writing books). The creation of good software demands a significantly higher standard of accuracy than those other things do, and it requires a longer attention span than other intellectual tasks.



这句话出自高德纳多年来关于“理论与实践”的一系列讲座；伴随着这份声明的幻灯片以他自己的工具创建的说明性字体呈现了它——枕头状弯曲的小写字母代表“软件”，深色、有棱角的大写字母代表“硬”。

The words come from a series of lectures Knuth has given over the years on “Theory and Practice”; the slide that accompanied this statement presented it in its own illustrative fonts created with his own tools—pillowy-curved lowercase letters for “software” and dark, angular capitals for “HARD.”

1986 年，高德纳在富兰克林研究所举行的纪念第一台完全可编程电子计算机 ENIAC 四十周年的活动上谈到这个主题时，他进一步阐述了他的意思：

When he spoke on the subject at a 1986 event at the Franklin Institute commemorating the fortieth anniversary of ENIAC, the first fully programmable electronic computer, Knuth expanded on what he meant:



与执行其他智力任务相比，在处理大型计算机程序时需要更长的注意力。我在《时代》杂志上读到，婴儿床被搬进了旧的 ENIAC 实验室，以便埃克特[J. 监督 ENIAC 建设的普雷斯珀·埃克特 (Presper Eckert) 和其他人可以通宵工作。那些睡过那些婴儿床的人会明白我的意思。。。。大量的技术信息必须同时保存在大脑某处的高速随机存取存储器中。。。。大型系统中技术细节的数量使得编程比写书要求更高。另一个原因是编程对准确性的要求要高得多。

A longer attention span is needed when you’re working on a large computer program than when you’re doing other intellectual tasks. I read in Time magazine that cots were brought in to the old ENIAC lab so that Eckert[J. Presper Eckert, who oversaw the construction of ENIAC] and others could work through the night. Those of you who slept in those cots will know what I mean . . . . A great deal of technical information must be kept in one’s head, all at once, in high-speed random-access memory somewhere in the brain . . . . The amount of technical detail in a large system is one thing that makes programming more demanding than book-writing. Another is that programming demands a significantly higher standard of accuracy.



作为一位里程碑式的作家，高德纳花了十年的时间来解决软件中的一个棘手的实际问题，他可能比任何其他在世的人更有资格比较写书和编写代码的相对困难。他的结论对那些梦想能够更快或更容易地生产软件的人来说是一个温和的警告。但是，像他的许多同事一样，他本质上是一个乐观主义者。他认为在 TeX 和 Metafont 上花费的岁月是值得的，不仅因为它们产生了成果，而且因为它们教给了他很多东西。他甚至声称，他将弥补在他的巨著上损失的时间，因为他的新工具使他能够更有效地工作。

As a landmark author who also devoted a decade to tackling—and solving—a fiendish practical problem in software, Knuth is probably better qualified than any other living human being to compare the relative difficulties of writing books and writing code. His conclusions serve as a gentle warning to anyone who dreams that software can be produced faster or more easily. But, like so many of his colleagues, he is an optimist at heart. He viewed the years spent on TeX and Metafont as worthwhile not only for what they produced but for what they taught him. He even argued that he would make up the lost time on his magnum opus because his new tools allowed him to work more efficiently.

计算机编程的艺术向程序员展示如何设计和测试算法以提高效率。编写一些将信息排序速度提高几分之一秒的代码可能看起来没什么大不了的，但如果计算机必须重复该算法无数次才能执行某些任务，那么您的微小节省可能会产生巨大的影响。此级别的增量微调需要与程序设计或调试级别的增量改进所需要的信念相同；你必须相信每一个微小的改变都会带来一些最终的价值。

The Art of Computer Programming shows programmers how to design and test algorithms for efficiency. Making some code that sorts information a fraction of a second faster may not seem like a big deal, but if the computer must repeat the algorithm a gazillion times in order to perform some task, your tiny savings can make a huge difference. Incremental fine-tuning at this level requires the same faith that incremental improvement at the level of program design or debugging demands; you have to trust that each little change will contribute to some final value.

丹麦诗人/科学家/设计师皮特·海因 (Piet Hein) 在他家的入口处创作了一首类似俳句的诗，浓缩了高德纳的信仰：

Knuth’s faith is distilled in the haiku-like poem by the Danish poet/scientist/designer Piet Hein that adorns the entryway to his home:



通往智慧的道路？——嗯，很简单

The road to wisdom?—Well, it’s plain

并简单表达：

and simple to express:

呃

Err

并犯错

and err

又犯错了

and err again

但较少

but less

以及更少

and less

还有更少。

and less.





Don Knuth 对编程领域做出了另一项值得注意的贡献。尽管他以其在算法方面相对深奥的工作而闻名，但他也是他所谓的“文学编程”概念的倡导者。文学编程的目的是解决一个令人痛苦的事实，正如 Joel Spolsky 所说，“阅读代码比编写代码更难。” Knuth 的建议强调编写人类可以理解的代码，认为除作者之外的程序员迟早也需要理解它，并且这样的代码最终也将具有更好的结构。

Don Knuth has made one additional contribution to the programming field that is worth noting here. Although he is best known for his relatively abstruse work in algorithms, he is also the advocate of a concept that he calls “literate programming.” Literate programming is intended as an antidote to the excruciating fact that, as Joel Spolsky puts it, “it’s harder to read code than to write it.” Knuth’s proposal emphasizes writing code that is comprehensible to human beings, under the thinking that sooner or later programmers other than the author will need to understand it, and that such code will end up being better structured, too.



让我们集中精力向人类解释我们希望计算机做什么，而不是想象我们的主要任务是指导计算机做什么。文学编程的实践者可以被视为散文家，其主要关注点是阐述和风格的卓越。这样的作者手里拿着同义词库，仔细地选择变量的名称，并解释每个变量的含义。他或她努力开发一个易于理解的程序，因为它的概念是按照最有利于人类理解的顺序引入的，使用了相互强化的正式和非正式方法的混合。

Instead of imagining that our main task is to instruct a computer what to do, let us concentrate rather on explaining to human beings what we want a computer to do. The practitioner of literate programming can be regarded as an essayist, whose main concern is with exposition and excellence of style. Such an author, with thesaurus in hand, chooses the names of variables carefully and explains what each variable means. He or she strives for a program that is comprehensible because its concepts have been introduced in an order that is best for human understanding, using a mixture of formal and informal methods that reinforce each other.



从某种意义上说，文学编程的论点是，如果你能够完整、清晰地记录你的代码，那么编写它就变得几乎微不足道。这是一个诱人的想法，但尽管它有爱好者，但它从未获得广泛的普及。大多数程序员只是太匆忙了。文档是一种干扰。

In a sense, the literate programming argument is that if you can fully and clearly document your code, writing it becomes almost trivial. It is an alluring idea, but although it has enthusiasts, it never achieved wide popularity. Most programmers are simply in too much of a rush. Documentation is a distraction.

此外，他们还有意见。

Besides, they have comments.

注释是嵌入在代码行之间的简单英语语句。每种编程语言都有一个或多个符号，程序员用它们来标记注释，以帮助其他程序员理解代码。这些符号告诉计算机：“这不适合你！别理会幕后的话语！”

Comments are plain English statements embedded between lines of code. Every programming language has a symbol or symbols that programmers use to mark comments that are intended to help other programmers understand the code. The symbols tell the computer, “This isn’t for you! Pay no attention to the words behind the curtain!”

带有良好注释的代码是良好编程实践的标志之一；它表明你关心你正在做的事情，并且考虑到那些会在你之后修复你的错误的人。但评论也是程序员之间交流的一种后台渠道，甚至偶尔会成为竞争的舞台或愚蠢的发泄渠道。

Well-commented code is one hallmark of good programming practice; it shows that you care about what you’re doing, and it is considerate to those who will come after you to fix your bugs. But comments also serve as a kind of back channel for programmer-to-programmer communication and even occasionally as a competitive arena or an outlet for silliness.

一位名叫 Vidar Holen 的挪威程序员热情地维护着一个标有“Linux 内核脏话”的网页。他在上面绘制了 Linux 源代码中注释中随时间变化的脏话程度的图表。一张图表显示绝对水平稳步上升；另一个例子表明，每行源代码的诅咒数量正在稳步下降。Linux 是否变得或多或少受到谩骂？霍伦并没有试图解释他的统计数据。

A Norwegian programmer named Vidar Holen lovingly maintains a Web page labeled “Linux kernel swear words.” On it he charts over time the levels of profanity in comments within the Linux source code. One graph shows that the absolute levels have risen steadily; another demonstrates that the number of curses per line of source code has steadily declined. Is Linux getting more or less foul-mouthed? Holen doesn’t try to interpret his statistics.

2004 年，当 MyDoom、Bagle 和 Netsky 等病毒开始在互联网上传播并感染 Windows 计算机时，研究人员发现这些病毒的作者在代码注释中粗暴地互相攻击：“别毁了我们的生意” ，想发动战争吗？” “天网杀毒-Bagle-你是个松鼠！！！” 这与 Don Knuth 的距离差不多了。称之为文盲编程。

In 2004, as viruses with names like MyDoom, Bagle, and Netsky began to spread across the Internet to infect Windows computers, researchers discovered that the authors of the viruses were crudely slagging each other in their code’s comments: “Don’t ruine our bussiness, wanna start a war?” “Skynet AntiVirus–Bagle–you are a looser!!!” This is about as far from Don Knuth as you can get; call it illiterate programming.

评论有时不仅充当解释性注释，而且充当情绪释放阀。尽管几十年来人们一直在涉足自动编程和软件工程的概念，但制作软件仍然是痛苦的。痛苦的程序员有时只需要说“操”。

Comments sometimes serve not just as explanatory notes but as emotional release valves. Despite decades of dabbling with notions of automatic programming and software engineering, making software is still painful. Anguished programmers sometimes just need to say “fuck.”

当他们在商业代码中这样做时，通常会假设该词将保密，因为公司外部没有人会看到源代码。但时不时地，我们会瞥见这个世界的内部。2004 年，Windows 2000 一个版本的部分源代码泄露到互联网上。着迷的程序员仔细研究了文本。他们惊讶地发现，在许多评论中，微软程序员责备自己、他们的工具、他们的同事和他们的产品。

When they do so in commercial code, it is normally under an assumption that the word will remain secret, since no one outside the company will ever see the source. But every now and then we get a glimpse inside this world. In 2004, the source code to parts of one version of Windows 2000 leaked onto the Internet. Fascinated programmers pored through the text. Among the surprises they found were many comments in which the Microsoft programmers berated themselves, their tools, their colleagues, and their products.



// 在该死的编译器周围，我们将最后一个参数作为 void 传递

// around the fucking peice of shit compiler we pass the last param as an void





// 我们真是白痴。Wiz97在IE4和IE5之间进行了重新设计

// we are such morons. Wiz97 underwent a redesign between IE4 and IE5





//我们必须这样做只是因为 Exchange 是个白痴。

//We have to do this only because Exchange is a moron.





// 我们是白痴。我们改变了IE4之间的IDeskTray接口

// We are morons. We changed the IDeskTray interface between IE4





// 应该在应用程序本身中修复。白痴！

// should be fixed in the apps themselves. Morons!



研究 Windows 2000 源代码的学生发现了四千多处提及“黑客”的内容。在一次引起人们注意的印刷中，一位程序员在代码中插入了以下警告：

Students of the Windows 2000 source found more than four thousand references to “hacks.” In one explosion of typographical attention-getting, a programmer inserted this warning into the code:



*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! ！

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! ！

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

*如果你将选项卡更改为空格，你就会被杀死！

*IF YOU CHANGE TABS TO SPACES, YOU WILL BE KILLED!!

*!!!!!!这样做会破坏构建过程!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

*!!!!DOING SO FUCKS THE BUILD PROCESS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! ！

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! ！

*!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!



自从北约最优秀和最聪明的人聚在一起解决软件危机以来，无论其他方面发生了什么变化，今天的程序员仍然在一个将制表符更改为空格的世界里工作，基本上让他们完蛋了。（不仅仅是在微软；钱德勒的 Python 也同样敏感。）他们的评论脾气可能不是什么艺术。但考虑到他们每天仍然要面对的令人抓狂的问题，谁会嫉妒他们的爆发呢？

Whatever else has changed in the nearly forty years since NATO’s best and brightest met to fix the Software Crisis, today’s programmers still work in a world where changing tabs to spaces leaves them, basically, fucked. (And not just at Microsoft; Chandler’s Python is just as sensitive.) Their comment-tantrums may not be fine art. But given the maddening nature of the problems they still contend with every day, who would begrudge them their outbursts?

第11章                           

CHAPTER 11                           

狗粮之路

THE ROAD TO DOGFOOD

[2004 年 11 月至 2005 年 11 月]

[NOVEMBER 2004–NOVEMBER 2005]

为了在任何大型软件项目中发挥作用，您必须全身心投入其中。你必须将其中的大部分内容融入你的大脑中。当我正在进行某个大项目时，我常常在晚上做梦。

To be effective at any large software project, you have to become so committed to it. You have to incorporate so much of it into your brain. I used to dream in code at night when I was in the middle of some big project.

——杰伦·拉尼尔

—Jaron Lanier

当我们在两章前（2004 年秋天）离开 OSAF 开发人员时，他们已经完成了 Chandler 0.4 并开始开发 0.5。他们再次为自己设定了一个周期目标：Chandler 0.5 将提供一个“dogfoodable 日历”，一个他们至少可以开始使用的可共享日历。但 Chandler 一直被设想为一个完整的 PIM，一个用于管理电子邮件和任务以及日历的程序，其设计比普通日历程序所需的范围更广泛。找出一些设计来构建可靠的工作日历，同时为程序的发展留出空间的工作落到了钱德勒的设计师 Mimi Yin 身上。

When we left the OSAF developers two chapters ago, in the fall of 2004, they had wrapped up Chandler 0.4 and were beginning work on 0.5. Once more they set themselves a goal for the cycle: Chandler 0.5 would deliver a “dogfoodable calendar,” a shareable calendar that they, at least, could begin to use. But Chandler had always been envisioned as a full PIM, a program for managing email and tasks as well as a calendar, and its design was broader than a plain calendar program would need. The job of figuring out some design for building a solid working calendar while leaving room for the program’s growth fell to Chandler’s designer, Mimi Yin.

尹已经发现，将钱德勒的所有功能和想法安装到一个屏幕上并不是一件简单的事情，而消除隔离不同类型数据的孤岛的目标只会让事情变得更加困难。她相信，最终，钱德勒的用户将依赖她提出的仪表板视图（从过去流向现在到未来的单个项目屏幕）作为他们日常信息管理的神经中枢。但仪表板已被搁置；程序员需要集中精力让日历发挥作用。因此，尹为钱德勒的界面设计了一个临时计划——她希望该计划在当前以日历为中心的程序中有意义，但随着电子邮件和任务管理功能的成熟，也能很好地服务于它。

Fitting all of Chandler’s functions and ideas onto a single screen was no simple matter, Yin had already discovered, and the goal of removing the silos that segregated different kinds of data only made it harder. Eventually, she believed, Chandler users would rely on her proposed dashboard view—a single screen of items flowing from past to present to future—as the nerve center of their daily information management. But the dashboard had been put on hold; the programmers needed to concentrate on getting the calendar to work. So Yin devised an interim plan for Chandler’s interface—one that she hoped would make sense in the current calendar-centric program but also serve it well as its email and task-management functions matured.

乍一看，Chandler 的基本三窗格结构与无数其他程序（包括 Microsoft Outlook）的结构相似。屏幕的中心被摘要视图（及其项目列表）和详细信息视图（其字段显示有关摘要视图中所选项目的信息）占据。左侧是侧边栏，用户可以在其中组织他们的项目集合并选择要查看的项目。Chandler 会包含几种不同类型的集合：程序自动为您提供的“开箱即用”集合，例如传入电子邮件、日历和垃圾箱；用户定义的或“临时集合”，它们是您自己创建和定义的项目的分组；以及共享收藏——其他人与您共享的收藏。侧边栏需要以某种方式考虑所有这些类型的集合，同时还要适应钱德勒的无筒仓结构，该结构允许项目存在于多个集合中，并且用户可以对项目进行标记，将它们从一种类型转换为另一种类型。

On first glance, Chandler’s basic three-pane structure resembled that of countless other programs, including Microsoft Outlook. The center of the screen was occupied by the summary view, with its lists of items, and the detail view, with its fields showing information about the item selected in the summary view. Over on the left sat the sidebar, where users would organize their collections of items and select which one to view. Chandler would include several different sorts of collections: “out-of-the-box” collections that the program automatically provided for you, like incoming email, a calendar, and a trash bin; user-defined or “ad hoc collections,” which were groupings of items that you created and defined yourself; and shared collections—those that other people had shared with you. The sidebar somehow needed to take all these sorts of collections into account while also adapting to Chandler’s silo-free structure, which allowed items to live in multiple collections and users to stamp items, transforming them from one kind into another.

Yin 提出的解决方案在侧边栏集合列表的顶部添加了一行四个按钮：“全部”、“邮件”、“任务”和“事件”。这个简单的按钮栏（最初称为“种类过滤器”，后来重命名为“应用程序栏”）将充当一种镜头或过滤器，控制当您从侧边栏列表中选择特定集合时，在摘要视图中显示哪些类型的项目。该设计力求全面，使其功能强大但又令人困惑。例如，按钮栏中不仅有一个“全部”过滤器，这意味着您没有过滤掉任何类型的项目，而且侧边栏列表中有一个“全部”集合，其中包括存储库中的所有项目。一些用例代表了常见情况。例如，如果您正在查看“全部”集合并按下“事件”按钮，那么您正在查看“所有事件”（实际上只是一个大日历），并且摘要视图将切换为日历格式。其他用例则更加不寻常，反映了钱德勒对无孤岛的渴望。例如，如果您创建了一个集合来包含与家居改造项目相关的所有项目，则“全部”按钮将显示整个集合，但“任务”和“事件”会将视图限制为这些类型的项目。由于钱德勒的标记功能允许您将任务转变为事件，反之亦然，因此某些项目可能会同时显示在任务和事件下。

Yin’s proposed solution added a row of four buttons to the top of the sidebar’s list of collections: All, Mail, Tasks, and Events. This simple button bar (initially called the Kind Filter and later renamed the Application Bar) would serve as a sort of lens or filter controlling which sorts of items showed up in the summary view when you selected a particular collection from the sidebar list. The design’s effort to be comprehensive made it powerful but confusing. For instance, there was not only an “All” filter in the button bar, which meant that you weren’t filtering out any type of item, but an “All” collection in the sidebar list, which included all the items in your repository. Some use cases represented common circumstances. If, for example, you were looking at your “All” collection and you pressed the “Events” button, you were viewing “all events”—really just a big calendar—and the summary view would switch to a calendar format. Other use cases were more unusual, reflecting Chandler’s aspiration toward silolessness. If, say, you had created a collection to contain all the items relating to a home remodeling project, the “All” button would show you the entire collection, but “tasks” and “events” would limit the view to those types of items. Since Chandler’s stamping feature allowed you to turn a task into an event and vice versa, some items might show up under both tasks and events.

Yin 的计划在 OSAF 的设计团队中酝酿，并经过讨论和完善。但当 Apps Group 开发人员有机会对其进行审查时，却引起了混乱和惊愕。他们中的一些人——尤其是约翰·安德森（John Anderson），他正在编写使侧边栏正常工作的代码——根本无法接受尹的设计。首先他们发现它不透明；后来，经过几周的会议，慢慢地让细节变得清晰起来，他们觉得这是不切实际的。

Yin’s plan gestated within OSAF’s design team, where it was debated and refined. But when the Apps Group developers had the chance to review it, it caused confusion and consternation. Several of them—particularly John Anderson, who was writing the code to make the sidebar work—simply could not warm to Yin’s design. First they found it opaque; later, after weeks of meetings slowly brought its details into focus, they felt it was impractical.

Yin 的出发点是关于用户希望如何组织他们的工作流程；开发人员首先想象用户将开发关于程序功能的“心理模型”。设计者认为，应用栏上的不同选择与用户行为的不同模式有关。开发人员认为她真正想要提供的是同一集合的一组视图，那么为什么他们不这么称呼它呢？Yin 将应用程序栏视为最后的妥协，是原始设计中唯一剩下的部分，该设计曾经包含许多更雄心勃勃的组件和功能；然而，开发人员发现她的草图过于雄心勃勃，充满了形状和特征，他们必须自定义代码，因为他们的 wxWidgets 工具包中没有现成的东西。

Yin started from ideas about how users would want to organize their workflows; the developers began by imagining the “mental model” the user would develop about the program’s functions. The designer argued that the different choices on the Application Bar related to different modes of user behavior. The developers argued that what she really wanted to provide was a set of views of the same collection, so why didn’t they call it that? Yin saw the Application Bar as a last-ditch compromise, the only remaining piece of an original design that had once included many more ambitious components and capabilities; yet the developers found her sketches overambitious, full of shapes and features that they would have to custom code since there was nothing like them ready-made in their wxWidgets toolkit.

程序员们并没有形成反对该设计的统一战线。有些人在哲学上反对它；有些人则从哲学上反对它。其他人则认为这只是没有经过充分考虑；还有一些人认为他们不妨尝试一下。但他们的不安是显而易见的，有关该主题的会议开始陷入循环对话。

The programmers didn’t form a united front against the design. Some objected to it philosophically; others thought it was just not fully thought through; still others thought they might as well give it a try. But their discomfort was obvious, and the meetings on the subject began to bog down in circular conversations.

在一场充满细节争论的漫长会议结束后，约翰·安德森表示，他正在寻找“设计中更具体的内容”。

At the end of one long meeting full of detailed wrangling, John Anderson said he was looking for “more concreteness in the design.”

凯蒂·帕兰特（Katie Parlante）的平静并不经常被激怒，她反驳道：“当你说你想要设计‘更具体’时，你需要更具体地了解需要更具体的东西！”

Katie Parlante, whose equanimity was not often ruffled, retorted, “When you say you want ‘more concreteness’ about the design, you need to be more concrete about what needs to be more concrete!”

到2004年11月初，整个讨论陷入僵局。

By early November 2004, the whole discussion had reached an impasse.

一个星期二，恰巧是总统选举的晚上，尹走到唐·丹曼的办公桌前要求谈话。他们最终聊了一个多小时，试图弥合设计师和程序员世界之间的鸿沟。丹曼回到家开始观看比赛结果，然后关掉电视。（“这对我来说很痛苦，”他告诉我，“我在俄亥俄州长大。”）他给 OSAF 开发名单写了一封电子邮件，概述了两人达成的妥协方案。它涉及将应用程序栏按钮和集合列表的交集视为一种二维网格；尽管用户看不到网格，但如果您以这种方式思考设计，如果您将其作为您的心智模型，那么它就会成为开发人员更容易接受的东西。

One Tuesday—it happened to be the evening of the presidential election—Yin walked over to Donn Denman’s desk and asked to talk. They ended up chatting for more than an hour, trying to bridge the gulf between the worlds of designer and programmer. Denman went home and started to watch the returns, then turned off the TV. (“It was painful for me,” he told me. “I grew up in Ohio.”) He composed an email to the OSAF development list outlining a compromise that the two had reached. It involved thinking of the intersection of the Application Bar buttons and the collection list as a sort of two-dimensional grid; though no grid would be visible to the user, if you thought about the design this way, if you made it your mental model, it became something a developer could more easily embrace.

丹曼于凌晨12:34 发送了电子邮件。米。那晚。虽然它几乎没有结束这个问题，但它为 Chandler 0.5 构建工作侧边栏扫清了道路。

Denman sent his email at 12:34 A.M. that night. While it hardly put an end to the issue, it cleared a path toward building a working sidebar for Chandler 0.5.





“设计师都应该花一些时间学习编程，”约翰·安德森有一天在午餐时宣称。“那么他们就不会继续提出这么困难的事情了。”

“Designers should all take some time and learn programming,” John Anderson declared one day over lunch. “Then they won’t keep proposing such really difficult things.”

“但那样他们就不会想出好主意了，”丽莎·杜索回答道。“他们会阻止他们。一旦你知道如何编程，你就会觉得这太难了。”

“But then they wouldn’t come up with great ideas,” Lisa Dusseault replied. “They’d block them. Once you know how to program, you think, it’s too hard to do that.”

“好吧，”安德森说，“我仍然有想法。但我会对他们有不同的看法！”

“Well,” Anderson said, “I’d still have the ideas. But I’d think about them differently!”





2004 年 10 月，Ted Leung 在他的博客中发布了一条注释，该博客在开源程序员中很受欢迎，称 OSAF 正在市场上寻找“热门 Python 黑客”来帮助重组和完善 Chandler“内容模型”，该模型的定义是程序用于访问它存储的数据。每个人都知道，这里的改进将大大加快 Chandler 的速度——帮助程序运行得更快，也帮助开发人员更快地编写程序。Phillip J. Eby 是一名 Python 程序员，他在 dirtysimple.org 上维护着自己的博客（博客标题开玩笑说，“让简单的事情变得困难，让复杂的事情变得不可能”），他在 11 月份响应了这个号召。在花了一些时间研究 Chandler 的代码库后，Eby 在他的博客上发布了一篇题为“Python Is Not Java”的长篇文章。

In October 2004, Ted Leung posted a note to his blog, which was popular among open source programmers, that OSAF was in the market for a “hot shot Python hacker” to help restructure and refine the Chandler “content model,” the definitions the program used to access the data it stored. Improvements here, everyone knew, would go a long way toward speeding Chandler up—helping the program run faster and helping the developers write it faster, too. Phillip J. Eby, a Python programmer who maintained his own blog at dirtsimple.org (“making simple things hard, and complex things impossible,” its header joked), answered the call in November. After spending some time studying Chandler’s code base, Eby posted to his blog a lengthy entry titled “Python Is Not Java.”



我最近正在查看一个基于wxPython的GUI应用程序的源代码。。。。该代码是由对 Python 相对陌生的 Java 开发人员编写的 ，并且存在一些性能问题（例如 30 秒的启动时间）。在检查代码时，我发现他们做了很多在 Java 中有意义的事情，但在 Python 中却很糟糕。并不是因为“Python 比 Java 慢”，而是因为在 Python 中可以通过更简单的方法来实现在 Java 中无法实现的相同目标。

I was recently looking at the source of a wxPython-based GUI application . . . . The code was written by Java developers who are relatively new to Python, and it suffers from some performance issues (like a 30-second startup time). In examining the code, I found that they had done lots of things that make sense in Java, but which suck terribly in Python. Not because "Python is slower than Java," but because there are easier ways to accomplish the same goals in Python that wouldn't even be possible in Java.



所以，可悲的是，这些可怜的人工作得比他们需要的要努力得多，为了产生比他们需要编写的更多的代码，然后这些代码的执行速度比等效的惯用Python慢​​得多。

So, the sad thing is that these poor folks worked much, much harder than they needed to, in order to produce much more code than they needed to write, that then performs much more slowly than the equivalent idiomatic Python would.



接下来是一长串关于如何像真正的“Pythonista”而不是新手一样使用 Python 的技术建议。伊比总结道：

There followed a long list of technical recommendations for how to use Python like a true “Pythonista” rather than a newbie. Eby concluded:



这只是Java->Python思维迁移的冰山一角。。。。本质上，如果您已经使用 Java 一段时间并且刚接触 Python，请不要相信您的直觉。您的直觉适合 Java，而不是 Python。退后一步，最重要的是，停止编写这么多代码。

This is only the tip of the iceberg for Java-> Python mindset migration . . . . Essentially, if you've been using Java for a while and are new to Python, do not trust your instincts. Your instincts are tuned to Java, not Python. Take a step back, and above all, stop writing so much code.



为此，对 Python 的要求更高。假装 Python 是一根魔杖，它会奇迹般地做你想做的任何事情，而无需你动一根手指。问：“Python 如何解决我的问题？” 以及“Python 语言的哪些功能与我的问题最相似？” 你绝对会惊讶地发现 你需要的东西已经以某种形式存在了。

To do this, become more demanding of Python. Pretend that Python is a magic wand that will miraculously do whatever you want without you needing to lift a finger. Ask, "how does Python already solve my problem?" and "What Python language feature most resembles my problem?" You will be absolutely astonished at how often it happens that [the] thing you need is already there in some form.



尽管伊比从未提到钱德勒的名字，但很清楚他在说谁。他的观点是不可否认的——Chandler 的关键开发人员，无论他们掌握了多少代码，都是 Python 新手，他们根本没有充分利用该语言的功能，有时反而被它们绊倒。

Although Eby never mentioned Chandler by name, it was pretty clear who he was talking about. His point was undeniable—that key Chandler developers, no matter how much coding they had under their belts, were Python newbies who simply weren’t taking full advantage of the language’s features and were sometimes tripping over them instead.

尽管如此，PJE（他惯常的称呼）公开揭露 OSAF 团队的失误的方式还是有些不雅——即使他正在接受与他们合作的面试。其他组织可能会反对这种行为。不过，在 OSAF，卡普尔一直鼓励对批评持开放态度：“如果我们有什么意义的话，”他会说，“我们就是一个知道如何学习的组织。”

Still, there was something, well, indelicate about the way PJE (his customary handle) was publicly exposing the OSAF team’s goofs—even as he was interviewing to work with them. Other organizations might have circled the wagons against such behavior. At OSAF, though, Kapor had always encouraged openness to criticism: “If we’re anything,” he would say, “we’re an organization that knows how to learn.”

因此，Eby 于 2005 年 1 月加入公司，在佛罗里达州棕榈滩的家中远程工作，并立即开始起草大规模代码清理的提案。其中一些工作很重要，但本质上是清洁工作，涉及“扁平化树”——删除源代码中的多层文件夹目录，以实现更简单、更容易掌握的结构。

And so Eby came on board in January 2005, working remotely from his home in Palm Beach, Florida, and immediately started drafting a proposal for a massive code cleanup. Some of the work was important but essentially janitorial, involving “flattening the tree”—removing multiple layers of file folder directories in the source code to achieve a simpler, easier-to-grasp structure.

概念上更雄心勃勃的是 Eby 重新思考 Chandler 代码的基本结构的想法：他设计了名为 Spike 的“推测性可行性原型”，其目标是“最大限度地减少人们为了做有用的事情而必须理解的事情的数量”。斯派克将钱德勒的基础数据概念重新组织成五个精心定义且整齐分开的层。这为 OSAF 的开发人员提供了一个干净的新模型，但它也涉及清理钱德勒的许多区域并从头开始重新设计它们——在花费了这么多时间和精力之后，这并不是一个诱人的前景。帕兰特和杜塞尔同意不全面采用 Spike，而是改编其中的好想法，这些想法可以融入到 Chandler 中，而不会破坏其缓慢但稳定的进展。

More conceptually ambitious was Eby’s idea for rethinking the basic structure of Chandler’s code: He devised “a speculative feasibility prototype” named Spike with the goal of “minimizing the number of things somebody has to understand in order to do something useful.” Spike would reorganize Chandler’s underlying data concepts into five carefully defined and tidily separated layers. That offered OSAF’s developers a clean new model, but it also involved clearing the decks in many areas of Chandler and reworking them from scratch—not an inviting prospect after so much time and labor. Parlante and Dusseault agreed not to adopt Spike wholesale but to adapt good ideas from it that could be integrated into Chandler without derailing its slow but steady progress.

Eby 再次转向他的博客报告他的工作。他描述了他创建 Spike 的过程：他借用了极限编程中的一种称为“测试驱动开发”的方法，其中程序员在编写函数本身之前编写评估程序函数成功与否的测试。然后，在工作的每个阶段，他们都可以确保他们的代码仍然有效并且符合最初的预期。伊比认为，斯派克的效果令人印象深刻：“这简直就是一件美丽的事情，是一颗具有连锁特征的虹彩宝石。”

Once more Eby turned to his blog to report on his work. He described the process he adopted to create Spike: He had borrowed a method from Extreme Programming called “test-driven development,” in which programmers write the test that evaluates the success of a program function before they write the function itself. Then, at every stage of work, they can be sure that their code still works and does what was originally intended. With Spike, Eby felt, the result was impressive: “It is quite simply a thing of beauty, an iridescent jewel of interlocking features.”

后来，埃比在后记中指出，这种热情洋溢的自我评价可能听起来很傲慢。他解释说，他的本意是对测试驱动方法的结果大肆赞扬，而不是拍拍自己的背。

Later, in a postscript, Eby noted that the glowing self-review might sound arrogant. He explained that he had meant to lavish praise on the results of the test-driven method, not to pat himself on the back.





在 0.4 版本中，OSAF 在 Chandler 中采用了一种新的共享方法——放弃旧的点对点愿景，采用 Lisa Dusseault 提倡的 WebDAV 方法。Morgen Sagen 已经开始编写代码，将项目从 Chandler 发送到 WebDAV 服务器，然后再将它们带回。但该服务器到底是什么？事实证明，并没有很多成熟的、广泛部署的开源 WebDAV 服务器，也没有实现新的面向日历的 CalDAV 标准。OSAF 开发人员还希望他们的服务器执行一些额外的技巧，因为他们试图保留 Chandler 将在服务器之间传递的一些特殊的“Chandlerosity”信息。

During 0.4, OSAF had adopted a new approach to sharing in Chandler—abandoning the old peer-to-peer vision and embracing the WebDAV approach Lisa Dusseault had advocated. Morgen Sagen had begun writing code to send items out from Chandler to a WebDAV server and bring them back in again. But what exactly was that server going to be? It turned out that there weren’t a lot of mature, widely deployed open source WebDAV servers around, and none that implemented the new calendar-oriented CalDAV standard. There were also a few extra tricks the OSAF developers wanted their server to perform as they tried to preserve some of the special “Chandlerosity” of information that Chandler was going to pass to and from the server.

杜塞尔不断游说在 OSAF 的保护下建立一个单独的服务器项目。它会为钱德勒服务，但又脱离它而存在。2005 年初，服务器项目（以 Chandlerthe-labradoodle 的哥哥的名字命名为 Cosmo）准备就绪。这是一项精益的工作，主要由一名程序员 Brian Moseley 承担。但由于它是全新开始的，并且与 Chandler 的所有交易都将使用规范的 WebDAV 标准进行，因此它不必遵循 Chandler 项目的任何先例。例如，Moseley 决定使用 Java 而不是 Python。

Dusseault steadily lobbied for the establishment of a separate server project under the OSAF umbrella. It would serve Chandler but exist apart from it. In early 2005, the server project—named Cosmo, after Chandlerthe-labradoodle’s elder sibling—geared up. It was to be a lean effort, mostly undertaken by a single programmer, Brian Moseley.
