But because it was starting fresh and because all its dealings with Chandler would transpire using the canonical WebDAV standard, it didn’t have to follow any of the Chandler project’s precedents. Moseley, for instance, decided to use Java instead of Python.

不久之后，Cosmo 就有了自己的邮件列表，Dusseault 开始重组 OSAF wiki，以便它可以容纳两个独立的项目。莫斯利倾向于在家工作，很少出席 OSAF 的会议。正如 Andi Vajda 所预测的那样，建立服务器的决定不仅使整个 Chandler 的工作变得更大，而且还巧妙地开始分叉 OSAF 组织。如果科斯莫遇到麻烦，这可能会引起警报。但服务器的运行并没有出现明显的危机或延迟——这与钱德勒面临的许多障碍形成了令人欢迎的对比。

Before long, Cosmo had its own mailing list, and Dusseault began reorganizing the OSAF wiki so it could accommodate two separate projects. Moseley tended to work at home and rarely showed up for OSAF’s meetings. The decision to build a server not only made the whole Chandler effort bigger, as Andi Vajda had predicted, but it also subtly began to fork the OSAF organization. That might have raised alarms if Cosmo hit trouble. But the server moved along without noticeable crisis or delay—a welcome contrast to the many roadblocks Chandler had faced.

Cosmo 只雇佣了一名开发人员，这一点很有帮助；这意味着它不必支付大量的协调成本。但与为用户编写软件相比，编写服务器软件始终具有一定的优势，这也是事实。服务器是一个几乎完全与其他程序和机器打交道的程序；它很少需要与人类直接交流。当它发生时，它需要与之交谈的人（例如，当它最初配置时，或者当它遇到障碍时）通常是专业人员、系统管理员或程序员，他们已经精通服务器自己的方言。

It helped that Cosmo employed only one developer; that meant it didn’t have to pay a lot of coordination costs. But it was also true that writing server software has always had certain advantages compared with writing software for users. A server is a program that deals almost entirely with other programs and machines; it rarely needs to communicate directly with human beings. And when it does, the human being it needs to talk to—when it is being initially configured, for instance, or when it hits a snag—is usually a pro, a systems administrator or programmer who is already fluent in the server’s own dialect.

因此，对于 Cosmo 来说，当钱德勒团队试图协调人类思维过程和工作习惯与软件系统和界面时，他们并没有遇到那些向他们发出嘶嘶声的蛇。莫斯利和杜塞尔面临着一系列相对易于管理的问题，例如，新用户如何设置帐户？或者，当一个时区的用户与另一时区的用户共享日历时，如何匹配时间？在钱德勒制定了模糊的野心和不断调整的日程安排之后，科斯莫精心界定的界限让他松了口气。

So for Cosmo there were no encounters with the snakes that hissed at the Chandler team as they tried to reconcile human thought processes and work habits with software systems and interfaces. Moseley and Dusseault faced a relatively manageable set of questions—like, how does a new user set up an account? Or, how do you match up times when a user in one time zone shares a calendar with a user in another? After Chandler’s amorphous ambitions and telescoping schedule, Cosmo’s carefully defined boundaries came as a relief.





在钱德勒 0.5 中，OSAF 的领导层故意缩减了他们的野心并降低了目标。他们暂时会忘记组织整个数据世界并使外部开发人员能够向意想不到的方向扩展程序的承诺。他们告诉团队，议程的灵魂是一件美丽的事情；但现在，我们可以建立一个工作日历吗？

With Chandler 0.5, OSAF’s leadership had deliberately scaled back their ambitions and aimed low. They would forget for the moment the promise of organizing the entire universe of data and enabling outside developers to extend the program in unexpected directions. The soul of Agenda was a beautiful thing, they told their team; but for now, could we please just build a working calendar?

然而，在 2004 年 11 月开始的 0.5 计划实施不久后，很明显，即使是这个适度的目标也无法实现。要让应用程序的机器正常运行，还有很长的路要走。已经取得了一些进展：约翰·安德森 (John Anderson) 和唐·丹曼 (Donn Denman) 根据他们称为“块树”的新设计改进了 CPIA 框架，他们希望这种设计能够使未来的更改更快、更容易。自从安德森第一次将闪烁问题记录为错误以来，大卫·苏罗维尔终于解决了困扰钱德勒的大部分闪烁问题。在 WebDAV 的帮助下，共享成为现实，在一种新的、简单的“共享邀请”方法下，Chandler 用户只需通过电子邮件向其他用户发送“票证”，即可授予他们访问共享日历的权限。迷你日历导航器（在大多数日历程序中看到的当前月份、上个月和下个月的微型显示）现在运行良好并且看起来不错。Andi Vajda 和 Ted Leung 通过中小型调整的积累提高了存储库的速度。

Yet not far into the 0.5 schedule, which began at the start of November 2004, it became obvious that even that modest goal was beyond reach. There was simply too far to go to get the application’s machinery functioning. There had been some progress: John Anderson and Donn Denman had revamped the CPIA framework according to a new design they called “trees of blocks” that would, they hoped, make future changes faster and easier. David Surovell had finally tamed most of the flicker issues that had plagued Chandler ever since Anderson first logged them as a bug. With the help of WebDAV, sharing was real, and under a new, simple approach to “sharing invitations,” Chandler users would simply email a “ticket” to other users that would grant them access to a shared calendar. The mini-calendar navigator (the miniature display of the current month, last month, and next month seen in most calendar programs) now worked well and looked decent. Andi Vajda and Ted Leung had improved the speed of the repository through an accumulation of small and medium tweaks.

但这样的进步并不意味着卡普尔可以开始进行内部测试。与此同时，该项目的新人涌入给进度带来了更多阻力。当登曼准备休陪产假时，OSAF 引进了布莱恩·斯特恩斯 (Bryan Stearns)，他是一位经验丰富的程序员，二十年前曾与登曼在最初的 Macintosh 团队中一起工作，斯特恩斯接管了细节视图。亚历克·弗莱特 (Alec Flett) 是一名长期的 Netscape 开发人员，他从编程中抽出一段时间担任学校教师；格兰特·贝利 (Grant Baillie) 是史蒂夫·乔布斯 (Steve Jobs) 的 Next 项目的资深人士，最近在苹果公司负责电子邮件项目，他们于 1 月份加入。这些新面孔代表了长期的增援，但从短期来看，他们每个人都需要花一些时间来了解钱德勒。布鲁克斯定律并未被废除。

But such forward steps did not add up to a calendar that Kapor could begin dogfooding. Meanwhile, an influx of newcomers to the project added more drag to the schedule. With Denman preparing for a paternity leave, OSAF brought in Bryan Stearns, an experienced programmer who had worked with Denman two decades before on the original Macintosh team, and Stearns took over the detail view. Alec Flett, a longtime Netscape developer who had taken some time off programming to work as a school-teacher, and Grant Baillie, a veteran of Steve Jobs’s Next who most recently had worked at Apple on its email program, joined in January. The new faces represented reinforcements for the long haul, but in the short term they each had to take some time to figure Chandler out. Brooks’s Law had not been repealed.

Chandler 现在有 150 万行代码，其中大部分是从 wxWidgets 和 Twisted 等其他项目合并而来的。OSAF 开发人员编写了大约 130,000 行特定于 Chandler 的 Python 代码。正如一名 OSAF 暑期实习生所说，开始这个项目就像搬到一个新城市并试图找到自己的方位一样。

Chandler was now 1.5 million lines of code, most of which had been incorporated from other projects like wxWidgets and Twisted. There were about 130,000 Chandler-specific lines of Python code that OSAF developers had written. Getting started at the project was, as an OSAF summer intern put it, like moving to a new city and trying to find your bearings.

2005 年 3 月 30 日，即 0.5 版本发布后的第二天，我问 Kapor，他是否因该项目已经走了多远、还有多远而感到沮丧。“我知道我们会做出一些伟大的事情，”他说。“我只是不知道曲柄还需要转多少圈。”

On March 30, 2005, the day after the 0.5 release, I asked Kapor whether he was at all discouraged by how long a road the project had already traveled and how far it still had to go. “I know we are going to come out with something great,” he said. “I just don’t know how many more turns of the crank it’s going to take.”





自 2003 年以来，每年 3 月，Python 爱好者都会聚集在华盛顿，参加一个名为 PyCon 的会议，这是专门为开源程序员举办的思想交流会。除了其他极客追求之外，PyCon 还举办“冲刺”——快速沉浸式研讨会，程序员在其中开展狭隘定义的项目，看看他们在两三天内能走多远。

Every March since 2003, Python enthusiasts had gathered in Washington for a conference called PyCon—an idea exchange for dedicated open source programmers. Among other geekish pursuits, PyCon holds “sprints”—quick-immersion workshops in which programmers take on narrowly defined projects and see how far they can get in two or three days.

2005 年，Ted Leung 与几位 OSAF 开发人员一起参加 PyCon，并帮助运行 Chandler 冲刺。他们和由三名感兴趣的志愿者组成的小组为 Chandler 制作了两个独立的新扩展，这些扩展包为该程序添加了新功能。其中一个允许 Chandler 连接到 Flickr，这是一种日益流行的基于网络的照片共享服务；另一个将 Chandler 与另一个名为 Del.icio.us 的服务连接起来，该服务允许用户发布和共享 Web 书签列表，并为这些书签提供描述性元数据标签。有了这些新的包，用户可以从 Flickr 导入和导出照片，从 Del.icio.us 导入和导出书签，然后在 Chandler 中组织它们。同样，Chao Lam 在帮助资助 OSAF 的大学联盟的一次技术会议上进行了另一次冲刺；它产生了一个包裹，将人们的公共“愿望清单”从亚马逊网站导入到钱德勒。

In 2005, Ted Leung traveled to PyCon with several OSAF developers and helped run a Chandler sprint. They and a group of three interested volunteers produced two separate new extensions to Chandler—parcels that added new capabilities to the program. One of them allowed Chandler to connect to Flickr, the increasingly popular Web-based photo-sharing service; the other hooked up Chandler with another service called Del.icio.us that allowed users to post and share lists of Web bookmarks and to give those bookmarks descriptive metadata tags. With these new parcels a user could import and export photos from Flickr and bookmarks from Del.icio.us, and then organize them from within Chandler. In a similar vein, Chao Lam had run another sprint at a technical meeting of the university consortium that had helped fund OSAF; that produced a parcel which imported people’s public “wish lists” from Amazon.com into Chandler.

一旦你把这些东西拉进钱德勒，你就可以对它做钱德勒式的事情，组织和标记物品，把它们从一种东西变成另一种东西。当 Alec Flett 在 PyCon 后向 OSAF 工作人员演示新包裹时，他使用 Flickr 包裹从 Kapor 的帐户导入了一批照片 - 所有都是他的狗的快照。然后他拍了一张标有“Cosmo at 3”的照片——一张戴着王冠的狗狗生日肖像——并将其标记为当天的活动。切换到日历视图，他将照片显示在日历上。

Once you pulled this stuff into Chandler, you could do Chandler-style things to it, organizing and stamping items, turning them from one kind of thing into another. When Alec Flett demoed the new parcels to the OSAF staff after PyCon, he used the Flickr parcel to import a batch of photos from Kapor’s account—all snapshots of his dogs. Then he took one labeled “Cosmo at 3”—a canine birthday portrait, complete with crown—and stamped it as an event for that day. Switching to the calendar view, he showed the photo there on the calendar.

钱德勒的每一次扩展本身并不是什么大不了的事，但正如摩根·萨根的相册项目曾经所做的那样，每一次都为钱德勒最初的承诺注入了生命。日历是 OSAF 开发人员必须集中精力的内容，但正是这些多功能性的小练习、这些数据炼金术实验让他们的火焰不断燃烧，并在如此多的延误和挫折中保留了议程的灵魂。当 Kapor 开始将 Chandler 的最新版本向业内朋友进行演示时（Chandler 0.5 完成后，他最终做到了），正是这些扩展，几乎毫不费力地将看似不同类型的信息和服务拼接在一起，哇。

Each extension of Chandler was in itself not a big deal, but as Morgen Sagen’s photo album program once did, each breathed life into Chandler’s original promise. The calendar was what OSAF’s developers had to concentrate on, but it was these little exercises in versatility, these experiments in data alchemy that kept their flames burning and preserved the soul of Agenda across so many delays and setbacks. When Kapor began taking the latest builds of Chandler out to demo for friends in the industry—as he finally did, once Chandler 0.5 was finished—it was these extensions, with their almost effortless stitching together of seemingly disparate types of information and services, that wowed.





随着时间的推移，钱德勒团队发生了一些非常不寻常的事情。它已成为一个主要由女性管理的开源项目，这并非有意为之，但也许并非完全巧合。卡普尔仍然是“终生仁慈的独裁者”，他在钱德勒邮件列表上半开玩笑地接受了这个头衔，这是对莱纳斯·托瓦兹使用这个短语的致敬。但凯蒂·帕兰特 (Katie Parlante) 和丽莎·杜塞尔 (Lisa Dusseault) 负责管理工程团队，希拉·穆尼 (Sheila Mooney) 负责产品管理，米米·尹 (Mimi Yin) 担任首席设计师，钱德勒在软件开发领域拥有令人印象深刻的女性领导力。

Something very unusual had happened to the Chandler team over time. Not by design but maybe not entirely coincidentally, it had become an open source project largely managed by women. Kapor was still the “benevolent dictator for life,” the title he had half-jokingly accepted on the Chandler mailing list in a tip of the hat to Linus Torvalds’s use of the phrase. But with Katie Parlante and Lisa Dusseault running the engineering groups, Sheila Mooney in charge of product management, and Mimi Yin as the lead designer, Chandler had what was, in the world of software development, an impressive depth of female leadership.

在软件领域，男性的数量一直多于女性，而在开源软件领域，这一比例更加不平衡。进入该领域的女性往往会做出有影响力和巨大的贡献，但她们的数量从来都不是很大，而且近年来进入计算机科学项目的女性人数实际上有所下降。解释这种差异的努力既可能引发刻板印象，也可能亵渎圣牛。但最有思想的学者指出，对女性的社会偏见往往胜过所有其他因素。在米尔斯学院教授计算机科学并研究这个问题多年的埃伦·斯珀图斯 (Ellen Spertus) 在 1991 年的一篇论文中写道，“虽然不能排除某些先天神经或心理差异的可能性，这些差异会导致女性不太（或更大）为了在计算机科学领域取得优异成绩，我发现对女性从事此类职业的文化偏见是如此之大，以至于即使存在固有差异，也无法解释整个差距。”

Men have always outnumbered women in software, and the ratio is even more lopsided in open source software. The women who do enter the field often make influential and outsized contributions, but their numbers have never been great, and the figures for women entering computer science programs have actually dropped in recent years. Efforts to explain the disparity risk both invoking stereotypes and profaning sacred cows. But the most thoughtful students of the matter point out that social bias against women tends to trump all other factors. In a 1991 paper, Ellen Spertus, who teaches computer science at Mills College and has studied this issue for years, wrote, “While one cannot rule out the possibility of some innate neurological or psychological differences that would make women less (or more) likely to excel in computer science, I found that the cultural biases against women’s pursuing such careers are so large that, even if inherent differences exist, they would not explain the entire gap.”

如今，走进一个软件项目的管理会议并遇到一群女性面孔仍然是一种异国情调的经历。我询问过的 OSAF 中，没有人曾在一个有这么多女性负责人的软件团队中工作过，几乎每个人都认为这种罕见的情况可能与办公室里压倒性的礼貌有关——令人讨厌的地盘争夺战相对罕见。以及粗鲁的侮辱和侵略性的自我展示。是的，确实存在冲突，但它被小心地压制住了。卡普尔是否为消除女性进步的常见障碍的项目定下了不同的基调？或者是那些才华横溢的女性登上了顶峰，然后创造了一个适宜的环境？

Today, to walk into the management meeting of a software project and encounter a group of female faces is still an exotic experience. No one at OSAF whom I asked had ever before worked on a software team with so many women in charge, and nearly everyone felt that this rare situation might have something to do with the overwhelming civility around the office—the relative rarity of nasty turf wars and rude insult and aggressive ego display. There was conflict, yes, but it was carefully muted. Had Kapor set a different tone for the project that removed common barriers to women advancing? Or had the talented women risen to the top and then created a congenial environment?

这种先有鸡还是先有蛋的问题可能是无法回答的。至少在 OSAF，女性程序员难得有机会掌控全局。随着节目的不断发展，一位女性尤其发现自己正在承担难以管理的管理职责。Parlante 负责 Chandler 的长期架构问题，同时她也是应用程序组的日常经理，该组不断增加新的开发人员。Kapor 在 0.4 期间决定聘请一名新的应用程序组经理向 Parlante 汇报，但寻找工作并不容易。直到 0.5 年底，也就是 2005 年 3 月，这个职位才最终被菲利普·博苏特 (Philippe Bossut) 填补，他是一位有条理、有讽刺幽默感、口音浓重的法国工程师。博苏特最近在 Macromedia 工作，和丽莎·杜塞尔一样，他也曾在微软工作过多年。

Such chicken-egg questions are probably unanswerable. At OSAF, at least, women programmers had a rare shot at running the show. As the show kept growing, one woman in particular found herself handling an unmanageable share of the management duties. Parlante was in charge of long-term architectural issues for Chandler, and she was also the day-to-day manager of the Applications Group, which kept adding new developers. Kapor had decided during 0.4 to hire a new Apps Group manager to report to Parlante, but the search hadn’t been easy. It wasn’t until the end of 0.5, in March 2005, that the position was finally filled by Philippe Bossut, a methodical French engineer with a wry sense of humor and a thick accent. Bossut had most recently worked at Macromedia, and, like Lisa Dusseault, he had also put in years at Microsoft.

Bossut 接管应用程序团队的第一件事就是制作一个电子表格，列出 0.6 上每个开发人员面临的每一项任务，以及估计任务长度的 SWAG（愚蠢的、狂野的猜测）。然后他将所有任务加起来，看看 0.6 实际需要多少时间。这在形式上有所不同，但本质上类似于 Dusseault 使用便利贴所做的事情以及 Michael Toy 几年前要求开发人员估计他们在 Bugzilla 中的任务完成时间时尝试做的事情。但它有更详细的内容；正如开发人员所说，它“更加精细”。

The first thing Bossut did on taking over the apps team reins was to make a spreadsheet listing every single task facing every single developer on 0.6 along with a SWAG (Silly, Wild-Assed Guess) estimating the task’s length. Then he would add up all the tasks and see how much time 0.6 would really take. This was different in form but similar in essence to what Dusseault had done with stickies and what Michael Toy had tried to do years before when he asked his developers to estimate their task completion times in Bugzilla. But it went into far greater detail; it was, as the developers put it, “more granular.”

“你把一个大问题分解成你可以单独理解和解决的小问题，”博苏特向我解释道。“这没有什么魔力。但你必须彻底。”

“You take a big problem, and you cut it into small problems that you can understand and solve individually,” Bossut explained to me. “There is no magic to it. But you have to be thorough.”

在 4 月中旬的第一次测试中，Bossut 发现每个开发人员需要大约 40 天的工作时间才能完成 0.5 结束时遗留下来的 bug 列表。这意味着 0.6 与几乎所有之前的版本一样，需要六个月或更长时间，而不是 Kapor 最初希望的三到四个月。“我很想说，只要我们能达到我们想要的 0.6，我不在乎是否需要 6 个月，”他告诉他的经理们。Kapor 认为，对于 0.6 来说，最重要的是最终投入一些时间来“安装和完成”工作，使用户界面变得漂亮、活泼。这是提供可用日历的最后一个主要障碍——不一定是技术营销人员始终瞄准的早期采用者，但至少是“第一采用者”，这些勇敢的灵魂很可能会在 OSAF 自己的队伍中找到。

On his first pass in mid-April, Bossut found that each developer faced roughly forty days of work just to close out the list of bugs that had been left over at the end of 0.5. This meant that 0.6, like nearly all the previous releases, was going to take six months or more, not the three to four months Kapor had originally hoped. “I’m tempted to say I don’t care if it takes six months so long as we get the 0.6 we have in mind,” he told his managers. The important thing for 0.6, Kapor felt, was to at last devote some time to “fit and finish” work, making the user interface spiffy and snappy. That was the last major obstacle to delivering a calendar that was usable—not necessarily by the early adopters that technology marketers always targeted, but at least by “first adopters,” brave souls who most likely would be found within OSAF’s own ranks.

于是开发人员就开始工作了。他们不断地减少虫子数量。他们开始向 Chandler 添加一些平凡但必不可少的功能，例如日历项目的颜色，这样当您叠加多个日历（“家庭”和“工作”，或者“我的”和“我的”）时，您就可以知道这些项目来自哪里。配偶的”）。他们重新设计了表视图中的列标题，这些标题一直看起来很难看。他们在迷你日历中添加了“繁忙栏”，显示哪些日子安排了活动。他们对整个界面进行了“国际化”和“本地化”Chandler 的改造，允许该程序以多种不同的语言进行定制，并支持不同的当地习俗，比如一周中的哪一天是最先出现的。这是开源让解决起来更容易的问题：IBM 提供了一个免费的库，它提供了您所需的所有关于语言和地区的详细信息，以及乌拉圭人是否喜欢在周日还是周一开始新的一周。它并不完美——事实上，一位乌拉圭开发人员在钱德勒邮件列表上提供了一些关于一些不准确之处的反馈——但它节省了大量的劳动力。

And so the developers got to work. They took steady bites out of the bug count. They started adding features to Chandler that were mundane but essential, like color for calendar items, so you could tell where the items came from when you overlaid multiple calendars (“home” and “work,” say, or “mine” and “my spouse’s”). They reworked the column headers in the table view, which had always looked ugly. They added “busy bars” to the mini-calendar, showing which days had scheduled events. They revamped the entire interface to “internationalize” and “localize” Chandler, allowing the program to be customized in a host of different languages and to support different local customs, like which day of the week comes first. This was the kind of problem that open source made easier to solve: IBM offered a free library that supplied all the specifics you needed about languages and localities, and whether Uruguayans prefer to start their week on Sunday or Monday. It wasn’t perfect—in fact, a Uruguayan developer provided some feedback on the Chandler mailing list about some inaccuracies—but it saved mountains of labor.

这些都是可以管理的任务。但钱德勒早年以来还有其他一些更棘手的问题最终也需要解决。其中之一是开发人员所说的“日期/时间小部件”——该程序的设备可让您指定事件何时开始和结束。在纸面上，宣布事件的日期和时间是一个相对灵活的事情：你可以说“5/15 at 3 P”。米。” 或“5 月 15 日 3 点”或“5 月 15 日 @ 3”，消息就会发送出去。早在 20 世纪 80 年代，Kapor 心爱的 Lotus Agenda 在解析日期和时间笔记方面就表现出色；即使是模糊地提及“下周一”，它也能挖掘出含义。没有人预料到钱德勒会做同样的事情——至少现在还没有。但尹咪咪希望至少能够克服基于计算机的日历的一些最烦人的特征。她认为钱德勒应该根据人们说话的方式对时间日期输入进行建模，并建议详细视图提供一个单一字段，用户可以在其中输入“一月”等文本。2004 年 3 日至 5 日下午 4 点至 6 点。”

These were manageable tasks. But there were other, trickier issues dating from Chandler’s early days that finally needed to be resolved, too. One was what the developers called the “date/time widget”—the program’s device for letting you specify when an event begins and ends. On paper, declaring the date and time of an event is a relatively flexible matter: You can say “5/15 at 3 P.M.” or “3 o’clock on May 15” or “15 May @ 3” and the message will get through. Back in the 1980s, Kapor’s beloved Lotus Agenda had done a remarkable job of parsing notes for dates and times; it could mine meaning even from vague references to “next Monday.” No one expected Chandler to do the same—not yet, anyway. But Mimi Yin hoped at least to overcome some of the most annoying traits of computer-based calendars. She argued that Chandler should model time-date entry on how people speak and proposed that the detail view offer a single field in which users could enter text like “Jan. 3–5, 2004 from 4–6 pm.”

“就在那里，这是一个非常复杂的信息，”细节视图的管理员布莱恩·斯特恩斯（Bryan Stearns）反对道。

“Right there, that’s a very complicated message,” Bryan Stearns, keeper of the detail view, objected.

对于开发人员来说，构建一个智能的、人性化的日期/时间小部件看起来像是另一个过于雄心勃勃的时间表破坏者。经过大量的辩论和谈判，尹的设计论点输给了他们务实的反对意见。对于 0.6，每个 Chandler 日历事件都有单独的开始和结束日期和时间字段 - 总共四个字段。

Building a smart, people-friendly date/time widget looked like another overambitious schedule buster to the developers. After considerable debate and negotiation, Yin’s design argument lost out to their pragmatic objections. For 0.6, each Chandler calendar event would have separate date and time fields for its start and end—four fields in all.





如果 Chandler 0.6 要为第一批采用者提供他们可以实际使用的日历，则必须添加另一个基本功能：重复事件。这些是您想要放在日历上然后定期重复的项目，例如您公司的每日部门会议或您孩子的每周吉他课。纸质日历从未提供过这样的服务，但这正是人们期望软件能够轻松完成的事情。

If Chandler 0.6 was going to provide first adopters with a calendar they could actually use, another basic feature had to be added: recurring events. These were items you wanted to put on your calendar and then have repeat at regular intervals—such as your company’s daily department meeting or your child’s weekly guitar lesson. Paper calendars had never provided such a service, but it was exactly what people expected software to do effortlessly.

然而，反复出现给钱德勒的开发者带来了一些实际和哲学问题。如果您想设置一个事件在特定时间段内重复发生（例如下个月每周），一切都很好。但是如果您不想指定结束日期怎么办？如果您希望该事件无限期地重复，直到您决定将其从日历中删除，该怎么办？

Recurrence, however, presented Chandler’s developers with some practical and philosophical problems. If you wanted to set an event to recur for a specific period—say, every week next month—all was well. But what if you didn’t want to specify an end date? What if you wanted the event to repeat indefinitely, until such time as you decided to take it off your calendar?

软件不能很好地处理无穷大。没有计算机有无限量的可用存储空间，当程序陷入无限循环（没有退出的过程）时，它就会停止响应。大多数日历程序都找到了解决无限期重复问题的方法：您可以简单地存储重复事件的单个“主”版本，然后根据管理它的任何规则显示它。或者，您可以选择 X 年的任意前瞻距离，并生成到该点的递归，不再进一步。Lisa Dusseault 在 OSAF 研究该问题时报告说，在另一个系统中，无限重复发生的事件会一直复制到 2038 年，然后停止。（事实证明，到 2038 年，所有基于 Unix 的计算机系统的内部时钟都会像里程表达到极限一样，归零。）“显然，”杜塞尔在一封电子邮件中写道，“世界将于 2038 年终结。好的一面是，2038 年之后就没有生日了，我们就不会变老了。”

Software does not handle infinity well. No computer has an infinite amount of storage available to it, and when a program gets caught in an infinite loop, a procedure with no exit, it ceases to respond. Most calendar programs found workarounds to the problem of indefinite recurrence: You could simply store a single “master” version of the recurring event and then display it according to whatever rules governed it. Or you could just choose an arbitrary look-ahead distance of X years and generate the recurrences up to that point and no further. In one other system, Lisa Dusseault reported as OSAF researched the problem, an indefinitely recurring event would replicate itself all the way until 2038, then just stop. (In 2038, it turns out, the internal clocks of all Unix-based computer systems will, like odometers reaching their limit, roll over to zero.) “Apparently,” Dusseault wrote in an email, “the world ends in 2038. On the bright side, with no birthdays after 2038 we won’t be getting any older.”

这些经过验证的解决方法总是会留下一些悬而未决的问题。例如，当您对重复事件的特定实例进行更改（例如为当天的会议添加注释）时，这些更改是否会传播到该事件的每个未来实例，正如您在使用单主方法时所期望的那样头脑？那么，如果您想向会议事件的单个实例添加注释怎么办？虽然许多成熟的日历程序已经找到了自己的方法来解决这个难题，但每一个新出现的日历程序都必须重新解决这个问题。

These tried-and-true workarounds always left some loose ends dangling. For example, when you made a change to a specific instance of a recurring event, like adding notes for that day’s meeting, would those changes propagate to each future instance of the event, as you would expect if you had the single-master approach in mind? What, then, if you wanted to add notes to a single instance of a meeting event? While many mature calendar programs had found their own ways to settle this conundrum, each new one to come along had to resolve it all over again.

钱德勒独特的设计给组合增添了一些进一步的问题。如果您将定期日历事件标记为任务，会发生什么情况？您是只对那一个实例进行标记还是对未来的所有实例进行标记？如果您以摘要或列表视图而不是日历格式查看事件，您是否会面临无数无限重复项目的单个实例的列表？用户界面存在问题，后端存储库也存在问题。有一些方法可以推迟问题，例如，仅当用户实际选择查看特定时间段时才生成重复事件的特定实例，但它们都存在陷阱。Grant Baillie 指出了一个困难的边缘情况：“如果一个用户（可能是由于拼写错误，或者可能出于对他/她的四十岁生日是一周中的哪一天的好奇）跳转到 2025 年怎么办？将二十年来重复发生的事件放入存储库中？”

Chandler’s unique design added some further problems to the mix. What happened if you stamped a recurring calendar event as a task? Were you stamping just that one instance or all future instances? If you were looking at events in a summary or list view instead of a calendar format, would you face an endless list of individual instances of indefinitely recurring items? There was trouble here for the user interface, and trouble for the repository on the back end. There were ways of postponing the trouble—for instance, generating specific instances of a recurring event only when the user actually chooses to view a particular time period—but they all harbored gotchas. Grant Baillie pointed out one difficult edge case: “What if a user (possibly through a typo or maybe out of idle curiosity as to what day of the week his/her fortieth birthday will be) jumps to the year 2025—are we going to stuff twenty years’ worth of recurring events into the repository?”

2005 年春季和夏季，OSAF 开发人员的 Chandler-dev 邮件列表开始充斥着关于如何实现无限重复事件并限制其无限性质的困难影响的多线程讨论。亚历克·弗莱特在一条消息中写道：“我认为这实际上是我们在钱德勒面临的最困难的问题。”

In spring and summer of 2005, the OSAF developers’ Chandler-dev mailing list began to fill with multiple threads of discussion about how to implement indefinitely recurring events and to limit the difficult implications of their unbounded nature. In one message, Alec Flett wrote, “I think this is actually the hardest problem we’re facing in Chandler.”





事件重复这个看似简单的问题为何如此困难，可以从“重复”一词本身找到线索。这不仅仅是因为软件制作过程中某些问题以如此怪异的规律性重复出现，以至于整个项目都让人感觉（正如米奇·卡普尔和杰伦·拉尼尔在不同时间抱怨的那样）就像电影《土拨鼠之日》中的时间旅行循环一样。递归也是“递归”一词的另一种形式，递归是软件中一切强大且有时难以控制的事物的核心。

A clue to why the deceptively simple-looking matter of event recurrence should prove so difficult can be found in the word recur itself. It’s not just that some problems recur with such eerie regularity in the making of software that the whole undertaking can feel (as both Mitch Kapor and Jaron Lanier had complained at different times) like the time-travel loop in the movie Groundhog Day. It’s that recurrence is also another form of the word “recursion,” and recursion lies at the heart of everything that is powerful and sometimes untamable about software.

重复的事物会重复，但递归的事物以一种特殊的方式重复：它们循环回到自身。它们是吃尾巴的蛇。

Recurring things repeat, but recursive things repeat in a special way: They loop back into themselves. They are tail-eating snakes.

从数学上来说，“递归”描述的是一个调用自身的函数；在计算机科学中，递归是指根据函数本身定义函数。递归逻辑允许简单、紧凑的语句生成复杂且详细的输出。它是许多计算机领域最著名、最鼓舞人心的系统和想法的核心。道格·恩格尔巴特的引导概念是一种加速人类进步的递归技术。Lisp——约翰·麦卡锡在 20 世纪 50 年代末发明的语言，几十年后仍然激励着 OSAF 的许多程序员——是一种伟大的递归机器。Alan Kay 喜欢指出 McCarthy 的“Lisp 1.5 手册第 13 页底部的半页代码”，并称赞它是“计算的麦克斯韦方程组”——集中、优雅的陈述，就像 James 一样，提炼出了该领域的基本原理。克拉克·麦克斯韦的四个方程阐述了机器时代初期电和磁的基本原理。Kay 引用的页面提供了名为“eval”和“apply”的两个函数的定义，McCarthy 本质上描述了 Lisp本身。凯说：“这就是我可以通过几行代码实现的整个编程世界。”

Mathematically speaking, “recursion” describes a function that calls itself; in computer science, recursion refers to defining a function in terms of itself. The logic of recursion allows simple, compact statements to generate complex and elaborate output. It lies at the heart of many of computing’s most celebrated and inspiring systems and ideas. Doug Engelbart’s notion of bootstrapping was a recursive technique for accelerating human progress. Lisp—the language invented in the late 1950s by John McCarthy that, decades later, still inspired many of OSAF’s programmers—is one great recursion machine. Alan Kay likes to point to McCarthy’s “half-page of code at the bottom of page 13 of the Lisp 1.5 manual” and praise it as the “Maxwell’s equations of computing”—concentrated, elegant statements that distilled the field’s fundamental principles just as James Clerk Maxwell’s four equations had laid out the essential workings of electricity and magnetism at the dawn of the machine age. On the page that Kay cited, which provides definitions of two functions named “eval” and “apply,” McCarthy essentially described Lisp in itself. “This,” Kay says, “is the whole world of programming in a few lines that I can put my hand over.”

你可以把手放在上面，但要理解它并不总是那么容易。递归会让人头疼。道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特 (Douglas Hofstadter) 的经典著作《哥德尔、埃舍尔、巴赫》可能是非数学家对这一概念最全面、最平易近人的解释。霍夫施塔特将某些数学领域中发现的神秘的自我参照效应与MC埃舍尔艺术中无限上升的阶梯以及JS巴赫俏皮的卡农和赋格曲联系起来，并给所有这些现象一个令人难忘的标签：奇怪的循环。霍夫施塔特对这一主题进行了近八百页的清晰探索。哥德尔、埃舍尔、巴赫递归地阐述了自己的主题——它奇怪地循环。

You can put your hand over it, but it is not always so easy to get your head around it. Recursion can make the brain ache. Douglas Hofstadter’s classic volume Gödel, Escher, Bach is probably the most comprehensive and approachable explanation of the concept available to nonmathematicians. Hofstadter connects the mysterious self-referential effects found in certain realms of mathematics with the infinitely ascending staircases of M. C. Escher’s art and with J. S. Bach’s playful canons and fugues, and gives all these phenomena a memorable label: strange loops. Hofstadter’s lucid explorations go on for nearly eight hundred pages of variations on the theme; recursively, Gödel, Escher, Bach illustrates its own theme—it loops strangely.

一个人在埃舍尔楼梯上可以永远攀登而永远不会更高。递归在软件中是危险的，因为必须有一个退出。否则，你的奇怪循环就会变成无限循环，而你的计算机——用精确的技术术语来说——就会被控制住。正如一本 Lisp 教科书所说：“任何递归函数如果没有适当的终止条件，都会导致堆栈溢出。。。。终止条件是递归定义中最重要的部分。”

A man on an Escher staircase can climb forever without ever getting any higher. Recursion is dangerous in software because there has to be an exit. Otherwise, your strange loop becomes an infinite loop, and your computer is—to use the precise technical terminology—hosed. As one Lisp textbook put it, “Any recursive function will cause a stack overflow if it does not have a proper termination condition . . . . The termination condition is the most important part of a recursive definition.”

确保每个函数或程序例程都有一个“终止条件”并且不会无休止地循环很重要，但当我们试图这样做时，计算机科学让我们面临一个令人不安的、不容屈服的事实：我们不能。我们可以尝试，但我们不能绝对确定我们已经成功。

Important as it is to make sure that every function or program routine has a “termination condition” and won’t just cycle endlessly, when we try to do so, computer science confronts us with a disturbing, unyielding truth: We can’t. We can try, but we can’t ever be absolutely certain we’ve succeeded.

在 20 世纪 30 年代数字时代的形成时刻，英国数学家艾伦·图灵在定义现代计算基础的基本抽象时，设计了一个令人惊讶的证明：他证明了不存在万能的、涵盖所有领域的计算机。 -检查任何给定程序及其初始输入并确定程序是否“完成”（或达到“终止条件”）的方法。另一种说法是，没有通用算法可以证明任何给定的程序都能完成所有可能的输入。换句话说，您编写的程序无法保证另一个程序最终总是会停止，无论您提供什么数据。

At the formative moment of the digital age in the 1930s, as he was defining the fundamental abstractions that would underlie modern computing, the British mathematician Alan Turing devised a surprising proof: He demonstrated that there is no all-purpose, covers-all-the-cases method of examining any given program and its initial input and being certain that the program ever “completes” (or reaches a “termination condition”). Another way to put it is that there’s no general algorithm which can prove that any given program will complete for all possible inputs. In other words, there’s no program you can write that will assure you that another program will always, eventually, come to a stop no matter what data you give it.

正如 David Harel 在他的《Computers Ltd.》一书中解释的那样， “尝试通过简单地模仿运行程序的模拟算法来解决问题是很诱人的。。。并等着看会发生什么。关键是，如果执行终止，当执行终止时，我们可以合理地停止并得出答案是“是”[程序确实完成]。。。。困难在于不确定何时停止等待并说“不”。我们不能在漫长的等待后简单地放弃，并得出结论说，既然模拟尚未终止，它永远不会终止。” 回答这个问题需要无限的时间；由于我们人类和世界上最快的计算机都没有这种奢侈，所以这个问题是无法确定的。

As David Harel explains in his book Computers Ltd., “It is tempting to try and solve the problem by a simulation algorithm that simply mimics running the program . . . and waits to see what happens. The point is that if and when execution terminates we can justifiably stop and conclude that the answer is ‘Yes’ [the program does complete] . . . . The difficulty is indeciding when to stop waiting and say ‘No.’ We cannot simply give up after a long wait and conclude that since the simulation has not yet terminated it never will.” Answering this question would require infinite time; since neither we human beings nor the fastest computers in the world have that luxury, the question is undecidable.

此后，没有人能够反驳图灵这一违反直觉但逻辑上可证明的理论。这被称为“停机问题”。它位于能够计算和不能计算的外部边界，代表了一系列令人惊讶的抽象问题中的第一个问题，尽管计算机的速度和能力令人难以置信，但它们根本无法解决。

No one has since been able to disprove Turing’s counterintuitive but logically demonstrable theory. It is known as “the halting problem.” Sitting at the outer boundaries separating what can and cannot be computed, it represented the first in what has turned out to be a surprisingly large set of abstract problems that computers, for all their mind-boggling speed and power, simply cannot solve.

像停机问题和其他类似的难以判定的问题困扰着计算机科学家，这些难题从来没有妨碍编写日常软件——我们用来跟踪利润和损失、保留日历或写书的程序。但它们对改进软件的努力有着真实、实际的影响。事实证明，自动程序“验证器”（一个可以检查任何其他程序并确定该程序是否为任何给定输入提供正确输出的程序）的梦想注定只是一个梦想。这个问题是无法判定的。您的程序可能会为许多个别情况提供准确的验证，但您永远无法绝对确定它在任何特定情况下都是正确的。正如哈雷尔所说，这“让我们对软件系统的希望破灭了，该软件系统可以确保我们的计算机做我们希望它们做的事情。” 这样的系统不仅难以想象、难以设计、难以实现，而且还难以实现。就我们今天最好的数学理解而言，这根本上是不可能的。

Conundrums like the halting problem and other similarly undecidable problems that haunt the sleep of computer scientists have never stood in the way of writing everyday software—the programs we use to track profits and losses, keep a calendar, or write books. But they have real, practical consequences for efforts to improve software. It turns out that the dream of an automatic program “verifier”—a program that could examine any other program and determine whether that program provides the correct output for any given input—is doomed to remain a dream. The question is undecidable. Your program might provide accurate verification for many individual cases, but you could never be absolutely certain it was right in any particular case. As Harel puts it, this “dashes our hope for a software system that would make sure that our computers do what we want them to do.” Such a system is not simply difficult to imagine, hard to design, and elusive to implement; it is, to the best of our mathematical understanding today, fundamentally impossible.





停止问题和类似的不可判定问题是形式逻辑和通过符号符号进行需求定义的问题。我们用程序员所谓的自然语言来解释它们，从而失去了精确性，正如我在这里努力做到的那样。但我们也得到了一些东西。它们也是有用的隐喻。

The halting problem and similar undecidables are matters of formal logic and demand definition through symbolic notation. We lose precision by explaining them in what programmers call natural language, as I’ve struggled to do here. But we gain something, too. They are also useful metaphors.

当 OSAF 的开发人员努力解决如何在 Chandler 中实现重复事件时，我发现自己面临着我自己的作者版本的停止问题。我已经关注卡普尔和他的程序员的工作近三年了。当我于 2003 年 1 月第一次出现在 OSAF 时，他们相信 Chandler 的完成——或者至少是可以贴上 1.0 标签的可用产品——还需要一年的时间。当然，我想。我已经在这个街区转了一两次了。当我计划我的书的时间表时，我立即将这个数字增加了一倍。我想我会做两年的研究。然后钱德勒就会完成，或者接近完成，我就会写。

As OSAF’s developers grappled with how to implement recurring events in Chandler, I found myself facing my own author’s version of the halting problem. I had been following the labors of Kapor and his programmers for nearly three years. When I first showed up at OSAF in January 2003, they believed that a finished Chandler—or at least a usable product that could be labeled 1.0—was a year away. Sure, I thought. I’d been around the block once or twice; I immediately doubled that number as I planned my book’s schedule. I would do two years’ research, I figured. Then Chandler would be done, or close to it, and I would write.

但我的怀疑是不够的。钱德勒的日程安排就像一个毛茸茸的狗故事一样漫长。进入第三年，仍然看不到“终止条件”。故事在什么时候会得出一个自然的结论？更糟糕的是，我能确定它会得出结论吗？

But my skepticism was inadequate. The Chandler schedule had stretched out like a shaggy-dog story. Deep into year three there was still no “termination condition” in sight. At what point would the story reach a natural conclusion? Worse, could I ever know for certain that it would reach a conclusion?

在规划我的项目时，我没有考虑到霍夫施塔特定律，即道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特以他的名字命名的递归原理：即使考虑到霍夫施塔特定律，它总是比你预期的时间要长。

In planning my project I had failed to take into account Hofstadter’s Law, the recursive principle to which Douglas Hofstadter attached his name: It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter’s Law.

这种奇怪的循环似乎定义了软件时间的本质。现在我自己也深陷其中。

This strange loop seemed to define the essence of software time. Now I was stuck in it myself.

三年后，钱德勒开始成为一个有点可用但不完整的日历程序。但我无法自信地说该项目需要多长时间才能实现其最初的承诺。OSAF 的管理人员制定了一项计划，其中涉及在大约两年内再进行四次“点发布”，以实现该计划的 1.0 版本，但该计划的形式和范围仍需进一步修订和修正。

After three years, Chandler was beginning to become a somewhat usable, though incomplete, calendar program. But I could not say with any confidence how much longer it would take for the project to deliver something like its original promise. OSAF’s managers had a plan that involved four more “dot releases” over roughly two more years to arrive at a 1.0 version of the program—but the shape and scope of that program remained open to further revision and course correction.

似乎自从我开始拜访OSAF的程序员以来，他们的目标就一直保持在大约两年的距离；随着时间的流逝，目标就像转瞬即逝的地平线一样逐渐消失。他们的工作帮助我找到了我开始使用的软件问题的一些答案。但现在我的故事线索开始消失在软件时间黑洞中。

It seemed that ever since I had started visiting OSAF’s programmers, their target held at a constant distance of roughly two years; as real time passed, the goal receded like a fugitive horizon. Their work had helped me find some answers to the questions about software that I started out with. But now my story’s threads were beginning to vanish into a software time black hole.





与编写软件中的许多问题一样，钱德勒的如何处理重复事件的问题被证明很容易受到有条不紊的划分、征服和押注活动的影响：将问题划分为可管理的部分，征服足够多的部分以使事情正常工作，然后推迟在不确定的未来解决最困难的问题。最终解决了大部分重复问题的开发人员杰弗里·哈里斯 (Jeffrey Harris) 最初是该项目的远程参与者，在邮件列表中发帖并贡献代码补丁。哈里斯曾在密歇根大学学习物理学，然后加入了密苏里州一个名为 Dancing Rabbit Ecovillage 的“有意社区”，在那里他建造房屋、唱歌并经营一家软件咨询公司。

Like so many problems in writing software, the question of how to handle recurring events in Chandler proved susceptible to a methodical campaign of divide, conquer, and punt: Divide the problem into manageable parts, conquer enough of them to make things work okay, and postpone tackling the most difficult pieces for the indeterminate future. The developer who ended up tackling most of the recurrence problems, Jeffrey Harris, had started out as a long-distance participant in the project, posting to the mailing lists and contributing code patches. Harris had studied physics at the University of Michigan, then joined an “intentional community” in Missouri called Dancing Rabbit Ecovillage, where he built houses, sang, and ran a software consulting business.

2005 年夏天，他搬到旧金山全职加入 OSAF，成为越来越多首次远程或作为志愿者参与该项目的 OSAF 员工之一。Mike “Codebear” Taylor 住在费城，几年来一直在为 Chandler 提供评论和想法，当时 OSAF 要求他接手管理其构建的棘手工作——照管源代码树、监督每个里程碑版本的机制、确保当 Tinderbox 图表变红且构建出现故障时，能够快速修复。

In summer 2005, he moved to San Francisco to join OSAF full-time, becoming one of a growing number of OSAF employees who had first hooked up with the project from a distance or as volunteers. Mike “Codebear” Taylor lived in Philadelphia and had been contributing comments and ideas on Chandler for a couple of years when OSAF asked him to take over the tricky job of managing its builds—tending the source tree, overseeing the mechanics of each milestone release, and making sure that when the Tinderbox charts turned red and the build broke, it got fixed fast.

这样一个核心运营角色可以由非洲大陆另一端的总部以外的人来担任，这表明 OSAF 已经朝着“真正的”开源项目的方向迈进了一步。2005年，OSAF的开发人员还将更多的技术辩论从会议室和私人电子邮件交流中转移到了项目的公共邮件列表上，以便志愿者和外部人员可以在更平等的基础上参与。

That such a central operational role could be filled by someone on the other side of the continent from the main office was one sign that OSAF had moved a little further in the direction of behaving like a “real” open source project. In 2005, OSAF’s developers also moved more of their technical debates out of the meeting rooms and private email exchanges and onto the project’s public mailing lists so that volunteers and outsiders could participate on a more equal footing.

但写了三年开源代码和建立一个开源社区并不是一回事。随着 Chandler 0.6 接近完成，Ted Leung 向 Mitch Kapor 发送了一份报告，评估 OSAF 在开源工作中的成功和失败。他发现，迄今为止 Bugzilla 记录的错误总数约为 4,400 个，其中约 100 个是由 OSAF 以外的人员提交的。而且只有少数来自外部的实际代码贡献。Kapor 和他的团队为成功的开源项目建立了一些必要的先决条件，例如在开源许可证下发布他们的代码以及在网络上公开他们的研究和审议。如果不是透明的话，它们就什么都不是。但是，梁写道，“旨在提供可见性的透明度和旨在产生合作的透明度是有区别的。”

But writing open source code for three years was not the same thing as building an open source community. As Chandler 0.6 neared completion, Ted Leung sent Mitch Kapor a report assessing OSAF’s successes and failures in its open source efforts. He found that of approximately 4,400 total bugs logged in Bugzilla to date, around 100 had been filed by people outside OSAF. And there had been only a handful of actual code contributions from outsiders. Kapor and his team had established some of the necessary preconditions for a successful open source project, like publishing their code under an open source license and making their research and deliberations public on the Net. They were nothing if not transparent. But, Leung wrote, “there’s a difference between transparency aimed at giving visibility and transparency that is aimed at producing collaboration.”

要实现后者，OSAF 还有很长的路要走。钱德勒集市仍然缺乏帐篷。开源并没有阻止钱德勒像无数其他雄心勃勃的软件项目一样陷入同样痛苦的时间扭曲中。也许埃里克·雷蒙德的《大教堂与集市》是错误的，而莱纳斯定律（“只要有足够的眼球，所有的虫子都是浅薄的”）终究没有超越布鲁克斯定律。或者，也许 OSAF 尽管其透明度很高，但迄今为止未能满足雷蒙德对集市式开源项目取得成功的要求——它必须承认、接受和奖励来自外部的好想法。

OSAF still had a long way to go to achieve the latter. The Chandler bazaar still lacked tents. And being open source hadn’t prevented Chandler from ending up in the same agonizing time warp as countless other ambitious software projects. Maybe Eric Raymond’s “The Cathedral and the Bazaar” had been wrong, and Linus’s Law (“‘Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow”) didn’t transcend Brooks’s Law after all. Or perhaps OSAF, for all its transparency, had so far failed to meet Raymond’s requirement for success with a bazaar-style open source project—that it must recognize, embrace, and reward good ideas from outsiders.

自由软件之父理查德·斯托曼 (Richard Stallman) 喜欢说，“当人们问我什么时候能完成某件事时，我会回答，‘如果你帮忙的话，它会更快准备好。’”OSAF 欢迎志愿者和外部贡献，但钱德勒的宏伟设计雄心勃勃的目标和缓慢的交付速度使得外来者很难介入。

Richard Stallman, the godfather of free software, liked to say, “When people ask me when something will be finished, I respond, ‘It will be ready sooner if you help.’” OSAF welcomed volunteers and external contributions, but Chandler’s grand design ambitions and sluggish pace of delivery had made it hard for outsiders to pitch in.

雷蒙德在《大教堂与集市》中写道：

In “The Cathedral and the Bazaar,” Raymond wrote,



很明显，人们无法以集市风格从头开始编写代码。可以用集市的方式进行测试、调试和改进，但是用集市的方式来发起一个项目是非常困难的。。。。您的新生开发者社区需要有一些可运行和可测试的东西来使用。当您开始社区建设时，您需要能够提出一个看似合理的承诺。您的程序不必运行得特别好。它可能是粗糙的、有缺陷的、不完整的和缺乏文档记录的。它必须做的是让潜在的合作开发者相信，在可预见的未来，它可以演变成真正简洁的东西。

It’s fairly clear that one cannot code from the ground up in bazaar style. One can test, debug and improve in bazaar style, but it would be very hard to originate a project in bazaar mode . . . . Your nascent developer community needs to have something runnable and testable to play with. When you start community-building, what you need to be able to present is a plausible promise. Your program doesn’t have to work particularly well. It can be crude, buggy, incomplete, and poorly documented. What it must not fail to do is convince potential co-developers that it can be evolved into something really neat in the foreseeable future.







当我与 OSAF 外部的人谈论 Chandler 时，最常见的批评是这样的：Kapor 从一开始就没有在浏览器中构建 Chandler，因此错过了机会。这将节省为三种不同操作系统构建跨平台软件的所有额外工作，以及构建复杂的基于 wxWidgets 的图形界面的所有工作。Web 浏览器会为您处理所有这些事情。它已经在多个平台上运行并提供现成的用户界面。现在，人们在 2005 年就说过，基于 Web 的软件显然是未来。Gmail 风格的 AJAX 技巧很热门。火狐浏览器很热门。浏览器就是该去的地方。

As I talked to people outside OSAF about Chandler, the most common criticism ran something like this: Kapor had missed the boat by not building Chandler inside the browser from the start. That would have saved all the extra work of building cross-platform software for three different operating systems, and also all the labor of building the complex wxWidgets-based graphic interface. The Web browser takes care of all that for you. It already runs on multiple platforms and provides a ready-made user interface. Now, people were saying in 2005, it was obvious that Web-based software was the future. The Gmail-style AJAX tricks were hot. Firefox was hot. The browser was the place to be.

卡普尔对这种批评持坚忍态度。首先，他会指出，2002 年钱德勒的基因结构首次确定时，世界看起来已经不同了。此外，如果您无法在线工作，基于网络的软件对您没有任何好处（尽管至少在美国，宽带和无线连接的广泛使用意味着对于许多人来说，他们可能花费的唯一地方长时间离线是在飞机内部）。最后，基于 Web 的 AJAX 风格的方法虽然令人兴奋，但尚未证明自己是 Chandler 所追求的那种新颖、灵活的设计的载体。

Kapor was stoic about this line of criticism. First of all, he would point out, the world had looked different in 2002 when Chandler’s genetic structure was first set. Furthermore, Web-based software did you no good if you weren’t able to work online (though in the United States, at least, the wide availability of broadband and wireless connections meant that for many people the only place they were likely to spend extended time offline was the interior of an airplane). Finally, the Web-based AJAX-style approach, exciting as it was, hadn’t yet proved itself as a vehicle for the kind of novel, flexible design Chandler aimed for.

尽管如此，卡普尔在他的博客上承认，他开始以不同的方式看待事物。即使是这位自称为“老应用程序专家”的人现在也即将接受这样的事实：网络交付的、基于浏览器的软件已经开始取代个人计算黄金时代的基于桌面的程序。他宣称，从现在开始，他很可能从一开始就为任何新项目采用 Web 界面。

Still, Kapor admitted on his blog that he was beginning to see things differently. Even this self-described “old applications guy” was now on the verge of accepting that Web-delivered, browser-based software had begun to overtake the desktop-based programs of personal computing’s golden age. From now on, he declared, he would most likely adopt a Web interface for any new project from the start.

2005 年夏天，随着 Chandler 0.6 和 Cosmo 服务器早期版本的工作取得进展，OSAF 开始了第三个小项目：一个基于 Web 的界面或客户端，供用户访问他们可能存储在 Cosmo 上的任何日历服务器。这个想法不仅为 Chandler 用户提供服务，还为其他日历程序的用户提供服务，包括 Macintosh 的 iCal 和支持新 CalDAV 标准的任何其他日历软件。

In the summer of 2005, as work on Chandler 0.6 and the early versions of the Cosmo server progressed, OSAF began a third small project: a Web-based interface, or client, for users to access any calendars they might have stored on a Cosmo server. The idea was to serve not only Chandler users but users of other calendar programs—including the Macintosh’s iCal and any other calendar software that supported the new CalDAV standard.

卡普尔经常说，OSAF 应该专注于制定一份好的日历的原因之一是人们确实需要一个日历。根据 2005 年期间出现的提供一种或另一种日历服务的小型初创公司和软件项目的数量，他是对的。但是，出现的新日历越多，如果这些多个日历彼此不兼容，用户和程序员将面临的混乱就越多。Infoworld专栏作家 Jon Udell写道，这已经是一场“火车失事” 。软件作家斯科特·梅斯（Scott Mace）开设了一个博客来跟踪这个问题；他将其命名为“日历沼泽”。

Kapor often said that one reason OSAF ought to focus on building a good calendar was that people really needed one. Based on the number of small start-up companies and software projects that emerged during 2005 to offer one or another kind of calendar service, he was right. But the more new calendars that emerged, the more of a mess users and programmers would face if these multiple calendars weren’t compatible with one another. It was already a “train wreck,” wrote Infoworld columnist Jon Udell. Software writer Scott Mace started a blog tracking the problem; he titled it Calendar Swamp.

OSAF 的开发人员希望他们的 CalDAV 标准能够将世界上松散的日历联系在一起并帮助排干沼泽。Lisa Dusseault 和 Brian Moseley 开始寻找另外两到三名开发人员来构建新的基于 Web 的客户端。为了与 OSAF 以狗为基础的产品命名方案保持一致，他们将其命名为 Scooby。

OSAF’s developers hoped that their CalDAV standard could tie together the loose calendars of the world and help drain the swamp. Lisa Dusseault and Brian Moseley began hunting for two or three more developers to build the new Web-based client. In keeping with OSAF’s dog-based product-naming scheme, they named it Scooby.





Chandler 0.6 的最初发布日期是 2005 年 9 月。到了夏末，bug 之山看起来仍然势不可挡，经理们同意将最后期限推迟到 11 月底。这次他们决心生产狗粮。他们将发布一个可以以某种临时方式实际使用的程序。他们知道，这将为他们改变世界：他们不会猜测下一步该做什么，而是会听到来自真实用户的评论和抱怨。这些真实用户是远在半个地球的另一端，还是坐在他们旁边的会议室，这并不重要；重要的是获得一些实际反馈。

The original release date for Chandler 0.6 was September 2005. By late summer the mountain of bugs still looked overwhelming, and the managers agreed to let the deadline slip to the end of November. This time they were determined to produce dogfood. They would release a program that could in some provisional way actually be used. And that, they knew, would change the world for them: Instead of guessing what to do next, they would hear comments and complaints from real users. It didn’t matter whether those real users were halfway around the world or sitting in the conference room next to them; the important thing was to get some hands-on feedback.

但随着 0.6 从一个里程碑走向另一个里程碑，意想不到的事情发生了。OSAF 的人们很早就开始对钱德勒进行测试。有件事提前发生了。这一次，软件时间运行得比实时时间还要快。

But something unexpected happened as 0.6 moved from milestone to milestone. People at OSAF started dogfooding Chandler early. Something was happening ahead of schedule. For once, software time had run faster than real time.

2005 年 9 月 23 日，Philippe Bossut 开始使用 Chandler 作为他的个人日历。他几乎立即开始发现新的错误，尤其是重复发生的事件。他在博客中讲述了他的经历：“我遇到了几个崩溃程序，我在日常使用中仔细地浏览过它们。我避免任何过于冒险的重复事件（例如在集合之间共享或移动......）。但尽管存在这些错误，好消息是：Chandler 正在迅速变得可用；我在 iCal 所做的一切都是我在 Chandler 做不到的。”

On September 23, 2005, Philippe Bossut began using Chandler as his personal calendar. Almost immediately he started finding new bugs, particularly with recurring events. He blogged about his experience: “I ran through a couple of crashers that I carefully walk around in my daily usage. I’m avoiding anything too adventurous with recurring events (like sharing or moving between collections . . . ). But despite the bugs, the great news is: Chandler is rapidly becoming usable; there’s nothing I was doing with iCal I found myself not being able to do in Chandler.”

不久之后，希拉·穆尼也开始对钱德勒进行测试。她的丈夫找到了一份新工作，即将搬到温哥华，她计划每月在那里工作一周。异地恋会给她一些测试日历共享功能的好机会。

Soon after, Sheila Mooney started dogfooding Chandler, too. Her husband had taken a new job and was about to move to Vancouver, where she planned to work for one week each month. The long-distance relationship would give her some good opportunities for testing the calendar’s sharing features.

到 10 月底，卡普尔本人正处于测试的边缘——将他现有的 iCal 活动导入钱德勒，并将其用作他的每日日历。有件事阻碍了这一点：钱德勒的重复事件功能允许您每天、每周或每月重复事件。但卡普尔的日历上有几项需要每两周重复一次。

By the end of October, Kapor himself was on the verge of dogfooding—importing his existing iCal events into Chandler and using it as his day-today calendar. One thing stood in the way: Chandler’s recurring events feature allowed you to repeat events daily, weekly, or monthly. But Kapor had several items on his calendar that needed to recur biweekly.

在 0.6 开发周期的此时，该版本被认为是“功能完整”；你不应该添加新功能，而应该专注于修复最高优先级的错误。但开发人员在网络下添加了一点额外的内容：Chandler 0.6 将允许您创建每两周一次的重复事件。

By this point in the 0.6 development cycle, the release was considered “feature-complete”; you weren’t supposed to add new features, just concentrate on fixing the highest-priority bugs. But the developers slipped in one little extra under the wire: Chandler 0.6 would allow you to create biweekly recurring events.





停机问题不仅仅是一个理论上的谜。每个软件项目的参与者在开始寻找工作终点时都会遇到现实世界的版本。每个团队都重新吸取了同样的惨痛教训：没有万无一失的程序可以判断项目何时完成以及是否实现了目标。

The halting problem is not just a theoretical enigma. The participants in every software project run smack into a real-world version of it as they begin to search for an end point to their work. And each team relearns the same painful lesson: There is no foolproof procedure for telling when a project is done and whether it has achieved its goals.

1999 年，Alan Cooper（一位在 90 年代初创建了大部分 Visual Basic 编程语言的软件开发人员，现在是一位著名的软件设计倡导者）出版了一本激烈的书，名为《The Inmates Are Running the Asylum》，其中提供了该软件的犯罪记录工业罪孽。库珀在文中写道，“软件开发缺乏一个关键要素——对‘完成’意味着什么的理解。”

In 1999, Alan Cooper—a software developer who created much of the Visual Basic programming language in the early nineties and is now a prominent software design advocate—published a fierce book titled The Inmates Are Running the Asylum that provides a rap sheet of the software industry’s sins. In it Cooper wrote, “Software development lacks one key element—an understanding of what it means to be ‘Done.’”

这个停止问题对软件开发进度产生了实际影响——钱德勒的开发人员三年来一直在努力解决这个问题。当软件出现在一家对投资者负责的初创公司的严酷考验中时，现金账户的减少和现金供应商的需求通常会强制执行项目的“终止条件”。或者，纯开源项目的进展速度取决于志愿者精力的增减。用 Linus Torvalds 的话来说，“因为该软件是免费的，所以在真正准备好实现某些销售目标之前，不存在发布它的压力。Linux 的每个版本只有在真正完成时才被宣布完成，这解释了为什么它如此坚固。” 钱德勒处于这些方法之间不同寻常的中间点，没有明确的路标来标记“完成”的时刻，甚至没有指示完成可能所在的方向。

This halting problem has practical consequences for software development schedules—consequences that Chandler’s developers had struggled with for three years. When software arises in the crucible of a start-up company responsible to investors, dwindling cash accounts and the demands of the cash’s suppliers typically enforce a project’s “termination condition.” Alternately, pure open source projects simply move at a pace governed by the waxing and waning of volunteers’ energy. In Linus Torvalds’s words, “Because the software is free, there is no pressure to release it before it is really ready just to achieve some sales target. Every version of Linux is declared to be finished only when it is actually finished, which explains why it is so solid.” Chandler sat at an unusual midpoint between these approaches, leaving it without clear signposts to mark the moment of “done” or even to indicate the direction in which completion might lie.

但软件开发的停滞问题还有另一个后果，一个不那么务实的后果，而是一个存在主义后果。“把事情做好”大师戴维·艾伦 (David Allen)谈到了知识工作者在面临大量开放式任务时所遭受的“令人痛苦的焦虑感”。软件开发人员总是有更多的事情要做；“完成”的定义，即使对于临时版本或小里程碑来说，也总是有些武断。在这一点上，他们的作品更像是作者的作品，而不是建设者的作品。“完成”对于观察者来说并不是显而易见的事情。“完成”是你必须自己决定的事情。

But there is another consequence of software development’s halting problem, one that is less pragmatic than existential. David Allen, the Getting Things Done guru, talked about the “gnawing sense of anxiety” suffered by knowledge workers who face mountains of open-ended tasks. Software developers always have more to do; the definition of “done,” even for an interim release or small milestone, is always somewhat arbitrary. In this their work is more like an author’s than a builder’s. “Done” isn’t something that is obvious to an observer. “Done” is something you must decide for yourself.

钱德勒显然还没有完成，甚至还没有完成。尽管如此，当人们用它来安排自己的日子时，它以前所未有的方式真实而活跃。它的开发者已经达到了一个心理里程碑；他们至少可以将大部分“痛苦的焦虑感”抛在脑后。

Chandler, obviously, was not done, not even remotely. Still, with people using it to schedule their days, it was real and alive in a way it had never been before. Its developers had reached a psychological milestone; they could put at least a chunk of that “gnawing sense of anxiety” behind them.





当软件以某种方式完成时，它可以具有惊人的寿命。尽管构建一个好的程序可能需要很长时间，但一个好的程序有时会持续很长时间。这是软件时间的另一个维度。用 Cobol（20 世纪 60 年代占主导地位的主流商业编程语言）编写的程序在 90 年代末仍在广泛使用。为了节省内存中曾经稀缺的空间，他们中的许多人只允许年份字段使用两位数字。随着 2000 年“千年虫”的临近，它们必须被修复或退役。

When software is, one way or another, done, it can have astonishing longevity. Though it may take forever to build a good program, a good program will sometimes last almost as long; this is yet another dimension of software time. Programs written in Cobol, the mainstream business programming language dominant in the 1960s, were still in wide use in the late 1990s. To conserve once-scarce space in memory, many of them had allowed only two digits for the year field. As 2000—Y2K—loomed, they had to be fixed or decommissioned.

最近的软件历史提供了许多程序的例子，这些程序在困难时期后蓬勃发展，或者在被遗忘后恢复生机。在技​​术方面，米奇·卡普尔 (Mitch Kapor) 在 Lotus 之后创立的公司只生产了卡普尔希望的软件的一小部分，但其 MeetingMaker 群组调度程序已广泛使用了二十年。接下来，史蒂夫·乔布斯 (Steve Jobs) 1985 年被苹果公司驱逐后创办的这家雄心勃勃的公司未能改变世界，甚至未能获得企业或消费者的广泛采用。但 Next 系统仍然是当今 Macintosh OSX 操作系统的基础。

More recent software history provides a wealth of examples of programs that flourished after hard times or returned to life after consignment to oblivion. On Technology, the company Mitch Kapor founded after Lotus, produced only a fraction of the software that Kapor had hoped it would, but its MeetingMaker group scheduling program has remained in wide use for two decades. Next, the ambitious company that Steve Jobs started after he was ousted from Apple in 1985, failed to change the world or even achieve any significant adoption by businesses or consumers. But the Next system lives on as the foundation for today’s Macintosh OSX operating system.

还记得我在 Salon 的同事于 2000 年构建的那个小型内容管理系统吗？它的灾难性部署一直困扰着我，并促使我开始对这本书进行探究？它变成了一个名为 Bricolage 的开源项目，并已被世界卫生组织、兰德公司和霍华德迪恩总统竞选团队使用。

Remember that little content management system my colleagues at Salon built in 2000, the one whose disastrous deployment haunted me and launched me on this book’s inquiry? It turned into an open source project named Bricolage and has been used by the World Health Organization, the RAND Corporation, and the Howard Dean presidential campaign.

您正在阅读的这本书的所有研究都是在一个名为 Ecco Pro 的旧 Windows 程序中组织、编译、概述、交叉引用和不断调整的，该程序于 1993 年首次发布。1997 年，Ecco 被其“孤儿”抛弃。业主，他们觉得自己无法与 Microsoft Outlook 竞争（尽管它使 Outlook 严格的 PIM 设计看起来像——哦，没关系！），而且 ECCO 代码近十年来一直没有被触及。但它在我的 Windows 计算机上运行得很好，而且在我使用它的这些年里，它从未丢失过我委托给它的任何数据。它不是跨平台的、开源的或基于网络的。但它仍然比我发现的任何其他程序更好地完成某些类型的大纲和灵活的组织（钱德勒承诺但尚未实现的那种事情）。在我在 OSAF 认识的程序员中，我很高兴找到了几位 ECCO 爱好者。

And all the research for the book you’re reading was organized, compiled, outlined, cross-referenced, and endlessly tweaked in an old Windows program called Ecco Pro that was first released in 1993. In 1997, Ecco was “orphaned” by its owners, who felt they couldn’t compete with Microsoft Outlook (though it makes Outlook’s rigid PIM design look like a—Oh, never mind!), and the Ecco code has not been touched in nearly a decade. But it runs beautifully on my Windows computer, and it has never lost a single piece of data I have entrusted to it in all the years I’ve used it. It is not cross-platform or open source or Web-based. But it still does certain kinds of outlining and flexible organizing (the kind of thing Chandler promises but hasn’t yet delivered) better than any other program I’ve found. Among the programmers I got to know at OSAF, I was happy to find several fellow Ecco enthusiasts.

旧代码很少提供流行的图形或本月流行的功能，但它有一个相当大的优势：它往往有效。一个被充分使用的程序就像一个被精心照料的古老花园或一把被很好地弹奏过的老式吉他：它的粗糙边缘已被锉掉，它的错误已被发现并修复，它的性能是众所周知的和良好的。有价值的数量。

Old code rarely offers trendy graphics or flavor-of-the-month features, but it has one considerable advantage: It tends to work. A program that has been well used is like an old garden that has been well tended or a vintage guitar that has been well played: Its rough edges have been filed away, its bugs have been found and fixed, and its performance is a known and valuable quantity.





正如我在 2006 年年中所写的那样，钱德勒的未来生活——数百万用户？脚注？——无法预测。我们所能打赌的是，它的故事很可能会继续发生不可预测的转折。最终到达与你预期去的地方完全不同的地方是这个世界的常态。软件项目是意外后果法则的主要例证，它们的创新和突破往往是副作用，而不是计划的结果。

As I write in mid-2006, Chandler’s future life—millions of users? a footnote?—is impossible to forecast. All we can bet on is that its story is likely to continue to take unpredictable turns. Ending up somewhere entirely different from where you expected to go is the norm in this world. Software projects are prime illustrations of the law of unintended consequences, and their innovations and breakthroughs are more often side effects than planned outcomes.

例如，沃德·坎宁安 (Ward Cunningham) 的 wiki 的出现并不是因为程序员打算构建任何人都可以添加的网页，而是因为他希望他的合作者能够修复自己的错误。1999 年，年轻的开发人员创办了一家名为 Pyra 的小公司，旨在开发一款协作项目管理工具；他们还构建了一个小程序来编写网络日记并与用户进行交流。这个小项目后来发展成为 Blogger，世界上最大的博客服务，拥有数百万用户（谷歌于 2003 年收购了它）。Ludicorp 是一家软件公司，为“大型多人在线角色扮演游戏”开发了系统原型；这个名为“Game Neverending”的项目很快就结束了，但它的创建者改进了其中的一些部分，并建立了 Flickr 照片共享服务，该服务于 2004 年成为网络的热门（并于 2005 年被雅虎收购）。

Ward Cunningham’s wiki, for example, came about not because the programmer set out to build Web pages that anyone could add to but because he wanted his collaborators to be able to fix their own mistakes. The young developers who started a small company named Pyra in 1999 aimed to produce a collaborative project management tool; they also built a small program to write a Web journal and communicate with their users. That little side project became Blogger, the largest blogging service in the world, with millions of users (Google acquired it in 2003). Ludicorp was a software company that prototyped a system for a “massive multiplayer online role-playing game”; the project, called the Game Neverending, ended pretty quickly, but its creators revamped some of its parts and built the Flickr photo-sharing service, which became the toast of the Web in 2004 (and was acquired by Yahoo! in 2005).

就这一点而言，看看 1991 年欧洲粒子物理实验室的一名程序员为简化互联网上的研究共享所做的一点努力，谁能预见到它会演变成今天的万维网呢？

For that matter, who could see, looking at a little effort by a programmer at a European particle-physics lab to ease the sharing of research on the Internet in 1991, that it would evolve into today’s World Wide Web?

一些观察家已经认为钱德勒造成了一个重大的意想不到的后果。根据这种观点，钱德勒是否成为一个有用的程序或实现其最初的目标都没有什么区别；重要的是，在建立他的开源组织的过程中，Kapor 认识了 Mozilla 的 Mitchell Baker，当 AOL/Netscape 决定停止支持开源浏览器时，他在正确的时间出现在正确的地点，帮助拯救它，助产士Mozilla 基金会的诞生，使 Firefox 走上了成功的轨道。在我撰写本文时，Firefox 突然崛起，赢得了超过 10% 的浏览器市场份额（本书付印时下载量已超过 2.12 亿次）。它的竞争迫使微软重新审视其长期闲置的 Internet Explorer 产品，并重新投入浏览器开发业务，为世界各地的网络用户带来回报。

Some observers already credit Chandler with one major unintended consequence. According to this view, it makes little difference whether Chandler ever becomes a useful program or achieves any of its original goals; what matters is that in building his open source organization, Kapor got to know Mozilla’s Mitchell Baker, and when AOL/Netscape decided to stop supporting the open source browser, he was in the right place at the right time to help rescue it, midwife the birth of the Mozilla Foundation, and set Firefox on its successful trajectory. As I write, Firefox has come from nowhere to win more than 10 percent of the browser market (more than 212 million downloads as this book goes to press). Its competition has forced Microsoft to revisit its long-fallow Internet Explorer product and get back into the business of browser development, with a payoff for Web users everywhere.

当钱德勒开始时，这不是卡普尔或其他任何人都可以预见的一章。这样的章节肯定还会有更多。

When Chandler started out, this was not a chapter Kapor or anyone else could have foreseen. There will certainly be more such chapters.





当 Chandler 的开发人员准备在 2005 年 11 月发布 Chandler 0.6 并开始认真地进行“测试”时，他们已经庆祝了四次出生和三次婚姻。他们迎来了数十位新同事，也向几乎同样多的新同事告别。他们已经编写了数万行代码。他们记录了数千个错误并修复了其中相当一部分。他们还面临着一个自从他们第一次梦想他们的项目以来已经发生了根本变化的软件市场。

As Chandler’s developers prepared to release Chandler 0.6 in November 2005 and to begin its “dogfooding” in earnest, they had already celebrated four births and three marriages. They had welcomed dozens of new colleagues and said good-bye to nearly as many. They had written tens of thousands of lines of code. They had logged thousands of bugs and fixed a fair portion of them. They also faced a software market that had changed radically since they first dreamed up their project.

微软的新版本 Windows 开始缓慢下滑，受到进一步延迟的困扰，其计划发布日期被推迟到 2007 年初。它已经放弃了 Longhorn 代号，现在被称为 Vista——具有讽刺意味的是，与 Andy 的名字相同赫茨菲尔德选择了钱德勒的早期原型。Windows Vista 曾经承诺像钱德勒一样改进计算机用户与其个人信息的关系；现在，尽管微软花了五年时间才创建它，但它似乎只是一次温和得多的升级。但是，当微软犹豫不决、钱德勒努力寻找立足点时，基于网络的软件生态系统已经爆炸：2005年，数十家小型新企业开始竞相为互联网用户提供新的个人信息管理服务，其中包括六家网络软件公司。仅基于日历服务。

Microsoft’s new version of Windows was beginning to lumber down the pike, plagued by further delays that pushed its planned release date back to early 2007. It had dropped the Longhorn code name and was now to be known as Vista—ironically, the same name Andy Hertzfeld had chosen for Chandler’s early prototype. Windows Vista had once promised a Chandler-like revamping of computer users’ relationship with their personal information; now, despite the half decade it took Microsoft to create it, it seemed likely to be a much more modest upgrade. But while Microsoft had dallied and Chandler had struggled to find its footing, the Web-based software ecosystem had exploded: In 2005, dozens of small new ventures began competing to offer Internet users new personal information management services—including a half-dozen Web-based calendar services alone.

我在 0.6 发布周期接近尾声时与 Kapor 进行了交谈，想知道他是否认为这种情况令人沮丧。钱德勒真的能脱颖而出吗？当然，他回答道：0.6 已经拥有一些潜在的“杀手级功能”。最重要的是读/写共享：让人们能够发布日历，以便其他人可以阅读和 编辑它。钱德勒处理数据的方法为共享增加了一些有趣的问题：例如，在两个忙碌的配偶共享彼此日历的情况下，就像卡普尔开始与他的妻子做的那样，如果你把日历上的一个项目添加到你配偶的日历中，然后稍后更改日历上的该项目，更改将传播并在两个日历上保持同步。“没有人这样做！” 卡普尔惊呼道。

I talked with Kapor near the end of the 0.6 release cycle and wondered whether he found this landscape disheartening. Could Chandler really set itself apart? Absolutely, he replied: 0.6 already had a handful of potential “killer features.” The most important was simply read/write sharing: giving people the ability to publish a calendar so that other people could read and edit it. Chandler’s approach to data added some intriguing wrinkles to sharing: In the case of, say, two busy spouses sharing each other’s calendars, as Kapor was beginning to do with his wife, if you took an item on your calendar and added it to your spouse’s, then later changed that item on your calendar, the changes would propagate over and stay in sync on both calendars. “Nobody does that!” Kapor exclaimed.

他是对的。正如他所说，这“实际上非常酷”。但这距离钱德勒早年改变世界的雄心还有很长的路要走，卡普尔承认感到“谦卑”。

He was right. This was, as he put it, “actually very cool.” But it was still a long way away from the world-changing ambition of Chandler’s early days, and Kapor admitted to feeling “humbled.”

我问他，如果他能穿越回到项目的开始，他会给自己什么建议。“这是一个二十人的项目，”他回答道。“这不是一个一个、两个或三个人的项目，也不是三百人的项目。雄心壮志需要一个中等规模的团队，而当你拥有一个中等规模的团队时，就会带来后果。有很多协调性。我们仍在学习，而且我们将继续学习。你如何执行？你如何设定目标？因为我以前没有做过这种雄心勃勃、需要亲自动手的二十人项目，所以有很多事情让我感到惊讶，并且继续感到惊讶。

I asked him what advice he would give himself if he could time-travel back to the start of the project. “It’s a twenty-person project,” he replied. “It’s not a one- or two- or three-person project, and it’s not three hundred people. The ambition requires a medium-size team, and when you have a medium-size team, that comes with consequences. There’s a lot of coordination. We’re still learning, and we’re going to continue to learn. How do you execute? How do you set goals? Because I had not done this kind of hands-on twenty-person project with this scope of ambition before, there are so many things that have been surprising and continue to be a surprise.

“我们一直在基础设施和设计方面过度投资，但其成果不会在下一个甚至两个开发周期内实现——也就是说，不会在接下来的六个月或十二个月内实现。你为此付出的代价就是失去敏捷性。我给出的建议是，我们要继续做更多我们过去几年所做的事情，即对创新进行排序，分阶段进行，并且不要那么雄心勃勃。不要建设 CPIA 等基础设施，除非您需要实现明年的目标。我越来越觉得这里的艺术是在不失去长期愿景的情况下进行敏捷开发——而且，坦率地说，我什至一开始就没有定义问题。”

“We’ve consistently overinvested in infrastructure and design, the fruits of which won’t be realized in the next development cycle or even two—that is, not in the next six or twelve months. You pay a price for that in a loss of agility. The advice I would give is to do even more of what we’ve been doing in the last couple of years, which is to sequence the innovation, stage things, and be less ambitious. Do not build out infrastructure, like CPIA, except insofar as you need to meet the goals of the next year. I’m more and more feeling like the art here is to do agile development without losing the long-term vision—and, frankly, I didn’t even define the problem as that to start with.”

面对所有令人沮丧的延误，他有没有考虑过让钱德勒停止工作？“不。有时我感到非常沮丧。但我在生活中（不仅仅是在这里）学到了，如果我有非常强烈的绝望感，我应该和他们坐在一起。我应该避免采取行动——因为这些感觉往往是短暂的；它们往往是由环境触发的。相反，就个人而言，抽出一些时间，无论是一个小时、几个小时还是一两天。这就是重新获得观点的过程的持续时间。每次我回来都会说，我相信我们可以通过调整我们的做法来找到实现长期愿景的方法。”

With all the dispiriting delays, had he ever considered shutting Chandler down? “No. There were times when I felt horribly depressed. But I’ve learned in my life, not just here, that if I have very powerful feelings of hopelessness, I should sit with them. I should refrain from taking action—because those feelings tend to be transient; they tend to be triggered by circumstances. Instead, just personally, take some time out, whether it’s an hour or a few hours or a day or two. And that’s as long as it’s ever been with this process to regain perspective. And every time I’ve come back, saying I believe we can find a way to accomplish the long-term vision by adapting how we go about doing it.”

我说，OSAF 似乎终于接受了其发布周期长达六个月的事实；在该项目的早期，他们一直致力于缩短工期。

OSAF, I said, finally seemed to accept that its release cycle was six months long; earlier in the project they had kept aiming for much shorter deadlines.

“还有更多的愿望——很多的愿望，”他若有所思地说。“我认为不切实际是没有帮助的。如果你能找到一种有效的方法来处理现实情况，而又不会变得士气低落或分裂，那么经历融入现实的痛苦总比不经历好。所以我们只是继续这样做，而且我们还没有完成。开发软件仍然很困难。二十年后，这并不比我刚开始时容易多少。你可以做得更多，但你有基本相似的协调问题。这就是我们现在生活的宇宙，所以我们必须做出适当的调整——把食物切成小块，小口咀嚼。并消化。继续前进。

“There was more wishfulness—a lot of wishfulness,” he said wistfully. “I think it just doesn’t help to be unrealistic. If you can find an effective way to deal with the real circumstances without becoming demoralized or breaking apart, it’s better to go through the pain of incorporating reality than not. So we’ve just continued doing it, and we are not done with it. Developing software is still hard. It’s not all that much easier twenty years later than when I first started. You can do more, but you have fundamentally similar problems of coordination. That’s the universe we’re living in now, so we have to make appropriate adjustments—cut our food into smaller pieces and chew it in smaller bites. And digest. And move on.

“我确实认为，”他补充道，“无论是在组织上还是个人方面，我们都学到了大量关于如何开发软件的知识。我们有点重新发明了轮子。这些是其他人知道的事情，所以我们花了更长的时间来学习这些事情。但在学习了它们之后，这就是一种智力资本，我绝对坚定地要重新应用它并坚持到底。”

“I do think,” he added, “that organizationally and personally we’ve learned an enormous amount about how to develop software. We’ve kind of reinvented the wheel. These are things that other people know, so it’s taken us a little longer to learn those things. But having learned them, that’s a kind of intellectual capital, and I’m absolutely firmly intent on reapplying it and staying the course.”





钱德勒从一个愿景开始——议程的灵魂在当代计划中重生，消除孤岛，并赋予用户以任何他们选择的方式切片和切块数据的能力。那愿景有一颗朴素优雅的心。但软件开发采用简单而优雅的愿景并将其原子化，将它们分成数百万个实现细节以及界面选择和妥协。从某种意义上说，制作良好软件的艺术在于能够通过雾化器发送视觉，最终可以将其重新组合在一起，就像数据包分开穿过互联网并重新组装成连贯的数据包一样。您的计算机的消息。或者就像企业号星舰的船员在传送室中溶解成粒子，然后在行星表面闪闪发光地恢复为人类形状。

Chandler started with a vision—the soul of Agenda reborn in a contemporary program, the leveling of silos, and the empowering of users to slice and dice data any way they choose. That vision had a simple elegant heart. But software development takes simple elegant visions and atomizes them, separating them into millions of implementation details and interface choices and compromises. The art of making software well is, in a sense, the ability to send a vision through that atomizer in such a way that it can eventually be put back together—like the packets of data that separate to cross the Internet and get reassembled into coherent messages for your computer. Or like a Starship Enterprise crew member dissolved into particles in the transporter room and shimmered back into human shape on a planet’s surface.

2005年底，钱德勒已经穿过那道光束，开始在人们的视野中闪烁光芒。三年前 Kapor 首次宣布 OSAF 时，大多数涌入 Chandler 邮件列表的软件爱好者和开源爱好者已经离开了，许多人将 Chandler 视为死胡同或失败的事业。钱德勒会半途而废，被咆哮的阿贾克斯球迷践踏吗？或者它会像 Mozilla 一样，在荒野多年之后，赢得大众的心和桌面？

In late 2005, Chandler had passed through that beam and was beginning to glimmer into view. Most of the software enthusiasts and open source devotees who had flocked to the Chandler mailing lists when Kapor first announced OSAF three years before had moved on, and many had written Chandler off as a dead end or a lost cause. Would Chandler fall by the wayside, trampled under by the roaring AJAX crowd? Or would it, like Mozilla, after years in the wilderness, emerge to win the hearts and desktops of a multitude?

我对钱德勒的成功抱有自私的兴趣。毕竟，有一天，在某些操作系统升级或计算环境发生其他随机变化之后，我的 ECCO 程序将停止工作。我刚刚开始尝试使用钱德勒作为我的日历；当我准备写另一本书时，如果能用钱德勒来组织我的研究，那就太棒了。但与此同时，我的钱德勒日历上有一个重要的日期迫在眉睫。

I had a selfish interest in Chandler’s success. Someday, after all, after some operating system upgrade or other random change in the computing environment, my Ecco program would stop working. I was just starting to play around with using Chandler as my calendar; by the time I was ready to write another book, it would be great to use Chandler to organize my research. In the meantime, though, my Chandler calendar had an important date looming on it.

是时候向 OSAF 和钱德勒告别了，不仅仅是因为我有一份手稿要上交。卡普尔和他的团队学到了很多关于为什么制作软件如此困难以及如何让事情变得更容易的知识。我希望我们也是如此。但我必须让钱德勒的故事本身成为未完成的、开放式的——因为，无论好坏，它都是开放式的。

It was time to bid OSAF and Chandler farewell, and not just because I had a manuscript to turn in. Kapor and his team had learned a great deal about why making software is so hard and how to make things a little easier. So, I hope, have we. But I must leave the Chandler story itself unfinished, open-ended—because, for better or worse, it is open-ended.

到本书出版时，OSAF 可能已经发布了该程序的另外两个版本。如果您是程序员，您现在可以访问该网站并下载源代码。或者您可能只想运行“最终用户安装程序”并查看项目已经进展了多少。它是否陷入了另一个软件时间循环？或者它是否实现了伟大事物的“看似合理的承诺”，激励开发者社区开始行动并使其变得更加伟大？

By the time this book is published, OSAF will have released perhaps two more versions of the program. You can go to the Web site now and, if you’re a programmer, download the source. Or maybe you’ll just want to run the “end-user installer” and see how much further the project has traveled. Has it gotten trapped in yet another loop of software time? Or has it achieved the “plausible promise” of something great, inspiring a community of developers to kick into gear and make it greater?

这里有一个数据点：当我写本章时，一个图标提醒我有一些新收到的电子邮件。我点击我的电子邮件程序，看到这是一条发布到 Chandler-dev 列表的帖子。不列颠哥伦比亚省维多利亚大学的程序员 Davor Cubranic 一直在 Chandler 邮件列表中闲逛，他提出了一个建议：“我是 Ecco PIM/outliner 的忠实粉丝，它的一个非常有用的功能UI 是允许通过单击模拟时钟下拉菜单[形状像钟面的菜单]来选择时间的方式。。。。因此，必须在 Chandler 中通过在文本控件中输入时间来输入时间，感觉就像倒退了一步，我尝试在 wxPython 中重新创建 ECCO 的时钟下拉菜单。”

Here’s one data point: While I was writing this chapter, an icon alerted me to some new incoming email. I clicked over to my email program and saw it was a posting to the Chandler-dev list. Davor Cubranic, a programmer at the University of Victoria in British Columbia who had been hanging out on the Chandler mailing lists, presented a suggestion: “I’m a big fan of Ecco PIM/outliner, and one of the very useful features in its UI is the way it allows selecting time by clicking in an analog clock dropdown [a menu shaped like a clock face] . . . . So having to enter times in Chandler by typing them in a text control felt like a step backward, and I tried to recreate Ecco’s clock dropdown in wxPython.”

Cubranic 的电子邮件不仅提出了这个想法，而且还提出了这个想法。它包含大约 180 行实现它的 Python 代码。“代码已经在 Windows 和 wxPython 2.6.1.0 上进行了测试，”他写道。

Cubranic’s email didn’t just propose the idea; it contained about 180 lines of Python code that implemented it. “The code has been tested on Windows and wxPython 2.6.1.0,” he wrote.

Ted Leung 回复道：“感谢您提供代码！我尝试在 Mac 和 Linux 上运行它。它在 Linux 上运行得很好。” 但在 Mac 上却出现了错误。

Ted Leung wrote back, “Thanks for the code! I tried running it on Mac and Linux. It works fine on Linux.” But on the Mac it caused an error.

Alec Flett 也做出了热情的回应，但表示在 0.6 周期中添加新功能为时已晚。

Alec Flett responded enthusiastically, too, but said that it was too late in the 0.6 cycle to add a new feature.

Heikki Toivonen 建议 Cubranic 将其归档为 Bugzilla 中的错误，Bugzilla 有一个特殊类别，用于真正“增强”而不是错误的事物。

Heikki Toivonen suggested that Cubranic file it as a bug in Bugzilla, which had a special category for things that were really “enhancements” more than bugs.

因此 Cubranic 将其输入为 bug 4520：“在事件详细信息视图中输入时间的另一种方法。”

So Cubranic entered it as bug 4520: “An alternate way to enter time in event detail view.”

结语                           

EPILOGUE                           

长期赌注

A LONG BET

[2005–2029 年及以后]

[2005–2029 AND BEYOND]

不知何处，有人的拳头再次敲击着桌子。为什么我们不能像建造桥梁一样构建软件？

Somewhere, someone’s fist is pounding the table again. Why can’t we build software the way we build bridges?

好吧，也许我们已经这样做了。

Well, maybe we already do.

当 OSAF 的程序员努力构建他们的代码塔、在数据存储库顶部的 Python 对象上堆积错误修复时，我目睹了海湾大桥东侧新跨度的工作进展情况。该项目诞生于 20 世纪 90 年代，最初的预算略高于 10 亿美元，该项目取代了每天有数十万辆汽车通过的 4.5 英里双层桥的一半。最初的设计要求修建一条低矮、朴素的堤道，但政治竞争和当地自豪感导致采用了更雄心勃勃、更独特的设计。新的跨度是一座“自锚式悬索桥”，将悬挂在一座塔上。一张电缆网将从那个孤独的塔尖延伸下来，从道路下方延伸到塔顶，形成一系列风景如画的巨大环路。这座桥不仅是一座美丽的桥，而且是一座概念上大胆的桥，一座自力更生的桥——一座温暖道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特(Douglas Hofstadter)心的自我参考桥。

As OSAF’s programmers labored to construct their tower of code, piling bug fixes atop Python objects atop the data repository, I watched the work proceed on the new eastern span of the Bay Bridge. The project, replacing half of the 4.5-mile, double-decker bridge that several hundred thousand vehicles cross each day, was born in the 1990s and first budgeted at a little over a billion dollars. The original design called for a low-slung, unadorned causeway, but political rivalries and local pride led to the adoption of a more ambitious and unique design. The new span, a “self-anchored suspension bridge,” would hang from a single tower. A web of cables would stretch down from that lone spire, underneath the roadway and back up to the tower top, in a picturesque array of gargantuan loops. It was going to be not only a beautiful bridge to look at but a conceptually daring bridge, a bootstrapped bridge—a self-referential bridge to warm Douglas Hofstadter’s heart.

只有一个问题：以前从未建造过类似的建筑。没有人愿意解决这个问题。当加利福尼亚州进行投标时，唯一参与投标的承包商的报价远高于预期。

There was only one problem: Nothing like it had ever been built before. And nobody was eager to tackle it. When the State of California put it out to bid, the lone contractor to throw its hat in the ring came in much higher than expected.

2004年12月，加州州长阿诺·施瓦辛格介入并暂停了该项目，宣布湾区地区将不得不承担该项目不断膨胀的更多成本，并呼吁重新审视桥梁设计。别介意半桥的施工已经很远了，每天早上你都可以看到车辆蜂拥而至，这条高架桥将载着驾车者缓慢爬升一英里多到达未来的主桥。通往新路基的临时坡道。施瓦辛格希望该项目缩减规模，采用不太新颖且更便宜的设计。州长、州立法机构、州交通机构和地方政府花了几个月的时间争吵和讨价还价。运输机构声称，每延误一天，该州就会损失 40 万美元。最后，在 2005 年 7 月，新的妥协方案重申了更新颖的单塔设计，通过提高桥梁通行费和其他措施来支付费用，并预计了桥梁的新完工日期：2012 年——洛马普列塔地震发生近四分之一世纪后旧桥面的一大块被震松了。

In December 2004, California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger stepped in and suspended the project, declaring that the Bay Area region would have to shoulder more of the ballooning cost of the project and calling for a second look at the bridge design. Never mind that work on half of the bridge, the water-hugging viaduct that would carry motorists for more than a mile on a slow climb up to the future main span, was already very far along, and every morning you could see vehicles swarming up a temporary ramp onto the new roadbed. Schwarzenegger wanted the project scaled back to a less novel and cheaper design. The governor, the state legislature, the state’s transportation agency, and local governments spent months bickering and horse-trading. The transportation agency claimed that each day of delay was costing the state $400,000. Finally, in July 2005, a new compromise reaffirmed the fancier single-tower design, to be paid for with bridge toll hikes and other measures, and projected a new finish date for the bridge: 2012—almost a quarter century after the Loma Prieta earthquake had shaken a chunk of the old bridge deck loose.

当我读到这场争议时，我不禁想起所有使用严格的程序和经过时间考验的土木工程标准的软件管理手册，作为一根棍棒，狠狠地敲打编程行业反复无常的梦想家。“软件开发需要更多的纪律，”他们会说。“没有人试图在桥梁建成一半后改变其设计！”

As I read about the controversy, I couldn’t help thinking of all the software management manuals that used the rigorous procedures and time-tested standards of civil engineering as a cudgel to whack the fickle dreamers of the programming profession over the head. “Software development needs more discipline,” they would say. “Nobody ever tried to change the design of a bridge after it was already half-built!”

加利福尼亚州在驳斥这一论点方面做得很好。

The State of California had done a fine job of undermining that argument.





为什么我们不能像建造桥梁一样构建软件？当然，这与加州建造桥梁的方式不同。提出这个问题的人梦想着建立在可靠公式基础上的严格纪律。但除非我们能够设计出一种“软件物理学”来匹配控制物理世界工程的质量、运动和能量的计算，否则我们可能无法做到这一点。尽管如此，软件开发的技术困难还是勉强让位于渐进式改进。同样的事情也发生在桥梁建设领域。如今，我们在这一领域的能力已被视为理所当然。我们已经忘记（或压抑）了从十九世纪到二十世纪初桥梁故障和倒塌的悠久历史，当时新技术和不成熟的做法创造了灾难和损失的记录，在许多方面使我们这个时代的软件灾难困境相形见绌。

Why can’t we build software the way we build bridges? Not, of course, the way California is building bridges; people who ask this question are dreaming of a rigorous discipline founded on reliable formulas. But until and unless we can devise a “physics of software” to match the calculations of mass and motion and energy that govern engineering in the physical world, we probably can’t do that. Nonetheless, the technical difficulties of software development have grudgingly yielded to incremental improvement. The same thing happened in the world of bridge building. Today, our competence in this realm is something we take for granted; we have forgotten (or repressed) the long history of bridge failures and collapses through the nineteenth century and into the early twentieth, when new technologies and immature practices created a record of disaster and loss that in many ways dwarfs our era’s software disaster woes.

随着技术流程的改进，我们错误地认为我们已经解决了问题。但围绕技术流程的人工流程仍然令人沮丧且棘手。如果像弗雷德里克·布鲁克斯（Frederick Brooks）所说的那样，“构建软件的难点在于决定说什么，而不是说出来”，那么你在桥梁构建上的编程模型有多接近都无关紧要。在“决定说什么”方面，桥梁的建造者并不比软件的建造者好多少。他们也是人。

As the technical process improves, we mistakenly conclude that we have solved our problems. But the human process surrounding the technical process remains frustrating and intractable. If, as Frederick Brooks said, “the hard thing about building software is deciding what to say, not saying it,” then it doesn’t matter how closely you model programming on bridge building. The builders of bridges are little better than the builders of software at “deciding what to say.” They are people, too.
